headline: An Unusual Feat in Congress: Student Loan Bill Breezes On
text: WASHINGTON — Something pretty rare happened in Congress on Wednesday: it approved and sent to President Obama a major piece of public policy by an overwhelming bipartisan margin.

headline: Head of Syrian Opposition Rejects Talks With Assad
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The head of Syria’s main exile opposition group added new conditions on Wednesday to the start of any negotiations aimed at ending the country’s civil war, further decreasing prospects that an internationally backed peace plan would progress anytime soon.

headline: Under Scrutiny, Goldman Offers to Speed Metal Delivery
text: Goldman Sachs has offered to speed up delivery of aluminum stored in warehouses that it controls as federal authorities examine how delays at the facilities have driven up the price of the metal.

headline: New Rule at N.F.L.’s Camps: No Tackling. It’s Just Practice.
text: Pro football summer training camps were once filled with two practices a day, grueling sessions that featured helmeted players clashing gladiator-style under a merciless sun.

headline: New Tools for Keeping the Lights On
text: RENSSELAER, N.Y. — After the lights went out for 50 million people from the Northeast to the Midwest on Aug. 14, 2003, investigators found readings from two obscure instruments that would have given them an hour’s warning — plenty of time to solve the problem if the devices had been wired to provide a stream of critical data.

headline: Shirtless Goes the City
text: California strikes. Manhattan is becoming Malibu. Once, in the long-gone “Mad Men” days, it was considered de rigueur for New Yorkers to wear a hat and gloves in town. Now dress codes have devolved to the point where folks wear fleecy slippers on the subway, flip-flops to the ballet, running tights for every occasion, repurposed pajamas as daywear and, recently, very little at all.

headline: Browsing
text: The Middle Ground

headline: Judge Rejects Fed’s Cap on Debit Card Fees
text: The billions of dollars that banks earn when consumers swipe their debit cards are under threat after a federal court ruling on Wednesday. The question is whether consumers will see any savings.

headline: Despite West’s Efforts, Afghan Youths Cling to Traditional Ways
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Walk through the streets of Kabul and evidence of the West’s decade-long war literally clings to the Afghan youth: the American labels emblazoned on their shirts and jeans, the stylish sunglasses they wear, the cellphones they clutch to update their lives on Twitter and Facebook.

headline: Mistrial in Mississippi Case Over Mayoral Election
text: Two months ago, the voters of Hattiesburg, Miss., tried to pick a mayor, but the outcome became the subject of a court battle that resulted in a mistrial on Tuesday.

headline: Embracing the West, Except Its Ideals
text: Despite being exposed to Western culture for the last decade, a new generation of Afghans is clinging to their society’s conservative ways.

headline: Hernandez’s Troubles Rose Under N.F.L.’s Vigilant Eye
text: In the N.F.L., security is serious business. The league and its 32 teams spend millions of dollars and countless hours on protecting and monitoring their buildings and players. The league’s director of security is a former head of the Pennsylvania State Police, and many on his staff are former law enforcement agents with extensive ties to local, state and federal authorities.

headline: Seen in New York, Shirtless Men
text: The recent heat wave has some New Yorkers wondering if longstanding rules of decorum are gone forever.

headline: Many Bars Misled Drinkers, New Jersey Says
text: A patron ordering a drink made with a high-quality spirit, like Bombay Sapphire gin, should presumably not have to wonder what winds up swishing around the martini glass.

headline: Eagles Receiver Cooper Apologizes for Using Racial Slur at Concert
text: PHILADELPHIA — Philadelphia Eagles wide receiver Riley Cooper apologized Wednesday after a video surfaced in which he used a racial slur at a country music concert.

headline: A Market Where the Beach Crowd Is Right at Home
text: Pioneer Market in Fair Harbor on Fire Island has been serving the in-season population since 1968.

headline: Banks Find S.&P. More Favorable in Bond Ratings
text: The Wall Street ratings game is back.

headline: The Hail-Mary-Moon
text: It’s a steamy summer day in the middle of vacation season, and the beach, whether on Martha’s Vineyard, Cape Cod or Sanibel Island, is packed. Couples — some a few years past their honeymoon but still sporting its glow, others creased from decades of togetherness — frolic in the sand, splash in the surf, slather each other with suntan lotion and toast with freshly mixed margaritas.

headline: No Shirt, No Shoes, No Problem
text: Pioneer Market is almost the first thing you see when you step off the ferry in Fair Harbor, a modest hamlet on Fire Island, off the South Shore of Long Island, known for family friendly charm. Just off the pier and past the wine shop, the grocery’s door is always open, letting in the sea breezes and summer air.

headline: Condemned to Die Because He’s Black
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — NEARLY 50 years after the end of Jim Crow, African-Americans are still facing execution because of their race.

headline: What Is ‘Seinfeld’ Worth?
text: WASHINGTON — THE tinkering of federal government accountants is rarely newsmaking stuff. But after a few tweaks to the way the Bureau of Economic Analysis calculates the gross domestic product, those accountants have pulled off something seemingly remarkable: in the blink of an eye this week, they made the size of the American economy grow by $560 billion.

headline: A Truce in Hand-to-Hair Combat
text: Paul Labrecque, the chain of salons in New York, sells many fancy-schmancy grooming products, including cosmetics from Clé de Peau Beauté and creams from La Mer, but so far this year, the best-selling item is a somewhat homely looking plastic item called the Tangle Teezer, which retails for $16.

headline: Film Academy’s New Leader Starts by Sizing Up Oscars
text: LOS ANGELES — A day after she was elected president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, Cheryl Boone Isaacs said her first order of business was to check in on the organization’s most valuable asset: the Oscars.

headline: Republicans: Blinded by Self-Righteousness
text: Two-thirds of Republicans recognize that the party needs to change in order to do better in future presidential elections, but they’re torn over what that change should be.

headline: Politics of a Screeching Halt
text: One of the least attractive legacies of Barack Obama will be the way he empowered freshman senators to believe they were only one or two good speeches away from the presidency.

headline: Grand Slam ... Maybe: Park Seeks Win at British Open
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — Grand slams are generally seen as quartets: a four-run homer in baseball; four major victories in the same calendar year in tennis and golf; four items from a list of choices in a Denny’s Grand Slam breakfast.

headline: Women as a Force for Change
text: As “women’s empowerment” has become a buzz phrase in the last few years, some people are pushing back. They resent this as the latest fad in political correctness, a liberal mission to troll for support from woolly-minded female voters.

headline: Raskin Would Be First Female Deputy at Treasury
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama nominated Sarah Bloom Raskin on Wednesday to be deputy Treasury secretary. If confirmed by the Senate, Ms. Raskin would be the highest-ranking woman to serve in that department.

headline: On Anniversary of ’63 March, Congress Finds Notes of Present Struggles
text: Nearly 50 years after John Lewis stood among the “Big Six” civil rights leaders before throngs of mostly African-American demonstrators, gathered on the National Mall for the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, he stood in the Capitol on Wednesday and declared the work of the movement unfinished.

headline: Mourning Victims and Assigning Blame After Fatal Boat Crash on the Hudson
text: PIERMONT, N.Y. — It was a gorgeous midsummer night on the banks of the Hudson, the first Friday since the recent heat wave broke, and business at Pier 701, this riverfront village’s newest restaurant, was brisk. Diners and revelers chatted happily on the new sprawling wooden deck, and across the darkened river the lights of Tarrytown twinkled.

headline: Road Through Roman History Creates Colossal Headache
text: ROME — Via dei Fori Imperiali, a multilane artery running through the heart of Rome, is typically a frenzy of swerving Vespas, zipping Smart cars and honking Fiat taxis.

headline: Lawmakers in Uruguay Vote to Legalize Marijuana
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Uruguay’s lower house late Wednesday night approved a sweeping bill to legalize marijuana, opening the way for the authorities to create one of Latin America’s most ambitious nationwide endeavors in overhauling drug policy.

headline: Openings, Sales and Events from the Week of August 1
text: Openings

headline: Adventures With Post Offices
text: Four Septembers ago, my husband and I were bundled up in a yurt in the Gobi Desert at the end of a trip around the world. Our journey had included 21 countries, both one- and two-humped camels, swims in the Nile and the Euphrates, and an escape from a herd of wild elephants. It had also included at least a dozen visits to the post offices of the world.

headline: 47 Rejections, Then the Booker Long List
text: Donal Ryan, a civil servant from Limerick, Ireland, wrote two novels. He sent them to agents and publishers and got back 47 rejections over three years. Finally an intern at Lilliput Press in Dublin fished “The Thing About December” out of the slush pile. Around the same time, an editor at Doubleday Ireland took interest in “The Spinning Heart.” Suddenly Mr. Ryan had a two-book deal, and from there his fortunes only improved. The Booker Foundation announced last week that “The Spinning Heart” had made the cut for the Man Booker Prize long list.

headline: Stunning Images of Destroyed Syrian City
text: In 1982, after President Hafez al-Assad’s forces leveled whole sections of Syria’s fourth-largest city, Hama, to suppress a revolt, the first foreign journalists allowed to view the rubble were shocked by the scale of the destruction.

headline: Comcast and CBS Post Strong Results, Aided by Web
text: Judging by the second-quarter earnings reported by two major media companies on Wednesday, the good times are still rolling in the television business.

headline: The Next Civil Rights Frontier
text: Federal civil rights officials reached an important settlement late last month with a California school district accused of discriminating against a transgender student by denying him equal access to educational programs and activities. Under the agreement, the Arcadia Unified School District in California will revise its policies and ensure that the student, who was born female but has since assumed a male name and identity, is treated fairly and like other male students. The agreement should be required reading for school officials at all levels nationally.

headline: Sending Message to Iran, House Approves Tougher Sanctions
text: The House overwhelmingly approved legislation on Wednesday that would impose the toughest sanctions yet on Iran, calling the measure a critical step to cripple the country’s disputed nuclear program and brushing aside calls for restraint by critics who said the Iranian president-elect should first be given a chance to negotiate.

headline: At Trading Deadline, Filling a Void Not Yet There
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Chicago White Sox, enduring their worst season in decades, were eager to trade starter Jake Peavy before the trading deadline this week. The Boston Red Sox, hoping for their first playoff appearance in four years, were eager to acquire him.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, August 1, 2013
text: “They’ll get plenty of hitting in the games. But we’ve got to get our guys to the games.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Safety of Imported Foods
text: The Food and Drug Administration proposed new rules last week that should go a long way toward ensuring the safety of imported foods. The need for stronger regulation is clear. Food imports have been soaring, inspections by the F.D.A. have been lagging, and imported foods have been blamed for a number of outbreaks of illness.

headline: More Fog From the Spy Agencies
text: The Obama administration released narrowly selected and heavily censored documents and sent more officials to testify before Congress on Wednesday in an effort to defend the legality and value of the surveillance of all Americans’ telephone calls. The effort was a failure.

headline: A Day’s Strike Seeks to Raise Fast-Food Pay
text: From New York to several Midwestern cities, thousands of fast-food workers have been holding one-day strikes during peak mealtimes, quickly drawing national attention to their demands for much higher wages.

headline: Beyond Bradley Manning
text: Will the outcome of the Manning trial have ramifications in other cases? How significant is this week's verdict?

headline: World Stage Awaits a Student Repertory Company From the Bronx
text: The Hostos Repertory Company does not have a manager and uses a classroom as a rehearsal space. Many of its 11 members have never spent much time out of the Bronx. Two have never been on a plane.

headline: Change of Scenery for Kennedy and Norris May Not Immediately Pay Off
text: After Jake Peavy, the veteran starting pitcher who was acquired by the Boston Red Sox before the nonwaiver trade deadline Wednesday, the two pitchers moved who gained the most attention were Bud Norris and Ian Kennedy. Unfortunately for the Baltimore Orioles and the San Diego Padres, the teams that acquired them, the chances that either player makes much of an impact this season are slim.

headline: Corrections: August 1, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: One Young Life and Several Traumas, With Songs Added
text: Press material for “Shida,” an earnest one-woman musical written and performed by Jeannette Bayardelle, says that it is based on a true story. But the piece, in which Ms. Bayardelle enacts one young woman’s difficult journey to the brink of adulthood, is more determined to showcase Ms. Bayardelle’s vocal and acting talents than to give us a real sense of the title character.

headline: Terse Invitation
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Let’s just get this one out of the way:

headline: Playing the Stadium Name Game
text: Explore the history of stadium naming rights deals in Major League Baseball, the N.B.A. and the N.F.L.

headline: Race Plays a Role in School Transfers in St. Louis
text: In June, the Missouri Supreme Court upheld a law allowing students from failing school districts to transfer to better ones.

headline: In Missouri, Race Complicates a Transfer to Better Schools
text: ST. CHARLES, Mo. — When the Missouri Supreme Court upheld a law in June allowing students from failing school districts to transfer to good ones, Harriett Gladney saw a path to a better education for her 9-year-old daughter.

headline: Possibilities Are Swirling as Rodriguez Confronts a Race Against Time
text: Alex Rodriguez’s effort to return to the Yankees’ lineup before Major League Baseball issues its expected suspension of him is moving into a decisive phase, with the possibility that the games he is set to play in minor league settings over the next few days could be his last ones for a long time.

headline: Yankees Are Quiet at Deadline but Hope to Make Noise Soon
text: LOS ANGELES — An impressive collection of talent turned out to watch the Yankees face Los Angeles at Dodger Stadium on Tuesday night: Chris Paul, Kevin Durant, Russell Westbrook and James Harden — a veritable dream team. And for the finale of the brief series Wednesday, Cristiano Ronaldo and Kobe Bryant were expected to attend.

headline: Judge Dismisses Suit to End Deportation Deferrals
text: A federal district judge in Dallas, in a surprise turnaround from an earlier opinion, on Wednesday dismissed a lawsuit by immigration enforcement agents seeking to halt an Obama administration program that gives reprieves from deportation to young undocumented immigrants.

headline: Mets Stand Pat, Play Hard and Fall to the Marlins
text: MIAMI — In the absence of any transactions, baseball’s nonwaiver trade deadline Wednesday afternoon became little more than a chance for the Mets to consider their present state and to reiterate their organizational mind-set.

headline: In Sentencing, U.S. Tries to Prove Harm by Manning
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — As the sentencing phase began Wednesday in the court-martial of Pfc. Bradley Manning, the government tried to demonstrate how his disclosure of hundreds of thousands of military and diplomatic documents to WikiLeaks had sown mistrust and damaged the United States.

headline: Dog of War Makes Ultimate Sacrifice for Sailor
text: The silence was what surprised him most. As the earth erupted in a puff of smoke just three feet away, Master-at-Arms First Class Leroy Williams Jr. found himself flying backward in an angry cloud of dirt and debris.

headline: China Reports Increase in Manufacturing
text: HONG KONG — A manufacturing index published by the Chinese authorities on Thursday provided an unexpectedly solid reading for July but did little to dispel the picture of an economy that is cooling more rapidly than many analysts had expected just months ago.

headline: A Modest Decline of Homicides in Mexico
text: Violence caused by the drug war in Mexico may be abating, according to figures released this week by the government. The data showed a modest decline in homicides in 2012, the first in six years. Mexico’s census agency, compiling reports of murders from the 32 federal entities, said there were 26,037 homicides last year, a 4.3 percent decline from 27,213 in 2011, which was the most in recent years. The homicide rate was 22 per 100,000 residents, a decline from 24 per 100,000 the previous year. The homicide rate in the United States is 4.7 per 100,000 people, according to United Nations figures, but Mexico’s rate was far lower than several other countries in the hemisphere. A number of analysts believe this data provides a good barometer of overall violence, which had surged because of infighting among criminal gangs and the government’s efforts to suppress them. In 2007, there were 8,867 homicides, the lowest number in the last six years.

headline: Primary Is Getting Closer? Cue the Negative Phase
text: With just six weeks to go before the primary, the slow burning races for New York City mayor and comptroller have suddenly turned hot.

headline: Interfaith Medical Center Plans to Close
text: Giving up the fight to stay open, Interfaith Medical Center, one of Brooklyn’s most financially troubled hospitals, asked a bankruptcy court on Tuesday to approve its closing and sent layoff warning notices to its 1,544 employees.

headline: Chilly Reception for Weiner in Rockaways
text: For much of his career in politics, Anthony D. Weiner was revered in the far-flung community of the Rockaways, Queens. He was credited with helping lead the fight to protect beaches and applauded for his efforts to assist families affected by storm damage.

headline: At Street Fair, Science Replaces Sausage
text: From a distance, it could have been just another New York City street fair. But instead of the usual socks, scarves and sausages, the booths in a park on 14th Street in Manhattan flaunted wares of a far more technological nature.

headline: In Senate, Arm-Twisting and Vote-Changing Lead to a Confirmation
text: WASHINGTON — With the help of a last-minute switch from a “no” to a “yes,” Senate Democrats on Wednesday narrowly overcame a Republican filibuster of President Obama’s nominee to lead the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives — a close call that could have unraveled a delicate truce between the two parties.

headline: León Ferrari, Provocative Argentine Conceptual Artist, Dies at 92
text: León Ferrari, an iconoclastic Argentine conceptual artist who marshaled ceramics, sculpture and poems as “revolutionary weapons” against war, government and religion, died last Thursday in Buenos Aires. He was 92.

headline: Peter M. Flanigan, Banker and Nixon Aide, Dies at 90
text: Peter M. Flanigan, a Wall Street investment banker who became one of President Richard M. Nixon’s most trusted, influential and well-connected aides on business and economic matters, died on Monday in Salzburg, Austria. He was 90.

headline: Mick Farren, British Rock ’n’ Roll Renaissance Man, Dies at 69
text: Mick Farren, a Renaissance man of the 1960s British rock ’n’ roll underground — singer and songwriter, rock critic and historian and the author of science fiction novels — died on Saturday in London. He was 69.

headline: $4 Million in Compensation Set for Man Left in D.E.A. Cell
text: LOS ANGELES — A year after Daniel Chong, a San Diego college student, was found hallucinating and suffering from kidney failure inside a Drug Enforcement Administration holding cell where he had been accidentally left for four days, the agency has agreed to compensate him for his ordeal.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,241 American service members who have died since the start of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday and Wednesday:

headline: Bernadette Lafont, 74, Actress and Muse
text: Bernadette Lafont, a French actress whose sensuality and ebullience made her a muse of the iconoclastic New Wave that overtook France’s film industry in the late 1950s and early ’60s, died on July 25 in Nîmes, France. She was 74.

headline: Abortion Law Is Blocked in North Dakota
text: A state judge on Wednesday temporarily blocked enforcement of a law requiring doctors who perform abortions to have admitting privileges at nearby hospitals. The law is similar to measures promoted by anti-abortion groups and blocked by courts in other states, including Mississippi and Alabama. It would have forced North Dakota’s only abortion center, the Red River Clinic in Fargo, to close because it uses out-of-state doctors who have been refused admitting privileges at local hospitals. Medical experts say such requirements do not improve patient safety since hospitals will accept and treat emergency patients regardless. The North Dakota lawsuit that resulted in Wednesday’s temporary injunction was brought on behalf of the clinic by the Center for Reproductive Rights, based in New York.

headline: Sadly, Too Big to Fail Is Not Over
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: The Ticktock of the Death Clock
text: With every new silver hair sprouting from my scalp, I can’t help but think of the shortening arc ahead of me. Now in my mid-50s, for the first time I’m no longer looking up, over and beyond. Rather, my trajectory points downward at the approaching horizon. In this frame of mind, I recently found myself at DeathClock.com, the “Internet’s friendly” — if not scientific — “reminder that life is slipping away … second by second.” After I completed the short questionnaire, the Death Clock’s algorithm quickly did the math, concluding: “Your personal day of death is Wednesday, April 23, 2031.”

headline: Word of the Day | bard
text: bard •\ˈbärd\• noun

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 10 P.M. (History) HATFIELDS & McCOYS: WHITE LIGHTNING About 150 years after their ancestors’ infamous feud turned the border region of Kentucky and West Virginia into a war zone, members of these clans try to put their bad blood aside to make and market moonshine under the Hatfield & McCoy label. One thing they agree on is that their St. Louis investor seems, as Mark Hatfield (above) put it, “as trustworthy as a fox in a henhouse.” In the premiere of this new reality show, he and Jim McCoy, the families’ patriarchs, tangle over whose brew is stronger and decide to settle the score by using them to fuel classic cars in a race.

headline: News Quiz | August 1, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Overbay Steps In for Yankees and Breaks Up Pitchers’ Duel
text: LOS ANGELES — Clayton Kershaw showered and dressed before returning to his locker to speak with reporters late Wednesday night, but the wet hair that he arrived with did little to cool him down.

headline: A Rare Sight in Pittsburgh as the Pirates Enter August in First Place
text: PITTSBURGH — In the sixth inning of the nightcap of Tuesday’s doubleheader, a black bat circled above the seats just behind the Pirates’ third-base on-deck circle and ultimately settled high on the fans’ side of the screen. There it remained for the duration, utterly immobile and impervious to those who soon rocked the sold-out stadium in celebrating the Pirates’ twin-bill sweep of the St. Louis Cardinals that reclaimed the National League Central division lead from the visitors.

headline: ArcelorMittal Reports 2nd Quarter Net Loss of $780 Million
text: LONDON — ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steel company, reported on Thursday a net loss of $780 million for the second quarter, compared with net income of about $1 billion in the same period a year earlier. The company also reported $1.7 billion in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, the commonly used metric in the steel industry, a figure that was in line with analysts’ consensus forecasts.

headline: How Not to Talk About Poverty in India
text: Growing up, I remember seeing young couples munching peanuts, idly walking past the banks of Dhakuria Lake, across the expanse of the open fields, in the heart of Kolkata, as dusk settled in. “Poor man’s romance” ran the wry joke drawing attention to the city’s severe economic plight and the benighted Calcuttan couple’s dwindling purchasing power. Predictably, the city’s peanut-munching, hand-holding subaltern lovers featured in many Bengali films, with Bengals’ joblessness and ubiquitous impoverishment at the heart of the narratives.

headline: Earnings at Shell and Exxon Fall Sharply in 2nd Quarter
text: Royal Dutch Shell, continuing to struggle with its operations in Nigeria and North America, on Thursday announced earnings that fell below analysts’ forecasts, and Exxon Mobil, the largest American oil producer, posted a 57 percent year-over-year earnings decline.

headline: Signs of Rebound as Sony Posts a $35 Million Profit
text: TOKYO — Sony said on Thursday that it was weighing “carefully” a shareholder’s proposal to spin off part of its entertainment arm, but executives said signs of a turnaround in the company’s long-suffering electronics business showed that their strategy was on track.

headline: Lloyds Banking Group Returns to Profit
text: Updated, 5:57 a.m. | LONDON – The Lloyds Banking Group said on Thursday that second-quarter profit more than doubled, as the partly nationalized British bank took another step toward privatization.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 1, 2013
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the Op-Doc “‘Occupy Bakery’.”

headline: Investment Banking Spurs Profit Surge at Société Générale
text: The French bank Société Générale reported better-than-expected second-quarter earnings on Thursday, buoyed by a strong performance in its investment and corporate banking division.

headline: Stop Blaming ‘Jaws’!
text: Imagine “Jaws,” if it were released in 2014.

headline: Decision Casts Doubt on Brain Scans for Alzheimer’s
text: For all the hue and cry about detecting the earliest signs of Alzheimer’s disease, the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services has concluded that amyloid brain scans for the purpose of diagnosing Alzheimer’s disease are not ready for prime time.

headline: A Sea Change for the America’s Cup
text: There is a moment when the yachts racing in this year’s America’s Cup go from being mere boats to something more like flying machines. It happens at around 17 knots, or 20 miles per hour, when both hulls of the carbon-fiber catamarans rise out of the water and the entire craft skims over the surface on a thin hydrofoil beneath the downwind pontoon. Free of the water’s drag, the vessels accelerate to speeds as great as 50 miles per hour.

headline: Bill Brandt’s Negative Beginnings
text: Young people sometimes look at the world with brash certainty, seeing only absolutes — stark blacks and bright whites. But time and experience teach us that life exists mostly in nuanced gray, and that ambiguity often provides insight.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Stacking Up the Bitcoins
text: In “Virtual Currency Gains Ground in Actual World,” Kate Murphy writes about a form of digital cash.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Not Just the Flu
text: The Challenge: Can you solve a medical mystery involving a 59-year-old woman who becomes deathly ill two weeks into what she calls the flu?

headline: New York Today: Before Weiner and Spitzer
text: In New York City, this is the year of the disgraced politician seeking a second act.

headline: Afghans Yield in Dispute With U.S. Over Stiff Fines for Cargo Shipments
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Faced with the possible loss of hundreds of millions of dollars in American aid, Afghanistan abruptly backed off a threat to impose steep fines on the NATO-led coalition over missing paperwork for cargo shipments, Afghan and coalition officials said on Thursday.

headline: At Bayreuth, Boos and Dropped Jaws
text: BAYREUTH, Germany — It has become almost an expected part of the Bayreuth Festival tradition that the audience boos when the director of a radical new production takes a curtain call. But there is booing, and then there is the kind of demonstration that happened here on Wednesday night at the end of “Götterdämmerung.” The occasion was the fourth, and final, installment of the festival’s new production of Wagner’s “Ring,” the most anticipated event of the international celebrations for Wagner’s bicentennial.

headline: Help! I’m Not a Numbers Person! (Part 2)
text: In yesterday’s post, I introduced Michelle VanAllsburg, who owns a salon, The Hair Co., in Grand Rapids, Mich. In debt and under stress, Ms. VanAllsburg contacted me, hoping I might be able to help her figure out how she could sell her salon. But then we ran the numbers, and much to her surprise, it looked as if she was actually making a profit. “But I don’t have any money!” she responded.

headline: Britain’s Benchmark Rate Stays Unchanged on Signs of Improvement
text: LONDON — The Bank of England kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged on Thursday amid tentative signs that Britain’s economic recovery is strengthening.

headline: South Korean Court Rules Inheritance Crosses Border
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The Supreme Court of South Korea has ruled for the first time that North Korean children of a South Korean citizen have the right to inherit their deceased parent’s property, court officials said Thursday.

headline: Economists Behaving Badly, Redux
text: Brad DeLong asks why the left views Larry Summers as a right-wing hyena. I think that’s a straw man, or maybe a straw hyena. What is true is that a lot of people even on the moderate left don’t trust Summers, even though much of his commentary over the years has been very much center-left — and since leaving office he has become one of our most prominent fiscal doves.

headline: Challenger to Zimbabwe’s President Says Election Was a ‘Huge Farce’
text: HARARE, Zimbabwe — Morgan Tsvangirai, the challenger to Zimbabwe’s longtime president, Robert Mugabe, asserted Thursday that the country’s presidential election had been a “huge farce” and called upon international observers to investigate what he described as widespread irregularities.

headline: When a Battlefield Becomes a Stage
text: TOWTON, England — Even on a blistering summer day in this tiny village near York, George Goodwin, a British historian and writer, sees the snow and fog of a Palm Sunday more than 500 years ago. It was then that 28,000 men lost their lives in the Battle of Towton, the most ferocious battle for the crown between the Houses of York and Lancaster during the Wars of the Roses.

headline: 36 Hours in Portsmouth, N.H.
text: Settled in 1623, Portsmouth lays claim to the title of third-oldest city in the nation, but at 21,000 inhabitants, it’s no metropolis. And that’s just fine. With a rich fishing, shipping and brewing past, and a still active working port, Portsmouth and its pleasures are smaller scale. They’re also best approached on foot. Visitors will find no end of brick sidewalks to stroll, boutiques to pop into, and Colonial, Federal and Georgian houses to tour. Then there’s the food: Portsmouth is blessed with an absurd selection of restaurants, cafes and ice cream parlors to ponder. After a long day’s shopping, gallery hop or boat ride, visitors seem to end up at a new favorite waterfront watering hole. Once installed at the bar or patio, raise a mug of frosty ale to this surprising little city of contrasts: touristy and local, cultured and blue collar, historically preserved and scrappy.

headline: Dell Takeover Bid in Peril
text: Michael S. Dell’s effort to buy the company he founded has been thrown into jeopardy after a special committee of the computer maker’s board refused his demand to change the voting rules on the buyout offer, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. With Dell shareholders set to decide on the deal on Friday, it appears that the offer of $13.65 a share, or a total of $24.4 billion, to take the company private is likely to lose the shareholder vote, people close to both sides say.

headline: Central Bank Signals Slight Optimism for Europe, but Interest Rates Stay Low
text: FRANKFURT — The euro zone has stabilized markedly in the last year, Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, said on Thursday, as he offered a slightly more upbeat assessment of the prospects for growth.

headline: Kerry, in Pakistan, Expresses Optimism on Ending Drone Strikes Soon
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Secretary of State John Kerry said Thursday that the United States had made significant headway in its drone campaign and that he hoped the strikes in Pakistan could end shortly.

headline: Confessions of an Application Reader
text: A HIGHLY qualified student, with a 3.95 unweighted grade point average and 2300 on the SAT, was not among the top-ranked engineering applicants to the University of California, Berkeley. He had perfect 800s on his subject tests in math and chemistry, a score of 5 on five Advanced Placement exams, musical talent and, in one of two personal statements, had written a loving tribute to his parents, who had emigrated from India.

headline: Like the Movie, Only Different
text: LOS ANGELES — To understand why Hollywood is moving aggressively into making musicals for Broadway, just look out the eighth-floor office window of Jimmy Horowitz, the president of Universal Pictures.

headline: A Lonely Bar in a Heat Wave
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Greece May Face Gap of 11 Billion Euros, I.M.F. Says
text: The International Monetary Fund warned in a report that a persistent recession and the government’s failure to accelerate overhauls may create an 11 billion-euro hole in Greece’s finances over the next two years.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook Shares Briefly Surpass I.P.O. Price
text: On Wednesday morning, Facebook’s stock crossed an important psychological barrier, trading for the first time above $38 a share, the price at which the company, the world’s leading social network, first sold shares to the public in May 2012, Vindu Goel reports.

headline: Italian Court Upholds Berlusconi Sentence, Setting Stage for Crisis
text: ROME — For years, former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi deftly navigated the labyrinth of Italian justice, always finding an exit — until Thursday, when Italy’s highest court handed him his first definitive sentence, upholding a prison term for tax fraud and sending Italy’s fragile government on the road to crisis.

headline: Defiant Russia Grants Snowden Year’s Asylum
text: MOSCOW — Brushing aside pleas and warnings from President Obama and other senior Americans, Russia granted Edward J. Snowden temporary asylum and allowed him to walk free out of a Moscow airport transit zone on Thursday despite the risk of a breach in relations with the United States.

headline: R.B.S. Is Said to Be Set to Name C.E.O.
text: LONDON – Royal Bank of Scotland is preparing to promote Ross McEwan to chief executive, a person with direct knowledge of the decision said on Thursday.

headline: New York Times Company Posts a 2nd-Quarter Profit
text: The New York Times Company swung to a profit in the second quarter on stronger circulation revenue and lower operating costs, but continued weakness in advertising weighed on results.

headline: Kerry Says Egypt’s Military Was ‘Restoring Democracy’ in Ousting Morsi
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Secretary of State John Kerry offered an unexpected lift to Egypt’s military leaders on Thursday, saying they had been “restoring democracy” when they deposed the country’s first freely elected president, Mohamed Morsi, on July 3 after mass demonstrations against his rule.

headline: Robert Glasper Releasing Sequel to Grammy-Winning ‘Black Radio’
text: The dark-horse winner for best R&B album at this year’s Grammy Awards was “Black Radio,” a genre-blending, guest-laden effort by the Robert Glasper Experiment. Now Blue Note Records says that a sequel, “Black Radio 2,” will be released on Oct. 29, with a new batch of songs and a new slew of special guests.

headline: Google’s Science Fellows Challenge the Company’s Fund-Raising for Senator Inhofe
text: Ten years ago this week, Senator James M. Inhofe, the Republican from Oklahoma, used a two-hour floor speech to launch his campaign on the credibility of climate science pointing to dangers from the unabated release of greenhouse gases. There was a a touch of lawyerly nuance in that speech – with Inhofe specifying he was asserting that “catastrophic” man-made global warming was a hoax.

headline: Perfectly Reasonable Question No. 3: On Web Links and Vulgarity
text: A reader, Susie Reiss, wonders about the practice of inserting links in the online version of articles, finding it inconsistent at times, and mentioned a case in which references to some schools in an article included links while others did not.

headline: More on Consumer Spending and Growth
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Student Crossword | The Renaissance
text: Learn more about The Renaissance by playing our crossword. You can find the answers here.

headline: A Fallen Wall Street Programmer Tells His Side
text: Sergey Aleynikov, a former Goldman Sachs computer programmer, has had a complicated journey since being convicted of stealing computer code from the bank. The latest chapter came on Thursday in the form of a profile in Vanity Fair.

headline: Ad Watch: Comptroller and Mayoral Races
text: Michael M. Grynbaum, a New York Times Metro reporter, discusses the latest political ads for New York City’s comptroller and mayoral races.

headline: History in the Making, and in the Dark
text: In case you missed it, and we know you have, an athlete stands on the brink of history. There is a reason everybody talks about the Grand Slams in golf, but never about the Grand Slam, winning all four of them in one year. That’s because no one has ever done it since golf gave up persimmon shafts and amateurism. Few even wander into the neighborhood. And yet, here we have Inbee Park, three major tournament victories in hand this year and favored to win a fourth (she shot a 69 in the first round of the women’s British Open on Thursday), and almost no one knows this is happening.

headline: James McBride: By the Book
text: The author of “The Color of Water” and “The Good Lord Bird” says his favorite novelist is Toni Morrison. “She plays off the horn, like Coltrane did. She busts through the form.”

headline: Spain’s Premier Says He Erred, but Rejects Calls to Step Down
text: MADRID — Spain’s embattled prime minister, Mariano Rajoy, made a rare appearance before lawmakers on Thursday morning, fending off demands for his resignation over systemic corruption in his governing party and declaring he erred by trusting an accountant now jailed over the hiding of millions of euros in a Swiss bank account.

headline: Kidnapper in Cleveland Is Sentenced by Judge and Condemned by Victim
text: CLEVELAND — Three months after her rescue from a quiet house where she had been held captive for a decade along with two other women, Michelle Knight, 31, confronted her abductor, Ariel Castro, 53, in a courtroom here on Thursday, offering an emotional last act to a traumatizing story.

headline: Life in India’s Juvenile Homes
text: On Magazine Road, near the Delhi University campus, a seedy, expansive complex with high, pale yellow walls, which served as a warehouse for arms and ammunition during the British rule, houses three of the six correctional facilities for juvenile offenders run by the Delhi government. Its most notorious inmate is the youngest defendant on trial for the gang rape and murder of a 23-year-old woman in Delhi.

headline: A New York Pier With Shops in a Box
text: In April, New York City approved a developer’s plan to turn the crumbling Pier 57 at 15th Street and the Hudson River into a 425,000-square-foot food, retail and cultural center, complete with a permanent rooftop outpost for the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Triple Play: Make Your Picks for Week 19
text: The Bats blog again tests our readers’ predictive skills with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, tea leaves, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

headline: First Date Ends in a Deadly Fall From a 17th-Story Balcony
text: It was the kind of temperate summer night that draws apartment-dwellers outside to sidewalk restaurants or rooftop bars or balconies high above the street.

headline: Japan’s Finance Minister Retracts Statement on Nazis
text: TOKYO — Japan’s finance minister on Thursday publicly retracted comments he made this week that appeared to call on Japan’s current conservative government to emulate Hitler’s takeover of prewar Germany. The gaffe underscored the potential for disputes over Japan’s own wartime history to derail its popular prime minister, Shinzo Abe.

headline: Millennials, in Their Parents’ Basements
text: Last year, a record 36 percent of people 18 to 31 years old — roughly the age range of the generation nicknamed the millennials — were living in their parents’ homes, according to a new Pew Research Center analysis of Census Bureau data. That compares to 32 percent of their same-aged counterparts in 2007, the year the recession began.

headline: Sour on Syrian Refugees
text: BEIRUT — The few Lebanese children who beg regularly around Hamra, a lively neighborhood full of universities, shops and bars, have been pretending recently that they come from Syria. “We’re refugees,” they tell those they approach for money, mainly foreigners like me, hoping to evoke some special sympathy.

headline: Who Will Stand Up for the Responsibility to Protect?
text: Last month, during her confirmation hearing to be our next Ambassador to the United Nations, Samantha Power was asked about a concept most Americans have never heard of, let alone understand—the Responsibility to Protect. Her cautious response spoke volumes about the ambivalence in the United States government towards a new idea that has gained traction as a tool for addressing conscience-shocking atrocities.

headline: Market Report | Black and White and Gray All Over
text: The fall collections now hitting stores include a wealth of seasonal staples with black, white and gray stripes or color blocking that project an air of discreet chic. The elegant arch of a stiletto from Dior and the modern curves on a ring from Cartier add some softness to these graphic swatches, while the shape of a J.W. Anderson sweater and crisp tailoring on a pair of Aquilano-Rimondi pants provide welcome structure.

headline: Lloyds Poses Front-Running Risk for Barclays
text: Who’s going to win, Antonio or Antony?

headline: Kitchen Faucet Basics
text: With many people choosing open kitchens, selecting fixtures takes on more importance. The once-inconspicuous kitchen faucet is now anything but.

headline: Maybe Most Parents Need to Worry More About College Choice
text: Here’s a novel thought: most American families worry too little about what kind of college their children attend.

headline: Cell Phones and the Expectation of Privacy
text: Ninety-one percent of American adults now own a cell phone, according to a survey by the Pew Research Center. Among those 44 and younger, ownership rises to more than 95 percent. The cell phone is as ubiquitous a piece of consumer technology as we have ever had, and may be the most rapidly adopted in history.

headline: Park’s Quest for a Record Begins, but Part of Her Game Deserts Her
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — Inbee Park’s second shot on the 16th hole Thursday at the Women’s British Open landed in one of the Old Course’s infamous pot bunkers, her ball sitting like a pimple on its face. Park’s emotions on the course run the gamut from A to B, but what her body language and expressions never convey was revealed clearly in her conversation with her caddie, Brad Beecher, on how to play the next shot.

headline: Did You Hear That? It Was Art
text: Shhh. Listen.

headline: Root of the Poisonous Tree
text: NEW DELHI — Twenty-three children in Gandaman village in the state of Bihar died last month after eating a free lunch provided by their primary school. According to a forensics report, the potato and soya curry they were served on July 16 was contaminated with monocrotophos, a highly toxic compound commonly used as a pesticide.

headline: Enough Resilience to Fill an Arena
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — At first it seemed that Beyoncé was taking one of her pop-star nicknames, Queen Bey, all too seriously. Her show at the Izod Center here on Wednesday night opened with a bombastic orchestral dirge and a video presenting her as a Marie Antoinette figure in a Gothic palace, receiving a crown. But as the queen’s female retinue — wearing white unitards and hoops without skirts — reappeared onstage, the dirge segued into the martial beat of “Run the World (Girls).” Beyoncé, shaking the epaulets on her shoulders and flipping her hair, was taking power not for herself but for her entire gender. The set that followed was not about aristocratic aloofness, but about energy, empathy and a beaming smile.

headline: The Gun Report: August 1, 2013
text: Did you hear that after seven years, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms finally has a new chief, B. Todd Jones? Yes, it does. The bureau had been leaderless through the entire Obama administration, thanks to the usual coalition of Republican Senators and the National Rifle Association, which preferred the A.T.F. to be as toothless as possible. Obama’s first-term nominee never even came to a vote.

headline: Anemia Tied to Dementia Risk
text: A large study has found further evidence that anemia — a deficiency of red blood cells and a common condition in the elderly — increases the risk for dementia.

headline: Sun Capital Court Ruling Threatens Structure of Private Equity
text: Think twice before you bet against the widows and orphans.

headline: A Mother’s Letter to Lincoln
text: “I am a colored woman and my son was strong and able to fight for his country and the colored people have as much to fight for as any,” declared Hannah Johnson, from Buffalo, N.Y., in a July 31, 1863, letter to President Abraham Lincoln.

headline: Image of the Day: August 1
text: Indian swimmer Sandeep Sejwal competing at a world championship in Barcelona, Spain.

headline: Museum Director in Ukraine Paints Over a Mural She Doesn’t Like
text: MOSCOW — The general director of the Mystetskyi Arsenal in Kiev, the largest art institution in Ukraine, has been accused of censorship and catering to church and state after she painted over in black a mural she had commissioned from the contemporary artist Volodymyr Kuznetsov.

headline: G.O.P. Rifts Lead Congress to Spending Impasse
text: WASHINGTON — Hours before leaving on summer recess, Congress on Thursday hit a seemingly intractable impasse on government spending, increasing the prospects of a government shutdown in the fall and adding new urgency to fiscal negotiations between the White House and a bloc of Senate Republicans.

headline: Luc Levesque of Trip Advisor, on Frequent Evaluations
text: This interview with Luc Levesque, the founder of TravelPod.com, a site that hosts travel blogs, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant. Mr. Levesque is also a vice president at TripAdvisor, which acquired his company in 2006.

headline: Wheelies: The Natural Gas Pickups Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: A Virtual Accounting Department for Small Businesses
text: When Ian Crosby was in college six years ago in Vancouver, British Columbia, he really wanted to work at a video game company and got a job at one — as its bookkeeper. He learned two things: bookkeeping wasn’t a job he liked much and automating many of the bookkeeper’s tasks saved him a lot of time.

headline: Imagine That: ‘Walter Mitty’ Is Centerpiece of New York Film Festival
text: “The Secret Life of Walter Mitty” originated as a classic short story in The New Yorker, so it’s only fitting that a new film adaptation of it should have its world premiere at the New York Film Festival. Ben Stiller’s cinematic take on the James Thurber tale, which Mr. Stiller directed and in which he plays the melancholy daydreamer of its title, will be presented on Oct. 5 as the centerpiece gala selection of the New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Thursday.

headline: Aug. 1: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: In the Ozarks, Finding the Local Groove
text: The Frugal Traveler drops in on a fiddle jam and visits a distillery during a stop on his summer road trip.

headline: Music and Moonshine in the Mellow Ozarks
text: Dinnertime comes early in the Ozarks, even during the long days of summer. So after I lingered over smoked trout, fried chicken liver and blackberry cobbler at Rockbridge Trout and Game Ranch’s friendly restaurant, wandered around its barn-red 19th-century grist mill and drove off to look for a motel, there was still daylight to spare. At 8 p.m., as I reached the utterly rural intersection of Missouri Routes 5 and 95, the sun had still not quite yet set. It was what photographers and filmmakers call the golden hour, when the last light of the day gives whatever land it falls on a temporary visual upgrade. So I stopped, parked, and sat on the hood of my car. Sloping pastures glinted and cattle grazed halfway to the horizon, beyond them purplish pink clouds hovered over barely distinguishable low-slung hills. The Ozarks were, finally, stunning.

headline: The Cellphone Gets Its Close-Up
text: “The Canyons” — directed by Paul Schrader, written by Bret Easton Ellis and starring Lindsay Lohan — is a dispiriting, unpleasurable work punctuated with flashes of vitalizing vulgarity. It isn’t a good movie in terms of the conventional norms (acting for starters), but it also exhibits a crude integrity. If you take the characters seriously or at their word, a mistake for such a dissembling, venal group, you may think that this is just another story about the dirty business of making movies. Hollywood types have been rolling around in the muck about as long as there’s been an industry (that’s what made Sammy run); the twist here is that no one here seems to care anymore.

headline: Does Snowden Deserve Asylum?
text: It’s hard not to feel for Edward Snowden. A young and perhaps not terribly worldly-wise man, he revealed documents to the world that contained information about government misbehavior that was of vital interest to Americans, as well as citizens of other countries. Being stuck in the departure zone at Moscow’s Sheremetyevo Airport cannot have been thrilling.

headline: U.S. Carmakers Post Strongest July Sales Since 2006
text: American automakers, buoyed this year by robust sales in pickups, said on Thursday that smaller cars and midsize sedans were helping to spur growth in the industry to levels not seen since before the recession.

headline: A New Way to Read Booming
text: Booming now publishes a weekly e-mail newsletter. This means you won’t have to go looking for us — we’ll find you. To sign up, just click here.

headline: Answers About Rheumatoid Arthritis, Part 3
text: Dr. Vivian P. Bykerk has been answering readers’ questions about rheumatoid arthritis, a disease that often starts in middle age and is more common in women. Part 1 of her answers is here. Part 2 is here.

headline: Spice Symphony
text: Inside the Midtown East restaurant that blends Indian and Chinese flavors.

headline: The Marriage of Indian and Chinese Cuisines
text: The scarlet sauce on a hillock of crispy, half-broken noodles is, ostensibly, Chinese sweet-and-sour. It is easy to pinpoint the familiar notes of soy, sugar and vinegar, but how to explain the steady, rippling bass line of chile heat? Squeeze of lime, whiff of cilantro, streaks of sour mango powder and black, sulfur-tinged salt: the balance tips toward tanginess and betrays the dish’s true roots, in India.

headline: Perfectly Reasonable Question No. 4: On Mentioning Brand Names
text: Dan Goldberg, who identifies himself as the user of an Android phone, thinks The Times is giving Apple some free publicity, and he doesn’t like it.

headline: Pick Your Own Judge
text: Nathaniel Popper’s excellent article on rating agencies today — demonstrating that Standard & Poor’s seems to have improved its market share in the rating of commercial real estate securitizations by lowering its standards — points to what a strange market the ratings agencies are in.

headline: Fusion Announces Premiere Date and Prime-Time Schedule
text: Fusion, the forthcoming cable channel that is a joint venture of ABC News and Univision, now has a premiere date — Oct. 28 — and a prime-time schedule.

headline: Icahn Sues Dell to Halt Changes to Buyout Vote
text: The billionaire Carl C. Icahn said Thursday that he had sued Dell Inc., seeking to prevent the company and its board from altering terms of a scheduled vote on a proposed $24.4 billion takeover bid by the computer maker’s founder.

headline: Barclays, Caught Short, Is Now in a Bind
text: “We continue to believe that we’re well capitalized.”

headline: Girls Not Allowed
text: I am a young lawyer (and a man). I work with a more-senior female lawyer, who refers to the secretaries in our office as “girls.” She’ll say, “Please give these papers to the girl outside,” or “The girl at reception has a package for you.” But these are mostly middle-aged women, and usually older than my lawyer colleague. Still, the women she’s talking about don’t seem to mind. Isn’t this behavior sexist? Should I say something?

headline: A Double Dose of Water Delights at Barretto Point Park
text: The Miser has gone off on vacation; he didn’t say where, but we imagine that he is perhaps surfing the waves somewhere sandy. Maybe we just have water on the mind — it sure seems to call in the summertime. Or, as E. E. Cummings put it, more poetically: “For whatever we lose (like a you or a me)/it’s always ourselves we find in the sea.”

headline: With Moto X, Google Enters a Crowded Marketplace
text: The time has come for Google, the king of online search, to show whether it has any business selling hardware.

headline: John Graves, Author Beloved by Fellow Texans, Dies at 92
text: A battered maple canoe paddle hangs on a wall at Texas State University in San Marcos, framed like a holy relic, which, to the many admirers of the author John Graves, is not far off.

headline: For Fans of Sendak, the Artist Keeps Giving
text: Maurice Sendak saved draft after draft of his illustrations for books, bookplates, posters, cartoons and prints. Sendak, who died last year at 83, befriended collectors of his drawings, and at times he would even customize his work for them.

headline: Made in Space
text: Venus Over Manhattan

headline: Hank Willis Thomas
text: Jack Shainman Gallery

headline: Scenes From a Village
text: Guzmán, Spain

headline: Better Data, but Not Enough for the Fed
text: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: Jimmy DeSana: ‘Party Picks’
text: Salon 94 Bowery

headline: It’s Easy to Be Happy on a Day Like This
text: The weather where I am today (in rural New Hampshire) is glorious. A smattering of clouds in a blue sky, sunshine, light breeze. This morning, I met the extra requests that my children made (things like another bowl of cereal after I’d put the box and milk away, or a return to the house for a forgotten pair of shoes) with equanimity, grace and acquiescence. “Of course!” I said to the child who asked if we could go back for her shoes (they were off to day camp, and she wanted both sandals and sneakers).

headline: Cleveland Kidnapper and Victim Speak
text: At Ariel Castro’s sentencing hearing, Michelle Knight told her captor that she could forgive him, but never forget. Castro apologized to his victims and said he is “not a monster.”

headline: Martín Gutierrez: Martin(e)
text: Ryan Lee Gallery

headline: Robert Arneson
text: David Zwirner

headline: Ferrari May Have Issues With Convertibles It Did Not Build
text: Any Ferrari built when the founder, Enzo Ferrari, was still in control of the company is, by definition, a collectible car. Because of the glamour of Ferrari convertibles built in that era, and their relative rarity compared with coupes, there is special place in the hearts and wallets of collectors for the open-top models known as Spiders.

headline: An American Man’s Quest to Become an Old Castilian
text: The A-1 national highway in Spain heads north from Madrid straight over the Guadarrama Mountains, the peaks jutting like jagged shark teeth that cut the rest of the world away. And then you’re floating, up through one last ear-popping puerta, or pass, perched above the upper Meseta Central, the football-shaped highlands that cover most of the country’s northern interior, the silted land below glinting with flecks of red, gold and green.

headline: Former Trader Is Found Liable in Fraud Case
text: Updated, 10:03 p.m. | A former Goldman Sachs trader at the center of a toxic mortgage deal lost a closely watched legal battle on Thursday, giving Wall Street’s top regulator its first significant courtroom victory in a case stemming from the financial crisis.

headline: F.B.I. Said to Find It Could Not Have Averted Boston Attack
text: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. has concluded that there was little its agents could have done to prevent the Boston Marathon bombings, according to law enforcement officials, rejecting criticism that it could have better monitored one of the suspects before the attack.

headline: Taking the Plunge on California’s Coasters
text: Twist, turn and listen to the screams as we take you on five of the state’s roller coaster rides.

headline: ‘Avatar’ Plans Now Include 3 Sequels
text: LOS ANGELES — James Cameron and 20th Century Fox said on Thursday that they now expected to make three rather than two follow-ups to their hit film “Avatar.”

headline: HootSuite Raises $165 Million in New Round of Financing
text: HootSuite, which provides services to manage multiple social media accounts like Facebook and Twitter, said on Thursday that it had raised $165 million in new financing from a trio of investment firms.

headline: Carrie Bradshaw, Anti-Heroine?
text: As we prepare for the final season of “Breaking Bad,” the best (by far, since “Mad Men” is in clear decline) of the current crop of anti-heroic television dramas, it’s interesting to read Emily Nussbaum’s case for why Carrie Bradshaw of “Sex in the City” deserves a place in the pantheon of television protagonists that includes Tony Soprano, Walter White, Don Draper, Al Swearengen and other so-called “difficult men.” Nussbaum’s point, and it’s a good one, is that Carrie’s arc on “Sex and the City” was often more troubled, and her character’s development more complicated, than the frothy Jimmy Choo stereotypes about the show would lead one to suggest. She writes:

headline: White House Reacts to Snowden Asylum
text: The press secretary, Jay Carney, said the Obama administration was “extremely disappointed” with the Russian government’s granting temporary asylum to Edward J. Snowden.

headline: Can You Guess What This Is?
text: RULES1. Player has not seen the photo beforehand.

headline: Where the SAT and ACT Dominate
text: A state by state comparison of the number of students who took the SAT and ACT.

headline: Red Bulls’ Cahill to Miss 3-4 Weeks
text: The term warrior is often overused when it comes to athletes. But the Red Bulls’ coach, Mike Petke, felt it fit in describing Tim Cahill’s game-long resolve in fighting through an injury.

headline: The Limits of Cosmetic Surgery
text: Patients who get facial plastic surgery often assume that they will look younger and more appealing afterward. But a new study, the first to try to quantify attractiveness after a face-lift, brow-lift or eyelid surgery, found only a tiny, insignificant increase in attractiveness. The study, published online in JAMA Facial Plastic Surgery on Thursday, also found that patients looked, on average, only three years younger, as judged by independent viewers who assessed photos of patients before and after cosmetic surgery.

headline: Breaking Free From the Nesting Doll
text: What do you owe someone who’s loved and healed you?

headline: Test of Wits and Sobriety
text: LIKE many New Yorkers, I was inspired when Arvind Mahankali, a 13-year-old from Queens, soared to victory in the Scripps National Spelling Bee in May by correctly spelling “knaidel.” Or “kneydl.” Or is it “knaydl”?

headline: ‘I’ Before ‘E’
text: At a bar in Brooklyn, adults compete in a monthly spelling bee.

headline: Athletes in Sochi to Be Barred From Advocating Gay Causes
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s minister of sports, Vitaly L. Mutko, said on Thursday that foreign athletes traveling to Russia for the 2014 Olympics in Sochi would be expected to obey a new Russian law banning “homosexual propaganda” or face criminal prosecution.

headline: Many a Twist on a French Classic
text: Fans of crepes don’t have far to go to indulge their cravings these days; like cupcakes, the thin, French pancakes with assorted fillings seem to be having a moment.

headline: Yves Klein’s ‘Monotone’ Symphony Is Headed to New York
text: On March 9, 1960, 100 people, all in black tie, gathered in a Paris gallery to see the artist Yves Klein conduct a 10-piece orchestra in a performance of his first sound composition. Called the “Monotone-Silence” Symphony, it consisted of a single chord played for 20 minutes straight, followed by 20 minutes of silence. At the same time, Klein directed three female models (whom he called his “living brushes”) to roll themselves in blue paint and press their bodies against sheets of paper lining the walls and floors. When the music stopped, the models froze.

headline: Fox Signals How ‘Glee’  Will Handle Monteith Death
text: LOS ANGELES — The Fox network and the producers of “Glee” have devised a plan to address the unexpected death last month of one of the show’s stars, Cory Monteith, with a direct treatment of the issue of drug addiction, Kevin Reilly, the chairman of entertainment for Fox, said on Thursday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Zimbabwe and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Zimbabwe, Israel, Ohio and Canada.

headline: Objectively Stylish
text: The New York Times has a long history of publishing style guides. We first released The New York Times Manual of Style and Usage in 1950 so that reporters inside and outside The Times could have a definitive resource for our somewhat quirky rules. In 2002, we published an update to that guide, and NYTimes journalists and editors use a frequently updated online reference version every day.

headline: ‘If This Were Your Mother, Doctor…’
text: The other residents and I sat in our blue scrubs with our attending physician in the windowless family meeting room just outside the intensive care unit. We had gathered around one end of the ovoid table with the family of the patient, two daughters and a son, at the other.

headline: Advocates for Immigrants Up the Ante in a Capitol Sit-In That Brings Arrests
text: WASHINGTON — Seeking to send a message to lawmakers as they leave to face their constituents over the August recess, 41 leaders of groups supporting an overhaul of the immigration system held a noisy but peaceful sit-in on Capitol Hill on Thursday and were arrested, in an escalation of their tactics.

headline: Mets’ Harvey Remains Winless Against a Lineup That’s Usually Hapless
text: MIAMI — Matt Harvey has mystified plenty of hitters throughout his All-Star season.

headline: Shanghai For Strivers
text: Tash Aw’s estimable third novel, “Five Star Billionaire,” takes its title from a fictional self-help book, and its mantras function as chapter titles: “Move to where the money is”; “Reinvent yourself”; “Cultivate an urbane, humorous personality.” Some of these mantras are touching, like “Know when to cut your losses.”

headline: Two Good Guys (or So They Seem) Behaving Badly
text: Big bangs and fast talk are the name of the genre game in “2 Guns,” a slick, slippery thriller that taps into the anarchic playfulness that made the best American action flicks of the 1980s and ’90s pop. Directed by Baltasar Kormakur, riffing on the cheerful irreverence of Shane Black and the hyperbolic style of Tony Scott, the movie turns on a pair of seemingly bad guys who may be good. A reissue of the five-part comic series on which it’s based sets the scene nicely: “Two guys walk into a bank. It goes badly.” It does in the movies as well, although now the duo spring off the page courtesy of Denzel Washington and Mark Wahlberg, one of the better odd couples to bond and bicker since Mel met Danny.

headline: Ex-Chairman of Freddie Mac Nominated to Lead I.R.S.
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said on Thursday that he would nominate John A. Koskinen, a widely respected manager who took charge of a bankrupt Freddie Mac, to head another troubled institution, the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: Nostalgic Finale, With Latin Touch, for a B-Boy Original
text: What do you call a B-boy when he’s a middle-aged man? Richard Colón was 13 in 1979, when he joined the two-year-old Rock Steady Crew. He wasn’t much older when, under the descriptive moniker Crazy Legs, he became world famous for spinning on his back. By then he was president of this group, and decades later he still is. For a long time he was the only original member performing. On Wednesday at Central Park SummerStage, he danced his final show.

headline: Novel Approach
text: There’s an absolutely essential video available on YouTube, of a 2012 segment from the public radio program “This American Life,” in which the writer and frequent guest David Rakoff walks onstage with his left hand tucked into his pocket. Rakoff has recently undergone surgery, his “fourth in as many years” for cancer, he explains, and now possesses a “flail limb.” Aside from “being able to shrug talmudically,” he says, “I can neither move nor feel my left arm.”

headline: One Tough Cookie
text: WHEN my friend Kathleen moved back to New York a few weeks ago, after living on the West Coast for 18 months, I wanted to welcome her home in style. I remembered reading that Tate’s Bake Shop, based in Southampton, N.Y., had opened its own gluten-free kitchen in April, and since Kathleen has a gluten sensitivity, I figured I would stage a dessert jamboree.

headline: Ride the Giant Dipper
text: Ride the Giant Dipper at Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk.

headline: Requiem for the Living
text: The author of this book is from Colombia, but he is nothing like Gabriel García Márquez. Juan Gabriel Vásquez’s brilliant new novel rejects the vivid colors and mythical transformations of his older countryman’s Caribbean masterpiece, “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” in favor of the cold, bitter poetry of Bogotá and the hushed intensity of young married love. In “The Sound of Things Falling,” we are closer to the noir palette of the Uruguayan genius Juan Carlos Onetti, whose fiction was apt to be set in a bankrupt shipyard or to feature a desperate writer striving to raise money for his wife’s cancer surgery.

headline: Steinem Makes a Video for Quinn
text: Seeking to capitalize on the historic nature of her candidacy, Christine C. Quinn sent out a video on Thursday of the feminist icon Gloria Steinem lauding Ms. Quinn and saying her election as mayor would inspire young women. Ms. Quinn, the City Council speaker, would be the first woman elected mayor of New York.

headline: In Store | A Berlin Boutique That Pays Tribute to New York Creative Culture
text: As any New York denizen knows, the rat is both the city’s unofficial mascot and the ruler of its underground domain. That’s why the artist Keren Richter and the art director Gabriel Kuo chose Rats as the name for their new curated pop-up shop in Berlin, which pays tribute to the underground creative culture of the Big Apple.

headline: Two Climate Analysts Fault Gas Leaks, but Not as a Big Warming Threat
text: Two prominent analysts of human-driven global warming have offered fresh criticisms of the way Anthony Ingraffea, a Cornell University engineering professor, has been portraying the contribution of natural gas leaks to climate change.

headline: Writers and Hunters
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Never Give In’
text: To the Editor:

headline: La Guardia, Legislator
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hirschman’s Influence
text: To the Editor:

headline: Treacherous
text: To the Editor:

headline: Being on the Rebound Never Felt So Good
text: Sutter Keely is a teenager with the gift of gab, able to flip the mood of an encounter with brash good will. You run into guys like this in teenage dramas or comedies, the charm often backed up with sarcasm or a pretty face. But Sutter has genuine heart, and his cheer masks closely held fears, an ambivalence about the future and an insecurity over his separated parents’ past.

headline: Ring Around the Collar at 535 Park Avenue
text: The trim elegance of 535 Park Avenue, unusual because it was built by its future owners instead of a developer, has long been marred by the fractured and soiled glazed terra cotta on two lower floors. Now the refined building, completed in 1910, is taking a radical approach to a longtime problem.

headline: Receiver With Ties to Eagles’ Coach Gets Last Shot
text: PHILADELPHIA — When Coach Chip Kelly sent David Ball a text message last week to ask him if he was free to join the Eagles at their training camp, Ball packed his gear and took an immediate sabbatical from his day job as a high school football coach in Vermont.

headline: Senate Easily Approves Obama’s U.N. Nominee
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday approved the nomination of Samantha Power as the next ambassador to the United Nations, a relatively smooth and quiet process that lacked the partisan acrimony of other recent confirmations.

headline: Seafood in a Skipper’s House
text: The Fort Rachel section of Mystic comprises a warren of hilly lanes with trim Colonial-era frame houses, views of sailboats bobbing in the harbor, and the 1754 Dutch colonial that is the Captain Daniel Packer Inne. The restaurant is currently run by Allison Kiley Nasin, the daughter of the couple who painstakingly restored the building and opened it 30 years ago.

headline: Increase in Urine Testing Raises Ethical Questions
text: As doctors try to ensure their patients do not abuse prescription drugs, they are relying more and more on sophisticated urine-screening tests to learn which drugs patients are taking and — just as important — which ones they’re not.

headline: Jailed Pussy Riot Activist’s Defiant Speech at Parole Hearing
text: As my colleague Melena Ryzik reported, the two members of the Russian activist collective Pussy Riot who remain imprisoned were both denied parole last week. At separate hearings, Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova were judged to be insufficiently repentant for the “punk prayer” they performed in a Moscow cathedral last year, calling on the Virgin Mary to “send Putin packing!”

headline: Banks as Bookies
text: Why did Fabrice Tourre’s security exist?

headline: New York State Investigates Disqualification of Customers by Banks
text: New York State’s top prosecutor is investigating some of the nation’s largest banks in connection with their use of credit-reporting databases that disqualify people seeking to open checking or savings accounts — an inquiry that has gained urgency as the ranks of the unbanked has swelled in the aftermath of the financial crisis.

headline: Good to the Last Rocking Drop
text: HOBOKEN, N.J. — “THIS room was a bit more to us than a performance room,” Richard Barone of the Bongos said about halfway through the group’s set at Maxwell’s here on Wednesday evening. “It was also our practice space. And it still feels like a practice space.”

headline: Comedy Listings for Aug. 2-8
text: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Double Bill: 2 English Composers, 3 Centuries Apart
text: LENOX, Mass. — The coupling of Henry Purcell’s “Dido and Aeneas” and Benjamin Britten’s “Curlew River” — English music dramas composed almost three centuries apart — makes a superlative double bill. It’s not unreasonable to claim that Purcell and Britten are the two greatest English-born composers, and in this centenary year of Britten’s birth, it’s good to link him to a composer he often championed. More than that, these are two intricate, tragic masterpieces. Each houses death and violent emotional affliction within several outer shells that, paradoxically, make anguish at once more bearable and more inexorable.

headline: Real Estate Q & A
text: Stabilized Tenant Urged to Buy Unit

headline: When a Poet’s Life and the Law Are at Odds
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — Press week at the Santa Fe Opera — when all five works in the season’s repertory are presented within five nights — got off to a head-spinning start, contrasting Offenbach’s frothy comedy “The Grand Duchess of Gerolstein,” on Tuesday evening, with Theodore Morrison’s pitch-black drama, “Oscar,” on Wednesday.
