In 2007, Twitter still seemed pretty revolutionary for the way it bridged the gap between public figures and private ones, between celebrity and anonymity. The most widely used new app these days, at least among my 20-something cohort, is Snapchat. It allows the bored user to send innumerable so-called selfies to any friend unlucky enough to have signed up, with the assurance that all pictures will disappear in the span of 10 seconds.

headline: Lonely Planet’s Plans to Make Up for Job Cuts
text: After Lonely Planet announced last month that it was eliminating 70 to 80 positions in a staff of 450, eulogies by travelers who had used its guidebooks flooded Twitter with hashtags like #LPMemories.

headline: After the Doctor and a Prince, He’s a Cop
text: The question at the center of “Broadchurch,” a British crime drama starting Wednesday on BBC America, is who killed a boy found dead on a beach in the picturesque seaside town of the title. Less of a mystery is why it stars David Tennant as Detective Inspector Alec Hardy. Though relatively unknown in the States, this wiry, energetic Scottish actor has long stood out on Britain’s stages and screens. When he starred in the Royal Shakespeare Company’s 2008 production of “Hamlet,” the critic for The Guardian proclaimed, “David Tennant is the greatest Hamlet of his generation.” And, while he is one of 11 actors to have played the titular centuries-old Time Lord on the long-running science-fiction series “Doctor Who,” his portrayal was among the most popular.

headline: The Breakup Album, 9 Months After
text: A year ago, the folk-rock duo the Civil Wars seemed to be golden. Their 2011 debut album, “Barton Hollow,” had sold a half-million copies without a major label and won them two Grammy Awards. They had toured with Adele and Emmylou Harris and collaborated with Taylor Swift on a hit song. More success seemed certain.

headline: Classics on the Coast
text: Some highlights from the more than six decades of the Pebble Beach Concours d’Elegance and surrounding events.

headline: The Promise of More Than Perfection
text: Even as a boy growing up in the Midwest, I was interested in food and cooking. Supermarket expeditions to the local A.&P. were entertaining, and so was racing along the aisles astride the shopping cart.

headline: Eagles Receiver Who Used Slur Takes Leave Amid Uproar
text: PHILADELPHIA — As a furor escalated over the use of a racial epithet by Eagles receiver Riley Cooper, and Philadelphia’s mayor criticized the team for issuing no punishment beyond a fine, Cooper took an indefinite leave Friday to seek counseling.

headline: Image of the Day: August 2
text: Muslims breaking their fast at Jama Masjid, a mosque in Old Delhi.

headline: Celebrating a Bond With Britten
text: Grecchinois, the name of Nicholas Phan’s engaging blog, reflects the Greek and Chinese heritage of this 34-year-old American tenor, who has fast made a name for himself as an expressive interpreter of the British composer Benjamin Britten. Raised Greek Orthodox in Ann Arbor, Mich., Mr. Phan, who initially studied the violin and played in a youth orchestra, discovered Britten when he played his “Young Person’s Guide to the Orchestra.” In college, as a gay man, he became fascinated with the relationship between Britten and the tenor Peter Pears, who lived together at a time when homosexual acts were illegal in Britain. He cites an experience performing Britten in a recital at Truman State University in Kirksville, Mo., around early 2006 as proof that the music, with its “beautiful combination of head and heart,” speaks to audiences everywhere.

headline: Onstage Together at Last
text: Everything about Annaleigh Ashford, a 28-year-old actress currently starring in “Kinky Boots,” the Broadway musical, is sunny and bright, like a new penny. Her hair is yellow; she often wears yellow dresses; her eyes shine like sequins.

headline: Forensic Art Expert’s Libel Case Against New Yorker Magazine Is Dismissed
text: A federal judge in New York has dismissed a libel suit brought against The New Yorker magazine and one of its writers by Peter Paul Biro, a forensic art expert who was the subject of a long article in July 2010.

headline: Odes to Heat-Struck New York
text: In last Sunday’s Metropolitan section, Benjamin Weiser exhumed an article about the summer heat that was published in this newspaper in 1852. No mere weather story, it combined meticulous detail, social commentary and references to art and literature — all rendered in spectacularly overwrought prose. We asked readers to write their own over-the-top odes to the temperature in response; a selection is below.

headline: Reborn Cosmos Return to the Field
text: They were the Galaticos in the alternate universe of American soccer in the late 1970s and early ‘80s.

headline: Summer on the Jersey Shore, After the Storm
text: Seaside Heights historically embodied both the natural beach-encrusted splendors and the boozy, boardwalk MTV excesses of the Jersey Shore. That status was only enhanced after pictures of its half-submerged roller coaster, long a destination for families in search of fun, became a post-Hurricane Sandy metaphor in news reports for nature’s triumph over what man had wrought.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Not Just the Flu, Solved!
text: Updated, 12:53 p.m., Monday Aug. 5

headline: Answers
text: We asked educators to submit questions they’d llike to see on the SAT. Below, they explain their answers.

headline: George Clooney Rebuts Loeb’s Critique of Sony
text: Daniel S. Loeb has been steadily ratcheting up his critique of Sony in recent days. But the conglomerate found a defender in a somewhat unlikely source: George Clooney.

headline: Testing, Testing
text: AS if applying to college isn’t taxing enough, the process seems to have been ratcheted up another notch. Ambitious high school students are no longer content with just one college admissions test. Not a single college requires it, but many applicants to the nation’s most selective colleges and universities are taking — and retaking — both the ACT and the SAT.

headline: What Would You Ask?
text: The College Board has announced plans for a fundamental redesign of the SAT, to be introduced in 2015. What should be on it? We invited educators to dream up a question they would like to see. Turn to the answers for an explanation of their choices.

headline: Owning Up
text: THE idea of anonymous confessions went viral last semester, with Facebook pages popping up at campuses large and small. The confessions page out of the University of Wisconsin, Madison, which went up in late February, says it’s the nation’s largest, with about 500,000 weekly views during the school year.

headline: To Catch a Cheat
text: FOR his recent MOOC, “Understanding Cheating in Online Courses,” Bernard Bull asked his students to share their stories. Cut-and-paste still rules, he found, but with a global twist that trips up plagiarism-detection software. Students are finding papers online in another language and running them through Google Translate.

headline: Skipping Class (All of Them)
text: You don’t even have to log in. A handful of companies have taken the essay mill to the next level. NoNeedtoStudy.com, WeTakeYourClass.com and BoostMyGrades.com, among others, will take an entire online course for you.

headline: Following the Money
text: FOR 18-year-old consumers, financial decisions escalate exponentially. Tall latte or a grande splurge? Lucky Brand or True Religion? State U. or N.Y.U.? Statistics or psych or maybe social work?

headline: Sneak Preview
text: SAY farewell to vocabulary flashcards with arcane words like “compendious,” “membranous,” “mendacious,” “pugnacious,” “depreciatory,” “redolent,” “treacly” and “jettison.” In the new SAT, to be unveiled in 2015, David Coleman, president of the College Board, wants to get rid of obscure words that are . . . just SAT words, and replace them with more common words like “synthesis,” “distill” and “transform,” used in context as they will be in college and in life.

headline: The Costliest Colleges
text: SINCE 2011, the Department of Education has tried to shame colleges over costs. This summer’s data release shows that 7 of the 10 most expensive private nonprofit colleges (in terms of net price, or total cost of attendance minus average grant aid) are art and music conservatories. In defense: tiny endowments, small studio classes and expensive glassblowing equipment and audio mixers. On the other hand: these are watercolorists and musicians.

headline: Talking With Teachers
text: FRESHMAN year at Hamilton College, in Clinton, N.Y., Bret Turner asked a music professor, “Why is music important?” Enthused by the passionate response, he decided to speak with every teacher on campus about his or her discipline. By the time he graduated, in May, he’d chatted with 200 of 223 faculty members, a half-hour to an hour each.

headline: Class Warfare Along Partygoer Lines
text: IN the fall of 2004, 53 young women arriving for their first year at a public research university found that one room on their dorm floor had a sign saying, “This room is occupied by sociology researchers studying college student social life.”

headline: Book Review Podcast: David Rakoff’s Farewell in Verse
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Paul Rudnick reviews “Love, Dishonor, Marry, Die, Cherish, Perish,” the final book by David Rakoff, who died of cancer last year at the age of 47. Mr. Rudnick said he was prepared to hate the book, “and not just because it’s so awful to contemplate a world without any more David Rakoff books, or any more David Rakoff.” He writes:

headline: An $18 Million Lesson in Handling Credit Report Errors
text: Even after sending more than 13 letters to Equifax over the course of two years, Julie Miller could not get the big credit bureau to remove a host of errors that it inserted into her credit report.

headline: A Seventh Day, but Not a Day of Rest
text: Stuff doesn’t stop for Sundays or holidays, and when you talk about Miriam Linna and her husband, Billy Miller, you’re talking about stuff. She collects paperbacks, with an emphasis on pulp fiction; they both collect records, the scruffier the better. Then they recycle the gems through their businesses. From their apartment in a converted school in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, she runs Kicks Books (recent titles include “Gone Man Squared” by the English beat poet Royston Ellis) and both run the resolutely lo-fi Norton Records. Since 1984, they have also made joyful noises with their garage rock band, the A-Bones, with Ms. Linna, 57, on drums, and Mr. Miller singing. Since Hurricane Sandy flooded their warehouse in Red Hook, they have been working to salvage records and books, including on Sundays. Roaming among their collections is their mixed-breed dog, Queenie.

headline: Beyond Dioramas: Nature’s New Story
text: LOS ANGELES — The traditional natural history museum is powerful and familiar, but it is also strange. It is weighty, ponderous, pieced together from relics of lost worlds. It evolved in the 19th century, displaying the geological cataclysms that molded the earth’s surface, the creatures that clambered into habitats and the indigenous cultures that were once considered closer to nature. No other museum genre has changed so glacially.

headline: Week in Review: Trial Sends Message to Midlevel Employees
text: Former trader is found liable in fraud case. | Trader’s hiring offers a glimpse of SAC practices. | Banks find S.&P. more favorable in bond ratings. | Million denied bank accounts for past errors. | JPMorgan looks to pay to settle U.S. inquiries. | Hunting for luxury, retail giant buys Saks.

headline: What Inspired You to Work in Video Games?
text: This summer, The New York Times is publishing essays by its critics about the moments or works that prompted them to write about the arts, along with stories from readers about their own epiphanies. Previously we heard from readers who work in television, classical music, dance and pop music.

headline: Keep On Truckin’
text: The connection may sound obscure, but as David Bowers of Absolute Strategy Research in London notes, there is a surprising correlation between the pace of truck sales and the ability of stocks to outperform bonds.

headline: The Trouble With Lemonade Stands
text: Last night at dinner, I announced that I planned to write about lemonade stands and the challenges they present for me.

headline: For That All-Important First Tent
text: Gifts to make the outdoorsy couple comfy.

headline: Over Canned Octopus, a First Date
text: You should not judge Maiden Lane, a 28-seat wine bar and seafood spot that opened on Tompkins Square Park in April, by its kitchen. It doesn’t have one. Thus the concept: cold tins of imported mussels, octopus, sardines and other sea creatures, as well as smoked fish and cured meats for customers not ready to fork their dinner out of cans. The walls are exposed brick, the room not too loud. Wednesdays are theme nights, sometimes involving hot food made on the lone induction burner — this Wednesday will be a celebration of striped bass, featuring the fish in ceviche, crudo and soup.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: A Bubble for Your Thoughts? Not for Long
text: In May, ACT Inc. announced its test will go digital. Is it the end of the No. 2 pencil and the bubbles on a standardized-test answer sheet?

headline: Off the Tracks, Turmoil Aplenty
text: With the 2013 racing season at its midpoint, more or less, two of the biggest series are finding that it’s anything but business as usual. Each of those series, the Formula One world drivers championship and the Nascar Sprint Cup, have shown cracks in their armor in recent months.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Media Whirlwind Doesn’t Faze Park; Afternoon Gusts Do
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — The storm passed through Friday morning, leaving puddles in its wake. The wind arrived later and tilted the Old Course in favor of the early starters. Inbee Park, who played in the afternoon in the toughest of the conditions, managed to identify the rainbow even as the clouds rolled in and darkened her path to history.

headline: Monterey’s Festival, Rich in Tradition
text: The birth of this country’s classic-car Olympics took place at Pebble Beach, Calif., on the scenic Monterey Peninsula, in the simpler, quieter time of November 1950.

headline: Upwardly Mobile, but Not in Any Hurry to Get There
text: It’s logical that the less money you spend on a car, the less car you should expect. But as I’ve heard repeatedly from automakers, small-car customers in this country have the same lofty expectations as other types of shoppers.

headline: ‘Baby BMW’ Takes On an Entirely New Meaning
text: Let’s make one thing clear: McLaren, the British maker of racecars and supercars like the new P1 is not the same company as Maclaren, the British manufacturer of premium baby strollers, known for its 1965 innovation of the folding umbrella model.

headline: Pebble Beach Stalwarts, Classics as Their Cause
text: When visitors new to the weeklong festival surrounding the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance see their first million-dollar car, they can’t help but be impressed. After all, there aren’t many like that back home. By the third day, million-dollar vehicles are like the spear-carriers in “Aida,” mere background for the real action.

headline: The Tappin’ Talkies, in a Movie Classic on Stage
text: THOSE DANCING FEET are the stars of the show presented in Patchogue by the Gateway Performing Arts Center of Suffolk County — but the show is not “42nd Street.” This one is “Singin’ in the Rain,” a less felicitous translation of a dance-savvy movie into a tap-happy Broadway musical. It shares many of the same elements, including a showbiz setting and a plot involving the vagaries of young love, the machinations of a domineering female star and the rise of a bright-faced ingénue.

headline: The Life of Jesus: Reza Aslan Talks About ‘Zealot’
text: In a recent interview heard round the world (or at least, round influential Twitter feeds), the Fox News host Lauren Green spoke to Reza Aslan about his new book, “Zealot: The Life and Times of Jesus of Nazareth.” Ms. Green’s focus on why Mr. Aslan, a Muslim, would write about Jesus, created a stir on social media (and traditional media), bringing more attention to the book, which was already on The New York Times best-seller list.

headline: Video Shows Iran’s President-Elect Was Misquoted on Israel
text: Last Updated, 6:46 p.m. | As my colleague Thomas Erdbrink reports from Tehran, Iran’s state media scrambled on Friday to correct comments wrongly attributed to the country’s president-elect, Hassan Rouhani, after he was incorrectly quoted calling Israel “a sore which must be removed.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Democratic Republic of Congo
text: Photos from the Democratic Republic of Congo, Pakistan, the West Bank and India.

headline: In the Hamptons, Mind Your Manners, or Else
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — The young professionals were promising “All Cash” up front for a fast rental in the Hamptons. So the agency they contacted in April scrambled to get them into as many of the properties as it could.

headline: Meeting the Disapproving Mother
text: RUTHLESS MOTHERS of all degrees have long been a forceful presence in dramatic literature. Oscar Wilde’s Lady Bracknell, Tennessee Williams’s Amanda Wingfield and Gypsy Rose Lee’s mama are among the maternal monsters who command the stage.

headline: The Next Edition
text: WASHINGTON — On the eve of the 2012 White House Correspondents’ Dinner, this city’s annual media-politico-Hollywood love fest, Katharine Weymouth convened the sort of Washington power dinner for which her grandmother, Katharine Graham, the pioneering publisher of The Washington Post, was famous.

headline: Textbook Funnies
text: AS shipping and receiving coordinator at Bethel University’s bookstore, Karl Stavem delighted in flipping through textbooks, and always seemed to find humor – especially in word problems that involved implausible dating situations. Last year, Mr. Stavem started curating his collection on Tumblr.

headline: ‘Hello, Dolly!’ in Another Light
text: Thanks to the likes of Carol Channing, Pearl Bailey and Barbra Streisand, we tend to think of Dolly Levi as a flamboyant, stage-devouring diva. But before this exuberant busybody took to song and exclamatory punctuation in “Hello, Dolly!” she was simply “The Matchmaker” in the Thornton Wilder play — not low-key, exactly, but suited to more homespun character actresses like Ruth Gordon and Shirley Booth.

headline: A Cheap Spying Tool With a High Creepy Factor
text: Brendan O’Connor is a security researcher. How easy would it be, he recently wondered, to monitor the movement of everyone on the street – not by a government intelligence agency, but by a private citizen with a few hundred dollars to spare?

headline: Aaron Sanchez and John Besh Discover Haiti’s Evolving Food Culture
text: Earlier this week, the TV personalities and James Beard Award-winning chefs Aarón Sánchez and John Besh headed to Haiti on behalf of Oxfam’s GROW program, which seeks to promote sustainable practices for food production around the world. While there, they checked out urban gardens in Port-au-Prince, and new rice-growing techniques that require less water in the countryside. They also made headlines when they were turned away from a farmers market by a mayor who feared they would take unflattering pictures. In between their various activities, the duo — who happen to be best friends and are planning to open a Mexican restaurant together — cooked up local dishes alongside Haitian chefs, farmers and culinary students. Here, Sánchez and Besh share their adventures.

headline: Under a Coaster, a Dream, or Maybe a Nightmare
text: In 1996, during an outing to Coney Island, Donna Dennis found herself unexpectedly captivated by the Cyclone roller coaster. But it wasn’t the thrill of the ride or the enthusiasm of the crowds that drew her; it was the strange landscape beneath.

headline: Prison Life, Real and Onscreen
text: The night before she reports to prison after pleading guilty to smuggling drug money, Piper Chapman, the protagonist of Netflix’s popular series “Orange Is the New Black,” frets about maintaining her blond hair and meticulously groomed eyebrows. She anticipates that at least she can use her incarceration to “get ripped,” read everything on her Amazon wish list, maybe even learn a craft. She asks her fiancé to keep her Web site updated, and when she walks into the penitentiary, she’s carrying a burrata sandwich.

headline: Movie Review: 'Our Children'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Our Children."

headline: Movie Review: ‘2 Guns’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "2 Guns."

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Canyons’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "The Canyons."

headline: Tested by Water and Fire, Yet Staying Put
text: Several decades ago, Katie Gallagher’s mother arrived in New York from County Kerry, Ireland, and secured work as a nanny with a prominent Manhattan family that spent the summers in East Hampton. Seduced by the beauty and serenity of the beaches of the ruling class, Ms. Gallagher’s mother thought to herself, “There must be a place like this for us,” her daughter told me. By “us” she meant people of comparatively meager circumstance, but she also meant the Irish. As it happened, there was a place on the shore for her far from the world of Further Lane, a place with its own codes and dignities and manner of exclusion on the western tip of the Rockaway peninsula called Breezy Point.

headline: “Wildebeest”
text: From The Handsome Family’s album “Wilderness” on Carrot Top Records.

headline: Models and Mechanisms (Wonkish)
text: OK, traffic is mysterious — and yes, I have read Tom Vanderbilt. Last week I fought rolling traffic jams all across CT in the middle of the day; today I zipped into Manhattan with barely a delay, late on a Friday afternoon. So I have a bit of time.

headline: Two Cities and Cultures, Linked on a Brooklyn Wall
text: On one side, an eagle reaches its claws out toward a big red apple. On the other side, a creature wearing multiple masks moves toward the apple. These are images in a mural meant to depict the struggles of people of different backgrounds to make it to New York City.

headline: World Youth Open Championships Unfold in Atlanta
text: ATLANTA — There are three tournaments within one taking place here. Along with the Summer Nationals, we have the North American Youth Championships, which started on Thursday and end on Saturday, and the World Youth Open Championships, which begin on Sunday and run through Aug. 11.

headline: Friday Night Music: Lucius, Two of Us on the Run
text: A bit of sheer aural joy:

headline: Bill Cunningham | Well Tanned
text: Leather skirts can declare victory as the big surprise of summer (and a major fall trend).

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: Two big advertising companies merge, fast-food workers strike for higher wages and a former Goldman Sachs trader is found liable for fraud in a mortgage-backed security deal.

headline: Far-Flung Students
text: Back to school? Students submitted photographs of themselves and where they come from.

headline: Montauk Comes to Queens
text: Imagine a beach club plucked from the East End of Long Island and dropped one block from the subway on Rockaway Beach Boulevard and you’ll start to get a picture of the Playland Motel, which began taking guests on the first weekend in July and, almost from the moment that it opened, became a destination both for residents of the Rockaways, Queens, and for what are known locally as D.F.D.’s, or Down for the Days.

headline: When Lindsay Lohan Hijacks a Film, She Also Saves It
text: “The Canyons,” starring Lindsay Lohan, written by Bret Easton Ellis and directed by Paul Schrader, will open today in New York and on video on demand today and in Los Angeles on Aug. 9. This is no small victory for the filmmakers, considering that when the movie was completed, it was unclear whether it would make it to theaters at all. When Stephen Rodrick’s article, “Here Is What Happens When You Cast Lindsay Lohan in Your Movie,” was published in the magazine in mid-January, the film had been rejected by both Sundance and SXSW.

headline: Pursuing Elusive 59, Woods Falls a Bit Short
text: The pursuit of golf’s magic score of 59 has been a wild ride this year, with two minor tour players reaching it, a 16-year-old amateur carding one and Phil Mickelson leaving a putt hanging on the lip to barely miss the milestone.

headline: In Catskills, City Buyers Recolonize Bungalows
text: Zoe Schneider was on the hunt for an affordable country house when her brother forwarded an ad to her from his Boerum Hill Listserv: a little place in the Catskills with a pool, basketball court and a playground. The price: $25,000.

headline: After a Fee Dispute With Time Warner Cable, CBS Goes Dark for Three Million Viewers
text: The war between CBS and Time Warner Cable intensified on Friday when the cable company withdrew the CBS stations of its three million customers in markets including New York, Los Angeles and Dallas.

headline: Making the Case for Eating Fruit
text: Fresh fruit should not become a casualty in the sugar wars, many nutrition experts say.

headline: Words Fortified With Movement, and the Narratives They Push Ahead
text: Steady rain on Thursday did little to dampen the sheer forcefulness of two artists as they strove to get their messages across at Lincoln Center Out of Doors. Both works had as much to do with social issues as with artistic ones, and certain heavy-handed leanings were their downfalls.

headline: Snapshots From a Saint’s Fervid Gallop to Martyrdom
text: SALZBURG, Austria — It always takes some mental adjustment to go from the Bayreuth Festival in Germany to the Salzburg Festival here, as I did on Thursday. Unless you are a resident of Bayreuth or a student at its university, there is only one reason for an outsider to visit that sleepy city: the Wagner festival. There are amenities for visitors but not much else to do.

headline: Postal Service Confirms Photographing All U.S. Mail
text: WASHINGTON — The Postal Service on Friday confirmed that it takes a photograph of every letter and package mailed in the United States — about 160 billion pieces last year — and occasionally provides the photos to law enforcement agencies that request them as part of criminal cases.

headline: Egypt General Has Country Wondering About Aims
text: CAIRO — When Egypt’s first elected president, Mohamed Morsi, promoted Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi to defense minister nearly a year ago, sweeping away an aging cadre of generals, many saw it as a triumph for the Islamist president, and for a fledgling democracy.

headline: Fickle Nature, Taunting an Ensemble From the North
text: Last year, when Les Ballets Jazz de Montréal was scheduled to perform in New York, Hurricane Sandy intervened. That run was rescheduled and went off without meteorological incident. But when the company returned on Thursday for a Celebrate Brooklyn! show under the Prospect Park Bandshell, the heavens opened up again.

headline: Congress Passes First Significant Energy Legislation Since 2009
text: Congress is heading home for its August recess having passed the first significant energy legislation, aside from some tax changes, since 2009, after the Senate approved two bills on Thursday that clear the way for faster licensing of hydroelectric projects.

headline: Surprise at TV Critics’ Gathering: DeGeneres Is to Host the Oscars
text: LOS ANGELES — The producers of the Academy Awards telecast announced on Friday that they were going back to a prominent television star, Ellen DeGeneres, to host the movie industry’s biggest event, the annual Oscar ceremony.

headline: Report Paints Dire Picture in Honduran Prison Fire
text: MEXICO CITY — The fire that killed 362 people in a Honduran prison last year started accidentally in an upper bunk in one cell and rapidly spread through locked gates and past frightened police guards, according to a report released Friday by the Organization of American States.

headline: Ronnie Cutrone, a Man of Another, Cooler City
text: When the artist Ronnie Cutrone died late last month, at 65 and apparently of natural causes, a quirky and marginal figure slipped off the cultural stage, taking with him a large and vital hunk of late-20th-century New York history.

headline: Yesterday’s Style, Today’s Hits
text: We first met Robin Thicke about a decade ago, zipping through the streets of Manhattan on a bicycle in his debut video, Jesus mane flowing behind him, then doing some sub-“Saturday Night Fever” moves in a freight elevator. The song was “When I Get You Alone,” and it sampled Walter Murphy’s “Fifth of Beethoven,” the 1976 disco-classical fusion, a hybrid of flash and seriousness that Mr. Thicke appeared perfectly comfortable with, even if few others were: wildly out of step with the sound of the time, his single never hit the American charts.

headline: Singer Files Suit Against Met Opera Over Fall
text: Updated, Aug. 5 | Wendy White, the Metropolitan Opera mezzo-soprano who was hospitalized in December 2011 after an eight-foot fall when a piece of scenery broke during a performance, is suing the Met for damages as a result of the accident. The lawsuit was filed on Thursday, but the Met will not be served with papers until Monday, Ms. White’s lawyer, Martin Edelman, said on Friday afternoon.

headline: Pressed on Syria, Hezbollah Leader Urges Focus on Israel
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In a rare public appearance on Friday, Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, urged Arabs and Muslims to stay focused on opposing Israel despite bitter disagreements over the Syrian war, and declared that his Shiite followers would not bend in the face of rising anti-Shiite sentiment among those who oppose his support for the Syrian government.

headline: Chinese Journalist Detained in Beijing, One Day After Human Rights Talk With U.S.
text: BEIJING — A Chinese journalist who had pressed for the release of a prominent human rights activist was detained Friday, one day after the United States completed annual discussions with China on human rights.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Facebook at DefCon and Selling the Moto X With Innuendo
text: The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Here’s what they noticed today. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Letters: Bike Helmets, Please
text: Thanks for “My Mademoiselle Summer” by Meg Wolitzer (Sunday Styles, July 21). It brought me back 50 years to my days as a Mademoiselle guest editor in 1963. Her description of her time at the magazine rang true for me. To be sure, the June heat in the tiny rooms of the Barbizon Hotel for Women was grueling. But New York in 1963 seemed wondrous and innocent. Anything was possible. It was a blast. It was an honor. I made lifelong friends.

headline: The New York Times Editorial Board
text: The editorial board is composed of journalists with wide-ranging areas of expertise. Their primary responsibility is to write The Times’s editorials, which represent the voice of the board, its editor and the publisher. The board is part of the Times’s Opinion department, which is operated separately from the Times newsroom, and includes the Letters to the Editor and Op-Ed sections.

headline: Nickelodeon on the Mend, Profit Soars at Viacom
text: Nickelodeon’s resurgence and a new online streaming deal with Amazon contributed to a 20 percent increase in profits at Viacom in its latest financial quarter of the year, the company said on Friday.

headline: Bank of New York Mellon Wins Sex Bias Case
text: A federal jury in New York decided on Friday that a woman who was one of 11 people in her division at Bank of New York Mellon laid off in 2010 was not a victim of sex discrimination. The case was unusual in that it even went to trial.

headline: An Avid Reader Scribbles a Wardrobe
text: Jennifer Weiner, 43, has written many a best-selling beach read. She lives in Philadelphia with her two daughters.

headline: In Mandela Legacy, a Place for Winnie?
text: SOWETO, South Africa — WHEN Winnie Madikizela-Mandela stepped out in late June onto the porch of the home here she once shared with Nelson Mandela, still looking as regal and outspoken as when she was known a quarter century ago as the “mother of the nation,” it was like a fiery echo of the past.

headline: Pulling Ahead
text: Sales of hybrid cars have steadily increased in recent years, but sales of electric cars and plug-in hybrids have been anemic by comparison.

headline: Pope Sends Message of Respect for Muslims
text: In a demonstration of what the Vatican spokesman called Pope Francis’ “particular attention to relations with the Muslim world,” the pope on Friday personally signed the Holy See message for Muslims at the end of Ramadan, calling for “mutual respect through education” between Christianity and Islam.

headline: The Week in Pictures, Aug. 2
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include hunting for treasure at Jones Beach, an interactive art show in a tunnel and mayoral candidates on the stump.

headline: Devil’s Head, Dead Chicken and a Swindle
text: In summer 1956, a bit of criminal history was made in a parlor on Madison Avenue, at precisely the moment when two women cracked open an egg and peered at its contents. There was no yolk, but instead, something sinister: a tiny head, with horns, eyebrows and a black goatee.

headline: The Bullpen Takes a Hit
text: The Mets’ bullpen was shaken up Friday before the club began its three-game series against the Kansas City Royals.

headline: Mexico: Blast Caused by Methane Gas, Report Says
text: The Mexican attorney general’s office said Friday that methane gas combined with vapors emitted by solvents caused the deadly explosion at the headquarters of Mexico’s state-owned oil monopoly, Petróleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, on Jan. 31. The basement blast killed 37 people and injured more than 120 others. In a statement summarizing the results of its investigation, the attorney general’s office said that hydrocarbons that had leaked into the ground decades before the building was constructed had contributed to the buildup of methane gas and that an electrical spark had probably ignited the combustible mix. Pemex is suffering from declining production and has long had a poor safety record. President Enrique Peña Nieto has said he hopes to win approval from Mexico’s Congress to open up the company to private investment before the end of the year.

headline: Repairs to a Storm-Damaged Tunnel Will Disrupt R Line Service for a Year
text: Extensive repair work on a subway tunnel connecting Brooklyn and Manhattan is scheduled to start this weekend, making many R train riders adjust their commutes for more than a year.

headline: Spain: Alarms Warned Train’s Driver Before Accident
text: At least three alarms went off inside the train that crashed last week in northwestern Spain moments before it derailed, prompting the panicked driver to activate the brakes three times even as he talked on the telephone with another employee, an examination of the train’s two black boxes released Friday revealed. The driver, Francisco José Garzón Amo, had answered a ticket inspector’s call on his cellphone and was traveling at a permitted speed of 199 kilometers per hour, or 123 miles per hour, before the train switched to another track in a reduced-speed zone. During the call, an alarm went off in the driver’s cabin. The black boxes recorded Mr. Garzón screaming as he tried to activate the brake. The train’s speed dropped to 195 k.p.h., or 121 m.p.h., but another alarm sounded, 500 yards from the curve where the accident took place. Mr. Garzón activated an emergency brake three seconds later. A third alarm sounded, and 13 train cars started derailing. Mr. Garzón activated another emergency brake as the train careened from the tracks and then slammed into a wall at 153 k.p.h., or 95 m.p.h., nearly twice the speed limit. Mr. Garzón was arrested last week and charged with reckless homicide in the deaths of 79 people.

headline: The Decline of the Prison Population
text: To the Editor:

headline: Personal Trainers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Missile Defense Tests
text: To the Editor:

headline: Engineering Degrees
text: To the Editor:

headline: Clearing the Docket
In Mali, a Race Between a Former Finance Minister and a Pro-French Favorite
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Two veteran politicians will face each other in a runoff this month in the second round of Mali’s presidential election, the country’s interim government announced Friday. It was another sign that Mali, a troubled West African nation, could be returning to normalcy after more than a year of armed turmoil.

headline: Civilian Afghan Casualties
text: To the Editor:

headline: Berlusconi’s Followers Threaten Fragile Truce in Italy
text: ROME — Lawmakers from former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s political party said Friday that they were prepared to resign en masse to protest Mr. Berlusconi’s definitive conviction for tax fraud, a move that would effectively sink the uneasy alliance supporting the government.

headline: A Hankering for Hybrids
text: DETROIT — When automakers rolled out their new electric cars three years ago, they had big plans. Even President Obama, in his State of the Union address in 2011, predicted there would be as many as a million of them on the nation’s roads by the middle of the decade.

headline: Amid Political Fight, Confusion and Fear About New York’s Health Exchange
text: Fear and confusion seized Dolores Persky in July when she received a letter announcing that Healthy NY, a state-subsidized program of private insurance that covers her family and 90,000 other New Yorkers, would end Dec. 31. They can seek other options for affordable coverage on the New York Health Benefit Exchange under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act starting Oct. 1, the letter from her insurer explained.

headline: Appalachian Hope and Heartbreak
text: BIG STONE GAP, Va. — A PERSON just passing through Big Stone Gap may not notice the corner drugstore on Wood Avenue with the fading sign, its windows dark and hollow like so many others in these rural coal towns. But for people who live here in the heart of central Appalachia, the Mutual Drug Cafeteria was a community hub, an extension of the family kitchen. It’s where residents could fill a prescription, pick up an oil lamp or a strawberry huller, find a plastic pirate sword for the school play and get a good cup of coffee with a plate of pork chops, soup beans, pickled beets and blackberry cobbler.

headline: At Christian Companies, Religious Principles Complement Business Practices
text: In June, a federal court ruled that Hobby Lobby, the art-supply chain, could not be fined for refusing to offer its employees morning-after contraception coverage. This challenge to the Affordable Care Act will surely go to the Supreme Court, where Hobby Lobby’s lawyers will argue that a commercial company can, legally speaking, be Christian — with the same rights to religious freedom that a person has.

headline: Once ‘Dark and Dank,’ a Lincoln Center Space Honors Its One-Millionth Visitor
text: The scene unfolded like the opening moments of the old quiz show “This Is Your Life,” which sprang a jaw-dropping surprise on someone who did not see it coming.

headline: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Is Charged In Plot to Sell Documents
text: A former F.B.I. special agent has been accused of conspiring to sell confidential bureau documents to a Bangladeshi man who was seeking to harm the reputation of a political rival in his native country, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: No Mincing of Words for a Coaching Titan
text: Bill Parcells will be inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame on Saturday, prompting some recollections of his wandering and winning journey as coach of the Giants, the Patriots, the Jets and the Cowboys over more than two decades.

headline: Justices Rule California Must Free Some Inmates
text: LOS ANGELES — The United States Supreme Court on Friday rejected California’s attempt to stop the release of nearly 10,000 inmates from state prisons to relieve overcrowding, dealing a blow to Gov. Jerry Brown’s efforts to fight federal court orders to reduce the prison population.

headline: U.S. Cuts Take Increasing Toll on Job Growth
text: WASHINGTON — The number of federal workers forced to work shorter hours soared this summer — to 199,000 in July, from 55,000 a year earlier — in a sign of the problems that federal budget policy is causing for the economy.

headline: Egypt Says It May Shut Entrances to Camps
text: CAIRO — The Egyptian government threatened on Saturday to block the entrances to a large protest camp where supporters of Mohamed Morsi, the ousted president, have been calling for his return as the Obama administration sought help from Persian Gulf nations to help end Egypt’s political crisis.

headline: Stephen Foster, the Wildebeest and Me
text: The difference between the way a swarm or herd moves and the way, say, a crowd of panicked people disperses is this: individuals in a swarming herd have no need to understand why they’re running before they run. Each creature in the herd reacts to the movements of her immediate neighbors so that when one caribou tenses because she sees a wolf on the ridge, a ripple of tensing muscles travels through the herd, one caribou at a time, at lightning speed. They are all running before most of them have considered why they’re moving or where they’re going. This mad dashing makes for quick escapes, but it has drawbacks. The wildebeest herds sometimes gallop straight off a cliff and hundreds are dead before they can manage to come to a stop.

headline: Open Season on History
text: CHESTER, Va. — FOR archaeologists like me, the Flowerdew Hundred Plantation near Williamsburg, Va., is our Woodstock, a sentimental spot where dozens of professionals earned their trowels. The farm’s incredible archaeological wealth ranges from 12,000-year-old Native American tools to a tree that shaded Union soldiers in June 1864.

headline: A Robber Put Her Bird in Someone Else’s Hand
text: Ana Marte loves Cuca.

headline: Qaeda Messages Prompt U.S. Terror Warning
text: WASHINGTON — The United States intercepted electronic communications this week among senior operatives of Al Qaeda, in which the terrorists discussed attacks against American interests in the Middle East and North Africa, American officials said Friday.

headline: Group Rooted in the Desert Looks Out for Migrants
text: ARIVACA, Ariz. — Monsoon rains tinge the desert with deceptive hints of green at this time of the year, but migrants crossing illegally from Mexico continue to risk death from thirst and exposure in the blazing heat. A fortunate few who become lost might stumble upon lifesaving gallon jugs of drinking water, scattered by a band of volunteers along makeshift footpaths that have been carved through the mountains and washes.

headline: In Complex Trading Case, Jurors Focused on Greed
text: When nine New York residents shuffled into a cramped jury room in the federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan on Wednesday, they were divided over Fabrice Tourre’s culpability in a toxic mortgage deal sold to investors.

headline: The Girls of Summer
text: Congress, like France, does not believe anybody should have to work during August. However, to be fair, the French feel compelled to do some stuff during the other 11 months.

headline: Despite Administration Promises, Few Signs of Change in Drone Wars
text: WASHINGTON — There were more drone strikes in Pakistan last month than any month since January. Three missile strikes were carried out in Yemen in the last week alone. And after Secretary of State John Kerry told Pakistanis on Thursday that the United States was winding down the drone wars there, officials back in Washington quickly contradicted him.

headline: Shh! Senate at Work on a National Secret.
text: Leaders of the Senate Finance Committee are trying to tackle the explosive issue of tax reform by offering an extraordinary guarantee of 50 years of anonymity to lawmakers skittish about publicly presenting candid views on which tax credits and deductions deserve to be dropped or altered in a new code. The fear is palpable among senators that disclosing even their thoughts on the subject could damage careers if power lobbyists and angry constituents were to get early wind via Washington’s relentless leak machine.

headline: Rodriguez Plays, but Return May Be Brief
text: TRENTON — At a news conference after a minor league rehabilitation game Friday night, Alex Rodriguez was peppered with questions about allegations that he was involved with Biogenesis, a now-defunct South Florida clinic accused of issuing performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Contraception and Corporations
text: At least three dozen lawsuits have been filed by private businesses challenging, on religious grounds, the new health care law’s requirement that most company health plans provide no-cost coverage of contraceptives. The lawsuits share a basic flaw: Profit-making corporations are not human beings capable of engaging in religious exercise to begin with.

headline: A Place to Go Outside, but Not Look Down
text: Clifford Milo’s balcony is small and clings to the side of his building’s ninth floor like a half-formed appendage, but he would not trade it for the world.

headline: A Race Like No Other
text: To grasp the strangeness of the modern America’s Cup, once the world’s premier sailing competition, it is helpful to imagine a Kentucky Derby that occurs not annually but intermittently and involves different ridable quadrupeds — horses, zebras, camels, elephants — each time the event occurs. The winners choose the venue of the next race, and there are, inevitably, legal challenges of one sort or another along the way. Then the race is run, and the process begins all over again.

headline: Clouds Spread to Democratic Side of Virginia Governor’s Race
text: For months, the governor’s race in Virginia has unfolded beneath a cloud of scandal over the Republican incumbent that spread to his would-be Republican successor, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Fernando Alonso, a Founder of Cuban Ballet, Dies at 98
text: Fernando Alonso, a Cuban ballet master and teacher who teamed with his brother and his wife at the time, the ballet star Alicia Alonso, to found a dance company that gained international renown as the Ballet Nacional de Cuba, died on July 27 in Havana. He was 98.

headline: A Star Philosopher Falls, and a Debate Over Sexism Is Set Off
text: Ever since Socrates’ wife was painted as a jealous shrew by one of his pupils, women have had it tough in philosophy.

headline: The Right Leader for the Fed
text: Let me start by getting the disclosure stuff out of the way. I’ve known Larry Summers for 20 years and have watched with particular interest as his multifaceted career has unfolded. More recently, I worked for him in the Obama administration, when he was director of the National Economic Council and I was the lead adviser on the auto bailout.

headline: Michael Ansara, Actor Who Played Cochise and Kang, Dies at 91
text: Michael Ansara, a busy and widely recognizable character actor who was best known for portraying American Indians and later a Klingon in three different “Star Trek” series, died on Wednesday at his home in Calabasas, Calif. He was 91.

headline: Leighton Gage, Crime Novelist, Dies at 71
text: Leighton Gage, a former advertising man from New Jersey who found a second career writing crime novels about a Brazilian police detective, died on July 26 at his home in Ocala, Fla. He was 71.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 3, 2013
text: “At a time of mass unemployment, it’s clear, the economics textbooks tell us, that this is not the right time for fiscal retrenchment. To watch it be ignored like this is exasperating, horrifying, disheartening.”

headline: Corrections: August 3, 2013
text: NATIONAL

headline: Transported
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, they’ve gone and done it. It was just a matter of time.

headline: Marriage and Minorities
text: We often hear that marriage is a panacea for our problems — as a nation as a whole, and especially for the black community, in which more than 70 percent of children are now born to unmarried women.

headline: Cory Booker for Senator
text: Voters in the Democratic primary in New Jersey on Aug. 13 for the United States Senate are lucky to have a choice among four candidates with solid credentials: two with experience in Congress and good voting records; one who has worked hard at the state level on women’s issues, in particular; and one who made a national name for himself by bringing new thinking, honesty and compassion to the hidebound, corrupt and cold city government in Newark.

headline: Colorado Presses for Uninsured to Enroll
text: DENVER — Television commercials have already run suggesting that buying health coverage through the state’s new insurance market, Connect for Health Colorado, will feel like winning the World Series.

headline: Missouri Citizens Face Obstacles to Coverage
text: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. — Looking for the new health insurance marketplace, set to open in this state in two months, is like searching for a unicorn.

headline: Gene Wettstone, Record-Setting Gymnastics Coach, Dies at 100
text: Gene Wettstone, a gymnastics coach who led Penn State University to a record nine N.C.A.A. championships in the sport, coached the United States men’s teams in the 1948 and 1956 Olympic Games and successfully promoted gymnastics on a campus better known for football, died on Tuesday in State College, Pa. He was 100.

headline: Charitable Giving, More or Less
text: William C. Thompson Jr. has earned a dubious distinction in the Democratic mayoral race: earning the most money while donating the least.

headline: A Seaver Bobblehead Sure, but One for Horwitz?
text: The 2013 season has been a busy one for Jay Horwitz, the Mets’ public relations man: he joined Twitter this past winter, showcased some erratic dance moves for the club’s Harlem Shake video, and, now, he will get his own bobblehead doll.

headline: Michigan: Another Hearing on the Detroit Bankruptcy
text: The City of Detroit expects to file a plan to adjust its debts by year’s end, a lawyer said Friday during a bankruptcy hearing. And a retiree committee will represent city retirees in bankruptcy proceedings, Judge Stephen Rhodes of Federal Bankruptcy Court ruled. But the judge said that it would be up to federal trustee officials to decide who will serve on the committee and to establish deadlines. The hearing touched on a litany of preliminary issues leading up to what is expected to be a long fight over the city’s eligibility to file for bankruptcy. Those hearings will begin Oct. 23 amid concerns that bankruptcy could lead to diminished pension benefits for more than 23,000 retirees.

headline: Catching Up on Jobs
text: The United States economy added a disappointing 162,000 jobs in July. The question is, does that put us any closer to economic recovery?

headline: Granderson in Lineup, but Rodriguez Is Focus
text: SAN DIEGO — Curtis Granderson was back in the Yankees’ lineup Friday, an important addition for their sluggish offense. But coming at a time of acute interest and speculation surrounding the fate of his teammate Alex Rodriguez, Granderson’s arrival was equally important for the insight he could provide in that regard.

headline: Group Helps Migrants Near the Border
text: Volunteers with No More Deaths camp 10 miles from the border with Mexico, aiming to prevent deaths in the harsh desert landscape.

headline: Mets’ Win Is Overshadowed by Loss of Wright
text: From start to finish, it was an unsettling Friday for the Mets.

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) CHASING MAVERICKS (2012) Rick Hesson (Gerard Butler), a surfer in Santa Cruz nicknamed Frosty, teaches Jay Moriarity (Jonny Weston, above right, with Mr. Butler), a legend-in-the-making with a dream and a battered board, the way of the waves — specifically, the monster crushers in Northern California on a break known as Mavericks. Curtis Hanson and Michael Apted shared the directing duties on this film, based on a true story that begins in 1987 and is lent authenticity by the real-life surfers Greg Long, Peter Mel and Zach Wormhoudt. “When the movie works, its buoyancy can be infectious and persuasive, particularly in the surfing scenes and in the mesmerizing shots of the heaving, churning ocean and waves,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York York Times. “The movie captures the hypnotic quality of this watery landscape, with its steel blue undulations and the Freudian oceanic feeling it summons. It invites you to gaze into this watery abyss, to ponder its mysteries as well as those of the swimmer whose image brackets the movie and evokes John F. Kennedy’s observation: ‘We are tied to the ocean. And when we go back to the sea, whether it is to sail or to watch, we are going back from whence we came.’ ”

headline: Sabathia’s Woes Continue as Yankees Struggle to Find Groove
text: SAN DIEGO — One by one they are returning, nursed to health and thrust into the lineup, hoping to resuscitate a sagging offense and flagging playoff hopes, all the while hoping their bodies can remain intact.

headline: Botulism Threat Found in Infant Formula Ingredients
text: HONG KONG — One of the world’s leading suppliers of dairy products said Saturday that a type of bacteria that could cause botulism had been found in tests of ingredients the company sells for use in infant formula and sports drinks, leading New Zealand officials to urge a recall.

headline: New York Times Company Sells Boston Globe
text: The New York Times Company, in its latest move to shed assets and focus more on its core brand, has agreed to sell The Boston Globe and its other New England media properties to John W. Henry, principal owner of the Boston Red Sox.

headline: Afghan Militants Kill 9 Near Indian Consulate
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Armed with assault rifles and an explosives-laden vehicle, three men tried to attack an Indian consulate in eastern Afghanistan on Saturday, killing at least nine people and offering a brutal reminder that tensions beyond this country’s borders threaten to fuel the conflict here long after the United States and its allies depart.

headline: The Secret Life of Business Class Seats
text: Jad Mouawad visits B/E Aerospace to see the technology behind business class seats.

headline: The Race to Build a Better Business Class
text: IN a confidential test lab in a remote office park near the Frankfurt airport, a small Lufthansa team holed up for five years, refining one of the German airline’s most closely guarded secrets. They called it the V concept.

headline: Vows: Erin and Ben
text: Erin Duggan took a spontaneous sailing trip and found Ben Kramer, a sailing instructor who was living on an island where she docked.

headline: A Camp That’s Easy as …
text: Two trends — learning vacations and nostalgia for good old-fashioned Americana — come together at one resort this fall. Paws Up in western Montana is kicking off its first pie camp Oct. 11 to Oct. 14.

headline: Chronicle of an Impasse Foretold
text: The big if hard-to-report story in DC last week was the ongoing collapse in governance, as Republicans proved themselves unable to reconcile their ideological commitment to drastically lower government spending with the reality that they and their constituents actually benefit from said spending. They’re willing to impose savage cuts on the poor — but even that gets them nothing like the spending cuts they claim they’ll make. Yet rather than acknowledge this reality, they’re basically sticking their heads in the sand. As the Times puts it:

headline: Remembering the Wrongness
text: I harp a lot in this blog on the wrongness of the inflation-and-soaring rates crowd — and I do so with a purpose. The reason Very Serious People have so much damaging influence is that they come across as, well, Very Serious; yet they have in fact been not just wrong but ludicrously so, and pointing that out, repeatedly, is one way to help get our economic conversation back on track.

headline: At 29, With Fifth Team, Jets Receiver Hoping Finally to Stick
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. — Scroll down the Jets’ training camp roster, past the players with the recognizable names. Past Mark Sanchez. Past Geno Smith. Past Antonio Cromartie and D’Brickashaw Ferguson and Nick Mangold, until there, a few rows from the bottom, is No. 86.

headline: Path to N.F.L. Winds Through Rink for Giants’ Rookie Running Back
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — How do you become an N.F.L. draft pick?

headline: 2 Years After 116 Police Bullets Flew, Few Answers
text: MIAMI BEACH — The last 90 seconds of Raymond Herisse’s life unfold on YouTube with chilling clarity.

headline: Choosing to Remember Rodriguez as an 18-Year-Old
text: In the summer of 1994, I was the clubhouse manager for the Peoria Chiefs, a job that entailed washing hundreds of dirty uniforms, setting out pregame meals and vacuuming copious amounts of chewed-up sunflower seeds out of the carpeting, all for about 40 cents an hour. Best job ever. I was paid to come to the ballpark every day, where I shagged balls in batting practice and traded obscenity-laced barbs with Jimmy Piersall.

headline: To All Surfing Enthusiasts, There Are Online Fantasy Leagues for You, Too
text: One of the most surprising aspects of fantasy surfing is there really is such a thing.

headline: Somalis Face a Snag in Lifelines From Abroad
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Compared with the trillions of dollars flowing through the international financial system every day, the estimated $1.3 billion sent each year from small storefronts in Somali neighborhoods in places like London and Minneapolis to families back home in the Horn of Africa is a mere droplet.

headline: Veteran Pitcher, in First Year With Royals, Nudges Them to Milestone
text: The Kansas City Royals had just lost a game at Yankee Stadium last month, and their bus filled up fast. James Shields, the veteran starter, could not find a seat. He could have pulled rank and bumped a rookie or a staff member, but instead he sat on the steps, near the driver, and grabbed the microphone.

headline: Betrayed by Braun, Brewers Owner Twists in an Ill Wind
text: Mark Attanasio was at a meeting in Los Angeles last month, on a video conference for his investment business, when Ryan Braun called his cellphone.

headline: Omission of Bengals’ Riley From Hall of Fame Is a Striking Oversight
text: When the City Commission of Bartow, Fla., held its regular meeting March 18, it filled a vacancy on the beautification advisory board, issued a proclamation endorsing Great American Cleanup Day and heard a resident’s complaint about his utility bill. Then, in its final order of business, the five commissioners voted unanimously to issue a municipal resolution supporting Ken Riley, one of Bartow’s own, for induction to the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

headline: Letters to the Sports Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Final Test for U.S. Solheim Cup Qualifying
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — Morgan Pressel stopped in the middle of an interview Friday to admire a reporter’s sequined sneakers. Pressel is as keen on fashion as she is on golf, and with career earnings of nearly $5 million, she can indulge in almost any wardrobe item her heart desires.

headline: Variety: Where Debs Sleep
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Well, of course I sleep in a bed. Moving right along.

headline: Jamaica Focuses on Farming
text: The country has taken on a bold new strategy in the face of expensive food imports: make farming patriotic and ubiquitous.

headline: As Cost of Importing Food Soars, Jamaica Turns to the Earth
text: KINGSTON, Jamaica — The scent of coconut oil and fiery jerk spice blows through kitchens across this green island, but as the country’s food imports have become a billion-dollar threat to finances and health, Jamaica has taken on a bold new strategy: make farming patriotic and ubiquitous, behind homes, hospitals, schools, even prisons.

headline: Interpol Asks Nations to Help Track Terror Suspects Freed in Prison Breaks
text: WASHINGTON — Interpol issued a global alert on Saturday asking member countries to help track hundreds of terrorism suspects who escaped in a wave of prison breaks over the past month — including in Iraq, Pakistan and Libya — and requesting assistance in determining whether any of the operations “are coordinated or linked.”

headline: Tunisian Islamist Finds Hope in Challenging Time
text: TUNIS — In the tense weeks before the military took power in Egypt, the leader of Tunisia’s dominant Islamic party says, he tried to mediate between President Mohamed Morsi and his opponents in a last-ditch effort to salvage the region’s most important test of whether Islamist instincts could be reconciled with democracy.

headline: When Politics Catches Up With ‘Portnoy’
text: THE plots and details seem lifted from Philip Roth or the early work of Woody Allen. Anthony D. Weiner, the Brooklyn bar mitzvah boy and would-be mayor whose intimate anatomy has now become a matter of public broadcast. Bob Filner, proud son of Forest Hills, Queens, whose California dream of a life — history professor, congressman, San Diego mayor — was undone by so much alleged lechery that the city he governed established a hot line for victims.

headline: Aug. 3: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Rearranging the Furniture in Business Class
text: Depending on the types of aircraft they fly, airlines can customize cabin layouts differently.

headline: The $4,000 Deal Gone Sour Behind the Doping Scandal
text: In October, Anthony P. Bosch, a troubled businessman who had a permanent suntan and a white lab coat with his name embroidered on it — though he had no medical license — clashed with an investor in his small anti-aging clinic in Coral Gables, Fla.

headline: An Involuntary Union of Football Rivals for Philadelphia High Schools
text: PHILADELPHIA — The football players at Martin Luther King High School gathered in a semicircle like a tired and rain-soaked choir. They placed their arms around one another’s shoulders and began swaying to a call and response.

headline: In Need of a New Hip, but Priced Out of the U.S.
text: WARSAW, Ind. — Michael Shopenn’s artificial hip was made by a company based in this remote town, a global center of joint manufacturing. But he had to fly to Europe to have it installed.

headline: Mets Place Wright on Disabled List
text: The Mets placed third baseman David Wright on the 15-day disabled list Saturday morning after a magnetic resonance imaging test revealed a Grade 2 strain in his right hamstring that they expect will sideline him for two to four weeks.

headline: A Great Manager Should Expect a Peaceful Vacation
text: This interview with Christopher J. Williams, C.E.O. of the Williams Capital Group, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Mugabe Wins Again in Zimbabwe, Leaving Rival Greatly Weakened
text: HARARE, Zimbabwe — President Robert Mugabe, who has led Zimbabwe since it threw off white rule in 1980, won another term on Saturday as the official results were announced for last week’s hotly disputed election, defeating his main challenger with 61 percent of the vote and roaring back to secure his grip on power after having to share it for the past five years.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Can Suburbs Help Cities?
text: Readers discuss taking a regional approach to reviving Detroit.

headline: Elastic Numbers Make It Hard to Get a Handle on the Economy
text: A TORRENT of economic numbers rained down from Washington last week. They provided a sharper historical perspective on the economy back to 1929.

headline: Clawbacks in Word, Not Deed
text: WHAT good is a policy if it’s never enforced?

headline: Misery Goes Digital
text: In the evenings, the lowest and busiest level of Penn Station, the Long Island Rail Road concourse, becomes an earthly purgatory, where tens of thousands of souls wait quietly for deliverance to arrive, in the form of a train matched to a track number.

headline: Shark Fins or Champagne?
text: The sign at Chung Chou City in Manhattan’s Chinatown says “shark fin clearance” in bold Chinese characters. Nearby, in glass jars that are slightly out of reach, 10-inch fins go for $488 a pound, down from $580. For 13-inch fins, the price is now $638 a pound. Like other shops and restaurants in the city’s Chinese communities, this store is selling off its stock of shark fins.

headline: Of Courage and Cantaloupes
text: After the Senate passed a comprehensive immigration bill in June, hope for reform shifted to the House. That is where hope sits, on ice, getting freezer burn.

headline: Structural Humbug
text: OK, this is really depressing. The PBS Newshour isn’t always a good place to get the best analysis, but it’s a terrific place to take the pulse of Washington conventional wisdom — and as Dean Baker notes, that conventional wisdom has clearly swung to the view that our high unemployment is “structural”, not something that could be solved simply by boosting demand.

headline: Return of the Jesus Wars
text: BEFORE “The Da Vinci Code” and “The Gospel of Judas,” before Mel Gibson’s “Passion” and Martin Scorsese’s “Last Temptation,” before the Dead Sea Scrolls were unearthed and the Gnostic gospels rediscovered, there was a German scholar named Hermann Samuel Reimarus.

headline: Addicted to Prayer
text: AS evidence accumulates about the many health benefits of religious practice, prayer is looking better and better. Some atheists have even gone public with their own prayer-for-health’s-sake practice.

headline: Robert Mankoff
text: Robert Mankoff is a cartoonist and the cartoon editor for The New Yorker.

headline: The Trauma of Being Alive
text: TALKING with my 88-year-old mother, four and a half years after my father died from a brain tumor, I was surprised to hear her questioning herself. “You’d think I would be over it by now,” she said, speaking of the pain of losing my father, her husband of almost 60 years. “It’s been more than four years, and I’m still upset.”

headline: Who’s That Candidate in the Teal Toenail Polish?
text: A WELL-DRESSED man at the West 72nd Street subway entrance stopped to take one of the fliers that Christine Quinn was handing out.

headline: How to Whitewash a Plague
text: THE New-York Historical Society’s current exhibition “AIDS in New York: The First Five Years” accomplishes a neat trick: it takes a black mark in New York City’s history — its homophobic, apathetic response to the early days of AIDS in the early 1980s — and transforms it into a moment of civic pride, when New Yorkers of all stripes came together to fight the disease. It’s a lovely story, if only it were true.

headline: The Woman Who Ate Cutlery
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — M is a 33-year old woman who swallowed silverware. She wasn’t psychotic, or out of touch with reality. She knew it was not a good idea to swallow forks and knives and she wasn’t trying to kill herself. In fact, each time she ingested utensils, she went to the emergency room so that doctors could remove them from her esophagus and stomach. Then the hospital transferred M to the psychiatric unit, where she was assigned to my care.

headline: The Freak Show as Fable
text: ONE young staffer on Anthony Weiner’s mayoral campaign saw a chance at bright lights and went after it, spilling secrets in return for a glamour shot on the front page of a major newspaper, determining that attention was worth whatever crassness it called for.

headline: I Am TOM. I Like to TYPE. Hear That?
text: BECAUSE Mike McAlary started reporting on cops for the New York tabloids in 1985, Nora Ephron’s play “Lucky Guy,” which recently completed its run, featured word processors on the newsroom desks rather than typewriters. Too bad. We in the ensemble would have loved to pound on bulky desk-crowding typewriters for the sound alone.

headline: A Washington Riddle: What Is ‘Top Secret’?
text: WASHINGTON — LESS than 24 hours after Pfc. Bradley Manning was convicted last week of handing off 250,000 State Department cables and defense documents to WikiLeaks, The Guardian published on its Web site the latest classified material from the leaker of the moment, Edward J. Snowden. That installment included the National Security Agency’s playbook for XKeyscore, a powerful surveillance program enabling the agency’s analysts to monitor and trace Internet searches around the globe.

headline: Crumbling American Dreams
text: My hometown — Port Clinton, Ohio, population 6,050 — was in the 1950s a passable embodiment of the American dream, a place that offered decent opportunity for the children of bankers and factory workers alike.

headline: The DNA of Helping People
text: I GREW up in a suburb of Chicago and attended a predominantly white high school. We were at the tail end of the civil rights movement but I never experienced any unrest. However, my parents were not as lucky. When I was in elementary school, my mother came home early one day from her job at a manufacturing company. She said the Ku Klux Klan was meeting in the company cafeteria at 4 p.m. and that there was actually a meeting notice on a bulletin board.

headline: Older, Unemployed, and Landing the Job
text: I WAS laid off four times in my career before I turned 50. But when it happened again two years ago, I had just turned 59. Getting laid off at that age is a different ballgame. I knew I could bring value to a company, but in moments of frustration during the job hunt, I wondered how long it would take to find another job, and there was always the chance I wouldn’t be able to find one.

headline: Public Pensions After Detroit
text: Detroit’s bankruptcy and the problems facing its pension funds offer two important lessons to other communities. One is that state and local governments need to do a much better job managing retirement funds. The other is that they should not pre-emptively reduce hard-earned benefits at the first sign of trouble.

headline: Republican No-Shows in the Budget Wars
text: Amid the morass of Washington’s endless budget fights there was a moment of sweet revelation last week: House Republicans choked outright when they failed to muster support for the draconian dreams of Paul Ryan, the Wisconsin legislator and fabled budget hawk who last year ran for vice president on a program of unforgiving fiscal austerity that his colleagues suddenly found too politically risky.

headline: What the Nation Got for $800 Billion
text: SINCE last September, when the Federal Reserve announced its third round of quantitative easing, known as QE3, the central bank has spent $800 billion buying bonds. That’s a stupendous sum, more than the budget for the Department of Defense and more than twice what the federal government spends on welfare programs, including food and nutrition assistance, unemployment benefits and disability payments.

headline: Writers as Architects
text: Great architects build structures that can make us feel enclosed, liberated or suspended. They lead us through space, make us slow down, speed up or stop to contemplate. Great writers, in devising their literary structures, do exactly the same.

headline: Iran’s President Puts New Focus on the Economy
text: TEHRAN — Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, vowed Saturday to work with the outside world to lift the “oppressive sanctions” crippling the Iranian economy, as he received the official backing of Ayatollah Ali Khamenei at a ceremony marking the start of his presidential term.

headline: For Obamacare to Work, Everyone Must Be In
text: TWO beliefs continue to shape debate on Obamacare. First, pre-existing medical conditions shouldn’t prevent people from obtaining affordable health insurance. And second, people who don’t want health insurance shouldn’t be forced by the government to purchase it.

headline: Life in a Toxic Country
text: BEIJING — I RECENTLY found myself hauling a bag filled with 12 boxes of milk powder and a cardboard container with two sets of air filters through San Francisco International Airport. I was heading to my home in Beijing at the end of a work trip, bringing back what have become two of the most sought-after items among parents here, and which were desperately needed in my own household.

headline: The Hipster Brewmeister of ... Beirut
text: LAST spring, at a public square in downtown Beirut, Lebanon, about 1,000 revelers attended a rock festival sponsored by 961 Beer, a very rare Middle East microbrewery. Acts included the Wanton Bishops, a band that would have been at home in Austin, Tex. In the front row were stylish women in sundresses beside men who showed a strong preference for black T-shirts and trendy eyewear.

headline: Helping Hollywood Players Hook Up
text: THE characters in an independent movie scheduled to begin filming this fall include a werewolf, a member of the band the Strokes and a cannibalistic yoga instructor. The plot? “It’s kind of a modern-day ‘Trainspotting’ set within a New York indie-rock backdrop,” says Noah C. Haeussner, the film’s producer and a senior vice president for financing and production at Union Entertainment Group.

headline: Obama Administration Overturns Ban on Apple Products
text: The Obama administration has vetoed a federal commission’s ban that would have forced Apple to stop selling some iPhones and iPads in the United States next week, a rare intervention by the White House and a victory for Apple in its heated patent war with Samsung Electronics.

headline: The Chatter for August 4, 2013
text: “We will continue to vigorously seek to hold accountable, and bring to trial when necessary, those who commit fraud on Wall Street.”

headline: Rodriguez Seeks Meetings With Baseball and Yankees
text: SAN DIEGO — Despite a combative stand Friday night that seemed to set him on a collision course with Major League Baseball over his impending suspension, Alex Rodriguez reached out to the commissioner’s office Saturday, through the players union, and also contacted the Yankees directly to seek a meeting, according to two people briefed on the matter who were granted anonymity because they were not permitted to speak about it publicly.

headline: Scandal in South Korea Over Nuclear Revelations
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Like Japan, resource-poor South Korea has long relied on nuclear power to provide the cheap electricity that helped build its miracle economy. For years, it met one-third of its electricity needs with nuclear power, similar to Japan’s level of dependence before the 2011 disaster at its Fukushima plant.

headline: Alex Rodriguez: A Continual Stir
text: Since Alex Rodriguez broke into the majors in 1996, he has been unable to escape the bizarre and controversial stories that seem to follow him on and off the field, the latest involving performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: The Hacking of Michael Pettis
text: Oh, wow. I mentioned a couple of weeks back that when I tried to get to Michael Pettis’s essential blog on Chinese economics, I ran into Viagra ads. At the time I found it funny; but I took another look today, and find Pettis reporting not just that he was hacked, but that it took place repeatedly, and that the blog is on hiatus while they rebuild.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 4
text: Congress left Washington this week as the national security community grappled with a new terror threat from Al Qaeda and the White House received news that Russia had granted temporary asylum to Edward Snowden. Sunday’s televisions talk shows examine the terror threat, Moscow-Washington relations, and lawmakers’ unfinished business on the economy, immigration and more.

headline: An Uneasy Football Merger
text: The nearly 100-year-old Germantown High School closed this year, leaving a community and its football team in flux.

headline: After Late Clutch Hit, Mets’ Bats Fall Silent in Extra Innings
text: Fresh off a plane from Nashville after playing a Class AAA game, outfielder Mike Baxter arrived in the Mets’ clubhouse early Saturday morning — an early indication of the severity of David Wright’s injury the night before.

headline: Should I Call the Repairman?
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Things break. Then, if the universe is kind to us, someone eventually shows up — usually on the least convenient day of the week, sometime between 12:00 p.m. and 5:00 p.m., sorry, we can only give you a window, not an exact time — and fixes them.

headline: Coin of Realm in China Graft: Phony Receipts
text: SHANGHAI — To begin to comprehend China’s vast underground economy, one need only visit this city’s major transportation depots and watch as peddlers openly hawk fake receipts.

headline: Why Must Voting Be So Hard?
text: If they really wanted you to vote, they would make it easy.

headline: Finally, Thousands of Old Rape-Evidence Kits Are to Be Tested
text: Thousands of evidence kits collected from rape victims that have sat untested for years in Texas can now be analyzed, thanks to an $11 million budget appropriation earmarked for the Texas Department of Public Safety.

headline: Thais Cast a Wide Net for Diverse Tourists
text: BANGKOK — Tolerance, the Thais have learned, is good for business.

headline: Abbott Faces Questions on Turnabout and Fair Play
text: When Greg Abbott’s spine was crushed by a falling oak tree in 1984, he had no health insurance and no paycheck. But he had a good lawyer and access to a civil justice system that — back then — was generally hospitable toward plaintiffs. So Mr. Abbott sued.

headline: A Day’s Toil in the Suicide Bombers’ Graveyard
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a city with no shortage of hard jobs, Khwaja Naqib Ahmad lays claim to one of the toughest of all — burying the unclaimed dead.

headline: Hotter Than Ever, a Texan’s Handmade Barbecue Pits
text: With the recent surge in barbecue’s popularity, the modern-day pit master is getting more attention than a grease fire in a barbecue pit. These smoked-meat craftsmen rely heavily on skill and experience, but their most important tool is a dependable pit.

headline: Pair’s Efforts Can’t Save U.S. From a Drubbing
text: China walked away with a one-sided victory over the United States last month at an event in Ningbo, China.

headline: Kongar-ol Ondar, a Master of a Vocal Art, Dies at 51
