text: Kongar-ol Ondar, an internationally renowned master of Tuvan throat singing, the Central Asian vocal art in which a singer produces two or more notes simultaneously — and which to the uninitiated sounds like the bewitching, remarkably harmonious marriage of a vacuum cleaner and a bumblebee — died on July 25 in Kyzyl, Tuva’s capital. He was 51.

headline: Richard S. Thomas, City Ballet Soloist and Teacher, Dies at 87
text: Richard S. Thomas, a prominent ballet teacher and a former soloist with the New York City Ballet, died on July 27 in a hospital near his home in Paintsville, Ky. He was 87.

headline: 16 Vying to Lead Troubled Detroit
text: DETROIT — There are 16 candidates here for a job that is difficult to imagine anyone wanting: mayor.

headline: Other Agencies Clamor for Data N.S.A. Compiles
text: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency’s dominant role as the nation’s spy warehouse has spurred frequent tensions and turf fights with other federal intelligence agencies that want to use its surveillance tools for their own investigations, officials say.

headline: Restraint Urged for Egypt’s Security Services
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s interim vice president said on Saturday that force could be used only as a last resort to disperse demonstrations held by supporters of Mohamed Morsi, who was deposed by the military a month ago.

headline: 16 Candidates Running for Mayor of Detroit
text: The 16 candidates running in the primary for mayor of Detroit:

headline: It’s Woods vs. Himself Entering Final Round at Bridgestone
text: AKRON, Ohio — Many story lines over the years have involved Tiger Woods versus someone, whether an individual or a collective.

headline: Newsweek, Sold in 2010, Is Changing Hands Again
text: Newsweek, the once venerable 80-year-old weekly magazine that suffered a precipitous decline in recent years, has been bought by the digital news company International Business Times for an undisclosed amount.

headline: Jeter, Still Hobbled, Returns to Bench as Yanks Use Caution
text: SAN DIEGO — Derek Jeter stood at his locker Friday night and insisted that he was healthy, that his legs — the left leg that had gone through a lengthy rehabilitation from a twice-broken ankle and the right one that sustained a quadriceps strain — were not bothering him.

headline: Red Sox Owner’s Purchase of Boston Globe Worries Journalists
text: BOSTON — As the list of potential purchasers of The Boston Globe leaked out, the newspaper’s longtime sportswriter and columnist Bob Ryan said his only thought was: please, let it be anyone but John Henry.

headline: First Ride: The Reborn 2014 Indian Motorcycles
text: The latest attempt to revive the historic Indian motorcycle brand was unveiled Saturday evening in Sturgis, S.D., where the massive annual biker rally was under way.

headline: Granderson Stands Tall for Yankees, but Jeter Has to Sit Out Again
text: SAN DIEGO — It was good to be back, Curtis Granderson had said the night before, even though he had gone through a hitless evening in his return from a second stint on the disabled list, visits that have cost him all but a handful of games this season.

headline: Car Drives Onto California Boardwalk, Injuring 12
text: A hit-and-run driver sped onto the crowded boardwalk at Los Angeles’s Venice Beach on Saturday evening, striking at least a dozen people and injuring two critically, before fleeing, Los Angeles Fire Department officials said.

headline: Reese Smith, Joby Earle
text: Charise Castro Smith and John Bryan Chamberlin Earle were married Saturday at Attic Studios, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. James Bundy, the dean of the Yale School of Drama who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Jillian Weinberger and Alex Levitov
text: Jillian Beth Weinberger and Alex Paul Levitov were married Saturday evening at the Tudor Arms Hotel in Cleveland. Rabbi Robert Nosanchuk officiated.

text: Kathryn Rose Critchell and Torren Jesse Haavik were married Wednesday on the Kohala Coast on the Big Island of Hawaii. The Rev. Dean Kauka, a minister of the United Church of Christ, led the nondenominational ceremony at the Fairmont Orchid Resort.

text: Nora Jane Lyons, a daughter of Nancy H. Lyons and Douglas B. Lyons of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married Saturday to Daniel James Fitchette, a son of Diane Skalny Campbell and Thomas A. Fitchette of Binghamton, N.Y. Melissa C. Jackson, an acting Supreme Court justice in Manhattan, officiated at Frankies 457, a restaurant in Brooklyn.

headline: Leigh McMullan, Adam Abramson
text: Leigh Fenwick McMullan, the daughter of Kate H. McMullan and James B. McMullan of Sag Harbor, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Adam Forrest Abramson, a son of Patricia P. Abramson and Alan B. Abramson of New York. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl officiated at Guastavino’s, an event space in New York

text: Bénédicte de Villardi de Montlaur and Keith David Yazmir were married Thursday at the town hall in Jaligny-sur-Besbre, France. Pierre-Henri Vinay, the mayor of the village, officiated.

text: Helen Olamipo Ogbara and Kevin Christopher Reeves were married Saturday evening at the Four Seasons Hotel in Miami. The Rev. Dr. Sydney S. Sadio, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

headline: Abby Himmelstein, Jordan Chalfin
text: Abby Rae Himmelstein and Jordan Bradley Chalfin were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Andrew Gordon at Cipriani 42nd Street in New York.

headline: Ji Shin and Brian Chen
text: Dr. Ji Young Shin and Brian Yuan Chen were married Saturday by the Rev. Daniel Mackle, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Patrick’s Church in Philadelphia.

text: Sara Catherine Hastings, a daughter of Arlen K. Hastings and Thomas E. Hastings of Princeton, N.J., was married there Saturday to Daniel Edwin Hayes-Patterson, a son of Priscilla E. Hayes and Peter D. Patterson of Robbinsville, N.J. Jessie L. Blum, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated at the Princeton University Chapel.

text: Dana Arielle Borowitz and Arthur Jacob Spector were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Alan Lurie at the C. V. Rich Mansion, a party space in White Plains.

text: Jolanta Agnieszka Bielat and Thomas Edgar Alberty were married Saturday at St. Joseph’s Parish in Central Falls, R.I. The Rev. Marek S. Kupka, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

text: Alexandra Emily Greif and Michael William Lewkonia are to be married Sunday at Highlands Country Club in Garrison, N.Y. Judge Kimba M. Wood of the Federal District Court in Manhattan is to officiate.

headline: Candice Plotkin, Ryan Taylor
text: Candice Nichole Plotkin, the daughter of Carol A. Plotkin and Martin Plotkin of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married Saturday evening to Ryan Douglas Taylor, the son of Lynda D. Taylor and Douglas J. Taylor of Beaverton, Ore. The Rev. William L. McLennan, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Geyserville Inn in Geyserville, Calif.

headline: Sunlen Miller and Alexis Serfaty
text: Sunlen Miller and Alexis Leigh Serfaty were married Saturday evening at Rose Park in Washington. Emily Guthrie, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Ashley Peterson, Matthew Siegler
text: Ashley Marie Peterson and Matthew Allen Blake Siegler were married Saturday by Rabbi Mordecai Finley at the John Thomas Dye School in Los Angeles, where they met in the fifth grade. The couple, both 30, graduated from Harvard, from which the groom also holds a law degree.

headline: The Hesitation Was Mutual
text: Rhonda Faye Levine and Arieh Albert Ullmann are to be married Sunday at Beth David Synagogue in Binghamton, N.Y. Rabbi Zev Silber is to perform the ceremony with Rabbi Barbara Goldman-Wartell participating.

headline: Anne Pierson, Robert Allen
text: Anne Clark Pierson and Robert Wood Allen were married Saturday in Lansing, Mich. The Rev. Ruth D. Fitzgerald, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at the Country Club of Lansing.

headline: Leigh Enoch, Arthur Wit
text: Leigh Sloan Enoch and Arthur Michael Wit were married Saturday by the Rev. Dr. David A. Johnson at Christ Episcopal Church in Charlottesville, Va.,

headline: A Slip of the Foot, a Walk Down the Aisle
text: Richard August Ericson III and Louis Raymond were married Saturday at the home of Carolyn M. Newberger and Dr. Eli H. Newberger, friends of the couple, in Lenox, Mass. Eric Widmer, another friend, who received a one-day solemnization certificate from Massachusetts, officiated.

headline: Ankita Ritwik, Sachin Desai
text: Ankita Ritwik and Sachin Satish Desai are to be married Sunday evening at the Museum of Science in Boston. Peter Ardagna, a Massachusetts justice of the peace, is to officiate, and Pandit Jayant Sane, a Hindu priest, will take part.

headline: Katherine Brown, Alexander Greeley
text: Katherine Marie Brown and Alexander Horace Greeley were married Friday by the Rev. Ferdinand A. Madaki, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Church of the Guardian Angel in Manhattan. On Saturday, the couple had another ceremony at the Harvard Club in Manhattan, where the Rev. Thomas J. Valenti, another Roman Catholic priest, gave a blessing.

headline: Erin Duggan, Benjamin Kramer
text: Erin Morya Duggan and Benjamin Michael Kramer were married Saturday evening at the Samoset Resort in Rockport, Me. The Rev. Dr. William A. Weisenbach, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony, which incorporated Jewish and Christian traditions.

headline: Kathryn Routhier, Jason Rathje
text: Kathryn Marie Routhier and First Lt. Jason Michael Rathje were married Saturday at Faith Lutheran Church in Groton, Conn. The Rev. John Rathje, a Lutheran minister and an uncle of the groom, performed the ceremony.

headline: Caitlin Caporale, Robert Benson Jr.
text: Caitlin Caporale and Robert Benson Jr. were married Saturday by the Rev. Paul A. Cannariato, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Mary’s Church in Closter, N.J.

headline: Leigh Argentieri, David Coogan
text: Leigh Hopkins Argentieri and Capt. David Ryan Coogan were married Saturday by the Rev. Nicholas J. Argentieri, a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the bride, at St. Maria Goretti, a Roman Catholic church in Pittsburgh.

headline: Melissa Glazer, Gabriel Marans
text: Melissa Anne Glazer, a daughter of Susan F. Glazer and Bradford A. Glazer of Cincinnati, is to be married Sunday to Gabriel Kampler Marans, a son of Nina L. Kampler and Dr. Zvi S. Marans of Teaneck, N.J. Rabbi Arnold B. Marans, the groom’s paternal grandfather, is to perform the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple of Cedarhurst, in Woodmere, N.Y.

headline: Katherine Regner, Matthew Cannan
text: Katherine Ann Regner, the daughter of Roberta A. Regner and Thomas M. Regner of Pinellas Park, Fla., was married Saturday evening to Matthew Anselm Cannan, a son of Candace E. Cannan and Brian P. Cannan of Dublin, Ohio. The Rev. Richard T. Conway, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross in Boston.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 4
text: “I look at them as humans and treat their bodies with respect because I believe that they were full of hope and life when they were alive.”

headline: Corrections: August 4, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Rodriguez Finishes Trenton Stint. Next Stop: Unknown.
text: TRENTON — Flanked by two Trenton law enforcement officers, Alex Rodriguez walked past a quote on the wall outside the home clubhouse: “There are never ex-Yankees, their pinstripes ensure them an immortal presence.”

headline: Suspect in Crash on California Boardwalk Is Arrested
text: The Los Angeles police have arrested a man accused of ramming his car through a crowd of people on the Boardwalk of Venice Beach on Saturday, killing one person and injuring at least a dozen others.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 8 P.M. (Discovery) AIR JAWS: COUNTDOWN TO SHARK WEEK 2013 This 26th-annual programming sensation returns with 11 new specials as well as a late-night talk show, starting with this search for the ultimate shark shot. In “Megalodon: The Monster Shark Lives,” at 9, the marine biologist Collin Drake tries to determine the creature responsible for attacking a fishing vessel off the coast of South Africa in April, killing everyone on board. And “Shark After Dark Live,” at 11, features celebrity guests, shark experts, survivors of attacks and highlights from the evening’s shows. In a first, the week will be punctuated by footage from a Shark Cam, a robot submarine that trails sharks in action. Above, a scene from the series.

headline: Putting the Taliban Back in Its Cage
text: America and Pakistan cooperate on the Taliban.

headline: IVF, Embryos and Choices
text: “Mommy, did you choose to make us twins or just sisters?”

headline: Aug. 4: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Is There Any Point To Economic Analysis?
text: A few further thoughts inspired by the sad revelation that Beltway conventional wisdom has settled on the proposition that high unemployment is structural, not cyclical, even though there is now a bipartisan consensus among economists that the opposite is true.

headline: The Great Fredini Dreams of a 3D Sideshow in Coney Island
text: During his years as a member of the Coney Island Circus Sideshow, Fred Kahl, 48, performed as a magician, a sword-swallower, a stuntman who could hammer nails into his skull and light up lightbulbs with his bare hands, and an impresario who helped found the Burlesque at the Beach. That was when he acquired another name: the Great Fredini.

headline: Jennifer Lopez Nears Deal for ‘American Idol’ Return
text: Jennifer Lopez, a judge on “American Idol” during Seasons 10 and 11, is closing a deal to return to the show. Deadline.com reported on Saturday that her return was expected to be announced in one to two weeks, once her contract is finalized.

headline: Syria Bans Use of Foreign Currencies for Business Deals
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria on Sunday banned the use of foreign currencies in business transactions, part of the government’s effort to prop up the Syrian pound, which has plummeted to 200 pounds to the dollar from 47 to the dollar in March 2011.

headline: Denzel Washington Has Another Strong Movie Opening
text: A medium-budget star vehicle dominated North American movie theaters over the weekend, while an animated sequel arrived on tiptoe. “2 Guns” (Universal Pictures), which cost about $60 million to make and stars Denzel Washington and Mark Wahlberg, took in an estimated $27.4 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data.

headline: Victims to Again Face Gunman in Fort Hood Trial
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — Staff Sgt. Alonzo M. Lunsford Jr. usually worked in the back of the Soldier Readiness Processing Center, giving smallpox shots to deploying and returning troops at the Fort Hood Army base here. But on Nov. 5, 2009, he was standing at the counter at the building’s entrance after 1 p.m., so that his colleagues could take a lunch break.

headline: Navigational Cells Located in Human Brains
text: Scientists’ discovery that rodents, bats and nonhuman primates have a system in the brain for what amounts to dead reckoning navigation is one of the most important brain research developments of the past few decades.

headline: Charles Varnadore, Whistle-Blower at Lab, Dies at 71
text: After Charles D. Varnadore complained about safety at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee, where he worked as a technician, his bosses moved him to an office containing radioactive waste. When an industrial hygienist recommended that either he or the waste be moved, he was put in a room contaminated with mercury.

headline: Computer-Brain Interfaces Making Big Leaps
text: Scientists haven’t yet found a way to mend a broken heart, but they’re edging closer to manipulating memory and downloading instructions from a computer right into a brain.

headline: Brooklyn, Where Exes May Lurk, Tests an Emotional Fugitive
text: Meet Nate Piven. Actually, if you’ve been anywhere near the Brooklyn literary scene in the last 20 years, you’ve already met him.

headline: In Germany, Union Culture Clashes With Amazon’s Labor Practices
text: In the United States, technology giants like Amazon are often celebrated as fonts of innovation and jobs.

headline: Teenager Is Shot and Killed by Officer on Foot Patrol in the Bronx
text: Just after 3 a.m. on Sunday, the pop of gunshots cut through the air. Two rookie police officers — barely a month out of the Police Academy, and now on foot patrol in the Bronx — hurried toward the sound.

headline: Wind Is at Lewis’s Back at British Open as Park Misses Record
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — Stacy Lewis forecast the Women’s British Open better than the meteorologists. It’s not her fault that few people were paying attention.

headline: In Nursing Homes, an Epidemic of Poor Dental Hygiene
text: Katherine Ford visited her father, Dean Piercy, a World War II veteran with dementia, at a nursing home in Roanoke, Va., for months before she noticed the dust on his electric toothbrush. His teeth, she found, had not been brushed recently, so she began doing it herself after their lunches together.

headline: A Scottish Actor to Star in ‘Doctor Who’
text: When a science-fiction hero has lived for centuries, journeyed to the farthest reaches of the universe and been reincarnated multiple times, how much change can he undergo in 50 years?

headline: Former Envoy to Syria Said to Be Choice for Cairo Post
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry has recommended that Robert S. Ford serve as the next American ambassador to Egypt, American officials said Sunday, a critical role at a time of rising turmoil and anti-Americanism in the traditional Arab ally.

headline: Maybe CBS Can Visit Me on Weekends
text: “There are several ways that you can still see your favorite shows, including using an antenna to get CBS free over the air.”

headline: Iranian President Is Sworn In and Presents a New Cabinet of Familiar Faces
text: TEHRAN — Hassan Rouhani was sworn in as Iran’s president during a ceremony in Parliament on Sunday, after which he presented a new cabinet dominated by technocrats who had previously served under a moderate former president, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.

headline: Thrown by Life’s Curveballs, a Star Missed the Signals
text: The singular event in the life of Alex Rodriguez is not his imminent suspension, or the career home run record that now will never happen.

headline: Traveling Through Time and Memory, Thanks to Adès and Beethoven
text: No music captures the time-crossing potential of the Mostly Mozart Festival quite like Thomas Adès’s “Arcadiana,” which the Calder Quartet played in a superb late-night concert at the Kaplan Penthouse on Saturday.

headline: No Show in Russia for Bloodhound Gang
text: MOSCOW – Memo to the Bloodhound Gang: In choosing acts of irreverent humor, keep in mind the next leg of your tour.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Venerable Traditions Meet to Stimulate Eyes, Ears and Souls
text: Two carnival cultures converged by way of New York City on Friday night at Damrosch Park. A Lincoln Center Out of Doors concert hailed the African diaspora kinship of two venerable parade traditions: Mardi Gras Indians from New Orleans, represented by Big Chief Monk Boudreaux and the Golden Eagles; and the maracatu de nação (nation maracatu) of Pernambuco, in northeastern Brazil, with Maracatu Nação Estrela Brilhante (“Maracatu Nation Bright Star”), from Recife.

headline: A Confession to Throwing a Stone
text: Excerpts from Muhammad Abu Hashem's interrogation by the Israeli police along with photos of his arrest.

headline: Born Again in a Second Language
text: In her exploration of the Catholic religion, “Letter to a Priest,” written the year before her death in 1943, Simone Weil noticed at some point that “for any man a change of religion is as dangerous a thing as a change of language is for a writer. It may turn out a success, but it can also have disastrous consequences.” The Romanian philosopher Emil Cioran, who was one such writer, talks of the change of language as a catastrophic event in any author’s biography. And rightly so.

headline: Whistle-Blower Has Inspired a Welsh Troupe
text: CARDIFF, Wales — “Bradley Manning is a traitor.”

headline: Mets’ Woes in the Field Look Ugly in Daylight
text: There was snow in Colorado, rain in Atlanta, a heat wave in July. Weather-related obstacles have seemed to trail the Mets all season.

headline: Tough Deals Aplenty at the Intercollegiate Championship
text: ATLANTA — The final of the Grand National Teams on Sunday was between the same two teams as last year. The two-time defending champions were District 9, Florida: Warren Spector of Palm Beach, Michael Becker and David Berkowitz of Boca Raton, Gary Cohler of Miami, and Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell of Clearwater Beach. They faced District 24, New York City and Long Island: Jared Lilienstein, Michael Polowan, Brian Glubok, Sam Lev, John Hurd and Joel Wooldridge, all of New York City.

headline: U.S. Extends Closing of Some Diplomatic Posts
text: WASHINGTON — Nineteen American diplomatic outposts across the Middle East and North Africa will remain closed this week, the State Department said Sunday, despite what officials said was no new information about terrorist plots that they believe are in the works.

headline: Forced Drug Treatment
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Buy Local’ Gets Creative
text: PITTSBURGH — For years, Barbara Johnstone, a professor of linguistics at Carnegie Mellon University here, bought shares in a C.S.A. — a community-supported agriculture program — and picked up her occasional bags of tubers or tomatoes or whatever the member farms were harvesting.

headline: A Sleeper Success Defines Novelist’s Debut and Legacy
text: The blockbuster novel of last summer was “Gone Girl” by Gillian Flynn, a dark, psychological thriller about a broken marriage, told by warring spouses in alternating chapters. This summer, there is “The Silent Wife” by A. S. A. Harrison, a sleeper hit that happens to answer to the same description.

headline: In Any Language, Torture Debases the Abused and the Abusers
text: For almost all of the 106 minutes that “National Security” requires to make its pounded-home point, we are confined to the same ugly, airless interrogation room as Park Won-sang, the film’s much-abused star. By the time we are all released, Mr. Park is unlikely to be the only one looking fatigued.

headline: An Open-Air Stage for Feet and Wings
text: VAIL, Colo. — The Vail International Dance Festival — this year celebrating its 25th anniversary — abounds in historic, daring and once-only conjunctions, partnerships, experiments. It seems only appropriate that hummingbirds and swallows are routinely seen during the early-evening walk from town, alongside a rushing stream, up to the Gerald R. Ford Amphitheater, that the open-air performances are surrounded by mountains, and that the walk back yields views of a night sky crowded with unusually large stars. This is my seventh summer visit here; I’ve learned to look forward to seeing wonders onstage and off.

headline: One Who Can’t Catch a Break
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Get out your telescopes, because we are looking to the STARs in Alan Arbesfeld’s Monday puzzle.

headline: Bass Updates Penny Loafer For Next Generation
text: THINK of Weejuns, the classic penny loafer made by G.H. Bass & Company, and images of preppy American style come to mind — students roaming Ivy League campuses and cool kids in the 1950s and ’60s sporting the shoes and rolled up jeans.

headline: Skirball Center Announces Its New Season
text: A performance of the composer John Zorn’s “Book of Angels,” a festival of works from Chinese artists and a broadcast of “Othello” from London’s National Theater are among the offerings in the 2013-14 season at the N.Y.U. Skirball Center for the Performing Arts.

headline: With 2 Hit Series Ending, a Transformed AMC Is at a Crossroads
text: It was less than a decade ago that the AMC network was known solely as a vintage movie site, if it was known at all, and seemed destined to sit out the creative revolution taking place on cable television.

headline: Redefining Cancer: The Breast-Condition Puzzle
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Gypsy Festival
text: Featuring artists from Turkey, Macedonia, Italy, France, the Netherlands and the United States, the ninth annual Gypsy Festival is scheduled to start on Sept. 9 in Manhattan. Opening night celebrates Balkan funk and jazz with the Dutch ensemble Arifa and the New York Gypsy All-Stars. Throughout the festival, fans and novices can catch performances by the Youngblood Brass Band, the New York group Escarioka, the Italian Gypsy folk band Taluna, Rhythm of Rajasthan from India, TriBeCaStan and Frank London’s Klezmer Brass All-Stars. A swing festival dedicated to the music of Django Reinhardt is scheduled for Sept. 28 at Pace University.

headline: What Makes It Hard to Kick the Habit
text: To the Editor:

headline: Playing Army and Arabs
text: Muhammad Abu Hashem participates in a role-playing game constructed around being arrested for throwing stones.

headline: Funeral Held for Victim of Manhattan Balcony Collapse
text: WOODBURY, N.Y. — Beneath a sky glimmering a bright summer blue, women in dark dresses and men wearing black skullcaps streamed silently into a single-level brick funeral home in Nassau County on Sunday to remember the life of Jennifer Rosoff and focus less on the manner in which she was killed: in a fall from her apartment balcony last week.

headline: A Bed and a Book
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tunnel Vision, for Art’s Sake
text: Visitors tried out the “Voice Tunnel” art installation — talking into speakers and hearing it echo, with lighting tied to the sound’s intensity — in the Park Avenue tunnel on Saturday. People and Rafael Lozano-Hemmer’s interactive work took over the normally car-clogged artery between 33rd and 40th Streets. The work, part of the Summer Streets series, will be restaged on Saturday and Aug. 17.

headline: Colleges Help Ithaca Thrive in a Region of Struggles
text: ITHACA, N.Y. — In many ways, this city is not so special. It has a nice lake, some attractive houses with lawns, and a couple of colleges. But many places in upstate New York have lakes and lawns and places of high learning.

headline: A Tale of Two Art Thefts
text: To the Editor:

headline: Vail International Dance Festival
text: Photos from the annual event in Colorado.

headline: A Rite of Passage, an Act of Defiance
text: The Palestinian stone throwers of Beit Ommar are a reminder of the tensions that animate relations between the Palestinians and the Israelis.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Aug. 5
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS The market will be closely watching remarks by Federal Reserve policy makers this week for more clues on when the central bank might begin to reduce its bond-buying stimulus policy, despite mixed signals from the job market. The latest job report on Friday showed nonfarm payrolls rose by 162,000 in July, below expectations, but the unemployment rate fell to 7.4 percent, its lowest since December 2008. On Monday, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, Richard W. Fisher, is to deliver a speech on the economy. On Tuesday, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, Charles L. Evans, is scheduled to speak.

headline: Bid to Honor Austen Is Not Universally Acknowledged
text: LONDON — It was a genteel campaign to ensure that British bank notes would continue to carry images of women, and it could have ended with the announcement last month that Jane Austen, the much-beloved novelist, would replace Charles Darwin on the £10 note.

headline: Self-Serving War of Words by 2 Giants in Television
text: As consumers in the modern age, we’ve become accustomed to the brinkmanship between cable distributors and programmers. Most of the time, there is much rattling of sabers and then some accommodation is reached. But sometimes, the war of words turns into an actual war, as it did on Friday when Time Warner Cable announced it would turn off CBS stations for three million of its customers in New York, Los Angeles and Dallas.

headline: Berlusconi Says Party to Back Italy’s Coalition
text: ROME — A visibly shaken Silvio Berlusconi, the former Italian prime minister, said Sunday that his center-right party would continue to support Italy’s fragile coalition government, releasing some of the political tension that has built in the country since his definitive conviction for tax fraud last week.

headline: End of Life, at Birth
text: ATLANTA — FIFTY years ago this Wednesday, Americans were gripped by the fate of a baby — Patrick Bouvier Kennedy, the first child born to a sitting president since the 19th century, and John F. Kennedy’s last. He arrived on Aug. 7, 1963, five and a half weeks premature. Despite medical heroics, including the use of a hyperbaric oxygen chamber, he died 39 hours later.

headline: Hog Farms Battling to Contain Deadly Virus
text: ANNAWAN, Ill. — The outside world is not allowed in a sanitized and isolated pig farm here, not far from the Iowa border.

headline: Demonstration at Arizona Border Divides Supporters of Immigration Overhaul
text: A protest by nine Mexican immigrants in which they tried to enter the country through a border station in Arizona even though they had no valid documents has provoked an unusual public argument among groups pushing Congress to overhaul the immigration laws.

headline: A Plan to Avert the Pension Crisis
text: LOS ANGELES — IT isn’t politically feasible for Washington to bail out Detroit, but President Obama and Congress must step in to avert the worst fiscal collapse in urban American history.

headline: Warning Labels on Helmets Combat Injury and Liability
text: Even by the alarmist standards of many product warnings, the labels on the backs of the football helmets are bracingly blunt: “No helmet system can protect you from serious brain and/or neck injuries including paralysis or death. To avoid these risks, do not engage in the sport of football.”

headline: Seven-Stroke Win by Woods Appears to Set Him Up Well for P.G.A.
text: AKRON, Ohio — Tiger has passed Jack. Now, can he catch him?

headline: Parodying Cable News With a Talk About Race
text: On Tuesday night on MSNBC’s “All In,” Chris Hayes had a very direct conversation about race with the Gawker writer Cord Jefferson. Prompted by a news report of a group of young people in Huntington Beach, Calif., who looted and vandalized property, the pair lamented the lack of community leadership and suggested that acting out in that manner was a learned behavior.

headline: A Reminder of the Yankees’ Failed Plan Deals Them Another Defeat
text: SAN DIEGO — The Yankees took a deep breath and exhaled Sunday before diving into the maw of whatever Alex Rodriguez drama awaited them on Monday and in the days beyond. And for a few hours, they set aside concerns about whether Derek Jeter was headed to the disabled list again.

headline: Republicans Against Reality
text: Last week House Republicans voted for the 40th time to repeal Obamacare. Like the previous 39 votes, this action will have no effect whatsoever. But it was a stand-in for what Republicans really want to do: repeal reality, and the laws of arithmetic in particular. The sad truth is that the modern G.O.P. is lost in fantasy, unable to participate in actual governing.

headline: The Price of ‘Made in China’
text: HERE is a symbol of China’s assault on the American economy: the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, which connects Brooklyn and Staten Island. This landmark, which opened in 1964, is North America’s longest suspension bridge. It’s also in urgent need of renovation. Unfortunately, $34 million in steel production and fabrication work has been outsourced to China.

headline: Hours to Go, Just to Get to Work
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — For someone with dropping blood-sugar levels and in the early stages of dehydration, Eva Roma was rather stoic as she began her one-and-a-half-hour commute home from her office in central Jakarta.

headline: A Wait for CBS and Time Warner Cable to Make Up
text: The two sides in the fee dispute between CBS and Time Warner Cable stayed in their respective corners Sunday, and may not engage in further direct confrontation for some time.

headline: Rodriguez Is Expected to Play While Appealing Suspension
text: SAN DIEGO — Leaving behind the tranquillity and sunshine of Southern California, the Yankees headed east Sunday night for a wild spectacle in Chicago, where Alex Rodriguez was expected to make his season debut despite a looming suspension by Major League Baseball.

headline: Mom Wants You Married? So Does the State
text: SEOUL, South Korea — As hopeful singles at the speed dating event shifted from table to table introducing themselves, Park Chang-won, a 32-year-old firefighter, grew more and more morose.

headline: In a West Bank Culture of Conflict, Boys Wield the Weapon at Hand
text: BEIT OMMAR, West Bank — Muhammad Abu Hashem, 17, was sleeping in a sleeveless undershirt when the Israeli soldiers stormed into his home here at 4 a.m. on the second Monday in July. As they led him away moments later, Muhammad’s mother rushed after with a long-sleeved shirt: they both knew it would be cold in the interrogation room.

headline: The Long Stall
text: After last week’s barrage of economic data, the best response anyone could muster was that conditions were likely to improve in the rest of the year. But even that looks like wishful thinking. Worse, though corrective government action is crucial, sound policy cures have not been forthcoming.

headline: Results of New Testing Standard Could Complicate Bloomberg’s Final Months
text: Michael R. Bloomberg has staked much of his reputation as the mayor of New York City on improving students’ test scores, and has trumpeted gains in math and reading as validation of his 12-year effort to remake the city’s schools.

headline: Florida Ignores the Supreme Court
text: Once again, a state is attempting to put to death a man who is clearly ineligible for execution under the Constitution. Once again, state and federal courts are ignoring uncontested facts by hiding behind the draperies of legal procedure. And once again we are forced to wonder why the Supreme Court is so reluctant to step in when a man’s life is at stake.

headline: Teachers’ Union v. City Hall
text: Since taking office in 2002, Mayor Michael Bloomberg has pursued an aggressive policy of replacing large, failing schools with smaller, specialized ones and greatly expanding the number of charter schools, which receive public money but are exempt from some state rules. In all, Mr. Bloomberg has shut down or begun to phase out 142 schools. In addition, the city now has 159 charters schools, up from just 17 when he took office.

headline: Women Scarce in the Top Posts of Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES — There are 1.9 million women in Los Angeles. The two senators from California are women, as is the state’s attorney general.

headline: Trial Set for Brotherhood Officials in Deaths at Anti-Morsi Riots
text: CAIRO — Three top officials of Egypt’s Muslim Brotherhood will go on trial on Aug. 25, on charges of inciting members of their group to kill rioters in front of its headquarters during the upheaval that led to President Mohamed Morsi’s ouster on July 3, a Cairo court ruled on Sunday.

headline: Israeli Decree on West Bank Settlements Will Harm Peace Talks, Palestinians Say
text: JERUSALEM — With peace talks scheduled to begin next week, an Israeli cabinet decision involving West Bank settlements on Sunday drew condemnation from the Palestinian leadership, highlighting the fragility of the Washington-brokered effort to resume long-stalled negotiations.

headline: Tycoon’s Trials Rivet Serbia, Land of Graft
text: PARIS — When Miroslav Miskovic posted a record $16 million bail late last month after spending more than seven months in jail on charges of fraud and tax evasion, the outsized sum solidified the reclusive 68-year-old tycoon’s reputation as one of the Balkans’ richest businessmen, even as it breached his well-known preference for understatement and invisibility.

headline: Route Between Green Bay and Minnesota Is Lined With Hard Feelings
text: MANKATO, Minn. — Jared Allen smelled trouble. Coming off the practice field on Thursday, Allen, a Minnesota defensive end, watched as reporters surrounded the new Vikings wide receiver Greg Jennings, a former Green Bay Packer.

headline: Kentucky Political Staple: Barbs and Barbecue
text: FANCY FARM, Ky. — The menu outside the Knights of Columbus hall boasted 9 tons of barbecue pork and mutton, 225 pounds of purple-hull peas and 1,400 pounds of potato salad.

headline: Feasting on Barbecue, Politics and One-Liners
text: At the Fancy Farm picnic, Senator Mitch McConnell and his opponents took part in a Kentucky tradition of hurling insults amid a raucous crowd.

headline: The Last Temptation of Tina Brown
text: On Nov. 12, 2010, Tina Brown gathered the staff of her Web site The Daily Beast in the third-floor conference room at its Chelsea offices with its commanding views of the Hudson. Brimming with the fervor she has brought to all her endeavors, she delivered some surprising news: the Web site would merge with Newsweek, a once-proud but struggling magazine brand.

headline: Boston Globe Is Another Metro Paper Gone Local
text: It was a coup for local newspaper owners when the news was announced early Saturday morning: John W. Henry, the owner of the Boston Red Sox, would purchase The Boston Globe, along with The Worcester Telegram & Gazette and other properties, from The New York Times Company for $70 million in cash in a deal that will close in a month or two. Despite the lateness of the hour, Mr. Henry, a Boston-area resident, did not contain his enthusiasm about the purchase.

headline: De Blasio Asks City to Address Its Inequalities
text: In a mayor’s race crammed with celebrity razzle-dazzle, historic candidacies and tabloid turns, a gangly liberal from Brooklyn is quietly surging into the top tier of the field by talking about decidedly unglamorous topics: neglected hospitals, a swelling poverty rate and a broken prekindergarten system.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Mixed Blessings
text: Pity the poor patient who tries to make sense of federal advisory committee reports that appear headed in opposite directions. For at least three decades, Americans have been told that it’s best to detect cancers early, when they are theoretically most curable. So it was not all that surprising when an authoritative advisory group recommended that very heavy smokers get an annual CT scan to check for early signs of lung cancer. It was much more surprising, however, when a separate group of experts suggested that for several cancers — including potential lung cancers — early scans are detecting too many abnormalities that aren’t dangerous and should not be treated.

headline: Men and Women Share Tournament, but Not Main Stage
text: WASHINGTON — The Citi Open is one of the 18 professional tennis tour events at which men and women compete together. Joint tournaments, which began with the four Grand Slam events, are becoming increasingly common.

headline: When to Burst Your Friend's Bubble
text: Huma Abedin's friends aren't the only ones who face this situation: Should you speak up when you disapprove of a friend's romantic choices?

headline: Playoff Contract Could Stand in the Way of Conferences Considering a Split
text: In recent weeks, the commissioners of three of the most prominent conferences in college sports have publicly mused about how the five most powerful leagues might soon be forced to create their own division in order to govern themselves.

headline: Paul Szilard, 100, Impresario Of Ballet and Modern Dance
text: Paul Szilard, a Hungarian-born dancer who went from managing a bar in Manila to managing international tours for major dance companies, notably the Alvin Ailey troupe, died on July 26 at his home in Manhattan. He was 100.

headline: Health Care Law Raises Pressure on Public Unions
text: Cities and towns across the country are pushing municipal unions to accept cheaper health benefits in anticipation of a component of the Affordable Care Act that will tax expensive plans starting in 2018.

headline: Falling Tree Kills Woman in Queens
text: A woman who was believed to have been pregnant was killed by a falling tree as she sat on a bench in Kissena Park in Queens on Sunday evening, the police said.

headline: For Decades, Fighting to Rescue a Bronx Park From Disrepair
text: Thirty-three years ago, Al Quiñones and his friends adopted Playground 52 in the South Bronx, determined to save their neighborhood park from the blight that surrounded it. Working out of a bathroom that doubled as their office, they cadged paint, garbage cans and anything else they could rustle up in their relentless mission to improve their Longwood neighborhood. They called themselves 52 People for Change.

headline: On R Train, Unwelcome Reminder of Storm’s Impact
text: In late May, executives from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority boarded an A train to the Rockaways to celebrate a hard-won milestone. For the first time since October, when Hurricane Sandy leveled the subway system with unprecedented damage, train service had been made whole again.

headline: G.O.P. Governors Warn Party Members in Congress Not to Shut Government
text: MILWAUKEE — Worried about the potential impact on the fragile economies in their states, Republican governors this weekend warned their counterparts in Congress not to shut down the federal government as part of an effort to block financing for President Obama’s health care law.

headline: The Referendum
text: In New York’s search for a mayor to succeed Michael Bloomberg, you’d think Bill de Blasio would loom large, and not just because he’s 6-foot-5. He is policy-smart, progressive, politically savvy and untouched by scandal. He’s connected. (He ran Hillary Clinton’s first Senate campaign.) He holds a citywide job, public advocate, that, while not very demanding, is nominally next in line to the mayor. From that post he has been none-too-subtly campaigning for the top job since 2010. As the city emerges from 20 years of Republican and independent leadership and shows its true colors — which are, by most indications, deep blue — candidates don’t come much bluer than Bill de Blasio.
