text: NEW YORK

headline: To Ensure Bone Health, Start Early
text: Most people don’t start thinking about the health of their bones until midlife or later, by which time it can be too late to do very much to protect against serious bone loss and resulting fractures.

headline: The Free-Trade Blues
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: Word of the Day | philatelist
text: philatelist •\fə-ˈla-tə-list\• noun

headline: AT&T, Not American Express, Will Be Chief Sponsor of Tribeca Film Festival
text: LOS ANGELES — Come April 16, the stars will strut, paparazzi will pop, and fans will file into packed theaters, turning Lower Manhattan into a temporary film capital during the 13th annual Tribeca Film Festival. But they will not be having all that fun under the ubiquitous, blue-and-white corporate logo of American Express.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 10:30 P.M. (Showtime 2) 2 DAYS IN NEW YORK (2012) Julie Delpy directed and stars in this tale about 48 hours in the life of Marion, a high-strung photographer; her partner, Mingus (Chris Rock, above left, with Ms. Delpy, right, Talen Ruth Riley and Owen Shipman), a journalist and radio host; and their two children from previous relationships, as they all deal with the arrival of Marion’s Parisian family members, who proceed to drive the couple crazy. Marion’s father (played by Ms. Delpy’s father, Albert) is detained at the airport for trying to enter the United States with cheese and sausage taped to his body; her sister (Alexia Landeau) and her sister’s boyfriend (Alex Nahon) smoke weed in an elevator and have noisy sex in the bathroom, possibly involving Mingus’s electric toothbrush. “The driving crazy part is hilarious and persuasive, partly because Ms. Delpy and her cast depart from the usual caricatures of Frenchness while still engaging in broad, silly satire,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. And although Marion and Mingus “never quite seem like a credible, comfortable couple,” he added, the film’s best parts “are those that cast an affectionate, unsentimental eye on the city, which looks lived-in, real and nonmythical, the way that Paris often looks in French movies and New York rarely does in Hollywood confections.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 5
text: “It’s a shame and embarrassing that in a city of 4 million people we are down to one woman.”

headline: Del Potro Outlasts Isner for Third Title in Washington
text: WASHINGTON — By showing off his impressive reach Sunday, Juan Martin del Potro looked more prepared than he has in years to contend for another Grand Slam title.

headline: Photo Replay: July 29-August 4
text: A look back at a week in sports that had athletes soaring off diving boards, running up mountains and surfing in downtown Munich.

headline: Dying With Dignity and the Final Word on Her Life
text: From the time she was a teenager, Jane Lotter, a lifelong resident of Seattle, loved to write — jingles for a greeting card company; news and features for a local real estate magazine; a weekly humor column in the now defunct Jet City Maven; and, most recently, a comic novel, completed shortly before her death last month.

headline: News Quiz | August 5, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Strawberry Fields Tanka
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Aug. 5, 2013
text: Test your math skills with this question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “Campaign Ad Cash Lures Buyers to Swing-State TV Stations.”

headline: Louis Draper, Plucked From Obscurity
text: Until recently, histories of photography would have ignored Louis H. Draper — not because of the quality of his photographs, but because of the color of his skin. With the exception of Gordon Parks, African-Americans were mostly glossed over or excluded altogether.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | More College Applications Ask About Sexual Identity
text: In “The Gay Question: Check One,” Samantha Stainburn writes about new information some colleges and universities are asking for–and connecting students with resources before they arrive on campus.

headline: New York Today: Tunnels of Woe and Whoa
text: Updated, 11:32 a.m. | Over the weekend, the Park Avenue car tunnel opened to pedestrians for the first time ever as part of a temporary art installation that entranced visitors.

headline: Navigating the Greenway: 1,200-Mile Journey in an Electric Bicycle-Car
text: Mark Stewart is a bike guy. But Mr. Stewart, a 65-year-old bicycle enthusiast, likes his car, too. By his way of thinking, he can keep his beloved yellow 1998 Saab convertible for a longer time if he rides his bike more. Simple math, he says: drive the car less, and it’ll last longer.

headline: HSBC’s First-Half Profit Rose 10%
text: LONDON – HSBC, Britain’s largest bank, said on Monday that earnings rose 10 percent in the first half of the year, thanks in part to lower charges for bad loans, especially in the United States.

headline: Food Stamps: A Correction
text: I assume we’ll put up a formal correction later, but I somehow confused x and 1/x in today’s column. House Republicans proposed doubling cuts to food stamps, not cutting them in half. Nothing important changes in my argument, but I did make a mistake. And it’s both Times policy and mine to acknowledge errors when you make them.

headline: Nate Silver, Superstar
text: Over at Barry Ritholtz’s place, Bob Lefsetz argues that Nate Silver’s departure from the Times heralds a new age of journalism in which the individual journalist builds his or her own brand, and the middlemen — like newspapers — lose power. In fact, he compares Nate to Arcade Fire, who pioneered the modern indie rock movement by creating their own position rather than by relying on record companies.

headline: Budget Bedlam
text: Lest you think that I am exaggerating the mess created by the madness of the GOP, the very sober Stan Collender weighs in. Scary stuff.

headline: Daily Report: Amazon Runs Up Against Germany’s Labor Culture
text: Even as President Obama spoke about middle-class jobs last week at an Amazon warehouse in Tennessee, Amazon was facing strikes at warehouses in Germany, its second-biggest market. Unions there say the company has imported American-style business practices — in particular, an antipathy to organized labor — that stand at odds with European norms, Nick Wingfield and Melissa Eddy report.

headline: Student Crossword | Famous Painters
text: Learn more about famous painters by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: The Road That Led to Telangana
text: The southern state of Andhra Pradesh was formed in 1956, with Hyderabad as its capital, on the principle of reorganizing Indian states on a linguistic basis. Andhra Pradesh combined the Telugu-speaking region of the former princely state of Hyderabad and the Telugu-speaking region of Seemandhra, which was part of the Madras Presidency. Hyderabad was a ruled by a princely ruler, the Nizam, and supervised by a British resident, and the Seemandhra region was ruled directly by the British authorities. The Seemandhra region includes four southern districts of Rayalseema region, and the nine districts of Coastal Andhra, along the shore of Bay of Bengal.

headline: A Focus on Greed in Tourre Case
text: Tension mounted among the nine jurors in the federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan last week as they examined the nuances of the Securities and Exchange Commission’s case against Fabrice P. Tourre, a former Goldman Sachs trader. By 3:12 p.m. on Thursday, the jury had reached a verdict, deciding Mr. Tourre was liable on six of the seven counts. “Ultimately, the jurors said, their decision came down to what they saw as the letter of the law and, for some, a broader concern that Mr. Tourre’s actions underscored a fundamental problem with society: Wall Street greed,” Susanne Craig, Ben Protess and Alexandra Stevenson report in DealBook.

headline: Hedge Fund Urges EADS to Sell Dassault Stake
text: Updated, 11:45 a.m. |

headline: New Zealand Dairy Giant Apologizes Over Tainted Formula
text: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — Fonterra, a large New Zealand dairy producer, apologized on Monday for the contamination of an infant milk formula ingredient with a potentially toxic strain of bacteria.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: August 2-4, 2013
text: The shooting of Trayvon Martin in a gated community in Sanford, Fla., drew public attention to the state’s self-defense statutes, and lawmakers there seem to be reacting: Florida’s House of Representatives will hold hearings this fall on its “Stand Your Ground” self-defense law, which was the first of its kind in the country when it was adopted in 2005.

headline: Samuel Beckett at 59E59 Theaters
text: Trevor Nunn’s well-received 2012 stage adaptation of the haunting Samuel Beckett radio play “All That Fall,” starring Eileen Atkins and Michael Gambon, will be presented in New York at the end of the year, following runs at two London theaters last fall. The show, a highlight of the coming season at 59E59 Theaters, features a deceptively simple plot: A woman heads to meet her blind husband at a train station. But this is Beckett, after all, and the story turns out to be more of a tragicomic meditation on life and death. Mr. Nunn’s production, because of restrictions set by the Beckett estate, is presented in the form of a live radio play, with actors holding scripts and using minimal props. The 2013-14 season at 59E59 Theaters, to be announced on Monday, is also to include “I Can See Clearly Now (The Wheelchair on My Face)” (Sept. 10 to 29), a solo show written and performed by Sonya Kelly, courtesy of the Dublin company Fishamble: The New Play Company; “Witnessed by the World” (Nov. 7 to Dec. 15), a play by Ronnie Cohen and Jane Beale, starring Tovah Feldshuh as a journalist fixated on the assassination of John F. Kennedy; Squonk Opera’s surreal meditation on the visualization of music, “Mayhem and Majesty” (Dec. 10 to 29); and “Beertown” (Jan. 30 to Feb. 16), about a town’s time capsule. “All That Fall” is scheduled to run Nov. 5 to Dec. 8 at 59E59 Theaters, which also produces the annual “Brits Off Broadway” festival, planned for April 1 to June 29.

headline: Alan Menken Goes for the EGOT (and the REGOT)
text: Few composers are more decorated than Alan Menken, a winner of eight Academy Awards for the songs and scores he has helped create for the animated features “The Little Mermaid,” “Beauty and the Beast,” “Aladdin” and “Pocahontas.” He has 11 Grammys, too, for his work on those films and on “Tangled,” and a Tony for his score of Broadway’s “Newsies the Musical.” (The original film from which that show is adapted also nabbed Mr. Menken a Golden Raspberry Award — better known as a Razzie — for worst original song.)

headline: Hellman & Friedman in Deal for Insurance Brokerage Firm
text: Hellman & Friedman funds are acquiring Hub International, a global insurance brokerage firm, in a deal that values the company at $4.4 billion.

headline: Sugary Beverages Linked to Higher B.M.I. in Young Children
text: It sounds like another page from the files of obvious research: a study published in the journal Pediatrics reveals a link between regular consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages (dubbed S.S.B.’s) and higher body mass index scores in 2- to 5-year-olds. Children who regularly drank sugar-sweetened sodas, sports beverages or fruit juice (as opposed to 100 percent fruit juice drinks) had both higher B.M.I.’s and “higher weight status” than those who drank them infrequently or not at all.

headline: G.M. Had a Version of OnStar in 1966
text: It has been nearly two decades since General Motors introduced OnStar. Since then, it has served as electronic emergency nurse, computerized auto theft detective and binary butler for millions of motorists. Sure, it’s had its problems – as when G.M. decided to make the switch to digital in 2008 and told all the analog customers their equipment would no longer work. But for the most part, it has been a functional system. It must be; OnStar has already cycled through nearly a dozen hardware and software updates over the years.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Susan Dominus on Spending Time With Stephen King and His Clan of Writers
text: Susan Dominus, a staff writer for the magazine, is the author of this week’s cover story about Stephen King and his literary family. Her last article for the magazine was a profile of Ikram Goldman, the owner of a Chicago fashion boutique.

headline: Aug. 5: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: All-You-Can-Fly Airline Plies the California Coast
text: BURBANK, Calif. — Meticulous, well-thought-out plans may be for some people, but not Wade Eyerly. At 16, he walked into the registrar’s office at the University of Central Missouri, not knowing he was supposed to have applied for admission. He walked out with a schedule of classes.

headline: Turkish Court Hands Down Prison Sentences in Coup Plot
text: IZMIR, Turkey — A Turkish court sentenced dozens of high-ranking military officers, politicians, journalists and others to long prison terms on Monday for plotting to overthrow the government in a long-running case that captivated the nation for its audacity, laid bare the deep divisions within Turkish society between Islamists and secularists and earned sharp criticism from the international community over issues of judicial fairness.

headline: The Seed of Obstruction
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: A Lab-Grown Burger Gets a Taste Test
text: A hamburger made from cow muscle grown in a laboratory was fried, served and eaten in London on Monday in an odd demonstration of one view of the future of food.

headline: Today in Small Business: Answering Health Care Questions
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Governor Intervenes at Last Minute to Forestall a New Bay Area Transit Strike
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A strike by employees of the San Francisco Bay Area’s main commuter railroad was averted at the last minute early Monday after Gov. Jerry Brown intervened in the stalled negotiations, guaranteeing service for seven days. But the negotiations, described by experts as unusually acrimonious, seemed likely to remain focused on two familiar issues: pensions and health benefits.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner | The Trayvon Martin Case
text: Each Monday through Sept. 2, we’ll be announcing the winner and runners-up for a different week of our Summer Reading Contest.

headline: Away From the Circus: Wins, Losses and Some Gold
text: On the day the circus was finally going to hit town — and yes, technically, the center ring is in Chicago as the Yankees set up their trapezes there, but you will get a whiff of the elephants from pretty much anywhere in the league — it’s tempting to think that Alex Rodriguez and his merry band of fellow suspected Biogenesis clients have swallowed the sports world whole.

headline: Citing Irregularities, City Board Rejects Public Money for Liu’s Campaign
text: Three months after the convictions of  two former associates of John C. Liu for participating in an illegal fund-raising scheme, the New York City Campaign Finance Board voted on Monday to withhold as much as $3.5 million in public money from his mayoral campaign.

headline: Portraits by Bob Dylan to Be Shown at London’s National Portrait Gallery
text: Bob Dylan told us that everything would be different when he painted his masterpiece, but for this iconoclastic singer-songwriter, creating artwork and having it shown at internationally regarded institutions is becoming an increasingly regular experience. On Monday, the National Portrait Gallery in London became the latest museum — and the first ever in Britain — to announce that it will devote to Mr. Dylan’s (non-musical) work. This exhibition, called “Bob Dylan: Face Value,” will open on Aug. 24 and will display 12 pastel portraits made by him, the museum said.

headline: Listen Up | A Soulful Torch Song From the Brooklyn Vocalist Diane Birch
text: The first song Diane Birch wrote for her forthcoming album, “Speak a Little Louder” (out Oct. 15), didn’t quite go as planned. “All the Love You Got” — which makes its world premiere here — is an irresistibly defiant, stirring anthem in the vein of Dusty Springfield and Diana Ross. But, “when I wrote this song, I was in the head space of the disco era, and early ’80s dance music,” explained the 30-year-old Brooklyn-based singer-songwriter. “It had a lot of Prince references, along with Madonna, Blondie and the music Nile Rodgers made with David Bowie. But then I realized it’s not a dance song — it had to be a ballad.”

headline: Surveilance Videos From the Shooting
text: Two surveilance videos show the suspect firing shots at and chasing his inteded target.

headline: Image of the Day: August 5
text: A horse cart race in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh.

headline: Fantasy Football: Receivers and Tight Ends to Avoid
text: Continuing our look at players being drafted higher than they should be, we turn our attention to the wide receiver and tight end positions. Although these players can be useful depending on when they are drafted, we will do our best to keep them off our fantasy football rosters this summer.

headline: Math for Love: The Angle Maze
text: Get lost in this angle maze and fall in love with the beauty of math.

headline: Gay Bashing Inside the Garden Ring
text: MOSCOW — After she got home at 5 a.m. Vera Kichanova wrote on Facebook,“I thought all those awful homophobia stories happened outside the Garden Ring,” referring to the avenue that circles central Moscow. “Inside the Garden Ring” is a geographic and social appellation: With its overpriced designer apartments, luxury boutiques and at least a couple of coffee shops on every block, the area is generally considered a world onto itself. Some use the term pejoratively, to indicate rich people who are out of touch with reality; others use it to denote a perceived protected space inside an increasingly reactionary country.

headline: Walkabout: Thai Tourism’s Wide Net; JetBlue’s Premium Side
text: Thai Tourism’s Wide Net In stark comparison to many of its neighboring countries, Thailand is marketing itself to a wide variety of tourists, including gay and Muslim travelers. (New York Times)

headline: Cricket and Power Politics in Sri Lanka
text: Until a few years ago, Hambantota was an obscure town in south-central Sri Lanka, around 190 kilometers (118 miles)  from the capital Colombo, with a population that barely exceeded 10,000. Its daily rhythms were defined by the twin activities of farming and fishing. But once Mahinda Rajapaksa, one of its native sons, became president in 2005, all that began to change.

headline: Icons of Cruelty
text: Two iconic photographs of former slaves documenting the torture inflicted on them by their owners were widely circulated during the Civil War as anti-slavery propaganda, and both appear in the current exhibit “Photography and the American Civil War” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Although the images were extensively reproduced and helped to turn public opinion against slavery, the stories of the two men in these shocking photographs are little known today.

headline: The Gray Line of ‘Confidential’ Information
text: The insider trading case against SAC Capital Advisors seems to be all about the trading “edge,” a term the firm’s owner, Steven A. Cohen, once said he hated. Under the securities laws, proving a violation requires showing that the information used was nonpublic, which means it was not already available in the stock market — the edge that can make for lucrative profits and sidestepping big losses.

headline: After Congress’s Cuts, Envoys Say, U.S. Trade Suffers for Want of Jet Fare
text: WASHINGTON — For those seeking to dramatize the high cost of across-the-board budget cuts in Washington, the temptation, understandably, is to paint in bold strokes: an aircraft carrier pulled out of the Persian Gulf or air traffic control towers gone dark.

headline: Mars Curiosity Rover Tracker
text: A selection of images from NASA’s Curiosity rover as it drives toward Mount Sharp.

headline: An Earth Year on Mars
text: On the first anniversary of its landing, halfway through its primary mission to Mars, NASA’s Curiosity rover still has a long way to go.

headline: Learning to Hire at a Growing Company
text: At the most recent She Owns It business group meeting, the owners talked about the importance of making the right hiring decisions, especially as a company grows.

headline: Using ‘Do Not Track’ Options
text: Using ‘Do Not Track’

headline: Subduing a Cackling Toy Monkey in the Next Seat, to the Relief of Many
text: I’VE lived in the United States for 20 years, and now that I’m a citizen, I find it kind of odd when I fly back to England for business or pleasure. First, everyone tells me I sound like a Yank. And second, I’ve become terrified of driving on the left, which is something I never thought would happen.

headline: Jersey Pho
text: Atlantic City, N.J., and the surrounding area offers a number of Vietnamese restaurants that rank among the nation’s most authentic.

headline: Where the Pho Is a Sure Thing
text: ATLANTIC CITY — New Yorkers have been known to grouse about the Vietnamese food in their city. Many have tasted mind-numbingly good pho in places like Houston, San Diego and Falls Church, Va. (national hot spots of Viet cuisine), yet when they encounter the iconic beef and rice-noodle soup at home, the flavors often seem pallid and unknit.

headline: Luring Away Gunmakers
text: The gun maker PTR Industries is moving from Connecticut to South Carolina, as tightening restrictions drive the firearms industry to gun-friendly states.

headline: For Some Gun Makers, Moving Lock, Stock and Barrel
text: BRISTOL, Conn. — Even gun makers want to be liked. So governors and other politicians from states eager to embrace the industry have descended on places where they are not so popular — like Connecticut, Maryland, New York and Colorado — offering tax breaks and outright cash grants to persuade them to relocate.

headline: Someone Tell Cantor: The Deficit Is Shrinking
text: On Fox News Sunday, Chris Wallace asked Eric Cantor, the House Majority Leader, for a preview of what will happen the next time Congress needs to raise the debt ceiling. It was a remarkable exchange, in part because Mr. Cantor made a remarkable error.

headline: Travels in the Fourth Dimension
text: Time can be weirdly elastic. For a sky-diver whose parachute won’t open, a few seconds can seem to last forever, but safe on the ground an hour can pass in a flash.

headline: Where to Place the Hole on No. 15? Fans Can Vote on It
text: At the United States Open, the British Open, the Masters and PGA Tour events, the 18 hole locations are determined the morning of each round by tournament officials who consider the speed and slope of a green and the weather forecast. But at this week’s P.G.A. Championship, at Oak Hill Country Club in Rochester, you — yes, you — can vote on where the cup will be on the 15th green in Sunday’s final round.

headline: Chocolate Factory Theater Announces New Season
text: The Chocolate Factory Theater in Long Island City has its dance card filled for the fall and spring season. Kicking off the performances of dance, theater, music and all-of-the-above is “Flutter” by MVworks, a New York City-based dance company founded by Megan V. Sprenger.

headline: The Dangers of a Sensationalist Portrayal of Veterans
text: If you listen closely to the national conversation about today’s veterans, you will hear two stories that seem to be at odds with each other.

headline: Republicans Threaten Networks Over Projects on Hillary Clinton
text: The chairman of the Republican National Committee threatened on Monday to refuse to partner with CNN or NBC on any presidential primary debates if the two networks move ahead with plans for television projects on Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Smarter Anti-Clotting Tools
text: Using infinitesimal particles of gold, researchers have discovered a way to stop blood from clotting, and then make it clot again.

headline: Climate Change Seen as Threat to Iberian Lynx
text: After 20 years and more than $100 million spent, the effort to save the endangered Iberian lynx is at risk because it fails to factor in the effects of climate change, scientists say.

headline: A Year With Curiosity, Nursing Homes’ Dental Problems, Your Dose of Healthy Sugar
text: After over 350 sols — that’s Martian days — NASA’s rover has a lot in its scrapbook; why so many nursing home residents don’t get proper dental care; if you’re going to have sweets, it’s better to pack it with pulp.

headline: There’s Big Revenue in Those Little Fees
text: SAN DIEGO — GOOGLE Maps puts the distance from my home in Tucson to the San Diego Convention Center at about 421 miles, a drive of a bit over six hours.

headline: NBC Taps Seacrest to Host ‘The Million Second Quiz’
text: Ryan Seacrest, who hosts “American Idol” on Fox and “New Year’s Rockin’ Eve” every year on ABC, now has a prime-time gig on a third broadcast network. On Monday, NBC announced that Mr. Seacrest would be the host of “The Million Second Quiz,” an interactive game show that is taking over nearly two weeks of the network’s schedule in September.

headline: A Unique Collection Worthy of Framing (Pictures Not Included)
text: At a gallery in Long Island City, Queens, Diego Salazar displays his unique collection of art, which is as lovely as it is peculiar. About 250 pieces hang in his main gallery, stacked one inside the next like Russian dolls. Some are covered in cherubs or crosses, others are gilded, and a few are more than 400 years old.

headline: Qaeda Leader’s Edict to Yemen Affiliate Is Said to Prompt Alert
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s decision last week to close nearly two dozen diplomatic missions and issue a worldwide travel alert came after the United States intercepted electronic communications in which the head of Al Qaeda ordered the leader of the group’s affiliate in Yemen to carry out an attack as early as this past Sunday, according to American officials.

headline: A Year on Mars
text: One year ago, the rover's arrival on Mars ushered in a new era of exploration. Since then, it has been inching toward a mountain that could yield fascinating insights.

headline: M.L.B. Suspends Rodriguez and 12 Others for Doping
text: Alex Rodriguez was among 13 players suspended by Major League Baseball on Monday for violating the league’s antidoping rules, the biggest single-day drug action in the sport’s history.

headline: Disney Magic May Not Have Worked on Pixar
text: Robert A. Iger, the chairman and chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, has another Pixar hit on his hands.

headline: ‘Leaning In’ to Lego Camp
text: When my daughter said she wanted to go to a Lego engineering summer camp, I tried to hide my excitement. I’ve had an eye on gender gaps in everything from government to the sciences since giving birth to Frankie. As far as I knew, though, she played with dolls, not Legos, on play dates. Frankie’s sudden interest in engineering felt like a win.

headline: Still a Firebrand, 2,000 Years Later
text: Jesus the loving shepherd. Bringer of peace and justice. Teacher of universal morals. Jesus the rabbi. Jesus the philosopher. Jesus the apocalyptic prophet. Jesus the Christ of faith.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | July 30-Aug. 5, 2013
text: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events that made news this week.

headline: ‘American Psycho’-Style Specs From Oliver Peoples and Miller’s Oath
text: Oliver Peoples frames were the preferred eyewear of the late-’80s business set (Patrick Bateman, of “American Psycho” fame, was a fan) because they were simply the best: carefully made, modern, low-key and refined. Now Larry Leight, the co-founder and creative director of the brand (now owned by Luxottica), is reaching back into his ’80s briefcase and issuing a capsule collection called Sir, which includes tortoiseshell versions of three iconic frames — the O’Malley, the Finley and the Kent — from 1987, the year Oliver Peoples came out with its first collection.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Riding an Uber Boat and the Origin of ‘O.K., Glass’
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: City Hall's Invisible Library
text: Among the millions of photos and documents in the storerooms below New York City’s municipal library, Edward I. Koch, Michael Jackson and Muhammad Ali are captured at the peak of their powers.

headline: Suspension Leaves Many Questions for Now and Later
text: Some questions and answers about Alex Rodriguez, who has been suspended by Major League Baseball but is appealing the ruling and has rejoined the Yankees’ lineup.

headline: The Changing State of Smartphone Competition in China
text: Will Android, a “little rice” and lot of cheap “China Droids” overwhelm Apple’s plans for China?

headline: Monday Motorsports: Kimball Gets First IndyCar Win
text: Charlie Kimball took the checkered flag at Sunday’s Mid-Ohio IndyCar series event, his first victory. Kimball took the lead with 18 laps to go in the 90-lap event, with a pass of Simon Pagenaud. Pagenaud, who didn’t give up easily, held on for a tenacious second place, followed by Dario Franchitti and Will Power. Helio Castroneves, the series points leader, finished sixth.

headline: Bring on the ‘Frankenburger’
text: Updated below, 4:15 p.m. | I first explored livestock-free approaches to keeping meat on menus in 2008 in a pieced titled “Can People Have Meat and a Planet, Too?”

headline: An American Cure
text: La Quercia Prosciutto Americano is produced by Herb Eckhouse in Iowa.

headline: Some Prosciutto Fans Turn to Iowa
text: NORWALK, Iowa — The decision came down to this: Would people buy prosciutto from a guy named Herb from Iowa?

headline: Comparing Republicans With the Mainstream
text: It seems like every week brings fresh evidence of the disconnect between Republicans and the mainstream. A Pew survey published last Wednesday indicated that 54 percent of Republicans think their ultra-conservative party is just not conservative enough. Today’s entry is a Quinnipiac poll that asked voters to rank politicians based on how they felt about them, from a cold zero to a hot 100. The gap between the general population and self-identified G.O.P. voters was vast.

headline: Third Point Reinsurance Fund Arm Seeks Up to $370.6 Million in I.P.O.
text: The reinsurance arm of Third Point, the hedge fund run by Daniel S. Loeb, disclosed on Monday that it was seeking to raise up to $370.6 million from its forthcoming initial public offering.

headline: Excerpt From 'Meistersinger'
text: A clip from a performance of a new production of  Wagner's "Meistersinger von Nürnberg" at the Salzburg Festival.

headline: Nesting Coffins and Low Expectations for a Comet
text: Science giveth, but it also taketh away. This week, a “high status” medieval coffin was opened to reveal another coffin. And what was being called “the comet of the century” is shaping up to be an interstellar bummer. But look, here comes the “Fireball Champion.”

headline: ‘Gnarly’ Moments in the Life of an Extreme Photographer
text: The photographer Mike Escamilla describes himself as a stuntman, professional BMX rider, actor, photographer, filmmaker, director, producer and designer. (He’s also a former X-Games competitor. In 2005 he set world records for the longest back flip and longest 360 on a BMX bike.) And he keeps an itinerary that would exhaust many photojournalists (and make many more envious); since May of this year he has been to Spain, Denmark, Sweden, Finland, Russia, Estonia, Latvia, Puerto Rico, Dominica, Ecuador, Germany, San Francisco and Colorado. When I came across his images on Instagram, it was clear that they were shot by someone with daring and an eye for unusual angles, giving new definition to Robert Capa’s famous advice to photographers: “If your pictures aren’t good enough, you aren’t close enough.”

headline: Slow Start for Taxi-Hailing Apps, City Data Show
text: They were billed as a game-changing way to hail taxis in New York City, upsetting the urban democracy of the outstretched arm and geographic savvy, and replacing it with a smartphone app.

headline: Can Immunity to the Common Cold Come With Age?
text: Q. My mother, who lived to be 92, never caught my sniffles in her later years, even though I was her sole caretaker. And now that I’m in my 60s, I notice that my colds are less severe. Is it possible to develop immunity to the common cold?

headline: MoMA Joins Tumblr to Reach Teens
text: The Museum of Modern Art in New York joined Tumblr on Monday with a new Web site aimed at teenagers, called MoMA Teens. Calder Zwicky, an associate educator at the museum, said they have been working on the site for the past nine months.

headline: Unforgiving Land (Its Desert Rodents, Especially)
text: Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Canelo Alvarez square off in a high-profile boxing match on Sept. 14, but you don’t have to wait until then to see a slam-bang fight. There’s an awfully entertaining one between two Arabian jirds on Tuesday night in “Wild Arabia,” on Animal Planet.

headline: A Back and Forth About Narcissism
text: The social-science journal Emerging Adulthood recently invited Jean M. Twenge and one of her most prominent critics, Jeffrey Arnett, to debate “whether today’s emerging adults are excessively ‘narcissistic,’ ” as Dr. Twenge asserts. Both wrote papers outlining their positions, then each wrote a reply to the other. Excerpts from the discussion follow.

headline: In Performance: Young Jean Lee
text: The playwright Young Jean Lee asks some darkly comic existential questions in her pop-music cabaret “We’re Gonna Die,” at the Claire Tow Theater. In this scene she talks about a painful breakup.

headline: Loss of a Baby (1 Letter)
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Learning From Hurt (1 Letter)
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Seeing Narcissists Everywhere
text: From the triumph of Botox to the rise of social networking and soccer teams that give every kid a trophy, Jean M. Twenge is constantly on the lookout for signs of a narcissism crisis in America.

headline: Moroccan Myth, Set to Music
text: “You woke me with your dreams,” the goatskin-wearing deity Boujeloud says to the Moroccan shepherd Attar in “Jajouka, Something Good Comes to You.” “With the music of your dreams! I want to hear it again,” the Pan-like figure implores.

headline: Whooping Cough Linked to Shorter Life Expectancy
text: People who are born during whooping cough epidemics and survive them are more likely to die prematurely later in life, according to a new study analyzing 158 years of Swedish population data.

headline: The Affordable, and Therefore Enjoyable, Vacation
text: Quality time with my family is on the top of the list of things that I value. In the past, however, when we went on vacation specifically to spend time together, I was often no fun to be around because I was so anxious about money.

headline: Cuba’s Hurricane Watch
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Turkey, Egypt, Israel and Kuwait.

headline: A Glance Inside an Obscure Archive
text: A selection of images from New York City’s Department of Records and Information Services.

headline: Bezos, Amazon’s Founder, to Buy The Washington Post
text: The Washington Post, the newspaper whose reporting helped topple a president and inspired a generation of journalists, is being sold for $250 million to the founder of Amazon.com, Jeffrey P. Bezos, in a deal that has shocked the industry.

headline: Bank Behind Sale of Washington Post to Amazon’s Bezos
text: In a week of big media deals, the sale of The Washington Post to Jeffrey P. Bezos of Amazon.com takes the cake.

headline: A Photographer Calling the Tune
text: Many aspiring country singers have day jobs, typically along the lines of waiting tables or tending bar. Not Mark Seliger. He has shot famous portraits of public figures — actors, dancers, politicians, rock stars and artists, from Jay Z to the Dalai Lama — for magazines like Time, Rolling Stone, GQ and Vanity Fair.

headline: Envoys Visit a Top Islamist Inside a Jail Near Cairo
text: CAIRO — A United States envoy met with a jailed leader of the Muslim Brotherhood on Monday as part of an intensifying international effort to end the political crisis that began after Egypt’s security services deposed President Mohamed Morsi last month.

headline: Dot Earth Makes Time Magazine’s List of 25 Top Blogging Efforts
text: [Updated, Aug. 6, 10:32 p.m. | Starting Wednesday, I’m on the road helping my elder son relocate from New Orleans to Los Angeles, so the blog will be tended sporadically through the weekend. Please consider this an open thread focused on ways to make Dot Earth, and Web discourse more generally, engaging, productive and fun.]

headline: A Library Where the Hush Is Over Its Very Existence
text: Nothing on the street outside says that it is there. First-time visitors must push through a revolving door of a court building in Lower Manhattan on faith, and hear their footsteps echo across a vast marble lobby before they finally glimpse a set of wooden double doors near a staircase leading down to a goblin-dark basement.

headline: ‘Photography Is My Wife, Music Is My Mistress’
text: Mark Seliger has been among the hardest-working men in the celebrity portrait business over the last quarter century, photographing thousands of boldface names, from President Obama and the Dalai Lama to Jay-Z and Johnny Cash.

headline: Rodriguez’s Suspension, by the Numbers
text: From home runs to earnings, some facts about Alex Rodriguez's career in the wake of his suspension by Major League Baseball.

headline: Stars, Gold, Dung Beetles and Us
text: Who was it that first said that people are stardust?

headline: ‘Teen Beach Movie’ Gets Big Ratings for Disney
text: “Teen Beach Movie” is a certified smash. Disney Channel said on Monday that about 13.5 million people had watched the beach party musical, which had its premiere on July 19. That total includes the number of viewers who watched it live (8.4 million) and a week’s worth of DVR playback viewing, a standard industry measuring stick.

headline: A Return to the Lineup and a Fight to Stay
text: CHICAGO — Alex Rodriguez sat in the far corner of the Yankees clubhouse Monday afternoon, staring at a computer screen displaying video images of Chicago White Sox pitcher Jose Quintana, whom he would soon be facing. A mere 30 minutes had passed since Major League Baseball had announced Rodriguez was being suspended for 211 games in connection with its months-long doping investigation, but Rodriguez, the 38-year-old third baseman, appeared unfazed.

headline: Bridges Under Construction at Newport Jazz
text: NEWPORT, R.I. — The Newport Jazz Festival, which ended Sunday at Fort Adams State Park here, is 59 now. It had early brilliance followed by middle-age aesthetic confusion, edging into pop and smooth jazz. Over the last nine years, it has corrected its course, entering a new period of steadiness and dignity as it seeks a new framing of jazz — and of its own audience.

headline: Nursing Homes’ Dental Problems
text: Catherine Saint Louis speaks about why daily oral care in nursing facilities is almost universally overlooked, and why that can lead to dangerous complications for residents.

headline: Fresh Memo From a Desk Full of Song
text: SALZBURG, Austria — The Salzburg Festival is celebrating Wagner’s 200th birthday with a fresh, charming and perceptive new production of “Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg,” which opened here at the Grosses Festspielhaus on Friday. The conductor Daniele Gatti, who won many new admirers for his performances of Wagner’s “Parsifal” at the Metropolitan Opera last season, drew a full-bodied and intriguingly intense performance of this composer’s sunniest score from the great Vienna Philharmonic. The cast over all was admirable, especially the distinguished German baritone Michael Volle, who brought the requisite gravitas and poignant vulnerability to his portrayal of the wise widower Hans Sachs, a shoemaker and the most beloved member of the guild of master singers in the medieval German city of Nürnberg, where the story is set.

headline: Small Troupe With Outsize Talent? You’re In
text: In 1998, about a year after Jessica Lang had graduated from the dance division of Juilliard, she went back to ask Benjamin Harkarvy, then the division’s director, for advice. She was interested in choreography, she told him, and since the first piece she had created had been well received, she thought she should start her own troupe. “Just because you made one good work,” Mr. Harkarvy replied, “doesn’t mean you should have a company.”

headline: Florida to Execute a Paranoid Schizophrenic
text: The Supreme Court has declined to stay the execution of John Errol Ferguson, who is scheduled to die at 6 p.m. Monday evening in Florida.

headline: In the Opera’s Shadow, Another Gem
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — The Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival presents top-flight performers in attractive theaters in the historic heart of the city each summer and has a strong following among locals and tourists alike. Sadly, it is overshadowed in national awareness, by the Santa Fe Opera, with its spectacular open-air theater a few miles north of the city and its fancy productions. Critics flock to the opera, often without even bothering to see what is playing at the chamber festival.

headline: More Music From Santa Fe
text: The Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival should not be overlooked in favor of the Santa Fe Opera.

headline: CDs From Leslie Grace, Derrick Hodge and Tye Tribbett
text: LESLIE GRACE

headline: A Reconsideration of Katue Kitasono, Japan’s Great Poet of Surrealism
text: Until recently, Japan’s artistic reputation in the United States was limited mainly to the very old and the very new: Edo-period ceramics and paintings, and the manga-inspired “Superflat” movement of the 1990s that was ushered in by Takashi Murakami. Recently, however, American curators have been taking stock of Japan’s compelling postwar output with 2013 exhibits like “Tokyo 1955-1970: A New Avant-Garde” at MoMA, the Guggenheim’s “Gutai: Splendid Playground,” about the progressive art collective that operated in the Kansai region, and last year’s Yayoi Kusama pop art extravaganza at the Whitney.

headline: Festival of Short Plays Inspired by Trayvon Martin Case
text: The New Black Fest, which supports innovative plays by and about black people, has brought together seven playwrights to create six plays about race and privilege in the United States in the wake of the Trayvon Martin case.

headline: Anita Lo’s Shanghainese Feast
text: Anita Lo, chef and owner of Annisa in Greenwich Village, visits Flushing, Queens, to sample dishes that have inspired her cooking.

headline: Anita Lo Finds Memories and Inspiration
text: Anita Lo was riding a train to Flushing, Queens, when she started talking about a creation of hers that, over the last 13 years or so, has become one of the must-try dishes in New York City: the foie gras soup dumpling at Annisa, her restaurant in Greenwich Village.

headline: Cruise Lines Report Crime Statistics
text: Three major cruise lines have posted on their Web sites the number of serious crimes reported on their ships, the first public airing of such statistics. The lines, Royal Caribbean Cruises, Carnival Corporation and Norwegian Cruise Line, released the figures in the wake of a Senate bill that would require all cruise lines that use American ports to report crime figures. (Currently, the Coast Guard reports crimes that are no longer under investigation by the F.B.I.)

headline: Biden Vacationing in the Hamptons
text: EAST HAMPTON — The Hamptons will play host to not one but two potential 2016 presidential aspirants this month, with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. arriving this week for a vacation in Southampton. Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton has rented a house for August here in East Hampton, the next township over.

headline: Detroit Manager Hires Christie’s to Appraise Holdings at City Art Museum
text: The city of Detroit, which has filed for bankruptcy, has formally hired the international auction house Christie’s to appraise part of the city-owned art collection held by the Detroit Institute of Arts, the auction house said Monday.Any decision about whether to sell the art to satisfy creditors has not been made, city officials have said, though all the city’s assets are being evaluated in light of the situation in Detroit, the largest American city ever to file for bankruptcy.

headline: How A-Rod Doesn’t Add Up
text: Before I played a single game of professional baseball, I was a fan. If my brother and I weren’t chipping the paint off our parents’ garage door with wayward pitches during an extra-inning session of Wiffle ball, we were playing simulated games like Strat-O-Matic or baseball on our then popular ’80s Intellivision video game system.

headline: Going Abroad, to Cut Health Costs
Rock Throwing in the West Bank: A ‘Rite of Passage’?
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Airport Screenings
The BP Settlement: How the Lawyers See Their Role

headline: Japan: U.S. Military Helicopter Crashes on Okinawa
text: One crew member was missing after a United States military helicopter crashed during a training exercise on Japan’s southern island of Okinawa on Monday, the Air Force said. The three other crew members were in stable condition after the HH-60 helicopter crashed in an uninhabited training area on an American base, the Air Force said. No Okinawan civilians were injured, the local news media said. Still, Japanese officials in Tokyo expressed concern that the accident could stoke anger against the large American military presence on Okinawa. Defense Minister Itsunori Onodera demanded an investigation.

headline: Street Style: Cut Outs
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of August 5.

headline: Jean-Claude Suares, 71, a Daring Times Op-Ed Artist
text: Jean-Claude Suares, an illustrator who radically altered the way editorial illustration was used at The New York Times as the first art director of its Op-Ed page, died on July 30 in Engelwood, N.J. He was 71.

headline: Triple Play: Week 18 Results
text: When Cardinals dropped the first four of their five-game series against the Pirates last week, the 12.5 percent of respondents who predicted St. Louis would relinquish first place looked good. The Cardinals rallied to win three of their final four games of the week, but it wasn’t enough to overtake Pittsburgh in the National League Central.

headline: Benefits of Breast-Feeding
Sony Rejects Loeb Proposal for Splitting Off Entertainment Unit
text: Updated, 6:31 a.m. | Sony said late on Monday that it planned to keep all of its vast entertainment arm, rejecting a proposal by one of its biggest investors, the activist hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb.

headline: Canada: Escaped Snake Kills 2 Children, Police Say
text: Two children were killed in their sleep by a python that escaped from a pet shop, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police said Monday. The boys, 5 and 7 years old, were sleeping over at a friend’s apartment above the store in Campbellton, New Brunswick, when the snake apparently made its way in through a ventilation shaft. An autopsy will determine the exact cause of death, but a police spokeswoman said it appeared that the children had been suffocated. It was not immediately clear how the snake had escaped from the store, but police officers recaptured it.

headline: Dying Lawyer Asks Judge to Free Her From Prison
text: Lynne F. Stewart, the outspoken former defense lawyer and a polarizing figure in the criminal justice system, is fighting her final battle.

headline: New York Tells Online Lenders to Abide by State’s Interest Rate Cap
text: Government authorities are homing in on a lucrative loophole that allows online lenders to offer short-term loans at interest rates that often exceed 500 percent annually, the latest front in a crackdown on the payday lending industry.

headline: Bankers’ Pay Deferrals Are Tougher in Europe
text: Soon after the financial crisis, international regulators identified Wall Street’s lush pay packages as one of the culprits and proposed an overhaul that was meant to apply equally to employees of American investment banks and their big European rivals.

headline: Lawyers of Sound Mind?
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — LAST week, swarms of sun-starved, soon-to-be lawyers emerged from hiding to celebrate completing the bar exam. Passing the exam, however, won’t guarantee them admission to the bar. They also have to demonstrate that they possess the requisite fitness and moral character for the practice of law.

headline: Striking Olympic Gold
text: Imagine this: it’s the opening ceremony of the 2014 Winter Games in Sochi, Russia. A huge television event, watched the world over. The American Olympians join the proud march of nations. They’re our emissaries, our exemplars. And as the television cameras zoom in on Team U.S.A., one of its members quietly pulls out a rainbow flag, no bigger than a handkerchief, and holds it up. Not ostentatiously high, but just high enough that it can’t be mistaken.

headline: Beyond the Airport: The T.S.A.’s VIPR Team
text: The Transportation Security Administration issued justification for conducting searches outside airports without probable cause, but an audit raised issues about the training and deployments of the VIPR teams.

headline: Michael J. Morwood, Archaeologist Who Helped Find ‘New Human,’ Dies at 62
text: Ten years ago, Mike Morwood was a leader of archaeological excavations in a limestone cavern on the Indonesian island of Flores, about midway between the continents of Asia and Australia. That was when he had the experience of a lifetime, as he said many times, the discovery of what he called “a new human.”

headline: A Heisman Winner, and a Rule Book, Under Fire
text: The fallout from the latest episode in Johnny Manziel’s dizzying, TMZ-chronicled off-season extended beyond his inner circle and beyond the campus of Texas A&M and into the offices of the N.C.A.A. That organization, which governs college sports, said nothing about Manziel on Monday, and yet its silence did little to dim the continued criticism lobbed in its direction.

headline: Marilyn Monroe’s Star Still Shines in Ad Campaigns
text: FOR an advertising campaign that aims to appeal to women from 18 to 25, Sexy Hair, the hair care brand, did not hire a celebrity spokeswoman within that age bracket like Selena Gomez or Emma Watson. Rather, the brand is featuring an actress who, had she not died in 1962, would be 87 today: Marilyn Monroe.

headline: With No New iPad, Tablet Market Takes a Dip
text: Last fall, Apple introduced both the fourth generation of its popular iPad tablet and a new, mini version. Tech industry researchers figured the double release would mean no new iPads to lift Apple’s sales in the first half of 2013, as had been the case in other years.

headline: T.S.A. Expands Duties Beyond Airport Security
text: WASHINGTON — As hundreds of commuters emerged from Amtrak and commuter trains at Union Station on a recent morning, an armed squad of men and women dressed in bulletproof vests made their way through the crowds.

headline: Across Forbidden Border, Doctors in Israel Quietly Tend to Syria’s Wounded
text: NAHARIYA, Israel — The 3-year-old girl cried “Mama, Mama” over and over as a stranger rocked her and tried to comfort her. She had been brought from Syria to the government hospital in this northern Israeli town five days earlier, her face blackened by what doctors said was probably a firebomb or a homemade bomb.

headline: A French Town Bridges the Gap Between Muslims and Non-Muslims
text: ROUBAIX, France — Wearing head scarves and long skirts, the women glide along the faded back streets of this poor French town as they make their way to the mosque to hear the last prayer of the evening.

headline: Groundwork Laid, Growers Turn to Hemp in Colorado
text: SPRINGFIELD, Colo. — Along the plains of eastern Colorado, on a patch of soil where his father once raised alfalfa, Ryan Loflin is growing a leafy green challenge to the nation’s drug laws.

headline: Art Donovan, a Behemoth of Modesty, Dies at 89
text: Art Donovan, a 300-pound tackle for the Baltimore Colts whose nimble brutality helped propel him to the Hall of Fame and his team to two championships in the 1950s, and whose humor-laced tales about himself and the game won him an equal helping of celebrity, died on Sunday in Baltimore. He was 89.

headline: What Killed Theory? (Wonkish)
text: Noah Smith has an interesting note on the “death of theory” in economics. Obviously that’s an exaggeration, but there has been a measurable decline in the number of papers that offer theoretical innovations as opposed to empirical analysis, and also a harder to measure but unmistakable shift in the profession’s value structure, with empiricists reaping greater rewards and theorists valued less.

headline: In Baseball Suspensions, Justice or a Scapegoat?
text: Is Alex Rodriguez even the right target, after decades of steroid abuse in major league baseball?

headline: Newspapers Are Billionaires’ Latest Trophies
text: Just $250 million.

headline: Falling Tree Shatters Lives and Dreams of a Family
text: The Dikov family keeps an album of photos that document the love story of their son, Aleksander, and his wife, Yingyi Li-Dikov. On each page, they beam, always hugging. In one, Ms. Li-Dikov kneels over a heart drawn in the sand, the initials A and Y at its center.

headline: Boston Trial of Crime Boss Is Set to Go to the Jury
text: BOSTON — After 36 days and the testimony of 72 witnesses, the lawyers in the criminal trial of James (Whitey) Bulger made closing arguments to the jury on Monday, with the defense not contesting that Mr. Bulger was a gangland criminal of the first order.

headline: A Big Name Back in the Lineup, but Crossed Off Baseball’s List
text: CHICAGO — Alex Rodriguez always wanted to be the face of Major League Baseball. That desire consumed him from a very young age, when he embarked on a path of relentless achievement. Fame and money and records — he wanted it all.

headline: The A-Rod Problem
text: I started writing a column for The Times about a decade ago, and I endured a tough first few months. That was, in part, because, like anybody starting a new job, I wasn’t sure I could pull it off.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Terrorism and the Embassies
text: The Obama administration’s decision to close nearly two dozen embassies and issue a worldwide travel alert was difficult to quarrel with. We obviously do not have access to the intelligence that was the basis for the extraordinary closures, but American officials who do claim that they uncovered one of the most serious plots against United States and other Western interests since Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: The Washington Post: Years of Triumph and Siege
text: Through eight decades of family ownership, The Washington Post became a journalistic powerhouse and the hub of a sprawling corporation with interests beyond media. But its foundations were shaken by the challenges of the Internet age.

headline: The Players Who Accepted a 50-Game Penalty
text: Twelve players accepted 50-game suspensions from Major League Baseball on Monday in connection with the investigation into the Biogenesis clinic. Here are snapshots of all 12.

headline: Rebels Gain Control of Government Air Base in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Rebel fighters on Monday swept into a sprawling government air base in northern Syria where isolated government troops had fought off their attacks for nearly a year, and by early Tuesday controlled almost all the base, seizing several tanks and other munitions and taking soldiers prisoner, rebel and opposition groups said.

headline: Plan Backed by Thompson to Invest in Northern Ireland Ended at a Cost
text: It sounded like a perfectly grand idea.

headline: Baseball Lowers the Boom
text: Major League Baseball suspended 13 players on Monday for violating antidoping rules, in its most sweeping and consequential enforcement action of the steroid era. The suspensions were expected but, nonetheless, striking because included was baseball’s highest-paid star, Alex Rodriguez of the Yankees, who received the longest suspension ever: 211 games, through the 2014 season.

headline: It’s Not Just Silvio Berlusconi
text: If the serial high jinks of Silvio Berlusconi were the sole cause of Italy’s prolonged malaise, his conviction for criminal tax fraud last week might have signaled better times ahead. But the three-time prime minister has hardly been the only reason for Italy’s economic underperformance and irresponsible political culture.

headline: Comforting the Loan-Sharked Brethren
text: Britain’s new archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Justin Welby, is inviting the humblest of money lenders, credit unions, into the temple. His aim is to undercut the “payday lender” industry that routinely and notoriously charges usurious interest rates to the working poor, and is now the subject of national scandal.

headline: Texas State Senator Says Bid for Governor Is Possible
text: WASHINGTON — Wendy Davis, the Texas state senator who captured the national spotlight with an 11-hour filibuster against restricting abortion rights, turned up in Washington on Monday with the news that she was considering a run for governor.

headline: Lhota’s War on Rats Includes Mint Bags
text: Visiting a distributor of building maintenance supplies in Queens on Monday, Joseph J. Lhota thrust a 13-gallon trash bag toward the face of a reporter.

headline: A Mogul Gets a Landmark in the Capital
text: SEATTLE — The Washington of Jeffrey P. Bezos has been the one of disruptive technology, fleece jackets and software engineers. He has shown little interest in the Washington of politics, power suits and Woodward and Bernstein.

headline: The Washington Post Reaches the End of the Graham Era
text: In late 2012, Donald E. Graham, the chairman and chief executive of The Washington Post Company, met with the paper’s publisher, Katharine Weymouth, to look at the paper’s future for the next three years. Their assessment troubled them.

headline: The Plot to Rule College Sports
text: “Be careful for what you wish for,” goes the proverb. “You just might get it.”

headline: One Weiner Idea: Cameras for the Police
text: Police officers on patrol would be required to wear miniature cameras. New Yorkers earning less than $40,000 would not pay city taxes. Helicopter rides over Manhattan would be banned for tourists and commuters.

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Make Off With Things
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — You have to watch her, that Lynn Lempel. You turn your back for one second and she’s making off with just about everything.

headline: Cannes Villa Is Expected to Play Role in Bribery Case Against Chinese Ex-Official
text: BEIJING — More than a decade ago, a mysterious foreign buyer looking for property in France settled on a villa along the sun-bleached Riviera. The house later became tied to a British businessman, Neil Heywood, whose death in 2011 in China set in motion a political crisis within the upper ranks of the Communist Party.

headline: Dog Park Opens With Help From Mayor’s Best Friends
text: They reside a rubber ball’s throw from Fifth Avenue, take chauffeured laps around town in a black sport utility vehicle, and occasionally scamper into a helicopter for a day trip.

headline: Who Just Bought The Washington Post?
text: Jeffrey P. Bezos is the founder of Amazon.com. He has spent his career relying on steady growth but says he is ready to push The Post to compete in a changing online world.

headline: Court Strikes Down New York City’s ‘Prevailing Wage’ Law
text: Handing a victory to the administration of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, a State Supreme Court judge on Monday struck down a law passed by the City Council last year that would have raised wages for janitors, security guards and other building service workers in structures that received substantial government subsidies or where the city was a major tenant.

headline: Chicago Sees Pension Crisis Drawing Near
text: CHICAGO — Corporations are moving in, and housing prices are looking better across the region. There has been a slight uptick in population. But a crushing problem lurks beneath the signs of economic recovery in Chicago: one of the most poorly funded pension systems among the nation’s major cities. Its plight threatens to upend the finances of President Obama’s hometown, now run by his former chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel.

headline: Senator Amplifies Her Voice to Referee Fiscal Showdown
text: WASHINGTON — Seven months into Senator Barbara A. Mikulski’s new assignment as chairwoman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, there is already a saying among members: “We loved Byrd, we respected Inouye, we fear Barbara.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, August 6, 2013
text: “I am happily living in ‘the other Washington,’ where I have a day job that I love.”

headline: In the Women’s Game, Solheim Cup Is Behind the Times
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland

headline: Liu Defiant Over Funding Setback
text: John C. Liu, New York City’s comptroller, said his mayoral campaign would continue after a campaign finance board denied him matching public funds.

headline: At 28, Rookie Refuses to Focus on Time Lost
text: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga. — As a nearly three-hour practice held first in searing heat and then under foreboding skies adjourned, the Atlanta Falcons linebackers trudged over to a phalanx of autograph seekers who extended items of various shapes, sizes and pliability to be signed.

headline: In Debate, Lesser-Known Candidates Struggle to Shake Booker’s Confidence
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — With just a week to go before the primary, the first debate among the four Democrats running for United States Senate in New Jersey had been regarded as a chance to shake up the dynamics of the race, allowing three lesser-known candidates to sharpen their differences with the front-runner, Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark.

headline: New York Ties Plentiful Among the Suspended
text: Six of the 13 players suspended Monday by Major League Baseball shared one notable thread: they either played or were on track to play in New York.

headline: Notice and Notoriety
text: As a Yankee, Alex Rodriguez won a World Series title in 2009 and Most Valuable Player awards in 2005 and 2007, but he might be better remembered for a number of bizarre moments in pinstripes.

headline: Cruz Suspension Leaves Rangers With Huge Hole
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The Texas Rangers — like seven other teams that on Monday had players suspended by Major League Baseball for their ties to the defunct Biogenesis clinic — had to make contingency plans.

headline: Modern Picnic Wares for Photo-Worthy Alfresco Dining
text: Too often, picnic wares are an afterthought — cheap wicker baskets, plastic gingham blankets, throwaway utensils. Of course, the primary attractions of do-it-yourself alfresco dining are a lavish spread, a natural setting and good company. But now, thanks to a handful of artisans, there are attractive, handcrafted goods for a decidedly modern (and Instagram-friendly) outdoor culinary experience.

headline: Study Links TV Viewership and Twitter Conversations
text: A first-of-its-kind study by Nielsen has affirmed what nearly everyone in the television industry already suspected: Twitter conversations sometimes do cause people to turn on the TV.

headline: The Sacrosanct Mortgage Interest Deduction
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the forthcoming book “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”
