text: altruistic •\ˌal-trü-ˈis-tik\• adjective

headline: Pettitte, in Shortest Outing of Season, Is Knocked Around by White Sox
text: CHICAGO — Alex Rodriguez entered, Derek Jeter exited, and very little changed. Andy Pettitte had another difficult start Monday and the Yankees lost, 8-1, to the Chicago White Sox, a team that had lost 10 straight games.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
text: 6:50 A.M. (Cinemax) MATCH POINT (2005) Chris (Jonathan Rhys Meyers), an Irish tennis player recently retired from the professional circuit, climbs the British social ladder after taking a job at a London club, helping its rich members polish their strokes. Soon, he has befriended Tom (Matthew Goode), an heir to a business fortune; has wooed his sister, Chloe (Emily Mortimer); and maneuvered himself into the family firm and into the family as Tom’s brother-in-law. But then Chris meets Tom’s fiancée, a scrappy American actress, Nola (Scarlett Johansson, above, with Mr. Rhys Meyers), and suddenly the temperature of his life increases from a polite simmer to a full sexual boil. “What passes between Chris and Nola is not only desire, but also recognition, which makes their connection especially volatile,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, describing this drama as “a Champagne cocktail laced with strychnine.” He added: “As their affair advances, Ms. Johansson and Mr. Rhys Meyers manage some of the best acting seen in a Woody Allen movie in a long time, escaping the archness and emotional disconnection that his writing often imposes. It is possible to identify with both of them — and to feel an empathetic twinge as they are ensnared in the consequences of their own heedlessness — without entirely liking either one. But it is the film’s brisk, chilly precision that makes it so bracingly pleasurable. The gloom of random, meaningless existence has rarely been so much fun, and Mr. Allen’s bite has never been so sharp, or so deep. A movie this good is no laughing matter.”

headline: A Reunion With My Younger, Hitchhiking Self
text: Summer of 1972: a slender 19-year-old (curly black hair, florid beard, 155 pounds) stood beside a Montana highway, thumb in the air. A truck pulled over. “Going as far as Missoula,” the driver said, opening the cargo doors. In the hold, others crouched, blinking back at him. “Thanks, man,” he said, hopping in. The doors shut; the latch turned.

headline: News Quiz | August 6, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: U.S. Denounces Vietnam’s New Limits on Dissent on Internet
text: HONG KONG — American officials criticized the Vietnamese government on Tuesday for its new limits on political dissent on the Internet, citing a decree that appears to restrict people from sharing news articles on social media and personal Web sites.

headline: Australian Central Bank Cuts Key Rate to Record Low
text: HONG KONG — The Australian central bank on Tuesday cut rates for the eighth time in less than two years in a bid to improve sluggish growth as a boom in mining investment over the past decade comes to an end.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 6, 2013
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the book review “Our Bodies, Our Ink.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Baseball Suspends Rodriguez and 12 Others
text: In “M.L.B. Suspends Rodriguez, 12 Others in Doping Investigation,” Steve Eder writes about baseball’s biggest single-day drug action in the sport’s history.

headline: U.S. and Britain Withdraw Personnel from Yemen
text: LONDON — After days of alarms and embassy lockdowns, the United States and Britain on Tuesday stepped up security precautions in Yemen, with Washington ordering “nonemergency” government personnel to leave and the Foreign Office in London saying it has withdrawn its diplomatic staff in the capital of Sana “due to increased security concerns.”

headline: Did We Waste a Recession?
text: Five years ago this month, before Lehman Brothers imploded and the global economy lurched to a halt, Fannie Mae issued a report that encapsulated the financial system’s biggest problem. The mortgage-finance company, which was wobbling on account of rising defaults, tried to reassure investors that it had $47 billion in capital, which was considerably more than the $30 million required by law. At the time, the report’s authors seemed to fear that some investors might think Fannie was too cautious. In any event, a month later, that protection seemed like a joke. Fannie may have conformed to the rules, but the rules didn’t conform to reality. The lender and its brother company, Freddie Mac, were declared insolvent and handed over to the U.S. government.

headline: Legal Paperwork and Legal Residences
text: Craig Reaves, a former president of the National Academy of Elder Law Attorneys, practices elder law in Kansas City, Mo., and fields occasional questions from New Old Age readers. Submit yours to newoldage@nytimes.com. Please limit your queries to general legal issues, as Mr. Reaves cannot respond with individualized legal advice.

headline: 5 Indian Soldiers Killed in Disputed Kashmir Region
text: NEW DELHI — Indian military officials said Tuesday that five Indian soldiers had been killed the night before when Pakistani troops attacked an Indian post on the disputed border that divides Kashmir into Indian- and Pakistani-administered parts.

headline: Daily Report: Tech Mogul in Deal for a Landmark in the Capital
text: Jeffrey P. Bezos, the founder of Amazon, will purchase The Washington Post, in a deal that took the newspaper industry by surprise, Nick Wingfield and David Streitfeld report.

headline: Credit Agricole’s Profit Soars After Bank Leaves Greece
text: Paris – Crédit Agricole, the big French bank, said on Tuesday that its second-quarter profit grew more than 12 times from the period a year earlier after it sold its Greek and Italian units, which had weighed on results.

headline: New York Today: Cold Wave
text: Updated, 12:04 p.m. | Technically, there is no meteorological definition of a cold snap, but New York Today is hereby declaring one.

headline: Standard Chartered’s First-Half Profit Fell 24%
text: LONDON – Standard Chartered reported on Tuesday that profit fell 24 percent in the first half of the year, as the firm took a $1 billion charge related to its operations in South Korea.

headline: I Want to Make a Profit
text: I have a problem: my business is not very profitable. Over the last three full years, 2010-12, our sales totaled $5,606,056. But our profits were only $81,646. That’s a pathetic 1.4-percent profit margin.

headline: Sheriff to Face Hospital Executive in Detroit Mayoral Runoff
text: DETROIT — Benny Napoleon, the sheriff of Wayne County, and Mike Duggan, the former chief executive of the Detroit Medical Center, will vie for the post of mayor after getting the most votes in a crowded field of primary candidates Tuesday in this blighted city seeking bankruptcy protection.

headline: Student Crossword | The Stock Market
text: Learn more about the stock market by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Hezbollah’s Choice
text: BEIRUT — When Hassan Nasrallah, the charismatic leader of Hezbollah, the Shiite political party and militia, gave a public speech in Beirut on Friday — something he rarely does these days for fear of assassination — he told his Arab audience to stay focused on resisting Israel. “We the Shiites of Ali bin Abi Taleb will not abandon Palestine,” he declared to the rapturous applause of several thousand supporters in a party stronghold in the southern suburb of the capital. Shiites consider Ali bin Abi Taleb, the cousin and son-in-law of the Prophet Muhammad, to be his rightful successor rather than Abu Bakr, who became Islam’s leader upon the Prophet’s death.

headline: Intersection: Beach Style in Rockaway
text: Sully Romero, who grew up in the Rockaways, describes herself as a “'90s, Salvation Army, thrifter babe, tomboy, New Yorker.”

headline: Indian Rupee Falls to Record Low
text: HONG KONG — The Indian rupee lurched to a record low against the dollar on Tuesday, shrugging off recent measures aimed at propping it up and underscoring the severe problems facing the economy as the country heads toward an election next year.

headline: Bezos Buys a Landmark in Washington
text: Jeffrey P. Bezos, the founder of Amazon.com, has agreed to buy The Washington Post for $250 million in cash, in a deal that has shocked the newspaper industry. Donald E. Graham, chairman and chief executive of The Washington Post Company, said he and the publisher “decided to sell only after years of familiar newspaper-industry challenges made us wonder if there might be another owner who would be better for the Post.” The sale is expected to be completed within 60 days.

headline: In Performance: Young Jean Lee of ‘We’re Gonna Die’
text: The downtown playwright Young Jean Lee asks some darkly comic existential questions in her pop-music cabaret “We’re Gonna Die.” Charles Isherwood called the show a “bizarre combination of pop concert and autobiographical lament for the human condition” when it ran at Joe’s Pub in 2011. It’s now playing (through Aug. 17) at the Claire Tow Theater at Lincoln Center, and is also available as an album. In this scene, Ms. Lee performs “Henry,” a monologue about a painful breakup.

headline: Spotted With a Man Who Wasn’t Her Husband
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Obama Outlines Plans for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
text: PHOENIX — President Obama hailed both this city’s and the country’s comeback from the housing bust on Tuesday, and said it was now time to reduce the federal role and risk in the mortgage market “to make sure the kind of crisis we went through never happens again.”

headline: Separatists Kill 13 in Southwestern Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Baluch separatists on Tuesday claimed responsibility for the killing of 13 people who had been abducted a day earlier in a remote area of southwestern Pakistan.

headline: Laura Bell Bundy Joins ‘Anger Management’
text: In the words of that future courtroom star Elle Woods: Omigod, you guys. Charlie Sheen has found his newest romantic challenge, at least for the fictional capacity of his FX sitcom “Anger Management,” and she will be played by Laura Bell Bundy, the Tony Award-nominated star of the “Legally Blonde” musical.

headline: Crackling Over the Radio, Spotter’s Voice Guides Syrian Rebels
text: They call him the Watchtower, although the nickname does not quite fit. He is the eyes and voice not of one man in one place, but of many men scattered across the northern Syrian countryside.

headline: Soros Endorses de Blasio for Mayor
text: In a move that could excite left-leaning New Yorkers — but turn away some more centrist ones — the billionaire financier and liberal icon George Soros endorsed Bill de Blasio, the public advocate, on Tuesday as the next mayor of New York.

headline: George W. Bush Released from Hospital After Heart Procedure
text: Updated, 10:39 a.m. | Former President George W. Bush was released from a Dallas hospital on Wednesday morning, a day after undergoing a surgical procedure to open up a clogged artery.

headline: The Growing Popularity of Having Surgery Overseas
text: As health care costs in the United States rise, an increasing number of Americans are going overseas for elective procedures, or are at least considering that possibility.

headline: Biogenesis Day at the Ballpark
text: In the end, the lasting feeling on baseball’s big drug day was sadness. It was sad to read the apologies from the players caught, suspended and accepting their fate. It was sad that some were so obscure that they did not need to apologize. It was sad that people in Chicago bought tickets to a White Sox game only to jeer the saddest spectacle of all, the Yankees’ Alex Rodriguez left on his own to tilt at the windmills of his imagination.

headline: PolitiFact and the Shape of the Planet, Deficit Edition
text: Steve Benen catches PolitiFact falling down on the job. But it’s actually even worse than he says.

headline: Another Bad Story Bites The Dust
text: One of the remarkable things about the ongoing economic crisis is the endless search for explanations of something that’s actually quite simple — the sluggish pace of recovery. You have a large overhang of private debt; you have a still-depressed housing sector; and you have contractionary fiscal policy. Add to this the well-established fact that recovery tends to be slow after recessions caused not by tight money but by private-sector overreach, and there’s just no mystery that needs explaining.

headline: Two Cars Destined for Pebble Beach Auction Shown in Manhattan
text: Two cars destined for the auction block at Bonhams Quail Lodge auction during the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance on Aug. 16 showed up at Bonhams’ Madison Avenue offices last week for a sneak preview. They were a one-off 1953 Ferrari 250 Europa Coupé and a rare 1931 Bentley 4½ Liter Supercharged Le Mans car.

headline: Lindsay Lohan, Talk-Show Host
text: On the celebrity rehabilitation tour, “Chelsea Lately” is a halfway house on the way to Oprah Winfrey. And Lindsay Lohan, fresh out of rehab and promoting a low-budget curiosity of a film directed by Paul Schrader, gratefully filled in for Chelsea Handler as host of the E! talk show on Monday.

headline: Pension Reform Could Disrupt Investment Funds
text: Detroit’s financial woes, exacerbated by underfunded pension liabilities, have brought renewed scrutiny to public pension plans. Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah, and others have suggested overhauling these plans to shift more responsibility to the private sector. Private insurance companies would assume responsibility for these defined benefit plans, offering annuities to beneficiaries in exchange for employer-paid premiums.

headline: Today in Small Business: Budget Bedlam Looming
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: How Sleep Loss Adds to Weight Gain
text: Losing sleep tends to make people eat more and gain weight, and now a new study suggests that one reason may be the impact that sleep deprivation has on the brain.

headline: Tech Sector Responds to Bezos Deal for The Post
text: For Jeffrey P. Bezos, Washington has been a place of software engineers and Starbucks coffee, not power suits and politics. But, from his tech frontier in Seattle where the company he founded, Amazon.com, is, Mr. Bezos has bridged those far-flung worlds, Nick Wingfield and David Streitfeld write.

headline: Veterans Group, Flying a Flag With a Message, Ruffles a City
text: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. — The way Moises Valencia describes things, it began with a simple idea.

headline: Serpico Subpoenaed in Another Whistle-Blower’s Suit
text: In the four decades since New York City formed the Knapp Commission to investigate sweeping charges of corruption in the Police Department, Frank Serpico, the police officer whose complaints led to the commission, has had no real contact with city or police officials.

headline: Aug. 6: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Kerry, Hagel and Russians Will Meet on Issues Imperiling Obama-Putin Visit
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry and Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel plan to meet here in Washington with their Russian counterparts on Friday for a day of talks that could determine the fate of a September summit meeting between President Obama and the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Iran’s New President Calls for Nuclear Talks Without Rejecting Direct U.S. Role
text: TEHRAN — Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, on Tuesday used his first news conference to call for serious negotiations to solve the decade-long dispute over the country’s nuclear program, and he repeatedly suggested openness to direct talks with the United States, an idea that until recently had been unthinkable for many years.

headline: Trailer: ‘Mother of George’
text: A preview of the drama directed by Andrew Dosunmu, about a West African immigrant living in Brooklyn.

headline: Albuquerque’s Role on ‘Breaking Bad’
text: Vince Gilligan now considers Albuquerque a character of “Breaking Bad,” the television series whose final eight-episode run will begin on AMC on Sunday.

headline: New York Comedy Festival Sets 2013 Lineup
text: Performances by Wanda Sykes, John Mulaney and Whitney Cummings, and a conversation between Larry David and David Steinberg are among the highlights of this year’s New York Comedy Festival, whose organizers announced its 2013 lineup on Tuesday. The festival, which is now in its 10th year and is presented in association with Comedy Central and produced by Carolines on Broadway, will run from Nov. 6 through Nov. 10. Among the announced events is a performance by Ms. Sykes (of “The New Adventures of Old Christine”) on Nov. 7 at the Beacon Theater. Nov. 8 will see performances by Nick Swardson, Bill Burr, Kathy Griffin and Ms. Cummings; and on Nov. 9, Mr. Mulaney (of “Saturday Night Live”), Jim Jefferies, Bill Maher and Anthony Jeselnik will perform at spaces including Town Hall, Carnegie Hall and the Beacon Theater. The conversation between Mr. David, the creator and star of HBO’s “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” and Mr. Steinberg, the longtime comic and host of Showtime’s “Inside Comedy,” will take place at Town Hall on Nov. 10.

headline: The Gun Report: August 6, 2013
text: A year ago yesterday, Wade Michael Page, a U.S. Army veteran and white supremacist, killed five men and one woman at a Sikh temple in Oak Creek, Wis., and wounded six others, including a police officer, before turning the gun on himself.

headline: Listen Up | The Singer-Songwriter Bill Callahan Makes a Foray Into Dub
text: “Expanding Dub”

headline: Defendant in Fort Hood Shooting Case Admits Being Gunman
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — Nearly four years after going on a deadly shooting rampage at the Fort Hood Army base here in 2009, Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan told a jury of senior Army officers on Tuesday that “the evidence will clearly show that I am the shooter.”

headline: Excerpt From 'Falstaff'
text: A clip from a performance of Verdi’s ”Falstaff” at the Salzburg Festival.

headline: Poor Children Show a Decline in Obesity Rate
text: After years of growing concern about obesity among children, federal researchers have found the clearest evidence yet that the epidemic may be turning a corner in young children from low-income families.

headline: Magazine Newsstand Sales Plummet, but Digital Editions Thrive
text: Magazines continued to struggle with sales of subscriptions and newsstand copies in the first half of 2013, but they made inroads in selling digital editions, according to data released on Tuesday.

headline: SAC Prosecutor Hits the Media Trail
text: Since Preet Bharara’s appointment in 2009 as the United States attorney in Manhattan, his office has racked up more than 70 insider-trading convictions. The press-savvy Mr. Bharara is also racking up the media appearances.

headline: Candy-Colored Headphones From Monster
text: With its Beats by Dr. Dre line, Monster helped lead the charge that made headphones fashionable for millions of young listeners. And when Beats and Monster parted ways in 2012, Monster wasted no time signing a partnership with NCredible Entertainment, a multimedia management brand founded by the entertainer Nick Cannon.

headline: A Waterproof Cover for the Samsung Galaxy S III
text: Now your Samsung Galaxy S III can go swimming with your iPhone 5.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Having it Both Ways on Birtherism
text: Via The Maddow Blog and Right Wing Watch

headline: The Guiding Hand Behind a Thriving Steel Maker
text: LINZ, Austria — From his office in a somewhat dated-looking building called the Blue Tower, Wolfgang Eder can look out over the Voestalpine steel mill complex that dominates this city.

headline: ‘NewsHour’ Appoints First Female Anchor Team
text: The PBS “NewsHour,” which was co-anchored for decades by the two men who created it, will soon be co-anchored by two women.

headline: Image of the Day: August 6
text: A view of the Ganges River in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh.

headline: Billionaires’ Battle Over LightSquared Breaks Into the Open
text: The hedge fund tycoon Philip A. Falcone may be down, just a month after regulators rejected his settlement over federal charges of market manipulation. But on Tuesday, he showed that he’s not out of the game yet.

headline: On Warhol’s Birthday, a Live Video Feed Streams From His Grave
text: Even Andy Warhol’s grave is getting its 15 minutes. Starting on Tuesday morning, the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh, along with the video network EarthCam, began a live video feed of the artist’s final resting place, to commemorate his birthday. Warhol, who died in 1987, would have been 85 on Tuesday.

headline: Giants Stay Home for Summer Camp
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Once upon a time, N.F.L. training camps were like other summer camps: dormitory-style rooms in a country setting, a day overloaded with physical activities, communal meals and lots of late-night bonding.

headline: Early Short Story by Stieg Larsson to Be Published
text: A short story by the 17-year-old Stieg Larsson will be published in English for the first time next year, possibly enticing fans of the best-selling Millennium trilogy that was released after Mr. Larsson’s death in 2004.

headline: Worker Bees on a Rooftop, Ignoring Urban Pleasures
text: On the rooftops above the office canyons of Midtown Manhattan, there is a corporate life for bees where new colonies pollinate green roofs and produce honey for the lucky tenants working below.

headline: Poor Record for Subsidiary I.P.O.’s a Factor in Sony’s Rejection of the Idea
text: Sony’s chief executive had a few numbers on his mind when he formally rejected a proposal by the activist hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb to partially spin off Sony’s entertainment unit.

headline: Liz Cheney and the Wyoming Challenge
text: The daughter of former Vice President Dick Cheney is running for a United States Senate seat in Wyoming in 2014, but many Republicans question the political wisdom of this move.

headline: The Cartes de Visite Craze
text: The most indelible images of the Civil War show us the ditches of Antietam, the fields of Gettysburg and the ruins of Richmond. They tell us about modern photography and modern war, but the staple photographs of the home front were not the battlefield views we now know so well. Cartes de visite, the 2 1/2-by-4-inch portraits that dominated commercial photography in the 1860s, both unified and contested wartime visions of the nation.

headline: Drawing the Line on Altering Human Minds
text: In my column this week, “Computer-Brain Interfaces Making Big Leaps,” I noted that a number of researchers and scientists were coming closer to technology usually reserved for science fiction: hacking our brains to remove unwanted and sad memories.

headline: Fishing License Becomes Issue for Liz Cheney in Wyoming Senate Race
text: It sounds like a small-bore infraction: Liz Cheney, a United States Senate candidate in Wyoming, bought a state fishing license last summer even though she had not lived in the state for a year, as required.

headline: Amazon Re-Enters Online Art Market
text: A day after the news that Amazon’s founder and chief executive, Jeff Bezos, is buying The Washington Post, his company officially entered another cultural arena: art. On Tuesday, the online retailer announced the start of Amazon Art, where customers can buy original and limited-edition art from more than 150 dealers and 4,500 artists, ranging in price from a $10 screen print by the up-and-comer Ryan Humphrey to a  $4.85 million painting by Norman Rockwell.

headline: A Travel Organizer for Families and Frequent Fliers
text: August is a time for families to wind down the summer with a final trip before school starts. Keeping on top of travel arrangements and changes is crucial.

headline: Special Delivery, of Sorts, for Wayward Dog Owners
text: BRUNETE, Spain — In the worldwide battle to get dog owners to clean up after their pets, enter Brunete, a middle-class suburb of Madrid fed up with dirty parks and sidewalks.

headline: Vegetables and Pasta: Summer Love
text: What’s for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: After Hours | Paulo Szot’s Outsize Broadway Grandeur
text: A major swath of New York fell in love with Paulo Szot when he appeared in the 2008 Lincoln Center revival of South Pacific. The mustachioed baritone won a Tony for his gravitas-laden turn as Emile de Becque, the French plantation owner who captures the heart of young Navy nurse Nellie Forbush. Last night, in the high-class-bordello setting of the Midtown supper club 54 Below, Szot, kicking off a weeklong stint there, captured several more hearts… of a certain age. Szot, who has a booming operatic voice and is built like a massive rectangle, swashbuckled into the room from the back, schmoozing his way to a stage where a jazz trio awaited him. Even amid his opening number, a playful mash-up of “Summertime” and “Too Darn Hot,” many a well-heeled matron shrieked or moaned aloud for him.

headline: Republicans, White Voters and Racial Polarization
text: This National Journal piece, the latest to misread Sean Trende’s columns on the “missing white voters” of 2012 as an argument that the G.O.P. should try to build a “whites-only” majority, reminds that I’ve been meaning to write about some of the various liberal responses to Trende’s argument. Not the responses saying that he’s factually or analytically wrong, but the responses that either imply or state that even if he were right that there are a lot of up-for-grabs white votes that the G.O.P. might pursue effectively, it would be immoral, tragic, and/or ruinously divisive if Republicans were to actually try to win this way.

headline: A Call for the Unofficial Mayors of New York
text: Updated, November 18, 2013 | We are no longer accepting submissions for unofficial mayors in the city. We received more than 200 nominations and have selected nine men and women affecting change in their communities. You can read their stories here. Thanks to everyone who participated!

headline: UBS Agrees to Settle Federal Claims in Mortgage Case
text: UBS agreed on Tuesday to pay $50 million to settle federal accusations that it misled investors about a complex mortgage security, a transaction that loomed over the government’s recent legal battle with a former Goldman Sachs trader blamed for his role in creating a similar security.

headline: Wheelies: The Power of Pickups Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: In Season Short on Star Power, Rodriguez’s Return Lifts Ratings on YES
text: Injuries have deprived the Yankees of nearly all of their star hitters for lengthy stretches this season. Power has been in short supply. And the starting pitching, most notably C. C. Sabathia, has largely underperformed.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Art in Hard Times
Sony Brushoff Leaves Loeb With Few Options
text: The tussle over Sony may be the most courteous shareholder battle ever. In May, the hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb respectfully suggested the company spin off a stake in its entertainment arm. Now, the Japanese group’s board has politely rejected the idea. But the activist appears to be digging in for the long haul.

headline: Bean Salad With Tomato Vinaigrette
text: What to do with summer’s oozing, overripe tomatoes? Make an intensely flavored vinaigrette.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Cloud Companies Face Fear-of-Spying Exodus
text: The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. While much of the tech and media industries pondered Jeffrey P. Bezos’s deal to buy The Washington Post, Facebook released a feature that re-surfaces old, but what it deems relevant, posts in a user’s news feed. Here’s what else we noticed today:

headline: To Every Vegetable’s Season, Another Season
text: I was strolling with Christopher Boswell in the vegetable gardens of the American Academy in Rome, where he is the chef, when he saved me from a rookie mistake.

headline: Facebook Adjusts Its News Feed to Bump Up Older Posts
text: The Facebook news feed is getting slightly less mysterious — and perhaps more relevant, too.

headline: Art Imitates Life, as a Villain Haunts a Stateside Parking Lot
text: The evil all but oozes from Alessandro Colla, who, as Richard III, shuffles across the asphalt in this year’s second offering from Shakespeare in the Parking Lot. The king’s body is damaged, of course. But, oh, his wicked mind: that’s always working.

headline: Fiona Shaw to Replace Deborah Warner in Directing Met Opera’s ‘Eugene Onegin’
text: Deborah Warner, the British director who was to have overseen the Metropolitan Opera’s new staging of “Eugene Onegin,” has withdrawn from the production. The Met, in a statement, said that she bowed out because of “an unexpected surgical procedure and the expected recovery time.”

headline: Justice Dept. Sues Bank of America Over Mortgage Securities
text: The Justice Department sued Bank of America on Tuesday, accusing the bank of defrauding investors by vastly understating the risks of the mortgages backing about $850 million in securities.

headline: Pennsylvania Gunman Feuded With Officials for Almost Two Decades Over Land
text: Angry that town officials in northeastern Pennsylvania took over his junk-strewn, wooded property at a sheriff’s sale last month, Rockne Newell opened fire at a township supervisors meeting on Monday night, killing three people and wounding two others before he was wrestled to the ground by two men, state police officials said on Tuesday.

headline: With Cooked Tomatoes, Stick With Cool Reds or Rosé
text: Raw tomatoes, high in acid, demand high-acid wines. But cooked-tomato dishes like this crostata are altogether mellower, and so welcome a wider range of wines. A high-acid wine like an unoaked barbera from Asti or Alba would still go beautifully, but so would a Sicilian nerello mascalese from Mount Etna or a good Provençal rosé. Serve the reds cool. White wines would work well, too, like a falanghina or fiano di Avellino from Campania, or a good sauvignon blanc on the herbal side. Personally, because I imagine the flavors of this crostata as broad rather than sharp, I would probably stick with reds or rosé. Other red options include Beaujolais, lighter pinot noirs like those from Sancerre or the range of light reds from northern Italy, like teroldego, lagrein, grignolino and those from the Valle d’Aosta.

headline: Confessions of a ‘Composeress’
text: What is the role of the ”woman composer” and why, after all these years, is she such a burning issue?

headline: A Murder Haunts a Rugged Coast
text: “Broadchurch” comes to BBC America on Wednesday, riding a wave of good tidings. The ratings in Britain this spring were very strong — just shy of what “Downton Abbey” earned in its first season — and the reviews were rhapsodic. Fox announced last week that it would develop a version of the show, even though the original is getting its own highly publicized American run.

headline: MP Taverna Astoria
text: Inside Michael Psilakis’s unrestrained take on a Greek taverna.

headline: Living in Lloyd Harbor
text: On Long Island’s north shore, a village with water views that come with a price.

headline: Lloyd Harbor, L.I.: This Market Is No Wading Pool
text: In May, after a dozen years in Manhattan, Brian and Kim Olson and their children left behind their Battery Park City rental for a meticulously renovated four-bedroom colonial they had bought for $1.775 million in Lloyd Harbor. Suddenly, the treks to the Hamptons that they had so consistently made from the city became a thing of the past. Mr. Olson, who grew up in this northwestern Suffolk County village an hour from Midtown, felt rejuvenated by his return, as if permanently on vacation.

headline: Indian Music Meets Jazz in Kipling’s Wild World
text: CHICAGO — The flora and fauna of India shimmer with eye-filling allure in the inventive new stage adaptation of “The Jungle Book,” having its premiere at the Goodman Theater here. Adapted from the Disney movie (based on the Rudyard Kipling stories) and directed by Mary Zimmerman, this modestly scaled and refreshingly spectacle-free family musical seeks to kindle children’s imaginations by softly blurring the line between man and beast, relying on the talents of designers and performers to create illusions rather than dazzling the senses with elaborate effects.

headline: A Second-Generation Ode to Greece
text: If there are tweezers in the kitchen of MP Taverna Astoria, they are banned from all tasks except, perhaps, yanking bones from branzino fillets before they go on the grill. Tweezers are definitely not asked to airlift feathery microgreens onto plates that endeavor to be meditations on negative space.

headline: How Should Gay Couples Fend Off Pressure to Marry?
text: Every other Tuesday, Steven Petrow, the author of “Steven Petrow’s Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners” (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience. Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

headline: Mayoral Race Is Awash With Clintons’ Friends
text: The race for mayor has been awkward for the Clinton family. Hillary Rodham Clinton’s close aide Huma Abedin is married to one of the contenders, Anthony D. Weiner, who has been damaged by his admission that he had a habit of sending sexually explicit messages and pictures to women over the Internet. And in all, Bill Clinton says, five people the family counts as friends are in the running for mayor.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Sudan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Sudan, India, Pakistan and Argentina.

headline: Deployment Factors Are Not Related to Rise in Military Suicides, Study Finds
text: In the largest study of its kind, military medical researchers have concluded that deployments to war zones and exposure to combat were not major factors behind a significant increase in suicides among military personnel from 2001 to 2008, according to a paper published on Tuesday.

headline: Bloomberg Sees Higher Costs in a Union-Friendly Mayor
text: Warning of the fiscal danger if New York City fails to rein in its spiraling pension and health care costs, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday challenged his would-be successors to take a tough line in negotiations with the city’s unions, while worrying aloud that whoever is elected will be too beholden to labor.

headline: In a Vivid Dream, the Old Folks Home Bristles With Life
text: SALZBURG, Austria — In the early 1890s, while working with the librettist Arrigo Boito on “Falstaff,” his final opera, Verdi was immersed in a plan to build a retirement home in Milan for singers and musicians who had fallen upon hard times. The architect was Camillo Boito, the brother of the librettist.

headline: As Detroit Flounders, Its Art Scene Flourishes
text: The night of June 20 was the Detroit native and photographer Sebastian Sullen’s first art exhibition, a group show called “Art Ethereal: Beauty and the Beast,” named for his contradictory subject: his city’s majestic architecture and scarred urban blight. Part of a monthly event called Third Thursday, the show packed the Detroit Mercantile Company, a retro general store and event space. There were carrot cake, beer from a nano-brewery and, in the storefront, “You Gotta Save Art!” stickers ($2.50) and T-shirts ($25) for sale in support of the Detroit Institute of Arts.

headline: A San Francisco Museum, Reborn on the Bay
text: On a recent afternoon along the Embarcadero, San Francisco’s downtown waterfront boulevard, vintage streetcars packed with tourists clattered toward Fisherman’s Wharf, joggers wove through pedestrian herds, and office workers in search of lunchtime sun camped out on every bench, chair and bayside perch. But as lively as this plein-air panorama might have been, it was downright dull compared with the hyperkinetic indoor action at Pier 15, where the new home of the Exploratorium science museum opened recently.

headline: Four Touches, and in the Net
text: The Red Bulls’ third goal against Sporting Kansas City on Saturday, the eventual game-winner, was a thing of beauty.

headline: New Tools Pinpoint Natural Gas Leaks, Maximizing a Fuel’s Green Qualities
text: WASHINGTON — Natural gas is hailed as green and safe, but its environmental benefits and ability to temper climate change are reduced by its tendency to leak into the air undetected. Now, laser technology, some of it borrowed from the telecommunications industry, is giving engineers and scientists crucial new tools to measure leaks and track them to their source.

headline: Can Parents Stay Friends With the Child-Free?
text: Time magazine’s latest cover piece, “The Childfree Life,” posits a new divide among women. We’ve moved on, it says, from pitting working and at-home parents against one another to stirring up unrest between the child-ridden and the child-free — also known as the child-blessed and the childless, depending on your point of view. (You could say “women with children” versus “women without children,” but then your title would be too long and not nearly provocative enough.)

headline: Dan Silverman Named Chef at Loews Regency Hotel
text: Headliner

headline: Copyright Lawsuit Targets Cover Songs on YouTube
text: In the latest sign of friction over the licensing of online music, a group of music publishers has sued Fullscreen, one of the largest suppliers of videos to YouTube, saying that many of Fullscreen’s videos — particularly cover versions of popular songs — infringe on the publishers’ copyrights.

headline: The Voice of the Syrian Watchtower
text: Mudar Abu Ali is the eyes and voice not of one man in one place, but of many men scattered across the northern Syrian countryside.

headline: Melinda Sullivan’s ‘Gone’
text: Ms. Sullivan’s new work combines two schools of tap-dancing, one rooted in jazz and the other in musical theater.

headline: A Show That Marries Pure, Rhythmic Tap to Its Musical-Theater Cousin
text: In her program note to “Gone,” a new dance-theater work, the choreographer Melinda Sullivan identifies two schools of tap-dancing. One comes out of jazz and is rooted in improvisational solos, emphasizing rhythm over spectacle and story. The other swerved through Broadway and Hollywood, producing the choreographed routines of musical theater. Though the divergence can be overemphasized — with racial connotations that Ms. Sullivan’s note carefully acknowledges — the distinctions are still in force.

headline: Fake Comments Muddy a Debate in Dallas
text: Many people have offered opinions in the long-running and literally heated battle between the Nasher Sculpture Center in Dallas and a next-door condominium called Museum Tower. The condominium stands accused of producing glare that has compromised the museum’s galleries and garden.

headline: Profit Flat at Disney, as ESPN and Parks Smooth   Setbacks in Film
text: LOS ANGELES — “The Lone Ranger” rode away with the Walt Disney Company’s growth in the last quarter and will force the entertainment conglomerate to take a write-down of up to $190 million in the current quarter.

headline: Obama's Ideas to Help Homeowners
text: The president outlined his plans to help responsible Americans own homes and addressed he bipartisan effort to overhaul the mortgage finance giants Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae.

headline: Scene City: Oprah Returns to the Spotlight
text: Oprah Winfrey, Forest Whitaker, Lenny Kravitz and other co-stars attended the premiere of Lee Daniel’s “The Butler.”

headline: Long Before Little Charlie Became the Face of Evil
text: “Little Charlie Manson was a disagreeable child,” Jeff Guinn writes in “Manson,” an otherwise brawny, deep-digging biography that’s much more riveting than might be expected. It’s no surprise that the Manson story no longer commands much attention. What a difference more than four decades make. Mr. Guinn is fascinating in his use of hindsight, and it allows him a more probing view of his subject than earlier biographers had. The book’s essential question is articulated in this opening quotation about the ’60s, which he attributes to Tom Hayden: “Over and over it came down to that question — what was reality in an unreal time?”

headline: Front Burner: A Biodynamic Wine Shop in Brooklyn, Hot Chocolate for Cold Sipping and More
text: To Shop: Selecting Wine That’s Biodynamic

headline: 10 Questions for Rand Paul
text: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has drawn more attention than most Republican politicians lately, as his party searches for a winning national formula. Clashing with the likes of New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie – a potential 2016 presidential rival – he has promoted a libertarian brand of Republican politics featuring a less aggressive foreign policy, a more tolerant social policy, and smaller government.

headline: From Winning to ‘Wow,’ Festival Fun Unfurls in Crisscrossing Acts
text: VAIL, Colo. — A number of Romantic ballets have central scenes set in the woods. Far from the madding crowd, within the realm of nature, the hero discovers the otherworldly heroine who satisfies his longing as the women of his own milieu do not.

headline: In-Demand Artist, Now on View in Vegas
text: Much has been made of the light and space artist James Turrell’s hat-trick retrospective: three simultaneous major museum shows, including one now at the Guggenheim for which he’s created the largest-ever temporary installation in the museum’s history.

headline: The Moto X From Google, iPhone’s Latest Challenger
text: It’s getting harder and harder to invent the iPhone Killer. Even for Apple.

headline: Gunfire at Board Meeting Traced to Eviction Dispute
text: Rockne Warren Newell lived alone in the Pocono Mountains of eastern Pennsylvania in utter poverty. His house was on the verge of collapse. His bathroom was a bucket.

headline: 60 Seconds With Pogue: The Moto X Phone
text: The Times’s David Pogue examines the Moto X smartphone, Google’s collaboration with Motorola.

headline: In Drums and Fans, the Spirit of Korea
text: There’s soul, and then there’s “S(e)oul.” On Sunday afternoon, Lincoln Center Out of Doors teamed up with the Center for Traditional Music and Dance to showcase “The S(e)oul of Korea,” a program with more to it than an embarrassing title. (What on earth were the presenters thinking?) This three-tiered presentation, which took place at Hearst Plaza, included two musical groups — the New York Korean Traditional Marching Band and Ensemble Sinawi — as well as the dance and music troupe Sounds of Korea.

headline: Modern Picnic Wares for Photo-Worthy Alfresco Dining
text: Too often, picnic wares are an afterthought — cheap wicker baskets, plastic gingham blankets, throwaway utensils. Of course, the primary attractions of do-it-yourself alfresco dining are a lavish spread, a natural setting and good company. But now, thanks to a handful of artisans, there are attractive, handcrafted goods for a decidedly modern (and Instagram-friendly) outdoor culinary experience.

headline: In American Greetings Deal, Echoes of Larger Buyout for Dell
text: This is a tale of two management-led buyouts.

headline: Even Before a Debate, an Unfriendly Exchange
text: It was only a matter of time before the race for mayor developed its own personal feud.

headline: Sometimes, They’re Sort of Who They Say They Are
text: “We’re the Millers,” a loose, halfheartedly raunchy, occasionally hilarious new comedy, is about a lot of different things; it’s the usual grab bag of jokes about drugs and body parts. But what really drives the movie is its own search for something to make fun of, and for a comic style that can feel credibly naughty while remaining ultimately safe and affirmative.

headline: U.S. Charges Libyan Militia Leader in Benghazi Attack
text: Federal law enforcement authorities have filed murder charges against Ahmed Abu Khattala, a prominent militia leader in Benghazi, Libya, in connection with the attacks on a diplomatic mission there last Sept. 11 that killed the United States ambassador and three other Americans, according to senior law enforcement and United States officials.

headline: What a Hero Goes Through to Become a Healer
text: Following the almost $226.5 million box office of the first Percy Jackson movie, the hero (Logan Lerman) has returned to save Camp Half-Blood, the training ground for Greek demigods and employer of the teacher-centaur Chiron (Anthony Head of “Buffy the Vampire Slayer,” at his Watcher-ly best, replacing Pierce Brosnan). When the magical tree that protects the camp is poisoned, Percy must retrieve the Golden Fleece to heal it.

headline: A Challenge in the Woods
text: The sparse, somewhat surreal “Kid-Thing,” a new feature from the Zellner brothers, is certainly disturbing. Whether it is anything more than that depends on how much time you want to invest in contemplating the fragments you’re given.

headline: Tapering of Stimulus Could Start as Soon as September, 2 Fed Presidents Hint
text: Two Federal Reserve regional presidents suggested on Tuesday that the central bank could ease its extraordinary efforts to stimulate the economy sooner rather than later, but stopped short of providing an exact time frame.

headline: Someone Hacked N.H.T.S.A.’s Servers
text: As it turns out, even highway safety regulators are vulnerable to the ravaging hand of cybercriminals. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration had some of its servers hacked last week, the agency confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: Back to School, With Perks
text: The North Atlanta High School, which opens on Wednesday, cost $147 million, the most expensive school in Georgia history.

headline: Leader Says Taliban Will Sit Out 2014 Afghan Election
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Despite efforts to broker a peace deal between the Afghan government and the Taliban, the insurgent group will not participate in the presidential election next year, its leader said in a statement Tuesday.

headline: 21st Century Fox Has 16% Jump in Revenue on Higher Cable Fees
text: The entertainment arm of Rupert Murdoch’s media empire, 21st Century Fox, on Tuesday reported a 16 percent uptick in revenue for the quarter ending in June, thanks in part to the higher subscriber fees for its cable channels.

headline: Chasing Milestones Near End of Road
text: As Alex Rodriguez marched toward his career total of 647 home runs, he passed many of the greatest hitters to ever play.

headline: Advance Ad Sales for New TV Season Called Lukewarm
text: IT may be the right moment to add another item to the Meh List (“Not hot, not not, just meh”): the performance of the broadcast networks in selling commercial time ahead of the 2013-14 television season.

headline: In the Jets’ Other Quarterback Battle, the Loser Will Hand In His Playbook
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. — Coach Rex Ryan opened his news conference Tuesday by announcing that Mark Sanchez would start the Jets’ preseason opener Friday night in Detroit, and then he went on to field eight consecutive questions about Sanchez and Geno Smith — their projected playing time and all that. It was as if Sanchez and Smith were battling for a job or something.

headline: National Push by a Local Immigration Activist: No G.O.P. Retreat
text: ATLANTA — He says the United States is filling up with immigrants who do not respect the law or the American way of life. He refers to Latino groups as “the tribalists,” saying they seek to impose a divisive ethnic agenda. Of his many adversaries, he says: “The illegal alien lobby never changes. It’s the Wall Street wing of the Republican Party joining forces with the Chamber of Commerce, the far left and the Democrats in an effort to expand cheap labor and increase voting for the Democratic Party.”

headline: Kremlin Critic Goes From Jail to Trail
text: MOSCOW — A handful of people hovered curiously around a drab plaza in Tyoply Stan, a neighborhood on the southern edge of Moscow, attracted by volunteers handing out leaflets and a makeshift platform affixed with banners showing a man who despite global renown remains largely unfamiliar here.

headline: Strong Earnings for Live Nation in Concert Season
text: With the worldwide concert business shaping up to have one of its best summers in years, the music and ticketing company Live Nation Entertainment on Tuesday reported strong earnings for its second quarter.

headline: A $147 Million Signal of Faith in Atlanta’s Public Schools
text: ATLANTA — The most expensive public high school ever built in Georgia opens Wednesday in an old I.B.M. office building.

headline: Many Mayoral Candidates Have Been What Bloomberg Is Not: Close to Cuomo
text: John A. Catsimatidis let Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo borrow a Gulfstream IV jet this spring so he could fly to Binghamton, N.Y., for a wedding. Bill de Blasio was a deputy to Mr. Cuomo during the Clinton administration; William C. Thompson Jr. was a chairman of Mr. Cuomo’s gubernatorial campaign; and Joseph J. Lhota served in his administration.

headline: An Attack on Equality
text: In New York, widely regarded as a gay-friendly city, reports of attacks on same-sex couples are on the rise. Here, one young couple tells their story.

headline: Bangladesh Takes Aim at Grameen Bank
text: The government of Bangladesh is considering nationalizing and breaking up the widely admired Grameen Bank, which pioneered the business of lending small amounts of money to poor women who want to start and grow businesses. Lawmakers should reject these destructive ideas and stop meddling in the affairs of this important financial institution, which serves 8.4 million rural women.

headline: The Iron Pipeline Thrives
text: When somebody pulls a gun and commits a crime in New York City, that weapon almost certainly comes from somewhere else. Mayor Michael Bloomberg announced last week that 90 percent of the guns used to commit crimes were purchased in other states, according to the latest data from 2011, compared with 85 percent in 2009. This “iron pipeline,” as this illegal trade is called, is a booming and deadly business.

headline: Hope for Childhood Obesity
text: After a long fight to control childhood obesity, there are encouraging signs that the tide is finally turning. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Tuesday that the obesity rate among preschoolers from poor families has fallen in 19 states and American territories, and it has risen in only three states.

headline: What’s the Point of a Summit?
text: Update: On Wednesday morning, President Obama canceled a planned summit with the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin,  after concluding that there had not been enough progress made on the “bilateral agenda” to make a meeting worthwhile.

headline: Violent and Chaotic, Central African Republic Lurches Toward a Crisis
text: BANGUI, Central African Republic — The two men lay still in the back of the pickup truck, staring up. Over them stood the uniformed rebels, rifles pointing out as the truck sped forward.

headline: Tech Magnates Bet on Booker and His Future
text: The conference room in the Mountain View, Calif., headquarters of LinkedIn was packed with the stars of Silicon Valley. Top executives of Facebook, Google and Twitter gathered around a table; the billionaire Sean Parker looked on from a back row. The guest of honor: Cory A. Booker, the mayor of Newark.

headline: Couldn’t the Yankees Have Waited a Day?
text: On opening night, the cheat hit cleanup. Of course he did, as the center of a circus that Alex Rodriguez was widely accused of foisting upon the poor (ha!), victimized (ha! ha!) and — more tellingly — offensively undernourished (aha!) Yankees.

headline: The Tea Party’s Path to Irrelevance
text: WASHINGTON — THE Tea Party has a new crusade: preventing illegal immigrants from gaining citizenship, which they say is giving amnesty to lawbreakers. Judson Phillips, the founder of Tea Party Nation, recently told Politico that his members were “more upset about the amnesty bill than they were about Obamacare.”

headline: Diversity and ‘Doctor Who’
text: BELGRADE LAKES, Me. — YOU could hear the sighs of disappointment spreading across the nerd-universe on Sunday when the BBC announced, with much fanfare, that the Scottish actor Peter Capaldi would be the new star of “Doctor Who.”

headline: Daring to Fail
text: Secretary of State John Kerry has pulled off a major achievement in getting Israelis and Palestinians to say yes to the United States. Can he now get them to say yes to each other?

headline: ‘An Attack on Equality’
text: New York is regarded as a gay-friendly city in a state that has legalized gay marriage, but this Op-Doc video shows that it can still be dangerous for a same-sex couple to walk down the street holding hands.

headline: Ex-Madam, Now Candidate For Comptroller, Is Arrested
text: Even in the topsy-turvy world of New York City politics, it is not every day that a candidate for city comptroller is arrested one month before a primary. But when the candidate is Kristin Davis, little is surprising.

headline: New Leaks Into Pacific at Japan Nuclear Plant
text: TOKYO — Tons of contaminated groundwater from the stricken Fukushima nuclear plant have overwhelmed an underground barrier and are emptying daily into the Pacific, creating what a top regulator has called a crisis.

headline: Bezos Brings Promise of Innovation to Washington Post
text: The big news in newspapers — that Jeffrey P. Bezos is buying The Washington Post — was not even 24 hours old when shock and wisecracks about the unexpected $250 million deal began to give way to acceptance and even envy.

headline: Reince Is Right
text: WASHINGTON — Reince Priebus says a lot of goofy things, but the chairman of the Republican National Committee has a point.

headline: At Home in This Village: Yiddish Speakers
text: NEW SQUARE, N.Y. — The very name of the village is a linguistic anomaly: New Square. Sounds as plain English as you can get, except that it was supposed to be called New Skvir after a Ukrainian town and was inadvertently Anglicized years ago as a result of a clerical error. (It is not shaped like a square, either.)

headline: When Younger Players Showed Way on Testing
text: CHICAGO — Paul Konerko is not a crusader. He never has been, and he is not comfortable being cast in the role. He is a ballplayer, studious about the art of hitting, professional in his demeanor, and he would prefer to leave it at that.

headline: Messages by Qaeda Chief Spur New Look at His Sway
text: WASHINGTON — The world has heard a good deal in recent days from a stern, 62-year-old Egyptian doctor thought to be hiding somewhere in Pakistan.

headline: 11 Trillion Reasons
text: Here’s a good line: “[U]nenlightened farm policy — with its massive subsidies for junk food ingredients — has played a pivotal role in shaping our food system over the past century. But that policy can readily be changed.”

headline: Pilots Switched Controlling Before a Rough Landing
text: WASHINGTON — Seconds before a Southwest Airlines flight hit the runway nose wheel-first at La Guardia Airport on July 22, the captain of the plane took control from the first officer, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Tuesday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Venus Williams, Still Not at 100 Percent, Loses in Return
text: TORONTO — Venus Williams made her return from a back injury on Tuesday at the Rogers Cup here, but after a three set defeat to the Belgian Kirsten Flipkens, she admitted she was still not at 100 percent.

headline: Elections to Be Easier for Voters With an App
text: The election process can, at times, feel impossibly old-fashioned, as evidenced by the return of mechanical lever voting machines for this year’s New York City primaries. But this election season, the city will try to make it easier to register to vote, give money and communicate with campaigns, all from the palm of your hand.

headline: 2 Senators Visit Egypt With Threat on U.S. Aid
text: CAIRO — On a visit at the request of President Obama, two Republican senators warned Egypt on Tuesday that the United States would cut off aid if the new military-appointed government failed to move rapidly toward democracy, including releasing the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, and other leaders of his Islamist party from detention.

headline: Thorn in Kremlin’s Side Runs for Mayor
text: Aleksei A. Navalny’s campaign has emerged as the most significant test for Russian politics since Vladimir V. Putin returned to the presidency last year.

headline: Outrage Over an Antigay Law Does Not Spread to Olympic Officials
text: The Winter Olympics begin six months from today in Sochi, Russia. Athletes find themselves in a risky situation. On the one hand, they face prosecution for advocating for gay rights. On the other, they face banishment by Olympic officials for publicly opposing Russia’s discriminatory new law.

text: Should the U.S. follow the E.U.'s lead in placing low caps on credit and debit card interchange fees?

headline: Axel Springer’s New Focus on Digital Draws Cries of Betrayal
text: BERLIN — The publisher Axel Springer’s role in Germany’s postwar history — from building its high-rise headquarters close to the Berlin Wall to antagonize the Communist authorities on the other side to denouncing the student movement in 1968 — has earned it respect and disdain in equal turns.

headline: Washington Steps Warily on Housing
text: WASHINGTON — In the seven years since the housing market started to fall apart, politicians of both parties have promised repeatedly to build a better system for financing the American dream of owning a home. There is little sign of progress.

headline: Cary Tamarkin
text: Mr. Tamarkin, 55, is the founder of the Tamarkin Company, an architecture and development company based in New York. The firm’s projects include the condominiums 508 West 24th Street and 456 West 19th Street, both near the High Line.

headline: Helping Housing
text: The share of new mortgages guaranteed by the federal government grew to more than 80 percent during the housing crisis and has remained there since, even as the market has begun to improve.

headline: Between Players and Doping, a Valet Seen as a Middleman
text: Last year, Everth Cabrera was a promising young infielder hoping to make the San Diego Padres roster, but a nagging shoulder injury threatened to stall his big league career just as it was beginning.

text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Drink Garnish
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Sometimes not recognizing the theme right away can be a good thing. As frustrating as it can be to not immediately conquer the grid, remember that this is Wednesday, so Will Shortz needs to slow your roll a bit, as it were.

headline: Florida: Exhumations Approved at Shuttered Reform School
text: Gov. Rick Scott and his cabinet on Tuesday voted to allow anthropologists from the University of South Florida to begin exhuming the remains of boys who were buried decades ago at the Dozier School for Boys in Marianna. The reform school, now shuttered, had a history of neglecting and abusing the boys in its care. Accusations of abuse spanned decades. A group of elderly “White House boys,” named for the building where they say they were beaten, have come forward in recent years to speak about the abuse. Anthropologists began identifying the graves in a portion of the school that had been set aside for black boys during segregation. Family members of some of the boys who died at the school have fought for more than a year to have the bodies exhumed, examined and reburied in cemeteries closer to home.

headline: George Duke, Keyboardist Who Crossed Genre Boundaries, Dies at 67
text: George Duke, who began his career as a jazz pianist in the 1960s but made his name by crossing musical boundaries, died on Monday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 67.

headline: Robert Bellah, Sociologist of Religion Who Mapped the American Soul, Dies at 86
text: Robert N. Bellah, a distinguished sociologist of religion who sought nothing less than to map the American soul, in both the sacred and secular senses of the word, died on July 30 in Oakland, Calif. He was 86.

headline: A Return to Downtown Birmingham
text: Long scarred as the site of brutal civil rights struggles and decades of industrial collapse, downtown Birmingham, Ala., has struggled to attract new business or visitors, even from its own region.

headline: Julius Chambers, a Fighter for Civil Rights, Dies at 76
text: Julius L. Chambers, a civil rights lawyer who endured firebombings of his house, office and car in winning case after case against racial segregation, including one that led to a landmark Supreme Court decision allowing forced busing, died on Friday at his home in Charlotte, N.C. He was 76.

headline: Length of Rodriguez’s Suspension Was Sticking Point
text: CHICAGO — Michael Weiner, the chief of the baseball players union, said the players association had recommended that Alex Rodriguez accept a suspension from Major League Baseball if it were for a reasonable number of games. That perhaps suggests that evidence uncovered in baseball’s investigation into Biogenesis, a defunct South Florida anti-aging clinic, demonstrated Rodriguez was guilty of something.

headline: Russia: Tycoon’s Prison Sentence Is Cut by Two Months
text: Russia’s Supreme Court on Tuesday reduced by two months the sentence of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former oil tycoon and political opponent of President Vladimir V. Putin, but declined to release him immediately as his lawyers had requested in an appeal. Mr. Khodorkovsky, who was convicted of fraud and tax evasion in 2005 and money laundering and theft in 2010, is now scheduled for release in August 2014.

headline: Obama Tells Leno Closure of Embassies Is No Overreaction
text: For a late-night comic Jay Leno certainly covered some serious ground with President Obama on Tuesday evening.

headline: Argentina: Gas Leak Causes Deadly Residential Blast
text: Twelve people died and at least 60 more were injured, officials said Tuesday, in an explosion in the center of Rosario, Argentina’s third largest city, with 1.2 million people. A gas leak from the ground floor of a residential building caused the blast on Tuesday morning, Mónica Fein, the mayor of Rosario, confirmed. Witnesses said it felt like an earthquake. “I woke up and there were no walls,” said Franco Járiton, who lived on the seventh floor. News channels showed that the middle block of the building, which was nine stories tall, had collapsed. There are fears that two adjoining blocks, which are badly damaged, will also fall. Fifteen people were missing. Neighbors said they had called the provincial gas company hours before the explosion, warning of a strong gas smell. The company, Litoral Gas, said it had not received any calls.

headline: “Amity Gardens”
text: From the Fountains of Wayne album “Utopia Parkway.”

headline: In Team Meeting, the Yankees Vent and Face Reality
text: CHICAGO — With a nightmarish season lurching into its final two months, the Yankees were at a crossroad on Monday when Derek Jeter and Joe Girardi decided to address the team in a brief postgame meeting, according to several people in the room.

headline: American Men Will Drop Out of Top 20 for First Time in 40 Years
text: There will not be an American man in the top 20 of the ATP rankings when they are released Monday, the first time that has happened since the rankings began nearly 40 years ago in August 1973.

headline: Dealing With Injuries and Suspensions, Mets Regroup and Win
text: The Mets came back to Citi Field on Tuesday after a rare day off. Like a family returning home from a long weekend, they found that some day-to-day concerns had piled up and demanded attention.

headline: Horace Mann Sues Insurers to Cover Abuse Liability
text: Horace Mann, the elite Bronx private school rocked last year by allegations of sexual abuse, filed a lawsuit on Tuesday against three insurers in an effort to recoup over $1 million in legal fees, damages and settlements paid to two victims.

headline: How Exercise Can Help Us Learn
text: Over the past decade, in study after study in animals and people, exercise has been shown to improve the ability to learn and remember. But the specifics of that process have remained hazy. Is it better to exercise before you learn something new? What about during? And should the exercise be vigorous or gentle?

headline: Health Care Inflation and the Arithmetic of Labor Taxes
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: What’s on Wednesday
text: 9 P.M. (BET) LUV (2013) A recent parolee (the rapper Common) dreaming of a better life decides to take his 11-year-old nephew (Michael Rainey Jr., above left, with Common) out of school for a day and teach him how to be a man in this crime thriller from the director Sheldon Candis. But as the boy eats his first oyster, tastes his first beer and learns how to steer a car, he also ends up being an accomplice — and perhaps a hostage — to a man who turns out to be a desperate criminal. “Mr. Candis, who wrote the script with Justin Wilson, balances the more sensationalistic aspects of the movie — guns are pointed and fired, blood is shed, and threats are issued with heavy, macho menace — with keen attention to details of character and place,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “The landscape of Baltimore’s African-American neighborhoods may be familiar to fans of ‘The Wire’ (as will the faces of a few of the actors), but ‘Luv’ is telling a different kind of tale about drugs, the law and urban life. It is, as the title suggests, a love story, focused on the complicated bonds between men who regard one another as family and whose lives are scarred and shadowed by violence.”

headline: Yankees’ Bats Contribute to the Quiet on Day 2 of Rodriguez’s Return
text: CHICAGO — A day after a news media circus descended on U.S. Cellular Field to chronicle the dueling narratives of Alex Rodriguez’s season debut and Major League Baseball’s announcement that it had suspended him, the Yankees faced a decidedly less frenetic atmosphere on Tuesday.

headline: News Quiz | August 7, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Blaze Damages Nairobi’s International Airport
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — A huge fire broke out Wednesday and raged for four hours at Nairobi’s international airport on the anniversary of the attacks on the United States Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, officials and witnesses said, bringing East Africa’s busiest airport to a standstill and turning parts of it into charred ruins.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Aug. 7, 2013
text: Test your math skills with this question, created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the FiveThirtyEight blog post “LeBron’s Odds of Catching Jordan.”

headline: Soccer Dreams of Tibetan Exiles
text: DHARAMSALA, Himachal Pradesh — In a cramped office at the Tibetan National Sports Association in the north Indian town of Dharamsala, amid the disorderly rows of files and sepia photographs, a brand new jersey hangs from a nail on a bookshelf. Stitched on the back are the words “Tibetan National Team.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The World’s First Lab-Grown Hamburger
text: In “A Lab-Grown Burger Gets a Taste Test,” Henry Fountain writes about the world’s first laboratory-grown hamburger.

headline: Study Suggests North Korea Is Doubling Area Devoted to Uranium Enrichment
text: North Korea appears to have doubled the size of the area used to enrich uranium at its Yongbyon reactor complex in recent months, a proliferation monitoring group reported Wednesday, raising new concerns that the country could increase production of weapons-grade fuel — even as it says it wants to relax tensions with South Korea and the United States.

headline: The Opt-Out Generation Wants Back In
text: Sheilah O’Donnel tells herself that her new home, a townhouse in a development in Chevy Chase, Md., just a stone’s throw from a Safeway, isn’t really all that bad. Sure, it’s near a gas station. And the front window, with its cheerily upholstered cushions, overlooks a dreary parking lot. And yes, it’s kind of small — “an apartment,” O’Donnel, who is 44, sometimes says bitterly, when she’s reminded of her former life with her ex-husband in their custom-built, six-bedroom home. But then again, it’s perfectly maintained and impeccably furnished, and most important, it’s rented with her own money, from the first real job she has had in almost a decade.

headline: Turning Back for the Missed Story
text: Edwin J. Torres, a 23-year-old photographer and filmmaker, is based in Manhattan but was born and raised in the Bronx. “I might move back,” he said. “I love it there.” He received a degree in American Studies from Colby College in Waterville, Me., but studied film and photography as well. He volunteers frequently at the Bronx Documentary Center and has been seleced to particpate in the Missouri Photo Workshop next month.

headline: Suicide Rates Are High Among the Elderly
text: In hindsight, Greacian Goeke can see that there were warnings.

headline: Daily Report: For Washington Post, a Promise of Innovation
text: With Jeffrey P. Bezos, the billionaire founder and chief executive of Amazon, buying The Washington Post, observers are now wondering how he will bring his technological background to bear upon the newspaper, Jenna Wortham and Amy O’Leary report.

headline: Volkswagen Reveals Cleaner, More Powerful Diesel Engine
text: In the United States, Volkswagen has been one of the few automakers to consistently offer diesel-power passenger cars over the last several decades. But with more manufacturers – even American ones – stepping up to the diesel plate, VW is ratcheting up its game with a new line of diesel engines.

headline: New York Today: Tested
text: Updated, 12:09 p.m. | With summer vacation in full swing, city students had probably just about forgotten the standardized tests they took months ago.

headline: Chinese Judges Disciplined in Prostitution Scandal After Videos Circulate Online
text: BEIJING — In a case that drew the attention of millions of Internet users in China, two judges and an official of the Shanghai high court have been expelled from the Communist Party and dismissed from their jobs after being seen on video apparently consorting with prostitutes in nightclubs.

headline: Japan Stepping In to Help Clean Up Atomic Plant
text: TOKYO — First, a rat gnawed through exposed wiring, setting off a scramble to end yet another blackout of vital cooling systems at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant. Then, hastily built pits for a flood of contaminated water sprang leaks themselves. Now, a new rush of radioactive water has breached a barrier built to stop it, allowing heavily contaminated water to spill daily into the Pacific.

headline: Distracted Aging
Mentoring Students to Prevent the ‘Summer Slide’
text: On a July morning at the Academy of American Studies, a public high school in Long Island City, N.Y., Vinay Jassi, a seventh grader, talks companionably to two awed-seeming third graders who have been put in his care.

headline: Border Clashes Between India and Pakistan Continue
text: Indian and Pakistani troops continued firing at each other’s positions Wednesday afternoon along the Line of Control, the disputed border dividing the Kashmir region between the two nuclear-armed neighbors, according to Indian and Pakistani military officials.

headline: In the Affordable Care Act, Some Children Left Behind
text: When supporters talk about the Affordable Care Act, they often take pains to stress the law’s light touch on small businesses. Those with fewer than 50 employees do not have to do anything under the law that they are not already doing, and the law provides temporary tax credits to the smallest companies for offering health coverage. That said, in at least one situation small companies may be forced to confront a surprising dilemma.
