text: Learn more about hurricanes by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Yemen, on Alert for Terrorism, Says It Foiled a Qaeda Plot
text: SANA, Yemen — Yemeni security officials said Wednesday that they had foiled an audacious plot by Al Qaeda to seize an important port and kidnap or kill foreigners working there, but the claim aroused some skepticism among Yemenis and independent terrorism analysts.

headline: Syrian Army Kills Scores of Rebels in Ambush
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian Army attacked a large group of insurgents near the capital, Damascus, on Wednesday, killing more than 60, according to monitors and state media.

headline: Carlyle Profit Rose in 2nd Quarter as Firm Continued to Cash Out
text: The Carlyle Group posted big gains for its second quarter on Wednesday, including a sizable jump in payouts to investors. But analysts expected a little more from its results.

headline: Witnesses to History, Some Still Unfolding
text: Oprah Winfrey was winding up her long-running talk show when the director Lee Daniels came calling. Mr. Daniels, who had worked with Ms. Winfrey when she was an executive producer and supporter of his 2009 film, “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire,” told her that he had a part for her in his new film. Despite pleading time constraints — she was starting her television network, OWN — Ms. Winfrey said she was ultimately compelled to embrace the project because it represented “something bigger than ourselves.”

headline: I Wear My Sunglasses in the Subway
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Design Advice on Reconfiguring an Emptying Nest, Part 1
text: This week’s expert, Danielle Galland, an interior designer, is answering readers’ questions about two kinds of living transitions that many baby boomers face: the semi-empty nest, with children leaving for college but returning during breaks, and the empty nest geared toward retirement.

headline: Devilish Issues of Management-Led Buyouts
text: The $612 million bid by the Weiss family to buy the American Greetings Corporation, the greeting card company the family controls, is not as well known as the headline-grabbing $24.4 billion bid by Michael S. Dell and the private equity firm Silver Lake to buy the computer company Mr. Dell founded. But both deals “illustrate the rising tide of shareholder power, as well as the devilish issues that emerge when management tries to buy a public company,” Steven M. Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column. “And even though Dell’s board has changed the voting rules, both companies are being tested by shareholders who view the buyouts as undervaluing their companies.”

headline: AOL to Buy Adap.tv, a Video Ad Platform, for $405 Million
text: AOL agreed on Wednesday to buy Adap.tv, a video advertising platform, for about $405 million in cash and stock, in its biggest acquisition since becoming an independent company.

headline: Image of the Day: August 7
text: An elephant hit by a train, about 85 miles east of Guwahati, Assam.

headline: Bank of England Ties Interest Rate to Employment
text: LONDON — In a significant shift in strategy intended to spur Britain’s economic recovery, the Bank of England said Wednesday that it would aim to keep interest rates at a record low until the nation’s unemployment rate declines to at least 7 percent.

headline: Ties Fraying, Obama Drops Putin Meeting
text: President Obama on Wednesday canceled next month’s Moscow summit meeting, ending for now his signature effort to transform Russian-American relations and potentially dooming his aspirations for further nuclear arms cuts before leaving office.

headline: At the World Trade Center Site, a Space Begins to Open Up
text: Something remarkable is happening where Greenwich Street used to run through the World Trade Center site.

headline: Video of Iran’s New President on Nuclear Talks
text: As my colleague Thomas Erdbrink reported, Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, told reporters on Tuesday that the dispute over his country’s nuclear program could be resolved “not in the distant future but very soon,” if the United States has the political will for “serious” negotiations.

headline: Test Scores Sink as New York Adopts Tougher Benchmarks
text: The number of New York students passing state reading and math exams dropped drastically this year, education officials reported on Wednesday, unsettling parents, principals and teachers and posing new challenges to a national effort to toughen academic standards.

headline: Egypt Government Hints at Force to End Large Sit-Ins
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s military-appointed government said on Wednesday that it was giving up negotiating an end to a five-week-old standoff with the Islamist backers of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, hinting that it might forcibly disperse tens of thousands of them from two sit-ins in the capital.

headline: Summer’s Super Swimmers
text: Catch a glimpse of a seal floating with its head above water, watch dolphins perform tricks at an aquarium or zip through ocean waves, and you can count yourself lucky for having had an extraordinary encounter, no matter how fleeting. Children interested in learning more about these wild animals will find enticing illustrations and fact-filled pages in two new books.

headline: Loeb Humbly Accepts Sony’s Rebuff of His Shake-Up Plan
text: For an investor known for caustically challenging companies who rebuff his advances, Daniel S. Loeb was uncharacteristically humble in acknowledging Sony‘s rejection of his proposal to shake up the Japanese company.

headline: Suppliers of Milk Powder to China Are Issued Fines
text: BEIJING — The Chinese government has fined six companies that sell infant milk powder a total of $109 million for anticompetitive behavior and price fixing, the country’s top economic planning agency said on Wednesday.

headline: The Price of Urban Family Living
text: When the Economic Policy Institute released a budget calculator last month to help estimate the income families need to live modestly, I could not resist entering our statistics. As a young family of four living in the pricey San Francisco Bay Area, we are constantly juggling our monthly expenses.

headline: Not Banks, but Still Lending Money and Drawing Investors
text: In one sense, much of Internet commerce is largely a matchmaking service, connecting people looking for relationships, taxis or spare bedrooms. One of the hottest areas is the market for personal loans, which is attracting money from venture capital investors, spurred by the fast growth of the largest online platform, Lending Club, and the paper profits for its early backers.

headline: AOL Posts Higher Revenue and Buys Company
text: AOL, the online portal that owns The Huffington Post and Patch, reported on Wednesday second-quarter revenue of $541 million, up 2 percent from the same quarter a year earlier.

headline: Early Film by Orson Welles Is Rediscovered
text: In 1941, Orson Welles made his debut as a feature film director with “Citizen Kane,” a fact well known to everyone who has ever taken Film 101.

headline: Today in Small Business: Can Florists Survive?
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: The Economics of the Affordable Care Act
text: David M. Cutler is Otto Eckstein Professor of Applied Economics at Harvard University. He served as senior health care adviser to the Obama presidential campaign in 2008.

headline: Jerry Wolman, Eagles and Flyers Owner, Dies at 86
text: Jerry Wolman, a small-town grocer’s son who made a fortune as a Washington real estate developer, owned the National Football League’s Philadelphia Eagles and helped found the National Hockey League’s Philadelphia Flyers in the 1960s, but who saw his financial empire crumble and his pro sports franchises pass from his hands by decade’s end, died on Tuesday in Potomac, Md. He was 86.

headline: Aug. 7: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: A Final Return to Woodstock for Richie Havens
text: The life of Richie Havens, the folk musician who opened the Woodstock festival in 1969, will be honored on Aug. 18 with a free concert at that famous site and his ashes will be scattered by plane, the Bethel Woods Center for the Arts announced. According to Mr. Havens’s family, he had requested that his ashes be spread over the original site where he performed, which is now known as Bethel Woods, before he died of a heart attack in April at his home in Jersey City. He was 72.

headline: Jeff Bezos, a Capitalist ‘Indifferent’ to Money?
text: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon.com, is worth $28 billion, Forbes estimates. In other words, he’s good for the $250 million he’s spending personally to buy The Washington Post, even if the purchase, announced this week, is being described as making little financial sense. Maybe he was on to something 14 years ago, when, as Peter de Jonge wrote in an entertaining and still relevant cover story for the magazine, Bezos and his company were fostering a “forced and incongruous indifference to money” among Amazon’s work force. They had lots of morale-boosting mottos but a volatile stock price. (When de Jonge expressed skepticism about the company, one Amazon executive told him, “I can tell you’re not a believer.”) De Jonge imagined that being employed there must have been “a little like living in Pompeii 2,000 years ago.”

headline: American Greetings Buyout Is Approved by Shareholders
text: Shareholders of the American Greetings Corporation approved a $606 million buyout of the company by its founding family on Wednesday, ending months of negotiation over the deal.

headline: Getting the Right Light, Even Indoors Looking Out
text: The eye can see a much greater range of light and dark than a camera can, which is why windows look like glowing boxes in daylight photos taken indoors.

headline: The Year of Living Stupidly
text: I didn’t realize it, but just before my lament over the imperviousness of conventional wisdom to evidence, Simon Wren-Lewis made a similar point, but more broadly. Reading his post, I had some further thoughts.

headline: Annotated English State Test Questions for Grades 3-8
text: A selection of sample test questions from the 2013 ELA/Literacy Common Core tests.

headline: How UrgentRx Crashed the Party at the Cash Register
text: The checkout line in Duane Reade drugstores encompasses some of the most coveted real estate in New York. Within a five-foot radius of the cash register, dozens of the biggest brands in the world vie for attention from hooks, racks and shelves, every inch of which have been allocated according to the product’s place in the retail pecking order.

headline: Finding Hypocrisy in a Search of Jerseys
text: We may not have learned much from the sports news in the last day or so, but we were reminded of a lot of things we already knew. We might not have wanted to know them, or wanted to be reminded of them, but there they were. It is, after all, summer, the season of reruns.

headline: NASA’s Deputy Administrator Is Leaving Agency
text: As lawmakers in Washington continue to wrangle over NASA’s financing and expeditions, a top administrator at the agency who played a large role in drafting the Obama administration’s controversial space policies is bowing out.

headline: A Spelling Mistake That Lincoln Himself Might Have Made
text: Too bad Abraham Lincoln isn’t around to argue on behalf of Thomas Hurley III of Newtown, Conn. Thomas, an eighth grader, lost a wager on the popular game show “Jeopardy!” last week when he was asked to name the 1863 document that Lincoln called a “fit and necessary war measure.” He referred to it as the “Emanciptation Proclamation.”

headline: Obama on Leno
text: President Obama’s habit of going on television comedy shows is sort of charming, and he engaged in some semi-funny banter last night with Jay Leno about aging and silver in his hair and his marriage.

headline: It Isn’t Just About Fun and Games
text: My family moved to Kansas in January 1981 — in local time, the first month of the first year after George Brett hit .390 and then homered off Goose Gossage at Yankee Stadium to send the Kansas City Royals to their first World Series. Video games came with us.

headline: Your First Video Game Crush
text: This summer, a number of New York Times critics are writing about their cultural first crushes — the moments or works that prompted them to write about the arts. A new essay will arrive each week, paired with stories from readers who work within the given discipline about their own cultural epiphanies.

headline: Cleveland Destroys Home Where 3 Were Held for Years
text: The Cleveland house where three kidnapped women were raped and tortured for nearly a decade was demolished by the city on Wednesday as part of a plea agreement that sent their abductor, Ariel Castro, to prison last week for life.

headline: The Cost of a Smoker: $5,816
text: A smoker costs a private employer in the United States an extra $5,816 per year compared with a nonsmoker, according to an analysis of data collected from earlier studies on the costs of smoking.

headline: Restaurant Report: Anton’s Taproom in Kansas City, Mo.
text: When a restaurant attempts many things, there is often a fear that it doesn’t do any of them particularly well.

headline: Hotel Review: NoMad Hotel in New York City
text: Rates

headline: Rules of the High Road
text: MEXICO CITY — Welcome to the streets of this city. Humans: 8.8 million. Cars: at least 4.2 million.

headline: The Gun Report: August 7, 2013
text: 59-year-old Rockne Newell, the perpetrator of the shooting at a community meeting in Saylorsburg, Pa., that killed three and wounded three Monday night, admitted to police after the shooting that his intended targets were the town’s supervisors and attorney. Newell, who’d been locked in a property battle with the town for 18 years, told state police, “I wish I killed more of them.” He also said he expected to be killed during his rampage.

headline: Fire at Nairobi Airport
text: Raw footage of a huge fire that forced the closing of the Jomo Kenyatta International Airport in Nairobi on Wednesday.

headline: Lincoln: War Management by Memo
text: President Abraham Lincoln wrote great and powerful speeches. Lincoln’s gifts as an orator and a writer came in part from his ability to express even the loftiest, most complex of sentiments in just a few words. He rarely used two words when one would do. This is perhaps best illustrated in the daily task of managing the war. A high percentage of his official communications are not letters at all, but notes by him that appear on the back of letters written by other people, many addressed to his attention. These memos, called endorsements, show Lincoln as an unrivaled wartime commander in chief.

headline: Have You Seen Other Examples of Creative Merchandising?
text: We’ve just published an article about Jordan Eisenberg, founder of UrgentRx. His company, which is based in Denver and expects more than $3 million in revenue this year, makes single-dose foil packets of flavored, powdered, over-the-counter medications, but the story focuses less on the products and more on the way Mr. Eisenberg has managed to place them in prominent positions in major retailers.

headline: In Chelsea, a Nice Place to Park His Life Savings
text: While renting in the West Village — paying a hefty $3,875 a month for a large duplex studio in the historic red-brick Archive building on Greenwich Street — Andrew Dumas decided he was “ready, financially and mentally, to commit to buying a place.”

headline: A Family Consents to a Medical Gift, 62 Years Later
text: Henrietta Lacks was only 31 when she died of cervical cancer in 1951 in a Baltimore hospital. Not long before her death, doctors removed some of her tumor cells. They later discovered that the cells could thrive in a lab, a feat no human cells had achieved before.

headline: Graduation Speech by George Saunders to Become a Book
text: Most graduation speeches, full of platitudes and pat advice, are instantly forgotten. Not the one given earlier this year by the writer George Saunders at Syracuse University, where he teaches.

headline: Children’s Advocacy Group Faults Learning Apps for Babies
text: The Walt Disney Company’s “Baby Einstein” videos do not turn babies into prodigies. And despite marketing claims by Fisher-Price, its popular “Laugh & Learn” mobile apps may not teach babies language or counting skills, according to a complaint filed on Wednesday with the Federal Trade Commission.

headline: Wheelies: The Rule, Britannia Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Protests in Morocco After King Pardons Spanish Pedophile
text: Protests have roiled major cities in Morocco after the country’s king recently pardoned a Spanish pedophile. The demonstrations have persisted since late last week even after the king later retracted the mistaken pardon of the convicted child rapist, Daniel Galván Viña, 63, and he was arrested again in Spain this week.

headline: Cheerleader for Health Care Repeal Retires, Blaming Gridlock
text: Rep. Rodney Alexander, Republican of Louisiana, announced on Tuesday that he won’t seek re-election, citing “partisan posturing” and “gridlock” in Congress.

headline: What Are Your Memories of the March on Washington?
text: Aug. 28 will be the 50th anniversary of the mass protest that helped energize some of the most critical social legislation in the nation’s history and inspired a generation of activists. We want to hear from people who were there.

headline: The Great Unwind
text: Merle Hazard, known for his economics-themed odes to the fiscal cliff, double-dip recessions and other highlights of the financial crisis and beyond, has released his latest music video: “The Great Unwind,” produced by Nashville Public Television (WNPT-TV). Enjoy.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
text: Attendants Need Not Come in a Matched Set

headline: A New Look for a Paris Art Museum
text: The Museum of Modern Art in Paris has invigorated its free permanent collections, displaying new acquisitions and reorganizing its collected works. Built in 1937, the museum has had a permanent collection since 2001.

headline: Annotated Mathematics State Test Questions for Grades 3-8
text: Take a test featuring two sample questions per grade from the 2013 Mathematics Common Core tests.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Prince Avalanche’
text: David Gordon Green, the writer and director of "Prince Avalanche," narrates a scene from his film.

headline: A Late Victorian Country Home in Surrey
text: Winterfold House in Surrey, built in 1887 by a parliamentarian and judge, is on the market for $4,600,800.

headline: House Hunting in ... Surrey
text: A LATE VICTORIAN COUNTRY HOUSE IN SOUTH SURREY

headline: What You Get for .... $1,300,000
text: STAUNTON, VA.

headline: Finding ‘Oz’ in Kansas
text: Swinging through the state during his summer road trip, the Frugal Traveler just happens to catch a local production of “The Wizard of Oz.”

headline: Homes for $1,300,000
text: An apartment and commercial space in Staunton, Va.; a ranch house in Montana; and a Spanish Colonial near Miami.

headline: In Kansas, Museums, Fried Chicken and, Yes, ‘Oz’
text: Kansas and New York City have more in common than I thought.

headline: David Gordon Green, Paul Rudd and Emile Hirsch on Making “Prince Avalanche”
text: For his latest film, “Prince Avalanche,” David Gordon Green sought a decidedly stripped-down approach to filmmaking. Inspired by his experience directing the now-infamous Super Bowl XLVI Chrysler commercial featuring Clint Eastwood — a process Green describes as “10 guys in a van” — the director, known for his early indie dramas like “George Washington” and lighter fare like the 2008 stoners-with-guns action-comedy “Pineapple Express,” resolved to make a movie that was similarly devoid of clutter.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene Video: ‘Prince Avalanche’
text: In this video, the writer and director David Gordon Green narrates a scene from his film “Prince Avalanche,” about two men who repaint traffic lines on a Texas road that has been damaged by a forest fire. This scene involves an encounter between one of those men, Alvin (Paul Rudd) and a woman (Joyce Payne) searching through rubble for her pilot’s license.

headline: Trying to Reinvent Itself, Yahoo Searches for a New Look
text: Since Marissa Mayer took over as Yahoo’s chief executive, the tech company has been spending its way back to importance, acquiring 20 companies under Ms. Mayer’s leadership, including the popular blogging service Tumblr and the company behind the social Web browser Rockmelt.

headline: On West Coast Swing, Obama Squeezes In Dinner With Donor
text: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif. – Many in Washington were surprised that President Obama came to California on Tuesday and did not, like presidents almost always do in the Golden State, squeeze in a fund-raiser.

headline: Icahn Bolsters His Assault on Dell, as Odds Mount Against Him
text: Michael S. Dell has succeeded in changing the voting rules for his proposed takeover of the computer maker that bears his name, bringing him much closer to victory. But his chief nemesis, the billionaire Carl C. Icahn, isn’t giving up.

headline: The Opt-Out Revolution
text: This article appeared in print on October 26, 2003, and is revisited in Judith Warner’s cover story in the August 11, 2013, issue of the magazine.

headline: Amazon Reviewers Have a Few Thoughts About That Monet
text: The day after Amazon unveiled its new fine art marketplace, the online retailer was finding that its customers are as willing to offer their opinions on a $1.45 million oil painting by the Impressionist master Claude Monet as they are of the $2.74 Hutzler 571 banana slicer.

headline: Nearly 70, a ‘Little Boy’ Seeks a Home for His Trove
text: LOS ANGELES — It is an overwhelming chore to process all that the eyes can see in the bright, 30,000-square-foot warehouse that is home to the Sports Museum of Los Angeles: thousands of artifacts, including old uniforms, pieces of equipment, trophies, plaques, newspaper clippings and photographs.

headline: She Broke Bad, Too, Just a Bit Later
text: Anna Gunn wasn’t sure what she thought about Skyler White after reading the pilot script for “Breaking Bad,” so she asked Vince Gilligan, the show’s creator, to elaborate. He couldn’t tell her much, he said, but what he could was enough.

headline: For Robin Thicke, the No. 1 Song and Album
text: For the last two months, Robin Thicke has had the No. 1 song in the country with “Blurred Lines,” a smooth disco tune inspired by Marvin Gaye’s “Got to Give It Up.” This week the song entered its ninth week at No. 1, the longest run by a male solo act since Flo Rida’s “Low” in 2008, which stayed on top for 10 weeks.

headline: Happy to Be Me, Boomers in Spandex Say
text: Last May, I wrote a “Booming” essay about the fact that I’m more comfortable in a bathing suit at age 58 than I was in my youth, when I actually had the body to rock a Speedo.

headline: Obama to Speak at March on Washington Anniversary
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will speak on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial to observe the anniversary of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom on Aug. 28 — 50 years to the day after one of the march’s organizers, the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., delivered his “I Have a Dream’’ speech.

headline: Leica Cameras Have Eye-Popping Prices, With Photos to Match
text: Today’s smartphones can take pretty crisp pictures, so buying a regular camera might sound like a waste of money. Now imagine buying a fully manual Leica digital camera that, with a body and lens, can cost as much as $20,000.

headline: A Timeless Love Affair With Leica
text: The Leica, with technology that dates back to the mid-1950s, allows photographers to take pictures that are truly timeless.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Kenya, Afghanistan, Thailand and India.

headline: The Scientism of Steven Pinker
text: Steven Pinker has an interesting and revealing essay in The New Republic dismissing the charges of “scientism” that are often leveled by the philosophically, artistically and religiously-minded against certain authors, polemicists and science popularizers. “The term,” he writes, “is anything but clear, more of a boo-word than a label for any coherent doctrine,” which inspires him to try to reappropriate “scientism” as a positive descriptor — denoting, he suggests, a belief in the intelligibility of the world and a commitment to the difficult-but-necessary quest for real objectivity about its workings, both of which which should inform our understanding of non-scientific spheres as well.

headline: Vacancies Hamper Agencies for Arts
text: The week before the Broadway producer Rocco Landesman was scheduled to deliver his first Congressional testimony as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, he traveled 2,000 miles from Washington to Jerome, Idaho, to take in a production of “Othello” at a high school. Sitting next to him that spring day in 2010 was his host, Representative Mike Simpson, the top Republican on the committee that controls the endowment’s financing.

headline: Fertility Diary: Baby Envy
text: Recently, a friend called to tell me she was pregnant.

headline: Nature’s Power Meets Star Power in Santa Fe
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — The five productions of the Santa Fe Opera season come in two kinds, a distinction made clear last week, when they were presented in quick succession for the benefit of the press and other completists looking to economize. (Good luck with that in Santa Fe.)

headline: Lawyer Says Fort Hood Defendant’s Goal Is Death
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — On the first day of his military trial on Tuesday, Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan told jurors that he was the gunman responsible for a shooting rampage at the Fort Hood Army base here in 2009 and that the semiautomatic handgun displayed by prosecutors was in fact his weapon. Major Hasan, who is representing himself after releasing his Army defense lawyers, asked only a handful of questions of the prosecution’s 12 witnesses, declining to cross-examine most of them.

headline: Veronica Beard, Sketching and Swatching
text: In the second installment of Countdown to Fashion Week, Veronica Miele Beard and Veronica Swanson Beard share their process for sketching and swatching a new collection.

headline: A Timeless Love Affair With Leica
text: The Leica has little in the way of bells and whistles, and its photography technology dates back to the mid-1950s. But it allows both amateurs and professionals to take pictures that are truly timeless.

headline: Countdown to Fashion Week: At Veronica Beard, Meeting in the Middle
text: The 50 (well, not 50) shades of green tacked to the wall of the Veronica Beard showroom on West 17th Street looked for an instant like the fixings for a leafy garden salad. Minute fabric swatches, they were pinned in tidy rows to a slab of slate-tone fiberboard, where they formed the understated counterpoint to a lineup of nautical stripes, fluorescent-bright daisies and eye-popping leopard spots.

headline: Daft Punk Cancels ‘Colbert Show’ Appearance Because of MTV Conflict
text: Stephen Colbert and his viewers learned the hard way on Tuesday night that MTV’s Video Music Awards are still a force in television and the music industry that is not to be trifled with.

headline: Searching Big Data for ‘Digital Smoke Signals’
text: The office has the look and feel of an Internet start-up. The workers are young, the dress is casual and the computer of choice is an Apple notebook. They inhabit a single open room. The walls have whiteboards for scribbling ideas when inspiration strikes.

headline: Florida Wins the Grand National Teams
text: ATLANTA — At the Summer North American Championships here on Sunday, the Grand National Teams was won for the third year in a row by District 9, Florida: Warren Spector of Palm Beach, Michael Becker and David Berkowitz of Boca Raton, Gary Cohler of Miami, and Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell of Clearwater Beach. As they did in last year’s final, they defeated Jared Lilienstein, Michael Polowan, Brian Glubok, Sam Lev, John Hurd and Joel Wooldridge, all of New York City, representing District 24, New York City and Long Island.

headline: Czech Government Loses Confidence Vote, Extending Instability
text: The new Czech government lost a confidence vote on Wednesday, extending the political instability that has undermined the country since a corruption scandal forced the collapse of the previous government in June.

headline: More Flowers for Brussels
text: Fans of the biennial “Flower Carpet,” the elaborately patterned blooms that form a tapestry covering Brussels’ central square every other August, will be happy to learn that the capital of Belgium is adding an alternating floral display on odd years.

headline: Small Bites, Seasonable and Subtle
text: Though the themes vary in this first of two programs of Summer Shorts at the 59E59 Theaters, a consistent standard is maintained. Its forays into show business rivalry, election year machinations and satirical fantasy don’t involve passages of dramatic histrionics or riotous hilarity; rather, they pursue an understated, and effective, path to success.

headline: Apps to Send Smartphone Files Into the Cloud
text: I tend to think of the word “cloud” in terms of cloud-decorated sunsets. Others may think of terrible thunderstorms or even tornadoes. But “cloud” has also taken on a high-tech meaning over recent years, as a label for online remote-access services.

headline: CNN Tweaks Its Lineup Amid Executive Changes
text: One day after revamping its evening program lineup, CNN continued a week of change on Wednesday with announcements affecting the assignments of a range of executives.

headline: Petersen Museum Pieces Among Cars Sold at Los Angeles Auction
text: Los Angeles has always been a challenging location for both pro football and collector car auctions. The latter is particularly odd since Southern California has always fancied itself as the epicenter of American car culture. Over the last few years, however, Barrett-Jackson and Russo & Steele have taken another stab at Los Angeles — albeit via Orange County.

headline: Confounding a Smoking Ban, and Bouncers
text: Maybe it was the thumping music, the alcohol or the beating sun, or some hallucinatory combination, but for a moment in early July, it appeared as if a waterfront state park in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, had turned into a smoker’s paradise.

headline: For Obamacare, Some Hurdles Still Ahead
text: Like other big employers, in the mid-1990s Harvard University was struggling with the ballooning cost of providing health insurance.

headline: Satellite Images Show Destruction in Aleppo
text: A series of satellite images analyzed by the human rights group Amnesty International and the American Association for the Advancement of Science graphically illustrate the devastation wrought upon Aleppo, Syria’s largest city, by months of ferocious combat between the government of President Bashar al-Assad and his rebel opponents.

headline: The Best Sports Movies: Abdul-Jabbar Tested, Vecsey Approved
text: What is it about so-called best-of lists that riles us up so? Why do we take such offense? They are clearly harmless opinions, compiled by whomever and have no bearing on our own predilections of film, music or whatever. The whole exercise of ranking things flies in the face of art, this idea of quantification and qualification.

headline: Fashion’s Blind Spot
text: Five years ago, the fashion industry faced a reckoning over the startling lack of diversity among the models on major designer runways. Reacting to complaints that many shows and magazines included nothing but white models, Vogue, in its July 2008 issue, featured a substantial article that asked, in its headline, “Is Fashion Racist?”

headline: Magician of Light and Silver, Circa 1860
text: Salman Rushdie, in his novel  “The Ground Beneath Her Feet”  (1999), described what we see in a photograph as “a moral decision taken in one-eighth of a second.”In the early days of photography, those moral decisions took longer to process. When Mathew Brady, the Civil War-era photographer, took a portrait, the shutter remained open for 10 to 15 seconds or more, long enough for a bit of wind, or the hint of a smile, to ruin everything. His subjects often had their heads stabilized by an unseen vise.

headline: Set of ‘The Drowned Man’
text:
The set designer Livi Vaughan describes the dressing room portion of “The Drowned Man: A
Hollywood Fable,” the new show from the Punchdrunk theater company of London.

headline: A London Troupe Thrives With Ambitious Free-Range Theater
text: LONDON — For his final directing project as a student at the University of Exeter, Felix Barrett had the sort of eureka moment that careers are built on.

headline: A Whirl of Premieres, From Jookin to Jetés
text: VAIL, Colo. — As artistic director of the Vail International Dance Festival, Damian Woetzel has become one of the foremost impresarios of American dance. To cite just one example: Without Mr. Woetzel, the jookin star Charles Riley, known as Lil Buck, might well have remained little known, and Memphis jookin itself would be considerably more obscure. And there are a number of other dancers and choreographers for whom this Vail festival has been an important stage of growth.

headline: Lighting, Textiles, Seating and More
text: Lighting, wall art, seating and sculptural room dividers are up to 90 percent off at Aswoon/Susan Woods Studio, while supplies last (a light tapestry, shown, regularly $15,000,

headline: Telling Stories, Selling Beauty
text: WEST CHESTER, PA. — “Hold on to your panties because I’m about to tell you a story,” said Mally Roncal, a makeup artist and the founder of the makeup line Mally Beauty, looking straight into the camera at the QVC studio here.

headline: ‘Hotel Chelsea’ by Victoria Cohen
text: In 2011, when the photographer Victoria Cohen heard that the Hotel Chelsea — the talent-suffused West 23rd Street building that housed the likes of Virgil Thomson, Bob Dylan, Janis Joplin, Charles Bukowski, Arthur C. Clarke, Allen Ginsberg and Sid Vicious — was to be sold and gut-renovated, she set out to document the rooms. “It became a responsibility, not just an artistic endeavor to capture the essence,” she said. “I was not photographing empty rooms, I was taking portraits.” The images in her new book, “Hotel Chelsea” (Pointed Leaf Press, $95), are as vivid and haunting as characters in a Fellini film. Shot in natural light, they summon the ghosts of those who lived with blood-red walls, spartan corner sinks or broken-down beds. An exhibition runs from Sept. 17 to Oct. 25 at Third Streaming, 10 Greene Street (Canal Street); pointedleafpress.com.

headline: Concealing an Electrical Panel
text: Q. How can I make the electrical panel in my apartment less of an eyesore?

headline: The Retro Breadbox Is Stale No More
text: Many baby boomers have fond memories of their parents’ kitchen gadgets: rotary egg beaters, electric percolators, Salton Hot Trays and various kinds of breadboxes. Countertop containers for baked goods were rife in the ’50s and ’60s, but they took on a minor role with the rise of commercially produced bread wrapped in plastic and loaded with preservatives. Now, with artisanal bread a staple in many homes, the breadbox is poised for a revival. Wesco, a German company, has reintroduced its Bauhaus-style Grandy model, designed in 1946 by Josef Neuhaus. Made of powder-coated steel, it has ventilation holes in the back, nonslip feet and a metal handle and hinges. The 16-inch-wide box comes in a glossy apple red from the Museum of Modern Art store, for $100. Available on Aug. 15 (orders starting Friday): (800) 851-4509 or momastore.org.

headline: Pull Up a Chair, Sandy
text: Jedediah Morfit’s bas-reliefs have roots that are traditional, though his interpretation is anything but. “My work takes inspiration from decorative plates or decorative plasterwork you’d see in old houses,” said Mr. Morfit, 40, who lives in Collingswood, N.J. But then it takes a sharp detour.

headline: An Island for Artists Only
text: Rabbit Island, a secluded artist’s colony in Lake Superior.

headline: An Island for One, With Room to Share
text: RABBIT ISLAND, MICH. — The list of people who own their own islands is small. Exclude royals and Richard Branson, and it is smaller still. Rob Gorski became an unlikely member of the club three years ago, when he bought a 91-acre island off the Keweenaw Peninsula of Michigan after spotting it on Craigslist.

headline: Using Baseball History to Teach Children Big Lessons
text: On a recent morning in the Longwood neighborhood of the South Bronx, residents on Fox Street were starting their day. Reggaeton played from a second-story window. A man whistled a nursery rhyme while briskly pushing a toddler in a stroller. A woman stood on the corner with rollers in her hair, smoking a cigarette. And in a room at the end of a hallway on the first floor of 830 Fox Street, about two dozen children, ages 6 to 12, sat before a big-screen TV mounted on the front wall.

headline: Mementos, Both Personal and Historical
text: A new exhibit at the Smithsonian features a selection of objects that Americans have saved as historical mementos.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: The Lindenwood Diner
text: The Lindenwood Diner in East New York, Brooklyn, has been open since 1967.

headline: Toys and Bits From the Attic
text: A curious mishmash is about to go on display in Washington. Among the items: a bagful of chads formerly hanging from Broward County, Fla., presidential election voting ballots; snippets of Rutherford B. Hayes’s hair; and a chestnut from Mount Vernon embedded with a tiny compass.

headline: Empty Nest as Urban Loft
text: A sleek new house in Mill Valley, Calif., home to the cycling Goldsteins.

headline: Riding in Tandem
text: Her husband, Ross, calls her Mosquito because that’s what she looks like to him — all awkward elbows and determination — when he is riding behind her on bicycle trips here in Marin County, Calif., or, farther afield, on more ambitious tours through the hills of Idaho or Italy.

headline: Pentagon Finishing Rules to Curb Sexual Assaults
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel is completing new rules to fight what he has called a “scourge” of sexual assault in the military, taking steps meant to guarantee high-level attention to accusations of wrongdoing and to offer greater protections to victims, according to Pentagon, administration and Congressional officials.

headline: Entry Hall Accessories
text: For the New York designer Suchi Reddy, an entry hall is more than a place to hang your hat. It’s an opportunity to be expressive.

headline: Shopping for the Entrance Hall
text: The foyer sits on the threshold between public and private realms and signals your sense of style.

headline: An Erica Tanov Boutique Opens at ABC Carpet & Home
text: In the 23 years since Erica Tanov first sold Bohemian-inspired lingerie in NoLIta, her company has grown to include ready-to-wear, leather goods and textiles. Last week, Ms. Tanov, now based in Berkeley, Calif., with three Bay Area stores, opened a boutique at ABC Carpet & Home. Paulette Cole, ABC’s chief executive, said she’s “long felt aligned” with Ms. Tanov’s philosophy, which “champions the connection between the self and home.” A highlight of the shop: cotton textiles from Ms. Tanov’s work with disabled artists from Creative Growth, a nonprofit, like the 18-inch pillow ($95), above left, sitting atop quilts ($202 to $453). There are also beeswax candles ($38), vintage Japanese plates ($35 each) and Indian leather notebooks ($46 each); 888 Broadway (East 19th Street), (212) 473-3000 or ericatanov.com.

headline: Your Own Private Idaho
text: The “Entering Stanley, Idaho” sign seemed more like a friendly warning than a welcome. “Population 63,” it read, as if to say: Congratulations, you’ve made it to the middle of nowhere. Stanley is the entry point to the Sawtooth Valley, a time warp of a place with four saloons, five mountain ranges and not much else. My husband, Josh, our two children and I had driven three hours from Boise along an empty, winding two-lane scenic byway for a week of summer adventure. Still, as we strolled down deserted, dusty Wall Street looking for a lunch spot, it was hard not to wonder: Where is everyone?

headline: Serenity in the Sawtooths
text: Staggering beauty? Check. Crowds? Not so much.

headline: Amid Turmoil, Lebanese Music Festival Presses On
text: BAALBEK, Lebanon — Under the towering columns of the Roman temples here, the Baalbek International Festival over the years has brought the likes of Mstislav Rostropovich, Miles Davis, Sting and the Egyptian singer Umm Kulthum for an annual musical celebration that for many Lebanese symbolizes the openness and cultural richness that coexists with their country’s periodic instability and war.

headline: First Impressions: Furnishing the Foyer
text: To hear Suchi Reddy tell it, the entrance hall gets no respect. “People just think about their couch, their TV and where they’re going to sleep and eat,” said Ms. Reddy, 46, the owner of the New York interiors firm Reddymade Design.

headline: The ‘Horticult’ at Home
text: A San Diego couple known for their gardening blog built almost all their outdoor furniture.

headline: Marriage Is Yard Work
text: SAN DIEGO — On a recent Thursday evening, the United States Navy notified Ryan Benoit that instead of tracking the $150 million overhaul of the Essex, an 844-foot-long air and amphibious assault ship, he should probably drink a couple of gin and tonics with his wife and water the drooping lettuce in his planter.

headline: On QVC, Beauty and the Tube
text: Selling cosmetics and grooming tools on television shopping networks has become a robust business, online and by phone. Below, a range of product picks from on the air.

headline: On the Verge | Uzes, the Hidden Gem of the South of France
text: “Oh little town of Uzès!” the French novelist André Gide wrote affectionately of his father’s hometown in the South of France in his 1924 memoir, “Unless the Seed Dies.” “If you were in Umbria, Parisians would be visiting you in herds!” Gide, who was born into a middle-class Protestant family and scandalized France with a blunt but elegant defense of his homosexuality in “Corydon,” also published in 1924, was a wry and astute observer of Parisian snobberies. So he’d surely be amused to learn that today a taste-making coterie of Parisians is falling in love with Uzès and settling there, despite the fact that it’s not in Umbria.

headline: For a Talent Scout, Big-League Space
text: LAST WEEK WAS a busy week in the life of Nevena Borissova, who opened her first Curve boutique in Los Angeles in 1997, when she was just 22, a high school dropout and a part-time assistant to fashion stylists.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: iOS Features and Will Foursquare’s Crowley Find His Way?
text: The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Here’s what we noticed today:

headline: Video of Veterans Describing Sexual Advances by San Diego Mayor
text: Last Updated | 6:45 a.m. Thursday. Two women who were victims of sexual assault in the military said Mayor Bob Filner of San Diego made unwanted sexual advances toward them after meeting them at a veterans event, my colleague Ian Lovett reports.

headline: The Stars Align for ‘The Butler’
text: Oprah Winfrey does not have a top-rated daily television show anymore, but that didn’t stop photographers from going positively mad on Monday night when she arrived at the Ziegfeld Theater for the premiere of Lee Daniels’s movie “The Butler,” in which she stars with Forest Whitaker.

headline: Cory Booker’s Silicon Valley Friendships Started at Stanford
text: Cory A. Booker has deep ties to Silicon Valley, ties so deep that they have raised questions about money and influence, particularly now that Mr. Booker, the mayor of Newark, is running for Senate.

headline: Blackstone Is Expected to Sell Hilton in I.P.O.
text: Updated, 8:10 p.m. | As private equity firms rush to cash in on their investments, the Blackstone Group is moving to sell one of the biggest companies to go private in recent years.

headline: Niese Is Set to Rejoin the Mets’ Rotation
text: Mets starter Jonathon Niese, on the disabled list with a partial tear in his rotator cuff, proclaimed himself ready to go after throwing a pain free minor league rehabilitation start Tuesday. He is scheduled to start Sunday against the Arizona Diamondbacks. Niese’s reintroduction into the rotation means the Mets will once again use a six-man staff for the foreseeable future.

headline: A Killer Hears About What Could Have Been
text: One by one, the relatives of a young man who was gunned down in Harlem last year while on a trip home from college, stood up in a courtroom to tell the killer that had he chosen a different path, he would have been welcomed into the loving home of his victim’s family.

headline: The Times Isn’t for Sale, Its Publisher Declares
text: After a week in which both The Boston Globe and The Washington Post were purchased by new owners, the publisher of The New York Times emphatically declared Wednesday night that the publication was not for sale.

headline: Getting a Head Start on Fall Fashion
text: At the risk of sounding springist, isn’t fall everyone’s favorite season for fashion? This time around, the range of trends — rock ‘n’ roll grunge (yes, still going strong), slick minimalism and lavish decadence — means that fashion has more room for individuality than 16 Handles. To get a jump on the season, look for everyday pieces and build on them. Here, some suggestions.

headline: From the Borough of Writerly Types, a Look Inward
text: At around 7 on a recent weekday evening, the day’s oppressive heat only just beginning to ebb, Adelle Waldman walked out among the picnic tables on the patio of the Hot Bird, a Brooklyn bar repurposed from an old garage, self-consciously carrying her just-published book, “The Love Affairs of Nathaniel P.”

headline: Haiti: Report Blames U.N. Camp for Deadly Cholera Outbreak
text: Adding to assertions that United Nations peacekeepers inadvertently brought a strain of cholera to Haiti, a new Yale University report holds the organization responsible for a recent outbreak and concludes that it should help the victims. Sewage from a United Nations camp contaminated one of Haiti’s largest rivers, the report said. The United Nations has steadfastly denied causing the epidemic, which has killed more than 8,000 people since it began in 2010, and has resisted paying any compensation. By not holding itself accountable to victims, the report stated, the United Nations is violating its obligations under international law.

headline: Special Night for Camping Not Far From City’s Lights
text: Anywhere else it would have been a typical summer scene.

headline: Wal-Mart Settles OSHA Case Over Cleaning Procedures
text: Wal-Mart Stores has agreed to a corporatewide settlement to improve safety conditions related to trash compactors and cleaning chemicals in more than 2,800 of its stores, the United States Department of Labor announced on Wednesday.

headline: Venezuelan Court Rejects Challenge to Presidential Election Results
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The Supreme Court on Wednesday rejected a series of legal challenges to the narrow election victory of President Nicolás Maduro, closing a chapter in what has been a bitter aftermath of the vote to replace the country’s popular longtime leader, Hugo Chávez.

headline: Times Reporter Seeks Subpoena’s Withdrawal
text: A lawyer for James Risen, an author and a reporter for The New York Times, has asked Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. to withdraw a subpoena requiring him to testify about a confidential source, in light of the Justice Department’s new guidelines for obtaining information from journalists in investigations. On July 19, a federal appeals court ruled that Mr. Risen must testify in the criminal trial of a former C.I.A. official, Jeffrey Sterling, who is charged with leaking classified information. The case involves material published in Mr. Risen’s 2006 book, “State of War.” The ruling came a week after Mr. Holder released a report on “significant revisions” to Justice Department policies intended to “strengthen protections for members of the news media.” The amended guidelines call for tactics like subpoenas to be treated as “extraordinary measures” to be used as a “last resort,” noted David N. Kelley, Mr. Risen’s lawyer, in a letter to Mr. Holder. “We urge you to apply those principles to this case,” Mr. Kelley wrote. A spokesman for the Justice Department said it was “examining the next steps in the prosecution of this case.”

headline: Owner of Music Schools Charged With Molesting 9-Year-Old
text: The 70-year-old owner of several private music schools for young children in Manhattan has been charged with sexually molesting a 9-year-old girl during lessons over the course of nearly two years.

headline: Even if Elected, He’s Just Serving Coffee
text: THE race for mayor of New York City is about to get more crowded, but the latest entrant promises, to borrow a phrase from baseball, to stay only long enough for a cup of coffee.

headline: Now Playing at the Women’s Tournament: Men
text: TORONTO —Three players who lost in the first round of the men’s Rogers Cup in Montreal will travel to Toronto to take part in exhibition matches during the women’s Rogers Cup event here.

headline: JPMorgan Reveals It Faces Criminal and Civil Inquiries
text: JPMorgan Chase disclosed on Wednesday that it faced a criminal and civil investigation into whether it sold shoddy mortgage securities to investors in the run-up to the financial crisis, the latest legal threat to the nation’s biggest bank.

headline: San Diego Mayor Faces New Claims, From Veterans
text: LOS ANGELES — The embattled mayor of San Diego has stepped away from city politics to attend a two-week behavior treatment program, but his absence from City Hall has not stemmed a tide of sexual harassment allegations against him.

headline: Boy, 15, Quits Board Tied to Booker Start-Up
text: Andrew Zucker, the 15-year-old son of Jeff Zucker, president of CNN, resigned on Wednesday from a board that advises an Internet start-up founded by Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark.

headline: Caustic Light on White House’s Reaction to  a Terrorist Threat
text: WASHINGTON — The gloating among jihadists and their sympathizers began last week, right after the United States shut down almost two dozen diplomatic posts across the Middle East in response to a terrorist threat.

headline: Higher Costs Seen for Some in Congress on Health Plans
text: WASHINGTON — Older members of Congress and those who smoke, like Speaker John A. Boehner, could be facing much higher health insurance premiums under a new official interpretation of President Obama’s health care law.

headline: Too Much Work?
text: Americans have undoubtedly learned more in the past couple of months about the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court and its extensive powers than in the previous 35 years of the court’s existence. But it shouldn’t have taken the renegade intelligence analyst Edward J. Snowden to let us in on a fact that, while hardly secret, had been little noticed: in establishing the court, Congress gave the authority to name its judges to one individual, the chief justice of the United States.

headline: Crazy Pills
text: CHICAGO — ON Oct. 16, 2002, at 4 p.m., I walked out of my apartment in Secunderabad, India, leaving the door wide open, the lights on and my laptop humming. I don’t remember doing this. I know I did it because the building’s night watchman saw me leave. I woke up the next day in a train station four miles away, with no idea who I was or why I was in India. A policeman found me, and I ended up strapped down, hallucinating in a mental hospital for three days.

headline: From Maoist Criminal to Popular Hero?
text: ANY day now — the authorities won’t say precisely when — China will begin one of the most sensational trials in its modern political history, when Bo Xilai, the former rising star in the Politburo and Communist Party boss in the megacity of Chongqing, faces corruption charges.

headline: Hollande Vows to Tackle Rising Unemployment, but the French Are Skeptical
text: PARIS — President François Hollande visited an employment center in France’s heartland this week, armed with promises to reduce record unemployment. That was not enough for Nathalie, a 50-year-old who has long struggled to find work.

headline: City Agrees to Expunge Names Collected in Stop-and-Frisk Program
text: The Bloomberg administration has been unmoved by criticism of the stop-and-frisk program, steadfastly declaring that the tactic is necessary to keep crime down.

headline: Not Native to N Train, a Shark Hitches a Ride
text: The Mustelus canis shark, often referred to as the smooth dogfish, is known to skulk from the edge of New England to the Gulf of Mexico, off the coast of Brazil and along the shores of northern Argentina.

headline: Eli the Rapper Gets a Thumbs Up From Some Big Critics
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The first preseason game is Saturday. There is a roster to trim and a playbook to install, but on Wednesday the monotony of Giants training camp was delightfully interrupted by a rap video.

headline: Disclosures From Mr. Booker
text: Mayor Cory Booker of Newark, who wants to be the next senator from New Jersey, has an obligation to give a full and personal accounting of his involvement in an Internet start-up that he formed with the help of several high-powered investors from Silicon Valley.

headline: Fast-Food Fight
text: The fast-food workers who have been walking off their jobs illustrate a central fact of contemporary work life in America: As lower-wage occupations have proliferated in the past several years, Americans are increasingly unable to make a living at their jobs. They work harder and are paid less than workers in other advanced countries. And their wages have stagnated even as executive pay has soared.

headline: New York’s Common Core Test Scores
text: Over the last decade or so, most states deceived the public about the dismal quality of public schools by adopting pathetically weak learning standards that made children appear better prepared than they actually were. Not surprisingly, when states like Kentucky dropped the charade and embraced more challenging standards, scores dropped precipitously.

headline: A Cafe Where the Spirit of the Arab Spring Lives On
text: TUNIS — In the heat of the afternoon, especially this past month of Ramadan, downtown Tunis plays dead. Offices and shops close at 2 p.m. and life is suspended as everyone, parched and hungry, waits for sunset and the breaking of the fast.

headline: Dispute Over Value-Added Tax on Movie Tickets in China Appears Near End
text: LOS ANGELES — A heated Chinese business and political dispute that has stopped about $200 million in box-office payments to Hollywood studios appears near a resolution, just as outlines of the fight were first emerging in public.

headline: Radical Life Extension
text: The United States — and indeed the world — is straining under the weight of an aging population, and that strain is only expected to grow.

headline: Unusual Deaths in the Indian River Estuary
text: Hundreds of manatees, pelicans and dolphins have died in the northern section of the Indian River estuary.

headline: Ruling Revives Florida Review of Voting Rolls
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — Gov. Rick Scott of Florida, newly empowered by the United States Supreme Court’s ruling in June that struck down the heart of the Voting Rights Act, has ordered state officials to resume a fiercely contested effort to remove noncitizens from voting rolls.

headline: A Yankee (Not Rodriguez) Creates Buzz
text: CHICAGO — After the 2000 World Series, when Alex Rodriguez was a free agent and a pipe dream for Mets fans, Bobby Valentine, then the Mets’ manager, made a more realistic request to the team’s assistant general manager, Omar Minaya.

text: Let’s talk about Gov. Chris Christie. Everybody is; he’s the politician of the hour. At the top of the latest poll of likely Republican presidential primary voters in New Hampshire. (Just two-and-a-half years to go until the Iowa caucuses!)

headline: Mine Deal Puts New Scrutiny on China’s State Industries
text: ZHONGSHE, China — A moribund coal mine here descends deeply, more than 3,800 feet underground. But the deal in which a Chinese state-owned conglomerate bought it may be even darker and more labyrinthine.

headline: Life Lessons From a Most Unlikely Duo
text: CARTAGENA, Colombia — This is a story of two unlikely allies, the wealthy executive/mother and the prostitute/drug smuggler, who rescued each other.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Judge Raises Prospect of Criminal Charges in Hospital Case
text: Invoking the specter of criminal charges against officials of the State University of New York for obstructing the delivery of emergency room services at Long Island College Hospital, a State Supreme Court judge warned lawyers for SUNY and the state on Wednesday that he might require a week of daylong hearings before deciding whether to dismiss the latest civil actions seeking to keep the hospital open.

headline: Deaths of Manatees, Dolphins and Pelicans Point to Estuary at Risk
text: MELBOURNE, Fla. — The first hint that something was amiss here, in the shallow lagoons and brackish streams that buffer inland Florida from the Atlantic’s salt water, came last summer in the Banana River, just south of Kennedy Space Center. Three manatees — the languid, plant-munching, over-upholstered mammals known as sea cows — died suddenly and inexplicably, one after another, in a spot where deaths were rare.

headline: De Blasio Takes His Modern Family on the Campaign Trail

headline: John Woodward, Leader of British Navy in Falkland Islands War, Dies at 81
text: Adm. John Woodward, who became Britain’s most acclaimed naval officer since World War II when he commanded the Royal Navy battle group sent to retake the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic after they were seized by Argentina in 1982, died on Sunday in Bosham, West Sussex, on England’s south coast. He was 81.

headline: Yankees’ Rodriguez Officially Appeals Suspension
text: CHICAGO — Alex Rodriguez’s appeal of his 211-game suspension for violating baseball’s drug policy was officially filed Wednesday, according to the players union. An arbiter will decide the case, and a decision is not expected until October or November.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Son Says de Blasio Will Be a Mayor for All
text: Bill de Blasio, the New York City public advocate and a Democratic candidate for mayor, is running his first television advertisement of the campaign. Titled “Dante,” this 30-second ad will appear on network and cable channels across the city starting on Thursday.

headline: Adding Golf to Its Lineup, Fox Sports Acquires Rights to United States Open
text: Fox Sports has never carried a golf tournament, but late Wednesday it agreed to a 12-year deal to carry the United States Open starting in 2015 on both its broadcast network and Fox Sports 1, a cable network that starts Aug. 17.

headline: The Health Tradeoffs of Entrepreneurship
text: Many people who work with startup companies say that entrepreneurs are among the healthiest people they know. The reason, they note, may relate to the disciplined and driven personalities required for entrepreneurship, along with the flexible work schedules self-employment allows.

headline: Insurance Group Rates Small Cars in Offset Crash Test
text: The results of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety’s test of small cars in its severe small-overlap front crash test are in, and small cars generally fared better than the compact crossovers and S.U.V.’s that the organization recently tested. Six of the 12 small cars evaluated received a Good or Acceptable rating as well as the institute’s highest designation, Top Safety Pick.

headline: Yankees’ One Constant Only Adds to the Chaos
text: CHICAGO — For eight and two-thirds innings Wednesday night, the Yankees appeared to have regained some sense of normalcy. Alex Rodriguez, they found out, will likely be with them for the rest of the season after appealing his 211-game suspension for violating baseball’s drug policy. The offense finally showed signs of stirring, and C. C. Sabathia delivered his best outing in a month. The Yankees had a one-run lead with the stalwart closer Mariano Rivera in to pitch the ninth inning.

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 9 P.M. (13) CASE HISTORIES In this “Masterpiece Mystery!” presentation, Jason Isaacs (“Harry Potter,” “Brotherhood”) portrays Jackson Brodie, a cop turned private eye plucked from the pages of Kate Atkinson’s novels. In the series’s first episode, Brodie struggles to balance the personal and professional as he tries to solve a case involving a girl who went missing 30 years earlier. “ ‘Case Histories’ is trying for something lighter (while remaining artfully blood soaked), and some mystery fans might find it a welcome change,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times when the series made its debut in 2011. Mr. Isaacs (above with Millie Innes) is “very likable as Brodie,” he added. “If you can ignore that he’s playing a character built on spare parts from Raymond Chandler novels and Willie Nelson songs, that may be enough.”

headline: News Quiz | August 8, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: N.S.A. Said to Search Content of Messages to and From U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency is searching the contents of vast amounts of Americans’ e-mail and text communications into and out of the country, hunting for people who mention information about foreigners under surveillance, according to intelligence officials.

headline: T-Mobile US Reports Resurgent Customer Growth
text: SAN FRANCISCO — T-Mobile US, the fourth-largest American carrier, lost thousands of customers over the last few years to rivals that offered more popular phones. But it appears to be rebounding.

headline: YouTube’s Founders Challenge Vine and Instagram With New Video App
text: After months of teasing, the wait is over: Chad Hurley and Steve Chen, who brought us the video-sharing site YouTube, are taking the wraps off their newest project, a video creation app called MixBit.

headline: The Battles for Gorkhaland
text: KOLKATA, West Bengal— Mangal Singh Rajput, a 45-year-old father of two, died in a hospital in Siliguri, West Bengal,  on Aug. 3, three days after he set himself on fire while shouting, “We want Gorkhaland!” Mr. Rajput’s self-immolation occurred on July 30, the day New Delhi set into motion the process for the creation of the state of Telangana, which will be carved out of the southern state of Andhra Pradesh. Mr. Rajput’s cry joins a clamor of pending statehood demands all over India, fueled by the central government’s announcement about Telangana.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 8, 2013
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “If the Lizards Look at Home, Credit Months of Zoo Labor.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | A Surprise Package in the Mail for Wayward Dog Owners

headline: The Cool Side of Campy Frozen Drinks
text: The frozen daiquiri, the piña colada, the frozen margarita: these drinks remind me of a certain kind of great-aunt — the one who has worn the same coral lipstick since 1959, the one whose laughter is like a wheezy rush of air, the one in the paisley caftan who had an affair with a famous bandleader back in the day. Some relatives might have cringed at the very thought of her. Others, like me, wanted to hang out with her all the time — and maybe even grow up to be her.

headline: Japan Protests Over Ships From China in Island Dispute
text: TOKYO — Japan lodged a protest with China’s top diplomat in Japan on Thursday after three Chinese paramilitary ships stayed in waters around disputed islands for longer than at any time since a fight over the area heated up last year, the Japanese Foreign Ministry said.

headline: Jailed Chinese Rights Advocate Speaks Out in Video

headline: International Flights Are Gradually Resumed at Airport in Nairobi
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — International passenger flights were slowly resuming from Nairobi’s main international airport on Thursday, one day after a devastating fire ripped through its main arrivals hall and disabled East Africa’s busiest air transportation hub. Officials said they expected full operations to be restored by the end of the day.

headline: JPMorgan’s Latest Legal Challenge

The investigation is the latest legal threat to the bank and one of several mortgage-related problems for the industry.

headline: Part Ramones Biography, Part Dreamscape
text: In 1979, the Ramones were recording at a studio in Los Angeles with the producer Phil Spector, whose work with the Ronettes, the Righteous Brothers and the Beatles had earned him a reputation as both a musical genius and an exacting, combustible egomaniac. He hadn’t produced a hit since John Lennon’s “Imagine” in 1971, and the Ramones, who had released four critically acclaimed albums of exuberant punk rock, were still searching for a commercial breakthrough. The sessions for the resulting album, “End of the Century,” were tumultuous, and the opening pages of the new book, “Gabba Gabba Hey!: The Graphic Story of the Ramones,” written by Jim McCarthy and illustrated by Brian Williamson, details some of Mr. Spector’s more notorious moments: forcing the guitarist Johnny Ramone to play the opening chord to “Rock ’N’ Roll High School” more than 70 times; pointing a gun at the bassist Dee Dee Ramone.

headline: Syrian Rebels Claim Attack on Caravan With Assad

headline: Bomb Attacks Kill Dozens of Mourners in Pakistan and Afghanistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The living were honoring the dead on both sides of the border between Pakistan and Afghanistan on Thursday when militant bombers struck, killing at least 44 people in two attacks that coincided with one of the holiest days on the Muslim calendar.

headline: Daily Report: T-Mobile US Expands Its Customer Base

headline: Bringing God Along For the Ride
text: HO CHI MINH CITY — Get on a bus in Vietnam and you’ll probably see a photo of the Virgin Mary, a bodhisattva or some other deity on the dashboard, if not an altar with fruit offerings. At first I was surprised by such public displays of devotion: Religion is so personal and private, bringing it to work seems like a recipe for offending people.

headline: Happy Birth Data! A New App Tracks Fertility
text: High-tech companies keep trying to fix America’s health care woes. This time, the effort is a combination of Big Data research and an old-fashioned Christmas club.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: P.G.A. Championship First Round
text: With Tiger Woods failing to capitalize on a good start in Thursday’s first round of the P.G.A. Championship, and Phil Mickelson sending golf balls to all corners of Oak Hill Country Club early in his round, it fell to Adam Scott to give the season’s final major a bit of star power.

headline: The Trouble With India’s MIG-21 Fighter Jets
text: On July 15, a Russian-made MIG-21 Bison fighter jet, operated by the Indian Air Force, crashed while attempting to land at the Uttarlai air base in the Barmer district of Rajasthan. This was the second MIG-21 crash, at the very same air base, in two months. However, unlike in the previous accident, which had no casualties, this time the pilot was killed. The crash has been attributed to pilot error.

headline: What Janet Yellen — And Everyone Else — Got Wrong
text: Don’t worry, this isn’t another entry in the Larry/Janet debate, where I’ve said my piece. Instead, it’s prompted by a nice but I think incomplete analysis by Matt O’Brien of the reasons Janet Yellen underestimated the damage a bursting housing bubble would do; analyzing that issue, it seems to me, is a good way to get at the broader question of why recovery has been so sluggish.

headline: Image of the Day: August 8
text: A demonstration in New Delhi demanding a ban on genetically modified crops.

headline: Cosmo Allegretti, ‘Captain Kangaroo’ Actor and Puppeteer, Dies at 86
text: Cosmo Allegretti, the actor and puppeteer who performed as a menagerie of plush characters on the CBS children’s show “Captain Kangaroo,” died on July 26 in Phoenix. He was 86.

headline: Sunny Gupta of Apptio, on the Half-Empty Glass
text: Q. Were you an entrepreneur early on?

headline: Lloyd Moss, 86, WQXR Host and Author
text: Lloyd Moss, a classical-music radio announcer who amused listeners with cheeky humor and young readers with rhymes in a Caldecott Honor book about the instruments in an orchestra, died on Aug. 3 in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 86.

headline: Edwidge Danticat: By the Book
text: The author of “Claire of the Sea Light” and “Breath, Eyes, Memory” would like to invite Colette, Zora Neale Hurston and Jean Rhys to lunch “and just listen to them talk.”

headline: From the Fire Hose: Arctic Methane, Scientists as Advocates, Vanishing Vaquita
text: My blogging time is limited over the next few days because I’m on the road with my two sons (helping my older son relocate from New Orleans to Los Angeles — a long drive in a 2005 Prius). So here’s a roundup of notable insights and updates scooped from the the information fire hoses that bathe us all — condensed via Twitter by me and others:

headline: Gail Levin, Documentary Filmmaker for ‘American Masters,’ Dies at 67
text: Gail Levin, a documentary filmmaker whose work for the “American Masters” series on PBS brought fresh perspectives to celebrities like Marilyn Monroe, James Dean and Cab Calloway, died on July 31 in the Bronx. She was 67.

headline: Two More Conductors Join the Injury Roster
text: With two more conductors sidelined, here and in Europe, just weeks after Andris Nelsons and Christoph Eschenbach bowed out of Tanglewood performances, the classical music world is compiling an injury list that rivals Major League Baseball.

headline: Today in Small Business: Free Pizza
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Inequality and Opportunity
text: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: Aug. 8: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: By Design | Paris Restaurants, Cali Vibes
text: A can-can kick away from the Moulin Rouge sits Le Dépanneur, a new restaurant in a corner of Pigalle, the red-light district in north-central Paris. The wraparound chrome siding suggests it’s an American-style diner, but the place, which opened last month after being shuttered for several years, has a different kind of stateside flavor. The clean palette, vast airiness and abundant flora creates a Palm Springs-by-way-of-Big Sur resort feel. On the main floor, a wealth of natural wood — slatted tables, floors painted with pastel geometric shapes, siding made of reclaimed timber and a polished bar — is complemented by potted succulents and painted white accents. Upstairs, there are hexagonal tables and vintage Modernist daybeds where guests can sip the restaurant’s agave cocktails and eat its organic burgers.

headline: A Doctor in the Family
text: My father died earlier this year. It was sudden, and in what some of our friends described as every wife’s worst fear, my mom came home from work to discover him collapsed on the kitchen floor, lifeless.

headline: Pneumonia Seen as Star’s Cause of Death
text: The autopsy results for Cullen Finnerty, the star college quarterback found dead in the Michigan woods in late May, revealed Thursday that he had chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E., the degenerative brain disease found in the autopsies of several former N.F.L. players.

headline: The Gun Report: August 8, 2013
text: Most of us who have boarded a plane in the years since Sept. 11 fret about bringing more than 3.4 ounces of shampoo in their carry-on. So it may come as a surprise that some Americans still try to board flights with loaded weapons.

headline: New Embarrassment for British Regulator
text: LONDON – Britain’s Serious Fraud Office faced renewed embarrassment on Thursday after it admitted it had lost thousands of documents linked to an investigation into the British aerospace giant BAE Systems.

headline: Living With Cancer: Patient Yoga
text: Although I sob during sappy movies, I did not cry as I staggered through the numerous surgeries, radiological procedures and chemotherapies that followed a cancer diagnosis four years ago. That is why I am grateful to yoga.

headline: Spike Jonze’s ‘Her’ Will Close New York Film Festival
text: If you can’t get a date for the closing night of the New York Film Festival you can always bring your laptop. The Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Thursday that the closing-night gala selection for this year’s festival would be “Her,” a new feature written and directed by Spike Jonze about a man who becomes smitten with his computer’s operating system.

headline: Those Overlapping Collaborations
text: It’s hard to win an Obie Award for sustained excellence — by the age of 31, no less — without some help along the way.

headline: A Musical’s Unorthodox Genesis
text: Daniel Wise invited a prominent Orthodox rabbi to a recent preview of “Soul Doctor,” the musical that Mr. Wise wrote about Shlomo Carlebach, the charismatic songwriting rabbi whose music has become the heart of many modern synagogue services. The show, which opens on Thursday at Circle in the Square, was still being tweaked, and because the rabbi, Shlomo Riskin, had known Carlebach, Mr. Wise wanted his opinion. As it turned out, Rabbi Riskin was impressed with the show’s star, Eric Anderson, a genial Californian who wears an untrimmed beard and has absorbed Carlebach’s moves and sound. Backstage, Rabbi Riskin complimented Mr. Anderson’s performance in phrases peppered with Hebrew. It was only when Rabbi Riskin left that Mr. Wise told him that Mr. Anderson is not Jewish.

headline: A Whistle-Blower Who Can Name Names of Swiss Bank Account Holders
text: PARIS — Hervé Falciani is a professed whistle-blower — the Edward Snowden of banking — who has been hunted by Swiss investigators, jailed by Spaniards and claims to have been kidnapped by Israeli Mossad agents eager for a glimpse of the client data he stole while working for a major financial institution in Geneva.

headline: A New and Improved Nexus 7
text: OK, we get it, Google — you want to be a hardware company.

headline: The Primary Colors of Argentine Politics
text: BUENOS AIRES — Argentines are being asked to vote on Sunday, and, if the past is any guide, the vast majority will. Just don’t ask them to explain what they’ll be voting for.

headline: Politics in a Refugee Camp
text: By early August 1863, Harriet Jacobs – former slave, memoirist, journalist and now aid worker in Virginia – had been at her work among the “contrabands” in Alexandria the better part of a year. She first visited the refugee camps the previous summer while reporting for William Lloyd Garrison’s The Liberator, and by the end of 1862 she had committed herself to the burgeoning relief effort for the former slaves flooding the region around the capital.

headline: O’Keeffe at Lake George
text: A new exhibition features works that recall George O’Keeffe’s time in upstate New York.

headline: Before the Desert, a Greener Side
text: GLENS FALLS, N.Y. — If you are a casual fan of Georgia O’Keeffe, you probably think of New Mexico when you think of her. After all, she lived there for decades and avidly explored the landscape in her work and her life, collecting stones and bones and accolades as one of America’s most celebrated painters.

headline: Study Says West Germany Engaged in Sports Doping
text: When the Berlin Wall fell in 1989, so did the secrecy around a pervasive, state-sponsored system of doping in communist East Germany known by the Orwellian euphemism of “Supporting Means.”

headline: The Worst Is Yet to Come
text: Not since Charlton Heston struggled to save humanity from itself have movies looked this grimly, resolutely fatalistic. The man who was Moses began fighting the fantasy good fight in 1968, battling damn dirty apes in “Planet of the Apes,” before going on to face zombie hordes in “Omega Man” and an overpopulated nightmare in “Soylent Green.” (Psst: It’s people!) Heston may be gone, but the zombie hordes have kept coming, along with other new and unusual annihilating threats, and now it’s back to the dystopian future with “Elysium,” a cautionary shocker from the director Neill Blomkamp about a Hobbesian war of all against all from which only Matt Damon can save us.
