text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Within Cairo, Impromptu Cities of Dissent
text: Camps of protesters in Cairo are the front lines in Egypt’s stalemate between a military-installed government and supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi.

headline: Boos and Cheers Yield to a Triumphant Final Roar for Yankees
text: Sometimes, the boos would come first, boiling up from within the Yankee Stadium stands, eliciting an immediate rejoinder of cheers and applause. Other times, the order was flipped — cheers, then boos. Whatever the exact sequence or proportion, the visceral responses to Alex Rodriguez on Friday were always loud, the dissonant noises intermingling.

headline: Mavericks’ Owner Chides Baseball
text: Mark Cuban, the Dallas Mavericks’ owner, delivered sharp comments about Major League Baseball and its stance toward Alex Rodriguez during an interview shown Thursday on “The Tonight Show.”

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 9 P.M. (CUNY) SPIES (1928) “Fritz Lang: Silent to Sound,” a five-film series, continues with this silent thriller, set to musical accompaniment, about a government agent (Willy Fritsch) trying to get the goods on a master criminal (Rudolf Klein-Rogge, above, with Gerda Maurus) with a vast network of spies. “Throughout the bewildering mass of scenes in the German production ‘Spies,’ there is always something to intrigue the eye, despite the fact that it is impossible to make head or tail of the story,” Mordaunt Hall wrote in The New York Times. “Its principal attributes are its excellent photography and its cleverly designed scenic effects. Its episodes are like a nightmare.” Still, Mr. Lang “handles his camera like a wizard.” Afterward Jerry Carlson, the host of “City Cinematheque,” interviews Geoffrey O’Brien, editor in chief of the Library of America.

headline: A Limping Cabrera Leaves Rivera Staggered
text: The world’s greatest hitter stepped to the plate against the world’s greatest closer with two outs in the ninth inning Friday at Yankee Stadium. The Detroit Tigers’ Miguel Cabrera had never gotten a hit off Mariano Rivera in six prior at-bats, postseason included, and on the first pitch, he lofted a pop-up toward the first-base dugout.

headline: 24 Hours at a Pro-Morsi Sit-In
text: Time-lapse video of supporters of the ousted Egyptian president, Mohamed Morsi, who have been occupying the area surrounding the Rabaa al-Adawiya mosque for more than a month.

headline: Learning to Write and Let Live
text: We asked Tony Gervino, author of this week’s Lives essay, to share with us the most helpful piece of writing advice he ever received.

headline: Death Panels and the Apparatchik Mindset
text: Aaron Carroll reads the Wall Street Journal, which is outraged, outraged, at the prospect that Oregon’s Medicaid system might seek to limit spending on treatments with low effectiveness and/or patients who aren’t going to live much longer in any case. Death panels!

headline: Italian Style at the Top of the Rock
text: It was an opportunity the accomplished Italian photographer Fabrizio Ferri, who now spends much of his time in New York, could not ignore.

headline: Globalization and Keynesianism
text: Looking at some of the comments on yesterday’s column, I see that a fair number of readers believe that Keynes is no longer valid because any increase in domestic demand will simply “leak” abroad. This is a widespread view, but it’s wrong. Globalization has been impressive, but it has not proceeded far enough to make Keynesian analysis irrelevant.

headline: Two Gaffes on Bases Loom Large in Mets’ Close Loss
text: PHOENIX — In a one-run loss, hindsight tends to magnify the opportunities that fizzled.

headline: For Iraqis, Some Relief Amid Violence: It’s Only 108°
text: BAGHDAD — For many of the weary residents of this city, who have faced a bloody summer of explosions at soccer fields, cafes and open markets resulting in Iraq’s highest death toll in five years, there are only small things for which to be grateful. Like the weather.

headline: Variety: A Peaceful Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — The subject of peace and its broad application across all walks of human life is a complex one, requiring open and frank discussion among greater minds than mine, so you can imagine how surprised I was to see it covered here in the [Not peace. PEAS. –Ed.]

headline: Witnesses Relive Horror of Fort Hood Attack
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — Sgt. First Class Maria Guerra crouched down on the floor of her office, put her back to the double doors and propped her feet on her desk, using her body to block the doors from swinging open. She told the two women she shared the office with to stay down and not stand up. She could hear screams beyond the doors.

headline: Century-Old Boat, and a Mostly Teenage Crew
text: LONDON — Jolie Brise needs no introduction in a Fastnet Race, but its skipper, Toby Marris, still makes a good one.

headline: Sisters for Life
text: In October, a woman you haven’t heard of who died in 1955 will be inducted into the National Women’s Hall of Fame in Seneca Falls, N.Y., along with Betty Ford, Nancy Pelosi, Kate Millett and Julie Krone, the great jockey. She is Mary Josephine Rogers, also known as Mollie, also known as Mother Mary Joseph, founder of the Congregation of the Maryknoll Sisters of St. Dominic.

headline: Aug. 10: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Punishments to Ponder
text: Major League Baseball recently suspended 14 players, including the stars Ryan Braun and Alex Rodriguez, for at least 50 games for violating its antidoping code. Only the Yankees’ Rodriguez has appealed his ban — his is for 211 games — and continues to play. Other players and many readers of The New York Times reacted to the penalties and their effect on the integrity of the game.

headline: Fresh Start for Chiefs’ Leaders on Team With Lingering Pain
text: ST. JOSEPH, Mo. — They came to Kansas City to start over. Alex Smith, the quarterback who lost his job the way no quarterback thinks he should, and Andy Reid, the successful coach who experienced personal and professional loss, are now relying on each other for redemption.

headline: Losing Games, but Not His Calm
text: When Robin Ventura first joined the Chicago White Sox, in 1989, the team finished last in its division. For the rest of his 16-year playing career, Ventura never finished in last place again, and as a rookie manager for the White Sox last season, he spent more days in first place than any other spot.

headline: Books to Have and to Hold
text: I finish reading a book on my iPad — one by Ed McBain, for instance — and I shelve it in the cloud. It vanishes from my “device” and from my consciousness too. It’s very odd.

headline: Marx’s Lesson for the Muslim Brothers
text: KARL MARX wrote that history repeats itself, first as tragedy, then as farce. He had in mind the Revolution of 1848, when a democratic uprising against the French monarchy collapsed into a Bonapartist dictatorship just as the French Revolution had six decades earlier.

headline: When Doctors Discriminate
text: THE first time it was an ear, nose and throat doctor. I had an emergency visit for an ear infection, which was causing a level of pain I hadn’t experienced since giving birth. He looked at the list of drugs I was taking for my bipolar disorder and closed my chart.

headline: Thomas Lewis
text: Thomas Lewis is a psychiatrist who is best known as an author of “A General Theory of Love,” which was published in 2001 and has been reissued twice and translated into eight languages. READING “Harlot’s Ghost” by Norman Mailer is tremendous, more than 1,000 pages, beautifully written and in a setting you’d think no one could ever use as a basis for literature. It tracks the career of a C.I.A. agent from 1955 to 1965. Also, “The Ocean at the End of the Lane” by Neil Gaiman. He’s kind of a macabre fantasist. I’ve only gotten to the part where the person actually gets to the ocean at the end of the lane, so I don’t know what happens after that.

headline: Changing Attitudes on Labor Color Bay Area Transit Dispute
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — With the threat of a railroad shutdown looming, Alice Jorgensen was at the Bay Area Rapid Transit’s MacArthur Station here on a recent morning, waiting for the service she uses 8 to 10 times a week to run errands and go to the library. A strike, she said, would be “a real inconvenience.”

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Sell Masterpieces to Help Save a City?
text: Readers discuss the value of art museums as Detroit weighs how to solve its financial crisis.

headline: Good Charity, Bad Charity
text: YOU are thinking of donating to a worthy cause. Good. But to which cause should you give?

headline: Lawless Sinai Shows Risks Rising in Fractured Egypt
text: SHEIKH ZWAYD, Egypt — Every night at dusk, the streets of this desert town near the Israeli border empty out, and the chatter and thump of gunfire and explosives begin. Morning reveals the results: another dead soldier, another police checkpoint riddled with bullets, another kidnapping. In mid-July, the body of a local Christian shop owner was found near the town cemetery, his head severed, his torso in chains.

headline: What if Novelists Took Steroids?
text: COLUMBUS, Miss. — WELL, Major League Baseball, you’re making me depressed. I can’t even revel in the satisfaction of the Braves having their longest winning streak since 2000 because every time I turn on “SportsCenter,” you’re there with your performance-enhancing drugs, with your suspensions, with A-Rod, Ryan Braun and then some more A-Rod.

headline: Better to Have Won Only Once ...
text: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — The footsteps of champions are not erased when the tide goes out, which Rich Beem pointed out to Shaun Micheel on a rainy Friday the way one might call attention to a rainbow.

headline: Another Twist in the Saga of Henrietta Lacks
text: When Henrietta Lacks was stricken with an aggressive cancer more than 60 years ago, doctors who treated her at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore took cells from her tumor without her permission or knowledge, as was common practice at the time. They soon learned that the cells were just as aggressive in a laboratory dish. Instead of dying quickly as previous cell lines had, they kept replicating at an astonishing rate, earning them the label “immortal” and making them immensely valuable to any scientist who wanted a stable base for experiments.

headline: A Clean-Car Boom
text: In a welcome development for the planet, the cars on American streets are becoming much more climate-friendly much sooner than many had expected. Consumers are increasingly buying fuel-efficient hybrid and electric vehicles thanks to breakthrough innovations and supportive government policies.

headline: California’s Continuing Prison Crisis
text: California has long been held up as the land of innovation and fresh starts, but on criminal justice and incarceration, the Golden State remains stubbornly behind the curve.

headline: Men of Few Words Are Talk of the Tournament
text: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — At the P.G.A. Championship on Saturday, the weather stopped fluctuating and the leader board began to rock back and forth. The third round at Oak Hill Country Club, played in abundant sunshine, low humidity and gentle breezes, turned into a seesaw ride with Jason Dufner and Jim Furyk taking turns going up and down.

headline: I Flirt and Tweet. Follow Me at #Socialbot.
text: FROM the earliest days of the Internet, robotic programs, or bots, have been trying to pass themselves off as human. Chatbots greet users when they enter an online chat room, for example, or kick them out when they get obnoxious. More insidiously, spambots indiscriminately churn out e-mails advertising miracle stocks and unattended bank accounts in Nigeria. Bimbots deploy photos of gorgeous women to hawk work-from-home job ploys and illegal pharmaceuticals.

headline: After Guantánamo, Another Injustice
text: ABOUT two months ago I learned that some of my books had been banned at Guantánamo Bay. Apparently detainees were requesting them, and their lawyers were delivering them to the prison, but they were not being allowed in because of “impermissible content.”

headline: When Leaning In Doesn’t Pay Off
text: WHY do women not have as many leadership roles in the workplace as men do? Some have pointed to internal barriers, suggesting that the problem is partly attributable to something about women themselves — they are not “ambitious enough” at work (while pursuing meaningful family goals), or are deeply committed to work but too hesitant to climb leadership ladders in organizations. Others cite structural or institutional barriers, like bias, discrimination or inadequate work-family flexibility. Sheryl Sandberg, in her now famous phrase, would have women “lean in,” to be more assertive at work and not let biases keep them from pushing forward. By leaning in, women would obtain more authority.

headline: How to Read Afghanistan
text: ON a sunny, crisp November day in 2008, three American civilians joined a platoon of United States soldiers on a foot patrol in Maiwand District, a flat, yellow patch of earth crowned by black-rock mountains in southern Afghanistan. The civilians were part of the Human Terrain System, an ambitious, troubled Army program that sends social scientists into conflict zones to help soldiers understand local culture, politics and economics.

headline: Rays Try to Promote Way Out of Attendance Skid
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — In their endless quest to get more people to show up for their games, the Tampa Bay Rays recently announced that they were revisiting one of their most popular fan giveaways: a figurine of Manager Joe Maddon dressed as a gnome.

headline: Edgy Is the Crown of the Hit Kings
text: If one word can describe the members of baseball’s 4,000-hit club, it is determination. A close second is anger.

headline: High Culture Goes Hands-On
text: THE quest for an experience has taken over giant portions of our lives. Everywhere, we are assaulted by endless opportunities and activities. We text and get texts wherever we are, even behind the wheel. We constantly post what we’re doing and where we are, letting friends know how active we are. We take part in ever more extreme sports. We work not on our own, but in teams and in social spaces, bullpens for offices, coffee shops for self-employed free agents. And when we go on vacation, we spend our time shopping, eating and seeking adventure. Even in Europe’s old cities of culture, some people might stop in at the Louvre or the Uffizi, but often just to snap a few pictures on their cellphones to prove they were there.

headline: Fatal Mercies
text: FEW of us get anything approaching the degree of control we’d like over our lives. Must we also be denied a reasonable measure over our deaths?

headline: Help Thy Neighbor and Go Straight to Prison
text: IF you want to understand all that is wrong with America’s criminal justice system, take a look at the nightmare experienced by Edward Young.

headline: Kansas and Al Qaeda
text: SALINA, Kan. — I’VE spent the last few months filming a Showtime documentary about how climate and environmental stresses helped trigger the Arab awakening. It’s been a fascinating journey because it forced me to look at the Middle East through the lens of Arab environmentalists instead of politicians. When you do that, you see the problems and solutions very differently. Environmentalists always start by thinking about the health of the “commons” — the shared air, soil, forests and water — that are the basis of all life, which, if not preserved, will undermine the whole society. The notion that securing the interests of any single group — Shiite or Sunni, Christian or Muslim, secular or Islamist — over the health of the commons is nuts to them. It’s as laughable as pictures of gun-toting fighters strutting on the rubble of broken buildings in Aleppo or Benghazi, claiming “victory,” only to discover that they’ve “won” a country with eroding soil, degrading forests, scarce water, shrinking jobs — a deteriorating commons.

headline: Madam President
text: WASHINGTON — PRESIDENT OBAMA proved himself a great segue artist Friday, as he smoothly glided from his previously unassailable position on the matter of surveillance to his new unassailable position on the matter of surveillance.

headline: How the Post Was Lost
text: MANY American newspapers were doomed to decline from the moment the Internet arrived on personal computers. But The Washington Post, just sold off unexpectedly to Amazon’s Jeff Bezos, was never really one of them.

headline: Hugh Martin, on the Importance of  Commitments
text: This interview with  Hugh Martin, chief executive of Sensity Systems, an LED lighting company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Measuring the Sycamore
text: PERHAPS it is a search for order, for scale, for the rules of proportion, some impulse to keep track, but human beings seem hard-wired to take measure of the world around them. It’s why we record everything from rainfall and ice melt to temperature and bird arrival dates. It’s also why I found myself one morning, not long ago, in the meadow of my friends Alex and Blair, in Wallkill, N.Y., along with George Profous, a senior forester with the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. He was there to measure the old sycamore tree.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Rodriguez Has Day Off but Talks to Reporters
text: Alex Rodriguez was not in the lineup for the Yankees’ Saturday afternoon game because Manager Joe Girardi decided to rest him after the late finish of Friday’s game, a 4-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers in 10 innings.

headline: Car Bombings Kill Scores Across Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — As Iraqis flooded the streets of their capital and other cities on Saturday to celebrate Id al-Fitr, the holiday that marks the end of the holy month of Ramadan, a string of car bombs struck in mostly Shiite neighborhoods, killing more than 60 people, officials said.

headline: Roy Rubin, Who Led Record-Losing 76ers, Dies at 87
text: The Philadelphia 76ers were pleading for help. In the spring of 1972, they ran advertisements in The Philadelphia Inquirer seeking applicants for their head coaching job. They had been N.B.A. champions in 1967, but poor trades and terrible draft choices had sent them plummeting, and they could not find anybody to fix things.

headline: This Ironman Market Is Still Lacking Respect
text: UNLESS you know they’re taking place, amazing feats of endurance and longevity are invisible in their early stages.

headline: The Housing Market Is Still Missing a Backbone
text: IN a speech in Phoenix last Tuesday, President Obama finally entered the debate over the future of United States housing policy. But his talking points offered few details about how to reduce the government’s giant footprint in the mortgage market.

headline: When a Co-Pay Gets in the Way of Health
text: ECONOMISTS specialize in pointing out unpleasant trade-offs — a skill that is on full display in the health care debate.

headline: Skip the Romance; She’s Going to Court
text: IN our last episode, a woman unhappy with the dating service It’s Just Lunch was offered a partial refund of her $1,000 membership. The catch was that to receive the check, she had to sign a contract in which she agreed to not disparage the company, ever.

headline: A Responsibility to Give Back
text: MY grandfather was a Methodist minister. When I was growing up in Washington, his sermons at the Park Road Community Church, which he helped to found, had a powerful impact on me. He made sure I understood that I had a responsibility to give back and help make life better for others.

headline: The Pigou Effect (Double-super-special-wonkish)
text: Via Brad DeLong, Robert Waldmann weighs in on the contributions or lack thereof of Milton Friedman, arguing that much of what he said was already there in Samuelson and Solow 1960. Actually, I’d give him more credit than that; the S-S paper — very unusually for both men, and for Bob Solow in particular — is one of those pieces sometimes described as “rich”, with many points alluded to but not many takeaway lines; to the extent that people did take something away, it was the crude notion of a usable downward-sloping Phillips curve, which turned out to be wrong.

headline: Amid Pipeline Debate, Two Costly Cleanups Forever Change Towns
text: MARSHALL, Mich. — As the Obama administration inches closer to a decision on whether to approve construction of the much-debated Keystone XL pipeline, costly cleanup efforts in two communities stricken by oil spills portend the potential hazards of transporting heavy Canadian crude.

headline: Microsatellites: What Big Eyes They Have
text: PEOPLE already worried about the candid cameras on Google Glass and low-flying drones can add a new potential snooper to the list: cameras on inexpensive, low-orbiting microsatellites that will soon be sending back frequent, low-cost snapshots of most of Earth’s populated regions from space.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 11
text: Tensions between the United States and Russia came to a head last week after Russia granted temporary asylum to Edward J. Snowden, the National Security Agency leaker, with the White House announcing President Obama would not meet with President Vladimir V. Putin next month.

headline: The Pirate Bay Offers Web Browser to Avoid Censorship
text: The Pirate Bay, one of the largest and most famous piracy sites on the Web for illegally downloading copyrighted material, has been in a constant game of cat and mouse with legal authorities from around the globe for the past decade. Government agencies have often tried to shut the site down, or thwart people from reaching it — because people use it to download movies, music, digital books and other intellectual property — only to see the site retaliate with new doorways for people to access its wares.

headline: A Victim of Mass Incarceration
text: My Sunday column looks at America’s failed policy of mass incarceration, through the case of a man who was recently sentenced to a mandatory minimum of 15 years in federal prison as an ex-felon in possession of seven shotgun shells. To me, it just seemed nutty. If he had burglarized storage containers, then state authorities should have prosecuted him for that. But 15 years in federal prison, at a cost of more than $400,000, for innocent possession of seven shotgun shells with no gun to go with them?

headline: Texting and Driving, the Aftermath in a Movie
text: Corporate videos are not often noted for their searing emotional content. But “From One Second to the Next,” a short documentary about texting and driving commissioned by AT&T from the acclaimed director Werner Herzog, tells four deeply harrowing tales of lives altered by a driver’s focus on a phone rather than on the road.

headline: In ‘Story of My People,’ Recalling an Industry (and Way of Life)
text: EDOARDO NESI has written a short memoir of great charm, for all its sadness a pleasure to read. A born writer, Mr. Nesi was also by birthright a manufacturer of fine woolens. He was bred from an early age to take over the Tuscan textile business that his grandfather and great-uncle began in the 1920s.

headline: The Chatter for August 11, 2013
text: “In Switzerland, the banks are so organized that they are able to circumvent new rules and laws to continue to enable tax evasion.”

headline: At Chekhov’s Estate, a Pastoral Literary Shrine Belies a Turbulent Century
text: MELIKHOVO, Russia — In a country as big and brash as modern Russia, it is always something of a surprise to discover a modest jewel of the culture that many Russians value so highly.

headline: Boy, 5, Is Killed in Hit-and-Run on Staten Island
text: A 5-year-old boy was killed and his mother and a sister were injured on Friday night when they were struck by a black Mercedes-Benz sedan as they were crossing a street on Staten Island after a prayer meeting, relatives said. The driver left the scene and was arrested on Saturday, according to the police.

headline: Rodriguez Rests, but It’s Hughes and Yanks Who Seem to Need a Break
text: Less than 24 hours earlier, Alex Rodriguez’s mere presence turned the Yankee Stadium crowd into a buzzing, inharmonious chorus. On Saturday afternoon, the Yankees were being blown out, Rodriguez spent the day on the bench, and the fans resorted to doing the wave for amusement.

headline: Added Satisfaction
text: Fair is foul, and foul is fair:Hover through the fog and filthy air. — Macbeth, Act I, Scene 1

headline: Obama Assures Disabled Veterans They Will Get Aid
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — President Obama on Saturday assured thousands of disabled veterans meeting here that while the war in Afghanistan was ending, like the one in Iraq before it, the work of helping the wounded warriors of those conflicts “has only just begun.”

headline: Democrats Look to Wendy Davis as the Charm
text: Texas Democrats are hoping Wendy Davis has some political magic, and that it’s contagious.

headline: The Workers Defense Project, a Union in Spirit
text: LIKE most construction workers who come to see Patricia Zavala, the two dozen men who crowded into her office in Austin, Tex., one afternoon in March had a complaint.

headline: Using the Law to Battle Zebra Mussels and Other Unwanted Pests
text: DENTON — Every two months, Christopher J. Churchill, a United States Geological Survey biologist, scuba dives in Ray Roberts Lake, northwest of Dallas, to monitor the growth rates of zebra mussels, which have wreaked havoc on several Texas lakes and rivers.

headline: Case by Case in Texas
text: THE Worker Defense Project receives about 500 complaints a year, largely from immigrant workers. Here are a few that were brought to the office in July:

headline: Fans Always Called Explosions in the Sky ‘Cinematic’ Anyway
text: It’s no secret that over the past decade, the music industry has become an increasingly difficult place for artists to make a living. But bands looking to navigate these shifting sands could take a tip from Explosions in the Sky, an Austin-based instrumental rock band that has raised its profile by diversifying its musical portfolio to include film scores.

headline: Lawrence Summers: A Life in the Limelight
text: The economist Lawrence H. Summers, formerly a top contender to lead the Federal Reserve, has frequently been a controversial figure in political and academic circles. Here are some highlights, and flashpoints, of his career.

headline: It’s Condor vs. Bull in Peruvian Ritual
text: In Peru’s High Andes, villagers capture and then cast condors against bulls in a pageant celebrating freedom from Spanish colonial rule.

headline: Dual Forces in an Andean Rite
text: The Blood Festival brings together bulls and condors in a contest symbolic of the celestial and earthly worlds.

headline: When Charter Schools Are in Churches, Conflict Is in the Air
text: Three years, 5,000 door hangers and several garage sales after its opening, Beta Academy has a long waiting list but an empty bank account.

headline: Pitting Heaven and Earth in a Fierce Andean Rite
text: COYLLURQUI, Peru — It is not easy to tie a wild condor with a seven-foot wingspan and a sharp beak to the back of an enraged 1,000-pound bull.

headline: The Fed, Lawrence Summers, and Money
text: When Lawrence H. Summers left his job as President Obama’s top economic policy adviser at the end of 2010 to return to Harvard University, one of his first steps was to set up a roster of part-time positions that would touch on just about every corner of the financial world.

headline: Adjusting on and Off the Course
text: Chie Arimura, a 25-year-old professional golfer from Japan, came to the United States on her own and has struggled to acclimate.

headline: Birth of a Palestinian City Is Punctuated by Struggles
text: RAWABI, West Bank — Two students came up with Rawabi, the Arabic word for hills, in a competition to name this new Palestinian city, the first to have been planned from the ground up. The developers rejected suggestions — like Arafat City and Jihad City — that evoked a more chaotic past.

headline: The New Math of Media Deals
text: In a span of just three days, the sales of three giants of the old-media world — The Washington Post, The Boston Globe and Newsweek — were announced, at prices a fraction of the properties’ former value. Wealthy men bought The Post and The Globe; Newsweek was sold to a company that hardly anyone had heard of. The Post announcement prompted the publisher of The New York Times, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., to say that the newspaper was not for sale.

headline: Federer Discusses Setbacks, Saying Motivation Is Still ‘Sky High’
text: MASON, Ohio — After a skid on grass and clay, Roger Federer is hoping the firm hardcourts of the United States will provide some needed sure-footedness to what has been one of the most disappointing years of his career.

headline: What’s the Going Price?
text: The sales of three giants of the old-media world — the Washington Post, The Boston Globe and Newsweek — in as many days suggest one kind of change, but their prices suggest another.

headline: At 41, a Player Regains His Edge and High Ranking
text: Unlike in football, basketball or baseball — where players lose their skills as they age — in chess some older players experience a competitive renaissance and regain the form that made them champions.

headline: For Freshmen in the House, Seats of Plenty
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Andy Barr, a Republican from Kentucky with little experience in the intricacies of Wall Street, was among the lucky House freshmen to secure a seat on the powerful Financial Services Committee.

headline: Grief, and Cries of Outrage, Follow Taser Victim’s Death
text: MIAMI BEACH — When Israel Hernandez Bandera, a former airline pilot, came to the United States from Colombia eight years ago with his wife and two children after being granted political asylum, he was deeply grateful to the country that shielded him from the guerrillas who had extorted money from him and threatened to appropriate his family’s land.

headline: Vows: Kaitlyn and Michael
text: Michael Philips and Kaitlyn Storey supported each other through Mr. Philips’s deployment to Afghanistan, but it was hardship at home that really brought them together.

headline: Cabrera, Feeling the Wear and Tear, Is Always Bright-Eyed When It Counts
text: Early Saturday morning in the Yankees’ clubhouse, the player formerly known as the best hitter in the game, Alex Rodriguez, stood among a crowd of reporters answering questions about the absurdity of his season. At the same time, in the Detroit Tigers’ clubhouse, the player currently considered the best hitter in the game, Miguel Cabrera, lay on a couch unbothered, his head at times slumping toward slumber.

headline: As Others Work to Overtake Him, Bolt Easily Wins His Opening Heat in 100
text: MOSCOW — The chase after Usain Bolt continues. It continued on opening night of the world track and field championships here with the first round of the 100 meters, in which Bolt won his heat but recorded only the seventh-fastest time of the balmy night.

headline: Williams Advances and Will Face Upstart for Rogers Cup Title
text: TORONTO — Top-ranked Serena Williams reached the final of the Rogers Cup after a tough 7-6 (3), 6-4 victory against fourth-ranked Agnieszka Radwanska on Saturday night.

headline: On Fate of Wild Horses, Stars and Indians Spar
text: It seemed at first like a logical alliance for boldface names in the interconnected worlds of Hollywood and politics. Bill Richardson, a former governor of New Mexico, and the actor Robert Redford, a staunch conservationist, joined animal rights groups in a federal lawsuit to block the revival of horse slaughter in the United States, proclaiming that they were “standing with Native American leaders,” to whom horse slaughter “constitutes a violation of tribal cultural values.”

headline: Unexpected Splits in Debate Over Horse Slaughter
text: Free-roaming horses are at the center of a passionate dispute playing out across the West about whether federal authorities should sanction their slaughter to thin the herds.

headline: Skillful Shots, and One Pants Pocket, Help a Swede Charge Into Contention
text: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — For Jonas Blixt, a 29-year-old Swede and a Florida State graduate, the third round of the P.G.A. Championship was a day of sound and unblemished golf. He did not have a bogey Saturday and played seamlessly as he charged into title contention entering the final round.

headline: Albany, Long Buried in Paper, Resolves to Save a Small Forest
text: In the waning days of the legislative session this year, document clerks piled a metal cart and hand truck high with sheaves of paper and wheeled them into the Senate and Assembly chambers. Bill after bill was stashed under desks, where each remained, occasionally kicked but seldom read.

headline: Dixie Evans, Who Brought ‘Monroe’ to Burlesque Houses, Dies at 86
text: Dixie Evans, a popular stage performer billed as the “Marilyn Monroe of Burlesque” — the first two words in very large letters and the last two in very small ones — died on Aug. 3 in Las Vegas. She was 86.

headline: In Comptroller’s Race, Spitzer Dwarfs Stringer in Spending
text: Eliot Spitzer spent at least $271,000 on the four-day petitioning blitz last month that won him a spot on the Democratic primary ballot for New York City comptroller, according to a new campaign finance filing.

headline: Sean Sasser, Who Was Half of One of TV’s First Gay Couples, Dies at 44
text: Sean Sasser, an AIDS activist and chef whose romance with Pedro Zamora on the MTV reality show “The Real World” in 1994 was among the first real-life gay relationships on television, died on Wednesday at his home in Washington. He was 44.

headline: John Billingham, Seeker of Extraterrestrials, Dies at 83
text: Dr. John Billingham, who as a NASA official in the 1970s helped persuade the federal government to use radio telescopes to scour the universe for evidence of extraterrestrial intelligence, even as critics mocked the idea, died on Aug. 4 in Grass Valley, Calif. He was 83.

headline: Four Bodies Are Recovered in Connecticut Plane Crash
text: Four bodies were pulled from the wreckage of a plane crash in East Haven, Conn., investigators said Saturday, but it was still unclear what caused the turboprop aircraft to plunge into a house and burst into flames on Friday.

headline: The Federal Reserve After Bernanke
text: Ben S. Bernanke’s strong policies averted a second major depression. Should he vacate his post as Federal Reserve chairman next year, those policies will leave challenges for his successor.

headline: From Today’s Paper: South Africans Fume Over Government Services
text: Soweto residents burned tires and hurled stones Saturday to protest the quality of South African government services in the area. Unrest has become more frequent in poorer parts of the nation.

headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 10 P.M. (AMC) LOW WINTER SUN Frank Agnew (Mark Strong), a Detroit homicide detective with a tragic past, is persuaded by a colleague, Joe Geddes (Lennie James, above), to help him kill another cop, who he claims murdered a loved one of Frank’s. But as holes surface in Joe’s story, Frank starts to worry that he has been played in this new series, based on a 2006 British mini-series of the same title. Ruben Santiago-Hudson portrays the precinct commander, who assigns Frank to lead the investigation into the cop’s death. David Costabile is an Internal Affairs detective delving into corruption. And James Ransone is a thug who, with his wife (Sprague Grayden), and a police officer on his payroll, looks to set up a drug and prostitution business. “It’s a deadly serious drama, but some of the early scenes are so overwrought that they are almost laughable,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. The series, she said, “doesn’t need to overreach. It has an intriguing story, an aptly sinister setting and an excellent cast.” She added: “It’s inevitable for viewers to yearn for the kind of odyssey that series like ‘The Wire’ and ‘Breaking Bad’ provided. ‘Low Winter Sun’ isn’t that, but it’s an entertaining way station.” The fifth, and final, season premiere of “Breaking Bad” leads in at 9. “Talking Bad,” a companion show hosted by Chris Hardwick that analyzes the series’s last eight episodes, follows at 11.

headline: Leaks at the Fukushima Nuclear Plant
text: Searching for the truth about fresh leaks from Fukushima.

headline: I Don’t Love My Second Child the Way I Love My First
text: I got pregnant when my son was a baby.

headline: Eydie Gorme, Voice of Sophisticated Pop, Dies at 84
text: Eydie Gorme, the lively singer with a remarkable range who performed a decades-long act with her husband, Steve Lawrence, that made them the sweethearts of mid-20th-century American pop music, died on Saturday in Las Vegas. She was 84.

headline: The Euro: A Pre-Mortem
text: Alan Taylor and Kevin O’Rourke have a very good analytical survey of the euro’s problems (pdf), putting it in historical perspective. I’d summarize their piece as saying that the euro suffers from all the problems euroskeptics warned about, plus one they didn’t — the dangers of lacking banking union. There’s a particularly good discussion of the problems of “internal devaluation”, with the demonstration that only in Greece, which is undergoing a full-blown depression, has there been any significant fall in wages:

headline: The Power of Incumbency, Health Care Edition
text: President Obama is finally making a strong case for his own health reform, mocking Republicans for their obsession with denying insurance to 30 million Americans. It’s about time; and many of us still feel that he did a remarkably bad job of explaining the reform in the past.

headline: Disruptions: As New Targets for Hackers, Your Car and Your House
text: Imagine driving on the freeway at 60 miles per hour and your car suddenly screeches to a halt, causing a pileup that injures dozens of people. Now imagine you had absolutely nothing to do with the accident because your car was taken over by hackers.

headline: Autism’s Unexpected Link to Cancer Genes
text: Researchers studying two seemingly unrelated conditions — autism and cancer — have unexpectedly converged on a surprising discovery. Some people with autism have mutated cancer or tumor genes that apparently caused their brain disorder.

headline: New Israeli Housing Bids Raise Tensions Before Peace Talks
text: JERUSALEM — Israel published bids on Sunday for the construction of more than 1,000 housing units in contested East Jerusalem and several large West Bank settlements. Hours later, the government announced the names of 26 Palestinian prisoners to be released this week as part of a deal for the resumption of Israeli-Palestinian peace talks here on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Elysium’ Tops Weekend Box Office
text: Neill Blomkamp’s “Elysium” was No. 1 at North American theaters, but ticket sales fell well short of expectations. An R-rated science-fiction tale about haves and have-nots, “Elysium” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) took in an estimated $30.5 million over the weekend. That’s a solid total, but the studio, which has had a rough summer at the box office, had hoped that the film would deliver opening-weekend ticket sales of $35 million to $40 million.

headline: Leaker’s Father Says He Will Visit Son in Russia
text: WASHINGTON — Edward J. Snowden’s father and the family’s lawyer said Sunday that they had obtained visas to visit the former intelligence contractor in Russia and indicated that they would encourage him to return to the United States to face federal charges for revealing secret American surveillance programs to journalists, but only if acceptable trial conditions could be negotiated.

headline: Aug. 11: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Mayoral Candidates See Cincinnati as a Model for New York Schools

headline: Friedman and the Austrians
text: Still thinking about the Bloomberg Businessweek interview with Rand Paul, in which he nominated Milton Friedman’s corpse for Fed chairman. Before learning that Friedman was dead, Paul did concede that he wasn’t an Austrian. But I’ll bet he had no idea about the extent to which Friedman really, really wasn’t an Austrian.

headline: Reconstructing a Lost Time of Love and Literary Ambitions
text: “Oh, I’ve been to Prague,” the lead in Noah Baumbach’s 1995 film, “Kicking and Screaming,” says to his girlfriend, shortly bound for that city. “Well, I haven’t ‘been to Prague’ been to Prague,” he clarifies, “but I know that thing, that ‘stop shaving your armpits, read “The Unbearable Lightness of Being,” date a sculptor, now-I-know-how-bad-American-coffee-is’ thing.” His attempted put-down hints at how quickly the post-college stint in post-Communist Prague became, for a certain set of sophisticated liberal-arts types, a cliché.

headline: Hushed Tones That Grab Attention
text: The contemplative allure of “the whisper opera,” the new piece of lyric theater by the composer David Lang that had its New York premiere on Saturday night at Lincoln Center’s Clark Studio Theater, comes from its pervasive softness, stillness and intimacy. For just over an hour the soprano Tony Arnold, the closest this experimental work has to an actual character, walks atop a small platform stage amid white lace curtains, sometimes humming chants but mostly whispering cryptic sentence fragments and phrases. She was accompanied by four instrumentalists playing cello, percussion, various flutes and clarinets, all members of the International Contemporary Ensemble, known as ICE. And accompanied is the right word, since the musicians actually follow Ms. Arnold, stationing themselves in different corners of the platform, also whispering incomplete sentences and unanswered questions.

headline: I Give
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — There’s an old story in the world of humor-writing about a very famous and self-absorbed comedian who loved to regale his friends with long tales involving his own amorous conquests, his many possessions and his series of successes in the world of show business.

headline: Time Magazine Branches Out Into Documentary Films

headline: The A B C’s of Ballet, Getting Considerations and Updates
text: When in modern ballet should men and women dance alike, and when differently? When is it appropriate for women to dance on point? How can the pulled-up, stretched-out style of classical ballet be married to the body language of ordinary people and the popular dance styles of our age? How can stories of psychological complexity be told in ballet? What are the practical and expressive implications of same-sex partnering? How can ballet work when accompanied by silence, unusual soundscapes, pop and rock music, or classical music not written for dancing?

headline: As Concerns Over Drugs Mount, the Jockey Club Says It Will Pay for Testing

headline: Police Put Off Dispersal of Pro-Morsi Sit-Ins
text: CAIRO — The Egyptian police appeared on Monday to have postponed once again their threat to begin choking off two Cairo sit-ins where tens of thousands have gathered to protest the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi, leaving in place a tense six-week-old standoff.

headline: No Fountain of Ruth in Sight for These Aging Yankees
text: This was a quarter after 11 on a sunny, breezy Yankee Stadium morning, and another captivating moment in the long and graceful goodbye of Mariano Rivera was about to occur.

headline: Republicans and Democrats Both Miscalculated
text: TWO years ago, Adm. Mike Mullen, at the time the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said that debt was the “single biggest threat to our national security” — not some rogue nation, or terrorist group, but debt. What makes the threat of exploding debt especially dangerous is that it’s not like a faucet that can be easily turned down. Federal, state and city governments in the United States have lost their fiscal grip, and the saga of Detroit’s bankruptcy is just one example.

headline: Bill Thompson, the Anti-Weiner
text: ON issue after issue in the race to be the next mayor of New York, Bill Thompson is the Goldilocks candidate — not too hot, not too cold. And, as a result, not too exciting. This is especially apparent when, as at a forum I attended last week, he is seated next to Anthony Weiner, who plays the hyperbolic huckster with such enthusiasm that he seems to be auditioning for a summer-stock production of “Elmer Gantry.” Thompson is, in his demeanor and his approach to public service, the anti-Weiner — even-keeled, not self-aggrandizing, careful, decent. His favorite adjective seems to be “balanced.” His oratory rarely rises above a simmer. (“No one will ever accuse him of being inflammatory,” Chris Smith dryly observed in New York magazine.) It is easy to forget that in 2009 he ran a close challenge to the seemingly invincible Michael Bloomberg despite being outspent 14 to 1.

headline: Celebrity Weeklies Are Reveling in a Royal Baby, and Sales
text: Celebrity weeklies reported large declines in newsstand sales for the first half of the year, according to figures released last week, but editors didn’t let the numbers get them down. They were too distracted by baby news.

headline: Niese Comes Back With Win as Pieces of Mets’ Puzzle Fall Into Place
text: PHOENIX — It was not a perfect performance, but Jon Niese’s outing in a 9-5 victory Sunday against the Arizona Diamondbacks quelled many of the Mets’ concern about him as they head to Los Angeles for a three-game series with the red-hot Dodgers.

headline: Milton Friedman, Unperson
text: Recently Senator Rand Paul, potential presidential candidate and self-proclaimed expert on monetary issues, sat down for an interview with Bloomberg Businessweek. It didn’t go too well. For example, Mr. Paul talked about America running “a trillion-dollar deficit every year”; actually, the deficit is projected to be only $642 billion in 2013, and it’s falling fast.

headline: Curfews Imposed in Indian-Held Kashmir
text: NEW DELHI — Indian forces and local authorities on Sunday enforced curfews in several towns in the Indian-controlled portion of Kashmir after rioting on Friday left two civilians dead.

headline: With I.P.O.’s on the Rise, Analysts Get New Scrutiny
text: The market for initial public offerings has made a comeback, surging to levels not seen since before the financial crisis. At the same time, concerns have resurfaced over the role of Wall Street research analysts in these lucrative deals.

headline: Quinn Leads Democratic Rivals in Money Race
text: With just a month to go before the Sept. 10 mayoral primary election, Christine C. Quinn and Anthony D. Weiner have more money than their Democratic competitors, allowing them to maximize their spending on the television advertising that is often crucial to persuading undecided voters.

headline: How to Play Baseball in All Innocence and Fun
text: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — Baseball fanatics like Ann Mika — an upstate New Yorker visiting Cooperstown the other day — are looking ahead to 2019, when Mariano Rivera, the peerless Yankee closer who has been clean as a hound’s tooth during the years of drug abuse scandals, should be safely eligible to be inducted into the baseball Hall of Fame. After all, how could performance-enhancing drugs improve her beloved Mariano’s cut fastball? Ms. Mika asks, managing to find comfort in the game as it suffers through another round of depressing disclosures of drug cheating and suspensions.

headline: A Veto of an Import Ban
text: The Obama administration did the right thing earlier this month when it vetoed the decision by a little-known federal agency to ban the import of certain older-model Apple iPhones and iPads that it determined had violated patents owned by Samsung Electronics.

headline: After a Day of Gritting His Teeth, Furyk Can Finally Smile
text: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — All week, Jim Furyk was reminded that he had the lead at the United States Open last year and lost it. Not surprisingly, it was not his favorite subject.

headline: Wrestling With Dying Hospitals
text: Think about New York City and public health, and the mind instantly goes to soda cups and cigarette bans, to Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s 12-year campaign of behavioral modification to make his fellow citizens ditch their bad habits. But eating better is not the only way to a healthier city, especially when so many New Yorkers lack access to decent health care in their own neighborhoods.

headline: Chinese Foot-Dragging
text: If there is ever going to be an end to tensions over the South China Sea, one of the world’s most strategically important waterways, countries in the region need to find a way to work out their volatile maritime disputes. China, more than any other nation, has fanned those hostilities with sweeping sovereignty claims and confrontations over disputed islands and even specks of rock.

headline: Preservationists Have Concerns About Plan to Sell Hudson River Park’s Air Rights
text: When state lawmakers passed a bill in June that would allow the financially troubled Hudson River Park to sell its air rights to developers across the street in order to pay for its pressing maintenance problems, the idea seemed like a novel solution. The plan would tap new revenue for the park, which was meant to be self-sustaining, without resorting to unwanted development within its boundaries.

headline: Prosecutors and F.B.I. Examine JPMorgan Over Losses
text: As federal authorities prepare to charge criminally two former JPMorgan Chase employees suspected of misrepresenting a multibillion-dollar trading loss last year, prosecutors in Manhattan are separately exploring ways to penalize the bank over the trading blowup that has come to be known as the “London Whale.”

headline: Bittersweet Deal in 22-Year Fight Over Toxic Site in Bronx
text: Kerri was 4 when she started having trouble walking. Justin was 5 when he got a nosebleed that would not stop. Danielle was 7 when her legs began to ache.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Lottery Numbers
Bursting the Neuro-Utopian Bubble
text: During my graduate studies in the Department of Religion at Columbia, I spent countless hours in the Burke Library of Union Theological Seminary, where I had a spectacular, cater-corner view of the construction and unveiling of the Northwest Corner Building, Columbia’s new interdisciplinary science building. Although the 14-story steel and aluminum tower was designed to complement the brick and limestone gothic tower of Union, its dominating presence on the corner of Broadway and 120th serves as a heavy-handed reminder of where we are heading. Walking from Union toward Columbia’s main campus through its doors, I often felt, passing through the overwhelmingly aseptic marble lobby, as if the building was meant to cleanse northwesterly intruders who have not been intimidated by the facade.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of August 12
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released this week include retail sales for July (Tuesday); the producer price index for July (Wednesday); the Consumer Price Index for July, industrial production for July, weekly new claims for unemployment benefits and the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia’s business outlook (Thursday); and housing starts for July and the University of Michigan’s consumer sentiment for August (Friday).

text: Why is this mysterious affliction so controversial, and what are the next steps to better understanding it?

headline: Italian-Americans Return to East Harlem So That St. Anthony’s Tower Can Rise Again
text: Among the items raised on Sunday at a festival in East Harlem — aside, of course, from the giglio, an 83-foot-tall wooden tower built in honor of St. Anthony of Padua — was a question of moral geography: Do New Yorkers actually have to live in a neighborhood to claim it as their own?

headline: Embassies Open, but Yemen Stays on Terror Watch
text: WASHINGTON — American diplomatic outposts reopened throughout the Middle East on Sunday, easing the sense of imminent danger that has preoccupied the Obama administration since it learned of a possible terrorist attack from communications between two high-ranking officials of Al Qaeda two weeks ago.

headline: Buildup to the End: What Viewers Seek in a Farewell
text: Television is in a finale frenzy.

headline: John Reilly, 74, a Champion of Documentary Video, Dies
text: In the late 1960s, rebellious young artists attacked television by turning the medium on its head. At Global Village they made an art form out of it.

headline: Moving to the Taft Mansion, a Yale Conservative Group Seeks a National Presence
text: NEW HAVEN — William Howard Taft was not born there; he did not live or even die there. But for a few years, the 27th president did own the house at 111 Whitney Avenue in New Haven, and that association has conferred on the structure a certain historical gravitas.

headline: A Fluttering Boost to Flickering Hopes
text: BALTIMORE — Standing in the outfield before a May game in Anaheim, Calif., Orioles Manager Buck Showalter did not like what he saw in Zach Clark, but it had little to do with Clark’s mechanics or repertory.

headline: Economic Expansion Slows Down in Japan
text: TOKYO — Japan’s economic growth slowed in the quarter that ended in June to an annualized rate of 2.6 percent, government data showed Monday, clouding the outlook for the economic policies of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and raising concerns that he may put off moves to tackle the country’s enormous public debt.

headline: American Is Moved to North Korean Hospital
text: An American tour operator imprisoned in North Korea has been moved from a labor camp to a hospital in the capital, Pyongyang, as his health continues to deteriorate, his sister said Sunday.

headline: Showing Homes in the Hamptons, From High Above
text: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y. — “We’re right over Sagaponack,” Christopher Burnside announced from the front seat of a four-seat Cessna as he cruised over an ocean of mansions and tennis courts. “I’m just looking for the house.”

headline: Piazza Vittorio's Many Voices
text: The emporium at Piazza Vittorio has evolved into the heart of multiethnic Rome. As Italy continues to grapple with immigration, the market presents a vision of easier coexistence through commerce.

headline: P.G.A. Championship Replay: Aug. 11
text: A look at the final round at Oak Hill Country Club in Pittsford, N.Y.

headline: Vibrant Market Is Heart of Multiethnic Capital
text: ROME — On a sweltering recent morning here, customers from around the world crowded the aisles of the food market in Piazza Vittorio Emanuele near Rome’s central train station, shopping for everything from plump Italian tomatoes and peaches to Thai basil, basmati rice and halal meat.

headline: The Wrong Lesson From Detroit’s Bankruptcy
text: When I was growing up in Gary, Ind., nearly a quarter of American workers were employed in the manufacturing sector. There were plenty of jobs at the time that paid well enough for a single breadwinner, working one job, to fulfill the American dream for his family of four. He could earn a living on the sweat of his brow, afford to send his children to college and even see them rise to the professional class.

headline: Tell Us About Your Experiences Being Gay in Russia / Быть геем в России: расскажите о вашем личном опыте
text: Russia’s adoption of legislation that outlaws “propaganda on nontraditional sexual relationships” among minors has spurred an international furor and a national debate on gays in society. As the Times reporter David M. Herszenhorn writes, the law is widely understood as an effort to suppress homosexuality, but it has galvanized Russia’s gay rights advocates and cast an unfavorable light on the discrimination and abuse gay people must contend with in Russia.

headline: Gays in Russia Find No Haven, Despite Support From the West
text: MOSCOW — If this article were published in a newspaper based in Russia, it could be labeled 18+ — like an X-rated movie — and start with the following disclaimer: “This article contains information not suitable for readers younger than 18 years of age, according to Russian legislation.”

headline: Justice Dept. Seeks to Curtail Stiff Drug Sentences
text: WASHINGTON — In a major shift in criminal justice policy, the Obama administration moved on Monday to ease overcrowding in federal prisons by ordering prosecutors to omit listing quantities of illegal substances in indictments for low-level drug cases, sidestepping federal laws that impose strict mandatory minimum sentences for drug-related offenses.

headline: Moving Forward on Housing Reform
text: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: Risk of Adult Anxiety Seen in Children’s Stomachaches
text: Children with chronic stomach pains are at high risk for anxiety disorders in adolescence and young adulthood, a new study has found, suggesting that parents may wish to have their children evaluated at some point for anxiety.

headline: Building Up Bones, With a Little Bashing
text: I’m not a sedentary person. In my 30s and 40s, I was a runner, and for decades, I played singles tennis three or more times a week. After a back injury in my late 30s, I took up swimming and cycling.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 6 A.M. (TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS Turner Classic Movies devotes 24 hours to Catherine Deneuve, starting with “Le Petit Poucet” (2001), Olivier Dahan’s adaptation of the tale of Tom Thumb. Highlights include “Repulsion” (1965), Roman Polanski’s horror film about an introverted Belgian manicurist living in London who is increasingly tormented by sexuality, at 7:45; François Truffaut’s “Mississippi Mermaid” (1970, with Ms. Deneuve and Jean-Paul Belmondo, above), in which the mail-order bride of a plantation owner turns out to be a con artist, at 9:45; Truffaut’s “Last Metro” (1980), about an actress who hides her Jewish husband in the theater they run during the Nazi occupation while falling in love with an actor (Gérard Depardieu), at 4 p.m.; Manoel de Oliveira’s “I’m Going Home” (2001), starring Michel Piccoli as an aging actor who learns that his family has been killed in a car crash, at 6:15; “The Umbrellas of Cherbourg” (1964), Jacques Demy’s musical about love and war, at 8; Luis Buñuel’s “Tristana” (1970), with Fernando Rey as a guardian obsessed with his charge, at 10; André Téchiné’s “Saison Préférée” (1996), in which a woman tries to reconnect with her brother, at midnight; Buñuel’s “Belle de Jour” (1968), about a frigid young housewife who becomes a prostitute, at 2:15 a.m.; and “The Hunger” (1983), Tony Scott’s film in which a female vampire falls for a research doctor (Susan Sarandon), at 4:15.

text: NBC News, a unit of Comcast’s NBCUniversal, on Monday will announce its acquisition of Stringwire, an early stage Web service that enables streaming live video straight to its control rooms in New York from the cellphones of witnesses.

text: After a legislative session that was tarnished by scandals involving state lawmakers, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo appears to be regaining his footing with voters, according to a poll released on Monday.

text: Updated 12:03 p.m. | When officials announced that the storm-damaged tunnel used by the R train between Brooklyn and Manhattan would close for 14 months for repairs, 65,000 riders let out a collective groan.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Judith Warner on Working Mothers
text: Judith Warner, a contributing writer, wrote this week’s cover story about women who left the work force to stay at home and are now trying to restart their professional lives. She is a senior fellow at the Center for American Progress and the author of “Perfect Madness: Motherhood in the Age of Anxiety.”You’ve written two books on the American family, one about medication and another on the changing cult of motherhood. How did you get interested in this particular aspect of family life — mothers’ attempts to return to the work force?

headline: Nazi War Crimes Suspect, 98, Dies Awaiting Trial
text: LONDON — A 98-year-old man whose name figured prominently on an authoritative list of suspected Nazi war criminals died over the weekend in Budapest while awaiting trial, his lawyer said Monday.

headline: The Memory Lady’s Daughter Tries to Fill the Gaps
text: Reading was my mother’s escape from the Texas farm where she grew up. As a child, she memorized poems and recited them in her school auditorium. Later, she memorized whole books and performed them for women’s clubs. She stood alone onstage in high heels and a large hat while her voice transported her listeners to another world. You couldn’t take your eyes or ears off of her. Our home was a house of books, hundreds of which she knew by memory. Now she’s 94 and her once famous memory is slipping away.

headline: It’s the Affordable Care Act. But What Is Affordable?
text: Under the Affordable Care Act, if a company with 50 employees hopes to avoid the penalty in the so-called employer mandate, it is not enough to merely offer those workers health insurance. The insurance must be “affordable,” among other things, and the law is very specific about what affordable means: It means the employee’s share of the premium cannot exceed 9.5 percent of the employee’s household income.

headline: Timing of Israeli Housing Plans May Be Part of a Political Calculation
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s announcement this week that it was building more than 1,000 housing units in East Jerusalem and the West Bank appeared to be part of a political balancing act to satisfy many Israelis before it released 26 Palestinian prisoners, whose names were announced Monday.

headline: Discounts for Last Weeks of ‘My Name Is Asher Lev’
text: For its final three weeks of performances, the critically praised Off Broadway play “My Name Is Asher Lev” will be one of the cheapest tickets in town for patrons 30 and under. The producer Darren Bagert announced on Sunday that the production would sell $10 tickets to that group two hours before performances. Most Off Broadway shows sell such discounted rush tickets in the $20 to $30 range; $10 tickets for a well-reviewed Off Broadway play are rare.

headline: Fresh Scrutiny for Wall Street Analysts
text: For years, Wall Street research analysts have been barred from pitching initial public offering business. But with the market for I.P.O.’s making a comeback, some analysts say Wall Street is slipping back to its old ways, Peter Lattman and Susanne Craig report in DealBook.

headline: Once Dominant, BlackBerry Seeks to Avoid Oblivion
text: Updated, 9:03 p.m. |  It is an unforgiving law of modern business: adapt or die.

headline: Water Wars in India’s South
text: The “temples of modern India” was how an enamored Jawaharlal Nehru described the country’s dams. Today, the sentiment rings true insofar as these behemoths, much like India’s ancient temples, remain a source of never-ending wrangling. The Mullaperiyar Dam, a 112-year-old reservoir located on the Periyar River in Kerala, is no different. The dispute over the dam, distinct as it may be in its historic makings, is ultimately symptomatic of a festering federalist crisis in India.

headline: The Mad Race for Moscow Mayor
text: MOSCOW — There is an election campaign in the city. It is not like most election campaigns: It lacks many typical election-campaign characteristics, and the winner is preordained. But it has already claimed its first casualties: hundreds of illegal immigrants, many from Vietnam, who are being rounded up all over the Russian capital and forced into a cluster of tents erected in the Golyanovo neighborhood on the city’s eastern edge.

headline: Dining a la Carte With Paola Navone and Crate and Barrel
text: The renowned Italian designer Paola Navone is known for her funky, colorful, East-meets-West style, which she has brought to her work for companies like Gervasoni and Driade. Now Crate and Barrel has asked her to envision an affordable home line with the prompt: “What would you do if you were having people over for dinner?” In response, Navone has designed all the components of her ideal dining room, from splotchy blue-and-white glazed plates to high-backed Windsor chairs to red steel hanging lights to a dining table with a tiled top and legs of reclaimed teak.

headline: Schumer Endorses Candidate for Public Advocate
text: Starting Monday, Senator Charles E. Schumer will make a rare appearance in a television commercial backing his preferred candidate in a New York City Democratic primary.

headline: The Re-education of My Perineum
text: Aude politely suggested that I insert the sonde, a tampon-like metal-and-plastic contraption with a long wire she would hook up to the computer. When I flinched, she reiterated the importance of perineal re-education. She delivered this practiced discourse with an air of utter professionalism, flicking through computer exercises with a mouse, her back pin straight. Thankfully. Because had she so much as cracked a smile, I wouldn’t have survived the ensuing psychic trauma.

headline: Dole’s Chief to Buy Out Company for $13.50 a Share

headline: Permanent Stimulus?
text: During the debate over fiscal stimulus, one line you heard over and over again was the claim that spending programs designed to fight the slump would inevitably become permanent fixtures. This claim was often made with an air of worldly wisdom — we all know what politicians are like, right?

headline: Dufner, a Slouch No More

headline: ‘Take Back’ Your Pregnancy? With Caution.
text: When Emily Oster writes in The Wall Street Journal that women should “take back” their pregnancies, I want to cheer her on. A closer, less hysterical read of the research that’s used to demand that women adhere to certain pregnancy rules or be subject to social scrutiny is a welcome one.
