headline: Born Again in Mississippi
text: Adjutant Gen. Lorenzo Thomas had assumed that General Ulysses S. Grant had lost his way. For two days, his small party of officers and orderlies had ridden around and across the same pair of bayous, making use of bridges and fords and sometimes swimming their horses. Caught in a terrific storm, they had spent a night on the ground — notwithstanding the distinguished guests in the company, General Thomas himself, on special assignment from Washington, and Congressman Elihu Washburne, Grant’s friend and patron from his home state of Illinois. Washburne later recalled with admiration how the commander traveled six days in May of ’63 with nothing more than a toothbrush, an example to his troops of military grit and mobility [1] .

headline: The Scene at a Sit-In in Cairo
text: Supporters of Mohamed Morsi, the ousted Egyptian president, gathered in the capital, awaiting an expected police response.

headline: Ads Seek to Clear Up Qualms About Cataract Surgery
text: Though it ultimately proved unsuccessful, the advertising campaign that introduced the phrase “This is not your father’s Oldsmobile” has had considerable influence on popular culture, with the phrase entering the vernacular as shorthand for something, usually in the commercial realm, that has been updated for a new generation of consumers.

headline: Diversification Isn’t Broken, It Just Takes a While
text: It’s a classic moment in sports history. With less than 20 seconds left in Game 6 of the 1998 N.B.A. finals and the Chicago Bulls down by one, Michael Jordan goes one-on-one with Bryon Russell of the Utah Jazz. He pushes off (clearly!), Russell stumbles and the ball hits nothing but net. Game over. Bulls win.

headline: SAC Capital Closes a Trading Unit as It Starts to Retrench
text: SAC Capital Advisors, once the envy of Wall Street for its investment returns, is adjusting to life as a criminal defendant.

headline: Assessing the Impact of Business Incubators
text: In our July 17 post about Austin’s start-up scene, we wrote that there were “at least 15” incubators and accelerators in the region. A reader in Austin questioned the effectiveness of incubators at creating successful companies in the long term. He compiled a list of the top 150 publicly traded software companies by top-line sales — his measure of success — and found that not one on his list had come out of an incubator.

headline: On View | The Hilarious, Poignant Humanity of eBay Auction Listings
text: “Clothing is an overlooked way of telling stories,” said Emily Spivack, a 35-year-old curator, editor, writer and social entrepreneur. “Sentimental Value,” her Internet found-art project (on display at the Philadelphia Art Alliance through Aug. 23), is all about sartorial narratives. It gathers some 40 of the more than 60 garments she has purchased on eBay and pairs them with revealing tales the sellers shared when they listed them.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Tyler Beck joined Publicis Dallas in a new post, senior vice president and director for consumer insights. He had most recently been executive director for strategy at Cheil USA, New York, part of Cheil Worldwide. Publicis Dallas is part of the Publicis Worldwide in the USA division of Publicis Worldwide, which is owned by the Publicis Groupe.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Synthesis Lost
text: A few more notes on the fading of Milton Friedman, which is actually part of a larger problem with economics as practiced for the past few decades. I’ve covered this ground before, but it’s been a while, and I think the case against the neoclassical synthesis (I’ll explain in a minute) is even stronger now.

headline: Bulger Guilty in Gangland Crimes, Including Murder
text: BOSTON — James (Whitey) Bulger, the mobster who terrorized South Boston in the 1970s and ‘80s, holding the city in his thrall even after he disappeared, was convicted Monday of a sweeping array of gangland crimes, including 11 murders. He faces the prospect of spending the rest of his life in prison.

headline: Contraction Shows Signs of Slowing for Greece
text: The Greek economy posted its 20th consecutive quarterly decline in the three months through June, government data showed on Monday, but a slower pace of contraction provided a glimmer of hope for beleaguered Greeks.

headline: An Everyman Champion for Golf’s Populist Era
text: PITTSFORD, N.Y

headline: Ace Plans to Open Luxury Hotel in Panama
text: The influential brand Ace Hotels — which will open its first outpost abroad next month in the Shoreditch neighborhood of London— is adding another foreign locale to its portfolio: Panama City.

headline: Instructions to the Jury
text: The instruction sheet that was handed to the jury in the James (Whitey) Bulger case.

headline: Teen Choice Awards Red Carpet
text: The Teen Choice Awards took place Sunday night in Los Angeles, and the red carpet was plentiful with stars, including Miley Cyrus in a racy outfit.

headline: For Police Departments, in City and Elsewhere, Court Oversight Is Not New
text: There was no ambiguity about where Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg stood on having a federal monitor oversee any portion of the New York Police Department.

headline: The Fiscal Side of Fighting Terror
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Sinkhole Swallows Part of a Building at a Resort in Florida
text: In the realms of fantasy near Walt Disney World, disaster rides abound. But no one would buy a ticket for the real-life sinkhole adventure that swallowed part of a building in nearby Clermont, Fla., early Monday and sent hundreds of vacationers out into the night.

headline: New Laws and Rising Costs Create a Surge of Supersizing Hospitals
text: Hospitals across the nation are being swept up in the biggest wave of mergers since the 1990s, a development that is creating giant hospital systems that could one day dominate American health care and drive up costs.

headline: A Roundup of What Happened While the Public Editor Was Away
text: Back from an intentionally unplugged vacation – where I got my news mostly through the print editions of newspapers and an occasional glance at the Twitter feed on my phone – I’m catching up with some of the issues that crossed the public editor’s desk in the past week.

headline: Anonymous Donation May Help Keep Austen’s Ring in Britain
text: A gold and turquoise ring once owned by Jane Austen and purchased last year at auction by the singer Kelly Clarkson may find a permanent home in Britain after all, thanks to an anonymous donor.

headline: The Questions Raised by Makeup
text: I’VE flown for the business for about the last 18 years. I’m in the beauty business and now work with Make Up For Ever. When I was with another brand, I used to oversee 23 countries, and was traveling to five or six countries a month. One time I had to go to six countries in three days. Fortunately, I don’t have to do those kinds of whirlwind trips anymore, but I’m still flying all the time.

headline: Listen Up | Teenage Folk-Singing Sisters Hit the Big Time
text: The Indianapolis-based sister folk duo Lily and Madeleine recorded their debut EP, “Weight of the Globe” (which came out in January), entirely on the weekends. That’s because on weekdays, they were too busy with high-school homework. “It’s weird that we’re, like, business partners now,” said Madeleine Jurkiewicz, 18, the older sister. Not long ago, she and 16-year-old Lily were anonymous bedroom singers; now they’re signed to Sufjan Stevens’ Asthmatic Kitty Records, with a namesake debut album on the way (on Oct. 29). “Devil We Know,” which makes its world premiere here, is the centerpiece of the record, an appealing back-country portrait comprised of a slow-rolling piano melody, deftly plucked acoustic guitar and the teens’ tender, swirling voices.

headline: Memorable Quotes From the Trial of James (Whitey) Bulger
text: The following is a collection of memorable quotations from the trial of James (Whitey) Bulger, the notorious Boston crime boss who was found guilty of gangland crimes, including murder.

headline: Driving a Work in Progress From Elio Motors
text: Phoenix-based Elio Motors has built a vehicle that isn’t exactly a car, but really isn’t a motorcycle either. Lodged somewhere in between those two classifications — although considered by many states to be a motorcycle — the 3-wheeler looks like something the Ministry of Information would have issued a low-level bureaucrat in Terry Gilliam’s classic dark comedy, “Brazil.”

headline: Carole King Musical Finds Its Carole King
text: The producers of “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical” have found their star.

headline: A Glut of Antidepressants
text: Over the past two decades, the use of antidepressants has skyrocketed. One in 10 Americans now takes an antidepressant medication; among women in their 40s and 50s, the figure is one in four.

headline: Korean Buckwheat Noodles With Chilled Broth and Kimchi
text: This recipe is inspired by the signature Korean summer noodle dish, naeng myung. The traditional dish is made with a strong beef broth. I’m using a vegetarian broth I make with dried mushrooms and kelp, adapted from a recipe in Deborah Madison’s “Vegetarian Cooking for Everybody.” You could also use chicken stock. The dish can include chicken or meat, or it can be vegetarian, as this version is, with tofu standing in for chicken. It can also be vegan if you omit the boiled eggs. Make the broth a day ahead so that it will be nice and cold.

headline: Barrage of Fees Is Starting to Follow Fliers to the Hotel
text: While a lot of attention has been focused on fees the airlines are piling on to basic fares, the hotel business has also been steadily gaining revenue from adding charges to the basic room rate.

headline: Who Would Buy BlackBerry?
text: At the rate BlackBerry is plummeting, it would stain any buyout.

headline: Steve King Still Stands by ‘Cantaloupe’ Comments
text: If the Republican Party is split between those who support immigration reform, and those who don’t, it is also split between those who realize the necessity, for their brand, of speaking sensitively and sensibly about the topic—and those who don’t.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘Rubble’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 25. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: Getting on Base a Lot Helps a Team Only So Much
text: Every batter approaches the game differently, but in the end, a solid goal for every at-bat is not to make an out. In August, no one in baseball has been better at not making outs than Mets first baseman Ike Davis.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Aug. 6 – 12, 2013
text: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events that made news this week.

headline: Suit Accuses Online Lender of Violating New York Rate Caps
text: New York State’s top prosecutor filed suit on Monday against an online lender that offers short-term loans at interest rates of more than 300 percent, the latest warning shot in a sweeping battle by state authorities to enforce local interest rate caps.

headline: A Year of Breast-Feeding
text: The longer a mother breast-feeds, the greater the benefit to the child’s brain development, a new study says.

headline: Kerry Washington Seals It With a Kiss
text: The Girl: The actress, making headlines (and the cover of August’s Vanity Fair) for her increasingly popular personal style, was sweet as sugar in a pastel pink frock with an embroidered pattern of lips and hearts at the MTV Teen Choice Awards last night. Her own bright red kisser pulled the whole look together.

headline: This Town and Its Newspapers
text: My Sunday column argued that the proper context for understanding how the Washington Post ended up passing from the Graham family to Jeff Bezos isn’t just the disruptive effects of the online revolution writ large. It’s also the more specific revolution wrought by the ex-Postie founders of Politico, who seized a market and an audience — obsessive political coverage for the political class — that had long belonged naturally to the Post, and that the Grahams’ newspaper clearly needed, and still needs, to compete successfully in the more nationalized and competitive media marketplace that the internet ushered in.

headline: Do New Yorkers Who Ride the Subway Risk Hearing Loss?
text: Q. Have any studies assessed the risks of hearing loss faced by New Yorkers who ride the subway? Does it help to cover your ears?

headline: Bloomberg on Stop-and-Frisk Ruling
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg responds to a federal judge’s finding that the controversial police practice violated the constitutional rights of minorities.

headline: ‘Breaking Bad’ Premiere Draws Biggest Audience in Its History
text: Surrounded by a whirlwind of media coverage and critical praise, the AMC drama “Breaking Bad” began its final run of eight episodes on Sunday night with the biggest audience in the show’s history, 5.9 million viewers.

headline: Judges Finds in Favor of Company Seeking to Build Headquarters Near the Palisades
text: A judge has ruled in favor of a company seeking to build a corporate headquarters in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., that opponents have tried to block because they say it would disrupt views of the Palisades.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Egypt Delays Plans to Clear Morsi Backers From Camps
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s military-appointed government on Monday again postponed its latest threats to forcibly clear two camps here of tens of thousands of supporters of Mohamed Morsi, the ousted president, raising new questions about when and how the authorities might seek to end the six-week-old standoff.

headline: The Firewall Paradox
text: An unexpected paradox involving black holes pits two basic tenets of modern science against one another: the theory of quantum mechanics, which governs subatomic particles, and Einstein’s theory of general relativity, which explains how gravity works.

headline: ‘Powerful Voices’
text: Mayoral candidate Anthony D. Weiner’s campaign advertisement from Aug. 12, 2013.

headline: Holder Calls for Drug Sentencing Changes
text: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. discussed modifications to low-level drug offense charges to reduce taxpayer spending on prisons and address unfairness in the justice system.

text: MOSCOW — It was not as if Amantle Montsho had not been warned.

headline: The Calculus of Primary Care
text: My patient Kevin developed a terrible rash. By the time he showed up, a few weeks into his new life as human scratching post, he was red and flaky from scalp to ankles. I asked a few basic questions and knew in less than 30 seconds exactly what to do for him.

headline: Timing a Rise in Sea Level
text: Thirty-five years ago, a scientist named John H. Mercer issued a warning. By then it was already becoming clear that human emissions would warm the earth, and Dr. Mercer had begun thinking deeply about the consequences.

text: Here are some highlights of events taking place in and around Pebble Beach this week:

headline: A Restaurateur’s Star Shines in Washington
text: Ashok Bajaj just opened his eighth restaurant in the district, Nopa Kitchen and Bar.

headline: Right This Way, Senator
text: WASHINGTON — In December 1988, when Ashok Bajaj opened the Bombay Club here, the city was gearing up for the inauguration of President George H. W. Bush. For Washington, that’s pretty much where the celebrating ended.

text: Photos from Gaza, Egypt, Mali and Iran.

text: This time, they say, Einstein might really be wrong.

text: Zachary Levi and Krysta Rodriguez sing the number “First Impressions” from the new Broadway musical about a blind date, now at the Longacre Theater.

headline: On the Verge | Yang Li’s Deliberately Imperfect Style
text: Last spring, the 25-year-old London-based designer Yang Li debuted his first runway collection, a line of reimagined street-wear staples with a gothic influence. For someone so young, Li has accomplished quite a lot: after dropping out of Central Saint Martins, he interned for Raf Simons, and by the tender age of 23 had already caught the eye of Michèle Montagne, the in-demand French publicist and stylist who helped shape the careers of Ann Demeulemeester and Haider Ackermann. Li’s clothes are made in Italy, and finished with absolute precision — except when they aren’t. He loves an element of spontaneity, like slashing the two front pockets of a slim-cut classic bouclé jacket. “Art is not all clean lines, but has a human touch,” he said. “Same with fashion.”

headline: ‘Serious’
text: Mayoral candidate Joseph J. Lhota released his first television ad in over two months.

headline: CDs From K. Michelle and Leo Genovese
text: K. MICHELLE

headline: How to Share Scientific Data
text: Stewart Brand, the founder of the Whole Earth catalog and a Silicon Valley muse, once said that information wanted to be free and expensive, simultaneously. That paradox is increasingly haunting the world of modern science.

headline: Making Art From Ocean Trash, Autism and Cancer, Genes and Sports
text: A team of scientists and artists collect plastics — lots of them — from Alaska’s remote shores; researchers have found that a small number of people with autism have mutated cancer genes that caused their brain disorder; the author of “The Sports Gene” talks about whether athletic ability is encoded in our genes.

headline: A Malaria Vaccine Works, With Limits
text: A new type of malaria vaccine gave 100 percent protection against infection to a small number of volunteers in recent tests — but under conditions that would be nearly impossible to reproduce in the countries where most malaria victims live.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Weiner’s ‘Powerful Voices’
text: SUMMARY Once an improbable frontrunner in the Democratic primary, Anthony D. Weiner has fallen to fourth place in many polls, his campaign engulfed by fresh revelations of online liaisons with women. In his first television ad, “Powerful Voices,” Mr. Weiner speaks directly to the viewer for a full 30 seconds, casting himself as an underdog hounded by the establishment and urging voters to ignore his critics.

headline: Kennedy, and What Might Have Been
text: As the 50th anniversary this November of the assassination of John F. Kennedy looms on the horizon, the debates over his legacy and presidency continue: a procession of “what ifs” and “might have beens,” accompanied by contradictory arguments, and informed and not-so-informed speculation. Would Kennedy have avoided Lyndon B. Johnson’s tragic escalation of the war in Vietnam? Would he have found a way to propel his stalled tax-cut bill and civil rights legislation through Congress and start a war on poverty, or was Johnson able to achieve these historic goals only through a combination of his bare-knuckled, tactical knowledge of Congress; his personal relationships on Capitol Hill; and his ability to use the momentum of sentiment generated by Kennedy’s death?

headline: The Stuff of Those Visions in Clinical Death
text: A surge of brain activity in dying rats may hold an explanation for the vivid, realistic visions experienced by some human victims of cardiac arrest, researchers say.

headline: New Studies Suggest an ‘Adam’ and ‘Eve’ Link
text: It may not have been the Garden of Eden, but two new studies suggest that the most recent common male ancestor of Homo sapiens — Y Chromosome Adam — and the most recent common female ancestor, Mitochondrial Eve, may have lived at the same time and in approximately the same region.

headline: Ways to Watch Live TV on a Laptop or Tablet
text: Watching Live TV

headline: An Odd Crown for Atlanta: Most Guns at the Airport
text: ATLANTA — For most fliers, the standard slap-your-forehead moment occurs after opening a suitcase upon arrival and discovering that they forgot to pack their prescription medicine, running shoes or perfect necktie.

headline: The Chicken Little Scale
text: Brad DeLong sends us to Dan Drezner, who rates Hubbard-Kane along what he calls the Cassandra Scale of excessive debt phobia. But while I like the scale, Drezner kind of messes up his mythology; after all, the point about Cassandra was that although nobody would believe her, she was always right — whereas the people he’s talking about are always wrong.

headline: Mother Says Son Is Messiah; Judge Says No
text: Updated, 6:14 p.m. | Asked to settle a dispute between a mother and a father over what their child’s last name should be, Martin or McCullough, a magistrate judge in Tennessee in search of a Solomonic compromise decreed last week that the boy should be known as Martin McCullough. The child’s mother, Jaleesa Martin, told the NBC News affiliate WBIR-Knoxville that she would appeal the ruling, mainly because the court order meant scrapping the first name she had given her son, Messiah.

headline: Intense and Dramatic Tango, Up Close and Sensual
text: On Sept. 25 and 26, the Argentine dancers Gabriel Missé and Analía Centurión will appear in City Center’s Fall for Dance opening program. Since they are among the world’s most wonderful dancers today, I look forward to it, just as I cheered them recently when they performed at the Vail International Dance Festival. Yet, although I have loved Argentine tango as a theatrical form since the 1980s, I increasingly have learned that tango is best seen at close quarters. Yes, tango is inherently dramatic and scintillatingly musical, but its whole emphasis can be distorted by rendering it theatrical or exhibitionistic.

headline: Reality Gold Is Scarce as Junkyard Ducks
text: Up on Porter Ridge, they have junkyards and hairy guys and explosives and pet bears. But do they have the makings of another duck nation? Probably not.

headline: A Wild Ride Through Stravinsky’s Early Years
text: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — Sometimes the Bard Music Festival has an agenda.

headline: Syrian War Shapes Trip by Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff
text: TEL AVIV — The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff opened a weeklong visit to the Middle East on Monday for discussions on potential additions of American support to Israel and Jordan, which are both facing border-security challenges from the conflict in neighboring Syria.

headline: Seriously, Levity Is Onstage
text: Series B in the Summer Shorts program at the 59E59 Theaters is a mixed bag, though consistently intriguing. Comedy is the order of the evening, and that’s more than welcome on a summer night.

headline: Selections for Marathon Couch Time
text: Choosing movies to watch online can be a lot like blind dating, except that your yenta is a piece of software telling you, “Because you liked X you might like Y.” What you see is what the algorithm gets: your past choices, your ratings, what other people are watching.

headline: Performing Shakespeare, With Help From Mandolin, Clarinet, and Saxophone
text: “Under the Greenwood Tree,” a musical adaptation of “As You Like It,” is frequently too thin and clumsily staged. But when a moment works, it works beautifully.

headline: Herd Mentality Online, and an Ancient Frieze
text: A family gains a say on how its genetic legacy is used in medical research. Internet users can be herded like sheep. A giant frieze in a Maya pyramid casts light on an ancient conflict. And for those who did not pick the right numbers in the Powerball lottery, there’s a $1.5 million prize from NASA waiting to be won.

headline: Family Seeks Compensation for British Businessman’s Mysterious Death in China
text: BEIJING — The wife and the mother of Neil Heywood, the British businessman whose mysterious death in China set off the downfall of a senior Communist Party official last year, have pressed for compensation over what the Chinese authorities had determined was a murder, according to people with knowledge of the case.

headline: The Documentary ‘Citizen Koch’ Regains Money
text: One year ago, the filmmakers Tia Lessin and Carl Deal thought they had hit the public television jackpot. ITVS, an arm of public television that finances independent documentaries, had signaled interest in subsidizing and broadcasting a film about the influence of big-dollar donors on elections. At the time, Ms. Lessin and Mr. Deal were calling their documentary “Citizen Corp,” and they were expecting $150,000 from ITVS to help them finish producing it.

headline: The Dresses Do All the Work
text: Journalistic responsibility requires me to refer to the Budapest Festival Orchestra’s presentation of Mozart’s “Nozze di Figaro” at the Rose Theater as a “staged concert performance.” This is the official description from the presenter, the Mostly Mozart Festival, and the orchestra’s esteemed founding conductor, Ivan Fischer, who also directed this highly anticipated event.

headline: In One Bundle of Mortgages, the Subprime Crisis Reverberates
text: A subprime deal came back to haunt Fabrice Tourre, a former Goldman Sachs trader, when a federal jury in Manhattan found him liable for civil securities fraud.

headline: In Move for Economy, Mexican President Seeks Foreign Investment in Energy
text: MEXICO CITY — President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico on Monday, pushing one of the most sweeping economic overhauls here in the past two decades, proposed opening his country’s historically closed energy industry to foreign investment.

headline: Science Bookshelf
text: 1 QUIET by Susan Cain. Crown. Introverts — one-third of the population — are undervalued in American society. (Last month’s ranking: 1.)

headline: Feeling For | A Modest Japanese Place Where Fashion Eats
text: While the fashion world is often drawn to new and shiny hot spots like Omar’s or Acme, it’s Omen, a dark, unassuming-looking Japanese restaurant on a sleepy block in SoHo, that has served as the unspoken clubhouse of the city’s stylish sets since the early ’80s. And with the international fashion community descending on New York in the next few weeks, Omen (which recently changed its name to Omen A Zen) will be in full swing.

headline: Talent Lies Within. But Where?
text: As an 800-meter runner at Columbia University, David Epstein often tested himself against his training partner, Scott. Mr. Epstein was a walk-on who had clawed his way onto the varsity team. Scott, the son of two Canadian track standouts, had set a national age-group record in 1997, the same year David had taken up track as a high school junior.

headline: The Verdict on Whitey Bulger
text: James (Whitey) Bulger, the mobster who terrorized South Boston in the 1970s and ’80s while he led the notorious Winter Hill Gang, was convicted on Monday.

headline: TimesTalks: ‘Breaking Bad’
text: The creator and cast of AMC's "Breaking Bad" discuss the ways the show has changed since its inception, and reminisce about some of its most iconic scenes.

headline: Lavabit Founder Says He Had ‘Obligation’ to Shut Service
text: Ladar Levison was not yet 20 years old when Congress passed the Patriot Act after the Sept. 11 terror attacks. It gave him a start-up idea: an e-mail service for what he thought of as “a tech-savvy crowd” that cared about privacy.

headline: Elon Musk Unveils Plans for Hyperloop High-Speed Train
text: Never let it be said that Elon Musk, a serial entrepreneur who was a co-founder of PayPal and the electric car company Tesla Motors, is afraid to think big.

headline: A Wave of Hospital Mergers
text: Over the last four years, there has been a surge in the number of hospital mergers.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Hullabaloo Over the ‘Hyperloop’
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. On Monday, much of the Internet and Twitterverse was aflutter in anticipation of an announcement by Elon Musk, a co-founder of PayPal and chairman of Tesla Motors, about the so-called Hyperloop, an alternative to high-speed rail.

headline: A Coin Is Historic, Priceless and No Longer in a Vault
text: For 10 months, the world’s most valuable coin sat wrapped in plastic on a folding chair in a little cagelike compartment behind a bright blue door at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. It was only a step or two away from billions of dollars’ worth of neatly stacked bars of gold bullion.

headline: Triple Play: Week 19 Results
text: Because of some technical difficulties last week, Triple Play was more of an E-5, but here are the results nonetheless. The Bats blog crew took extra infield practice this week to avoid future problems.

headline: BlackBerry Faces Dwindling Options for a Deal
text: BlackBerry Ltd. indicated on Monday that it was seriously weighing a potential sale of itself. But it is not clear that anyone will want to pay up.

headline: Rebel Chief in Syria Visits Assad’s Home Region
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The commander of the Free Syrian Army, whose forces claim to be leading the insurgency but have been overshadowed by the gains of their tactical jihadist allies, has visited the coastal province that is home to President Bashar al-Assad, according to a video circulated by activists on Monday.

headline: Banklike Company Offering Cash-Back Rewards to Close
text: PerkStreet Financial, an upstart quasi-bank that aimed to offer generous cash-back debit-card rewards, announced Monday that it would cease operations next month because of a lack of financing.

headline: A.A.U. Coach Arrested on Drug Charge
text: The head of a major Amateur Athletic Union basketball program in Washington was arrested last week on drug trafficking charges after what law enforcement officials said was a yearlong investigation by the Drug Enforcement Administration.

headline: Web Services to Challenge Post Office in Bill-Paying
text: WASHINGTON — As losses mount at the United States Postal Service, new digital mail companies are trying to take advantage by promising to give customers the ability to pay bills without having to lick envelopes, buy stamps or even get out of their chairs.

headline: On the Crony Safari, a Tour of a City’s Corruption
text: PRAGUE — Several dozen people, Czechs and foreigners alike, crammed aboard a bus called the Crony Safari on a recent day for a decidedly unusual tour.

headline: After Decision, Mayoral Candidates Offer Many Opinions but Few Concrete Plans
text: Many of the candidates for mayor of New York have called the city’s use of stop-and-frisk policing unconstitutional, unwarranted and unfair to black and Hispanic communities.

headline: The Rich Drive Differently, a Study Suggests
text: Jokes about BMW drivers being, on average, somewhat less than courteous are fairly common. They often run along the lines of, “Despite its good brakes, a BMW will usually stop with a jerk.” Sometimes the language is more colorful.

headline: A Former Engine of the G.O.P., the Town Hall Meeting, Cools Down
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Pete Sessions, a Texas Republican, is no stranger to town hall meetings and their political possibilities. Four summers ago, he helped his party use them to stoke opposition to President Obama’s health care bill. Across the country, forums like his fed a budding Tea Party movement and set the stage for returning the House to Republican control in 2010.

headline: New Orleans and U.S. in Standoff on Detentions
text: NEW ORLEANS — The Orleans Parish sheriff will no longer honor many requests from the federal immigration authorities to detain people who are suspected of being here illegally, making New Orleans one of a growing number of jurisdictions to adopt such a policy and the first to do so in the Deep South.

headline: For Pilot, a Detour on the Way Back
text: BROOKLINE, Mass. — Andy Aduddell was playing the best golf of his life 12 years ago when he showed up for a practice round before a tournament at his home course in Texas — and never hit a ball.

headline: What’s on Your Mind?
text: My husband is a saint. He knows how tedious I am, but loves me anyway. At night, for instance, we often watch an episode of some series that’s available on Netflix: “Kingdom,” “George Gently,” “Sherlock.” It’s always a mistake, though, because all I do is judge the characters, wonder what will happen next, ask questions and solicit my husband’s opinion about whether he thinks most men behave the way the ones on TV do.

headline: Russia Steps Up Raids Against Migrants
text: MOSCOW — It all began with the arrest of a rape suspect in an open-air market two weeks ago. A brawl erupted. A police officer was injured.

headline: Migrant Workers Detained in Russia
text: The detentions have exposed the complexity and corruption of Russia’s labor market and have tapped into the country’s simmering ethnic animosity.

headline: The Ad Campaign: ‘Serious’ Lhota Tries to Stand Out From Circus
text: SUMMARY Joseph J. Lhota is seen by many as the leading Republican candidate for mayor, but on television, another Republican has been more visible: John A. Catsimatidis, who is campaigning with his own money. On Monday, Mr. Lhota, a former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and deputy mayor for Rudolph W. Giuliani, began running a new television advertisement, his first in over two months. The 30-second spot, titled “Serious,” is appearing on cable and broadcast stations.

headline: The First Couple’s Chance to Put Themselves First
text: EDGARTOWN, Mass. — President Obama and his wife, Michelle, have begun a weeklong holiday on Martha’s Vineyard that, for now at least, is more a romantic getaway than a family vacation.

headline: Moving Beyond Stop-and-Frisk
text: MY husband and I are about the same age and build, wear the same clothes and share the same gender, but I am far more likely to be stopped by the police. This isn’t because I have a criminal record or engage in furtive movements. Nor is my husband a choirboy. Statistically speaking, it’s because I’m black and he’s white.

headline: The Olympics’ Leadership Mess
text: ON Sept. 10, members of the International Olympic Committee will vote for a new president for the first time in 12 years. The campaign for the I.O.C. presidency is a quiet event that does not attract much news coverage (how many of the six candidates can you name?), but if you care about human rights, the stakes are high. This may be the last chance for many years to reform the committee’s approach to repressive governments that seek to host the games. It is imperative that the committee elect a president willing to lead, not cave in, on this issue.

headline: Tackling the Roots of Rape
text: Steubenville. The Naval Academy. Vanderbilt University. The stories of young men sexually assaulting young women seem never to stop, despite all the education we’ve had and all the progress we’ve supposedly made, and there are times when I find myself darkly wondering if there’s some ineradicable predatory streak in the male subset of our species.

headline: Where Stop-and-Frisk Tactic Is Business as Usual, Skepticism Prevails
text: In the Brooklyn neighborhood perhaps most accustomed to the stop-and-frisk policing strategy, word that a federal judge had ruled that the practice violated the constitutional rights of minority New Yorkers prompted some residents to say that they understood — and even supported — the rationale behind the strategy, though not how it unfolded around them day after day.

headline: New York City's Economic Challenges
text: Inequality, taxes, jobs. Where should the next mayor start?

headline: Off-Color Wordplay From Kraft, Part of a Big Marketing Blitz
text: THE Kraft Foods Group is continuing a major marketing blitz with an initiative for a new product line — budgeted at more than $30 million in the first year — that seeks to tap into the current mania with all things chef.

headline: Racial Bias Claim Dismissed for Paula Deen
text: ATLANTA — A federal judge on Monday ruled that a white former employee had no standing to bring claims of racial discrimination in a lawsuit against Paula Deen, the celebrity chef who was the target of criticism this summer after she acknowledged using a racial epithet.

headline: U.S. Subpoenas Goldman in Inquiry of Aluminum Warehouses
text: Goldman Sachs has been subpoenaed by federal regulators investigating complaints that the financial giant’s metals warehouses have intentionally created delays and inflated the price of aluminum.

headline: Blackstone Is Said to Buy Apartments From G.E.
text: With a big deal for apartment buildings, the Blackstone Group is making a huge wager on housing.

headline: Raonic Has Second Thoughts on a Montreal Net Controversy
text: MASON, Ohio — Milos Raonic came into the Cincinnati Masters having just made the finals in Montreal and become the first Canadian in the top ten. So it would have been easy for Raonic to focus only on his current highs.

headline: The Government as a Low-Wage Employer
text: In 1965, in a nation torn by racial strife, President Johnson signed an executive order mandating nondiscrimination in employment by government contractors. Now, as President Obama has observed, the nation is divided by  a different threat: widening income inequality. He could respond much as Mr. Johnson did — with an executive order aimed, this time, at raising the pay of millions of poorly paid employees of government contractors.

headline: Shortsighted Thinking on Israeli Settlements
text: There was a certain internal political logic to two announcements made by the Israeli government, just days before Wednesday’s scheduled resumption of peace talks with the Palestinians. Early Monday, the government released a list of 26 Palestinian prisoners to be released Tuesday, most serving sentences for murder and other violent crimes. A few hours before that, the government published bids for the construction of more than 1,000 new housing units in East Jerusalem and existing West Bank settlements — a move apparently designed to mollify right-wingers who would oppose the prisoner release.

headline: Racial Discrimination in Stop-and-Frisk
text: Judge Shira Scheindlin of Federal District Court in New York upheld the bedrock principle of individual liberty on Monday when she ruled that the tactics underlying New York City’s stop-and-frisk program violated the constitutional rights of minority citizens. She found that the city had been “deliberately indifferent” to police officers illegally detaining and frisking minority residents on the streets over many years.

headline: Back Home, Still Taking On the World
text: Clint Dempsey runs his own routes. This is how he became one of the most productive scorers the United States has ever sent out into this wide, soccer-loving world.

headline: Arms Shipments Seen From Sudan to Syria Rebels
text: Syrian rebels, frustrated by the West’s reluctance to provide arms, have found a supplier in an unlikely source: Sudan, a country that has been under international arms embargoes and maintains close ties with a stalwart backer of the Syrian government, Iran.

headline: A Limit on Consumer Costs Is Delayed in Health Care Law
text: WASHINGTON — In another setback for President Obama’s health care initiative, the administration has delayed until 2015 a significant consumer protection in the law that limits how much people may have to spend on their own health care.

headline: Don’t Kill Fannie Mae
text: Could it get any worse for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac? Last week, even President Obama joined the growing chorus of those who want to put them out of business.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Two Powerful Signals of a Major Shift on Crime
text: WASHINGTON — Two decisions Monday, one by a federal judge in New York and the other by Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., were powerful signals that the pendulum has swung away from the tough-on-crime policies of a generation ago.

headline: Texas: After Illnesses, Compounded Drugs Are Recalled
text: A pharmacy has recalled all of its compounded sterile products after 15 patients in two Texas hospitals fell ill from what federal health officials said were tainted sterile infusions. The patients developed bacterial infections in their bloodstreams from infusions of calcium gluconate made by Specialty Compounding of Cedar Park, the Food and Drug Administration said. The substance is used to treat conditions related to low calcium levels. No patients died. Lawmakers are developing legislation that would toughen rules for pharmacy compounding, the practice of custom-mixing medicines, after a Massachusetts pharmacy caused a deadly meningitis outbreak last year.

headline: In the Worst Slump of His Career, Rivera Stays Coolheaded in Finding a Fix
text: Mariano Rivera does not share the public’s sense of concern about his well-being despite his recent slump, in which he has blown three consecutive save opportunities for the first time in his career.

headline: ‘Love’s Labour’s Lost’
text: Scenes from the Shakespeare in the Park production at the Delacorte Theater.

headline: Reactions to Stop-and-Frisk Ruling
text: Residents of Brownsville, Brooklyn, were divided over the policing strategy after a federal judge ruled that it violated the constitutional rights of minority New Yorkers.

headline: California: Rights Guaranteed for Transgender Students
text: Gov. Jerry Brown signed legislation on Monday that guarantees transgender students access to interscholastic sports, gym classes, locker rooms and bathrooms based on their gender identity, irrespective of their biological sex. Interscholastic athletic commissions in several states, including California, have policies that allow students to compete on teams that correspond with their gender identities rather than the sex listed on their school records. California will be the first state to write access for transgender students to sex-segregated activities into law.

headline: Jobs Announcement
text: “For I am he born to tame you, Kate,And bring you from a wild Kate to a KateConformable as other household Kates.And yet, you wanton rampallian, you hath sunk my BATTLESHIP.” -The Taming of the Shrew, more or less, Act II, Scene 1

headline: Shakespearean Mood Swings in Progress
text: The young man has been caught by his best friends in a seriously compromising position. One of four forsworn swains in the splashy, hit-or-miss musical adaptation of Shakespeare’s “Love’s Labour’s Lost,” which opened on Monday night at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, this red-faced lad has been found — oh, the shame of it — composing a love poem to a member of the opposite sex.

headline: Giants Look for Consistent Offense After Preseason Game Shows Holes
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — After practice Monday, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin quickly pointed out that there were only nine workout days remaining before the regular season.

headline: N.S.A. Leaks Make Plan for Cyberdefense Unlikely
text: WASHINGTON — Even while rapidly expanding its electronic surveillance around the world, the National Security Agency has lobbied inside the government to deploy the equivalent of a “Star Wars” defense for America’s computer networks, designed to intercept cyberattacks before they could cripple power plants, banks or financial markets.

headline: Stephens Trying to Survive Glare of Spotlight
text: MASON, Ohio — Sloane Stephens has found it more and more difficult to deal with the growing crowds that swarm her at American tournaments.

headline: More Options, if Woodson Chooses
text: Last week, the Knicks quietly added to their hectic off-season by signing Beno Udrih, a Slovenian guard who played for the Orlando Magic last season, to a one-year contract. With little cash to spend in free agency, the Knicks were bargain hunting and found Udrih, a nine-year N.B.A. veteran, a nice way to bolster their backcourt cheaply.

headline: Bloomberg Signs Bills to Aid Disaster Planning
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed nine bills on Monday intended to close large holes in disaster planning that were exposed after Hurricane Sandy, which left vulnerable residents without help or adrift in shelters for days.

headline: Ticketmaster’s President Is Expected to Be Ousted by Live Nation
text: Live Nation Entertainment will oust Nathan Hubbard, the president of its Ticketmaster unit, in coming days, as part of a revamping of the division, according to two people with knowledge of the situation.

headline: Kerry and Colombia Leaders Discuss Guerrilla War and Spying
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Secretary of State John Kerry met Monday with leaders of Colombia, Washington’s top ally in South America, offering support as negotiators move ahead with talks aimed at ending that country’s long-running guerrilla war, and seeking to assuage concerns over the scope of the National Security Agency’s surveillance practices.

headline: William P. Clark, Influential Adviser in Reagan White House, Is Dead at 81
text: William P. Clark, who as one of President Ronald Reagan’s most trusted advisers successfully nudged him toward more hard-line positions on military spending, arms control and involvement in Central America, died on Saturday at his ranch near Shandon, Calif. He was 81.

headline: Myanmar: U.N. Envoy Visits Troubled State
text: A United Nations human rights envoy on Monday visited the state of Rakhine just days after the police opened fire on protesters seeking access to the body of a Rohingya Muslim fisherman. One person was killed and 10 others were wounded in the confrontation on Friday, said a government spokesman, Win Myaing. Over the past year more than 250 people have been killed in religious violence, most of them minority Muslims, and 140,000 have been forced to flee their homes. A United Nations special rapporteur on human rights, Tomás Ojea Quintana, is on an 11-day visit, including a stop in Rakhine, scene of some of the worst bloodshed. After the battered body of a fisherman washed ashore on Friday in Sittwe, rumors spread among Rohingya Muslims that he had been killed by the police. Mr. Win Myaing said the police fired into the air when 500 Rohingyas who were demanding access to the body attacked a police checkpoint. After more protesters gathered, the officers shot into the crowd, wounding at least 10, he said. One of the men died of his wounds, he said. (AP)

headline: Boater’s Death Was Likely an Accident, Police Say
text: MONTAUK, N.Y. — The authorities are investigating the death of a Manhattan interior design executive who was reported to have fallen off the stern of a 45-foot yacht that she and her husband had anchored some two miles northeast of here early Sunday morning. But the Suffolk County police said the preliminary results gave them no reason to believe that the death was anything other than an accident.

headline: Times Chairman Sells a Portion of His Stock
text: Arthur O. Sulzberger Jr., chairman of The New York Times Company, sold 50,000 shares of his company’s stock last week, a day after declaring that the family-owned newspaper was not for sale.

headline: Mayor’s Take on Policing Lacks Nuance
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, were in fine fettle on Monday, which is not to be confused with doing themselves any favors.

headline: Much Ado About Who: Is It Really Shakespeare?
text: For nearly two centuries, scholars have debated whether some 325 lines in the 1602 quarto edition of Thomas Kyd’s play “The Spanish Tragedy” were, in fact, written by Shakespeare.

headline: Rodriguez Has Added Noise, if Not Production
text: The die-hard Yankee fans like to remember old Yankee Stadium as a place that would rumble and shake during the loudest cheers.

headline: In New Jersey, Short Senate Primary Race Ends With Final Appeals to Voters
text: TRENTON — As New Jersey residents prepared to vote in a primary on Tuesday to fill a seat in the United States Senate, candidates traveled around the state to make their final pitches.

headline: Vote Tuesday in New Jersey
text: Our recommendation in the special Democratic primary election for United States Senate is Cory Booker.

headline: Fort Hood Gunman Told Panel That Death Would Make Him a Martyr
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — One year after he waged a deadly shooting rampage at the Fort Hood Army base here in November 2009, Major Nidal Malik Hasan told a panel of military mental health experts that he wished he had been killed during the attack because it would have meant God had chosen him for martyrdom.

headline: Sanity Board Report for Major Nidal Malik Hasan
text: Documents released to The New York Times through the civilian lawyer of Major Nidal Malik Hasan provide the first account in his own words of his deadly shooting rampage at the Fort Hood Army base in November 2009.

headline: Clinton Calls for Action to Protect Voter Rights
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton waded into the battle over voting rights on Monday in the first of a series of speeches in which she says she plans to address some of the most pressing issues in Washington.

headline: To Keep Flores’s Bat in Lineup, Mets Plan to Move Him Around the Infield
text: LOS ANGELES — Terry Collins was asked Monday afternoon if the Mets would consider using infielder Wilmer Flores, who has been impressive over his first few days as a major leaguer, as a corner outfielder to find him more chances to play.

headline: Corrections: August 13, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Shirley Herz, Press Agent for Broadway and Beyond, Dies at 87
text: Shirley Herz, a theatrical press agent whose career stretched from the days of planting blurbs in Walter Winchell’s newspaper column to the television and Internet eras, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 87.

headline: Perks for Donors: Table Tennis Game
text: Some political candidates offer donors the chance to rub elbows with celebrities. But Bill de Blasio is offering something more: the chance to play table tennis against one.

headline: Weiner on a Roommate, Therapy and the Clintons
text: Unfazed by past unpleasant encounters with the Internet, Anthony D. Weiner stopped by a Midtown bar on Monday evening for an interview with Ben Smith, editor in chief of Buzzfeed, the popular online outfit known for cute animal pictures and breezy “listicles” (along with political reporting). Mr. Smith drank a pint of beer; Mr. Weiner, who said he no longer drinks alcohol, sipped iced coffee. What follows is a Buzzfeed-inspired account of the evening.

headline: Stringer Goes After Spitzer During a Blistering Debate
text: The second face-off between the Democratic candidates for New York City comptroller was even nastier than the first.

headline: Achieving a Velvet Complexion
text: In a runway season that was dominated by a bold stained lip and a heavily lined eye, one couldn’t help but take notice of the velvety, void-of-blush face that served as a canvas for these trends. Linda Cantello, the Giorgio Armani makeup artist who designed one of the best versions of the look in Milan, explains how to create this new porcelain take on the matte complexion.

headline: The Deduction for State and Local Taxes
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Word of the Day | befuddle
text: befuddle •\bi-ˈfə-dəl, be-\• verb

headline: News Quiz | August 13, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: What’s on Tuesday
text: 8 P.M. (ESPN) RUNNER By 1972, the American distance runner Mary Decker was already a world-class athlete, but, at barely 14, was too young to be eligible for the Munich Olympics. In 1976 leg stress fractures kept her out of the Montreal Games. And in 1980 the United States boycott prevented her from competing in Moscow. In this “Nine for IX” documentary, Shola Lynch tells the story of Ms. Decker (above, in 1984) as she prepared to make her Olympic debut in the 3,000 meters at the Games in Los Angeles — and the collision with Zola Budd, an 18-year-old barefooted South African running for Britain, that derailed her dreams.

headline: Mets Squander Mejia’s Strong Start in Loss to Dodgers
text: LOS ANGELES — Jenrry Mejia’s pitches dipped and darted while he defanged the Los Angeles Dodgers — baseball’s best team the past month and a half — through the first five innings on Monday night. But like one of Mejia’s cut fastballs, the game took a sharp, swift turn as the Mets’ defense fell apart during a sloppy sixth.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 13, 2013
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Thea Alvin on Life With Pebbles and Bam Bam.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | New York’s Stop-and-Frisk Practice Violated Rights, Judge Finds
text: In the article “Stop-and-Frisk Practice Violated Rights, Judge Rules,” Joseph Goldstein writes about Monday’s ruling about New York City’s stop-and-frisk policy.

headline: Is It Nuts to Give to the Poor Without Strings Attached?
text: Bernard Omondi lives in a small Kenyan village in a rural district called Siaya that sits right on the Equator and is almost impossible to get to. He has spent years working on and off as a day laborer, moving stones on construction sites, and commuting long distances over rough dirt roads. When he could find work, he made about $2 a day. When he couldn’t, his two sons sometimes went hungry. Then one morning last year, Omondi woke up to an unusual text message. “When I saw the message, I jumped up,” he recalled. “My wife said, ‘Bernard, what is it?’ ” He told her he had just been given $500 with no strings attached. “ It’s here! ” he said.

headline: How Laura Poitras Helped Snowden Spill His Secrets
text: This past January, Laura Poitras received a curious e-mail from an anonymous stranger requesting her public encryption key. For almost two years, Poitras had been working on a documentary about surveillance, and she occasionally received queries from strangers. She replied to this one and sent her public key — allowing him or her to send an encrypted e-mail that only Poitras could open, with her private key — but she didn’t think much would come of it.

headline: Q. & A.: Edward Snowden Speaks to Peter Maass
text: In the course of reporting his profile of Laura Poitras, Peter Maass conducted an encrypted question-and-answer session, for which Poitras served as intermediary, with Edward J.  Snowden. Below is a full transcript of that conversation.

headline: A Street-Level View of Kuala Lumpur
text: Che’ Ahmad Azhar sits so quietly in the corner of a room, you might not notice him. But take him to the lively streets of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, and he becomes a maestro, conducting a symphony of noise, action, light and shadow in the best tradition of street photography.

headline: A Conversation With Katrina Lantos Swett, on Religious Freedom in India
text: Few Indian politicians evoke dislike and admiration as intense as that inspired by Narendra Modi, the chief minister of the western state of Gujarat. Mr. Modi is the de facto prime ministerial candidate for India’s leading opposition party, the Bharatiya Janata Party, in the 2014 parliamentary elections. Mr. Modi has been remodeling himself as a pro-business, pro-development leader who can bring about economic growth and make difficult decisions. Yet the ghosts of the 2002 sectarian violence, in which more than  1,000 Muslims were killed and tens of thousands displaced from their homes under his watch in Gujarat, along with his continuing use of derogatory language to refer to India’s Muslims, has raised concerns about his political rise.

headline: Wheelies: The Civic Tourer Edition
text: In which we find you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: In Testing, a Principal  Leans on Her Experience
text: Since 2000, Anna Allanbrook has been the principal of Public School 146 in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn, one of the highest achieving elementary schools in the city. It is so popular that each year she holds an admissions lottery — last spring, 1,538 children applied for 175 slots.

headline: CVC Capital to Buy Extended Warranty Company for $1.2 Billion
text: LONDON – The private equity firm Advent International agreed on Tuesday to sell Domestic and General, an extended warranty company, to the private equity firm CVC Capital Partners.

headline: New York Today: Flood Watch
text: Updated 12:01 p.m. | It will rain today – possibly a whole lot.

headline: Daily Report: BlackBerry Considers Alternatives to Oblivion
text: After enduring years of dwindling sales, BlackBerry, a giant of the pre-iPhone era, said on Monday that it was exploring “strategic options” — business code for searching for a savior, Ian Austen reports.

headline: Intersection: Eclectic Style in Brighton
text: Dr. Lazar Feygin, who lives in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, says his style has changed since he moved to the United States from Russia 25 years ago. It took time to earn enough money to be stylish.

headline: On Eve of Talks, Israel Approves More Housing and Stops a Rocket
text: JERUSALEM — In a new affront to the Palestinians on the eve of resumed peace talks, the Israeli Interior Ministry’s final approval of nearly 900 new apartments in a contested part of Jerusalem has been officially published, Israeli news media reported Tuesday. It was Israel’s second move since Sunday to advance housing construction in areas sought by the Palestinians for a future state.

headline: My Search for a Smart Way to Share Profits
text: As I explained last week, I recently decided to use profit-sharing to reward my people for changing our ways on the shop floor. Once I came to that conclusion, I started looking at a variety of approaches.

headline: Rise of Inflation Eases in Britain
text: LONDON — Consumer prices in Britain increased at a slower rate in July after hitting a 14-month high in June, relieving some pressure on households but remaining well above the central bank’s inflation target.

headline: American Inmate in North Korea Seeks Help From Washington
text: SEOUL, South Korea — An American tour operator imprisoned in North Korea on charges of plotting to harm the socialist country through Christian missionary activities has appealed to Washington to send a high-ranking official to North Korea to help free him, according to a videotaped interview made public on Tuesday.

headline: Ackman Resigns From Penney’s Board
text: Updated, 7:32 a.m. | The activist investor William A. Ackman has resigned from the board of J.C. Penney, the retailer said on Tuesday, days after starting an unusually public rebellion against his fellow directors over the future of the company.

headline: The Obama Foreign Policy Show
text: The president struggles with the multiple demands of U.S. international relations.

headline: Ackman and Penney Directors Part Ways
text: The hedge fund manager William A. Ackman has stepped down from the board of J.C. Penney, after a public clash with his fellow directors, the company announced on Tuesday morning. In its statement, Penney said that it had added Ronald W. Tysoe, a former vice chairman of Federated Department Stores, to its board, and said it planned to add another director in the near future.

headline: In Performance: Zachary Levi and Krysta Rodriguez of ‘First Date’
text: In the new Broadway musical “First Date,” Zachary Levi plays Aaron, an awkward but cute finance guy who is set up on a blind date with Casey, a pretty, dark-edged art chick played by Krysta Rodriguez. In the number “First Impressions,” they size each other up right after meeting. “First Date,” written by Austin Winsberg (book) and Alan Zachary and Michael Weiner (music and lyrics), is at the Longacre Theater.

headline: What People (Don’t) Know About The Deficit
text: A little while back I expressed a desire to see a poll of voters asking whether they knew about the plunging federal budget deficit. Just as a reminder, here’s what the CBO numbers for the recent past and projections for the near future look like:

headline: Wish I’d Said That, Rand Paul Edition
text: Matt O’Brien follows up on Rand Paul and Milton Friedman, and finds the senator trying– in the face of all the facts — to claim that Friedman would have supported his monetary views. Again, Paul is a self-proclaimed Austrian, and Friedman was contemptuous of the Austrians:

headline: The Price of Settling
text: JERUSALEM — The European Union adopted guidelines in June that bar Israeli entities from grants, prizes or loans if they operate in the areas of the West Bank, East Jerusalem and the Golan Heights that Israel occupied in 1967. Naturally, the Israeli government is not pleased — so much so that on Friday it decided not to sign any new deals with the E.U. until the E.U. “clarifies” the new regulations (read: alters them). The government said it was “ready to negotiate” with the Europeans, but that “if the terms are the way they are today” then “we won’t be able to do it.”

headline: Rising Output in Factories Hints at Growth in Europe
text: PARIS — European factories ramped up their output of consumer durable goods in June, official data showed Tuesday, and economists said the news signaled an end to the recession that has made the Continent the laggard of the world economy.

headline: If You Like Bill Haley and His Comets, Try JD McPherson
text: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: The Developing World Gets Unlimited Digital Storage
text: You may have thought it was just everyone you knew. In fact, at least one company is hoping that about 200 million more people worldwide are leading digitally swamped lives, in need of organizing.

headline: A Chef in the Field | Wheat Berries
text: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

headline: Court-Appointed Police Monitor Has Fought for City and Against It
text: His name appears only a few times in more than 230 pages of judicial findings and court orders filed on Monday in the federal case over the New York Police Department’s stop-and-frisk policies.

headline: Student Crossword | Immigration
text: Learn more about immigration by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Bangladesh Descends into Chaos
text: MUMBAI—Last Saturday night, Adilur Rahman Khan arrived home  in Dhaka after visiting his family over Eid to find a group of men waiting outside his house. Mr. Khan, secretary of the prominent Bangladeshi human rights group Odhikar, had been expecting this day might come, but being confronted by members of the Detective Branch, who were there without a warrant late at night, was a surprise.

headline: Fertility Diary: I’m Old
text: “You’re old and dried up,” a troll commented on my recent article about why I wish I had frozen my eggs when I was younger. “Children are for young people, not selfish men and women who were too busy to decide until their lives are half or 2/3 over,” said another.

headline: Gilbert Is Still Teaching How to Win Ugly
text: Brad Gilbert was ranked as high as No.4, and was coach of stars like Andre Agassi, Andy Roddick and Andy Murray. But to the recreational tennis player, he is also known as the author of “Winning Ugly.”

headline: Hard Rock to Open Hotel in Ibiza
text: Hard Rock International recently announced plans to open its first hotel in Europe. The Hard Rock Hotel Ibiza, scheduled to open next May, is expected to be followed by more hotels on the Continent, a natural move, said Michael Shindler, the firm’s executive vice president of hotels and casinos. “We got our start there,” he said, noting that the first Hard Rock Cafe opened in London 42 years ago and that now there are 32 in Europe

headline: New Jersey Jitney Drivers Squeezed Between Competition and Demands for More Safety
text: WEST NEW YORK, N.J. — From behind the wheel of his 21-seat minibus, Joseph Cruz sees things with exceptional clarity. He has divided the world — at least, the helter-skelter world of commercial minibuses in which he has made his living for 11 years — into two camps: the safe drivers and everyone else.

headline: Aug. 13: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Appointment of 19 Generals as Provincial Governors Raises Fears in Egypt
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s new military-appointed government on Tuesday named a roster of generals as provincial governors, raising fears of a return to the authoritarianism of former President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Mount Fuji, So Popular It Hurts
text: The words printed on the buses that drive through Kawaguchiko, a scenic town in the foothills of Japan’s tallest and most sacred mountain, were as reassuring as they were disconcerting: “Preserve the Nature of Mt. Fuji.”

headline: U.S., Filing Suit, Moves to Block Airline Merger
text: Updated, 8:44 p.m. | After a decade of rapid consolidation in the nation’s airline industry, the Justice Department filed a lawsuit on Tuesday to block the proposed merger between American Airlines and US Airways, which would create the world’s largest airline.

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Servers Restored After They Were Hacked
text: About 10 days after a few of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s servers were hacked and taken offline, service has been restored. The servers were used to store and make available to the public documents like reports from automakers about plans for recalls, as well as communications between automakers and agency officials regarding investigations.

headline: A Rating With a High Return: NC-17
text: Updated, 10:32 p.m. | with comment from Michael Cieply.

headline: 'Believe'
text: The first television ad from the Thompson campaign focuses broadly on his platform and his background.

headline: A Tale of Two Flat Countries
text: Simon Wren-Lewis writes about the rise of extremist parties in the UK and the Netherlands. As he notes, in a way this shouldn’t be surprising. The Netherlands, in particular, has the kind of Grand Bargain the Washington Post editorial page dreams of — a government of national unity committed to fiscal austerity. It’s as if Harry Reid, John Boehner, and President Obama had all agreed to implement Simpson-Bowles, with some extra front-loaded cuts thrown into the bargain too. And here’s the thing: it’s not working. So what you have is a frustrated populace, finding no “respectable” politicians willing to challenge a failing orthodoxy:

headline: A Wall St. Brawler’s Winning Qualities Also Play Out in Defeat
text: Updated, 9:27 p.m. |  The hedge fund titan William A. Ackman is not an investor known to make small bets. Yet one of his gambles, on turning around a dowdy department store chain, has blown up, leading him to make an embarrassing retreat.

headline: The Gun Report: August 13, 2013
text: Two months after the deadly shooting at Santa Monica Community College, guns have been banned at all nine community college campuses in Los Angeles. The unanimously approved resolution passed by the Board of Trustees last week cited “repeated, serious occurrences of campus-based shootings.” It also stated “the presence of firearms, even when nonoperational and in the instructional setting, lends itself to the potential for panic and fear.”

headline: John Lewis on Race and Voting Rights
text: Ahead of the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, Congressman and civil rights leader John Lewis discusses race relations and voting rights with reporter Sheryl Gay Stolberg.

headline: Still Marching on Washington, 50 Years Later
text: WASHINGTON — John Lewis was the 23-year-old son of Alabama sharecroppers and already a veteran of the civil rights movement when he came to the capital 50 years ago this month to deliver a fiery call for justice on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial.

headline: Today in Small Business: Walmart Vs. Amazon
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: John Lewis 50 Years After the March on Washington
text: The sole surviving speaker from the 1963 march, Mr. Lewis is taking on the Supreme Court’s decision on voting rights.

headline: Into the Gyre
text: A team of artists and scientists traveled to Alaska to document water pollution. Carl Safina, an ecologist and Mark Dion, an artist, talk about their observations from the trip.

headline: 'Manny's Law'
text: A new ad from the Quinn campaign focuses on the creation and passing of Manny's Law.

headline: Herbalife Safety Issue Draws Scrutiny
text: Updated, 9:15 p.m. |  After Herbalife, the nutritional supplement company, began producing its best-selling drink mix at a plant in California, anxious executives had to scramble in early 2011 as they faced a potentially serious product safety threat.

headline: Booker Coasts in Primary; ‘Make Me Your Senator,’ He Tells New Jersey
text: Cory A. Booker, the mayor of Newark, who rose to prominence with his efforts to remake a notoriously troubled city and then used that perch to build a national reputation as a charismatic and media-savvy star in the Democratic Party, easily won the Democratic nomination for United States Senate on Tuesday night.

headline: Lady Gaga Releases a New Song After It Leaks Online
text: Lady Gaga has released the first single off her forthcoming album a week early because the song was circulating on the Internet, the BBC reports.

headline: The Civil War and Hawaii
text: Almost 5,000 miles and half an ocean away from the killing fields of Gettysburg, Chickamauga, or Spotsylvania, Hawaii and Hawaiians might be assumed to have not played a role in the Civil War. Yet regardless of proud protestations of neutrality by the Hawaiian monarchy – the islands were not American territory at the time – many of the islands’ residents participated in the conflict, on both sides. And for good reason: though they lived on one of the most geographically isolated island chains in the world, Hawaiians kept abreast of international events, knowing that the outcome of the war could greatly affect Hawaii as well.

headline: Discord in an Intergenerational Home
text: “Mother Daughter Me,” Katie Hafner’s new memoir about her attempt to form a multigenerational household, reminds me of those horror movies where the heroine (it’s always a heroine) is about to plunge heedlessly into a darkened basement/attic/forest instead of sensibly dialing 911. You want to yell, “Nooooo!”

headline: Costata
text: Inside Michael White’s steakhouse on Spring Street.

headline: Image of the Day: August 13
text: Children playing soccer on the Arabian Sea coast in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

headline: An Old Flame, Whispering ‘Steak’
text: So this is where he decides to bring us: back to the same place on Spring Street where it all started. The year was 2002, the restaurant was called Fiamma, and he was just another hungry 29-year-old chef from the Midwest. We didn’t know yet that his name was Michael White. We just knew that when he cooked Italian food, he could make us forget about all the others for a while.

headline: Wines to Accompany Grilled Flank Steak
text: A fine piece of grilled flank steak is an open invitation to a world of red wines to show their stuff. But what happens when you add chile’s heat, to say nothing of nomadic travelers in the wine world like tomatillo and pineapple? Not to worry. The char of the meat will still be the dominant flavor, though amplified and augmented by the additions. I recommend a dry Loire red, like one of the less-structured Chinons, Bourgueils or Saumur-Champignys. Unless they are too tannic, they seem to have an affinity for chiles. What’s more, their fruit, spice and acidity will take naturally to the fruitiness of the tomatillo, pineapple and, indeed, the chile. Other options: cru Beaujolais and West Coast gamays, if you can find them; lighter-bodied Ribeira Sacra and Bierzos, made from the mencía grape; and Austrian blaufränkisches and zweigelts.

headline: Avivo’s Custom Cellphone Cases, Pretty but Tricky
text: For ease of use, most cellphone cases typically have a single, integrated design. To change the look, you have to change the entire case. Avivo thinks owners should be able to swap a few parts instead.

headline: Brolly Umbrella Frees Thumbs for Texting
text: Umbrellas are decidedly low-tech devices. They really serve only to keep our gadgets, and heads, dry. Unfortunately, holding an umbrella usually precludes the use of said gadgets, but Brollytime, a company based in Chicago, has come up with an innovation to change that.

headline: Pacific Northwest Car Collectors Celebrate 60 Years of Corvette History
text: It was a no-brainer for LeMay–America’s Car Museum to open an exhibition honoring America’s sports car, the Chevrolet Corvette. As David Madeira, president and chief executive of the Tacoma, Wash., museum said at the opening of “60 Years of ‘Vette” on Friday, “Sixty years of continuous production speaks to the importance of this car in our culture.”

headline: Hillary Clinton Returns to Political Life
text: Hillary Clinton seized upon exactly the right issues in her return to political life this week, issuing a firm defense of voting rights Monday in a speech to the American Bar Association. The danger is that she will see this as a box that’s been checked, an obligation addressed, and will then move on to other subjects in a policy parade.

headline: For Sports Fans, Before the Internet, There Were the Complete Handbooks
text: Zander Hollander sat silently on his couch. Rows of books — a large portion of them ones he created, edited and nurtured — hovered above him, dominating a wall in his Manhattan apartment.

headline: Blacked Out in 3 Cities, CBS Still Wins Ratings Race
text: The 11-day old blackout of CBS on Time Warner Cable systems seems to be having a minimal effect on the network’s ratings.

headline: A Challenge to Industry in Small-Town Australia
text: A ruling in a Rio Tinto case could upend a system that favors the mining industry.

headline: Coal Mine Fight Embodies an Economic Struggle in Rural Australia
text: BULGA, Australia — Bulga, a hamlet nestled in the verdant hills of the wine country north of Sydney, is at the center of a legal dispute that could reshape the regulatory environment of a national economy heavily dependent on natural resource extraction.

headline: Conan the Barbarian Rampages Into Prestigious Archive
text: Conan the Barbarian, the pulp fiction action hero introduced in 1932 by Robert E. Howard, will soon be rubbing shoulders with the spindlier literary characters of David Foster Wallace, Don DeLillo and Norman Mailer, thanks to the recent acquisition of a large Howard collection by the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin.

headline: Great Story, Compelling and Rich: ‘Anchorman’ Ron Burgundy to Write Memoir
text: In his time as a television broadcaster Ron Burgundy has boasted that he discovered the wheel and built the Eiffel Tower out of metal and brawn. And while he may have accomplished neither of those things, he will soon be the author of a memoir.

headline: Hiring to Carry Out Tasks Vs. Hiring to Achieve Goals
text: At the most recent She Owns It business group meeting, the owners talked about hiring employees who could grow along with their companies. Susan Parker, who owns Bari Jay, said she initially doubted that her most recent customer service hire was right for the job because she seemed overqualified and interested in doing more than customer service. Still, Ms. Parker’s sister, Bari Jay’s co-owner, persuaded her to choose this candidate over another with a more typical customer service background.

headline: New Novel by Dave Eggers Due in October
text: Dave Eggers is perfecting the art of sneaking onto bookshelves. His new novel, “The Circle,” will be published in October, according to the Web site of his publisher Alfred A. Knopf. Like his last book, “A Hologram for the King,” which was published less than a month after its existence was announced, “The Circle” will appear without much lead time.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Quinn Supporter’s Testimonial of Her Effectiveness
text: First aired: August 13, 2013

headline: Toto Koopman, Model Spy
text: All but forgotten today, in her time Toto Koopman shocked the world. As the first famous biracial model (she was half-Javanese, half-Dutch), Koopman posed for Chanel in Paris and appeared on the cover of French Vogue in the 1930s. She was fluent in six languages, which served her well when she later became a spy for the Italian resistance during World War II — until she was thrown in a Nazi concentration camp. In his new biography, “The Many Lives of Miss K.,” Jean-Noël Liaut likens the secretive Koopman to “a squid hiding behind its cloud of ink.” Though she was never monogamous — she took lovers into her 70s, including the actress Tallulah Bankhead, Winston Churchill‘s son Randolph and the press baron Lord Beaverbrook — she devoted the second half of her life to Erica Brausen, the visionary art dealer, who, with Koopman’s help, launched Francis Bacon’s career from her Hanover Gallery in London. The couple never concealed their relationship, even though homosexuality was a criminal offense in Britain at the time. “Being around them,” a friend recalled, “I really came to understand the meaning of freedom.”

headline: Capture, a Camera Strap Attachment, Gets an Update
text: The Capture, a device from Peak Design that attaches a camera to any belt or strap, has become a bit smarter. A refined version, called the Capture Pro, is now being shipped to some Kickstarter investors, and will be available to the public in September.

headline: Pain and Gain:  ’50 Shades’ Author Tops Earnings List
text: The publishing phenomenon “Fifty Shades of Grey” has made its author, E. L. James the No. 1 writer in the world in terms of earnings over the last year with an estimated $95 million, according to an annual list released by Forbes of the top-earning book writers.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘Perceval’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 25. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.Poor Perceval apparently didn’t have as good a publicist as some other Knights of the Round Table did, but he gets title-character treatment from a troupe called the Immediate Family in this spunky, stripped-down show.

headline: The Future of American Airlines
text: And just like that, American Airlines’ easy path out of Chapter 11 has hit a dead end.
