text: First aired: August 13, 2013

headline: Delta to Offer Shuttle Between Los Angeles and San Francisco
text: Delta Air Lines will begin hourly nonstop shuttle service between Los Angeles International and San Francisco International airports on Sept. 3, “tailored to business travelers while adding a California perspective,” the carrier said earlier this month.

headline: Sudsing Up, Memorably
text: Instead of treating showers as utilitarian afterthoughts or relying on the old trend of rain-forest showerheads, some hotels are getting creative when it comes to getting wet.

headline: Lewis Says He Will Back Hillary Clinton for President if She Runs
text: Representative John Lewis, the Georgia Democrat and elder statesman of the civil rights movement, said in an interview that he would support Hillary Rodham Clinton if she sought the White House in 2016, and called her “the most qualified person in America to be president.”

headline: Recipe Lab: Blueberry Jam
text: Julia Moskin makes blueberry jam with lime from Kevin West’s canning cookbook “Saving the Season.”

text: The activist hedge fund boss William A. Ackman is always ready for a fight – just maybe not so many at once.

headline: Art Dealer Suspected of Selling Fake Paintings Is Released on Bail
text: Glafira Rosales, the Long Island art dealer who was arrested this past spring on charges that she laundered money and evaded taxes as part of a scheme to sell multimillion-dollar forgeries, was released on bail Monday.

headline: Jackery Air Auxiliary Battery Has Power to Spare
text: Batteries may sometimes pose vexing problems for the automotive and aircraft industries, but for mobile devices they seem to be improving.

headline: Getting Started With Blueberry Jam
text: Recipe Lab, a monthly feature, invites you to cook with the Dining section. We’ll publish a standout recipe from a cookbook for you to try; the next week, the book’s author will join Julia Moskin and readers in a live video chat.  If you’re interested in participating in the chat, please fill out this form. You can watch this month’s chat on Wednesday, Aug. 21, at 2 p.m. Eastern time, at nytimes.com/dining.

headline: Subsidized Child Care: For the Poor, By the Poor
text: For a parent with a minimum-wage job in retail or fast food, finding a really good in-home child-care provider is like choosing the Auntie or Gramma of your dreams: loving, secure and available for emergencies. Find the right woman (and it is almost invariably a woman) and she’s got your back. If Dunkin’ Donuts calls with a shift change, or the painful tooth you couldn’t afford to have the dentist treat turns into a trip to the E.R., you have one less thing to worry about.

headline: U.S. Accounting Regulator Proposes More In-Depth Reports From Auditors
text: The federal regulator that polices accounting firms is proposing a major overhaul of how company audits are reported to the public, a move that could provide investors with deeper insight into the health of corporations.

headline: Afraid to Get Tested? Slow Down and Think About It
text: Many patients are eager to search bottomless troves of health information on the Internet. But when it comes to learning whether they are at risk for certain diseases by getting a medical test, millions would rather just not know.

headline: In Bangkok, Chefs Look Beyond Thailand
text: Bangkok’s renowned local food scene established the city long ago as one of the most exciting, well-priced and diverse culinary capitals in Southeast Asia. These days some heavyweight chefs, both foreign and homegrown, have gone from showcasing a more highbrow take on Thai classics to looking at other, more far-flung menus for inspiration.

headline: Restaurant Report: &Samhoud Places in Amsterdam
text: It’s been a busy last 12 months or so for Amsterdam: a royal coronation, the reopening of the Van Gogh Museum and the Rijksmuseum, the 400th anniversary of the city’s emblematic canals. So it’s not surprising that a delicious development has gotten a bit lost in the shuffle: the opening of a serious and strikingly original restaurant. The curiously named &Samhoud Places made its debut last August in the modern and redeveloping Oosterdokseiland district, and was awarded two Michelin stars in November.

headline: Veterans Bare Their Souls in Literary Events
text: Veterans live in the world in between. Never fully civilians culturally, no longer service members by profession, we do our best to find a balance, to create comfortable zones.

headline: From Outsiders to Innkeepers in China’s Sleepy Countryside
text: XIZHOU, China — Brian Linden welcomed the guests to his boutique hotel in one of its courtyards at the end of a cobblestone alley here, surrounded by old stone walls and polished wood balconies.

headline: Track’s New Power Couple Prove It With Medals
text: MOSCOW — One month after their marriage, Ashton Eaton and Brianne Theisen-Eaton have two shiny new wedding presents.

headline: Scene City: New Faces for Hamptons Art Gala
text: Chuck Close is honored by Guild Hall in East Hampton.

headline: Icahn Says He Has Large Stake in Apple
text: For an old-school investor, Carl C. Icahn has quickly become a force in technology stocks.

headline: How to Charm: Remember Their Names
text: Along with Oliver Sacks, Jane Goodall and Brad Pitt, Chuck Close has prosopagnosia, which is commonly known as face blindness.

headline: New Poll Suggests That de Blasio Is Now First Among Voters
text: In a jolt to the Democratic campaign for mayor, a new poll suggests that Bill de Blasio, the most liberal of the leading candidates, has vaulted into first place among likely voters.

headline: U.S. Faces Obstacles in Bid to Arrest 2 in Big Trading Loss at JPMorgan
text: Federal investigators, seeking to bring criminal charges against two former JPMorgan Chase employees at the center of the bank’s multibillion-dollar trading loss in London last year, are facing logistical hurdles in planning arrests.

headline: Family Transcends a Wall Between East and West
text: Suffused with the odors of coal fire and hot bockwurst; resonant with the clanks of Lada and Trabant automobiles; replete with references to Trotsky, Gorbachev, Erich Honecker, Sputnik and the gulag, Eugen Ruge’s “In Times of Fading Light” might sound like an edifying but ultimately dour Eastern Bloc affair. Yet one of the most remarkable things about this multigenerational saga of an East German family before and after the demise of Communism is how contemporary and, well, Western it seems.

headline: Officers Are Wistful as Crown Vic, Long a Fleet Staple, Nears Retirement
text: SPOKANE, Wash. — The greatest muscle car that ever wore a uniform is now racing toward retirement. After more than a decade as the most widely used law enforcement vehicle in the nation, the Ford Crown Victoria Police Interceptor — the Crown Vic, as it has become known — went out of production in 2011.

headline: Lawyers Hint at Possible Recovery of Stolen Art
text: BRUSSELS — Paintings worth tens of millions of dollars that were stolen last October from an art museum in the Netherlands have not been burned, and a Romanian gang behind the theft wants to cut an unspecified deal with the authorities so the artwork can be returned, lawyers for the defendants said on Tuesday as they went on trial in Romania.

headline: Farmer Chic in Farm Country
text: New restaurants are bringing urban chefs’ ideas of farm-to-table back to the land.

headline: An Upriver Current
text: HUDSON, N.Y. — In 2011, the New York City restaurateurs Zak Pelaccio and Mark Firth bumped into each other at a friend’s house near here, two hours north and a world away from the city.

headline: One-Upmanship Continues After Publicis-Omnicom Deal
text: TOKYO — For years, the two highest-profile chief executives in the advertising business — Sir Martin Sorrell of WPP in London and Maurice Lévy of Publicis Groupe in Paris — had engaged in one-upmanship across the English Channel as they jousted for industry dominance.

headline: Beijing Orders Demolition of Rooftop Art
text: BEIJING — In a city brimming with look-at-me architecture, the sprawling addition that Zhang Biqing, a health care magnate, built atop his 26th-floor apartment is a showstopper.

headline: Order That Police Wear Cameras Stirs Unexpected Reactions
text: In more than a decade in office, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has often championed the use of cutting-edge technology to help solve age-old problems in New York.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bahrain and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Bahrain, Egypt, Afghanistan and South Korea.

headline: Living South of West Fourth Street
text: By turns raffish and intimate, boisterous and quaint.

headline: South of West Fourth Street: Tracking the ‘Ghosts of Bohemia’
text: By turns raffish and intimate, boisterous and quaint, Greenwich Village below Washington Square Park and West Fourth Street has such a distinct local feel that it might best be described with one self-referential word: “Villagey.”

headline: A Thriving Financial Product, Despite a Record of Failure
text: On Wall Street, strange financial products sometimes exist not because they are good for investors or companies, but because they offer their promoters a way to profit.

headline: Stringer and Spitzer Slug it Out
text: Eliot Spitzer and Scott Stringer battled through their second New York City comptroller debate on Monday evening. It was an ugly, uninspiring event.

headline: An Irish Pub’s Toast to Women
text: Danny McDonald, an owner of several New York bars, including Swift Hibernian Lounge and Ulysses, had been nursing the idea of opening a place that honored “the more feminine side of the Irish pub” for years. But when he thought of his partners (Peter Poulakakos, Paul Lamas and Michael Jewell), he realized something was missing: women.

headline: As March’s 50th Anniversary Nears, King Memorial Repairs May Be Delayed
text: WASHINGTON — A contractor repairing the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial was not insured to use the sculptor’s preferred method for part of the work, putting in doubt whether the repairs will be finished before the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom.

headline: Counselor and Ex-Con, Adjusting to New Worlds
text: In Chad Hartigan’s resolutely low-key film, the Martin of the title, a fresh transplant from the East, is starting over as an outreach counselor at a Reno, Nev., penitentiary after a crisis of belief. He meets Travis, who is newly sprung after years in prison, and takes him under his wing. The slightly bewildered new ex-con sees freedom stretched out before him and immediately worries that he’ll blow his chances.

headline: Gift Bolsters Denver Museum’s Collection of Western American Art
text: The Denver Art Museum, which has been steadily establishing itself as a center for Western American art for more than a decade, announced that it would receive the bulk of one of the most important private collections of 19th- and 20th-century Western art in private hands.

headline: New York and U.S. Open Investigations Into Bitcoins
text: Updated, 8:55 p.m. | State and federal officials are starting broad investigations into shortcomings in the oversight of upstart virtual currencies like bitcoin.

headline: Hospital Reverses Decision and Adds Teenager to Heart Transplant List
text: Last Updated | 9:21 p.m. An Atlanta children’s hospital reversed course on Tuesday and decided to list a 15-year-old boy for a heart transplant, only days after refusing to do so because of concerns that he would not follow medical advice, including taking medication, after surgery.

headline: AOL Chief Apologizes Over Firing of Worker
text: Tim Armstrong, the chief executive of AOL, issued an unusual apology on Tuesday to his entire staff for the public manner in which he fired an employee during an internal conference call last Friday.

headline: Mapping the Brain Circuitry That Spots Movement, in Flies
text: Building on decades of prior research, scientists have mapped the precise circuit in the fruit fly brain that enables the tiny gnat to detect movement in its visual field — an impulse essential to its skill at avoiding swatting hands and other existential threats.

headline: As She Tends, a Wife Starts to Find Herself
text: Life and death circle each other restlessly and then furiously in the Afghan-set movie “The Patience Stone.” Life takes the form of an unnamed beautiful young woman (the fine Iranian actress Golshifteh Farahani) who, when the story opens, is caring for her wounded, much older husband, also unnamed (Hamidrez Javdan), an immobilized Mujahedeen fighter with a bullet in his neck and the slender tube of a medical drip bag snaked into his mouth. They’re simply two people inside an austere room. Yet, as bombs shake the walls and she places a bloodied compress on his head, they are quickly transformed into a time-tested, outwardly reassuring vision of a woman heroically ministering to a wounded, possibly dying man.

headline: Front Burner: Nourish in Greenwich Village, Tomato Soup, Potato Chips and More
text: To Shop: Wholesome, Yes, but Tasty, Too

headline: Autism's Unexpected Link to Cancer Genes
text: As surprised researchers have discovered, some people with autism have mutated cancer or tumor genes that apparently caused their brain disorder.

text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Here’s what we noticed today:

headline: Sony Wants Pizzeria Out of Building in Midtown
text: Something as basic as a New York slice has provided the recipe for a fierce fight over a lease in the Sony Building in Midtown, pitting a restaurateur against giant landlords.

headline: Juni Opens in the Hotel Chandler in Midtown
text: Headliner

headline: Tasting Triumph in Serving of a Heart
text: LENOX, Mass. — Within minutes of the premiere of George Benjamin’s “Written on Skin,” at the Aix-en-Provence Festival last summer, opera houses around the world jostled for production rights to this darkly erotic opera about a love triangle in medieval Provence, set to a searing text by Martin Crimp. In the past year, it has been staged in London, Amsterdam, Toulouse, Munich and Vienna, each time bringing audiences to their feet and leaving critics to pull out superlatives they hadn’t thought they’d ever use in the context of new opera.

headline: Stories Told With a Twirl Here and a Leap There
text: Battery Park, with its views across the harbor and the Hudson River, should be one of New York’s glories. Currently, however, it’s a mess and a maze, and, with its palings and barriers, it looks like a no man’s land. Trying to find the opening performance of the Downtown Dance Festival on Sunday proved so circuitous that I missed the opening troupe, Chapter Two. Once there, however, I sat contented for the remaining two and a half hours.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘Slaughterhouse-Five’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 25. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: A White House Warrior on Poverty, Vietnam and Race
text: Lyndon Baines Johnson has long been recognized as a figure of Shakespearean dimensions, perhaps first in Barbara Garson’s 1967 blistering satire, “MacBird!” — in which Johnson was Macbeth and behind the murder of his leader, John Ken O’Dunc.

headline: Food Matters | Bodega Coffee Flavor, Brewed Right in Your Kitchen
text: “I’ve been a salesman all my life,” said John Vassilaros, a third-generation coffee maker whose family company, Vassilaros and Sons, has been peddling its home-roasted, hand-blended beans around New York, New Jersey and Connecticut for nearly a century. “The trick to selling is don’t talk too much,” he added. “Just let them taste it.” He wouldn’t dream of leaving a pound of coffee behind for prospective clients to try later. Instead, he gets behind the counter to brew up Vassilaros and Sons’ trademark brew for side-by-side taste tests. He claims he usually wins. The proof is in the ubiquity of his familiar-tasting medium roast, a complex blend of South American beans prepared every Tuesday in Queens, which can be found in hundreds of New York City delis, bodegas and coffee shops, not to mention restaurants like the Boathouse Restaurant in Central Park.

headline: Another Banksy Mural to Go From Wall to Auction
text: Under cover of night, in 2008, Banksy, the pseudonymous British artist, stenciled a mural on a wall of a gas station in Los Angeles: the silhouette of a girl holding a basket of flowers and peering up at a security camera. About nine months ago, that 5,000-pound, 9-by-8-foot chunk of brick wall was removed, and, in the latest of a string of controversial sales of Banksy street work, will soon be on the block. In December, Julien’s Auctions in Beverly Hills, Calif., will offer “Flower Girl,” the first Banksy street art to be sold in the United States, the auctioneers said.

headline: What Analysts Expect From the Next iPhones
text: No one outside Apple really knows what products the company will introduce next, but that hasn’t stopped Wall Street analysts from prognosticating about potential new iPhones.

headline: Art’s Future Meets Its Past
text: VENICE — What’s new in contemporary art? Old. We’re in an age of remake culture, an epidemic of re-enactment fever. Young painters are working in styles that were hot half a century ago. Yesteryear’s performance art is being re-performed. Exhibitions that have been done and done — on Matisse, Picasso, European abstraction — are being done again.

headline: Is Athletic Prowess Genetic?
text: David Epstein, who has written a new book called “The Sports Gene,” searches for answers about athletic ability and our genes.

headline: Potent Memories From a Divided India
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — Growing up, Guneeta Singh Bhalla heard a terrifying story from her grandmother. In August 1947, as British India was being partitioned into independent India and Pakistan, her grandmother fled Lahore, in what was soon to become Pakistan, for Amritsar, in what was soon to become India. All around her was carnage. Clutching her three young children, she looked out the train window to see bodies strewed along the tracks. The memory haunted her until she died.

headline: Discussing ‘Native Speaker’
text: Updated, 9:30 p.m. | Our live conversation about Chang-rae Lee’s 1995 novel of immigration and New York City politics, “Native Speaker,” has finished. But you can still post your thoughts and questions in the comments section below.

headline: Scent Adds Sophistication to Hair Products
text: Remember the shampoo Gee, Your Hair Smells Terrific?

headline: Norwegian Leader’s Not-So-Candid Camera
text: What at first appeared to be a daring political stunt — having the prime minister of Norway pose as a cab driver, ferrying unsuspecting passengers around Oslo to eavesdrop on the national conversation — turns out to have been at least partly staged, as five of the citizens whose shocked reactions were caught on hidden cameras had been cast in the roles, the Norwegian tabloid VG revealed on Monday.

headline: Feeling For | When It Comes to Furniture, Brown is the New Black
text: “Brown furniture” as decorators derisively refer to it, is ripe for reconsideration: the best of the old stuff is beautifully made and shockingly well priced. While working with Ilse Crawford on our new Madison Avenue store, we came up with the concept of a “mash up” of Georgian furniture to display our bespoke lines. Handmade and old-school like my made-to-order leather goods, it made me wonder if “proper” antique furniture could once again become fashionable?

headline: Kohlberg Declines to Raise Bid for Steinway
text: A contest to buy the maker of Steinway & Sons pianos is ending in a diminuendo.

headline: Man Granted New Trial in Child Sexual Abuse Case
text: A federal judge this week threw out the conviction of a 66-year-old Long Island man found guilty in 2008 of molesting his granddaughter and two of her friends after defense lawyers investigated a serial number on the back of a photograph that refuted a key portion of the prosecution’s case.

headline: Joseph A. Tahl
text: Mr. Tahl, 51, is a founder and the president of Tahl Propp Equities, a privately held real estate investment, development and management company based in Manhattan. Tahl Propp specializes in affordable housing and retail space in Harlem.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: The Booksellers’ Tale
Running, Away From the Circus
text: New York election candidates can struggle to be heard over the Weiner-Spitzer cacophony. Sal Albanese walks a Brooklyn district that has seen much demographic change in 30 years, like the city itself.

headline: Custody Battle Continues Despite Ruling by Justices
text: DENVER — It has been nearly two months since the Supreme Court ruled that an American Indian child should not have been taken from her white adoptive parents in 2011 to live with her biological father, a member of the Cherokee tribe. But the decision has done little to bring a swift resolution to this bitter custody battle, which has become a crucible for debate over how adoptions involving Indian children should be handled.

headline: Safety Concerns Delay U.N. Chemical Arms Inquiry in Syria
text: Nearly two weeks after Syria said it would allow United Nations experts to investigate three sites where chemical weapons may have been used in that country’s civil war, their visit has been further delayed because an agreement has yet to be reached with Syria on measures to ensure their safety, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon’s office reported on Tuesday.

headline: Clashes in Egypt Persist
text: Supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, confronted security forces as they marched through the streets of Cairo.

headline: A Second-Year Jet Strives to Play Beyond What He Knows
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. — Dennis Thurman, the Jets’ defensive coordinator, has been impressed with the way inside linebacker Demario Davis has performed during training camp. Yet Thurman is trying to persuade Davis to keep his own expectations at a reasonable level.

headline: Divining the Regulatory Goals of Fed Rivals
text: WASHINGTON — Lawrence H. Summers, as Treasury secretary, presided over the group of senior Clinton administration officials who reached the fateful decision in the late 1990s that there was no need to regulate a new family of financial transactions known as over-the-counter derivatives. Janet Yellen attended some of those meetings, too, as chairwoman of President Clinton’s Council of Economic Advisers. But she did not speak.

headline: Government Must Continue Review of Nevada Nuclear Waste Site, Court Says
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission was “flouting the law” when it stopped work on a review of the proposed nuclear waste dump at Yucca Mountain, despite the Obama administration’s insistence that the site be shut down.

headline: The Overlapping Clinton World
text: The addition of Hillary Rodham Clinton to the Clinton foundation further intertwines the political, philanthropic and business ventures of the family.

headline: Music Stars Join First Lady to Get Youths Off the Couch
text: Hip-hop artists have been name-dropping the Obamas in song since they moved into the White House, and now some of them are volunteering for Michelle Obama’s “Let’s Move!” campaign with an album inspired by her work fighting childhood obesity.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: Recent Sale

headline: Preserving Partition
text: The 1947 Partition Archive is gathering oral histories of those who lived through the violent split of India and Pakistan.

headline: In Brazil, Kerry Is Told Spying Sows ‘Distrust’
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s foreign minister on Tuesday excoriated the surveillance practices of the United States, dismissing as unsatisfactory Secretary of State John Kerry’s explanation of the wide-ranging collection of data on telephone and electronic communications and describing the spying as “a new type of challenge” in Brazil’s relationship with the United States.

headline: Back Where Golf Found a U.S. Foothold
text: BROOKLINE, Mass. — There had been so many chances before, including a near miss at his home course outside Philadelphia five years earlier. So by the time 38-year-old Jay Sigel pummeled David Tolley, 8 and 7, in the final round of the 1982 United States Amateur, his relief was palpable.

headline: Pepsi Wins Battle in Cola Wars: $21 Million CUNY Deal
text: The City University of New York, no stranger to campus skirmishes, has now taken a stance in the cola wars: “no Coke, Pepsi.”

headline: Clearing the Air on Diesel’s Dismal Reputation
text: BMW of North America is revving up its diesel engines again, starting an ambitious effort to encourage car buyers to consider six new diesel-power models for 2014.

headline: Our Daily Cup of Facebook
text: Checking Facebook has become almost as embedded in the lives of Americans as getting a cup of coffee.

headline: Competition, Not Mergers, May Bolster the Airlines
text: Can the American airline industry turn a profit in a competitive market?

headline: Rehabilitation Trip for Jeter Is Set, but His Return to Lineup Isn’t
text: Derek Jeter on Tuesday took batting practice on the field with the Yankees for the first time since being placed on the disabled list on Aug. 6 with a strained calf, raising the possibility that he could be activated from the disabled list as early as next week.

headline: Manning Played Vital Role in Iraq Despite Erratic Behavior, Supervisor Says
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — A former leader of Pfc. Bradley Manning’s Army intelligence unit in Iraq allowed him to keep working with classified information despite recurring concerns about his mental health because the unit was understaffed and Private Manning was playing an irreplaceable role in analyzing insurgent threats, according to testimony at his court-martial trial on Tuesday.

headline: Oil Reforms by Mexico May Upend Markets
text: HOUSTON — A sweeping reform suggested for Mexico’s energy laws has the potential not only to return the country to its early-1980s heyday of energetic oil drilling, when it was one of the world’s most promising producers, but also to reduce further the United States’ dependence on OPEC producers, according to oil experts.

headline: Questions Follow Acid Attack on British Women in Zanzibar
text: LONDON — The two young volunteers from London had been briefed on how to dress respectfully. They had been warned not to wear anything provocative while teaching on the island of Zanzibar during the month of Ramadan.

headline: For Women, a Second Sentence
text: NINE years ago, I served 11 months at the Federal Correctional Institution in Danbury, Conn., for a decade-old nonviolent drug crime. Danbury is the sole women-only federal prison in the Northeast and is part of a complex that typically incarcerates low-security female offenders from Maine to Pennsylvania. The aging hulk of the facility dates from 1940 and has housed women for nearly 20 years.

headline: The Real Price of Congress’s Gridlock
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — CONGRESS began its summer recess last week and won’t reconvene until after Labor Day. You’d be forgiven for not noticing a difference. With just 15 bills signed into law so far this year, the 113th Congress is on pace to be the most unproductive since at least the 1940s.

headline: Smarter Sentencing
text: You know a transformational moment has arrived when the attorney general of the United States makes a highly anticipated speech on a politically combustible topic and there is virtually no opposition to be heard.

headline: Keeping Air Travel Competitive
text: In a federal lawsuit filed on Tuesday, the Justice Department makes a strong and convincing case for why the proposed merger of American Airlines and US Airways should be blocked under antitrust laws.

headline: Subpoenas for Albany
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York warned legislators earlier this year that if they failed to pass crucial reforms, including public financing of political campaigns, then he would establish a commission to investigate and subpoena public officials suspected of misconduct.

headline: Obama, Snowden and Putin
text: You only get one chance to make a second impression. It seems to me that Edward Snowden should use his and that Russian President Vladimir Putin has blown his.

headline: As Critics United, Stalled Battle Against Frisking Tactic Took Off
text: As the Police Department performed a mounting number of stops on New York streets, voices of opposition, slow and scattershot, struggled to be heard.

headline: Giants’ Rolle Could Miss Preseason
text: Giants safety Antrel Rolle said he was unsure about his status for the rest of the preseason after spraining his right ankle during practice this week.

headline: Germany Fights Population Drop
text: SONNEBERG, Germany — At first glance, this town in central Germany, with rows of large houses built when it was a thriving center of toy manufacturing, looks tidy and prosperous. But Heiko Voigt, the deputy mayor here, can point out dozens of vacant homes that he doubts will ever be sold.

headline: Vaccination Appears to Have Halted a Meningitis Outbreak
text: A bacterial meningitis outbreak among gay and bisexual men in New York City that had raised fears of a new AIDS-type epidemic has subsided after an aggressive vaccination campaign, leaving city health officials cautiously optimistic that it has been contained.

headline: To Judge Sleep Aids, U.S. Looks at Drowsy Driving in the Morning
text: The first test for a new sleep drug is — unsurprisingly — how safely it puts people to sleep. Now comes a second test: how safely it lets people wake up.

headline: Simeon Golar, Who Fought for Public Housing, Dies at 84
text: Simeon Golar, the first New York City Housing Authority chairman to have grown up in public housing, which he championed in the face of fierce neighborhood opposition in the early 1970s, died on Sunday in the Bronx. He was 84.

headline: A Helping Hand Into the Saddle
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — You have to say it right, or Harry Rice III is not going to give you his attention. He has a lot going on.

headline: Germany Tackles Shrinking Fertility Rates
text: In its most recent census, the country discovered it had lost 1.5 million inhabitants. By 2060, experts say, the nation could shrink by an additional 19 percent.

headline: Summers of Our Discontent
text: WASHINGTON — I have no doubt that Larry Summers can speak truth to power. Indeed, I’ve seen him yawn at power.

headline: Lottery Numbers
North Carolinians Fear the End of a Middle Way
text: EDEN, N.C. — When Pat McCrory, a Republican former mayor of Charlotte, was elected governor last year, he pledged to “bring this state together,” and to focus on bread-and-butter issues amid an ailing economy.

Israel Releases 26 Palestinian Prisoners, to Cheers and Anguish
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Israel released 26 long-serving Palestinian prisoners late Tuesday as part of an American-brokered deal allowing the resumption of Israeli-Palestinian peace talks on Wednesday.

headline: You Can Hardly Believe It
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — I must say, I really liked this one by Sarah Keller. Not only were all the theme entries fun and fresh (see FLIMSY ALIBI) but they all hang together under a hilarious premise: they all are THINGS WITH HOLES.

headline: In Mexico, a Healer Who Asks for Nothing in Return
text: SAN CRISTÓBAL DE LAS CASAS, Mexico — Every morning, Sergio Castro crisscrosses this city to treat the intimate struggles behind its closed doors.

headline: The Cure for the $1,000 Toothbrush
text: Here is a basic fact of health care in the United States: Doctors and hospitals know what they charge, but patients don’t know what they pay. As in any market, when one side has no information, that side loses: price secrecy is a major reason medical bills are so high. In my previous column, I wrote about the effect of this lack of transparency on the bills patients pay out of pocket.

headline: A Rural Lifeline in Mexico
text: Sergio Castro, who arrived almost half a century ago to work as an agronomist and veterinarian, fills a hole in Mexico´s ragged safety net for the sick in Chiapas State.

headline: Unease at Clinton Foundation Over Finances and Ambitions
text: Soon after the 10th anniversary of the foundation bearing his name, Bill Clinton met with a small group of aides and two lawyers from Simpson Thacher & Bartlett. Two weeks of interviews with Clinton Foundation executives and former employees had led the lawyers to some unsettling conclusions.

headline: Clinton Calls to Protect Voting Rights
text: Speaking at an American Bar Association conference, Hillary Rodham Clinton criticized a Supreme Court ruling that allows states to change election laws without advance federal approval.

headline: Sharp Debate by Rivals for Brooklyn Prosecutor
text: In the first head-to-head debate in the race for the Brooklyn district attorney’s office, Kenneth P. Thompson sought to portray his opponent, the 23-year incumbent Charles J. Hynes, as the out-of-touch chief of an office run amok. Mr. Hynes countered by dismissing Mr. Thompson’s record, which he said contained little significant management experience, and accusing him of mishandling his cases.

headline: Merkel Enters Last Leg of Re-election Bid With a Push to Draw In Youths
text: BERLIN — After a summer dominated by questioning of her policy toward Europe and tangles over Germany’s role in large-scale intelligence gathering by the United States, Chancellor Angela Merkel kicked off the final phase of her campaign for re-election on Tuesday with an unusual visit to a high school in the former East Berlin.

headline: Seeking a Mayor Friendly to Films
text: The end of the era of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been greeted with consternation in any number of New York’s professional subcultures, including the real estate and banking industries and the rarefied sphere of art museums and cultural groups.

headline: Massachusetts: Two Plead Not Guilty to Aiding Marathon Bomb Defendant
text: Two college friends of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the 20-year-old accused of working with his brother to place two bombs at the Boston Marathon, pleaded not guilty in federal court Tuesday to charges that they hindered the investigation into the bombings. The two men, Dias Kadyrbayev and Azamat Tazhayakov, both 19, each face a count of obstructing justice and conspiracy to obstruct justice, which carry maximum penalties of 20 years and 5 years in prison, respectively. Prosecutors say the two removed items including a laptop and a backpack containing fireworks from Mr. Tsarnaev’s dormitory and that Mr. Kadyrbayev later put the backpack in trash outside the New Bedford, Mass., apartment the two shared.

headline: Quinn Is Chided for Missing Forum
text: On stage at a mayoral forum in Harlem on Tuesday, the moderator strode along a line of cushy Ultrasuede chairs, stopping at each with a pointed question: What percentage of government contracts should be reserved for businesses owned by members of minority groups and women?

headline: Limits on Young Pitchers Tick Away
text: LOS ANGELES — The Mets went back to a five-man rotation this week, a move that will revive some familiar issues as the club tries to groom its young, promising pitching staff.

headline: Debating Live on TV, Mayoral Rivals Take Aim at Quinn
text: With the Democratic mayoral primary less than a month away, Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, came under repeated attack from her rivals on Tuesday night over her role in helping Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg win a third term four years ago.

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Barbara Mertz, Egyptologist and Mystery Writer, Dies at 85
text: Barbara Mertz, an Egyptologist who wrote best-selling mysteries and supernatural thrillers, many of them set in the Middle East, under the pen names Elizabeth Peters and Barbara Michaels, died on Aug. 8 at her home in Frederick, Md. She was 85.

headline: Pauline Maier, Historian Who Described Jefferson as ‘Overrated,’ Dies at 75
text: Pauline Maier, a distinguished historian of the United States’ formative years whose challenges to conventional thinking included the assertion that Thomas Jefferson was “overrated,” died on Monday in Cambridge, Mass. She was 75.

headline: A Chiapas Medicine Man
text: Crowded hospitals and clinics in the Chiapas region of Mexico cannot absorb many poor patients. Sergio Castro taught himself how to treat those in need.

headline: A Simple Device to Detect Concussions
text: The start this month of high school and college football seasons across the country renews concerns about the issue of repeated head impacts and how to manage or, preferably, avoid concussions. Unfortunately, the resources to deal with the problem remain limited. Newly released, state-of-the-art football helmets, for instance, may measure how much force each player’s head is absorbing and relay that data via telemetry to trainers on the sidelines, but at $1,500 or so per helmet, they are unattainable for most teams.

headline: Baby-Sitter Robots and Population Growth
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Democrats Clash in Mayoral Debate
text: Five Democratic mayoral candidates, Christine C. Quinn, Anthony D. Weiner, William C. Thompson Jr., John C. Liu and Bill de Blasio, met in a television debate Tuesday night.

headline: Word of the Day | synthesis
text: synthesis •\ˈsin(t)-thə-səs\• noun

headline: The Yankees’ Offense, Led by Soriano, Bails Out a Wild Sabathia
text: Manager Joe Girardi realizes that time is running out on his team’s chances to make a playoff push. With the offense mostly dormant this season, Girardi knows it will take an almost perfect pitching performance each night to send the Yankees on a long winning streak.

headline: Motion Picture Chief Says China Will Pay Studios for Film Distribution
text: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood studios will soon begin receiving overdue payments for the distribution of their films in China, the Motion Picture Association of America chief executive Christopher Dodd said in a statement on Tuesday. About $200 million in payments had been withheld by the China Film Group, which oversees the importation of foreign films into China, while the group disputed its responsibility for the payment of a new value-added tax on theater tickets.

headline: Study Offers a Picture of Young Immigrants Seeking a Reprieve From Deportation
text: A new study by the Brookings Institution presents what the group calls “an emerging portrait” of young immigrants who have sought a temporary reprieve from deportation under a year-old program that is one of President Obama’s signature immigration initiatives.

headline: Explosion Partly Sinks Indian Naval Submarine
text: NEW DELHI — A huge explosion ripped through an Indian naval submarine docked in Mumbai early Wednesday, sending part of the vessel sinking to the bottom of the port.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
text: 9 P.M. (BBC America) LAW & ORDER: UK As the investigation into the death of a suicidal man who caused a fatal train crash continues, Detective Sergeant Sam Casey (Paul Nicholls, center right, with Paterson Joseph, far right) is suspended, sending him on a path of self-destruction, while Detective Sergeant Ronnie Brooks (Bradley Walsh, near right) reaches out to his estranged daughter. Senior Crown Prosecutor Jake Thorne (Dominic Rowan), meanwhile, gets to know his new sidekick, Kate Barker (Georgia Taylor), a defense barrister turned crown prosecutor used to getting her way. In “Broadchurch,” at 10, the mystery surrounding Danny Latimer’s death deepens, forcing Detective Inspector Alec Hardy (David Tennant) and Detective Sergeant Ellie Miller (Olivia Colman) to identify the key suspects quickly. But where, exactly, is the murder scene?

headline: Booker Wins New Jersey Nomination
text: Cory A. Booker, the mayor of Newark and a charismatic star in the Democratic Party, swept the Democratic nomination for United States Senate in New Jersey Tuesday night.

headline: Joseph M. McLaughlin, Judge and Fordham Law Dean, Dies at 80
text: Joseph M. McLaughlin, a former federal judge in New York and dean of the Fordham University Law School, died on Thursday in a Queens nursing home. He was 80.

headline: Sex Ed, 1964
text: Every once in a while I read about sex ed in middle school and kids putting condoms on bananas and I feel kind of sad I missed out on this. This is not just because of the comic possibilities of condoms on bananas, actually anything having to do with bananas, but because kids today have so much accurate information.

headline: Streaking Dodgers Win One Against Harvey
text: LOS ANGELES — Matt Harvey, the Mets’ ultracompetitive ace, brooded at his locker here Tuesday night after falling to his fourth defeat this season. But maybe, this one time, he should not have been so hard on himself.

headline: Seeking Better Teachers, City Evaluates Local Colleges That Train Them
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has used data to rate restaurants, track the repair of potholes and close lackluster schools in New York City. Now he is bringing his results-oriented approach to an area far outside his usual purview: teacher colleges.

headline: Hundreds Die as Egyptian Forces Attack Islamist Protesters
text: CAIRO — Egyptian security officers stormed two encampments packed with supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, on Wednesday in a scorched-earth assault that killed hundreds, set off a violent backlash across Egypt and underscored the new government’s determination to crush the Islamists who dominated two years of free elections.

headline: Mercedes-Benz Introduces GLA-Class Crossover
text: Mercedes-Benz released details on Wednesday of the production version of the GLA-Class Mercedes-Benz, which is, predictably, a toned-down version of the Concept GLA the automaker displayed at the Shanghai auto show last April. The basic, relatively sporty shape and tasteful interior remain, but gone are the recessed door handles, huge 20-inch rims and futuristic movie projector headlamps.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,245 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Grim Hunt for 18 Indian Sailors Trapped on Navy Submarine After Explosion
text: NEW DELHI — Indian naval divers on Wednesday afternoon opened the main hatchway of a stricken, Russian-made Indian submarine that caught fire, blew up and sank at dock earlier in the day in one of the worst naval accidents in Indian history.

headline: Barclays C.F.O. Moves Up Departure, Citing Ill Health
text: LONDON – Christopher G. Lucas, the chief financial officer of Barclays, announced on Wednesday that he was leaving the bank earlier than expected for health reasons.

headline: Israel Strikes 2 Gaza Sites Hours Before Start of Talks
text: JERUSALEM — In the hours before Israeli-Palestinian peace talks were to start here on Wednesday, Israeli warplanes struck two sites in Gaza in response to rocket fire from the Palestinian coastal territory against southern Israel the night before, according to the Israeli military.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Aug. 14, 2013
text: Test your math skills with this question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “A Shuffle of Aluminum, but to Banks, Pure Gold.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Parkour Gyms Open for Enthusiasts and Beginners
text: In the article “Parkour, a Pastime Born on the Streets, Moves Indoors and Uptown,” Samantha Storey writes about the opening of parkour gyms in Brooklyn and other cities.

headline: For Summer Cooking, Embrace Simplicity
text: Peak summer is upon us, the corn as high as an elephant’s eye, tomatoes fat and nearly bursting on the vine. On the East Coast, down in the shallows of low tide, you’ll find people doing the shimmy with their bare toes, or pulling hard with a rake, looking for clams. There is basil in the window box and bacon in the fridge. This is the time of year to make like a chef: Embrace the simplicity of this, and allow the ingredients to talk for themselves.

headline: The Hard Life of Celebrity Elephants
text: One hot morning in Kerala, a tropical sliver of a state along the southwestern coast of India, I took a ride to Maradu, a town of nearly 45,000, to meet an elephant named Mangalamkunnu Ayyappan. He’s a leading-man type: darkly handsome, a bit of a rogue, the star of two feature films. During Kerala’s festival season, which nowadays stretches from December to May, he never gets a day off, parading in more than 200 festivals a year. As the tallest elephant among seven at Maradu’s annual function, he would be granted the honor of carrying a golden idol that evening.

headline: BP Sues U.S. Over Contract Suspensions
text: LONDON — BP has sued the United States government to overturn the suspension of most BP entities, including its exploration arm, from federal contracts.

headline: Connecting With Neighbors, in Baghdad or the Bronx
text: Michael Kamber photographed internationally for The New York Times from 2002 to 2012 and is a co-founder of the Bronx Documentary Center. His book “Photojournalists on War” is an oral history of the Iraq war as recounted by those who documented it from the front lines. An exhibition of portraits he made in the Bronx — grouped with portraits made in Africa, Afghanistan and Iraq — opens Wednesday evening at the Bronx Art Space. He spoke with James Estrin this week about that exhibition. The conversation has been edited.

headline: Euro Zone’s Recession Ends, at Least for Now
text: PARIS — Bolstered by stronger consumption and investment in Germany as well as growth in France, Europe broke out of recession in the second quarter, ending its longest postwar contraction, official data showed on Wednesday. But the weak upturn, high unemployment and other problems on the Continent left open the question of whether the nascent recovery can last.

headline: New York Today: Ka-Boom!
text: Updated, 10:45 a.m. | If you missed the Civil War but still want to see (and hear) a cannon fired from close range, here’s your big chance.

headline: Daily Report: Bitcoin and Other Virtual Currencies Face Legal Scrutiny
text: State and federal officials are starting broad investigations into shortcomings in the oversight of upstart virtual currencies like bitcoin, Nathaniel Popper reports.

headline: Lessons From the Emergency Room
text: A few weeks ago, I found myself in the emergency room on a Friday afternoon, suffering from lightheadedness and dizziness. As the cold EKG transmitters were stuck to my chest, I wondered if they were going to find anything wrong. Perhaps my body had finally caved into to the pressures and exhaustion of building and running my company for the last several years.

headline: Owner Who Plans to Sell a Banksy Mural Steps Forward
text: The anonymous gas station operator whose shop walls were graced with a Banksy mural, which he subsequently cut out and put up for auction, has decided to come forward.

headline: The Solheim Cup’s Fresh Continental Look
text: For most of its history, members of the European Solheim Cup team have come from only three places: England, Scotland and Sweden.

headline: Design Advice on Reconfiguring an Emptying Nest, Part 2
text: This week’s expert, Danielle Galland, an interior designer, is answering readers’ questions about two kinds of living transitions that many baby boomers face: the semi-empty nest, with children leaving for college but returning during breaks, and the empty nest geared toward retirement. Part 1 of her answers appeared here. This feature is now closed to new questions.

headline: Hurdles in Making JPMorgan Arrests
text: Federal investigators are facing logistical hurdles as they seek to arrest and criminally charge two former JPMorgan Chase employees at the center of the bank’s multibillion-dollar trading loss in London last year, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook.

headline: U.P.S. Cargo Plane Crashes in Alabama
text: A United Parcel Service cargo plane crashed during its landing approach at the Birmingham, Ala., airport on Wednesday morning, killing the pilot and the co-pilot, the authorities said.

headline: To His Collection of Steinways, Hedge Fund Titan Adds Their Maker
text: Updated, 9:16 p.m. | John A. Paulson, the hedge fund billionaire, already owns three Steinway & Sons pianos: the medium model M grand, the larger model O and the nearly seven-foot-long model B, together worth tens of thousands of dollars.

headline: Faces of Pakistan
text: Multiple facets of Pakistan as a nuclear armed country as it celebrates its 67th year of independence.

headline: Koreas Agree to Reopen Factory Park in North
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North and South Korea agreed on Wednesday to reopen a joint industrial complex in a sign that the two sides are inching toward a thaw after months of high tension earlier this year.

headline: Live Nation Chief Sells Nearly $12 Million in Stock
text: Michael Rapino, the chief executive of Live Nation Entertainment, has sold $11.7 million of stock in the company in recent days, representing about 38 percent of his direct holdings, the company revealed in a regulatory filing late Tuesday.

headline: By Design | A Second Act for a Legendary San Francisco Watering Hole
text: Last summer the actor Sean Penn heard that the owner of the legendary Tosca Cafe in North Beach, San Francisco’s iconic Italian neighborhood, was being evicted, so he sent a text to his friend Ken Friedman, the New York restaurateur behind the Spotted Pig and the Breslin. Friedman used to hang out at Tosca when he worked for the concert promoter Bill Graham, mixing with local power players like former Mayor Willie Brown and Gov. Jerry Brown. In fact, generations of cultural figures ranging from Hunter S. Thompson to Sam Shepard to Johnny Depp have gathered within Tosca’s muraled walls to swap stories and make deals, often over the “house cappuccino” — a variation on Irish coffee made with cocoa and brandy that was invented there during Prohibition. “There was always opera on the jukebox, and I remember the drinks being better than they actually were,” Friedman said. “From Sean’s text on, it was, ‘Let’s save Tosca from becoming a Subway shop or a whiskey bar.”

headline: Student Crossword | The Civil Rights Movement
text: Learn more about the Civil Rights Movement by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Disappearance of Activist Priest in Syria Stirs Fears He Is Dead
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — An Italian Jesuit priest who spent decades promoting religious dialogue in Syria and championed the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad embarked recently on a new mission: persuading an extremist Islamic group to release its prisoners and halt the battles that had spread violence across the country’s northeast.

headline: Remembering a Zealous Advocate of Lower Manhattan
text: When the ribbon is cut next year to open Lower Manhattan’s new subway hub at the Fulton Center, one figure will be conspicuously absent from the crowd: Elizabeth H. Berger, the president of the Downtown Alliance, who died on Aug. 5, at 53, after a decade with pancreatic cancer.

headline: Taking the Stands
text: LONDON — I was teaching in a Turkey under martial law in the summer of 1982 when I was invited to a think-tank in Bonn to present my first serious academic paper. Also invited were some well-known professors of politics from Istanbul, all of them with good leftist credentials. I was nervous, but mostly excited: What forbidden topics would we be discussing given all the freedoms under siege back home?

headline: Charges Against 2 Traders Fault JPMorgan for Lack of Oversight
text: More than three thousand miles from the Park Avenue headquarters of JPMorgan Chase, traders in an office building nestled near the Thames River disguised the extent of their losses as a huge bet spun out of control last year, federal authorities say.

headline: ‘A Naked Singularity,’ From Self-Published to PEN Award
text: The journalist Katherine Boo, the playwright Larry Kramer and the first-time novelist Sergio De La Pava are among the winners of the 2013 Pen Literary Awards, announced today by the PEN American Center.

headline: Hyundai Recalls 259,000 Vehicles for Corrosion and Axle Problems
text: Updated, 1:53 p.m. |

headline: ‘Physiological Cost’ Is Part of Tennis’s Evolution, Reyes Says
text: Gil Reyes shook his head in disbelief thinking about how the game has changed since he began working with a young Andre Agassi in 1989. Back then, wooden rackets were still a familiar memory and the new graphite technology that would revolutionize the sport beyond all recognition was still in its infancy.

headline: Updates on Security Crackdown in Egypt
text: The Lede is following events on Wednesday in Egypt, where the security forces used deadly force to disperse sit-ins by supporters of the deposed president, Mohamed Morsi.

headline: Egypt Cracks Down on Sit-Ins

headline: The Flames of Kishtwar
text: JAMMU – Chowgan, a sprawling ground in the heart of the mountainous town of Kishtwar, offers one of the most picturesque views in Indian-administered-Kashmir. Tall poplars line the roads and magnanimous chinar trees provide immense shade.

headline: Oil Regulator in Indonesia Arrested in Bribery Investigation
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesia’s anticorruption agency has arrested the head of the country’s oil and gas regulatory authority in connection with a bribery investigation, officials said Wednesday, in the latest setback for the country’s troubled energy sector.

text: Yesterday Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader, appeared to attempt to act like a leader by throwing cold water on the government shutdown plan, which many Republicans have endorsed as a way to stop the implementation of the Affordable Care Act.

text: Two recent photographs and a video have raised questions from readers that are worth considering about The Times’s standards and practices for its visual journalism.

headline: Wide-Ranging Talks at New-York Historical Society
text: Affirmative action, New York’s Armory Show and the presidency of Woodrow Wilson are some of the topics at the New-York Historical Society’s coming season of the Bernard and Irene Schwartz Distinguished Speakers Series, which begins this fall.

headline: A Fitness Program Gets Faster
text: The Ranch at Live Oak, the popular weeklong fitness program in Malibu, Calif., is beginning a four-day version this September at the Four Seasons Westlake Village in the nearby Conejo Valley.

headline: Pace Arts Center’s Upcoming Season Will Feature New Opera Series
text: A new series of recitals by rising opera stars will be among the leading attractions in the 2013-2014 season at Pace University’s Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts, the center in lower Manhattan has announced.

headline: Jewelry Forged by Love, From TenThousandThings and Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin
text: This fall, the fashion photography duo Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin are turning their creative efforts to a collaboration with TenThousandThings, the cult jewelry brand known for its organic-looking designs. Based on a design that Matadin commissioned for van Lamsweerde last year — a chain strung with a pair of intertwined rings and a tiny star, symbolizing the couple’s love for each other and their 10-year-old son — the collection features rings, bangles and necklaces.

headline: Arab Spring Countries Find Peace Is Harder Than Revolution
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In Libya, armed militias have filled a void left by a revolution that felled a dictator. In Syria, a popular uprising has morphed into a civil war that has left more than 100,000 dead and provided a haven for Islamic extremists. In Tunisia, increasingly bitter political divisions have delayed the drafting of a new constitution.

headline: Jesse Jackson Jr. Gets 30 Months, and His Wife 12, to Be Served at Separate Times
text: WASHINGTON — Little more than a year ago, Jesse L. Jackson Jr. was a popular young Democratic congressman pushing to increase the federal minimum wage, an issue that fit his reputation as an advocate for the less fortunate, especially those in his Chicago-area district.

headline: Echoes of the Savage and Sublime on Mount Tamalpais
text: Seventeen years ago — divorced, with three children aged 12 to 18, and some money in my pocket, thanks to a movie that had been made of a novel I’d written — I put a For Sale sign on the front of my big old house in Keene, N.H., and flew to San Francisco to see if the Bay Area might be a good place for us to live. I wanted to expand my children’s horizons, and my own. I wanted to find “the sunny side of the street,” and I supposed it lay in California.

headline: Just Try to Top Geoffrey Kent’s Travel Tales
text: At its independence in 1963, Kenya’s government began a resettlement program to redistribute landholdings to Africans, and most European farmers, given some financial compensation, were leaving the country.

headline: To Our Customers
text: As you may know, our Web site was unavailable for a period of time earlier today. The outage occurred within seconds of a scheduled maintenance update, which we believe was the cause. We are working on fully restoring service and apologize for any inconvenience.

headline: The Gun Report: August 14, 2013
text: Last month, The Children’s Defense Fund compiled some statistics about children and guns which can be found in a report, “Protect Children Not Guns 2013.” Here are some of those gruesome statistics, using 2010 data, which the most recently available, from the Center for Disease Control:

headline: In Defense of Reza Aslan
text: Since I wrote about the latest “real Jesus” bestseller two weeks ago, its author, Reza Aslan, has taken a fairly comprehensive beating in a variety of outlets. The Washington Post ran a skeptical piece about Aslan’s tendency to overemphasize his academic credentials even when he isn’t being cross-examined on Fox News, and his interpretation of Jesus’s life has been treated dismissively by a wide range of informed reviewers, from The Nation to The Jewish Review of Books. The consensus in these pieces is that Aslan’s book makes a hash of more careful scholarship on its way to preordained conclusions, and that his portrait of Jesus as a political revolutionary is just another predictable example of the way that the Nazarene’s contemporary biographers almost aways produce (as The Nation’s reviewer puts it) “theological Rorschach tests that tell us far more about those who create them than about the elusive historical Jesus.”

headline: Fearing Obsolescence, a Company Charts Its Reinvention
text: It may be the most terrifying moment a business owner can face: the realization that what you have been doing successfully, possibly for years, no longer works. For Clint Smith, co-founder and chief executive of Emma, a Web-based marketing and communications company, that moment came three years ago when his team attended the annual South by Southwest Music and Media conference in Austin, Tex.

headline: In I.O.C., New Obstacles for an Expert at Clearing Them
text: MOSCOW — It is strange to see Sergei Bubka — the man who broke 35 world records — as an underdog.

headline: Destination: Downtown Manhattan

headline: Morocco, From Market to Kitchen
text: For travelers eager to act on the promise of heaping piles of vegetables and colorful spices found in Moroccan markets, the Marrkesh boutique hotel El Fenn newly offers a hands-on opportunity to shop and cook with the chef in its restaurant kitchen.

headline: Gen. David C. Jones, Former Chairman of Joint Chiefs, Dies at 92
text: Gen. David C. Jones, who as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff in the Carter and Reagan administrations helped set in motion a sweeping reorganization of the nation’s military command, died on Saturday in Potomac Falls, Va. He was 92.

headline: A Night at the Megachurch
text: “You’re not at a nightclub, you’re at church,” the minister said, welcoming a thousand or so churchgoers to Irving Plaza’s storied ballroom one Sunday night in April. I don’t know if the place was technically sold out — can a church sell out? — but the line to get in ran the length of Irving Place and then snaked halfway down 16th Street, and the place was packed. The crowd was young, beautiful and, it seemed, unattached. I saw almost no one over 40, and none had brought children.

text: The director Lee Daniels narrates a scene from his drama featuring Forest Whitaker and Oprah Winfrey.

headline: House Hunting on ... Lake Como

headline: Vive la Difference
text: It seems right that books about difference should be unusual themselves. That’s certainly true of “Digby Differs” and “Maude the Not-So-Noticeable Shrimpton,” both of which take as subjects protagonists who feel at odds with their environments. These books are out of the ordinary in appearance and tone, too, and suited, perhaps, not to the typical child (if such a person exists) but rather to older readers who sympathize with that feeling of disconnection.

headline: When It Comes to New York Wines, the Governor Likes Them All
text: As the leader of a diverse dining-and-drinking state, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo doesn’t play favorites with the state’s wide variety of wines, so much so that when he is asked what his favorite one is, he mentions practically all of them. “It’s red, and white,” the governor said on Wednesday of his tastes. “And did I say rose?”

headline: Could Outmoded Phone Booths Become E.V. Charging Stations?
text: Consider New York’s public pay telephones. They may be outdated in the digital age, but they have telephone wiring and are often supplied with electricity. More important, they already occupy precious city real estate — and already have the permits necessary to stay there. Is it possible to imagine some of them seamlessly replaced with electric vehicle charging stations, with vital dedicated parking spaces?

headline: Wines of The Times: Albariños From Spain
text: Albariños are the bright and thirst-quenching signature white wines of the Rías Baixas region of Galicia, in northwestern Spain.

headline: U.S. Puts a Helpful Face on Its Fraud Case
text: The so-called London Whale, whose trading in credit default swaps ended up costing JPMorgan Chase more than $6 billion in losses, appears to have a new role as the linchpin of the government’s criminal case against two employees of the bank. His cooperation shows that the Justice Department has learned an important lesson about putting on cases involving complex Wall Street financial machinations that are said to have involved fraud.

headline: A Good Race Spoiled
text: For golf fans, it already feels like autumn. No matter how much the PGA Tour wants you revved up for its “playoffs,” well, the final major of the year is over and the N.F.L. mandates that now we all become football fans and forget those lovely walks along golf fairways. So, Tuesday gave us one last chance to savor Jason Dufner with the sheer absurdity of his making the New York media rounds after his P.G.A. Championship victory, and the PGA Tour comes along and reminds us that fun must be eradicated from the game at all costs.

headline: U.S. Condemns Crackdown but Announces No Policy Shift
text: EDGARTOWN, Mass. — The Obama administration on Wednesday condemned the Egyptian military’s bloody crackdown on Muslim Brotherhood protesters, but showed no signs of taking any tough steps, like suspending American aid, in response.

headline: What Do You Do When What You Have Been Doing No Longer Works?
text: As he explains in a small-business guide we have just published, Clint Smith, co-founder and chief executive of Emma, a Web-based marketing and communications firm, had a moment of realization three years ago when his team attended the annual South by Southwest Music and Media conference in Austin, Tex. Suddenly, Mr. Smith knew that Emma had to re-think its platform and its products.

headline: Lost In Cyberspace
text: In case you’ve been wondering, Chinese Viagra salesmen gremlins have apparently attacked the New York Times. Blog access went down first, so my attempts to post this morning failed; the regular paper is now back up, but so far we can’t do images, which makes posts that included charts not worth doing for the moment.

headline: The Civil Wars Top the Charts
text: The Civil Wars may never tour again, given that the members of the folk-rock duo have been estranged for months, but their second studio album still topped the Billboard 200 chart this week, selling 116,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

headline: Turning to Your Phone for a Better Night’s Sleep
text: I’m terrible at sleeping. Over the years, I have tried various remedies and tricks, and they haven’t helped. I figured there wasn’t much I could do about my problem until I discovered sleep-aid smartphone apps.

headline: Doctors Without Borders to Pull Out of Somalia
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — One of the world’s most tenacious humanitarian groups said Wednesday that it could no longer endure the risks that come with operating in Somalia, in a move that underscored the continued violence in the country despite recent steps toward stability.

headline: Hawks, Doves, and Ostriches
text: More than four years ago Allan Meltzer issued a dire prediction: the Fed’s policy of expanding its balance sheet will lead to high inflation. We’re still waiting for that to happen. So it might behoove Meltzer to admit that he was wrong and ask where his analysis went wrong.

headline: The Great Recession Test
text: A postscript to my Meltzer post: I actually feel some human sympathy for Meltzer (though not too much). After all, put yourself in his position: you’ve literally spent decades promoting yourself as an authority on monetary policy, co-founding the Shadow Open Market Committee to critique the Fed. And now comes your moment of glory. This time the Fed has really done it, adopting a policy you consider wildly irresponsible and inflationary. So you deliver your dire warnings of the doom ahead, and wait for vindication.

headline: 76ers Owner Expected to Buy Devils
text: Josh Harris, the principal owner of the Philadelphia 76ers, will buy the Devils and assume the team’s lease at Prudential Center in Newark, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Chegg, a Textbook Rental Start-Up, Seeks to Go Public
text: Chegg, a start-up focused on the business of renting textbooks, filed for an initial public offering on Wednesday, intending to use the proceeds to raise additional capital and reduce debt.

text: After days of heavy fighting between the Mahdi Army militia and Iraqi and American troops and aircraft, Sadr City surveyed the damage.

text: Iraqi troops pushed deep into Sadr City Tuesday in an effort to regain control of the troublesome neighborhood. Details provided on the map below are based on a survey of sections of the neighborhood conducted by Times reporters in the afternoon.

headline: Manning, Facing Prison for Leaks, Apologizes at Court-Martial Trial
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — Pfc. Bradley Manning, who is facing up to 90 years in prison for leaking 700,000 government files to WikiLeaks, apologized on Wednesday for the “unintended consequences of my actions.” He told the judge at his court-martial trial that while he “believed it was going to help people, not hurt people,” he now realized that what he did was wrong.

headline: New Ways With Ballet Vocabulary Are Mirrored in Relationships
text: Because the Seattle company Whim W’Him is straining against the orthodoxies of ballet, it made, on Monday and Tuesday, a usefully provocative addition to the Joyce Theater’s current Ballet v6.0 festival, which features small experimental ballet troupes. It challenges conventional ballet’s presentations of sociology, gender and music. That’s welcome. So I’m sorry that I don’t welcome the results in the three ballets that Whim W’Him showed here.

headline: This Time the Topic Is Movies
text: Marisha Pessl’s first novel, “Special Topics in Calamity Physics,” was a maddening, twisty, eventual knockout of a book. It sparkled with showy erudition and the electricity of a true original. A prestigious, successful debut novel, it’s a tough act to follow.

headline: Unreliable Guesswork in Valuing Murky Trades
text: On Wall Street, bets worth hundreds of billions of dollars are valued using a considerable amount of guesswork.

headline: Your First Visual Arts Crush
text: This summer, a number of New York Times critics are writing about their cultural first crushes — the moments or works that prompted them to write about the arts. A new essay will arrive each week, paired with stories from readers who work within the given discipline about their own cultural epiphanies.

headline: Predicting Who Will Vote in Mayoral Primary
text: With the New York City mayoral primary less than a month away, campaign strategists are focusing on an increasingly urgent question: Who will show up at the polls?

headline: Warm Welcome for Italian Conductor

On Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, though, the festival presented a significant conductor on the international scene, Gianandrea Noseda, in his Mostly Mozart debut.

headline: A Ballerina Glittering in Ascent
text: LONDON — What makes a star? What is the inner light that compels your eye toward one person on a stage and not another? Olga Smirnova, who is just 21 and ranked as a “first soloist” at the Bolshoi Ballet, has been the talk of the company’s three-week season here, only briefly eclipsed by the unexpected appearance of the troupe’s director, Sergei Filin, at the end of Monday night’s performance at the Royal Opera House.

headline: Times Says Web Site Failure Is Not a Result of Cyberattack
text: The Web site of The New York Times was off-line for about two hours on Wednesday in what company officials say was a failure during regular maintenance of NYTimes.com and not the result of a cyberattack.

headline: Who Is Cory Booker?
text: A look at the career of Cory A. Booker, the mayor of Newark and Democratic nominee for the United States Senate, who has achieved star status in his party.

headline: New Debate on Prostate Cancer Drug
text: A new study has reignited a debate about whether men should use a baldness drug to prevent prostate cancer.

headline: Wild Applause, Secretly Choreographed
text: MOSCOW — In the crowd that enters the Bolshoi Theater before the ballet, it is not hard to spot Roman Abramov and his team, as long as you know what you’re looking for.

headline: Licensing Plan Gives Fresh Plays to Beatles
text: As Paul McCartney closed the Grammy Awards last year with an all-star Beatles medley, Owen Husney, a veteran music executive, read Twitter in horror. In one message after another, young people asked a question that could give a baby boomer a heart attack: “Who is Paul McCartney?!”

text: CARMEL, Calif. — A 1953 Ferrari 375 MM with Pininfarina convertible coachwork, in its first outing since a recent restoration, won best of show honors here on Tuesday in the Carmel-by-the-Sea Concours on the Avenue.

headline: Jordan Asks for Assistance in Securing Syrian Border
text: AMMAN, Jordan — With no end in sight to the violence in Syria, which has already sent a half-million refugees into Jordan, authorities here appealed to the United States on Wednesday for surveillance airplanes and intelligence help to secure a border that is favored by arms smugglers.

headline: Poland Triumphs at Spingold Knockout Teams
text: ATLANTA — On Sunday evening here, the 64-board Spingold Knockout Teams final held the Bridge Base Online spectators on the edges of their seats. As the diagramed deal, Board 64, was played, they thought that Joe Grue of Las Vegas; Brad Moss of Denver; Jacob Morgan of Madison, Wis.; Leslie Amoils of Toronto; Peter Bertheau from Sweden; and Thomas Bessis from France were leading Bridge 24 (Wojciech Gawel, Rafal Jagniewski, Jacek Kalita and Michael Nowosadzki from Poland) by 9 international match points.

headline: In London, Crystal Amid the Brick
text: Residents of the Shoreditch neighborhood in London may have noticed that Electra House on Rivington Street has a fresh coat of paint. Lee Broom, a designer who works in the Victorian brick building, has just installed a showroom there.

headline: Amanda Hesser’s Other Kitchen
text: Don’t think of competing with Amanda Hesser and Merrill Stubbs in the area of kitchen workouts. As the founders of Food52, a culinary Web site that last week introduced an e-commerce section called Provisions, they cook out of a kitchen in their Chelsea office, preparing as many as 15 recipes a day for photo shoots. Designed by Brad Sherman, the kitchen is meant to perform with precision while looking comely.

headline: The Passive House: Sealed for Freshness
