headline: Sales at Thomas Paul, Arhaus and Others
text: Pillows are 25 percent off at Thomas Paul through Saturday (a 12-by-20-inch Amalfi Whale pillow, usually $80, is $60; a 22-inch Leopard pillow, shown, usually $104, is $78); (718) 797-8758, shopthomaspaul.com.

headline: Got a Headache? This Cabinet Might Help
text: There is no shortage of good-looking medicine cabinets, but most modern ones are mirrored boxes in chrome or stainless steel. Those seeking something warmer might consider Think Fabricate Wall*nut medicine chests, which have walnut frames with gently rounded corners, brightly colored interiors and an asymmetrical composition of doors. The design is about efficiency.

headline: A Gift of Gods as Worcester Art Museum Gets a Veronese
text: It’s still a long way from Valentine’s Day but the Worcester Art Museum in Massachusetts is getting an early present.

headline: Bound to a Place, Despite Life’s Thorns
text: I owned the cottage right from the beginning. Or it owned me.

headline: Finding Poetry on the Page and, Later, on the Canvas
text: I’ve been writing about art professionally for more than 30 years, and I fell in love with language before I fell in love with art. Words ended up being my connection to art, and writing came first.

headline: A Bloody Crackdown in Egypt
text: The Egyptian authorities used armored vehicles and fired tear gas to clear two camps in Cairo occupied by supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi.

headline: Food Matters | The Cookbook Not Meant for Home Cooks
text: Only the fourth woman in history to be awarded three Michelin stars, Anne-Sophie Pic is routinely described as the best female chef in the world. That her culinary achievements are often qualified by gender might irk another chef, but the 44-year-old embraces the softer side of cooking. At La Dame de Pic, her year-old restaurant in Paris, the dishes are light and delicate, and each menu comes with a perfume strip to evoke the various flavors of the meal. In her new cookbook, ‘‘Le Livre Blanc’’ (her first in English, available Sept. 1), she features recipes like Normandy scallops topped with a ‘‘sunset’’ of rose petals and radicchio and crab topped with Chinese white-jasmine tea foam, which are accompanied by lovely, spare photographs. It’s as much an art book as a practical guide; Pic explained that she doesn’t expect home cooks to replicate her recipes — after all, who has gariguette strawberries in the fridge? ‘‘But,” she added, “I will be very happy if they were inspired by my associations of taste.’’

headline: In Pursuit of the Perfectly Passive
text: KINDERHOOK, N.Y. — The little passive-solar house that the architect Dennis Wedlick designed more than 25 years ago with his life partner, Curt DeVito, was state of the art back then. It has all the whimsical geometry of a Wedlick house: an acute isosceles triangle on top of a pillbox; four round white pillars on the narrow porch; floor-to-ceiling windows for the most effective solar gain.

headline: Dirty Old Factories
text: Since 1913, L.C. King Manufacturing Co., of Bristol, Tenn., has been making workwear under its Pointer Brand label. The fashion world is taking notice.

headline: At Home With a Passive Pioneer
text: The architect Dennis Wedlick designed the home he shares with Curt DeVito 25 years ago.

headline: She Used Her Gut Instincts
text: For 12 years, Nicole Juday and her family lived across the street from a derelict 19th-century house that was the despair of the neighborhood.

headline: $125,000 But No Bargain
text: The 19th-century house in Philadelphia required an extensive renovation that cost $400,000 just to make it habitable.

headline: An Outsize Vision, Forever Filling Voids
text: MANCHESTER, ENGLAND — “Earplugs MUST be worn” warned signs all over the New Century Hall, where the D.J. collective Despacio was holding a party to show off its custom-designed sound system. Boxes stacked in pyramids around the edges of the dance floor showed the decibel level on electronic readers and flickering needles as hundreds of people danced wildly under purple lights refracted by a giant disco ball.

headline: A Tennessee Clothing Factory Keeps Up the Old Ways
text: Not long ago, I got an e-mail from a man thanking me for mentioning his label, Pointer Brand, in an article in 2006. This was no thank-you note. I read on: “With a lot of hard work and persistence, we recently celebrated 100 years of manufacturing in Bristol Tennessee.” It was signed: “Jack King, fourth generation, L. C. King Manufacturing Company.”

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Controversy Over Gmail Privacy
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Here’s what we noticed today:

headline: Reining In Johnny Football
text: Texas A&M’s Johnny Manziel hasn’t always made good decisions since winning the Heisman Trophy last December. William C. Rhoden says strong action by the N.C.A.A. might be what Manziel needs.

headline: Publicis Groupe, Awaiting a Big Deal, Makes Another
text: The urge to merge on Madison Avenue is intensifying as evidenced by an acquisition made on Wednesday by an advertising holding group that has already agreed to a blockbuster deal to form the world’s biggest ad company.

headline: The Internet’s Verbal Contrarian
text: For every revolution, there is a counterrevolutionary. And so the digital one has brought us Evgeny Morozov.

headline: Farmed and Fried in Iowa
text: Seth Kugel travels through Iowa and finds both farm freshness and greasy comfort foods -- sometimes even in the same meal.

headline: Eating in Iowa: Farm-Fresh, Fried and Frugal
text: The lunch and dinner I enjoyed on a recent day in Iowa didn’t belong on the same planet, let alone in the same state. The first was a sandwich of loose ground meat on a workaday hamburger bun slathered with melted cheese, ketchup and mustard, served in a drab old building underneath a parking garage. The second, served in a reconstructed barn surrounded by miles of corn, was polenta-stuffed zucchini with kale, eggplant and squash, the vegetables raised on site and the polenta made from corn ground just 50 miles away.

headline: Regis Philbin Returns to TV
text: Regis Philbin’s talk show “Crowd Goes Wild” starts Monday on Fox Sports 1, a network from Rupert Murdoch’s 21st Century Fox.

headline: Regis Philbin’s Talk Now Turns to Sports
text: GREENWICH, Conn. — On the expansive patio of their stone colonial-style mansion — which has a pool, tennis court, gym and wine cellar named for his idol Dean Martin — Regis Philbin asked his wife, Joy, “What have we been doing for the last year and a half?”

headline: Video: Reining In Johnny Football
text: Investigations into controversial autograph-signing sessions, from-the-hip tweets and general boorish behavior. Those are just some of the issues following Johnny Manziel, the Heisman Trophy winning quarterback from Texas A&M, this off-season. Manziel is just a sophomore, so it could be a kid acting like a kid. But maybe strong action by the N.C.A.A. will help him mature in a hurry.

headline: Fashion Tips on How to Wear Pastels
text: If the sheer number of baby pinks and chalky blues on the fall runways was any indication, pastels will be making a big statement this fall.

headline: Fashion Tips on How to Wear Fall Pastels
text: If the sheer number of baby pinks and chalky blues on the fall runways was any indication, pastels will be making a big statement this fall. At the Céline, Rochas and Carven shows, among many others, designers sent out a startling array of garments in colors straight out of the nursery. There were boxy pullovers, just-below-the-knee skirts and, most unexpectedly, all manner of coats — tailored, mannish and often oversize. But, come September, how do you pull off sugary pastels without looking like an artisanal ice cream sundae?

headline: California Teenager Answers Questions About Kidnapping
text: Hannah Anderson, the 16-year-old California girl rescued last weekend in the Idaho wilderness after being held hostage for six days, shared extraordinary details of her ordeal as she fielded dozens of questions on a social media account, since deleted, that her family and friends say belonged to her.

headline: Sandra Oh to Leave ‘Grey’s Anatomy’
text: The future of ABC’s long-running prime-time medical soap, “Grey’s Anatomy,” got a little murkier this week when Sandra Oh, below, who has played Dr. Cristina Yang since the show’s debut, announced she was leaving the series (but not until the end of this season). Ms. Oh, who was nominated for five Emmy Awards as Dr. Yang, has played one of the show’s most consistently popular characters. Her decision to leave comes early, which should make it easier for the show’s creator, Shonda Rhimes, to write the character off the show. But there is a chance Ms. Oh will not be the only departure. Most of the show’s regulars, including Ellen Pompeo, Patrick Dempsey, Chandra Wilson and James Pickens Jr., have contracts that end after the coming season. ABC released a statement saying, “It’s our intention to have ‘Grey’s’ on the air for many years to come, with as many of the original cast as possible.” The network has good reason to push for further seasons: the series remains ABC’s highest-rated drama, though its numbers have fallen in recent years from its days as a prime-time phenomenon.

headline: Cautious vs. Instinctive: Who Wins the Race?
text: “Owner’s Manual,” a reality show that starts on Thursday on AMC, sounds like such an amusing idea. But the execution doesn’t live up to the description.

headline: Changing Engines of Growth
text: As growth in the BRIC countries is slowing, the developed economies of Japan, Europe and the United States are picking up the slack.

headline: Bespoke Jewelry, Made With You in Mind
text: Temple St. Clair, a NoHo jewelry designer, has built her reputation on ready-made yellow gold amulets, which usually cost from $2,000 to $10,000 at places like Saks and Bloomingdale’s.

headline: Bespoke Jewelry Carves a Niche
text: In a bid to attract more high-end clients and burnish their brands, jewelry designers are working with buyers to come up with pieces especially for them.

headline: Eva Chen, Trending Now at Lucky Magazine
text: Eva Chen, the latest editor in chief of Lucky magazine, begins many days photographing her accessories while sitting in the back of a taxi on the way from her apartment near Union Square to her large, light-filled sixth-floor office on Times Square. These pictures will be posted on Instagram, where she has 58,173 followers.

headline: Altidore’s Hat Trick Spurs U.S.
text: Only days from making his expected debut for Sunderland in England’s Premier League, the American striker Jozy Altidore stamped an exclamation point — make that three — on an emphatic summer that erased any doubts that he has matured into one of the most dangerous strikers in United States soccer history.

headline: An Ode to a City Overcoming Its Usual Summer Doldrums
text: WASHINGTON — Something strange has happened this August. The tomatoes sold in the nation’s capital are far better than those available at the farmers markets in Los Angeles. No one in Southern California may wish to admit this, but that is really the way it is.

headline: Once a Symbol of Brazil’s Might, Billionaire Sells Controlling Stake in a Company
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The troubled Brazilian businessman Eike Batista has taken further steps toward dismantling his once high-flying empire of energy, logistics and mining companies.

headline: The Changing Face of a Strong Woman
text: Fifty years ago this month, Jamie Wyeth, all of 17, approached a summer cottage in Cotuit, a tiny village on Cape Cod, trembling in anticipation of making his first commissioned portrait.

headline: Jonathan Adler Expands Into Accessories
text: JONATHAN ADLER has always referred to himself as a humble potter, though the pervasiveness in home décor pictorials of his whimsical white porcelain objets (and the 25 stores he has opened in 19 years of business) would suggest he is more of an empire builder than he lets on.

headline: Cameraman for British Network Is Killed in Cairo
text: A veteran cameraman for the Britain-based news network Sky News was among the hundreds of people killed in Cairo on Wednesday. Other journalists described close calls in the streets, and several were detained by local authorities.

headline: Collaborations, Openings and Sales for the Week of Aug. 15
text: Collaborations

headline: Lara Deam: Cool Comfort in Modern Design
text: Sitting in her Manhattan office, swathed in dark Rick Owens leather and with a blond blunt cut, Lara Deam, 46, the founder of Dwell magazine, seemed the living embodiment of a New York kind of Usonia.

headline: The Rosebud NYC
text: While Hell’s Kitchen is now the de facto home of the city’s gay night life, the people behind the Out NYC hotel thought there was something missing. “There were no upscale cocktail bars in the neighborhood,” said Juan Skinner, the general manager of the Rosebud NYC, which opened at the hotel last month.

headline: Gay Spouses of Members of Military Get Benefits
text: WASHINGTON — The Defense Department announced Wednesday that it would begin offering benefits to the same-sex spouses of military personnel and other employees by early September, in response to the Supreme Court decision that struck down the Defense of Marriage Act.

headline: Third Point Reinsurance Arm Prices I.P.O. at $12.50 a Share
text: The reinsurance arm of Third Point, the hedge fund run by Daniel S. Loeb, priced its initial public offering at $12.50 a share, at the bottom end of an estimated price range.

headline: Second-Half Adjustments Are Key to U.S. Victory
text: After a dismal first half, the United States played a dominant second half to defeat Bosnia-Herzegovina, 4-3, and extend its record winning streak to 12 games.

headline: Hagel Tries to Blunt Effect of Obama Words on Sexual Assault Cases
text: WASHINGTON — In an effort to stop military lawyers from using comments by President Obama to prevent sexual assault prosecutions, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel has sent out a directive ordering the military to exercise independent judgment in the cases and effectively ignore the president’s remarks.

headline: Global Powerhouses Sputter and Stall
text: Brazil, Russia, India and China, better known as the BRIC nations, once enjoyed soaring economic growth. Today, they are each contending with a slowdown in investments and major inflation.

headline: Old Economies Rise as Growing Markets Begin to Falter
text: The balance of world economic growth is tipping in another direction. Just as economists have begun lowering their forecasts for China and many other developing economies, the American economy is bouncing back. Japan appears to have turned a corner and is ending almost two decades of grinding deflation. Economic data out of Europe on Wednesday provided the first solid indication that many countries in the euro zone may be escaping the clutches of recession.

headline: Beautiful Pathologies
text: BOSTON

headline: Assault on Morsi Supporters in Egypt
text: Just after dawn Wednesday, tens of thousands of supporters of Egypt’s ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, were confronted by armored vehicles, bulldozers, tear gas, snipers and live ammunition at two sit-in camps in Cairo.

headline: After Jets Lose a Landry, Another Steps In as a Leader
text: CORTLAND, N.Y. — Antonio Allen has a simple mantra whenever he has a question relating to his safety position: ask Dawan.

headline: A Chance to Own a Home for $1 in a City on the Ropes
text: GARY, Ind. — As a tower of black smoke rose above this blighted city last week, a group of neighbors huddled across the street from a burning house, trying to guess which other vacant properties on their block would be arsonists’ next target.

headline: Glory Days, Until They Pass By
text: When you root for the Yankees now, clearly, you root for the past to flicker to life. The players are familiar from the glory of their younger days. Great older players will say they can do what they once did, just not as often. So it is with the Yankees of 2013, and with Alfonso Soriano this week.

headline: Fierce and Swift Raids on Islamists Bring Sirens, Gunfire, Then Screams
text: CAIRO — Hayam Hussein had gone to sleep, with her infant daughter by her side, after early-morning prayers. One moment, silence. Then, the sound of war.

headline: How to Really End Mass Incarceration
text: WASHINGTON — IN 2003, I represented dozens of African-American residents in Tulia, Tex., who had been convicted after a botched drug sting. Jason Jerome Williams, a 22-year-old with no prior criminal record, had been sentenced to 45 years in prison for four sales of an eighth of an ounce of cocaine. Freddie Brookins Jr., 25, had received 20 years for a first-time offense of selling less than four grams of cocaine. Joe Moore, a 56-year-old hog farmer, had gotten 90 years for two cocaine sales totaling under five grams. Others accepted plea deals to try to avoid such lengthy prison terms.

headline: After Injuring Knee, Giants’ Thomas Repaired Spirit
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — After tearing the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee for a third time during training camp in 2012, Giants cornerback Terrell Thomas left his family and his new home in New Jersey and moved to Pensacola, Fla., to begin an arduous rehabilitation. He rented an apartment near the Gulf of Mexico, hoping the vista and the solitude would soothe him.

headline: Things to Skip in August
text: August. A dead shark was found on a New York City subway. Meanwhile, at the Iowa State Fair, vegan activists broke into a refrigerated case in the Dairy Building and threw red paint on the butter cow. In San Diego, the mayor claimed the city should pay the costs of defending him in a sexual harassment lawsuit because he had never been given sensitivity training.

headline: Military Madness in Cairo
text: UPDATE: President Obama said on Thursday that the United States would pull out of  joint military exercises with the Egyptian army scheduled for September.

headline: Obvious Inequality
text: Despite polls that show broad public support for allowing same-sex couples to marry, New Jersey, to its great shame, has refused to follow the example set by other states in the Northeast — Connecticut, Delaware, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New York, Rhode Island and Vermont — in granting marriage equality.

headline: Werner Herzog Says: Don’t Text and Drive
text: Werner Herzog, the prolific German filmmaker behind “Fitzcarraldo,” “Rescue Dawn” and “Cave of Forgotten Dreams,” has directed a 35-minute documentary on the perils of texting while driving. America’s four largest wireless carriers financed the film, “From One Second to the Next,” and released it online last week. AT&T will take the lead in distributing it to more than 40,000 high schools. Maddening and moving, it may be the first example of a new genre: the arthouse public service announcement.

headline: Racial Profiling Lives On
text: LOS ANGELES — THE historic ruling by Judge Shira A. Scheindlin that the stop-and-frisk practices of the New York Police Department violate the Constitution is being applauded as a major victory against unreasonable policing.

headline: Still Starting His Days Early, the Yankees’ Wells Reawakens His Bat
text: A couple of hours before the official start of batting practice Tuesday, Vernon Wells was in the batting cage getting in a few early swings. He slapped line drives over the left-field fence, the balls struck so hard that stadium workers in the outfield grandstands had to move out of the way to avoid being hit. One worker jokingly yelled at Wells to be careful. Wells waved and laughed.

headline: The Balancing Act That Bike-Share Riders Just Watch
text: In its opening months, New York City’s bike share system has found itself locked in a perpetual race against its riders — to remove bikes from fully occupied stations, and to refill stations before the supply runs dry.

headline: The Challenge of Helping the Uninsured Find Coverage
text: OAKTON, Va. — Cyndy Dailey held a job fair at her nonprofit agency here last weekend, with a major caveat: she did not yet know if she could hire.

headline: U.S. Seeks Arrest of Mexican Kingpin Who Was Freed in American’s Murder
text: WASHINGTON — The United States has formally asked Mexico to re-arrest a drug kingpin who was released from prison in the middle of the night last week despite his conviction for masterminding the murder of an American drug agent nearly 30 years ago, officials from both governments said Wednesday.

headline: Cisco Plans to Cut 4,000 Jobs, as It Posts Profit Gain
text: Cisco Systems, the technology industry’s biggest computer infrastructure equipment maker, said on Wednesday that it planned to cut 4,000 jobs, or roughly 5 percent of its work force, in an effort to trim costs and reorganize during what executives described as a “challenging” global economic climate.

headline: Feud Between Prosecutor and Sheriff Goes to Court
text: CARMEL, N.Y. — Mix consistently fractious small-town politics, an ugly rape accusation and a made-for-reality-television script and you have the unlikely drama playing out in Putnam County, where the district attorney, Adam Levy, on Wednesday filed a defamation lawsuit against Sheriff Donald Smith.

headline: Justice Dept. Alters View of Mergers by Airlines
text: A day after the Justice Department filed a lawsuit to block the merger of American Airlines and US Airways, regulators and industry officials continued to wrestle with a central question: What is the best way to protect consumers?

headline: Giving Troubled Youth a Chance to Leap and Soar
text: LEEDS, England — Trey was nervous. He tapped his bare feet on the studio floor and pulled the zipper on his indigo jumpsuit up and down so fast it sang. He was talking a lot. He was talking too much.

headline: Facing Criticism, N.Y.U. Will Cease Loans to Top Employees for Second Homes
text: New York University said on Wednesday that it would no longer lend money to top employees to buy vacation homes and would grant faculty members more participation in school decisions, part of a slate of changes designed to lower tensions between the university’s leaders and its rank-and-file professors. The university also announced that its president, John Sexton, who has been the subject of five no-confidence votes by the faculty this year, would step down once his term ends in 2016.

headline: Police Dept.’s Focus on Race Is at Core of Ruling Against Stop-and-Frisk Tactic
text: The long-awaited decision declaring the New York Police Department’s use of stop-and-frisk tactics unconstitutional was mostly expected; even the staunchest defenders of the practice anticipated that Judge Shira A. Scheindlin would find the stops violated the Fourth Amendment’s protections against unreasonable searches and seizures.

headline: Pine Ridge Reservation Votes to End Alcohol Ban
text: For practically as long as the Oglala Sioux have lived on the Pine Ridge reservation, alcohol has been seen as one of the tribe’s greatest enemies.

headline: Awe Inspiring
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — I will admit that I snorted when I got to 58 Across’s “One with a pretty strong hunch?” I’ve been doing this long enough to know that this was going to be punny, not just because the clue had a question mark at the end, and not just because it is Thursday. It’s because I know Jeff Chen and Will Shortz, and neither one would use the word “hunch” in a clue without grabbing the opportunity to highlight the word’s two very different meanings.

headline: A Take on the City Will Take Some Time
text: Downtown scenesters, take note: Have you ever wanted to test yourself with a show that gives new meaning to the phrase “endurance theater”?

headline: Lottery Numbers
Is This the End of the Arab Spring?
text: Has the military's bloody crackdown in Egypt dashed any hope that democracy can thrive in the Middle East?

headline: Intermittent Nature of Green Power Is Challenge for Utilities
text: The 21 turbines at the Kingdom Community Wind farm in Vermont soar above Lowell Mountain, a testament in steel and fiberglass to the state’s growing use of green energy.

headline: Appeals Court Blocks Attempt by Vermont to Close a Nuclear Plant
text: WASHINGTON — States cannot shut down nuclear plants over safety worries, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled on Wednesday, upholding a lower court’s decision that allowed the Vermont Yankee plant to keep running despite a seven-year effort by the Vermont Legislature to close it.

headline: Israel Releases Palestinian Prisoners
text: As part of an American-brokered deal, Israel released 26 Palestinian prisoners, spawning protests in Tel Aviv and celebrations in Ramallah.

headline: Prosecutor Silent on Questionable Claim
text: Silence does not become Charles J. Hynes.

headline: Special Parking Rules
text: Because of the Feast of the Assumption, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Panel Wants to End Ban on Church Political Work
text: A commission of 14 evangelical Christian leaders has recommended that churches and other houses of worship be allowed to endorse political candidates without losing their tax-exempt status. Under a ban in place since 1954, tax-exempt religious organizations may endorse political causes and legislation, but not candidates. In a report issued on Wednesday, the Commission on Accountability and Policy for Religious Organizations said the ban inhibits free speech, is confusing and is enforced inconsistently by the Internal Revenue Service. A minority report written by some of the 66 religious leaders advising the commission disagreed and supported keeping the prohibition. The commission was convened by Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, initially to recommend ways to prevent financial corruption in religious ministries investigated for misusing donations.

headline: When the New York City Subway Ran Without Rails
text: It was immediately hailed as positively futuristic and yet dismissed as a fantasy.

headline: New Jersey Court to Hear Same-Sex Marriage Case
text: The Supreme Court’s landmark rulings in favor of same-sex marriage earlier this summer have restarted the longstanding battle over allowing same-sex marriage in New Jersey, one of only two states in the Northeast where it is not yet permitted.

headline: Dance Boot Camp
text: School dropouts and petty — and not so petty — criminals, these teenagers have been, as one youth worker put it, “sentenced to dance.”

headline: Marco Rubio’s Un-American Dream
text: In the run-up to 2016, one of the key questions for Republicans will be how to frame, market and package the issue of immigration reform. How can they make reform palatable to the party’s dominant right wing while substantially lessening Hispanic animosity?

headline: With ‘Breaking Bad’ Approaching Its End, Marketers May Clamor to Buy Commercial Time
text: NO television show is hotter than “Breaking Bad,” which set a ratings record for the premiere of its final season on Sunday — doubling its previous high — and is headed toward a finale, on Sept. 29, likely to rival any in recent television history in terms of national anticipation.

headline: Inside the Keurig Vue V700, a Single-Serve Coffee Maker
text: Sometimes, one cup of coffee is just enough. First introduced in 1998, Keurig’s machines run water through small packs to make one cup of coffee — or other beverages, including hot chocolate and tea.

headline: Absence of American Men in Top 20 Is Met With a Shrug
text: MASON, Ohio — American players at this week’s Western & Southern Open expressed little concern over the absence of American men in the top 20 for the first time since the ATP rankings were started in 1973.

headline: Jack Germond, Political Reporter of the Old School, Dies at 85
text: Jack Germond, an irascible old-time newsman who employed horse sense and shoe leather to inform Americans about the ups, downs and twisty turns of their nation’s politics as a newspaper reporter, syndicated columnist and television pundit, died on Wednesday at his home in Charles Town, W.Va. He was 85.

headline: Pakistan Says Indian Military Killed a Civilian in Kashmir
text: Pakistani military officials said the Indian military killed a civilian, the latest in a round of accusations of cross border violations in the disputed region of Kashmir, which the two countries claim in its entirety. Tensions flared over the last week as the relative calm over the Line of Control, the border that divides Kashmir, was broken after each side accused the other of breaking a 2003 cease-fire. A Pakistani military official said the civilian was killed by Indian shelling Tuesday night in Pakistani-administered Kashmir. Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan on Wednesday stressed the need for more diplomacy to cool tensions on both sides.

headline: Soriano’s Revived Bat Stirs Postseason Hopes
text: During the Yankees’ four-game losing streak last week, their playoff chances appeared buried. In fact, several statistical Web sites said their chances stood at less than 5 percent.

headline: Tompall Glaser, Country Artist in Outlaw Movement, Dies at 79
text: Tompall Glaser, a key figure in country music’s outlaw movement of the 1970s, died on Tuesday on his way to a hospital in Nashville. He was 79.

headline: Dodgers’ Summer Goes From Hot to Blistering
text: LOS ANGELES — It took only about seven weeks to lift the suffocating tension and calamitous aura from Dodger Stadium and turn it into what has felt these days like an endless, rollicking party.

headline: New Rangers Coach Chooses Assistants
text: The Rangers announced the hiring of three assistant coaches Wednesday, marking another departure from the team’s structure under the departed coach John Tortorella.

headline: Corrections: August 15, 2013
text: SCIENCE TIMES

headline: Europe’s Slow Financial Reforms
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Word of the Day | sloth
text: sloth •\ˈslȯth, ˈsläth also ˈsloth\• noun

headline: Wimbledon Champion Retires, Citing Recurring Pain
text: MASON, Ohio — Only 32 days after surprising the tennis world by winning the Wimbledon title, Marion Bartoli abruptly announced her retirement after losing a second-round match at the Western & Southern Open, a warm-up to the United States Open.

headline: Japan’s Premier Stays Away From War Shrine, but Sends Offering
text: TOKYO — Japan’s hawkish new prime minister, Shinzo Abe, observed the anniversary of his nation’s defeat in World War II by sending an offering to a controversial Tokyo war shrine instead of visiting it himself, a compromise move meant to try to satisfy his right-wing base without inflaming passions in the region.

headline: What’s on Thursday
text: 4:15 P.M. (Sundance) ORLANDO (1993) A beautiful young nobleman (Tilda Swinton, above) adored by an aging Queen Elizabeth I (Quentin Crisp) falls asleep one night in the 17th century and wakes up five days later as a woman. “Same person, no difference at all,” she says, unflustered. “Just a different sex.” She continues to learn about life through the centuries up until the present, pondering the differences between men and women — as well as their similarities — in this adaptation by Sally Potter of Virginia Woolf’s 1928 novel. Charlotte Valandrey plays Sasha, a wanton Muscovite princess with whom the male Orlando falls in love. Billy Zane is the American with whom Orlando’s female version has a more enduring if less sexually demanding relationship. “This ravishing and witty spectacle invades the mind through eyes that are dazzled without ever being anesthetized,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. “Throughout Ms. Potter’s ‘Orlando,’ as in Woolf’s, there are a piercing kind of common sense and a joy that, because they are so rare these days in any medium, create their own kind of cinematic suspense and delightedly surprised laughter. ‘Orlando’ could well become a classic of a very special kind, not mainstream perhaps, but a model for independent filmmakers who follow their own irrational muses, sometimes to unmourned obscurity, occasionally to glory.” More than anything else, he added: “ ‘Orlando’ is Ms. Swinton’s triumph. With the firmest but lightest of touches, she has spun gossamer.”

headline: South Korea Proposes Talks to Reunite Families Divided by War
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Park Geun-hye of South Korea said Thursday that South and North Korea should resume arranging reunions of families separated by the Korean War six decades ago, and she renewed a proposal to build an “international peace park” straddling their heavily armed border.

headline: Dodgers Rally Past Mets, Adding Drama to Sweep
text: LOS ANGELES — Even while they were being held hitless through the first three innings, even as they entered the ninth inning facing a two-run deficit, it seemed inevitable: the Los Angeles Dodgers, baseball’s hottest team, would find some way to win.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 15, 2013
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Your Own Private Idaho.”

headline: Islamists Debate Their Next Move in Tense Cairo
text: CAIRO — Gathering Thursday morning around a mosque used as a morgue for hundreds killed the day before, many Islamists waited confidently for a surge of sympathetic support from the broader public. But it failed to materialize.

headline: Five Minutes That Split Lifetimes
text: Christopher Capozziello was born five minutes before his fraternal twin brother, Nick. While other twins might jokingly pull rank on each other, in the Capozziellos’ case those five minutes altered the courses of their lives.

headline: The Strange Ascent of ‘Strained Pulp’
text: In his 2012 review of the Steven Soderbergh film “Haywire” in The New York Times, A. O. Scott identified and named a new phenomenon in popular culture: strained pulp. “Nowadays,” he wrote, “everyone must love (or at least pretend to love) pleasures that were supposedly once disdained or taken for granted: dive bars, street food, trashy films. But knowing, sophisticated attempts to replicate those things often traffic in their own kind of snobbery, confusing condescension with authenticity. Movies like ‘The American,’ ‘Drive’ and now ‘Haywire’ offer strained pulp, neither as dumb as we want them to be nor as smart as they think they are and not, in the end, all that much fun.”

headline: Peter Berg Threw Himself Under a Bus. Now What?
text: Peter Berg wanted me to box with him. “Come on, you’re a tough guy,” he said. I tried to disabuse him of that notion. I told him I’d been in only one fight in my adult life, and I lost that one.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Hype About the Hyperloop
text: In the article “Elon Musk Unveils Plans for Hyperloop High-Speed Train,” Nick Bilton writes about “a project that seems the stuff of science fiction.”

headline: Freedom for Midnight’s Daughters
text: Independence came to India at the stroke of midnight, that hour of darkness and, often, danger. The appointed time on August 15, 1947, for India’s “tryst with destiny” was chosen by astrologers, who deemed it auspicious for the country’s birth. Since then the midnight hour has become synonymous with freedom. Is that the case for women, though?

headline: Heart Stents Still Overused, Experts Say
text: Every year, more than half a million Americans undergo procedures to have a narrowed coronary artery propped open with a small metal mesh tube, or stent. In an emergency, when someone is having a heart attack, the operation can be lifesaving.

headline: 14 Monk Competition Semifinalists Are Named
text: Fourteen semifinalists have been selected for the Thelonious Monk International Jazz Competition, to be held on Sept. 15 and 16 in Washington. The instrument in focus this year is the saxophone, and as usual the winner will receive a $25,000 music scholarship, a recording contract with the Concord Music Group and one of the most prestigious honors available to an emerging jazz musician.

headline: New Federal Rule Requires Vehicle Recall Information to Be Searchable by ID Number
text: On Wednesday, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration issued a final rule that will require all major automakers and motorcycle manufacturers to provide free access on their Web sites to information about recalls of specific vehicles that consumers can find by typing in a vehicle identification number, or V.I.N. Although some automakers already have such tools on their Web sites, the rule will require all of them to comply by Aug. 14, 2014.

headline: New York Today: Civic Duty
text: Updated 12:22 p.m. | New York is often portrayed as the ultimate big-city Democratic bastion.

headline: Daily Report: Cisco to Cut 4,000 Jobs, Despite Rising Revenue
text: Cisco Systems, the technology industry’s biggest maker of computer infrastructure equipment, said on Wednesday that it planned to cut 4,000 jobs, or roughly 5 percent of its work force, in an effort to trim costs and reorganize during what executives described as a “challenging” global economic climate, Jenna Wortham reports.

headline: Running the Numbers, a Business Reassesses Its Performance
text: One of my clients is a specialty manufacturing company that makes a beauty product. The company has about 200 employees, and we started talking recently about the efficiency of its manufacturing plant. The company’s chief financial officer volunteered that he thought the company was running at an efficiency rate of 89 percent.

headline: August 16 (a Message on Love)
text: The calendar entry for Tuesday, Aug. 16, 2011, reads simply, “Love One Another.” My wife, Terry, handed me the entry, a leaf torn from a pad, that morning. A drawing beneath the caption depicts a late middle-aged couple embracing as they walk down the beach, eyes sparkling, mouths agape, sharing a hearty laugh. The sun is setting behind them, throwing glitter across the water. Since Terry gave it to me nearly two years ago, that calendar page has remained on my desk in our bedroom, placed so that I see it every time I pass by.

headline: News Quiz | August 15, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: The Year of Laughing Furiously
text: Dave Chappelle was something of a prodigy, starting in comedy clubs at 14, drawing glowing press and interest from Hollywood while still a teenager. He struggled to live up to his early buzz for almost a decade, but “Chappelle’s Show” on Comedy Central catapulted him to stardom. He completed only two seasons, but in 2004, the year before he left television, Mr. Chappelle had one of the most impressive years in comedy history.

headline: 18 Indian Navy Men Feared Dead After Submarine Explosion
text: MUMBAI— Eighteen crew members remain trapped inside the sunken submarine docked in Mumbai despite Indian Navy divers’ efforts to reach the vessel after it caught fire and exploded.

headline: A Comic Quits Quitting
text: In 2005, Dave Chappelle was merely the hottest comedian in America. Then he left his job and became a far more singular cultural figure: A renegade to some, a lunatic to others, but most of all, an enigma.

headline: Mobile Devices Overtake PC Sales at Lenovo
text: TOKYO — Lenovo, the world’s largest PC maker, now sells more smartphones and tablets than computers.

headline: Oversight at JPMorgan Is Scrutinized
text: Criminal charges on Wednesday against two former traders for JPMorgan Chase intensified the scrutiny of the bank’s executives in New York, where, federal authorities say, lax controls and the pressure for profits made the problem worse, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook.

headline: End of the Road Comes Early for Marion Bartoli
text: MOSCOW — Marion Bartoli created what looked like the surprise of the tennis season by winning Wimbledon, but the French player saved the bigger surprise for Wednesday in Cincinnati: tearfully announcing her retirement from the sport — effective immediately — just 39 days after radiating joy and fulfillment with the trophy in her grasp on Centre Court.

text: Military assaults killed hundreds and underscored the government’s determination to crush the Islamists.

headline: Dane Atkinson of SumAll, on Making Pay an Open Book
text: This interview with Dane Atkinson, chief executive of SumAll, a data analytics company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Guatemala to the Border
text: This amazing photo essay shows migrants making the dangerous trek from the mountains of Guatemala through Mexico to the edge of the United States. It gives a hint of the courage and determination  that the journey requires.

headline: Hunting and Gathering at Canyon Ranch
text: Taking a page from the Boy Scouts – or a cue from reality TV – the destination spa Canyon Ranch in Tucson, Ariz., dips a manicured toe into the world of wilderness survival in a four-day survival skills class.

text: Less than an hour’s drive from San Francisco, rustic Suisun Valley is still quiet and unpretentious.

headline: The Good Web
text: Jonathan Chait mocks Robert Samuelson for his column lamenting the rise of the Internet. I don’t especially want to pile on; but this does give an occasion to say something about my own perceptions of how the web has changed journalism.

headline: For Stringer, Stint as Barkeeper Proved Humbling
text: Scott M. Stringer’s career in politics seemed preordained: the son of a city councilwoman and a former City Hall counsel, he campaigned for his cousin Bella Abzug before his bar mitzvah and won a spot on a local planning board at age 16.

headline: Muslim Malaise
text: LONDON — On Saturday, while Muslims were celebrating Id-al-Fitr to mark the end of the holy month of Ramadan, four windows of the Tonna Mosque in Neath, Wales, were smashed by vandals. This is the latest, and by no means the most violent, incident in a series of anti-Muslim assaults across Britain. According to a report released in June, approximately half of Britain’s mosques and Islamic centers have been attacked since 9/11.

headline: School Standards’ Debut Is Rocky, and Critics Pounce
text: The Common Core, a set of standards for kindergarten through high school that has been ardently supported by the Obama administration and many business leaders and state legislatures, is facing growing opposition from both the right and the left even before it has been properly introduced into classrooms.

headline: Third Point Reinsurance Climbs in First Day of Trading
text: Updated, 4:30 p.m. |

headline: Cleanup in Cairo
text: In Cairo, cleanup efforts were under way at two camps of supporters of Mohamed Morsi that were destroyed Wednesday by security forces.

headline: Jaguar Recalls 940 Cars for Stalling Problem
text: Jaguar will recall 940 American market XFs from the 2013 model year equipped with a 2-liter turbocharged 4-cylinder engine for a possible stalling problem, according to a report the automaker filed with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Jaguar says that a part of the turbocharger – the charge air cooler hose – may detach, causing the engine to stall, which could in turn cause a loss of power assist to the brakes and steering as well as make it difficult to restart the vehicle.

headline: His Options Few, Obama Rebukes Egypt’s Leaders
text: CHILMARK, Mass. — President Obama announced Thursday that the United States had canceled longstanding joint military exercises with the Egyptian Army set for next month, using one of his few obvious forms of leverage to rebuke Egypt’s military-backed government for its brutal crackdown on supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi.

headline: Today in Small Business: Loan Demand Declines
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Having More Doctors Might Reduce Health Spending. Or Maybe Increase It.
text: Would increasing the supply of doctors lead to lower health costs?

headline: By Design | Furnishings That Are Made to Age
text: The Los Angeles-based collective Commune, responsible for hip projects like the Ace Swim Club in Palm Springs and the Opening Ceremony boutique in Tokyo, are starting a well-made, understated line of furniture in keeping with their rustic, minimalist style. “I want to make things that age well and are not disposable,” the Commune principal Roman Alonso said. The collection uses two types of wood — black walnut and white oak — and includes subtle metal cleats and brass or copper trim, which will acquire a patina over time. There are customizable options as well: a chair’s slipcover and a daybed’s bolster come in organic materials like linen and shearling. How do the partners make decisions collaboratively? “We only make it if we want it ourselves,” Alonso said.

headline: Image of the Day: Aug. 15
text: Schoolchildren, dressed in tricolors, participating in Independence Day celebrations in New Delhi.

headline: A Bacterial Swarm
text: A common species of bacteria called Pseudomonas aeruginosa sprays out gooey molecules that form a slippery carpet that it can slither over.

headline: A Bacterial Hyperswarm
text: After a few generations, a common species of bacteria called Pseudomonas aeruginosa evolved into a much faster swarmer.

headline: A Mesh of Bacteria
text: A 3-D sheet of bacteria called a biofilm, with normal bacteria in red and the few remaining hyperswarmers in green.

headline: Obama’s Remarks on Violence in Egypt
text: Following is the text of President Obama’s remarks about the military crackdown on protesters in Egypt, as transcribed by Roll Call.

headline: The Gun Report: August 15, 2013
text: Antonius Wiriadjaja, 29, a victim of a drive-by shooting in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, N.Y., on July 5, is documenting his painful recovery in a blog, How I Survived a Gunshot Wound to the Gut, in an effort to push for gun control. Struck by a stray bullet in a drive-by shooting, he still feels incredible pain in his stomach and bleeding from his chest, he told WABC. The writing is therapeutic because he suffers from post-traumatic stress.

headline: Grim Picture of Recovery in Forecasts by Retailers
text: A lot of Americans are still spending their money only on socks and other essentials, highlighting the disparity between younger and poorer consumers and those who are benefiting from the economic recovery.

headline: Family of Briton Killed in China Sought $8 Million, Lawyer Says
text: BEIJING — Relatives of Neil Heywood, a British businessman murdered in China in 2011, demanded $8 million in compensation from the family of the woman convicted last year of poisoning him, according to a lawyer associated with the woman’s family.

headline: Watching Bacteria Evolve, With Predictable Results
text: If we could somehow rewind the history of life to the dawn of the animal kingdom, it would be unlikely that we humans would ever evolve, the evolutionary biologist Stephen Jay Gould argued. The history of life was shaped by too many flukes and contingencies to repeat its course.

headline: When There’s Trouble at Sea, This Captain Sees His Paycheck
text: Capt. Jack Schachner strained his eyes as the waves crashed over the rail of his towboat. It was a moonless night in Jamaica Bay and a storm had pitched the black water, making the conditions even more dangerous than usual as he sped along a rocky stretch of shoreline in pursuit of his bounty.

headline: Obama Deplores Crackdown in Egypt
text: The president announced that the United States had canceled joint military exercises with Egypt next month in response to the violent move to end protests.

headline: Breaking Out of His Pop Prison
text: Meeting Barry Manilow for the first time comes with all sorts of surprises. For someone who sings big songs in an unapologetically open-lunged manner, Mr. Manilow speaks quietly in interviews, often more mumbling than mellifluous.

headline: Penn Jillette: By the Book
text: The illusionist and author of “Every Day Is an Atheist Holiday!” and “God No!” says he ends up liking nearly everyone, but reading Joseph Campbell “made me crazy.”

headline: All the Rage | These Clothes Are Watching You
text: Sometimes it seems like a group of designers all get the same memo. This fall? Optical allusions.

headline: Infertility Less Likely in Women With Children
text: We know — the headline seems laughable (and it was irresistible). But recently released data supports what anecdote has long suggested: once a woman has a child, she is more able to get pregnant again, even if she is past the age at which women usually get pregnant with ease.

headline: Loose Cannons, Now Firing Freely
text: A couple of years ago, when the Odd Future major-domo Tyler, the Creator made his television performance debut on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon,” it was a transfixing eruption of untamed energy and nerve, pop savvy and mayhem, ending with his jumping on Mr. Fallon’s back and grinning for the cameras, a misfit who just ran wild through the castle.

headline: Black Man, White House, and History
text: Nobody who has seen “Shadowboxer,” “Precious” or, heaven knows, “The Paperboy” would mistake Lee Daniels for a realist. Nonetheless, his new film — released, as a result of a ridiculous film industry food fight, with the ungainly official title “Lee Daniels’ The Butler” — is a brilliantly truthful movie on a subject that is usually shrouded in wishful thinking, mythmongering and outright denial.

headline: Gay and Fearful
text: If you’ve been out of the closet for decades and you live in a state that has marriage equality and, better yet, your city and neighborhood reflect the diversity that’s a hallmark of urban life at its most rewarding, it is easy, most of the time, to feel as respected and at ease in society as any straight person does.

headline: Dance United in Training
text: Participants of Dance United, which is made up of school dropouts and petty — and not so petty — criminals who have been “sentenced to dance.”

headline: Staging 'The Color Purple'
text: The big-budget Broadway musical "The Color Purple" is being restructured for a new production in London, by the award winning director John Doyle.

headline: Stripping a Southern Musical to Its Core
text: London — As the director John Doyle started streamlining the big-budget Broadway musical “The Color Purple” for a new production at a 190-seat theater here, his cuts looked like a blood bath worthy of “Sweeney Todd,” the show about the throat-slitting barber that won Mr. Doyle a Tony Award in 2006.

headline: New Call in Baseball: Previous Play Is Under Review, in New York
text: In baseball, there have always been two options for plays on the bases: safe or out. Next season, very likely, there will be another possibility: a challenge by the manager.

headline: A Last Word on the Post and Politico
text: I’m quite sure I’m hitting diminishing returns in my analysis of the Washington D.C. newspaper scene, but let me just reply to this piece in Buzzfeed, in which an ex-Politico staffer makes the case that it would be a tragedy if the Post took what he thinks was my Sunday column’s advice and tried to transform itself into Politico:

headline: Ryanair Fires Pilot Who Questioned Airline’s Safety on TV
text: PARIS — Ryanair, the Dublin-based budget airline, confirmed Thursday that it had fired one of its most senior pilots and was pursuing legal action against him after the pilot raised safety questions about the airline’s fuel policy in a British television interview.

headline: Behind the Southern Road Trip
text: When I decided to write about L.C. King Manufacturing in Bristol, Tenn., I wasn’t really thinking about Made in America. Somehow, the marketing around American-made fogs the actual picture — the hows and whys a garment is made, as well as the problems. I marvel at the skills of people who make things, whether it’s jeans or a Paris couture dress. And, as I tried to say in today’s article, a factory like L.C. King can impart a specific difference — through its needle, its work-wear tradition and whatever is floating in the air of that 100-year-old facility.

headline: Dear Diary
text: On July 7, 1863, just three days after the fall of Vicksburg, Miss., Cpl. John White of the 20th Regiment, Wisconsin Volunteers, walked into the beleaguered city to pick up contraband and prisoners. Like many Union soldiers carrying diaries in their packs, White recorded the moment for posterity: “Today I went into the city of Vicksburgh. Had a good ramble. Very hot day. The prisoners are getting their paroles. Vicksburgh is quite a pretty place.”

headline: Latest SpaceX Rocket Test Successfully Goes Sideways
text: Imagine taking a 10-story building, launching it, angling it so that it shifts 330 feet to the side as it rises 820 feet into the air – and then landing it on the same spot it started.

headline: Puzzle Awaits the Capital: How to Solve 3 Fiscal Rifts
text: WASHINGTON — On the endgame for the budget showdown looming in Washington this fall, only this is clear: President Obama thinks Republicans cannot risk another debt crisis or government shutdown, and Republican leaders agree.

headline: Citing Russian Anti-Gay Law, Miss Universe Co-Host Pulls Out of Pageant
text: Andy Cohen, the host of Bravo’s late-night talk show “Watch What Happens Live,” has declined to continue his co-hosting duties for a different event, the Miss Universe pageant, because of the competition’s location in Russia and that country’s recent adoption of anti-gay laws.

headline: What We Spend to Raise a Child — and What We Don’t
text: The annual United States Department of Agriculture numbers on the cost of raising a child are out for children born in 2012. (I love that it’s the Agriculture Department, which suggests that we raise children like we do cattle.) Not surprisingly, nearly everything has gone up: parents of children born in 2012 are projected to spend more on child care, education, health care and clothing than parents of kids born in 2011, with an estimated total of $241,080 ($301,970 adjusted for projected inflation) for middle-income families in two-parent households.

headline: Hezbollah TV Video of Beirut Bomb Aftermath
text: Updated, 6:16 p.m. | The aftermath of a deadly bombing in a southern suburb of the Lebanese capital, Beirut, on Thursday was captured in video broadcast by the satellite channel run by Hezbollah, the militant movement and political party based in the area.

headline: Auto Loans and Risky Borrowers
text: Auto lending is up, which has brought concerns about whether risky loans are driving the trend. A new analysis from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York finds new auto loans to borrowers with low credit scores have indeed risen, but are still well below the levels seen during the credit bubble years leading up to the financial crisis.

headline: By Design | The Masterful Work of Renzo Mongiardino
text: There is no one I can compare to Mongiardino, except people who have tried to copy him. His sense of color and light was extraordinary, like nothing I’d ever seen. Perhaps this sensitivity came from working in the theater and in film with the artist Lila de Nobili and the director Franco Zeffirelli.

headline: Star of NASA Planet Hunting Falls Idle With Broken Parts
text: NASA said Thursday that its celebrated planet-hunting Kepler spacecraft, which broke down in May when a reaction wheel that controls its pointing failed, could not be fixed and would never again search for planets around other stars.

headline: Bipartisan Group Offers Recommendations on Immigration Overhaul
text: The Bipartisan Policy Center’s immigration task force released a set of recommendations on Thursday for an overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws and called on members of Congress to participate in a civil discussion aimed at finding areas of consensus.

headline: Deadly Blast Rocks a Hezbollah Stronghold in Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A blast from a powerful car bomb tore through a southern suburb of this city on Thursday, killing at least 18 people and wounding nearly 300 in the heart of a stronghold of Hezbollah, the militant Shiite movement that has the country’s strongest military force.

headline: A Powerful Tool in the Doctor’s Toolkit
text: It was well past midnight and most of the patients had settled in. The hospital ward was quiet, except for “the howler.”

headline: The Cost of Hope
text: Avastin can cost $100,000 a year per patient but studies show that it prolongs life by only a few months at most.

headline: Jasper Johns Assistant Charged With Stealing the Artist’s Work
text: In the 27 years that James Meyer worked for the Pop Art master Jasper Johns, the assistant answered the artist’s phone, stretched his canvases, bought his paintbrushes and even drew lines on his canvases.

headline: With Eyes on Syria, U.S. Turns Warehouse Into Support Hub for Jordan
text: AMMAN, Jordan — On the outskirts of Jordan’s capital is a corrugated steel warehouse that serves as a testament to the fact that with enough plywood, electrical cable and bottled water, any austere structure anywhere in the world can be converted into an American military headquarters.

headline: Deconstructing a Horse Race
text: Russell Baze, the winningest jockey in American history, reveals his techniques of the trade.

headline: Playing Doubles: U.S. Open Will Get 2 Roofs
text: The first United States Open match under a closed roof at Arthur Ashe Stadium will probably be played in 2016 or 2017. But even after 10 years of roof research and $100 million, the United States Tennis Association would prefer that future matches be played in immaculate weather.

headline: Why a Twitter I.P.O. Should Go Dutch

text: MUMBAI, India — In the wake of global scandals involving kickbacks and accounting fraud, one unlikely country, India, is aiming to set a tone in overhauling its corporate oversight laws.

headline: Glasses That Solve Colorblindness, for a Big Price Tag
text: A few weeks back, I wrote about special lenses that were developed to give doctors “a clearer view of veins and vasculature, bruising, cyanosis, pallor, rashes, erythema, and other variations in blood O2 level, and concentration,” especially in bright light.

headline: Tea Party to Lamar Alexander: Stop Compromising
text: When it comes to flexing political muscle, Tea Party zealots don’t hesitate to be downright threatening, as in their warning to Senator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee that he’d better retire from office because “our great nation can no longer afford compromise and bipartisanship, two traits for which you have become famous.” The warning was in an open letter from a score of Tea Party groups, most of them county operations in the senator’s home state. They said he would face a right-wing primary challenge if he should opt to run next year for a third term.

headline: Hot Rod Hearts
text: Shirley and Dave Ziolkowski’s custom 1988 Dodge Shadow has helped the couple rekindle the cruising days of their youth.

headline: Can You Guess What This Is?
text: RULES1. Player has not seen the photo beforehand.

headline: Composers Chime In as Minnesota Orchestra Dispute Drags On
text: The latest salvo in the battle between the players and management of the Minnesota Orchestra, where the musicians have been locked out since October, comes from a group of musicians who are not directly involved in the talks but have a stake in the orchestra’s healthy existence: composers.

text: The Tony Award winning performer Patina Miller talks about her workout.

text: At the Edinburgh Festival Fringe a few weeks ago, the English playwright Mark Ravenhill delivered a scathing opening address, taking his contemporaries to task for accommodating themselves to the political and economic culture responsible for the global financial crash while abandoning their role as seekers and tellers of truth.

headline: Not Tonight, or Any Other Night
text: In Nicholson Baker’s recent novel, “House of Holes,” there’s a hotel in which every room has a Sex Now button. Press it, and an aroused person (male or female) will arrive, ardent to attend to your needs.

headline: Dean to Speak at Iowa Labor Conference
text: Howard Dean is returning to Iowa, the birthplace of his innovative 2004 presidential campaign — and the site of his amplified death wail.

headline: Sony and Viacom Reach Tentative Deal to Stream Cable Channels
text: In a deal that may signal the start of a new era of competition for entrenched cable and satellite providers, Viacom has tentatively agreed to let its popular cable channels — like Nickelodeon and MTV — be carried by an Internet TV service that Sony is creating.

headline: Los Tacos No. 1 and Tres Carnes
text: Inside two taco places, one in Chelsea Market, the other in the Flatiron District.

headline: Tacos Two Ways, Garnished With Simplicity
text: We know: we can be insufferable. If you live on the East Coast and you have friends like me who have moved from the West Coast or the Southwest (even from ostensibly mellow pockets of California and Texas like Santa Barbara and Austin), you have probably learned that it is sensible to steer clear of the whole subject of tacos.

headline: Multiple Wildfires Raging in Western States
text: Hundreds of firefighters are battling large wildfires that have consumed more than 700,000 acres across several Western states, including blazes that have destroyed homes near mountain resort towns in Utah and Idaho, according to the National Interagency Fire Center.

headline: Now Screening | Forty Years of Love and Art and Chaos
text: “Cutie and the Boxer,” the debut feature-length documentary from Zachary Heinzerling, chronicles the four-decade marriage and careers of the New York-via-Japan painters and sculptors Ushio and Noriko Shinohara. But it’s anything but a dewy-eyed love story. The film, which won the Directing Award for best United States documentary at Sundance this year, shifts its focus from Ushio’s career to Noriko’s as she emerges from her husband’s shadow.

headline: Retiring the Therapy Couch
text: My husband and I are close friends with another couple. After years of dissatisfaction, the husband began an affair. He moved out of the house, but still returns almost daily for meals and laundry and to see the children. His wife wants to save the marriage and see a counselor. But the husband told us (though not his wife) that he will never reconcile with her. For months, they have sought no professional help. Instead, they come to us, separately and together, to vent and for advice. I told the husband he had to tell his wife the truth. He became upset, but nothing changed. At what point does our advice become unproductive interference?

headline: Patina Miller’s Broadway Workout
text: Thanks to Broadway, Patina Miller is in the best shape of her life.

headline: Magician of the Rolling Hills and Rocky Shore
text: William Trost Richards had a thing about ocean waves. He would wade in among them or stand on the beach, studying them for hours, “until people thought he was insane,” one of his children recalled. He was not crazy, though. He was an American Pre-Raphaelite, a follower of the English critic John Ruskin’s dictum of artistic truth to nature, the achievement of which should brook no compromise. The payoff for Richards’s observational extremism came in the form of landscape and maritime paintings and drawings of arresting, nearly photorealistic intensity, a selection of which can be seen in “William Trost Richards: Visions of Land and Sea,” at the National Academy Museum.

headline: 3 Brazilians Convicted of Gang-Raping American Student
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — A Brazilian court has convicted three men of gang-raping an American student on a transit van, a crime in Rio de Janeiro’s Copacabana seaside tourist district that shocked the nation and focused attention on a surge of reported rape cases in Brazil.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Egypt, Bahrain, Lebanon and India.

headline: Shunning One Museum, Artist Heads to Another
text: The California artist Ed Ruscha, who resigned from the board of the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles, last year along with other artists to protest the institution’s leadership, has packed his trustee bags and headed north.

headline: Marching On
text: Calling all comedy fans! The following scenes, set in the American slave era, were produced this year or last. Which is from a Hollywood blockbuster, which from a Comedy Central series, and which from a magnificent new novel by the best-selling author James McBride?

headline: The Long March
text: The 50th anniversary of the 1963 March on Washington is bringing forth innumerable commemorations and reminiscences in all forms. But memories of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I Have a Dream” speech that Aug. 28 afternoon always threaten to overwhelm, if not obliterate, other aspects of what still remains the most famous mass gathering in American history.

headline: There Will Be Blood
text: I’ve never met Charles Manson, although I did meet one of his former cellmates in the late 1980s, at an ill-­begotten writers’ conference on the Oregon coast. He was the protégé of an elderly and naïve writing coach, and he leapt from her car, heading straight for me, probably because I was the only true-crime writer there. He waved a creased note and shouted: “Charlie gave this to me! See — there’s his signature. I know Charlie Manson personally!”

headline: On Location: A New England Village
text: SHELBURNE FALLS, Mass. — UP in the highlands of western Massachusetts, a Brigadoon lies squirreled away in the dense forest.

headline: Excerpt: 'Soul Doctor'
text: A scene from the number “Sinnerman” from the new Broadway musical at Circle in the Square Theater.

headline: In Burgundy, Winemakers Who Don’t Own Land
text: BEAUNE, FRANCE — Many vintages ago, the négociants, or wine brokers, were considered the big, bad guys of Burgundy. In their barrel rooms in this small city, they controlled the fortunes of hundreds of small growers, unilaterally setting the prices they would pay for wines or grapes. In some bad years or when the economy was depressed, they might decide to buy nothing at all.

headline: Dell’s Profit Declines 72% on Sluggish Sales of PCs
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Decades ago, Dell gained fame as a maker of affordable, customizable computers. But it missed the industrywide shift toward smartphones and tablets.

headline: Getting a Close-Up of the Silent-Film Era
text: FROM the days of Thomas Edison, the New York area has been a big part of the film industry, and now modern technology is turning some of the strip malls and storage sheds of New Jersey and New York into silent-movie shrines. With help from the Web, fans of those films can hike along parking lots, weedy streambeds and gritty alleys where early screen actors posed as American Indians, Confederate soldiers, Soviet spies, Dickens characters and escaped convicts.

headline: Seeing Hamlet With a Twist or Even a Raised Mug
text: During my fifth beer, “The Hamlet Project” got even funnier.

headline: ‘Duck Dynasty’ Season Opens to Record Ratings
text: The backwoods reality show “Duck Dynasty” drew 11.8 million viewers Wednesday night on A&E, the largest audience ever for a nonfiction telecast on cable television.

headline: The SpaceX Grasshopper
text: On Aug. 13, the Falcon 9 test rig, also known as Grasshopper, completed a successful lateral fight maneuver.

headline: Bringing Some of the Rust Belt to Sag Harbor
text: The words “rust belt” aren’t heard together often in the verdant Hamptons, unless someone is chatting about a fashion accessory. It is just as unusual for a young former steelworker to have a solo exhibition there.

headline: The Virtual World Welcomes Toy Players
text: Many people still think of video games as the province of children, precisely because, at the moment of their mass-market origins in the 1970s, they were genuinely kids’ stuff. A December 1980 article in The New York Times Magazine reported that electronics was transforming the toy industry the same way that plastics had 30 years earlier. The article barely differentiated the video games made by Atari, Coleco and others from the electronic toys made by Texas Instruments and Milton Bradley, including the once-omnipresent color-coded memory game Simon.

headline: Triple Play: Make Your Picks for Week 21
text: The Bats blog again tests our readers’ predictive skills with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, tea leaves, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

headline: Of Love and Art
text: Images of the artist couple Ushio and Noriko Shinohara, the subjects of the documentary “Cutie and the Boxer.”

headline: ‘Dunhuang’: ‘Buddhist Art at the Gateway of the Silk Road’
text: China Institute Gallery

headline: Central Park South, the View That Sneaked Up on the City
text: Central Park South has long been a reservoir of apartment-house construction, the expansive north views as attractive in the 1870s as they are now. The sweep of its history runs from the long-gone Bradley of 1877 to the modernist 240 Central Park South of 1940 — by way of the original Plaza Hotel of 1882 and the artistic Gainsborough of 1908. But as it turns out, it took awhile for developers to arrive at a full appreciation of Central Park South’s dazzling prospect.

headline: The Soft Bigotry of Low European Expectations
text: It really is kind of pathetic to see European leaders claiming vindication after one whole quarter of positive growth, at the thrilling annual rate of 1.2 percent. Just to say the obvious: when you’ve suffered a huge hit to output and employment, you’re supposed to have a long period of fast growth to make up the lost ground. Otherwise you’re making the definition of success way too easy.

headline: Bruce Davidson: ‘Time of Change: Civil Rights Photographs, 1961-1965’
text: Howard Greenberg

headline: One Disappears, Another Delves
text: Is it fair to compare “The Lady Vanishes,” a new “Masterpiece Mystery!” movie on Sunday night, with the Alfred Hitchcock thriller of the same title from 1938? It doesn’t really matter, because if you’ve seen the original, it’s impossible to do otherwise.

headline: African Union and Somalia to Investigate Rape Accusation
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The African Union and the Somali government said Thursday that they had set up a joint team to investigate allegations by a Somali woman that she was held hostage and gang-raped by international peacekeepers, in a case that has prompted local outrage and could strain ties between the public and foreign troops in the country.

headline: Piotr Janas: ‘Minotaurs’
text: Bortolami

headline: Former Fill-In for Yankees Helps End Their Winning Streak
text: On the long list of players to have cameo roles in the Yankees’ infield this season — as Manager Joe Girardi mixed, matched and manufactured ways to replace Derek Jeter and Alex Rodriguez — the name Chris Nelson would probably not strike a chord with many fans.

headline: The Art of Marriage, or Marriage of the Art?
text: “Cutie and the Boxer” is a movie that makes you feel less like a spectator than a guest, a friend welcomed into the home of an odd and fascinating couple. Ushio and Noriko Shinohara, both from Japan, met in New York in 1973 — he was a 41-year-old painter and sculptor and she was a 19-year-old student — and have lived here together pretty much ever since. Their marriage is the subject of Zachary Heinzerling’s cleareyed and touching documentary, which uses their work as background for exploring a complex, sometimes volatile relationship.

headline: In Electric Moments, History Transfigured
text: There is nothing in American art quite like the elegant, urgent, boldly colored murals that Hale Woodruff painted between 1938 and 1942 for Talladega College, a historically black institution in Alabama. Clear in hue, form and narrative, these six canvases constitute the heart of “Rising Up: Hale Woodruff’s Murals at Talladega College,” a stunning exhibition at the 80WSE Gallery on the campus of New York University.

headline: What I Love | Betty Halbreich
text: A long-held apartment is a showcase for the personal taste of Bergdorf Goodman’s personal shopper.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘Carol and Cotton’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 25. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: A Personal Shopper’s Home Away From Bergdorf’s
text: Before Betty Halbreich, Bergdorf Goodman’s renowned personal shopper and the breakout star of the 2013 documentary “Scatter My Ashes at Bergdorf’s,” waited on the rich and famous for a living, people waited on her. “We had live-in help,” said Ms. Halbreich, sitting at the mahogany dining table that can seat 16 in the sprawling eight-room Park Avenue apartment where she has lived since 1947.

headline: When the Grandchildren Grow Older, and Closer
text: Growing up, Melanie Cortese always felt close to her maternal grandmother, who lived eight blocks away in South Plainfield, N.J. What really cemented their relationship, though, was adulthood.

headline: Video Shows Civilians Gunned Down in Cairo
text: As Egyptians continue to count the dead on Thursday, one day after the military-installed government used deadly force to disperse protests, supporters of the deposed president, Mohamed Morsi, drew attention to video of civilians being cut down by gunfire during the assault on a sit-in near the Rabaa al-Adawiya mosque in Cairo.

headline: Washington Post Site Hacked by Syrian Group
text: Visitors to some articles on The Washington Post’s Web site Thursday morning were being redirected to the site of the Syrian Electronic Army, a hacker collective that supports the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad.

headline: 36 Hours in Monaco
text: Monaco, a constitutional monarchy on the Riviera measuring less than a square mile, evokes high-stakes gambling, multimillion-dollar yachts, Russian oligarchs, racecar drivers, James Bond films, spotless sidewalks and no public debt. Hotel suites with a view of the sea during the Grand Prix can cost thousands, even tens of thousands, of euros. A starter of pea soup with gnocchi goes for 76 euros (about $100) at the Louis XV, Alain Ducasse’s Michelin three-star restaurant at the Hôtel de Paris. Monaco is a place where high-priced female “escorts” with long legs and exotic accents decorate the nightclubs and hotel lobbies. Visitors can drop their dogs off at free kennels, and car owners feel safe enough to leave their keys in the ignition. Prince Albert II is pushing to make Monaco a family-friendly, environmentally correct vacation spot. Look hard enough and you will discover a world of art, natural beauty and good food and lodging at affordable prices.

headline: Scenes From Monaco
text: From shopping to the sea, you can find plenty in this tiny principality.

headline: Overcoming the Past in Lively Kampala
text: “Art-Culture-Life”: So beckoned the humble sign. Being a fan of all three, I made my way inside.

headline: A Ballad for Those Lost in Love and in Pride
text: “This was in Texas,” a title at the beginning of “Ain’t Them Bodies Saints” tells us, but we would most likely have figured that out before too long. We are in a land of courteous lawmen and soulful outlaws, skinny women in plain dresses and squinty-eyed killers in black hats. These folks ride around in battered pickup trucks and peek out through the screen doors of peeling clapboard farmhouses. Occasionally one of them will aim a rifle or a pistol in another’s direction. An older fellow says “howdy.” What other state could it be?
