He figured that with a 2 to 3 percent return, it made more sense to put the money into a dividend-paying stock and have his brother lease additional land.

headline: Banks and the Monetary Base (Wonkish)
text: Cullen Roche is unhappy with the way I treat monetary expansion in my old Japan paper (pdf); or actually he’s unhappy with the way I talk about it. I’m actually kind of reluctant to even get into this, because any discussion of these issue brings out the people who believe that they have discovered the hidden secrets of the monetary universe, somehow missed by generations of economists. But here goes anyway.

headline: For Airlines, It May Be One Merger Too Many
text: Shareholders and employees of American Airlines and US Airways may well be wondering: why us?

headline: Becoming the Parent With the Child in the Wheelchair
text: As I pushed the wheelchair carrying my son down our neighborhood’s main street, a mini-van pulled up, the passengers waving. It was the same car I had passed while crossing the street two nights earlier. The driver had given me a familiar look — that sweet, half smile at our family’s misfortune — then, his face contorting, he looked again.

headline: Behind the Poison Pen
text: Deborah Blum talks to Michael Mason, deputy science editor, about her new column.

headline: What Inspired You to Work in Theater?
text: This summer, The New York Times is publishing essays by its critics about the moments or works that prompted them to write about the arts, along with stories from readers about their own epiphanies. Previously we heard from readers who work in television, classical music, dance, pop music, video games and the visual arts.

headline: Clip: ‘Short Term 12’
text: A scene from the drama "Short Term 12," directed by Destin Daniel Cretton and featuring Brie Larson.

headline: Aston Martin Unveils Vanquish Volante at Pebble Beach
text: MONTEREY, Calif. — Aston Martin does not deal in bread-and-butter cars, but the 2014 Vanquish Volante that made its North American debut at the private Monterra estate could be called baguette-and-pâté for the Vanquish model’s future.

headline: Jesus Under the Microscope
text: Reza Aslan’s “Zealot” reaching the top of the best-seller list is a reminder that books on the historical Jesus have been popular for a very long time. In 1846, George Eliot translated “Life of Jesus, Critically Examined,” by David Friedrich Strauss, from German into English. Nearly 150 years later, Evelyn Toynton, writing about “Jesus: A Life” for the Book Review in 1992, said A. N. Wilson’s study “does not pretend to add much to the scholarship on the subject.” According to Toynton’s reading, Wilson, like Aslan, argued that Jesus “never saw himself as anything but a Jew or desired any following among the gentiles,” and “was crucified as a terrorist, not as a religious figure.”

headline: A Tree Grows, and Grows
text: For more than half my life, I have been party to the ongoing burial of a literary reputation. Strangely enough, I don’t think my victim entirely deserves it.

headline: Inside the List
text: SPECIAL EDUCATION: John Green is arguably the most popular young adult author in America today — three of the 10 spots on the current Y.A. list belong to his books, including the sweetly tragicomic cancer novel “The Fault in Our Stars,” at No. 1 after 37 weeks. (The others are “Looking for Alaska,” at No. 5 after 37 weeks, and “Paper Towns,” at No. 8 after 27 weeks.)

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE INFATUATIONS,  by Javier Marías. Translated by Margaret Jull Costa. (Knopf, $26.95.) Amid a proliferation of alternative perspectives, Marías’s novel explores its female narrator’s relationship with the widow and the best friend of a murdered man.

headline: ‘Liberated Carbon, It’ll Turn Your Night to Day’
text: Via Climate Nexus and Daniel M.N. Turner, here’s video of my performance of “Liberated Carbon,” my short musical history of humanity’s love affair with fossil fuels, at the ScienceOnline Climate conference in Washington, D.C., yesterday.

headline: Good Decisions Eventually Bear Fruit
text: Brie Larson could have been another teenage actor who never graduated to adult roles. After an early start in forgettable sitcoms, like the 2001 Bob Saget series “Raising Dad,” she began a side career in bubble gum pop music. She also played a rebellious wild child on three seasons of Showtime’s “United States of Tara” and in the movie “Scott Pilgrim vs. the World.”

headline: The Art of Passing for Them
text: Please. Get back in your body. All I said was“I’m a poet.” I tried not to. We get along fineuntil then, talking about golf which I don’t play,and tennis which my friends pay menot to play, about how much you hate teachersbecause they ruined your life, left you hatingeverything, so all you can do is “make money,and know nothing. Nothing! Horrible people, teachers.Horrible! I hope you don’t know one,”and since I am one, I know I’m passing.It must be the pearls. The off-the-shoulder dress.

headline: Nickel and Dimed
text: In Mitchell S. Jackson’s powerful debut novel, “The Residue Years,” we know how things will end for Champ Thomas and his mother, Grace, before we know how they get there. In the prologue — one of the few I’ve read that is organic to the story that follows — a mother is visiting her son in prison. This imbues what follows with a sense of hopelessness that becomes ever sharper in contrast to the novel itself, which is, in its way, full of impossible hope.

headline: A Sporting Chance
text: For two months in spring, the Indian Premier League is watched more than anything else on Indian television. Test cricket is played between nations over five days, without guarantee of a winner. I.P.L. matches last three hours and are played between Indian teams owned by businessmen and movie stars. Results are guaranteed.

headline: Underground Idol
text: The true believers come out at night. They meet in condemned buildings marked by the symbol of a stylized eye to watch a “night film” — one of the psychologically punishing horror pictures of Stanislas Cordova, a master filmmaker who has shunned publicity with a zeal that makes Thomas Pynchon look like a shameless attention hog. Adding to the mystique is a sense that Cordova might have retreated because he has something unsavory to hide. Bad things happen to those who try to pick his locked closet for a look at the skeletons. Consider the star reporter Scott McGrath, who plunged into disgrace after a preliminary investigation into Cordova’s secrets blew up in his face. McGrath has a score to settle, so when Cordova’s achingly gifted daughter turns up dead in a Manhattan ruin, it’s Take 2 for the unemployed journalist. Nor is McGrath the only one who wants to know what’s been going on behind the camera; in short order he’s joined by a shabby but smoldering drug dealer named Hopper and a breathless ingénue, Nora Halliday. Together, the three make an adorably awkward family of misfits, who will be even more appealing should George Clooney, Ryan Gosling and Alison Brie be cast for the movie adaptation.

headline: Digging Up Family Roots in Sicily
text: As a writer I’ve always tended to seek out origins. My first book, about the search for the historical Jesus, was an attempt to get at the “real” story behind my Catholic upbringing. After living in Manhattan for several years, I wrote “The Island at the Center of the World,” a book about the Dutch settlement of New Amsterdam, the seed from which New York City grew.

headline: On Foreign Shores
text: A number of remarkable short novels have emerged in the recent past: “Tinkers,” by Paul Harding; “Train Dreams,” by Denis Johnson; “The Sojourn,” by Andrew Krivak; “The Buddha in the Attic,” by Julie Otsuka. Far from slight, they all deal with large themes and subjects that could easily fill 500-page books, yet have been compressed into poemlike works. Page count is one of the most prosaic ways to categorize a book, but it points to the fact that one approaches these works differently — the experience more akin to reading poetry or short fiction, where what is left out is at least as important as what remains. With “Snow Hunters,” Paul Yoon proves himself well suited to the short form.

headline: Service Jobs
text: In his beguiling 2009 memoir, “When Skateboards Will Be Free,” Saïd Sayrafiezadeh recounted being raised by devout members of the Socialist Workers Party. His Jewish mother did the actual raising; his Iranian-born father abandoned the family for the cause. Both believed a workers’ revolution was imminent. It was a childhood, Sayrafiezadeh observed, devoted to “a peculiar set of rules” that were both ethically impeccable and entirely at odds with the dominant culture.

headline: In Istanbul, Seeing Art Through Two Lenses
text: The art scene in Istanbul has gradually shifted from a heavily traditional one that celebrates the city’s history to a contemporary one that prizes its upstarts. Less than a decade ago, the city’s Museum of Modern Art was inaugurated. Last year the contemporary art space SALT opened. This year a number of Istanbul galleries will be on hand at London’s Frieze (as they were at the Randalls Island New York version and at Art Basel in Basel and Hong Kong).

headline: Political Journalism Chronicle
text: THE CENTER HOLDS  Obama and His Enemies  By Jonathan Alter  Simon & Schuster, $30.

headline: Fruit of Knowledge
text: Rebecca Solnit’s latest book, a series of essays loosely about story­telling, has a table of contents that sits on the page like a mountain tipped on its side. The essays’ titles mirror or refract one another, imparting symmetry. The summit, a chapter titled “Knot,” evokes another of the book’s metaphors, the bringing together of narrative threads. The tipped mountain shape resembles the traditional rise and fall of story structure. But this isn’t the only visual conceit. “Imagine all the sentences in this book as a single thread around the spool that is a book,” Solnit writes. You needn’t imagine it, though: One unspooled essay runs like a news ticker along the base of every page.

headline: Witness to War
text: Long before I could locate the peninsula of Gallipoli on a map, as a Briton I knew it as a place where we did something awful to the Australians. Down Under they have a clearer memory. Having fought bravely and loyally for king and empire in two world wars, they have never shaken the belief that they were used as cannon fodder when Britain (and France) launched a disastrous attack on this strategic outpost of the Ottoman Empire in 1915.

headline: King of the Jean Pool
text: Thirty-five years ago, Renzo Rosso co-founded Diesel, the company that almost single-handedly incited the premium denim craze. Now 57 and worth an estimated $3 billion, the farmer’s son who created his first pair of jeans on his mother’s sewing machine has expanded his empire to include fashion brands like Maison Martin Margiela, Marni and Viktor & Rolf, all under the umbrella of his parent company OTB (short for his personal motto, Only the Brave). Despite these successes, Rosso’s life is in many ways very small. Case in point: the Italian businessman owns only one home, an 18th-century Palladian villa just an hour drive from his hometown of Brugine. Of course when he wants to go further, there’s always the private jet.

headline: Movie Review: 'Lee Daniels' The Butler'
text: A. O. Scott’s review of “Lee Daniels’ The Butler.”

headline: Paperback Row
text: IRON CURTAIN: The Crushing of Eastern Europe, 1944-1956,  by Anne Applebaum. (Anchor, $17.95.) In her Pulitzer Prize-winning “Gulag” (2003), Applebaum documented the horror of Stalin’s Soviet terror machine. Now this remarkable sequel, drawn from newly opened archives and survivor interviews, shows how the Soviet Union imposed its totalitarian will upon Eastern European nations ravaged by World War II.

headline: Movie Review: 'Kick-Ass 2'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Kick-Ass 2."

headline: Deep Cuts at Patch, AOL’s Local News Sites
text: AOL on Friday moved to cut losses at Patch, its struggling local news service, eliminating as many as 500 positions and closing or consolidating many of its sites across the country.

headline: In God’s Name, or Baby ‘Messiah,’ Competing Claims of Religious Freedom
text: Last week, when a Tennessee judge forcibly changed an infant’s name from Messiah to Martin, it was hard to decide which was more noteworthy, the parents’ grandiosity in naming their child for the one they consider their Savior or the judge’s religious zealotry in prohibiting the name.

headline: Movie Review: 'Jobs'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Jobs.”

headline: Across the Cumberlands
text: On Aug. 16, 1863, Henry Campbell recorded in his diary how his unit, the 18th Indiana Battery, had just climbed the front range of the Cumberland Mountains, which separate the fertile Cumberland Basin of middle Tennessee from the eastern part of the state. A rainstorm impeded their ascent, making the road “exceedingly steep, slippery, and winding.” As they labored upward, the soldiers were enveloped by a dense fog. Suddenly, as they approached the top of the mountain, they found themselves entirely above the clouds, looking down, Campbell wrote, on “one of the grandest sights I ever witnessed.” Bright sunlight poured through the rain, creating “hundreds of rain bows on the sides of the mountains beneath us.” The 18-year-old Hoosier struggled to convey in words a sublime spectacle “that no pen could describe.”

headline: Bombing in Beirut
text: Video shows the aftermath of a car bomb that tore through a southern suburb of Beirut on Thursday, killing at least 18 people and wounding nearly 300.

headline: Image of the Day: August 16
text: Renjith Maheshwary, an Indian athlete, at the IAAF World Championships in Athletics event in Moscow, Russia.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Trinidad and Tobago; Lucas, Ohio; Charlottesville, Va.
text: The Biswas House, Trinidad and Tobago The childhood home of V. S. Naipaul, above, the Nobel Prize-winning author, which is at the center of one of his best-known novels, “A House for Mr. Biswas,” has been converted into a literary museum that will open in October. Some sections of the property, in Trinidad and Tobago in the Port of Spain suburb of St. James, resemble how it would have looked in the late 1940s, when it was acquired by the Naipaul family. Many original furnishings and items, some described in the 1961 novel, will be on display.

headline: Fund Set Up for UBS Bailout Repays Loan
text: LONDON — The Swiss National Bank said Friday that a fund set up as part of UBS’s bailout five years ago had fully repaid a loan it received as part the rescue.

headline: Good Deeds Gone Bad
text: ON your way to work today you may have paused to let another car merge into your lane. Or you stopped to give a dollar to a subway artist. A minute later, another chance to do the same may have appeared. Did your first act make the second more tempting? Or did you decide you had done your good deed for the day?

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘The Nightmare Dream’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 25. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: Witness Accounts of Sectarian Attacks Across Egypt
text: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick in Cairo reported, supporters of the ousted Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi, have lashed out across Egypt since two pro-Morsi sit-ins were violently dispersed by the armed forces, blocking bridges and highways, storming government buildings and attacking churches of the country’s Christian minority.

headline: Lee Miller: Light on Her Fashion
text: “I’d rather take a picture than be one,” Lee Miller remarked to a New York newspaperman in October 1932, as she stepped off a ship from Europe and was recognized among the “cargo of celebrities on board.”

headline: Learn Campus, Meet Dorm Neighbors, Get Ready to Vote
text: In the back-to-school rush of choosing courses and decorating dorm rooms, college students might be tempted to tune out the city’s coming elections.

headline: A Pact to Make the Heart Grow Fonder?
text: When Andrew and I left our Vermont college town, we thought we were so incredibly in love, we tried an experiment. He flew home to Canada to work, I drove to San Francisco, and we agreed not to have sex for almost a year. Not with each other during visits. Not with anyone.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 16
text: Subjects include graffiti in Greenpoint, Brooklyn; swimming lessons in Far Rockaway, Queens; and a protest march on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.

headline: Roosevelt Island Tramway, 12:05 P.M.
text: Passengers aboard the Roosevelt Island Tramway on Friday looked down at the Ed Koch Queensboro Bridge, where a truck fire closed the bridge for a time and snarled traffic.

headline: The Eagles' Elephant in the Room
text: Eagles players should take a stand against using the kind of language that Riley Cooper used that caused a recent controversy regarding race.

headline: Surf’s Up
text: The amount of Internet traffic zooms ever upward, but economic indicators have risen at a vastly slower pace.

headline: Voter Fraud! Wait, No.
text: We’ve written before on allegations of voter fraud that, upon close or even cursory examination, turn out not to hold water. Like when South Carolina’s Republican Attorney General, Alan Wilson, claimed 900 dead people had voted in “recent elections” (spoiler alert: there were no zombies, but click the link for the whole story).

headline: A Mayor Who Puts Wall Street First
text: On March 15 of last year, at a moment when many New Yorkers found themselves increasingly disturbed by revelations that the Police Department had conducted constitutionally suspect surveillance of Muslim communities, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made an unplanned visit to the offices of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Still Tingling Spines, 50 Years Later
text: Brian Wilson of the Beach Boys estimates that he’s heard “Be My Baby,” by the Ronettes, more than 1,000 times. The very first listen, 50 years ago this month, still haunts him.

headline: American Hurdler Puts Her Potential on the Starting Line
text: MOSCOW — A young woman who has handled the day-in-day-out pandemonium of having six younger brothers is not likely to panic at the prospect of facing seven other hurdlers.

headline: Wait Ends for a Yiddish Version of ‘Godot’
text: “Waiting for Godot,” Samuel Beckett’s signature, absurdist play, has a new twist: the New Yiddish Rep and the Castillo Theater are presenting what they bill as the first-ever production in Yiddish. The play, to run Sept. 20 to Oct. 13 at the Castillo Theater, presents the characters as Holocaust survivors. The boy who is Godot’s messenger is played by a young African-American actor.

headline: Video: The Eagles’ Elephant in the Room
text: Eagles players should take a stand against using the kind of language that Riley Cooper used that caused a recent controversy regarding race.

headline: The Fig Now Yields Its Charms
text: There’s a magnificent century-old fig tree on the farm my friend Bob Cannard has near Sonoma, Calif. It keeps giving fruit year after year. It’s a mammoth of a tree, with thick, gnarled, low branches that span outward, then twist to form a natural gazebo 20 feet in diameter. You don’t climb up the tree so much as step into it to find a place to perch.

headline: Judge’s Ruling Removes Hurdles to a Dell Takeover Bid
text: Updated, 6:03 p.m. | A Delaware judge on Friday denied a bid by Carl C. Icahn to derail a vote on a nearly $25 billion takeover bid for Dell Inc., dealing a blow to his fight against the buyout offer.

headline: Earl Sweatshirt and ASAP Ferg Step Up
text: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss new records by two hip-hop lieutenants who are making a move.

headline: A Gumdrop Shape, Good and Plenty
text: Ask 5-year-olds to draw you a tree and they will unwittingly sketch you a pin oak.

headline: Before Saying ‘I Do,’ Define Just What You Mean
text: Writing your own vows, Lois Kellerman says, is like making homemade cookies.

headline: Popcast: Earl Sweatshirt and ASAP Ferg Step Up
text: This week: two hip-hop lieutenants make a move.

headline: Every Cat Has Its Day: Hermitage Museum’s Mouse Catchers Are Immortalized in Portraits
text: MOSCOW — While it might seem risky to keep dozens of cats near some of the world’s most precious pieces of art, cats are regarded as treasured guardians of the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia, patrolling the basement for mice and rats and treated like furry royalty by doting staff members.

headline: Hotel Drinking Gets Specialized
text: Bartenders are a mainstay at most upscale hotels, but some properties today have staff members who are specialists in just one type of alcohol.

headline: They’ve Come Back for One Last Pint
text: “The World’s End,” a new comedy directed by Edgar Wright and written by Mr. Wright and Simon Pegg, is a reunion movie in the most literal sense: it tells the story of a burned-out and reckless middle-aged man (Mr. Pegg) who reunites a gang of reluctant childhood friends (Nick Frost, Martin Freeman, Paddy Considine and Eddie Marsan) to complete the hometown pub crawl they couldn’t quite finish in their youth — only to discover some very sinister developments are afoot in their former stamping grounds.

headline: Stagflation, Stagnation, and Intellectual Asymmetry
text: Brad DeLong weighs in on the Friedman legacy, and notes that there have been two big successful sort of meta-predictions in macroeconomics over the past half-century. In the late 60s, Friedman and Phelps warned of the risk of stagflation, and were vindicated in the 1970s. In the late 1990s, some economists warned of the risk of Depression-type liquidity traps, and were vindicated in the Naughties. The first success led to Friedmam’s promotion to demigod status; the second success has not produced any comparable elevation.

headline: Despite Fears, King Memorial Is Ready for Anniversary
text: WASHINGTON — Repairs to the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial have been completed, erasing doubts about whether the site would be ready for the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington and Dr. King’s “I Have a Dream” speech on Aug. 28.

headline: What Happens When the N.S.A. Gets Sloppy
text: All institutions make mistakes, but when an organization as vast and unsupervised as the National Security Agency gets sloppy, the mistakes quickly amount to a serious abuse of government authority. Barton Gellman’s article today in the Washington Post was remarkable not just because it showed widespread incompetence by the agency, but because it showed the real dangers in allowing the N.S.A. to exercise overly broad power with almost no oversight.

headline: A Kung Fu That Maims and Romances
text: Wong Kar-wai was recounting his research for “The Grandmaster,” the tale of the kung fu innovator who trained Bruce Lee. As he described crisscrossing the mainland to talk to aging martial artists, he could have been setting the scene for a movie.

headline: Closing the Proficiency Gap in New York Schools
text: As befits a tech mogul, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been a resolute supporter of digital initiatives in New York City, from hiring the city’s first chief digital officer, Rachel Sterne Haot, to strong patronage of the thriving Silicon Alley start-up community.

headline: Schroedinger’s Price Index
text: Apparently Republicans are trying, once again, to extract chain-linking of Social Security benefits as the price of some kind of deal. I have no idea whether this will go anywhere; my guess, or maybe just my hope, is that Obama the Grand Bargainer has vanished from the scene.

headline: The Gun Report: August 16, 2013
text: The Gun Report began seven months ago, after I wrote a column that simply grabbed examples of gun violence from the week’s news. Since then, we have tried to document the awful range and scope of daily gun violence, from accidents involving small children who get their hands on guns, to drive-by shootings, to killings that transpire in a flash of anger. Now, however, the Gun Report is going to take a short break. We will be back after Labor Day.

headline: Artists on Artists | Chris Johanson on the Apocalyptic Machines of Kal Spelletich
text: After a two-year hiatus, the skateboarder-turned-art Chris Johanson is back in a major way, with his first comprehensive museum solo show, “Within the River of Time Is My Mind,” at the Museum of Contemporary Art Los Angeles (through Oct. 13) and a self-titled new monograph from Phaidon.

headline: A Prayer Before the Complaints Roll In
text: Sherone Lewis works for the City of New York and loves her job — a common enough sentiment, you might say, but consider this: For the last 11 years, Ms. Lewis, 46, has worked for the city’s 311 line, managing the complaints and dissatisfactions of a populace that approaches them as Olympic events. Ms. Lewis started as a call center representative, or C.C.R., in December 2002, just as the Bloomberg administration was consolidating the city’s help lines into 311, and is now a call center manager. Sundays often find her working the evening shift downtown, commuting from her apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, which she shares with her 25-year-old daughter.

headline: Can a Child Be Too Young for Shared Custody?
text: A reader finds herself “abruptly” getting divorced, with two small children: 15 months and 5½ years old. The circumstances of the divorce aren’t happy ones, and she is angry and upset, but writes that she is trying “to protect the relationship my children have with their father while still providing them with the necessary stability for them to thrive.”

headline: Boop-Boop-a-Doo on Blu-ray
text: Betty Boop began her life as a floppy-eared dog and ended it as a happy homemaker dressed in an apron. But at her peak — roughly from 1931 to 1934 — she was a major figure in American movies, despite being, as her theme song put it, “made of pen and ink.”

headline: Gabriel Kreuther Will Leave the Modern
text: Gabriel Kreuther is stepping down as executive chef at the Modern, where he has been since 2004. “It’s the dream of most of the chefs to open their own place someday and for me the moment is now,” he said. He probably will not leave before the end of the year, he said. In announcing the news, Union Square Hospitality Group, which runs the high-end restaurant at the Museum of Modern Art along with its cafe and private dining room, said it wished him the best and was “beginning a search for out next executive chef.”

headline: Bank of America May Merge Merrill Lynch With Parent
text: Bank of America is still trying to get its arms around the big acquisitions it did amid the financial crisis.

headline: A Love Embraced, Some 35 Years Later
text: Anyone who has ever had one knows there is nothing quite like a perfect summer beach romance in the spring of life. But, like a great bottle of wine, once it is done it is done, its pleasures left only to memory.

headline: Duet for Composition and Software
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — On a recent Tuesday afternoon, Tod Machover, a professor of music and media at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology’s Media Lab and head of the Opera of the Future group there, assembled his students in his glass-walled lab. The space was cluttered with computers, triangular-headed robots, colorful fabric-covered children’s toys and digital control tables. A large metal chandelier hung suspended from the ceiling, its swooping curves and fanned-out spokes giving it the look of a mathematically minded jellyfish.

headline: No Rest in Peace for the Wicked
text: “America loves a serial killer,” the detective Jane Rizzoli (Angie Harmon) says in Tuesday’s episode of “Rizzoli & Isles,” at 9 p.m. on TNT. So why not bring one back from the dead? The episode, “No One Mourns the Wicked,” gives fans of this reliable series another look at Charles Hoyt, one of the most memorable recurring characters the show has had since its debut in 2010. Hoyt was Rizzoli’s archnemesis until he was killed off in Season 2. Or was he?

headline: Release the Hounds of Memory
text: This is not a comparison that any playwright wants to have to live up to, but Anne Washburn has always struck me as the American author most like Caryl Churchill. Like that justly hailed British playwright, Ms. Washburn (“The Internationalist”) writes formally daring, ominous and prickly dramas that urgently address topical issues while creating worlds that seem very foreign. In her new work, “Mr. Burns, a Post-Electric Play,” which drew raves in its run in Washington, she tackles global disaster, adaptation and the peculiar power of stories passed down over generations.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: Viand Cafe
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has made Viand, just around the corner from his townhouse, a place for power breakfasts.

headline: Spirit of Parker, Freely Inhaled
text: The Charlie Parker Jazz Festival, now in its 21st year, doesn’t always genuflect directly to its namesake, the alto saxophonist and bebop paragon commonly known as Bird. But this year the lineage is clear. Two anchors of the lineup are Jimmy Heath, who earned the sobriquet “Little Bird” early in his career, and Lee Konitz, who became known in the same era for his stubborn independence from the Parker style. Mr. Heath, 86, will lead his big band in the premiere of a suite called “Bird Is the Word” on Friday night; Mr. Konitz, 85, will work with a quartet on Sunday afternoon.

headline: M.I.T.’s Opera of the Future
text: The professor Tod Machover and his students work on building better sounds.

headline: In the Jungle, Eccentric at Work
text: The title of the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s Werner Herzog series, “Parables of Folly and Madness,” perfectly describes “Fitzcarraldo” (1982), a work of many-splendored obsession. Fitzcarraldo — “a conquistador of the useless” — has a quixotic dream: to build an opera house in the middle of the Peruvian jungle.

headline: Rodriguez Denies Implicating Others
text: BOSTON — Alex Rodriguez arrived at Fenway Park on Friday to begin a three-game series against the Red Sox, bracing for an extended chorus of derision from Red Sox fans getting their first crack at him since baseball suspended him for 211 games. The punishment came after he was linked to a South Florida clinic that supplied players with performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Fresh Pieces, Crisp Players
text: Among the many changes that the Mostly Mozart Festival has instituted in recent years to shore up intrigue and innovation, few have stood out as sharply as this season’s residency by the International Contemporary Ensemble. A reliably persuasive new-music group, the ensemble opens the week with fresh pieces by Felipe Lara and Tyshawn Sorey  on Sunday, and by Maria Stankova and Nathan Davis  on Monday. On Tuesday, the ensemble celebrates the 80th birthday of the maverick composer Pauline Oliveros, collaborating with her in a range of chamber works. A final offering on Thursday pairs a premiere by George Lewis with Beethoven’s Septet in E flat.

headline: A Photographer’s ‘Tender Ardor’
text: In 1863, when Julia Margaret Cameron was 48, her daughter and son-in-law gave her a camera for Christmas. The British-born Cameron was a mother of six and religious. She was also a friend of many Victorian artists, poets and thinkers, many of whom she photographed in a dreamy, soft-focused manner that was often condemned by her contemporaries for its lack of craftsmanship. “From the first moment I handled my lens with a tender ardor,” she wrote, “and it has become to me as a living thing, with voice and memory and creative vigor.”

headline: A Classic, Outrageous Still
text: This year marks a century of ominous springtime shudders. “Le Sacre du Printemps (The Rite of Spring),” Stravinsky’s disquieting ballet about an ancient tribe’s spring sacrifice of a young woman to appease the gods, had its premiere in 1913. Many choreographers have tackled this score, among them Martha Graham, whose 1984 version is being revived by the Martha Graham Dance Company.

headline: Ford’s Big Payout on the C-Max Hybrid
text: Dominic Franchella, owner of Stamford Ford Lincoln in Connecticut, has some satisfied C-Max hybrid customers. “We haven’t had one customer complain to us about not getting the mileage,” he said in a telephone interview.

headline: Costly Rents Push Brooklynites to Queens
text: It was only a matter of time, after Bushwick was given a featured role in the HBO show “Girls,” that the young creative types who established this gritty Brooklyn neighborhood as an artists’ enclave began to be priced out.

headline: A Divide Between Two Neighborhoods
text: Bushwick and Ridgewood are close on the map, but monthly rents are a different story.

headline: Hard-Swinging Sounds, With the Help of Friends
text: Warren Wolf WOLFGANG

headline: No Reservations at the Mayor’s Table
text: Angel Pelengaris led the way to Table 14, saying it was the booth to sit in “if you want to be mayor for five minutes.”

headline: One Dip Into a 401(k) Often Leads to Another
text: Some people can’t seem to stop at just one.

headline: Brazilian Fund, Under Fire, Has a Defender
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — GP Investments, one of Latin America’s largest private equity funds, has come under fire over its executives’ compensation while its stock price languishes, but the fund is receiving some support from Wall Street.

headline: Hot Days, Cold Noodles
text: For a light but satisfying meal during the last days of summer, consider cold Asian noodles, suggests Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health. She writes:

headline: Fantasy Football: Walking Through a 12-Team Draft
text: The following 12 team, 15 round draft primer is not an all-inclusive draft guide. Rather, it offers a couple of different approaches depending on where you are drafting from. It also contains a summary of opinions I have come to form over the years, and over the course of a very active mock draft season. The rules and the level of competitiveness will vary greatly from one person’s fantasy league to the next, and ultimately you will need to form your own draft day game plan as they relate to these deciding factors.

headline: The Petermann Glacier
text: Late July and early August, 2012: NASA satellites observed a giant chunk of Greenland’s Petermann Glacier gradually break off and then drift towards the open sea.

headline: Smog Over China
text: Oct. 20, 2012: A dense smog covered most of China.

headline: Fires in Sumatra
text: June 2013: Dense clouds of smoke from fires set on the Indonesian island of Sumatra choked neighboring Singapore.

headline: Sandstorm Over the Mediterranean
text: May 29, 2013: Following the course of an immense sandstorm across the Sahara Desert in a northerly direction over the Mediterranean Sea.

headline: Blackberry Crumb Muffins
text: When there are are so many fresh summer berries available, why not fold some into your muffin batter?

headline: Muffins With Blackberries and a Buttery Crumb Topping
text: There are muffins that aspire to be healthful, filled with the likes of whole grains, wheat germ and fruit purée. Then there are rich, chocolate chip-laden muffins that are more like cupcakes in disguise.

headline: The Rupee’s Decline
text: The economies of many emerging markets are struggling, as Nathaniel Popper pointed out in The Times earlier this week. In China, for example, credit has dried up so much that all but one of the car dealers in the once booming city of Shenmu in the northwest have failed. Perhaps the country the world should be most worried about is India. The country’s currency, the rupee, fell sharply against the dollar on Friday, briefly passing 62 to the dollar; it was at 55 to the dollar as recently as May. Inflation remains high even as growth is slowing.

headline: Week in Review: Failed Trades in London Add to Inquiry in New York
text: Criminal cases against two former JPMorgan Chase traders who worked in an office building near the Thames River spotlighted federal authorities’ inquiry of bank executives on Park Avenue.

headline: Allyson Felix Tears Hamstring in 200 Meters
text: MOSCOW — On one side of the track in Luzhniki Stadium, Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce was celebrating her first major 200-meter victory with the Jamaican flag in hand and the Bob Marley song “Three Little Birds” playing over the loudspeakers.

headline: Killing of Strikers Alters South Africa Politics
text: MARIKANA, South Africa — Had the memorial held on an outcropping of rock here on Friday taken place two decades ago, the African National Congress almost certainly would have led it.

headline: Near Seat of Government, Seats of Power
text: At City Hall, the power-lunch spot that opened near you-know-where in the late Giuliani years, sometimes the challenge is keeping the planets out of one another’s orbits, said Henry Meer, the chef and owner. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg favors Table 41, a booth along the western wall — as do Raymond W. Kelly, the police commissioner, and Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the Manhattan district attorney. Representative Gregory W. Meeks typically takes Table 21, and the mayoral candidate Joseph J. Lhota’s regular spot is Table 23. Judges, lobbyists and officials have their turf. Though Mr. Meer tries to keep regulars at their regular tables, sometimes the powers’ lunch needs overlap. “In that case, I usually give the table to whoever called first,” Mr. Meer said.

headline: Libertarian Populism and Its Critics
text: Let me assume, one more time, the mantle of libertarian populism’s friendliest critic, and say something about the ongoing arguments that the concept has inspired. (The latest round-up includes Ben Domenech vs. Ezra Klein, Conn Carroll vs. Brian Beutler, Jonathan Chait vs. Will Wilkinson … and I could easily go on.) In particular, I’d like to address what seems like the core critique of the lib-pop idea, common to its left-wing, centrist and conservative critics alike, which is that it might call itself populist but it’s too, well, libertarian to ever be truly popular.

headline: G.M. Recalls 293,000 Chevrolet Cruze Models Over Braking Problem
text: Almost 293,000 Chevrolet Cruzes from the 2011-12 model years will be recalled for a braking problem, General Motors has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. In a news release Friday, the automaker said it was aware of 27 low-speed crashes related to the problem, but it was not aware of any related injuries.

headline: The Impossible Mayor of the Possible
text: The question was a trap, put to a novice politician who had only just been elected mayor and had no government experience whatsoever.

headline: Israel Keeps a Wary Eye on Turmoil in Egypt
text: JERUSALEM — Before the violence this week in Cairo, the Israeli government was quietly pleased with the overthrow of President Mohamed Morsi and the crackdown on the Muslim Brotherhood, which has always been hostile to Israel. But now the mass killings have left Israel in the uncomfortable position of being a spectator to the crisis unfolding in Egypt, though one with a huge stake in the outcome.

headline: Feeling For | Postcards With a Graphic Pop
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Trying to Make Google Glass Fashionable
text: In the 2006 movie “The Devil Wears Prada,” with a high-end fashion magazine’s office as its backdrop, there’s a memorable scene when the character Miranda Priestly, played by Meryl Streep, is picking between two belts for a photo shoot that look almost identical. As she surveys them in her hand, her assistant, Andy Sachs, played by Anne Hathaway, starts to laugh quietly.

headline: Ivete Sangalo, a Brazilian Belter, Extends Her Reach
text: If Ivete Sangalo were an American singer, rather than the most popular female vocalist in Brazil, she would undoubtedly be described as a belter. Onstage, she is bold, brassy and boisterous, part of a lineage that includes Tina Turner, Janis Joplin and Bette Midler, and on her records she has often favored songs that allow her to emote loudly and dramatically.

headline: A Marriage of Economy and Serenity
text: TESTED 2013 Lincoln MKZ Hybrid

headline: Chevrolet’s Cheap Minicar, the Spark, Is a Surprisingly Strong Seller
text: The tiny Chevrolet Spark from General Motors is about as bare bones as cars come these days, with no floor mats and one of the smallest engines of any car. But to the surprise of even G.M. itself, which has traditionally struggled to sell small cars, the Spark has become an unlikely hit as many American buyers warm to a car that is cheap to buy and to operate.

headline: Plugging an Outbreak of Leaks
text: Audis with coolant drips and Nissans that shudder at moderate speeds are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

headline: Move Over, CB Radio: Trucker Apps Are Helping to Haul the Load
text: STRASBURG, VA. — If you’re old enough to remember 1970s trucker films like “Smokey and the Bandit,” “Convoy” and “White Line Fever,” you may think of truck drivers as free-spirited individuals tethered to the world by nothing more than citizens band airwaves. That depiction was a stretch even then, but today’s truckers are often as Web-connected as the technophiles occupying the local Starbucks. Even on the loneliest stretches of the Interstates, smartphones and tablet apps provide diversions and lend a helping hand.

headline: She Brings Out His Soft Side, but It’s Bad for Business
text: In “Once Upon a Time in Mumbai Dobaara,” Shoaib (an effective Akshay Kumar) is a gangster to his core: he looks the part — sunglasses, slicked-back hair, sleek suits — and has a firm grip on Mumbai’s underworld. The character’s rise was told in the action-packed 2010 movie “Once Upon a Time in Mumbai,” but for this sequel, Milan Luthria, who directed both, wanted to show that his villain has a heart.

headline: The Bane of Four Mayors
text: “Just a few more months with the devil,” Rafael Martínez Alequin announced, standing in the middle of City Hall’s Blue Room, which was packed with journalists on Monday waiting for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to arrive.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: James Truman, a Crown Prince in a New Kingdom
text: Of all the new careers one might expect for a 55-year-old former publishing executive, part-time record producer is not the most likely.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Fox Decides Not to Produce Hillary Clinton Mini-Series
text: An outlet of Fox Entertainment said on Friday that it would not be involved with the hotly debated Hillary Rodham Clinton mini-series on NBC, after all.

headline: A Big, Blingy Indian Love Song for a Brandy-Swigging Elephant
text: In Sunday’s magazine, I write about the lives of famous elephants in the Indian state of Kerala – animals who have their own fan clubs, appear in movies and get trucked around the state for half the year to appear as the main attraction at temple festivals. One of the foremost chroniclers of Kerala’s elephant craze is a filmmaker named Sreekumar Arookutty, who was the creator, director, writer and host of a popular local TV show called “E4 Elephant.” Earlier this year, Arookutty wrote the lyrics to a pop song, “The Lord of Beauty,” in tribute to a star elephant named Thiruvambadi Shivasundar. “He is a jewel, the pearlstone of Kerala,” the song goes. “As beautiful as a poem carved in stone.” Arookutty also directed the music video below, starring Shivasundar himself, which provides about as vivid a taste of Kerala’s elephant-fan culture as could be hoped for.

headline: Friday Night Music: Carolina Chocolate Drops, Leaving Eden
text: A little plain and simple beauty to end the week:

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Egypt, Lebanon, Syria and South Africa.

headline: Veiled Group Shows Ease of Using Web for Attack Ads
text: The ad popped up on YouTube over a week ago, a slickly produced, sneering attack against Bill de Blasio, run by a mysterious group identified only by its account name, Citizen Truth.

headline: Sergeant Who Confronted Fort Hood Gunman Faces Him in Court
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — The last time Sgt. Kimberly D. Munley faced Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, they stood about eight feet apart, and each of them was holding a gun. It was shortly after 1 p.m. on Nov. 5, 2009, outside the building on the Fort Hood Army base where Major Hasan had waged a brief but deadly shooting rampage with a laser-equipped semiautomatic pistol.

headline: The Corrupt World of Then, So Similar to Now
text: “Last Tango in Berlin,” the title of Ute Lemper’s, dense, fiery new show at 54 Below, refers to the disappearance of European cabaret traditions under the relentless onslaught of pop. Berlin may be the cultural capital of Europe, observed Ms. Lemper, who was born in Germany in 1963, but today it is “almost without any memory.” Genres like the caustic, cynical cabaret of Germany’s Weimar period and the more romantic French chanson are all but forgotten.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: A Review of ‘Jobs’ and Marissa Mayer in Vogue
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Big Ticket | $12 Million for a Luxury Co-op at the Pierre Hotel
text: A luxury co-op with Central Park frontage at the Pierre Hotel, the 1930 white-glove landmark that underwent a $100 million renovation in 2005, sold for $12 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Winners of the Roth Open Swiss Teams
text: ATLANTA — One other major national championship was decided here on Sunday evening, the Roth Open Swiss Teams.

headline: A Former Madoff Penthouse Goes Back on the Market
text: It would be criminal to tarnish an elegant 87-year-old New York City penthouse with guilt by association, unfair to imply that it is haunted by the ghosts of white-collar crooks or burdened by bad karma and negative vibes. But the classically proportioned seven-room duplex at 133 East 64th Street where the serial swindler Bernard L. Madoff once lived is poised to enter the marketplace yet again. He bought it for a song in 1984 compared with what his fellow financiers were spending on tonier Park and Fifth Avenues, and had lived there until 2009, when he traded his final weeks of high-end house arrest for a 150-year prison term in bucolic North Carolina.

headline: Inside the Former Madoff Duplex
text: The three-bedroom four-and-a-half-bath penthouse is back on the market.

headline: Squeezebox and Strings as Charmers, Coaxing New Magic From Beethoven
text: Beethoven is hardly lacking for attention. So, amid many fresh programming initiatives at this summer’s Mostly Mozart festival, its “Celebrate Beethoven” project stands out as a dull idea.

headline: Plan to Ban Oil Drilling in Amazon Is Dropped
text: Six years ago, President Rafael Correa of Ecuador offered the world what he considered an enticing deal: donate $3.6 billion to a trust fund intended to protect nearly 4,000 square miles of the Amazon jungle and his country would refrain from oil drilling in the rain forest.

headline: By Design | The Kitchen Apron Gets a Stylish Upgrade
text: If you ate only at the Los Angeles restaurants whose chefs sport Hedley & Bennett aprons, you’d be eating at some of the finest places the city has to offer. Jon Shook, Vinny Dotolo and Ludo Lefebvre use them at Trois Mec, the toughest reservation in town. Michael Voltaggio places a new order every week for Ink. Nancy Silverton sells a version of the one she uses at Mozza. And Michael Cimarusti proudly sports them at Providence, where Ellen Bennett, the aprons’ creator, works two days a week. (“I shucked 85 oysters yesterday!” she says.)

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Resumes Shows After Injury
text: “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” is once again facing questions about safety.

headline: Luke Bryan, the Leading Gentleman of Country
text: The most uncomfortable Luke Bryan sounds on “Crash My Party,” his fourth album, is at the beginning of the second song. It’s called “Beer in the Headlights,” and it’s about a familiar kind of romantic infatuation. Mr. Bryan begins the ode by sketching out a magical rural night: “Honeysuckle in the air/Breeze blowing through your hair.”

headline: A Rare Auction Consignment: A Reigning Pebble Beach Winner
text: MONTEREY, Calif. – A year ago, a one-of-a-kind 1928 Mercedes-Benz 680S Torpedo Roadster pulled up on the lawn at the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance to be crowned Best of Show. This week, it’s here again, although this time it’s headed for the auction block.

headline: A Haven for Wit and Whimsy Dusts Off Its Welcome Mat
text: SHELBURNE, Vt. — Don’t get the wrong idea when you encounter Manet’s “Grand Canal, Venice” (1875) at the inaugural exhibition of the new visitors’ center at the Shelburne Museum. Don’t get the wrong idea, either, from the solemn name of the 18,000-square-foot building: the Pizzagalli Center for Art and Education. Despite signs of aesthetic ambition, increased professionalization and expanded educational goals, this quirky, astonishing institution is not jettisoning its distinctive oddities.

headline: For the Met, Opera History Lives in a Newark Parking Lot
text: NEWARK — The costumes were all wrong for “Andrea Chénier.” At the center of the action were men in white protective suits, not tailcoats and breeches, and they were aiming high-pressure hoses at pieces of the set. Not one of them sang a note.

headline: Invoking the Divine in Tiny Gestures
text: Every year, the Downtown Dance Festival devotes one of its open-air lunchtime performances solely to Indian dance. This, organized by the Indo-American Arts Council as part of its Erasing Borders festival, serves as a rich sampler of the various Indian dance forms and has become one of the highlights of New York’s dance year.

text: Discard Old Leases ‘at Your Own Risk’

headline: Talking Bloomberg
text: Notable New Yorkers weigh in on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s legacy.

headline: 401(k) Loans May Hurt Your Bottom Line
text: Taking multiple loans from a 401(k) plan will diminish the final account balance significantly.

text: Man-made perils to the universe’s garden of life are evident from space.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 16
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include graffiti in Greenpoint, Brooklyn; swimming lessons in Far Rockaway, Queens; and a protest march on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.

text: To the Editor:
