text: Jay Samuel Stowsky and David Allen Kerr were married Wednesday morning at City Hall in San Francisco. Gabriel Breitzke-Rivera, a deputy marriage commissioner, officiated.

headline: Mets’ Mejia Is Injured in Loss to Padres
text: SAN DIEGO — The Mets’ 8-2 loss to the San Diego Padres on Saturday night at Petco Park was compounded by an injury to the right-hander Jenrry Mejia, who left the game during the fourth inning while feeling discomfort in his elbow.

headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE LADY VANISHES In this “Masterpiece Mystery!” movie, based on Ethel Lina White’s 1936 novel, “The Wheel Spins,” from which Alfred Hitchcock adapted his 1938 thriller, “The Lady Vanishes,” Iris Carr (Tuppence Middleton, above, with Tom Hughes), a beautiful young socialite, is befriended on a train by an older Englishwoman named Miss Froy (Selina Cadell), who then disappears — after which Iris’s fellow passengers deny she ever existed. Only Max Hare (Mr. Hughes), the infatuated engineer, pays heed to Iris’s conviction. Is it fair to compare this film with Hitchcock’s? Mike Hale asked in The New York Times. “It doesn’t really matter, because if you’ve seen the original, it’s impossible to do otherwise,” he decided. “This new ‘Lady Vanishes,’ directed by Diarmuid Lawrence (‘South Riding’) from a screenplay by Fiona Seres, is a perfectly adequate television mystery of the week. But it forgoes the crackling pace, light touch and surprisingly sophisticated sexual banter of the original, opting for melancholy, ominousness and sentimentality.”

headline: Sotheby’s to Auction Rare Blue Diamond
text: HONG KONG — China’s economy is cooling, and Asia’s once-rosy prospects look less shiny than they did two years ago, but this has not deterred Sotheby’s from choosing Hong Kong as the place to sell a rare multimillion-dollar diamond in October.

headline: North Korea Agrees to Talk About Reunions for Families
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea on Sunday accepted a South Korean proposal to discuss the reunions of elderly relatives who had been separated from their parents, siblings and children since the Korean War six decades ago.

headline: China Answers One Question About Trial: A Date
text: HONG KONG — Bo Xilai, an ambitious and divisive Chinese politician whose downfall shook the Communist Party elite, will stand trial on Thursday on charges of corruption, taking bribes and abusing power, state-run news media announced Sunday.

headline: 42 Heavy-Metal Bands, 2,000 Fans, My Son and Me
text: When my son Dylan was 18, he asked me to accompany him on a Royal Caribbean cruise. But this wasn’t your normal cruise. This one was called 70,000 Tons of Metal, and it featured 42 heavy-metal bands and 2,000 metal fans. I did not like heavy-metal music, and I did not particularly like my son very much those days, either.

headline: Yes, We Can (Tomatoes)
text: Mark Bittman offers something different and really interesting — a qualified paean to the tomato-canning industry. As he describes it, the whole process — including, yes, the infamous square tomatoes, suitable for mechanical harvesting — produces a pretty good product, with less environmental damage and better working conditions than you might think.

headline: The Dynamo and Big Data
text: James Glanz relays skepticism about the economic impact of Big Data, with

headline: Disruptions: Texting Your Feelings, Symbol by Symbol
text: I recently had to sit my friend down for a modern-day digital intervention. It wasn’t that he was using his phone at dinner, or that he was hitting “reply all” on e-mail threads, or leaving unnecessary voice mail messages. No, this was much worse.

headline: A Stylish Tavern’s Unlikely Origins, and Location
text: Every so often, along this industrial strip of Hicks Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, you could make out a man — a tall, thin figure moving behind the fogged-up, heirloom-tomato-brimmed windows of the storefront at the corner of Degraw Street.

headline: Islamists Killed While in Custody, Egypt Confirms
text: CAIRO — The Egyptian government acknowledged that its security forces had killed 36 Islamists in its custody on Sunday, as the country’s military leaders and Islamists vowed to keep up their fight over Egypt’s future.

headline: Aug. 18: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Samsung Said to Be Preparing to Unveil Smart Watch
text: Samsung Electronics plans to introduce a wristwatch in September that can make phone calls, play video games and send e-mails, potentially beating Apple to market with a piece of technology that moves mobile communications beyond the smartphone.

headline: Pebble Beach Weekend: Ferrari 275 GTB/4 Spider Brings $27.5 Million
text: Amidst a host of other multimillion-dollar sales on the Monterey Peninsula of California this weekend, the 1967 Ferrari 275 GTB/4 N.A.R.T. Spider sold by RM Auctions for $27.5 million has become, according to RM, the second most expensive car ever to be sold at auction — and the most expensive Ferrari ever to cross the block.

headline: A Strong Start for ‘Lee Daniels’ The Butler’
text: Oprah Winfrey served up a surprise No. 1 finish for “Lee Daniels’ The Butler” at the weekend box office, while the superhero sequel “Kick-Ass 2” tripped on its cape. “The Butler” (the Weinstein Company) took in about $25 million in North American theaters, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. A biographical drama that cost roughly $30 million to make, “The Butler” was aggressively promoted by Ms. Winfrey, who plays an alcoholic wife in the film. Pent-up demand for more serious cinema also helped sales, as did enthusiastic reviews and a tempest-in-a-teapot fight over the film’s title.

headline: Stringer Gets Endorsements of Three City Newspapers
text: Three major daily newspapers in New York City made it bluntly clear this weekend whom they did not want to see as the next comptroller: Eliot Spitzer.

headline: At the Printer, Living Tissue
text: SAN DIEGO — Someday, perhaps, printers will revolutionize the world of medicine, churning out hearts, livers and other organs to ease transplantation shortages. For now, though, Darryl D’Lima would settle for a little bit of knee cartilage.

headline: Most of U.S. Is Wired, but Millions Aren’t Plugged In
text: The Obama administration has poured billions of dollars into expanding the reach of the Internet, and nearly 98 percent of American homes now have access to some form of high-speed broadband. But tens of millions of people are still on the sidelines of the digital revolution.

headline: Public Funds Take Control of Assets, Dodging Wall Street
text: Investors responsible for more than $2 trillion recently gathered at a resort in the Canadian Rockies, far from the news media and, more important, far from Wall Street.

headline: Printing Out a Biological Machine
text: URBANA-CHAMPAIGN, Ill. — Not all bioengineers who are using printers in the lab are trying to create tissues or organs. Some are intent on making biological machines.

headline: Communicating Economics
text: A somewhat belated response to Roger Farmer, who accused me of cribbing from his writings. The truth is sadder; I haven’t read any of his stuff. I’ve tried, a couple of times, but found it very hard to penetrate and gave up — and several other economists I’ve talked to had the same reaction.

headline: Firefighters’ Survivor Benefits Value Some Lives Over Others
text: DENVER — As a wilderness firefighter, Caleb Renno hiked over mountains until his heels bled, living out of tents and eating packaged food for weeks at a time in rugged corners of the burning West. He did not love the work, but like many young adults in southern Oregon, he knew he could always find steady pay fighting fires.

headline: The New Growth Fizzle
text: A sort of side-thought inspired by Brad DeLong on the end of Malthusian economics and all that, plus what looks like deja vu all over again on the payoff or lack thereof to Big Data: whatever happened to New Growth Theory?

headline: Another Gold for Bolt as World Championships End
text: MOSCOW — Usain Bolt, as is now customary in track and field, had the last word Sunday at the world championships.

headline: Britain Detains the Partner of a Reporter Tied to Leaks
text: WASHINGTON — The partner of Glenn Greenwald, the journalist for The Guardian who has been publishing information leaked by the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden, was detained for nine hours by the British authorities under a counterterrorism law while on a stop in London’s Heathrow Airport during a trip from Germany to Brazil, Mr. Greenwald said Sunday.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘The Spider’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 25. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: Selfless Star, Ultimate Sacrifice
text: CUMMING, Ga. — Before her husband’s funeral a year ago this month, Bernadine Roundfield recalled another one they had attended together. After the eulogies, on the way home, he told her, bluntly, “When I go, make sure no one tells any lies or makes me out to be something I wasn’t.”

headline: A Television Unit Flourishes in an Often Overlooked Corner of Sony
text: CULVER CITY, Calif. — Next month, the broadcast networks will introduce more than 20 new series, and four of the most ambitious will be supplied by Sony.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Aug. 19
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Postal Service Applies Old Promise to New Priority
text: THE Postal Service is identified with a promise that neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night would stay its couriers from the swift completion of their appointed rounds. But the Internet? Don’t ask.

headline: Baidu Deal May Reduce App Piracy in China
text: TOKYO — The biggest Internet takeover to date in China has already sharpened a rivalry among the country’s digital powerhouses, but the deal could also bring more order to China’s messy world of mobile apps.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Upon a Sylvan Riverside Lawn, Woeful Darkness Settles
text: GARRISON, N.Y. — Been thinking of taking early retirement? Before making that decision, you might want to hear about this guy I met up in Putnam County on the gorgeous grounds of a Hudson River mansion. He looked to be no more than, say, 50-something.

headline: Unloading the Weightiness of Brahms With a Few Flicks
text: Sprezzatura is not a term usually associated with Brahms. Coined in 16th-century Urbino by Baldassare Castiglione, the author of the Renaissance blockbuster guide to courtly manners, the Italian word denotes an elegant lightness of bearing that masks the effort behind the composure. The music of Brahms? The opposite, surely, with quill-chewing, meticulous labor audible in every earnestly created bar.

headline: This Artificial Intelligence Is Ruining My Commute
text: Machines have been proving themselves to be our enemies for years, at least in the science-fiction world. The danged things keep becoming sentient and turning against us. They do it again in “Delete,” a television movie that has its debut on Reelz on Monday night.

headline: Knocking the Crowns Off Pageant Winners
text: At the start of Francesca Harper’s “Art Prototype 2013,” a dance-theater production using beauty pageants as its point of departure, a woman slowly crossed the stage while trailing two long strips of white fabric. Another performer passed the other way, marking the stage with an X. The dancer Eriko Iisaku, her body both lissome and punctuated, dashed across and underneath the pieces of the fabric before landing on her rear; gradually, her legs splayed. Then, like much of what happened throughout this congested work, the moment was abandoned; it trailed off, leading to nowhere.

headline: Quinn’s Wife Edges Onto the Political Stage
text: Kim M. Catullo does not like giving interviews or getting behind a microphone. At political events, she tends to hover in the background, so much so that she is sometimes mistaken for a member of her wife’s security detail.

headline: Off to a Good Start
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — In today’s puzzle, constructor Jean O’Conor riffs on the many meanings of one common English word by demonstrating the myriad ways it can be used. For a single four-letter word with only three unique letters, it’s got plenty of versatility – my edition of Webster’s spouts off 51 definitions – and the six examples that Jean uses show its diverse denotations in action. After all, it’s not readily apparent that there’s a verbal link between POPPY SEEDS and WALLPAPER.

headline: Theft Charges Reverberate in Connecticut Art World
text: For 16 years, William Morrison has watched the passing parade at his airy, contemporary Morrison Gallery in Kent, in northwestern Connecticut, where luminaries like Meryl Streep, Sam Waterston, Kevin Bacon and Kate Winslet, and far-flung artists great and small live the understated good life of the Litchfield Hills.

headline: Student’s Trip Ends; A Mystery Just Begins
text: Gone Home, the first game from the Fullbright Company, is the greatest video game love story ever told and proof, in case any more were needed, that video games do not require shooting or punching or jumping or action of any kind to create gripping fiction.

headline: Ballerina Leaves Her Comfort Zone
text: BECKET, Mass. — Entering the world of modern dance, as she does in her program “Restless Creature,” Wendy Whelan exhibits the same qualities of temperament she has shown for years as a principal dancer of New York City Ballet: She’s uncompromising, generous, bold, enthusiastic, adult, at the same time decisive and investigative. Few dancers in any genre show better that a work should be a process of self-discovery.

headline: John Hollander, Poet at Ease With Intellectualism and Wit, Dies at 83
text: John Hollander, a virtuosic poet who breathed new life into traditional verse forms and whose later work achieved a visionary, mythic sweep, died on Saturday in Branford, Conn. He was 83.

headline: A Heavy-Metal Narrative That Speaks in the Many Dialects of Music
text: Phil Anselmo started his remarkable set on Friday night at Gramercy Theater by tenderizing the crowd on the subject of his new group, Philip H. Anselmo & the Illegals, bragging and downplaying, joking and turning serious. “I apologize ahead of time,” he said. His voice has lost most of its melody after three decades of nicotine and grandiose yelling, but it still works; even his apologies sound like commands.

headline: Resisting the Siren Call of the Screen
text: My house may be like your house.

headline: Manifesta Curator Named
text: Kasper Konig, a Berlin curator who has defended art against censorship by conservatives, has been named chief curator of the 10th edition of Manifesta, the roving European contemporary art biennial. This year the event is to be held in Russia for the first time, just as the country’s treatment of gay men and women is being criticized internationally. Manifesta 10 is to be held in St. Petersburg from June 28 to Oct. 31, 2014, with activities centered in the restored contemporary art wing of the State Hermitage, Russia’s most important museum, which is in the former Winter Palace of the czars. The museum will be celebrating its 250th anniversary, and Manifesta will be recognizing its 20th as a post-cold-war platform for cultural dialogue.

headline: Project in Moscow Loses Norman Foster
text: The British architect Norman Foster has resigned from a proposed expansion of the Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow. The plan was to expand and modernize the 101-year-old institution and had an estimated cost of $670 million. The project was approved by the Russian government in 2009, but it stalled over disputes between Russian officials and preservationists, according to The Art Newspaper. The architecture firm Foster & Partners released a statement last week that said Mr. Foster, above, had sent a resignation letter in June to Irina Antonova, the former director of the Pushkin. “Foster & Partners took this action because the museum, for the last three years, has not involved us in the development of the project, which was being carried out by others,” the statement said. Ms. Antonova resigned in July as museum director, a post she held for more than 50 years. She was said to have supported Mr. Foster’s involvement.

headline: Mark Itabashi Wins Fishbein Trophy in Atlanta
text: ATLANTA — The Fishbein Trophy is presented to the player who wins the most master points at the Summer North American Championships. This year’s was awarded to Mark Itabashi of Murrieta, Calif. He won two major national championships, the von Zedtwitz Life Master Pairs and the Truscott/United States Playing Card Senior Swiss Teams to finish 45.69 points head of Jacek Kalita and Michal Nowosadzki from Poland.

headline: Azarenka Upsets Williams; Nadal Tops Isner for Title
text: MASON, Ohio — Losses have been rare in this chapter of Serena Williams’s career: her established power is now paired with consistency, making her perhaps an even more reliable favorite.

headline: A Summer of Troubles Saps India’s Sense of Confidence
text: NEW DELHI — For the last 10 years, India seemed poised to take its place alongside China as one of the dominant economic and strategic powerhouses of Asia. Its economy was surging, its military was strengthening, and its leaders were striding across the world stage.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Aug. 19
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released this week includes minutes from the Federal Reserve’s meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee in July, and the National Association of Realtors sales of existing homes for July (Wednesday); the Conference Board’s index of leading indicators and the Labor Department’s initial weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and the Commerce Department’s new home sales for July (Friday).

headline: Death Row Improvises, Lacking Lethal Mix
text: The decision by the Missouri Supreme Court to allow propofol, the same powerful anesthetic that caused the death of Michael Jackson, to be used in executions — coming at a time when Texas, Ohio, Arkansas and other states are scrambling to come up with a new drug for their own lethal injections — is raising new questions about how the death penalty will be carried out.

headline: Top Presidential Candidates Barred From Election in Madagascar
text: JOHANNESBURG — A court in Madagascar has removed several prominent political leaders from a list of presidential candidates eligible to run in the country’s election, scheduled for Friday, which many in the region hope will settle the island nation’s long-running political crisis.

headline: Braced to Remake Itself, Detroit First Awaits Challenges to Bankruptcy Eligibility
text: Before Detroit can start remaking itself in bankruptcy court, there is a basic question that stands in its way: Does it even qualify?

headline: Spanish Fishermen Protest Restrictions Off Gibraltar
text: MADRID — About 40 Spanish fishing boats confronted British police vessels on Sunday in a dispute over access to the waters off Gibraltar, a British territory at the tip of the Iberian Peninsula that has long been a political sore point between Spain and Britain.

headline: Stringer’s Claim of ‘Money Laundering’ by Spitzer Starts a Legal Debate
text: Among the accusations that political candidates sling at one another during debates, “money laundering” does not usually come up.

headline: Mets Get Glimpse of Bright Future and Dim Present
text: SAN DIEGO — Matt Harvey, the Mets’ ace, and Travis d’Arnaud, the organization’s promising young catcher, played together for the first time Sunday afternoon during the Mets’ 4-3 loss to the San Diego Padres, doing their small part to stoke hope for the club’s outlook.

headline: Feminists Ask for Protection After Attack in Ukraine
text: MOSCOW — Leaders of Femen, the Ukrainian women’s rights group known for staging bare-breasted political protests, demanded government protection on Sunday after two of them and a male associate were assaulted while on vacation in the Black Sea port city of Odessa.

headline: A Call for Aid, Not Laws, to Help Women in Italy
text: ROME — Responding to the persistent problem of violence against women, Prime Minister Enrico Letta this month announced “very harsh, very tough” measures to counter domestic abuse and what he called “femicide,” the killing of women because they are women, often at the hands of current or former husbands or boyfriends.

headline: Again Away From Delaware, but Finally at Home
text: ROSEMONT, Ill. — Chicago trailed the Minnesota Lynx by 3 points late in the fourth quarter on Aug. 11. The game clock ticked under 10 seconds. Elena Delle Donne, a 6-foot-5 do-it-all rookie for the Sky, rose and fired a 3-point shot over two pairs of outstretched hands. Swish.

headline: McCain Takes His Work Home to Arizona, Promoting an Immigration Bill
text: TUCSON — For Senator John McCain, the Congressional summer recess has turned into a race against the clock, and against other Republicans. As the most senior member of the bipartisan Senate group that drafted the omnibus immigration bill pending in the House, he has spent his days prodding constituents to pressure Arizona’s Congressional delegation to support it.

headline: U.N. Team Arrives in Syria to Assess Possible Chemical Arms Use
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A United Nations team arrived in Damascus on Sunday to begin a long-awaited investigation into the alleged use of chemical weapons in the civil war in Syria.

headline: Doctors Who Profit From Radiation Prescribe It More Often, Study Finds
text: WASHINGTON — Doctors who have a financial interest in radiation treatment centers are much more likely to prescribe such treatments for patients with prostate cancer, Congressional investigators say in a new report.

headline: Second Act for the Temple of the Stars
text: LOS ANGELES — It was known as the Temple of the Stars: a soaring sanctuary capped by a 100-foot-wide Byzantine dome, built by Hollywood moguls on the eve of the Depression and splashed with the kind of pizazz one might expect at a movie palace rather than a synagogue.

headline: An Afghan Poet Shapes Metal and Hard Words
text: KHOST, Afghanistan — The poet guided a strip of sheet metal into the ancient steel clippers, cutting shimmering triangles that fell with a dull clang on the shop floor.

headline: David Howard, Revered Teacher of Dancers, Dies at 76
text: David Howard, who for nearly half a century was one of the most sought-after ballet teachers in the United States and far beyond, with a student roster that included Gelsey Kirkland, Patricia McBride and Mikhail Baryshnikov, died on Aug. 11 in Manhattan. He was 76.

headline: Al Jazeera America Promises a More Sober Look at the News
text: Fourteen hours of straight news every day. Hard-hitting documentaries. Correspondents in oft-overlooked corners of the country. And fewer commercials than any other news channel.

headline: The Core of ‘Mind and Cosmos’
text: This is a brief statement of positions defended more fully in my book “Mind and Cosmos: Why the Materialist Neo-Darwinian Conception of Nature Is Almost Certainly False,” which was published by Oxford University Press last year. Since then the book has attracted a good deal of critical attention, which is not surprising, given the entrenchment of the world view that it attacks. It seemed useful to offer a short summary of the central argument.

headline: Learn to Talk in Beggars’ Cant
text: RULERS have long kept certain powers hidden from their subjects. But this summer’s disclosures concerning the surveillance practices of the National Security Agency have made it clear that today’s freedom of expression comes at the price of a new power: the state’s ability to burrow ever deeper, by technological means, into the private language of ordinary citizens.

headline: Misrule of Law
text: XU ZHIYONG, a lawyer for the underprivileged, knew he risked his freedom by challenging the Chinese Communist Party to fulfill its vows to fight corruption and promote the rule of law.

headline: A Flawed Background-Check System
text: The Federal Trade Commission has rightly intensified scrutiny of the companies that provide the criminal background checks used by most firms and corporations to screen job applicants. In too many cases, the reports are out of date and incomplete, causing job seekers who may have been arrested but never charged — or who have had their cases expunged or even dismissed — to be unfairly locked out of the job market.

headline: Bangladesh’s Workers Deserve Better
text: Four months after a building collapse killed more than 1,100 factory workers in Bangladesh, their families are still waiting for adequate — and in some cases, any — compensation. This is a shocking lapse by Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and her government.

headline: Wanted: Another Green Mayor
text: New York has been a dirty, gritty city practically forever, but it has also had farsighted leaders who qualify as green visionaries, going back to the 19th century. They preserved valuable real estate as irreplaceable public parkland; dreamed up an astonishing system of aqueducts to carry clean mountain water, unpumped and unfiltered, to city taps; and built a walkable, ridable, electric-train metropolis generations before “smart growth” and “transit-oriented development” were buzzwords.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Graying Prisoners
text: MORE and more United States prisons resemble nursing homes with bars, where the elderly and infirm eke out shrunken lives. Prison isn’t easy for anyone, but it is especially punishing for those afflicted by the burdens of old age. Yet the old and the very old make up the fastest-growing segment of the prison population.

headline: More Friction Between Yankees and Rodriguez
text: BOSTON — Feeling betrayed and disappointed by his star player, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman sat in the visitors’ dugout at Fenway Park on Sunday, calling Alex Rodriguez a liar and saying he no longer trusted Rodriguez enough to discuss any substantive matters with him. Yet when Rodriguez is in the batter’s box, Cashman roots hard for him to succeed.

headline: Questions on the Dual Role of a Clinton Aide Persist
text: WASHINGTON — When news surfaced in May that the State Department had approved an arrangement that allowed Huma Abedin, a top adviser to Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, to take on work for private clients, officials at the department described it as nothing unusual.

headline: One Reform, Indivisible
text: Recent political reporting suggests that Republican leaders are in a state of high anxiety, trapped between an angry base that still views Obamacare as the moral equivalent of slavery and the reality that health reform is the law of the land and is going to happen.

headline: Israel Escalating Efforts to Shape Allies’ Strategy
text: JERUSALEM — Israel plans this week to intensify its diplomatic campaign urging Europe and the United States to support the military-backed government in Egypt despite its deadly crackdown on Islamist protesters, according to a senior Israeli official involved in the effort.

headline: Leaving Military Aid Intact, U.S. Takes Steps to Halt Economic Help to Egypt
text: CHILMARK, Mass. — The Obama administration has taken preliminary steps to withhold financial aid to the Egyptian government, officials said on Sunday, though it is curtailing economic assistance, not the much larger military aid on which Egypt’s generals depend.

headline: This Inning (First Pitch, Walk, Weather and Broadcast Booth) Is Brought to You by ...
text: A collection of on-air ads during one Yankees game.

headline: Fighting Crime With Pencil and Paper
text: It is one of the most recognizable tools of police investigations: the shaded and unsmiling face of a potential suspect on a flier. Yet around the nation, the police sketch can look like a dying art.

headline: Here’s the Pitch. But First, One From Our Sponsor.
text: “Phelps painted the corner,” the Yankees radio announcer said, describing a strikeout pitch. “Painting at the corners is sponsored by CertaPro Painters. Because painting is personal.”

headline: Egypt Lashes Out at Foreign News Media’s Coverage
text: CAIRO — Amid an international outcry over a bloody crackdown, the new government installed by Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi is putting concerted pressure on the only remaining news outlets in Egypt covering criticism of the violence: the foreign news media.

headline: Bare Trees Are a Lingering Sign of Hurricane Sandy’s High Toll
text: When spring came, Ike Sinesi of Mill Island, Brooklyn, noticed something strange about the old weeping cedar on his front lawn. For the first time since it was planted, the powdery blue needles had not returned. His neighbors on this outcropping of land, surrounded on three sides by inlets off Jamaica Bay, saw similar signs.

headline: Jets’ Coples Is Sidelined Indefinitely
text: The Jets lost a versatile and important piece of their defense when it was determined that outside linebacker Quinton Coples would be out indefinitely after sustaining a hairline fracture of his right ankle in Saturday night’s preseason game against Jacksonville.

headline: Pebble Beach Concours: 1934 Packard Wins Best of Show
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — A 1934 Packard 1108 Twelve Dietrich Convertible Victoria that spent much of its life in Puerto Rico — painted a garish red and orange and thrashed about as a taxi — was named Best of Show on Sunday at the Concours d’Élégance here.

headline: Leaving His Mark on the City’s Courts
text: Life was no game for Robert Garcia in early 1987. He had just been cut from Wesleyan’s basketball squad — for the third time. Come spring break, he headed home and went straight to Goat Park at Amsterdam Avenue and 99th Street, where he had always practiced and studied hoops with fierce dedication. He was not tall or fast, but he was on fire.

headline: Drug War Apparently Has Mexican President’s Attention
text: MEXICO CITY — Even before he took office in December, Mexico’s president, Enrique Peña Nieto, made clear that he saw the drug war as his predecessor’s problem: a political liability best pushed aside to make room for his sunnier plans to overhaul the economy, education and energy.

headline: Poverty Group Appoints City Official as New Chief
text: The Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty, an influential social-services organization, is reaching into the Bloomberg administration for new leadership, one week after its longtime executive director was fired amid allegations of financial misconduct.

headline: Paced by a Cool Rookie, Europe Beats the U.S. and Keeps the Solheim Cup
text: PARKER, Colo. — Before the first ball was struck in the Solheim Cup, Suzann Pettersen of Norway was asked what the Europeans could do to hand the United States its first loss on home soil.

headline: Cruz and Baas Are Injured Early, and the Giants’ Night Doesn’t Get Much Better
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Preseason N.F.L. games are for knocking the rust off and for restoring the rhythm and coordination among teammates. The Giants accomplished some of those goals in a dreary 20-12 loss to the Indianapolis Colts on Sunday at MetLife Stadium.

headline: For Apologists, a Confessional Phone Line Is Reborn
text: Late one night in the fall of 1980, Allan Bridge started illicitly slapping up eye-catching posters around TriBeCa — then a rough-edged neighborhood where artists predominated — encouraging wrongdoers to “get your misdeeds off your chest!”

headline: Penelope Casas, Spanish Food Author, Dies at 70
text: Penelope Casas, a Greek-American writer from Queens who was an authority on the foods of Spain, and helped introduce Americans in the 1980s to a continental Spanish cuisine distinctly different from its Mexican and South American counterparts, died on Aug. 11 in Manhasset, on Long Island. She was 70. The cause was complications of treatment for leukemia, said her daughter, Elisa.

headline: U.S. Workers Are Grounded by Deep Cuts
text: WASHINGTON — Geological visits to monitor volcanoes in Alaska have been scaled back. The defense secretary is traveling to Afghanistan two times a year instead of the usual four. For the first time in nearly three decades, NASA pulled out of the National Space Symposium, in Colorado Springs, even though representatives from France, Germany and China all made the trip.

headline: War on the Core
text: I respect, really I do, the efforts by political scientists and pundits to make sense of the current Republican Party. There is intellectual virtue in the search for historical antecedents and philosophical underpinnings.

headline: Not Really Made in China (or the United States)
text: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: Tested Recipes for Kitchen Safety
text: Today’s kitchens easily supplant the bathroom as the home’s most dangerous room. While scalds and falls on tile can inflict serious harm in the bathroom, modern kitchen appliances and gadgets offer many more opportunities for injury. Even a seemingly simple kitchen task can result in a devastating injury.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 5:10 P.M. (MoreMax) JANE EYRE (2011) Mia Wasikowska, above, portrays Charlotte Brontë’s beleaguered governess, in flight from her employer and soul mate, Edward Rochester (Michael Fassbender), in this adaptation of the novel, set at Thornfield Hall on the misty moors of England. Jamie Bell is St. John Rivers, the clergyman who helps nurse Jane back to health; Judi Dench, the gossipy housekeeper; Sally Hawkins, the nasty aunt; and Imogen Poots, the rich girl who almost derails Jane’s chances at love. “This ‘Jane Eyre,’ energetically directed by Cary Joji Fukunaga (‘Sin Nombre’) from a smart, trim script by Moira Buffini (‘Tamara Drewe’), is a splendid example of how to tackle the daunting duty of turning a beloved work of classic literature into a movie,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Neither a radical updating nor a stiff exercise in middlebrow cultural respectability, Mr. Fukunaga’s film tells its venerable tale with lively vigor and an astute sense of emotional detail.”

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 19
text: “A poet’s job is not to write about love. A poet’s job is not to write about flowers. A poet must write about the plight and pain of the people.”

text: NATIONAL

headline: Hit by Pitch, Rodriguez Recovers, as Do Yanks
text: BOSTON — Alex Rodriguez has been at odds with Major League Baseball and the Yankees’ front office for weeks, but until Sunday night his battles were waged strictly off the field. Then came Ryan Dempster, who injected himself into the narrative with a 92-mile-per-hour fastball to Rodriguez’s rib cage.

headline: To Cover New York, Zillow Buys a Rival Site
text: It is the parlor game that has long been played in Manhattan’s upper social circles: guessing how much so-and-so paid for their apartment, and how nice it is.

headline: Pistorius Is Indicted on Murder Charge
text: JOHANNESBURG — In a case that has transfixed many in the sporting world and beyond, Oscar Pistorius, the double amputee who became an international track star, was indicted Monday in a South African court on a charge of premeditated murder in the shooting death of his girlfriend.

headline: Egypt in Tumult as Court Orders Mubarak Freed
text: CAIRO — A court on Monday ordered the release of former President Hosni Mubarak, and for the first time it was conceivable he might go free — a measure of how far the tumult now shaking Egypt has rolled back the sweeping changes and soaring hopes that followed his exit two and a half years ago.

headline: Train Hits Hindu Pilgrims in Eastern India, Killing Dozens
text: NEW DELHI — An express train plowed into a crowd of Hindu pilgrims who were crossing the tracks at a remote station in eastern India on Monday, killing dozens of people and leaving a scene of carnage.

headline: An Instagram Shootout
text: Imagine being in Springfield, Mass., in 1891, when James Naismith nailed a peach basket to an overhang in the gym and encouraged his students to throw a ball into it. You couldn’t have known how central to the American experience basketball would become — or how much money it would generate — but 60 years later you would have had an amazing story to tell your grandchildren.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Out of the Trash Can and Into the Fuel Tank

headline: Atlas Copco of Sweden to Buy Edwards Group
text: LONDON – The Swedish engineering company Atlas Copco agreed on Monday to buy the British industrial company Edwards Group for up to $1.2 billion.

headline: As Divers Find Sixth Body, Mumbai Firefighters Recall a Burning Waterfront
text: MUMBAI— A little after midnight Tuesday, a loud explosion woke Dharmendra Kumar Jaiswal, the manager of a public toilet across the street from Mumbai’s navy yard.

headline: New York Today: Cucumber Time
text: In the Netherlands, journalists speak of a stretch of summer they call “cucumber time,” when newsmakers are out of town and the papers put silly stories on the front page.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Peter Maass on How He Got the Very Secret Laura Poitras to Open Up
text: Peter Maass, a contributor to the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story on Laura Poitras and Glenn Greenwald, the two journalists to whom Edward Snowden leaked material concerning N.S.A. surveillance programs. Maass is the author of several books, most recently “Crude World: The Violent Twilight of Oil,’’ and is working on a new book about surveillance and privacy.

headline: Daily Report: ‘Digital Inequality’ Holds Back Millions in U.S.
text: The Obama administration has poured billions of dollars into expanding the reach of the Internet, and nearly 98 percent of American homes now have access to some form of high-speed broadband. But tens of millions of people are still on the sidelines of the digital revolution, Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: When You Promote Someone and It Doesn’t Work Out

text: Federal authorities have opened a bribery investigation into whether JPMorgan Chase hired the children of Chinese officials to help the bank win business, Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Ben Protess and David Barboza report in DealBook.

headline: European Commission Steps Into Dispute on Gibraltar
text: MADRID — The European Commission on Monday stepped into a dispute between Britain and Spain over Gibraltar, the British territory at the tip of the Iberian Peninsula, saying that it would soon send inspectors there and warning Madrid not to raise tensions further by charging people for crossing into the territory.

headline: CVC Capital Buys Online Payment Company

Bradley Manning.

headline: Statoil Sells North Sea Assets to Austrian Rival

headline: This Accursed Month

headline: A Salmonella Warning for Vegetarians

headline: Sochi’s Old Believers’ Cemetery, Then and Now

headline: How Judge’s Ruling Ends Legal Threat to Dell Buyout
