text: New works by Joel and Ethan Coen, Hayao Miyazaki, Richard Curtis, J. C. Chandor and James Franco are among the features that will be presented in the main slate of the New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Monday. That roster includes “Inside Llewyn Davis,” the Coen brothers’ look at a fictional folk singer in 1960s New York; “The Wind Rises,” the first animated feature directed by Mr. Miyazaki in five years; “About Time,” a romantic comedy that Mr. Curtis (“Four Weddings and a Funeral”) says will be his swan song; “All Is Lost,” Mr. Chandor’s film starring Robert Redford as a yachtsman adrift in the Indian Ocean; and “Child of God,” Mr. Franco’s adaptation of the Cormac McCarthy novel.

headline: Fast Start for Altidore in Sunderland Loss
text: Chances. Jozy Altidore and Sunderland had several; Fulham had one Saturday. Guess who won.

headline: 'Dignity'
text: A new ad from the de Blasio campaign looks at the candidate's position on stop and frisk.

headline: Aftermath of Indian Train Accident
text: Video of the burning Rajya Rani Express train, which was set on fire by a mob after running over a group of Hindu pilgrims.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
text: The eagerly-anticipated taste test of in-vitro meat (whose secret ingredient is unborn cow blood) met with mixed reviews.

headline: Target Practice With Mr. Lincoln
text: The old saying “You can take the boy out of the country…” was well suited to Abraham Lincoln. His log cabin “rail splitter” provenance is well known, and it helped make him hugely popular with average voters hungry for a new political hero. Despite his lack of family pedigree, fortune or schooling, Lincoln made a career of being underestimated, overcompensating with a brilliant, active intellect. The farmboy turned president especially loved innovations and inventions. He is the only American president to win a patent – No. 6,469, issued in May 1849 for a “Method of Buoying Vessels Over Shoals.”

headline: Getting Inside an Elephant’s Head
text: An animal behavior specialist turns to middle-school students to help unlock the inner workings of the elephant mind.

headline: Albert Murray, Scholar Who Saw a Multicolored American Culture, Dies at 97
text: Albert Murray, an essayist, critic and novelist who influenced the national discussion about race by challenging black separatism, insisting that the black experience was essential to American culture and inextricably tied to it, died on Sunday at his home in Harlem. He was 97.

headline: Children Lost in War Zones and Disasters Find Their Families With an App
text: Entrepreneurs often talk about the “pain points” their new app or service will ease, but as it has been repeatedly pointed out, the problems they solve are more often than not the problems of affluent and hyper-connected 20-somethings in cities with great cell service and ample Wi-Fi.

headline: Beatles Tribute Will End Broadway Run Months Early
text: The insatiable appetite for all things Beatles-related has driven up prices for memorabilia, kept bookshelves well-stocked and kept the group’s record label busy with compilations, reissues and remastered versions of classic discs and films. But the appetite for Beatles tribute shows on Broadway is not so strong, apparently.

headline: A Loyalty Program Offers Spas and Meals
text: Hotel loyalty programs typically reward regular customers with upgrades and free nights. Now the new iPrefer program from the Preferred Hotel Group adds a range of hotel amenities and services into the mix, including spa treatments, cocktails and meals.

headline: Joan Baez, Jack White and Marcus Mumford to Headline ‘Inside Llewyn Davis’ Concert
text: Joan Baez, Jack White, Marcus Mumford and the Avett Brothers are among the performers who will take part in a benefit concert at Town Hall in September celebrating the folk music of the 1960s and promoting the soundtrack for the Joel and Ethan Coen movie “Inside Llewyn Davis,” organizers announced on Monday.

headline: Pebble Beach Weekend: Cadillac Reveals Elmiraj Concept
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — Cadillac’s persistent threats to re-establish its premier status among luxury automakers became more serious Thursday night with the unveiling of the dreamy Elmiraj, a concept coupe that suggests that the General Motors luxury division has a clear and confident view of the future.

headline: The Ad Campaign: De Blasio Speaks Against Stop-and-Frisk Tactics
text: Bill de Blasio, the city’s public advocate and a Democratic candidate for mayor, is running his second television commercial of the campaign. Titled “Dignity,” this 30-second ad will appear on network and cable channels across New York City starting Monday.

headline: End of the Options Backdating Era
text: Before the clamor about the lack of prosecutions from the financial crisis and the current crackdown on insider trading, the practice of backdating stock options came to light seven years ago and prompted a flurry of prosecutions. The practice is now long forgotten, but it looks as if the last of those cases has finally concluded, and as the Grateful Dead put it so well, “What a long, strange trip it’s been.”

headline: Anna Karenina and the Business Cycle
text: Antonio Fatas and Ilan Mihov have a new paper in which they propose rethinking the way we classify business cycles. I’m still trying to decide what I think of their methodology, and I’m troubled by their dates – for example, I don’t believe that the U.S. economy was operating at capacity in late 1992. But I’m very much in sympathy with their underlying view about the asymmetry between booms and busts; the question is why, exactly, it feels right.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Brian Bennett joined PPC Associates, San Mateo, Calif., in a new post, vice president for sales and customer development. He had most recently been vice president for channels and partners at Conductor, New York.

headline: Don’t Write What You Know
text: In another installment in which we ask writers to reflect on their own work, we had B.C. Edwards, author of this past Sunday’s Lives essay, share with us the most helpful piece of writing advice he ever received.

headline: Keynes, Kalecki, Konczal, etc.
text: John Quiggin has an interesting take on some of what two modern Ks — me and Mike Konczal — have been saying about two illustrious former Ks — Keynes and Kalecki. Interesting comment thread too — if you’re not reading Crooked Timber, you’re missing out.

headline: Justin Bieber and Michael Jackson Joined, Briefly, in Song
text: Justin Bieber and Michael Jackson were united in song over the weekend when a recording of Mr. Bieber singing along with vocals previously recorded by Mr. Jackson surfaced online, provoking a hailstorm of news reports and stoking a great deal of fan interest on social media. The track, “Slave 2 the Rhythm,” also was played on British radio, The Guardian reported.

headline: ‘Mixed Kids Are Always So Beautiful’
text: Like many other people of color, I am no stranger to awkward conversations about race. Strangers have complimented my English, remarked on how tall I am “for an Asian” and — more times than I can count — asked where I am really from. Since becoming a parent five years ago, I’ve had to learn to field a whole new set of questions and comments regarding my multiracial children.

headline: Moody’s U-Turn on Hybrid Bonds
text: Moody’s is exposing the shaky foundations underpinning the hottest product in European corporate finance.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Amy Schumer and Aerin Lauder
text: Amy Schumer (left), star of the unfiltered sketch series “Inside Amy Schumer,” and Aerin Lauder, the Estée Lauder scion behind the luxury lifestyle brand Aerin, test out earring cuffs, sex on TV, a snood and more.

headline: The Beauty of Limits
text: How often do we hear ourselves saying we want more? More freedom, more money, more time. More seems as if it would always be great, until we get it. Then we’re faced with a new set of problems that comes with having more.

headline: This Pet Food Critic Is as Catty as They Come
text: The menagerie of advertising pitchcharacters and spokesbeasts is about to get a new member as a maker of pricey pet foods introduces a campaign with a furry know-it-all as the star.

headline: Why Was Glenn Greenwald’s Partner Detained?
text: Britain’s Labour Party has called for an urgent investigation into whether security officials at Heathrow Airport abused the British Terrorism Act in detaining the partner of Glenn Greenwald, the journalist who has been publishing most of the documents leaked by Edward Snowden.

headline: Banks Are Falling Short in Planning for the Worst, Fed Says
text: Most large banks appear to have been sailing through the annual “health checkups” they have had to undergo since the financial crisis.

headline: Gulf Spill Sampling Questioned
text: An analysis of water, sediment and seafood samples taken in 2010 during and after the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico has found higher contamination levels in some cases than previous studies by federal agencies did, casting doubt on some of the earlier sampling methods.

headline: Tyne Daly to Star in New Terrence McNally Play on Broadway
text: The Tony and Emmy Award-winning actress Tyne Daly (“Gypsy”) will return to Broadway in the spring of 2014 to star in “Mothers and Sons,” a new play by the Tony Award-winning playwright Terrence McNally (“Love! Valour! Compassion!”). Sheryl Kaller, who in June directed the show’s premiere at the Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope, Pa., will reprise her duties for Broadway. Additional casting, run dates and a theater are to be announced.

headline: Prosecutors Are Contemplating More Arrests in $80 Million Art Fraud Case
text: More arrests are expected in the investigation into one of the most audacious art frauds in recent memory, a federal prosecutor handling the case against an obscure art dealer charged in the case told a judge on Monday. The prosecutor and the dealer’s lawyer also said they expected the case to be resolved soon.

headline: Weekly News Quiz  | Aug. 13 – 19, 2013
text: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events that made news this week.

headline: Another Shake-Up at NPR as Chief Steps Down
text: NPR, which has suffered a succession of leadership changes over the better part of a decade, needs a new chief executive again.

headline: MSNBC Brings ‘The Ed Show’ Back to Weekday Lineup
text: After a slide in its prime-time ratings in recent months, MSNBC made a move on Monday to shore up the hours leading into prime time. The network is bringing back Ed Schultz, once its 8 p.m. anchor, to take over the 5 p.m. weekday slot now occupied by “Hardball.”

headline: The Wild Past of Domestic Cats
text: Q. What do scientists think is the ancestry of domestic cats?

headline: Chris Brown Cancels Concerts After Probation Ruling
text: The singer Chris Brown has canceled four scheduled appearances in Canada, the CBC reported. Mr. Brown was to be the headliner at the Energy Rush festival, with stops in Halifax, Toronto, Saint John and Winnipeg. In a statement, Stephen Tobin, owner of Drop Entertainment Group, which is producing the events, said the decision was made “in light of the performer’s recent personal and health-related issues.”

headline: Climate Panel Cites Near Certainty on Warming
text: An international panel of scientists has found with near certainty that human activity is the cause of most of the temperature increases of recent decades, and warns that sea levels could conceivably rise by more than three feet by the end of the century if emissions continue at a runaway pace.

headline: Dressing Up the Loaner Jacket
text: It was a humid day, but every man seated in the Grill Room of the Four Seasons was wearing a jacket.

headline: Comptroller Race Leaves Paterson Tongue-Tied
text: Former Gov. David A. Paterson was, abnormally, at a loss for words.

headline: Christy Turlington Burns and Citizens of Humanity Promote Maternal Health
text: The latest addition to “Just Like You,” a video series from the socially conscious denim brand Citizens of Humanity that highlights influential people doing inspirational things, is a two-minute spot by Christy Turlington Burns about her three-year-old women’s health nonprofit Every Mother Counts. The goal of the organization is to help “people understand that pregnancy and childbirth, even though it’s a joyous experience for so many women, really is a risky endeavor for millions of other women,” according to Erin Thornton, its executive director, who happens to be expecting right now herself. “To this day, hundreds of thousands of women will die in pregnancy and childbirth, but 90 percent of those could be prevented just with basic, simple access to health care.”

headline: Rio de Janeiro Makes Woody Allen an Offer
text: Apparently Rio de Janeiro is not satisfied with being chosen as the site of the 2016 Summer Olympics and the host of the championship game of next year’s World Cup of soccer. Now Brazil’s most effervescent city also wants Woody Allen to make a movie there.

headline: 21st Century Birding
text: Andrew Farnsworth, the project leader of BirdCast, discusses new methods to aggregate data from birders with the help of modern technology.

headline: Business Meetings Move Poolside (Don’t Overdress)
text: The contract negotiations were progressing well until the woman in the tiny bikini interrupted to ask Mitchell Stevenson and his client if they wanted drinks.

headline: Crowdsourcing, for the Birds
text: HELENA, Mont. — On a warm morning not long ago on the shore of a small prairie lake outside this state capital, Bob Martinka trained his spotting scope on a towering cottonwood tree heavy with blue heron nests. He counted a dozen of the tall, graceful birds and got out his smartphone, not to make a call but to type the number of birds and the species into an app that sent the information to researchers in New York.

headline: Birding as Big Data, Inkjet Cartilage, Our Chemical Lives
text: A Web site called eBird pulls together hundreds of thousands of birders’ observations from around the globe; making clumps of human cells using a desktop printer; we debut a new column called “Poison Pen.”

headline: China Takes Aim at Western Ideas
text: HONG KONG — Communist Party cadres have filled meeting halls around China to hear a somber, secretive warning issued by senior leaders. Power could escape their grip, they have been told, unless the party eradicates seven subversive currents coursing through Chinese society.

headline: Street Style: Summer White
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Aug. 12.

headline: Detroit Institute of Arts Won’t File Objection in City’s Bankruptcy Proceeding
text: The Detroit Institute of Arts, whose world-class art collection has become a potential target for the city’s creditors in Detroit’s federal bankruptcy case, announced on Monday that it would not file an objection in court to the city’s eligibility for relief under Chapter 9. Monday was the deadline for objections to the city seeking bankruptcy protection.

headline: Being Printed, Living Tissue
text: At labs around the world, researchers have been experimenting with bioprinting, but there are many formidable obstacles to overcome.

headline: A Trophy Owner Also Familiar With Turmoil
text: Jeff Bezos’s purchase of The Washington Post raises the possibility that he acquired the paper as a trophy to celebrate his success as the founder and chief executive of Amazon.com. The acquisition comes after the purchase of The Boston Globe by John W. Henry, the owner of the Boston Red Sox and a trading firm billionaire. The purchases are part of a broader trend toward private ownership of media companies.

headline: Software That Exposes Faked Photos
text: Using algorithms designed to sniff out suspicious shadows, computer scientists from Dartmouth and the University of California, Berkeley, say they have developed software that can reliably detect fake or altered photos.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘The Unfortunates’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 25. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: Indoor Tanning Remains Popular, Despite Risks
text: Despite warnings about skin cancer, about a third of the young and adult white women in a new study said they used tanning beds, and many were using them frequently. Tanning beds are widely believed to have played a large role in the increasing rates of skin cancer in recent decades. The most serious type, melanoma, has risen sharply among young white women in particular.

headline: Egyptians Share Gruesome Images of Dead Prisoners and Soldiers
text: Last Updated, 5:38 p.m. | As our colleagues David Kirkpatrick and Rod Nordland report from Cairo, Egypt has seen two grisly mass killings in the last 24 hours. The government has acknowledged killing 36 Islamist prisoners in its custody under circumstances that remain unclear, and an attack by suspected militants in a remote corner of the Sinai peninsula left at least 24 police officers dead and 3 injured.

headline: A Dry Pipeline for Psychiatric Drugs
text: Fully 1 in 5 Americans take at least one psychiatric medication. Yet when it comes to mental health, we are facing a crisis in drug innovation.

headline: At Home at Animal Farm: An Orwell Collection
text: In a life that was relatively brief but exceedingly active, George Orwell was, among other things, a police officer in Burma, a dishwasher in France, a tramp in England, a combatant in Spain, a war correspondent in Germany and a farmer in the Hebrides. Like many people of his era — he was born in 1903 and died in 1950 — he was also a prolific letter writer, and a particularly captivating and thoughtful one at that, thanks partly to the wealth of experience he had acquired.

headline: Only Essential Travelers Remain, Warily, in Egypt
text: THEY’VE been through the drill there before, but global security and medical response companies say that deteriorating security conditions throughout Egypt have reduced the number of foreign business travelers there to workers who are deemed necessary.

headline: Pill Can Prevent Fatal TB in H.I.V. Patients
text: An inexpensive daily pill can often fend off a lethal bout of tuberculosis in people with H.I.V., according to a large new study.

headline: European Union Sets Emergency Session on Suspending Aid to Egypt
text: LONDON — European Union foreign ministers will meet in an emergency session on Wednesday to discuss suspending aid to Egypt, but the continuing military crackdown there has been a devastating blow to European efforts to negotiate a political solution and fill a vacuum left by Washington.

headline: Progress in Quest for a Reusable Rocket, and Teleporting Data
text: Our theme this week is things that move in unexpected ways. In Texas, a rocket flew 800 feet in the air, then traveled sideways for 300 feet before returning to Earth. Elsewhere, two teams of researchers devised a method for teleporting small bits of information. And a wounded $600 million telescope is like a shopping cart with a broken wheel, says NASA. Onward and upward.

headline: G.O.P. Purity Control
text: After losing the 2012 election the G.O.P. engaged in a bit of soul-searching, and talked publicly about changing their image, if not their policies. That phase is definitively over. The Republicans are back to denouncing every utterance that strays from an absolutely rigid right-wing orthodoxy, and even ones that really don’t.

headline: Hagel on Egypt at the Pentagon
text: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel speaks about the United States’ relationship with Egypt after days of intense violence there.

headline: At Sentencing Hearing, Lawyers for Manning Urge Leniency
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — Pfc. Bradley Manning’s defense lawyers on Monday made a last-minute personal plea to the military judge hearing his court-martial, asking her to be lenient in sentencing and to allow Private Manning a chance to rehabilitate himself. A prosecutor in the case urged a 60-year sentence for disclosing hundreds of thousands of documents to WikiLeaks.

headline: Pregnant, and Disputing the Doctor
text: During her pregnancy, Emily Oster didn’t appreciate her doctor’s habit of issuing blanket rules: Don’t gain more than 35 pounds. No need to discuss amniocentesis — you’re not 35. No eating in the delivery room.

headline: Beers Implicated in Emergency Room Visits
text: Nationwide, roughly a third of all visits to emergency rooms for injuries are alcohol related. Now a new study suggests that certain beverages may be more likely to be involved than others.

headline: College Prep, This Time for Health
text: To me, the strangest thing about my son’s college health forms was that they did not require my signature.

headline: Simon & Schuster and Barnes & Noble Reach a Deal
text: After a dispute over terms that stretched for most of the year, Simon & Schuster and Barnes & Noble said in a joint statement on Monday that they had “resolved their outstanding business issues.” Both parties “look forward to promoting great books by Simon & Schuster authors,” they said.

headline: Petersen Automotive Museum Announces Exterior Redesign
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. – Not long after it began liquidating nearly a third of the 400 cars in its collection, the Petersen Automotive Museum in Los Angeles announced a major exterior redesign of the museum Sunday at a news conference held here at the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance.

headline: Thompson Tries to Turn Caribbean Ties Into Votes
text: A steel drum band welcoming the guest of honor? Check. The flags of Grenada, Barbados, Trinidad and Tobago, and other Caribbean island nations adorning the mirrored walls? Check.

headline: 4 Officials Convicted of Negligence Over Russia Flooding
text: MOSCOW — A court in southern Russia convicted four local officials of criminal negligence on Monday for failing to alert residents to flash flooding in the city of Krymsk last summer that killed more than 170 people. The verdict came as Russia was coping with disastrous flooding again, this time in the country’s Far East.

headline: Listen Up | All Is Not Lost for the Civil Wars
text: The Civil Wars’ self-titled sophomore album, which was No. 1 on the Billboard 200 chart last week, tells the story of a duo in turmoil. Recorded earlier this year amid building tension between the bandmates Joy Williams and John Paul White (they abruptly halted a European tour last November because of “internal discord and irreconcilable differences of ambition”), the album is rife with allusions to heartache and regret, providing subtext for the two singer-songwriters’ own conflict.

headline: Harley-Davidson Unveils Project Rushmore Bikes
text: Harley-Davidson unveiled eight new 2014 motorcycles on Monday that were developed under Project Rushmore, an initiative to bring a new level of sophistication to the brand’s biggest motorcycles.

headline: Part Gel, Part Muscle
text: Researchers at the University of Illinois have created tiny biological machines called "biobots" using heart cells from a rat and gel, merged by a 3-D printer.

headline: In Performance: ‘Soul Doctor’
text: Eric Anderson and Amber Iman sing the number “Always With You” from the new Broadway musical about the life of Shlomo Carlebach, the folk-singing rabbi. The show is at the Circle in the Square.

headline: The Sources of Christie’s Campaign Cash
text: Jonathan Martin’s story about Gov. Chris Christie’s re-election efforts noted that more than a third of the Christie campaign’s $8.3 million intake has come from outside New Jersey. But where are those out-of-state donors from, and how much have they given?

headline: Falcone to Admit to Wrongdoing as S.E.C. Takes a Harder Line
text: Wall Street’s regulator sent a message on Monday that it was now taking a more aggressive stance on securities settlements as it extracted its first admission of wrongdoing under a new policy.

headline: 160-Million-Year-Old Fossil of an Omnivore
text: Researchers have discovered a 160-million-year-old fossil of a fast-running, agile omnivore that resembled the modern-day African dormouse.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Logano Wins Michigan 400; Former BMW and Fiat Executive Is Killed in Vintage Bike Race
text: Joey Logano took the lead with three laps remaining Sunday, holding off Kevin Harvick to win the 400-mile Nascar Sprint Cup event at Michigan International Speedway.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, India, the Philippines and Egypt.

headline: The Bulls of the Camargue
text: These bovines, raised only in Southern France, are a delicacy in the restaurants of the region.

headline: In Southern France, the Braising of the Bulls
text: ARLES, France — I was finishing the first course at the one-star Michelin restaurant La Chassagnette when Armand Arnal, the chef and owner, rushed into the dining room and ordered me to follow him. He led me out the door and into his five-acre fruit, vegetable and herb garden.

headline: Samsung Offers Up Another Jumbo Phone
text: Samsung Electronics on Monday introduced a mobile device in the United States with a 6.3-inch screen — large enough to blur the lines between a tablet and smartphone. It’s another example of how the South Korean manufacturer is willing to make just about anything in any size to see what sticks with consumers.

headline: Fitting More on a DVD
text: Fitting More

headline: Travel Is Great, but There’s No Place Like Home
text: AFTER I finished interviewing roughly 200 women and men about their successes, failures and regrets for a book I was writing, the one thing I repeatedly heard was that most people wished they had traveled more.

headline: A Newcomer Asks Questions and Sketches Some Fresh Answers
text: In “The Impulse Wants Company,” a new ballet by Troy Schumacher, the young dancer Harrison Coll, in profile, steps into arabesque. One arm stretches forward into space, one leg continues the line behind him — whereupon first his colleague Kaitlyn Gilliland, tall and mature, goes to support him, keeping him in that position. Next, other companions cluster around, partnering him, sharing and amplifying the gesture. This image coalesces before our eyes like a rapid coral formation. It’s a collective moment, and the company that performs it is called BalletCollective.

headline: Oversight Board Faults Broker-Dealer Audits
text: Auditors performed complete and correct audits of at least three brokerage firms last year, the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board said Monday.

headline: The Results of the Baby-Llama Naming Contest
text: When you’ve raised as many llamas as Richard Snyder has — hundreds, over several decades — naming the new babies can be a chore. This year Mr. Snyder, who was featured in a recent article about llama enthusiasts, invited Times readers to help name the three crias, or baby llamas, born on his farm in Milford, Pa., in May. There were two males and a female, and their parents’ names were given as inspiration.

headline: In Rome, a Melodic Nero Burns With Love
text: It did not take long for the medium of opera, as it coalesced in Italy in the first half of the 17th century, to discover the heady combination of glorious music put to the service of venality and vice. Monteverdi, a founding father, certainly had it down by the time of his final opera, “L’Incoronazione di Poppea,” which appeared in Venice in 1643.

headline: Our Egyptian Unrealpolitik
text: In a column on Egypt written while Hosni Mubarak’s regime was teetering — that is, two and a half years and an eternity ago — I closed with the following observation about ideology and foreign policy:

headline: Former C.E.O. of Willis Group Joins K.K.R. as Senior Adviser
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Monday that it had hired a former chairman and chief executive of the Willis Group as a senior adviser, adding another veteran corporate boss to its roster of outside experts.

headline: Still Tough Mothers, if a Bit Warmer
text: LENOX, Mass. — Though they’re marginal improvements on Mrs. Bates, the lady who sent little Norman around the bend in “Psycho,” these are not mothers you could bring anyone home to meet. One is a conniving, endlessly itinerant businesswoman so hard-bitten that she’ll haggle over the price of her child’s life.

headline: A Surplus of Good TV? Try Depression Economics
text: Eighty years ago, President Franklin D. Roosevelt taught us what to do when confronted by a surplus of something: Pay people not to make any more of it. And what we have a surplus of right now is good television.

headline: In Fashion | Candylike Pastel Coats to Brighten Up Fall
text: Fall’s sugary pastels — lavender, pistachio, pale rose, butter cream — are a romantic respite from so much hard-working black and white.

headline: Rome’s Start to Architectural Hubris
text: Granted that Rome was not built in a day, the unresolved question among scholars has been just how long did it take. How early, before Julius Caesar came, saw and conquered, did Romans begin adopting a monumental architecture reflecting the grandeur of their ambitions?

headline: Oklahoma Judge Blocks Law Limiting Morning-After Birth Control
text: A judge in Oklahoma on Monday blocked an attempt by the state’s Legislature to restrict access to morning-after birth control pills.

headline: Stravinsky’s Many Rites of Passage Are Distilled
text: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — While Igor Stravinsky successfully cultivated the air of a rootless cosmopolitan during his long stretch as the 20th century’s most renowned composer, modern scholarship has firmly established his links to a broader tradition of Russian music and the debt many of his works owe to his culture and forebears. But with that facet of his multifarious career having been summarily addressed during the first weekend of this year’s Bard Music Festival, there was plenty more to cover during three more jam-packed days and nights.

headline: Even Ocean Dwellers Decorate for Company
text: For years, scientists were baffled by large circular patterns on the ocean floor. These “crop circles” of the ocean floor are created by male puffer fish in order to attract females.

headline: Pebble Beach Weekend: Spyker Reveals B6 Venator Spyder
text: CARMEL VALLEY, Calif. — The sparkling sunshine and mild breezes demanded an open-top car at Pebble Beach this weekend. Spyker, the tiny Dutch automaker, obliged on Friday by introducing the B6 Venator Spyder at the 2013 Quail Motorsports Gathering.

headline: A Daughter’s Visit Turns Into a Family Stress Test
text: “Old Cats” takes place almost entirely in an apartment in Santiago, Chile, occupied by Isadora (Bélgica Castro); her second husband, Enrique (Alejandro Sieveking); and the felines of the title, a pair of roly-poly tabbies described by Isadora as “the kings of the house.” The enclosed space and the age of the couple — as well as Isadora’s increasingly frequent lapses of lucidity — may remind you, at first, of “Amour,” Michael Haneke’s unsparing end-of-life excursion. But “Old Cats,” written and directed by Sebastián Silva and Pedro Peirano (originally released in Chile in 2010, long before “Amour”), is less concerned with the austere reality of death than with the stress and mess of living.

headline: Where Words Mean as Much as Objects
text: Four years ago, the American Museum of Natural History agreed to return to the Apaches 77 objects from its collection, including headwear, feathers, bows and arrows, medicine rings and satchels containing crystals and charms.

headline: Christie Signs Bill Outlawing a Gay ‘Cure’
text: BELLEVILLE, N.J. — Gov. Chris Christie signed a bill Monday outlawing therapy that aims to convert gay children to heterosexuals, making New Jersey the second state to ban the controversial practice.

headline: Superchunk and Tedeschi Trucks Band Release Albums
text: SUPERCHUNK

headline: Petition Wants Met Gala Dedicated to Gay Rights
text: The furor over Russia’s new law placing restrictions on the discussion of homosexuality has spread to the world of classical music, with some opera fans calling on the Metropolitan Opera to dedicate its opening-night gala performance of Tchaikovsky’s “Eugene Onegin” to the support of gay people.

headline: Pebble Beach Weekend: Galpin Unveils 1,024-Horsepower Ford GTR1
text: CARMEL VALLEY, Calif. — Road-testing began Sunday for the Galpin Ford GTR1 – a modern-day interpretation of the classic Ford GT40 – that was revealed on Friday at the Quail Motorsports Gathering.

headline: Mets Give Rookie Catcher an Extended Stay
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Shortly after learning the Mets planned to keep him for the rest of the season, the rookie catcher Travis d’Arnaud returned to his locker and found the veteran reliever LaTroy Hawkins standing in front of it talking to a reporter. Protocol and humility are vital for someone with only three days in the major leagues, so d’Arnaud, 24, asked Hawkins if he could slip by, careful not to offend his 40-year-old teammate.

headline: Web Site Down? How Dare You!
text: SEATTLE — On occasion, I visit a small store in my neighborhood only to find a sign saying the store is closed for an hour or so. It’s mildly irritating, but it has never occurred to me that those moments are worth freaking out over.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Zuckerberg’s Facebook Page Hacked and McAfee’s Regrets
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Earlier in the afternoon, Amazon.com went down. It came, as Nick Wingfield noted, after a week in which several of the Internet’s biggest companies went dark for a time.

headline: Prime Minister of Pakistan Open to Talks With Taliban
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — In his first televised policy speech to the country since assuming office in June, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif on Monday hinted at his government’s inclination to hold talks with Taliban militants even while maintaining the option of military action against them.

headline: Germany: Police Foil Hostage Taker
text: Chancellor Angela Merkel canceled a campaign appearance in the northern Bavarian town of Ingolstadt on Monday after a 24-year-old man armed with a knife and a realistic plastic replica of a pistol took three hostages in the local city hall. The police later stormed the building, freeing the hostages and wounding the suspect. It was unclear whether the episode had any connection with Ms. Merkel’s plans for an appearance in a nearby square. She was to proceed with a planned appearance in the nearby city of Regensburg later Monday. Ms. Merkel is seeking a third term in federal elections on Sept. 22. All three hostages were unharmed, said Günther Beck, a police spokesman. The suspect suffered a gunshot wound and was being treated by doctors, but he was expected to appear in a local court on Tuesday, Mr. Beck said.

headline: Seized Guns Offer Look at Pipeline From South
text: The guns often arrived by Chinatown bus, packed into patterned bags and destined for sale in a Brooklyn rap studio or in the backs of cars on the Lower East Side.

headline: Syria: Thousands Flee to Iraq
text: At least 29,000 Syrians have flooded into northern Iraq since Thursday, the United Nations refugee agency said Monday, calling it one of the largest cross-border migrations since the Syrian conflict began in 2011. Officials said 20,000 crossed over on Thursday alone. More than 1.9 million Syrians have already sought refuge in neighboring countries; more than 180,000 are now in Iraq.

headline: South Korea: U.S. Joins War Drills
text: South Korea and the United States began another round of military drills on Monday. In the past, North Korea denounced the drills as a rehearsal for an invasion, but on Tuesday its criticism was less harsh, which analysts said was a sign of the North’s interest in continuing diplomacy. The drills, which continue until Aug. 30, involve 30,000 American and 50,000 South Korean troops in computer-simulated war exercises.

headline: Prosecutor in Enron Case Expected to Be Named to Justice Dept. Post
text: The Justice Department is expected to name Leslie R. Caldwell, the former lead prosecutor in the Enron case, as the next head of its criminal division, according to people briefed on the decision.

headline: At U.N., Labor Tensions Mar 10th Anniversary of Bombing
text: The United Nations commemorated the 10th anniversary of the single deadliest assault in the organization’s history on Monday, the bombing of its Baghdad offices that killed 22 people, with Secretary General Ban Ki-moon warning in a speech that since then “the attackers who target us have grown more sophisticated, more brazen and better armed.”

headline: Michigan: Many Object to Bankruptcy
text: ﻿About 100 objections to Detroit’s eligibility for bankruptcy were filed in federal court before a midnight deadline on Monday. The challenges, most from individual city retirees or residents, contend that city officials did not prove insolvency or negotiate enough with creditors before seeking Chapter 9 protection last month. Unions also argued that the case should be dismissed because it will violate pension protections under the State Constitution. The state attorney general, Bill Schuette, who will defend pensioners in later bankruptcy proceedings, did not protest the city’s eligibility.

headline: As a Boom Slows, Peru Grows Uneasy
text: LIMA, Peru — From his office window, Henrik Kristensen, the chief executive of the company that runs Peru’s main port, can still look out at rows of newly arrived, shiny Kia automobiles from South Korea and shipping containers stacked four high, full of imported items like television sets and brand-name clothing bound for the growing number of malls that serve this country’s burgeoning middle class.

headline: Smith Feels Pressure as Sanchez Finds Comfort
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — As much as Jets Coach Rex Ryan insists the quarterback competition is not over, the demeanor and words of the incumbent Mark Sanchez and the rookie Geno Smith on Monday appeared to hint at the more likely outcome.

headline: Obama Presses for Action on Bank Rules
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama urged the nation’s top financial regulators on Monday to move faster on new rules for Wall Street, telling them in a private White House meeting that they must work to prevent a repeat of the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: Uncertainty Over a Palace of Parking
text: BERLIN — The preservation of a sooty parking garage covered with graffiti is a tough sell in a city whose landmarks include fragments of the wall that for decades defined the cold war, a jagged church tower that stands as testament to the ravages of World War II and elegant Prussian palaces where German leaders host visiting dignitaries.

headline: Using U.S. Golf System to Help Defeat U.S.
text: PARKER, Colo. — The Solheim Cup victory was another plume in what has become a tribal headdress for golfers from the other side of the Atlantic. A European team led by Charley Hull, an irrepressible 17-year-old from England, put the finishing touches on its record 18-10 drubbing of the Americans hours after another British teenager, Matthew Fitzpatrick, 18, became the first Englishman in more than a century to win the United States Amateur.

headline: Prime Lot, Empty for Years (Yes, This Is Manhattan)
text: This hole in the ground is the length of three city blocks. It is a carpet of sand, weeds and prairie grass sloping down to the river, interrupted only by a low ridge of broken bedrock. Around it, a black chain-link fence catches the plastic cups, paper and other debris that roll along like tumbleweeds.

headline: Baas Is in Doubt for Giants’ Opener
text: A knee injury to the Giants’ starting center, David Baas, will jeopardize his chances of being available for the team’s season-opening game Sept. 8, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin said Monday.

headline: Deaf Student, Denied Interpreter by Medical School, Draws Focus of Advocates
text: Speaking with the parents of a sick infant, Michael Argenyi, a medical student, could not understand why the child was hospitalized. During another clinical training session, he missed most of what a patient with a broken jaw was trying to convey about his condition.

headline: Egypt’s Media Cheers on Army Crackdown
text: Updated, Tuesday, 5:32 p.m. | As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports from Cairo, criticism of the deadly crackdown on Islamist protesters by security forces there has all but disappeared from the Egyptian media since channels that supported the Muslim Brotherhood were shut down last month.

headline: With a Little Help From My Friends
text: My new technique was born of laziness and lack of imagination. I was trying to come up with a name for a character in my latest novel, “Swann Dives In.” He was a disbarred lawyer, a friend of the protagonist, Henry Swann, himself a money-obsessed skip tracer unafraid to cut a few corners. Rather than waste too much time, which as it happens is a specialty of many writers when it comes to writing, I slipped in the name of my friend Mark Goldblatt, as a place holder. He had no special significance to the story or the character. I would just use it, I thought, until I came up with something more appropriate.

headline: N.C.A.A. Restores Marine’s Eligibility to Play Football
text: Early this summer, Steven Rhodes sent tapes of himself playing football to college coaches around the country, hoping to be invited to join their practices. The tapes included footage from some games Rhodes participated in while at Air Station Miramar, the Marine Corps base in San Diego.

headline: Bo Guagua’s Statement
text: Following is the statement that Bo Guagua released to The New York Times on Monday. Mr. Bo’s father, Bo Xilai, a former Chinese Communist Party official, is scheduled to go on trial on Thursday on charges of taking bribes, corruption and abuse of power.

headline: Fallen Chinese Official’s Son Is ‘Denied Contact’ With Parents
text: BEIJING — Bo Guagua, the younger son of a fallen Communist Party leader scheduled to go on trial this week, made a rare public comment on the case on Monday, saying in a statement that he had been unable to communicate with his father or mother for a year and a half and drawing attention to their “clandestine detention.”

headline: America Has No Leverage in Egypt
text: WASHINGTON — EGYPT has entered a dark tunnel, and it is difficult to say when, and in what condition, it will emerge.

headline: The Real Costs of Policing the Police
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — SETTING aside the legal wisdom of the recent decision by a federal judge against the New York Police Department and its stop-and-frisk policy, one thing seems clear: the judge’s remedy will be enormously expensive and time-consuming to implement, and at a time when the number of stops is falling dramatically.

text: Starting my morning off right with the commute from hell, courtesy of the ever-reliable & always punctual LIRR.

text: The Yankees were off on Monday, but there was no letup in an increasingly contentious battle between the team’s highest-paid player, Alex Rodriguez, and seemingly the rest of the baseball world.

headline: False Choices on Egypt
text: A surprising number of world leaders and foreign policy experts have effectively acquiesced in the continued brutality of Egypt’s generals, arguing that support for the military is the only way to restore stability in the Arab world’s most populous state and limit wider regional turmoil. But this is just one of several false choices misinforming the debate and one that is certain to ensure more unrest, not less.

headline: Trifling With the Arts and Humanities
text: More than eight months ago, the high-wattage Broadway producer Rocco Landesman announced his departure as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts. Mr. Landesman, who took the job in 2009, will be hard to replace but not impossible. The White House has taken too long to nominate a successor. It also needs a new leader for the National Endowment for the Humanities, which has been missing a permanent chief since May.

headline: Carwash Managers Held in Immigration Raids
text: PHOENIX — Federal agents arrested 11 managers and supervisors of a local car-washing chain on immigration fraud and other charges in weekend raids that brought in more than 200 people, setting off fear among immigrants already on edge by years of relentless enforcement in a state at the core of the debate over illegal immigration.

headline: Back to the Future on Wall Street
text: It has been about a year since the JOBS Act sailed through Congress with the support of bipartisan majorities, President Obama and the banking industry — despite warnings that it would harm investors by weakening the standards and procedures that companies and their bankers must follow when they seek to raise money from the public.

headline: Saudi Arabia Promises to Aid Egypt’s Regime
text: CAIRO — Saudi Arabia has emerged as the foremost supporter of Egypt’s military rulers, explicitly backing the violent crackdown on Islamists and using its oil wealth and diplomatic muscle to help defy growing pressure from the West to end the bloodshed in search of a political solution.

headline: Girardi Stands, and Jumps Up, for What’s Right
text: If Joe Girardi detests cheating in baseball as much as he says, then some part of him must disapprove of his third baseman. Alex Rodriguez has a long rap sheet that would appear to read as the antithesis of the values Girardi stands for.

Indictment in Immigration Raids at Arizona Carwashes

The company’s founder and chief executive was An Wang, a brilliant Chinese immigrant who was widely hailed as a visionary entrepreneur and philanthropist.

But when Josh Isay talks about Christine Quinn and the chance of her becoming the next mayor of New York, you see something else, something more. His eyes actually mist.

text: Almost wherever she goes, Christine C. Quinn encounters hostility from a small group of protesters critical of her record as City Council speaker. On Monday, that rancor erupted, when the publisher of a community newspaper slapped a state senator and an intern who were supporting Ms. Quinn.

text: Beau Biden, the son of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., has been admitted to a hospital in Houston after “an episode of disorientation and weakness,” according to a White House statement released Monday night.

We have our second mention of the A.D.A. in as many days – hey, we just want to make sure you brush your teeth on the regular.

text: SANDY HOOK, N.J. — For a quarter-century, the ritual never changed.

headline: Scandal-Weary San Diego Asks a Question: Where’s the Mayor?
text: SAN DIEGO — In the five weeks since Mayor Bob Filner was first accused of sexual harassment by an aide, San Diego has almost felt like a city held hostage.

headline: Suicides Worry Experts at Big Jail in Capital
text: WASHINGTON — Mike Johnson, 53, hanged himself in his cell at the Central Detention Facility here two weeks ago and died shortly after at the Prince George’s Hospital Center. On June 29, Walter Calloway, 42, hanged himself in his cell. Just two weeks before that, another inmate, Paul Mannina, 58, cut his throat and bled to death.

headline: Intersection: Fete Fashion in Rio
text: In Rio de Janeiro’s Madureira neighborhood, locals show off their style outside a charme dance party.

headline: At Whiskey Soda Lounge, More Than Just a Place to Wait
text: On Monday night, as ever, a line of impatient diners marked time on Columbia Street in Brooklyn, craving admission to Pok Pok Ny, the chef Andy Ricker’s super-hot, country-style paean to the cuisine of northern Thailand. Seven doors down the block, though, guests were slow to arrive at Whiskey Soda Lounge Ny, Mr. Ricker’s new watering hole, which opened to the public at 5:30 p.m.

headline: For 2nd Term, a 2nd White House Dog
text: WASHINGTON — There is a new resident at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, and a new playmate for Bo, the presidential pooch.

headline: Lee Thompson Young, Detective on TV, Dies at 29
text: Lee Thompson Young, an actor who played a child star on the Disney Channel show “The Famous Jett Jackson” and a detective on the hit TNT series “Rizzoli & Isles,” was found dead on Monday at his home in Los Angeles after he failed to show up for work. He was 29.

text: The photo project “Meals Interrupted,” by Claudia Ficca and Davide Luciano, consists of elaborate spreads ruined by annoying and sometimes devastating events.

headline: ‘Today’ Is Starting Oprah-like Book Club
text: “Today” will introduce a new monthly book club on Tuesday, a happy development for a publishing industry frustrated by years of shrinking television time devoted to authors.

headline: Triple Play: Week 20 Results
text: Jose Iglesias led this race, at least on the ballot, with more than 46 percent of the vote to 37 percent for Alex Rodriguez. But Rodriguez, in his second week back since off-season hip surgery and playing through the appeal process of his 211-game suspension, was the victor on the field. His performance for the week also helped ignite a stagnant offense, and the Yankees were the only one of the four teams mentioned in Question 1 with a winning record for the week.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 8 P.M. (Sundance) THE PLAYER (1992) In this film directed by Robert Altman, Griffin Mill (Tim Robbins), the head of production at a large Hollywood studio, tries to fend off a young genius (Peter Gallagher) rumored to have been hired as his replacement while figuring out who is writing him poison-pen postcards. When the hate mail’s author — a screenwriter (Vincent D’Onofrio) Griffin failed to get back to — turns up dead, he becomes a suspect, partly for falling in love with the writer’s girlfriend (Greta Scacchi, above, with Mr. Robbins). Whoopi Goldberg and Lyle Lovett play the detectives who make Griffin squirm. “As a satire, ‘The Player’ tickles,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. “It doesn’t draw blood.” Mr. Altman’s most subversive message, he added, “is not that it’s possible to get away with murder in Hollywood, but that the most grievous sin, in Hollywood terms anyway, is to make a film that flops.” In “Short Cuts” (1993), at 10:15, Mr. Altman intertwines the experiences of Los Angelenos in adaptations of Raymond Carver stories. Mr. Robbins reappears as a philandering motorcycle cop who can’t be faithful to the woman (Frances McDormand) with whom he’s cheating on his wife (Madeleine Stowe). Lily Tomlin is a diner cook who hits a small boy with her car. Bruce Davison and Andie MacDowell are his parents; Mr. Lovett is the baker who makes his birthday cake. Fred Ward, Buck Henry and Huey Lewis are three pals who find a dead woman while fishing. And Jennifer Jason Leigh is a mother who supports her family by doing phone sex, sometimes while washing dishes or changing diapers. “The lives are often desperate and the characters inarticulate, but the group portrait is as grandly, sometimes as hilariously, realized as anything the director has ever done,” Mr. Canby wrote. “When future social historians want to know what the temper of life was like in one corner of America in 1993, ‘Short Cuts’ will be a mother lode of information. It’s also a terrific movie.”

headline: Britons Question Whether Detention of Reporter’s Partner Was Terror-Related
text: LONDON — Demands grew on Monday for the British government to explain why it had used antiterrorism powers to detain the partner of a journalist who has written about surveillance programs based on leaks by the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden.

headline: News Quiz | August 20, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Butter Chicken in Ahmedabad
text: Himanshu Desai, a 53-year-old businessman, runs a fast-food restaurant, Sandwichworkz, near the Indian Institute of Management campus in Ahmedabad, the most populous city in the western state of Gujarat. Mr. Desai, a tall, portly man who was born near the Gujarat city of Surat and grew up in Delhi, serves meat food— an uncommon choice in the state capital, especially for a Hindu. His friends advised him against it, pointing to the brisk business vegetarian food outlets did in Gujarat. “When KFC came to Gujarat, there were agitations,” said Mr. Desai, laughing. “My father taught us that eating meat did not make us lesser Gujaratis or lesser Brahmins.”

headline: Test Yourself | History, Aug. 20, 2013
text: We’ll be featuring a history question on Test Yourself every Tuesday this school year. Some, like the one below, will relate current events around the world to history, while others will test students’ knowledge of important past events. Let us know what you think!

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | How Mayor Bloomberg Reshaped New York City
text: The interactive feature “Reshaping New York” provides a tour of the ways New York City’s physical landscape has changed in the last 12 years.

headline: ‘Orange’ Is the New Green
text: After furiously binge-streaming all 13 episodes of “Orange Is the New Black,” the Netflix comic drama about a former Connecticut debutante serving a 15-month jail sentence for laundering drug money, I devoured, equally eagerly, the book from which it was adapted. Then I took my obsession to what some might consider the extreme: I attended the American Correction Association’s 143rd Congress of Correction outside Washington.

headline: Photo Editors Who Made a Difference
text: Photo editors play a bigger role in photographers’ lives than just choosing their best pictures. Often, it’s an editor’s voice that photographers hear in the back of their mind, urging them to strive harder for the defining image. They become lifelong friends, confidants and mentors. They can become surrogate parents or siblings — and, as with most family members, there’s a good chance they’ll drive you nuts.

headline: Pakistani Court Indicts Musharraf in 2007 Assassination of Bhutto
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — In a sudden erosion of military privilege and impunity, a Pakistani court indicted the former ruler Pervez Musharraf on Tuesday in connection with the 2007 assassination of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto — the first time that such a senior general has faced criminal charges.

headline: New York Today: A Struggle Far From Home
text: The unrest in Egypt may feel far-off for many New Yorkers.

headline: The 2013 Woodward Dream Cruise: A Perfect Day for Cruising
text: DETROIT — The Woodward Dream Cruise, an annual automotive celebration along the famous avenue that bisects the Detroit metropolitan area, attracted tens of thousands of interesting cars and more than a million spectators to its 19th edition on a perfect summer Saturday. The event, now a weeklong street festival, also drew more police officers than a law-enforcement convention, as units from all over Michigan pitched in to help control the cars and the crowds.

headline: Coffin Shopping for Mom
text: I have recently planned my mother’s funeral with the clear-eyed precision of an accountant and the organizational skills of the activities director at the assisted-living facility where she lives. And I have done it within a budget where there are no line items for grand final wishes.

headline: An Egypt Arrest, and a Brotherhood on the Run
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s authoritarian government has harassed and repressed the Muslim Brotherhood for most of its existence. But for the last three decades the authorities stopped short of touching the group’s revered leader, the supreme guide, who oversaw the country’s most effective social, political and religious organization despite its outlawed status.

headline: Designing a Profit-Sharing Plan
text: At the end of March, I devoted a meeting of what I call my operations committee — there are seven of us on the committee — to my ideas for a profit-sharing plan. (I wrote my first post in this series two weeks ago.) I had been thinking a lot about exactly what it might look like and how I would explain it to everyone so that it didn’t seem as if I had thought up the plan on a whim.

headline: North Korean Defectors Tell U.N. Panel of Prison Camp Abuses
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Shin Dong-hyuk said his earliest memory of life in a North Korean prison camp was the public execution that inmates were forced to watch when he was 5 years old. Inmates, he told a hushed audience here in Seoul on Tuesday, were so hungry that they devoured live rats and the raw hooves of a goat that prison guards had thrown away after slaughtering the animal.

headline: U.S. Influence in Egypt
text: Egypt’s generals threaten not to take America’s billions.

headline: New Chinese Agency to Increase Financial Coordination
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese authorities said on Tuesday that they would set up a group to coordinate financial regulation, in an apparent attempt to reduce risk and wean the economy off easy credit and steer it toward a slower, more sustainable expansion.

headline: Carlyle Hires G.E. Executive for Power Investment Team
text: The Carlyle Group said on Tuesday that it had hired Matthew J. O’Connor from General Electric as a new co-head of its power investments group.

headline: The S.E.C.’s Tougher Stance
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission has signaled that it was now taking a harder line on securities settlements, as it extracted its first admission of wrongdoing under a new policy, DealBook’s Alexandra Stevenson reports. The S.E.C. said on Monday that the hedge fund manager Philip A. Falcone had agreed to admit wrongdoing and to be barred from the securities industry for at least five years to settle accusations of market manipulation. He and his fund, Harbinger Capital Partners, must also pay more than $18 million.

headline: Gay Widower Finds Himself Opposed by Partner’s Family
text: Every other Tuesday, Steven Petrow, the author of “Steven Petrow’s Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners” (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience. Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

headline: Branagh’s ‘Macbeth’ Coming to New York’s Park Avenue Armory in 2014
text: Fresh off a highly praised run at the Manchester International Festival in England, a new production of “Macbeth” directed by Kenneth Branagh and Rob Ashford is coming to Manhattan next year. First mounted in a deconsecrated church with the audience seated in long pews, the play will be reimagined in June for the 55,000-square-foot space in the Park Avenue Armory’s Drill Hall.

headline: In Performance: Eric Anderson and Amber Iman of ‘Soul Doctor’
text: The real-life folk-singing Rabbi Shlomo Carlebach is the subject of the new Broadway musical “Soul Doctor,” which opened last week at the Circle in the Square. In this scene, the rabbi, played by Eric Anderson, sings the number “Always With You,” about his friendship with the singer Nina Simone, played by Amber Iman.

headline: Fort Hood Gunman Told His Superiors of Concerns
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — Days before he opened fire inside a medical processing building at Fort Hood here in 2009, Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan sent two e-mails to his Army superiors expressing concern about the actions of some of the soldiers he was evaluating as a military psychiatrist.

headline: Tank Has Leaked Tons of Contaminated Water at Japan Nuclear Site
text: TOKYO — Three hundred tons of highly contaminated water has leaked from a storage tank at the ravaged Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant on Japan’s Pacific coast, its operator said Tuesday, prompting regulators to declare a “radiological release incident” for the first time since disaster struck there in 2011 and adding new fears of environmental calamity.

headline: Could Climate Campaigners’ Focus on Current Events be Counterproductive?
text: This graph is from “Climate Risks: Linking Narratives to Action,” an important new essay in the Stanford Social Innovation Review on the gap between major environmental groups’ messaging on human-driven global warming and the focus of their programs and spending. The message these days has become all about extreme events, from the Frankenstorm to intense droughts, but the programs remain locked mainly on strategies for curbing the flow of greenhouse gases, according to the authors, Amy Luers, Carl Pope and David Kroodsma. Please read the piece.

headline: That Boston Fan? He Wants to Run New York

headline: Palestinian Is Killed in Raid by Israel in West Bank Camp
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli soldiers killed a young Palestinian man early Tuesday during a confrontation in the Jenin refugee camp in the northern West Bank, as troops arriving to arrest an Islamic Jihad member suspected of planning terrorist attacks were greeted by violent protesters, Israeli officials said.

headline: A Novelist Who Made Crime an Art, and His Bad Guys ‘Fun’

He was 87.

headline: Seen Any Artisanal Gangsters?
text: As I was leaving the office the other day, I snagged a crime novel called “At the End of a Dull Day,” by Massimo Carlotto, off our giveaway table. I often do this as a random test. I’ll read a couple of pages on the subway, typically lose interest and then find a place to leave it. This novel, however, completely hijacked my attention, and I finished it that same night.

headline: A Check on Premature Hospital Discharges

headline: Empty Prison in Chelsea Is Now a Valuable Piece of Real Estate

Until recently, residents of the 82-year-old Art Deco building could watch strollers on the High Line and golf balls flying into netting at Chelsea Piers.

headline: A Food Scene With Local Roots Sprouts in Maryland

The flourishing culinary scene is undoubtedly the biggest change. Natives of this metropolis of 65,000 are transforming the city, one hour from Washington, by opening restaurants and food shops.

headline: On the Verge | Los Angeles, Where the Wild Things Are

Angelenos aren’t particularly concerned with the zeitgeist; there’s always another wave, after all. Which is one reason the fashion industry, with its rhetoric of the new and the on-trend, never put much stock in L.A.

headline: Crespéu
text: Crespéu is a traditional Provençal dish consisting of several frittatas layered one on top of the other. On my summer trips to Provence over the last few years I’ve noticed that the dish has become popular in charcuteries, baked in breadpan-shaped terrines and sold by the slice. These usually consist of three or four different types of frittata and they are different from the stack of thin frittatas that I learned to make years ago. Traditionally you would make these simply by making the frittatas, leaving them a little runny on the top and stacking them, then finishing the stack in the oven or just weighting it with a plate and chilling. But it’s easier and faster (though still quite time consuming) if you’re making the crespéu in a breadpan or tureen to cook the eggs and filling like runny scrambled eggs and layer each batch in a breadpan, then bake in a water bath. You can use 3 eggs in each batch instead of 4, but the layers will be thinner.

headline: Istanbul Skyline Reflects Cheap Dollars Now Growing Scarce

headline: Home Depot Credits Housing Recovery for 17% Jump in Earnings
text: Evidence of the housing recovery grew a bit stronger on Tuesday, as Home Depot blew past analyst estimates and its internal projections, increased its yearly earnings forecast and said it “had one of the best quarters in our recent history.”

headline: They Can’t Handle The Health Care Truth
text: Aaron Carroll talks about the Republican health care dilemma, and makes a good point: it runs deeper than the specific fact that Obamacare looks the way it does because it has to. At the most fundamental level, you can’t guarantee adequate health care to everyone unless the people who don’t need help right now — the young, healthy, and affluent — are induced, one way or another, to contribute to the care of those who do need help. You can do this purely with taxes, via a single-payer system (and maybe even by having the government act as provider), or you can do it, Swiss or Massachusetts style, via a combination of regulation, taxes, and subsidies. But some way of corralling the lucky healthy into contributing is necessary.

headline: Ocean Township, N.J.: The ‘Ocean’ Is Aspirational
text: Ocean Township in Monmouth County has a bit of an identity problem. To start with, there’s another Ocean Township in neighboring Ocean County. Then there is the fact that despite its name, no part of the town is on the ocean (it’s about a mile inland). And as if those issues were not enough, most people who reside in the 10.8-square-mile community never actually say so, identifying instead with their specific neighborhood: Wayside or Wanamassa, Oakhurst or Colonial Terrace, Deal Park or West Allenhurst, to name several.

headline: A Path to the World for Chinese Directors
text: BEIJING — If you think documentary filmmaking in the United States is a vocation for masochists with empty bank accounts, consider the challenges Chinese directors face: detention, beatings and censorship. Directors willing to play by the government’s strict rules can see their films screened on Chinese television or at a small number of officially sanctioned “independent” film festivals. Others can walk away with generous state support.

headline: With Waves and Turns, a Soloist Tells the Story of Two Indian Saints
text: Drive East at La MaMa — accurately subtitled a Journey Through South Asian Music and Dance — is an extraordinary feat, covering more ground than many other festivals. In seven days, it presents 26 performances, none repeated, of music and dance. Six of India’s classical dance forms — Bharata Natyam, Odissi, Kathak, Kuchipudi, Mohiniattam and Kathakali — will be represented. The music includes Carnatic and Hindustani vocals and individual performances devoted to the tabla, sitar, flute and other instruments. Few of us in the West know nearly enough about these rich and compelling genres; I hope this festival recurs in years to come.

headline: Dark Day at Saratoga Is Hardly a Quiet One

It is a chance to turn off the OTB Channel, swear off speed and pace figures and do something nice for yourself. Like your laundry. Or retire to the Roosevelt Spa to soak in the healing mineral waters as Diamond Jim Brady, J. P. Morgan, Lillian Russell and a roll call of celebrities from a century past once did.

headline: Nonprofits Are Balking at Law on Disclosing Political Donors

headline: Lottery Numbers
Wanted: A Boring Leader for the Fed
text: MEDFORD, Mass. — THE debate over who should succeed Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has been exceptionally personality-driven. Supporters and opponents of the two leading contenders — Lawrence H. Summers, a former Treasury secretary and adviser to President Obama, and Janet L. Yellen, a Clinton administration veteran like Mr. Summers, and now the Fed’s vice chairwoman — have been feuding in public. Mr. Obama has called the decision, which is expected soon, one of the most important of his presidency.

headline: In High Costs of City’s Litigation, a Litany of Missed Opportunities

headline: N.F.L. Fans Met by Tighter Bag Policy
text: Joe and Lynn Gurski and their infant son, Ryan, arrived prepared to see the Jets play the Jaguars at MetLife Stadium on Saturday.

headline: Boycotting Vodka Won’t Help Russia’s Gays
text: VILLANOVA, Pa. — AMERICA’S favorite sex-and-relationships columnist, Dan Savage, has called for a boycott of Russian vodka to protest violent attacks on gays by nationalist thugs and antigay legislation backed by President Vladimir V. Putin. It’s an understandable response, but the prospects for the boycott’s succeeding are slim, and the potential for it to backfire on gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender Russians is high.

headline: Close to the Edge
text: Of all the troubling images from Cairo these days, none could be worse than the pictures of the many civilian casualties. But nearly as disturbing was footage from last week showing an Egyptian police vehicle toppling off the 6th of October Bridge, which spans the Nile in central Cairo. News accounts differed over whether the vehicle was pushed over by protesters or, in a panic, the driver burst through the bridge railing and plunged into the river. Either way, the bridge was badly damaged, the car was lost, the fate of its passengers unknown.

headline: Curtain Falls on a Club for Clowns and Comics
text: New York can be a tough town for a clown.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Law Blog Shuts Down Over Government Surveillance
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Villagers Tell of Slaughter by a Soldier in Kandahar
text: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash. — One by one, the Afghan men and boys took the witness stand inside a military courtroom on Tuesday to tell of a night of gunfire, bloodshed and horror a world away.

headline: Republicans Retreat From a Shutdown
text: Whether out of pure self-preservation or a sudden attack of common sense, a growing group of Republicans is saying no to the strident extremists who want to shut down the government this fall if health care reform is allowed to proceed. “I think it’s the dumbest idea I’ve ever heard of,” Senator Richard Burr, a Republican of North Carolina, said recently.

headline: Time to Stop Stalling on Nuclear Waste
text: A federal appeals court has given the Nuclear Regulatory Commission a well-justified rebuke for “flouting the law” when it stopped analyzing the safety of the proposed nuclear waste site at Yucca Mountain in Nevada, some 100 miles northwest of Las Vegas. The commission engaged in some questionable maneuvers aimed at preventing the Yucca site from ever opening, thus carrying out pledges to scuttle the facility made by President Obama, while campaigning for the presidency in 2008, and Senator Harry Reid, a Democrat of Nevada and the majority leader, who has ferociously opposed the site for years.

headline: Rules for Wall Street to Live By
text: President Obama’s meeting on Monday with several of the nation’s top financial regulators was designed, a spokesman said, to convey the urgency he feels about getting “regulations under Wall Street reform implemented promptly.” That sounds impressive, but the fact is these reforms should have been in place a long time ago. The challenge at this late date is not simply to move faster — which could imply a slipshod effort — but to issue strong rules without further delay.

headline: At Cairo Morgue, Families Face Menace From Nameless Men
text: CAIRO — The unmistakable smell of death wafted several blocks away from the Zeinhom morgue on Tuesday, and feral dogs scrounging in the rubbish-strewn lanes lifted their noses into the hot, still air and trotted toward it, until deterred with swift kicks.

headline: Guns and Gays in New Jersey
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has in the last few days confounded political forces on both sides. Pleasing Democrats and moderate Republicans, he signed a humane law banning the junk-science practice of “gay conversion therapy” on minors. Delighting the Republican right, he vetoed a bill banning .50 caliber rifles.

headline: Line’s Reshuffling Leads to a Starting Audition for the Giants’ Top Pick
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The knee injury that sidelined center David Baas figured to shake up the Giants’ offensive line. But in something of a surprise, the line’s reconfiguration has turned into a prime-time audition for the team’s first-round draft pick, Justin Pugh.

headline: The Ambiguous Allure of the E-Cig
text: Are electronic cigarettes really helping smokers quit or prolonging nicotine addiction? How should they be regulated, if at all?

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:
