headline: For Maine Governor, Issue Is What They Said He Said
text: BOSTON — Gov. Paul LePage of Maine was hoping to make a national splash for his state when he sent promotional boxes of lobster bisque, tails and spreads to the nation’s 49 other governors on Monday. By Tuesday morning he had made a splash all right, but it had nothing to do with lobsters.

headline: Irritating and Inspiring the Yankees
text: The record will show that the Yankees were playing fairly well before Ryan Dempster drilled Alex Rodriguez with a fastball on Sunday night at Fenway Park. The narrative might read a little differently.

headline: Taxi Commission Targets Apple-Green Impostor Cabs
text: For decades, New York City taxi-hailing has come in only one color — a yellow so indelible that other cabs were forbidden to adopt its eye-catching tones.

headline: At Bo Xilai Trial, a Goal to Blast Acts, Not Ideas
text: BEIJING — The paraphernalia of the global left litters the bookstore called Utopia on the sixth floor of an office tower here: tomes titled “Mao Zedong’s Road to Success” and “The Marxian Legacy,” and canvas satchels with Che Guevara’s visage.

headline: Amid Talk of White House Run, Texas Senator Targets Obama’s Health Plan
text: DALLAS — Senator Ted Cruz, after two days of bedevilment over his birthplace and eligibility for the presidency, returned to form on Tuesday night with a rally here before the conservative faithful aimed at ginning up support to defund President Obama’s health care overhaul.

headline: Obama to Offer Plans to Ease Burden of Paying for College
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will offer a series of proposals this week aimed at making college more affordable by reshaping the way Americans pay for higher education, he said in an e-mail to supporters on Tuesday.

headline: Life Advice for Youth Resurfaces for a Jet
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — When Danny Lansanah counseled teenagers at Alternative Rehabilitation Communities in his hometown, Harrisburg, Pa., he urged them to follow their dreams no matter how much adversity they encountered, no matter how high the odds seemed stacked against them.

headline: Corrections: August 21, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Fun in the Sun
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Spoiler alert: If you don’t want to hear about the theme, save this post until later.

headline: South Sudan: Commander Arrested
text: The president ordered the arrest of a high-ranking army commander over suspected violations of human rights, a military spokesman said Tuesday. Brig. Gen. James Otong was relieved of his command in Jonglei State and flown by helicopter back to the capital, Juba, on Monday, said the spokesman, Col. Philip Aguer. “There are allegations of human rights violations,” said Colonel Aguer, as well as violations of the military rules of engagement. He referred specifically to killings of civilians by soldiers in Pibor, where General Otong was based. Jonglei was the scene of clashes in July after thousands of fighters from the Lou Nuer ethnic group raided towns and villages belonging to members of the Murle group. More than 300 people died.

headline: Bill’s Turn at Bat
text: So it turns out that Michael Bloomberg and Bill de Blasio, who’s campaigning for mayor on a promise to de-Bloomberg Gotham, do have something in common.

headline: One Hit From a Debatable Milestone
text: Ichiro Suzuki was only 18 years old when he was called up to join the Orix Blue Wave’s senior team in Japan in 1992. This was the beginning of what became a remarkable career, but Suzuki had so little faith in himself at the time that he initially balked at the promotion.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, August 21, 2013
text: “They broke through the gates and stole whatever they could. What they couldn’t steal, they burned.”

headline: Candidate for Brooklyn Prosecutor Drew Criticism for Signature Case
text: The hundreds of reporters and camera operators who crowded into the Brooklyn megachurch two summers ago had come to see one woman: Nafissatou Diallo, the hotel housekeeper who was accusing the head of the International Monetary Fund, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, of sexually assaulting her.

headline: Newest Spy Court Pick Is a Democrat but Not a Liberal
text: WASHINGTON — Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., who has filled a secret court that oversees surveillance almost entirely with Republican-appointed judges, has named Judge José A. Cabranes, a Democratic appointee, to the panel that hears rare appeals of the surveillance court’s rulings.

headline: Jane Harvey, 88, Jazz Singer With Long and Varied Career, Dies
text: Jane Harvey, whose career as a jazz vocalist lasted nearly 70 years and included recordings with Benny Goodman and Duke Ellington, died on Aug. 15 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 88.

headline: James Sterling Young, Oral Historian, Dies at 85
text: James Sterling Young, who established the country’s only program dedicated to compiling comprehensive oral histories of the American presidency, and who also amassed a vast oral history of Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s career, died on Aug. 8 at his home in Advance Mills, Va. He was 85.

headline: Cedar Walton, Pianist and Composer, Dies at 79
text: Cedar Walton, a pianist who distinguished himself as both an accompanist and a soloist, and who wrote some of the most enduring compositions in modern jazz while a member of Art Blakey’s Jazz Messengers in the early 1960s, died on Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 79.

headline: Facebook Leads an Effort to Lower Barriers to Internet Access
text: MENLO PARK, Calif. — About one of every seven people in the world uses Facebook. Now, Mark Zuckerberg, its co-founder and chief executive, wants to make a play for the rest — including the four billion or so who lack Internet access.

headline: Mets Quietly Go About Their Business in Victory
text: Ten miles from Yankee Stadium, where the barnstorming soap opera starring Alex Rodriguez resumed its local run, the Mets were back home, too, finding relative peace at Citi Field, which has become an unlikely baseball oasis this season.

headline: U.S. Diplomats, Relieved After Libyan Attack, Are Reinstated
text: WASHINGTON — Four midlevel State Department officials who were placed on administrative leave after the deadly attack last year on the United States mission in Benghazi, Libya, have been reinstated by Secretary of State John Kerry and were given new assignments on Tuesday, the department confirmed.

headline: Carmen Almon, the Naturalist
text: The greatest botanical artist of this century quietly works by hand at her home in the south of France.

headline: Robotic-Task Economics
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: How Exercise Can Help Us Sleep Better
text: As a clinical psychologist and sleep researcher at the Feinberg School of Medicine at Northwestern University, Kelly Glazer Baron frequently heard complaints from aggrieved patients about exercise. They would work out, they told her, sometimes to the point of exhaustion, but they would not sleep better that night.

headline: Word of the Day | degradation
text: degradation •\ˌde-grə-ˈda-shən\• noun

headline: What’s on Wednesday
text: 12:50 P.M. (TMC) COOL RUNNINGS (1993) Three Jamaican sprinters — played by Leon, Malik Yoba and Rawle D. Lewis — fail to qualify for the Olympics in track and field but earn a second chance at a gold medal when they enlist a pushcart racer (Doug E. Doug, above, far left, with, from left, Mr. Yoba, Mr. Lewis, John Candy and Leon) and a disgraced former bobsled champion (Mr. Candy) as their coach to become Jamaica’s first bobsled team. Writing in The New York Times, Janet Maslin described the film, very loosely based on events at the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary, Alberta, as “a cute, buoyant sports fantasy, jolted along by a reggae soundtrack and playfully acted by an appealing cast.” She added: “This new Disney comedy is slick, funny and warmhearted, very much in the old-fashioned Disney mode.” She also commended the performance of Mr. Candy: “His obligatory Big Speech defending the Jamaicans’ right to compete is handled with a minimum of self-righteousness or corn.”

headline: Facial Scanning Is Making Gains in Surveillance
text: WASHINGTON — The federal government is making progress on developing a surveillance system that would pair computers with video cameras to scan crowds and automatically identify people by their faces, according to newly disclosed documents and interviews with researchers working on the project.

headline: Images of Death in Syria, but No Proof of Chemical Attack
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Scores of men, women and children were killed outside Damascus on Wednesday in an attack marked by the telltale signs of chemical weapons: row after row of corpses without visible injury; hospitals flooded with victims, gasping for breath, trembling and staring ahead languidly; images of a gray cloud bursting over a neighborhood.

headline: News Quiz | Aug. 21, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Aug. 21, 2013
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Climate Panel Cites With Near Certainty That Planet Is Warming
text: In the article “Climate Panel Cites Near Certainty on Warming,” Justin Gillis writes about a new draft report by the Nobel Prize-winning Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.

headline: Mandy Patinkin: ‘I Behaved Abominably’
text: It was the fifth take, or maybe the seventh or maybe the ninth. Down in the bowels of Langley, or at least in its reasonable facsimile in Charlotte, N.C., where Showtime’s “Homeland” is shot, Saul Berenson, currently the acting director of the C.I.A., was talking to a new hire, a young analyst, Fara Sherazi. Abu Nazir, the mastermind terrorist, was still dead. They were chasing someone else now. There’s always someone else.

headline: Editing Pictures, Influencing Photographers
text: Not only do photojournalists get to travel the world, wear funky scarves and meet all kinds of people, they usually get their name underneath their images when they are published in magazines and newspapers or online. Photo editors, on the other hand, are usually stuck in an office, toiling anonymously. No matter how good a job they do, their name won’t appear in the newspaper the next day. (Unless they commit a crime.)

headline: New Chief at Vestas, Ailing Maker of Wind Turbines
text: LONDON — Vestas, the Danish wind turbine maker that once led the industry but that has struggled in recent years, ousted its chief executive on Wednesday and appointed a successor, while also reporting another quarter of lackluster results.

headline: Study of 2012 Movies Finds Few Gay Characters on Big Screen
text: In its first substantial study of releases from the major film studios, the media watchdog group Glaad faulted Hollywood for its lack of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (L.G.B.T.) characters last year. This study, issued by Glaad on Wednesday and titled “2013 Studio Responsibility Index,” found that of 101 films from the six major studios in 2012, 14 included characters who were identified as lesbian, gay or bisexual, and none who were transgender.

headline: The Twists and Turns of Owning a 1965 Chevrolet Corvair
text: The Corvair broke down the day after I bought it. It was hard enough to kick my daily driver out of the garage, but now the yellow Monza coupe, which I had just driven 180 miles from the outskirts of Chicago to Indianapolis without incident, refused to accelerate. Buyer’s remorse began to set in.

headline: New York Today: Another Chance to Debate
text: Updated, 8:40 a.m. | The first televised general topic debate for the Democratic nomination that features all seven main mayoral candidates can be seen tonight at 7 p.m. on NY1.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook Leads Effort to Widen the Net
text: About one of every seven people in the world uses Facebook. Now, Mark Zuckerberg, its co-founder and chief executive, wants to make a play for the rest — including the four billion or so who lack Internet access, Vindu Goel reports.

headline: Student Crossword | Musical Instruments
text: Learn more about musical instruments by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: A Bangalore Ambulance Driver’s Battle With Traffic
text: BANGALORE— Srirangaiah, 55, is an expert – and somewhat maniacal – Bangalore driver.  Day after day, he dangerously hops lanes in traffic. He deliberately jumps red lights and speeds the wrong way on one-way streets. Often, he hurtles in the direction of oncoming traffic.

headline: The Tough Love GPS
text: I’m getting ready for a summer road trip. I had hoped to update my GPS device, but that requires a degree from M.I.T.: download a program onto the computer, get in the car with the computer and encourage the two systems to talk. That update, which I am pretty sure was some manual writer’s idea of a joke, would have turned down the volume of the iPod when directions were given instead of the current program in which the GPS Lady cannot be heard over Dion and the Belmonts, while I’m yelling: “What? What?” Then I miss the exit, and the GPS Lady, a condescending shrew who — believe me —I would never be friends with in real life, says, “Recalculating, you nitwit.”

headline: Business for Sale: Would You Pay $2.5 Million?
text: In my posts, I occasionally take a look at businesses for sale, which can offer interesting lessons in both how to market a business and how to buy one. For this post, we’ll look at a distributor of electrical components. This company has been in business for more than 20 years and is on track to do almost $12 million in sales this year.

headline: Rupee Suffers Another Record Low
text: HONG KONG — The beleaguered Indian rupee continued its steep descent on Wednesday, hitting a record low of 64.54 to the dollar amid global nervousness about the timing and scale of the Federal Reserve’s likely scaling back of its bond-buying program.

headline: ‘The Show’ at Tatiana Restaurant
text: At the Brighton Beach establishment, weekend patrons can watch a half-hour show that includes dance, acrobatics, and fire spinning.

headline: Advice on Addiction in Boomers, Part 1
text: Readers have been sending questions about baby boomers and addiction to Dr. Barbara Krantz, an addiction expert at the Hanley Center, a nonprofit addiction recovery center in West Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Between Bites, Catch the Tour Jetés
text: It’s good and true that there are still places in New York that take you out of New York. But Tatiana feels like a hallucination.

headline: Wall Street Courts ‘Princelings’
text: Wall Street’s biggest banks have for years hired the children of senior Chinese government officials in the hopes that they can open doors and secure deals, David Barboza reports in The New York Times. The hirings, while not well publicized, were no secret. But they are gaining new attention after a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation has raised the question of whether such practices crossed a line at JPMorgan Chase.

headline: China Arrests British Adviser Hired by GlaxoSmithKline
text: SHANGHAI — The police in Shanghai have arrested a British investigator who specialized in advising foreign investors on fraud, cheating and other business risks in China, a spokeswoman for the British Embassy in Beijing said on Wednesday.

headline: Walking Zombies on the Sidewalks
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Rising Onion Prices Tempt Highway Robbers in India
text: NEW DELHI— On Saturday night, Mintu Chottelal, 30, a truck driver, and his helper, Rinku Gujjar, 19, were driving along the Delhi-Jaipur Highway on their way from the town of Nagore in Rajasthan to the town of Meerut in Uttar Pradesh. Suddenly, a minivan came to a halt in front of them. Three men jumped off the vehicle, overpowered Mr. Chottelal and Mr. Gujjar, and drove away with their loot.

headline: Other Voices: Sturgeon Moon
text: I occasionally try to draw attention to the work of other communicators focused on sustaining a thriving planet through the age of man. Lynne Cherry, Carl Safina and Nick Brandt come to mind. Today I’d like you to get to know my friend John Cronin.

headline: A Much-Needed Treat, and a Welcome Surprise
text: It was an uneventful Saturday afternoon, the day I ended up crying in the drive-through at my local Starbucks. It was my turn to do the grocery shopping, and I had just completed my wife’s book-length shopping list at the Walmart across the street when she sent me a text message:

headline: A Back-to-School Booklist for New Readers
text: From KJ Dell’Antonia: As even the youngest children prepare to head back to school after the long summer break, many of us are trying to get our kids’ heads back in the school game. One way to get children ready for more time spent at desks or in circles, thinking and writing and drawing instead of running and jumping and rolling, is to ramp up our time spent reading and looking at books at home.

headline: Mubarak to Be Transferred to House Arrest
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s military-appointed government ordered former President Hosni Mubarak transferred from prison to house arrest late Wednesday after a court said he could no longer legally be held behind bars.

headline: The Real Future of Clean Water
text: What would it take to ensure that everyone in the world had access to clean water? I’m prompted to ask this question in response to a recent New York Times Magazine article, which focused on Charity: Water, an organization that has reportedly raised $100 million to finance water projects in the developing world, making it the largest water-focused nonprofit in the United States.

headline: Another Euro Teaser From VW: The Golf R
text: So far this year, Volkswagen has released the Golf GTI, Golf GTD, Golf Variant and Golf TDI BlueMotion. The automaker announced the latest weapon in its Golf arsenal on Tuesday: the Golf R, which it said would be the nameplate’s flagship.

headline: Aug. 21: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Bloomberg to Increase Oversight After Privacy Lapses
text: Updated, 8:10 p.m. | Bloomberg L.P. said on Wednesday that it was making several changes to its journalism operation after an investigation commissioned by the company detailed problems with the past use of client data.

headline: Marian McPartland, Jazz Pianist and NPR Radio Staple, Dies at 95
text: Marian McPartland, the genteel Englishwoman who became a fixture of the American jazz scene as a pianist and, later in life, hosted the internationally syndicated and immensely popular public radio show “Marian McPartland’s Piano Jazz,” died on Tuesday at her home in Port Washington, N.Y. She was 95.

headline: A Dream Revisited
text: Fifty years have passed since the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his famous “I Have a Dream” speech during the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom in 1963. “Martin & Mahalia: His Words, Her Song” and “My Daddy, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.,” two new picture books, use expressive illustrations and powerful text to educate young readers about the effects of prejudice, and to advocate for change.

headline: Manning Sentenced to 35 Years for a Pivotal Leak of U.S. Files
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — A military judge sentenced Pfc. Bradley Manning on Wednesday to 35 years in prison for providing more than 700,000 government files to WikiLeaks, a gigantic leak that lifted the veil on American military and diplomatic activities around the world.

headline: Ackman Acknowledges ‘Mistakes’ in Letter to Investors
text: The activist investor William A. Ackman finds he is being held to account.

headline: Guns, Guns and More Guns
text: The array of weapons was alarming. Large caliber pistols and a semi-automatic Soviet-era rifle were among the 254 firearms on display Monday as part of the largest gun seizure in New York City history.

headline: Supplements Fail to Relieve Joint Pain in Study
text: Joint pain and swelling in postmenopausal women is common, and some studies have suggested that one cause may be low vitamin D and calcium levels. But a randomized clinical trial found that vitamin D and calcium supplements are no better than a placebo for relieving joint problems.

headline: For Kids, a History App Meant for Museums
text: How to get a kid jazzed about the oldest stories in the world in an age of distraction? Make a game of it. That’s the idea behind History Hero, a new app for portable Apple devices that asks children to defend history – for video-game-style points — against an alien group known as the Erasers.

headline: High on Landmark Panel’s List: A Post Office Lobby
text: No one has ever said that the Bronx has more than enough grand civic spaces, where citizens feel ennobled just by walking through the doors.

headline: Listen Up | Three Indie Frontwomen Who Are Leading the Pack
text: The singers of Braids, Hunters and Diana are not so quietly making some of indie rock’s most innovative music.

headline: In a Montreal Neighborhood, Barbershops and Bars
text: A semi-industrial no man’s land stirs with new life and acquires a new nickname in the process.

headline: In Store | Santi Moix's Mural at Prada
text: The Spanish artist transformed the brand's Rem Koolhaas-designed SoHo store, a process captured in this exclusive time-lapse video.

headline: Cannabis Country
text: BUENOS AIRES — For the people of Buenos Aires, Uruguay, the small country just across the Río de la Plata estuary, can seem like paradise. It’s not just about the beaches; the place has also become a darling of foreign investors even while passing the most progressive social policies in Latin America.

headline: On Set | The Frontwomen of the Future
text: The lead singers of Braids, Hunters and Diana talked to T about everything from their personal style to female icons.

headline: Masaharu Morimoto’s Tribeca Canvas Is Closing
text: Masaharu Morimoto is closing his restaurant Tribeca Canvas less than a year after it opened to tepid reviews, and he will reopen it next month with new partners and a revamped menu. At Tribeca Canvas, Mr. Morimoto, formerly of Nobu, created his take on Asian-style comfort food. He will continue as chef at the new restaurant, to be called Canvas, with his new partners, Patrick Fahey of the Macao Trading Co. and Emmanuelle LaSalle Hill and Tommy Hill, partners at Los Americanos in Chelsea. The restaurant, which will stay at 313 Church Street, will be redesigned.

headline: 2009 And All That
text: There has been a lot of commentary on Neil Irwin’s report on why the White House doesn’t want Janet Yellen to chair the Fed, with good reason. The merits of Yellen versus Summers aside, it sounds as if the WH wants Summers, and doesn’t want Yellen, for all the wrong reasons. They want a team player — and consider Yellen’s somewhat independent stance as a liability, even though she has been consistently right. They consider Yellen diminished because she wasn’t part of the team making policy in 2009 — when most people outside the WH don’t consider 2009 anything like a policy triumph.

headline: The Point of Economath
text: Noah Smith has a fairly caustic meditation on the role of math in economics, in which he says that it’s nothing like the role of math in physics — and suggests that it’s mainly about doing hard stuff to prove that you’re smart.

headline: Weighing In on Bloomberg’s Legacy
text: Notable New Yorkers reflect on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s accomplishments as he gets ready to leave office.

headline: Jasper Johns: Gray
text: Images from the show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Wind Farms Take Root Out at Sea
text: BREMEN, Germany — In a warehouse district on the outskirts of Bremen in northwestern Germany is a big, well-lighted work space dominated by the massive top section of a wind turbine called a nacelle.

headline: Would a Gay Man Be Welcomed Home in Montana?
text: A few years ago, the band Little Big Town had a hit song called “Boondocks.” It was a twangy, boot-stompin’ ditty about the raptures of rural living: “I feel no shame. I’m proud of where I came from. I was born and raised in the boondocks.”

headline: Your First Theater Crush
text: This summer, a number of New York Times critics have written about their cultural first crushes — the moments or works that prompted them to write about the arts. A new essay was published each week, paired with stories from readers who work within the given discipline about their own cultural epiphanies.

headline: Image of the Day: August 21
text: A man working on environmentally friendly models of Hindu god Lord Ganesh in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh.

headline: In Store | At Prada, a Provocative Mural by Santi Moix
text: We live in an era of increased security, but still the Spanish painter Santi Moix was stunned by the number of men in black who circled him during the 48 hours he recently spent inside the Prada Epicenter store in SoHo. “Tons of them, looking like secret agents” kept tabs on him, he said, as he temporarily transformed the Rem Koolhaas-designed space. “Now you can go to Gagosian, they have security everywhere,” he added, “but Prada was the first to have protection for the bags and the shoes.”

headline: ‘Read It Very Slowly’
text: On Aug. 14, 1863, James C. Conkling invited President Abraham Lincoln to Springfield to attend a mass rally of “Unconditional Union men” on Sept. 3. Conkling was a former mayor of Springfield and a member of the Illinois House of Representatives. In a letter of introduction earlier that year, the president called him “my personal friend of long standing.”

headline: A Ship Capsizes, and a Boy’s Heart Leaps
text: Nobody is born with good taste. Or bad taste, either. A sensibility is developed only over many years. Innate sympathies are cultivated or coarsened by contact with whatever aspects of culture you happen to come across, or later search out, as your worldview opens up beyond the realms of immediate need — food, drink, toys! — to the more complicated constructs that, at their best, we call art.

headline: Video Chat on Canning Blueberry Jam
text: Right now you can still eat berries straight off the bush, but come winter, a warm piece of toast topped with a sweet blueberry jam may just hit the spot.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'The World's End'
text: Edgar Wright, the director of “The World’s End,” narrates the opening sequence from his film.

headline: De Blasio Campaign in Fight Over Money From Alec Baldwin Fund-Raiser
text: The dinner was one of the early highlights of Bill de Blasio’s campaign for mayor — supporters were asked to make a donation, of any amount, and they would then have an opportunity to attend a dinner with Alec Baldwin.

headline: Drip Drip: More N.S.A. Revelations
text: Every few days, we learn that the government’s constitutionally dubious dragnet of telephone and Internet communications is broader, deeper and even more intrusive than we thought.

headline: The Next Branding of Detroit
text: YOU BEGIN TO SHOP Shinola not at its new TriBeCa flagship, but somewhere back in your teenage years, when social causes were first stamped into your consciousness, when you were first taught that your dollar has not just purchasing power, but also ideological power.

headline: JPMorgan Chase Not Akin to Nazis, Report Finds
text: An outside review of Bloomberg L.P.’s practices found that a controversial article that compared the damage in an Italian town after a bad deal with JPMorgan Chase to the fallout from the Nazis’ occupation in World War II went “too far.”

headline: Newly Released Tapes Show Nixon Maneuvering as Watergate Unfolds
text: WASHINGTON — Just hours after a national address promising “no whitewash” of Watergate, President Richard M. Nixon privately urged his new attorney general not to appoint a special prosecutor and suggested that a former aide avoid questions by asserting national security.

headline: Why the Nest Isn’t So Empty Anymore
text: My husband and I recently ended a child-free month. Our 15-year-old son was away at camp, and our 21-year-old daughter — who attends a nearby college and often comes home during the school year — had a summer internship in New York. The time with just the two of us was blissful.

headline: 'Respect'
text: Anthony D. Weiner's latest television advertisement focuses on his plan to change stop-and-frisk.

headline: Calling No Witnesses, Defendant in Fort Hood Shooting Rests His Case
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — Months after deciding to act as his own lawyer, Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan declined to present a defense in his military trial on Wednesday, passing up an opportunity to counter hundreds of witnesses and pieces of evidence prosecutors have used to persuade a jury to find him guilty of murdering and wounding dozens of unarmed soldiers in 2009.

headline: Study Ties Poor Oral Health to Cancer-Causing Virus
text: People with swollen gums, missing teeth and other signs of poor dental health are more likely to be infected orally with the human papillomavirus, researchers reported on Wednesday.

headline: Laws of Attraction
text: I was at a party with the actor James Gandolfini about two weeks before he died. It was a wedding in Hollywood, and around midnight he was pouring shots of tequila for a group of men who would have laughed — slamming another Don Julio — to learn that the major preoccupation of our time is whether one is beautiful or not. Gandolfini himself was 51: he was grizzled, overweight, red in the face and complex in the soul, but to many people, men and women, he had never looked better in his life. (“I would,” a woman back at my table said.) In this not entirely fair world of ours, men, as they grow older, get to look distinguished, while women often feel they disappear. The actor toasted the stars and drank as if the only thing that told on you was your experience. He was near the end, God bless him, but he didn’t go out wishing he was somebody else.

headline: 2013 Fantasy Football Player Rankings
text: Rankings will be updated each week throughout the regular season. Follow Jason and Justin Sablich on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Weiner Seeks Middle Ground on Stop-and-Frisk Issue
text: In the white-hot debate over stop-and-frisk policing, Anthony D. Weiner, the mayoral candidate and former United States representative, is seeking middle ground. Mr. Weiner’s campaign began running a 30-second television advertisement on Monday that seemed aimed at New Yorkers skeptical of the stop-and-frisk policy. But he also suggested he would keep tough crime-fighting tools in place.

headline: Devices Lead the Way to a Smarter TV
text: Someday, our televisions will be smart. With a flick of the wrist or a voice command, couch potatoes will be able to binge-view “Scandal” or children will watch any episode of the Disney series “Dog With a Blog.” Maybe just thinking about Walter White will bring up “Breaking Bad” on the big screen.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene Video: ‘The World’s End’
text: The director Edgar Wright has teamed up again with the actors Simon Pegg and Nick Frost to make his latest comedy, “The World’s End.” In this video, he narrates a segment from the film’s opening sequence, a prologue set in 1990. He discusses using 16-millimeter film to shoot the sequence and using prosthetics on some of his young actors.

headline: Cabby Had Violations Before Crash in Midtown
text: The cabdriver who slammed into a cyclist and severed the lower left leg of a British tourist in Midtown faces the suspension of his cab license, the Taxi and Limousine Commission said on Wednesday, and officials said such a move could have been taken as early as April based on his driving record.

headline: Video Shows Victims of Suspected Syrian Chemical Attack
text: Last Updated, 5:40 p.m. | As my colleagues Ben Hubbard and Hwaida Saad report from Beirut, antigovernment activists accused the Syrian government of deploying chemical weapons in a string of towns in the rebellious countryside east of the capital, Damascus, on Wednesday, killing hundreds of men, women and children.

headline: Household Income’s Slow Climb Back
text: While median household income has risen slightly over the past two years, it is still 6.1 percent lower than it was when the recession began, according to two former Census Bureau officials.

headline: Why R.B.S. Should List Its Bank Branches
text: The Royal Bank of Scotland should list the branches it must shed, not sell them. The British bank is likely to decide shortly between three bids for the assets that the European Commission wants it to offload, after a failed attempt last year to sell them to Santander. The best choice would be one that allows R.B.S. to share in any upside.

text: James Franco, who has portrayed a demented artist named Franco on “General Hospital” and displayed his own work in exhibitions in Los Angeles and New York, among other pursuits, will host and produce an hourlong show about art for the Ovation network.

text: ROCK HILL, S.C. — The legend of Jadeveon Clowney began on Carolina Avenue.

text: Median household income has begun to recover over the last two years, but households still have not come close to regaining the purchasing power they had before the financial crisis began, a new study says.

text: You release the pitch, you see a flash of white and you try to react. It is not much of a defense, but for a pitcher facing a line drive from less than 60 feet away, there is nothing else to do.

headline: Countdown to Fashion Week: Thank the Deli for That Dress
text: Just past the sheer curtains marking the entry to Sally LaPointe’s studio and workshop on Thompson Street in SoHo, things were in a state of flux. Strips of organza and georgette wafted, neglected, from an inspiration board. Alongside them were rows of photographs showing floral bouquets in sundry stages of decline. The desiccated originals were tacked to a third board nearby.

headline: ‘Old Jews’ to Stop Telling Its Jokes in New York
text: After a healthy 15-month run, “Old Jews Telling Jokes,” the revue of Jewish-themed comedic songs and ethnic humor, will close on Sept. 15 at the Westside Theater, the show’s producers announced on Tuesday. (A sample gag: Why don’t Jewish mothers drink? They don’t want to dull the pain.) When it closes the show will have played 22 previews and 552 regular performances.

headline: Senior House Democrat Sues I.R.S. Over Tax Exemptions
text: Representative Chris Van Hollen filed suit in Federal District Court on Wednesday to force the Internal Revenue Service to block tax-exempt “social welfare” organizations from engaging in any overt political activity.

headline: Tension Rises for Trial of Ex-Party Leader in China
text: JINAN, China — The trial of Bo Xilai, the fallen Communist Party aristocrat, began Thursday morning in a closed-door hearing in this eastern provincial capital, after security officers, journalists and some supporters of the charismatic Mr. Bo had fanned out in the streets around a downtown courthouse, looking for signs of how the session might unfold.

text: Aditya Pipersenia came to New York as a graduate student at Columbia University, living in a dorm room at International House. After three years there, having graduated and begun work as a software developer for a bank downtown, it was time for him to leave.

headline: Choosing to Die After a Struggle With Life
text: Peggy Battin and her husband, Brooke Hopkins, were the subjects of my cover story last month on decision-making at the end of life. Peggy is a philosopher known for her defense of people’s right to choose the manner and timing of their own death. Brooke, a former English professor, was paralyzed in a bicycle accident in late 2008 and held on to life with a vengeance for almost five years. On Saturday, July 27, six days after the article was published in print, he finally decided he’d had enough.

text: Katy Perry has made a splash with her latest single, “Roar,” selling more downloads in a week than any other song this year. But it was not quite enough to make her No. 1 on Billboard’s official singles chart.

text: Needing to abide by their tribe’s traditions of modesty, Hasidic women want the city to post a female lifeguard during a women-only swim session at a municipal pool in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and have lobbied a local councilman to take up their cause.

text: David D. Kirkpatrick, the Cairo bureau chief of The New York Times, answered questions from readers on Twitter on Wednesday about the political crisis in Egypt. Readers asked about a variety of issues, including the possible release of former President Hosni Mubarak, the recent wave of attacks against the Christian minority, Saudi Arabia's role in the crisis and how Egypt's liberals have responded to the interim government's assault on the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Charcoal in Beauty Products
text: Charcoal, long used as a purifier in air filters and fish tanks, is cropping up in beauty products. Proponents say it helps to naturally draw impurities and excess oil out of the skin, and works as a detoxifier. Many of the products use activated charcoal, which has been treated with oxygen to increase the pores on its surface area, which supposedly improves filtration.

headline: Lunchables, the Lunchbox King, Faces a Rival Vowing Higher-Quality Fare
text: Until now, there have been Lunchables and, well, Lunchables.

headline: Cyprus Bank’s Bailout Hands Ownership to Russian Plutocrats
text: LIMASSOL, Cyprus — When European leaders engineered a harsh bailout deal for this tiny Mediterranean nation in March, they cheered the end of an economic model fueled by a flood of cash from Russia. Wealthy Russians with money in Cyprus’s sickly banks lost billions.

headline: Learning to Read, With the Help of a Tablet
text: I learned long ago that the iPad’s game and video apps cast a magical spell over my children, but this summer I’ve also been pleased by how much they have learned while using their tablets. This is important, as my 4-year-old is going to “real” school for the first time. His reading skills, in particular, have been helped by some great apps. These have helped him move from knowing shapes and sounds of letters to actually reading words.

headline: In ‘Blue Jasmine,’ Suzy Benzinger Turns Clothes Into Characters
text: When awards season rolls around, and other actresses start slinking for the exits as Cate Blanchett collects all the statuary for her virtuosic turn in Woody Allen’s “Blue Jasmine,” one crucial aspect of her characterization may be overlooked.

headline: Maine Republicans to G.O.P.: You’re Too Liberal
text: Thirteen leaders of the Maine Republican Party announced this week that they were leaving the party in protest of its current path. One might assume that they’d finally had enough with Tea Party nihilism, or the preference for ideology over governing, or indifference to the poor, women’s rights, immigrants and the environment.

headline: In Store | Nike’s Newest Collection Looks Runway Ready
text: Fleece doesn’t exactly scream “high fashion,” despite a recent trend among top men’s wear designers to insert athletic-inspired elements into their collections. But a new line of Nike active wear has elevated the utilitarian sports fabric. The Nike Tech Fleece Collection, available Aug. 29, features five pieces of casual sportswear made from Nike’s reinvented fabric — a plush foam core sandwiched between layers of smooth cotton jersey, which is both warmer and lighter than standard fleece. Cut in slimmer silhouettes with minimal topstitching and seaming, the jackets, sweatshirts and sweatpants have a modern, clean look that is as ready for the runway as it is for the gym.

headline: As Tennis Stats Proliferate, Software Tries to Make Sense of It All
text: When fans think of statistics, baseball, football and basketball often come to mind first. But motion-capture cameras and other automated technologies are ubiquitous enough that a sport like tennis is being overrun with data not only on aces, double faults and first-serve percentages, but also on more subtle statistics like break-point conversions, net approaches and unforced errors.

headline: 36 Hours in Izmir, Turkey
text: “Infidel Izmir.” That’s the nickname that was long ago bestowed on Turkey’s third-largest metropolis. Known for most of its history as Smyrna, this port city was, in Ottoman times, a melting pot that included Greeks, Armenians, Jews, French and Italians. Today’s Izmir is largely Turkish, but the moniker lingers. For religious Turks, the label seems appropriate for this sunny, palm-fringed seaside city, with its relaxed attitudes and many nonobservant Muslims. For most residents, though, the nickname is proof of Izmir’s progressiveness. Reverential images of Ataturk, the founder of modern secular Turkey, are everywhere, and in June many in the city protested against Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan after his Islamist-inspired government cracked down on peaceful demonstrators in Istanbul who had mobilized to save a city park from developers. Izmir — which is among four international cities that are vying to hold the World Expo in 2020 — has much to offer visitors: a renovated waterfront, an ever-evolving night-life district and slick new design hotels. Meanwhile, a vast traditional bazaar and the spectacular nearby ruins of Ephesus bear witness to a rich past.

headline: Near Qingdao, Hiking a Magical Mountain
text: The sun was low and the air still hot when I swallowed the last drops from my canteen. My companion and I were hiking up the southern pass of Laoshan, a mountain of sun-bleached granite and hidden oases, rising over the Yellow Sea on China’s eastern shore.

headline: ‘SNL’ Through the Years

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 1 P.M. (IFC) THE CABLE GUY (1996) Jim Carrey plays Chip Douglas, a sociopathic cable television installer who first invades the home and then the personal and professional life of Steven M. Kovacs (Matthew Broderick, above left, with Mr. Carrey) in this dark comedy directed by Ben Stiller. Jack Black is the friend who warns Steven that Chip is not as harmless he initially appears. “Mr. Carrey, who won legions of fans just by speaking from his buttocks, now tries the creepy gambit of talking with a lisp, sneering at strangers, behaving like a deranged stalker and wallowing in sad, stale references to ancient television shows,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. His character “is a pure creature of the television age, and the film suggests he is to be both pitied and tuned out.”

headline: Comments by de Blasio’s Wife Lead to Dispute With Quinn
text: Two Democratic front-runners, Bill de Blasio and Christine C. Quinn, on Wednesday got into an ugly dispute over whether Mr. de Blasio’s wife had suggested that Ms. Quinn could not understand the problems of parents because she did not have children herself.

headline: Trailing in Polls, Stringer Woos Black Voters
text: With polls showing Eliot Spitzer leading in the Democratic primary for New York City comptroller, buoyed by strong support among African-Americans, his opponent, Scott M. Stringer, is stepping up his efforts to reach black voters.

headline: Riding Away From a Bar Crawl With Citi Bikes
text: It started as a normal date night: Shawn, a bearded graduate student who favors lumberjack plaid, went to Williamsburg for dinner and drinks with his girlfriend. But instead of taking the L train from their Chelsea apartment, they decided to ride Citi Bikes there and back.

headline: A Quartet, a Quarter of It New, Plays On
text: First of all, for those who were wondering: They’re still standing. The podium is the same, too, only there’s a different man sitting on it. On Monday evening, the Emerson String Quartet made its first New York City appearance with its new cellist, Paul Watkins, who took over the seat vacated by David Finckel early this summer. Playing to a packed Alice Tully Hall in its customary manner — the cellist sitting on a raised platform, the other three standing — the “new” Emerson Quartet sounded and looked enthused, at ease and passionately engaged with the music.

headline: Hazare Embarks on His Next Movement
text: Two years ago, public disgust over the depth of corruption in India boiled over into huge protests led by the longtime social activist Anna Hazare. His nearly two-week hunger strike brought out hundreds of thousands of people and forced lawmakers to support his legislative proposal to create an independent anticorruption agency, known as Lokpal.

headline: Elmore Leonard: A Man of Few, Yet Perfect, Words
text: When “Freaky Deaky” came out in 1988, Elmore Leonard’s writing credo hadn’t quite kicked in yet. Though he would later deliver 10 great rules for writing with streamlined tough-guy elegance, the dedication for “Freaky Deaky” thanked his wife for giving him “a certain look when I write too many words.”

headline: In Store | Illesteva Totes Out New Line of Handbags
text: Handbags are the latest offering from Illesteva, the accessories brand that first drew a celebrity following with eyewear in 2009 and has since added umbrellas and collaborations with the likes of Zac Posen and Dasha Zhukova to its repertory. Alina Silberman, who founded the line along with her brother Daniel Silberman and their friend Justin Salguero, came up with the idea. “It wasn’t planned, to be honest,” she said. “I just really wanted to do it. I thought it was too expensive, what was out there, and I thought we could do it better.” The collection, which includes chic clutches and round purses, isn’t just for women. Daniel said he has been traveling the past month with the backpack, one of the four designs that are available at illesteva.com, some of which will be for sale at Barneys New York early next month. Since the team often flies between New York, where the boys live, and Germany, Italy and France, where their glasses are manufactured, travel was a big inspiration for the project.

headline: Marketers Invade Montauk This Summer
text: It was a balmy afternoon at the Montauk Beach House, and the English pop singer Natalia Kills was performing before 500 fans. Dark-haired models worked the pool deck in colorful skirts and tops by Milly. In the pool, a sea of toned guys in reflective sunglasses and fedoras drank Heinekens.

headline: In Toasting a Composer, Sound Itself Is Celebrated
text: During the International Contemporary Ensemble’s concert in the intimate black box Clark Studio Theater on Tuesday evening, the composer Pauline Oliveros stood in front of the audience and listened intently as various popping, gurgling and breathy sounds unfolded around her.

headline: Gen Y and Boomers, Suffering the Most
text: As my colleague Robert Pear reports, a new study from Sentier Research finds that four years after the start of the economic recovery, the median American household income is still down 4.4 percent. Incomes have risen a little since their recent trough in August 2011, but not enough to make up for the losses sustained earlier.

headline: What Does Tory Burch Want?
text: Flip through stacks of glossy magazines, and you are all but guaranteed to find Tory Burch, the designer who has built an empire on tunics and gold-medallioned flats.

headline: A Simple Shape Wrapped in Complexity
text: In 2011, William Sofield, a designer with a classical bent, created furniture for the San Francisco company McGuire, including a popular chair called Cocoon. Made of walnut wrapped in Danish cord, it was his homage to American rush seating. “I wanted to create a fairly iconic chair where all the complications came from the geometries of the cord,” he said.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘Brenda’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 25. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.Given that she’s the title character of Cory Finley’s comedy, Brenda Garrison takes a long time to arrive. (Too long.) Rather, it’s her feckless son Wallace (Sam Bolen) who guides us into a cockeyed world that includes his lunkheaded jock roommate, Mike (Bill Coyne), and Jen (Emily Kron), a high-strung co-worker at the Best Cosmetics counter.

headline: A 500-Year Bond Reflected in Porcelain
text: There are many ways to mark a 500-year-old cultural exchange between Portugal and Brazil. Transatlântica tableware from the Portuguese company Vista Alegre does it with cobalt, gold and tiny sea horses and firearms.

headline: Surf Style Meets Japanese Artistry
text: Last month, while visiting the Los Angeles neighborhood of Venice, I had the exhilarating (and financially dangerous) shopping experience of walking into the Tortoise General Store. The boutique, which features the work of Japanese artists, was hosting a pop-up shop for Stussy Livin’ General Store, the lifestyle offshoot of the California surfwear brand, and between the two it was a feast of Pacific design.

headline: Please Pet the Geranium
text: Next month, the Dallas Arboretum will open the Rory Meyers Children’s Adventure Garden, an eight-acre, $62 million, mostly open-air learning center. The 150 interactive exhibits include an edible garden, a treetop walkway, a native wetlands ecosystem, and a lab for solving nature mysteries “CSI”-style. Designed to teach children the life and earth sciences, the garden has been a 17-year project of Maria Conroy, the arboretum’s vice president for education and a former elementary school teacher.

headline: Sales at Desiron, Mondo Collection and Others
text: All furniture floor models and warehouse inventory are up to 70 percent off at Desiron, Aug. 26 through Sept. 7 (the Hudson Sofa, originally $8,320, will be $4,160); 200 Lexington Avenue (East 32nd Street), Suite 702, (212) 353-2600, desiron.com.

headline: Revisiting the ’80s
text: A quirky West Village co-op gets a facelift for a new owner.

headline: Left Over, Reshaped, and Ready to Roll
text: Like many woodworkers, Michael Robbins was lured to the Hudson Valley by affordable old barns and access to what he claims are the best hardwoods in the country. The 30-year-old, from Oneida, N.Y., introduced a collection of tables, chairs and lamps two years ago, and found himself with a pile of leftover wood pieces. Those scraps of white ash, walnut, maple, sycamore and catalpa have now found life as rolling pins.

headline: Still Kooky After All These Years
text: Merrill Rose took one look at the wildly eccentric apartment on Fifth Avenue in Greenwich Village, with its fanciful yacht-like features and campy, round loft bedroom, and knew it was all wrong for her. There was far too much lacquer and Art Deco for her traditional Southern taste. And yet she tingled at the thought of waking up every day in such a whimsically conjured space.

headline: Turning a Small Room Into a Big Closet
text: Q. Our house has five small bedrooms. Would converting one into a large walk-in closet for the master bedroom be good for resale?

But Carla Kihlstedt and Matthias Bossi were feeling more than the usual sense of urgency when they came up with a novel plan, a subscription Web site, Rabbit Rabbit Radio, to distribute new music by their latest band, Rabbit Rabbit.

headline: By Royal Decree, the Children Get the Power
text: Sometimes it seems that nothing changes faster than the moods and minds of children: They jump for joy one minute, cry in despair the next. The toy or game they love now may bore them next week. But how can you expect consistency? They’re kids.

headline: Pink Robots at the Gate
text: PALM SPRINGS, CALIF. — Kenny Irwin Jr. is not one of those brooding, creatively blocked artists, as one glance at his father’s backyard confirms. Ken Irwin Sr. once owned a pristine two-acre spread in a prized part of town. Then he made the generous or foolish decision, depending on your viewpoint, to hand over the property to his son as a place to build and display the astonishing over-scaled sculptures that Kenny Jr. makes by fusing found materials with tons of glue.

headline: This Higher Education in Argentina Is All Politics
text: The hero of Santiago Mitre’s film “El Estudiante” (“The Student”) is just that, a student. Roque has come to Buenos Aires from the provinces to go to a university. But what he learns has little to do with the classroom, although we see him in one now and again, engulfed in heated arguments about Machiavelli and Marx.

headline: Biden’s Son to Be Released From Houston Hospital

headline: Secret Court Rebuked N.S.A. on Surveillance

headline: Fix the Census’ Archaic Racial Categories
text: STARTING in 1790, and every 10 years since, the census has sorted the American population into distinct racial groups. Remarkably, a discredited relic of 18th-century science, the “five races of mankind,” lives on in the 21st century. Today, the census calls these five races white; black; American Indian or Alaska Native; Asian; and Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander.

headline: Imagining the Court
text: It’s unlikely that the Supreme Court will get its hands on Federal District Judge Shira A. Scheindlin’s ruling that New York City’s aggressive stop-and-frisk police tactics violated the constitutional rights of the minorities whose communities the police targeted. The Democratic candidates running to succeed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who is appealing the decision, have vowed to overhaul the stop-and-frisk approach and end the city’s appeal. Because the plaintiffs in the lawsuit, Floyd v. City of New York, requested only an injunction and not monetary damages, in all likelihood there will be no case left after Inauguration Day.

headline: Shadowy Inauguration for Sunshine Law
text: The New York state ethics commission voted behind closed doors last June to exempt a leading abortion-rights group, Naral Pro-Choice New York, from a new ethics law requiring tax-exempt organizations to disclose their major donors as they lobby in public forums. The action is causing understandable controversy and cries of liberal bias. It should be reconsidered — out in the open and in the spirit of the law’s goal to shed more sunshine, not less, on the entwined workings of government and political lobbying.

headline: Bradley Manning’s Excessive Sentence
text: The 35-year sentence a military judge imposed on Pfc. Bradley Manning Wednesday morning was in some sense a vindication of his defense: following his conviction last month on charges of violating the Espionage Act, Private Manning faced up to 90 years in prison. He had previously pleaded guilty to lesser versions of those crimes that exposed him to 20 years behind bars. For a defense lawyer, a sentence of one-third the potential maximum is usually not a bad outcome. But from where we sit, it is still too much, given his stated desire not to betray his country but to encourage debate on American aims and shed light on the “day to day” realities of the American war effort.

headline: Pardon Rates Remain Low
text: Attorney General Eric Holder said many encouraging things in his important speech on the future of sentencing reform, but the most striking thing may have been what he did not say. In all his 4,000 words on America’s “broken” legal system — and particularly on its outlandishly harsh and ineffective sentencing laws — there was not one mention of executive clemency.

headline: Georgia: Suspect in School Scare Was Heavily Armed, Police Say
text: The man accused of exchanging gunfire with the police at a Decatur elementary school was held without bond Wednesday  on charges that included aggravated assault on a police officer and terroristic threats. Investigators were trying to determine whether the man, Michael B. Hill, 20, had stolen the AK-47 they say he used in trying to seize control of the Ronald E. McNair Discovery Learning Academy on Tuesday. The police said the weapon belonged to an acquaintance of Mr. Hill, who was carrying 498 rounds of ammunition. No one was injured.

headline: Sid Bernstein, Who Helped Import the Beatles, Dies at 95

headline: Iran: Another Nuclear Official to Be Replaced
text: Iran’s longtime ambassador to the International Atomic Energy Agency will leave in September, news agencies reported Wednesday, making him the third senior Iranian nuclear official to be replaced under the new administration of President Hassan Rouhani. The ambassador, Ali Asghar Soltanieh, frequently criticized the agency, the nuclear monitoring arm of the United Nations, as well as what he views as Western bias against Iran. Mr. Rouhani, who took office this month, has vowed to pursue a more flexible approach toward resolving the dispute over Iran’s nuclear program, which many countries suspect is aimed at giving it the capability to produce nuclear weapons, despite Iranian denials. Last Friday Mr. Rouhani replaced the head of Iran’s Atomic Energy Organization, which runs the country’s nuclear facilities. On Tuesday state news media signaled that negotiations over the nuclear program would now be handled by Mr. Rouhani’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, an American-educated diplomat.

headline: Mets’ Hefner Appears Headed for Tommy John Surgery

A soldier was also seriously wounded.

headline: England: Queen’s Swan Is Barbecued and Eaten
text: The charred carcass of one of Queen Elizabeth’s own swans was found on a riverbank near Windsor Castle after having been barbecued and eaten, according to the police and a charity called Swan Lifeline. The swan was one of about 200 that live on Baths Island and belong to the queen. Until 1998, under a law dating to the 12th century, killing or injuring a swan was classified as treason, and the crown retains ownership of all unmarked mute swans in areas along the River Thames. Wild swans are also protected under a 1981 act, and to injure or kill a swan — let alone eat one — is against the law. Wendy Hermon of Swan Lifeline said that “the whole breast had been removed, and it looked like it had been eaten for lunch.” There was “just a swan skeleton left,” she said. “It’s absolutely disgusting, I can’t imagine the kind of people that would do this.” She said the carcass, with its feathers still attached, was taken by her group to be cremated.

headline: Li Na, China’s Tennis Rebel
text: The patch of Wimbledon grass known as the Graveyard of Champions was supposedly exorcised four years ago, when the blue-blazered gentlemen of the All England Lawn Tennis Club demolished Court 2, built a new grandstand in its place and, in 2011, renamed the haunted space Court 3. But the tennis fans watching the 2013 championships still knew. Li Na, China’s tennis rebel, knew, too. This was the same cursed court where top seeds like Pete Sampras and Serena Williams had suffered ignominious defeats, falling to unheralded players in the early rounds. Now Li, the former French Open champion and sixth-ranked player in the world, teetered one game away from a third-round loss to the Czech veteran Klara Zakopalova. “At that moment,” she told me later, “I suddenly saw myself with my bags going to the airport. It made my heart ache.”

headline: Generation B (For Bubble)
text: So, the flood of money into emerging markets now looks in retrospect like another bubble. For the moment, I don’t see a good reason to believe that the bursting of this particular bubble will be catastrophic — what made the Asian crisis of 1997-8 so bad was the high level of foreign-currency denominated debt, and that seems less of an issue now. In fact, the main danger, as Ryan Avent says, seems to be policy overreaction: countries raising interest rates to defend indefensible exchange rates, leading to unnecessary slumps. But I have to admit that I’m less certain than usual about my diagnosis, because I’m still coming up to speed on the Indian economy in particular.

headline: After Dodging Harassment Allegations, San Diego Mayor Is Reported Set to Resign
text: LOS ANGELES — As part of an agreement with city officials, the embattled mayor of San Diego, Bob Filner, was expected to resign on Friday, ending weeks of political turmoil over allegations that he sexually harassed more than a dozen women, officials close to the mediation effort said Thursday.

headline: ‘I Am a Female,’ Manning Announces, Asking Army for Hormone Therapy
text: WASHINGTON — One day after being sentenced to 35 years in prison for leaking vast archives of secret government files to WikiLeaks, Pfc. Bradley Manning said Thursday that he was female and that he would seek hormone therapy, setting up a potential conflict over a treatment the Army said it does not provide its inmates.

headline: The Late Unpleasantness
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Bradley Manning Sentenced
text: See no secrets, hear no secrets, tell no secrets.

headline: More Economath
text: Bryan Caplan weighs in on the math-in-economics debate, and argues that

headline: U.N. Presses Australia to Release 46 Refugees
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia’s indefinite detention of 46 recognized refugees amounts to cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment, a United Nations committee said Thursday, applying more international pressure on the government’s toughened policies toward asylum seekers.

headline: Aug. 22: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: The Bernanke Years
text: A chronology of Ben S. Bernanke’s formative years and the challenges of his tenure as Federal Reserve chairman.

headline: Comparing Immigrants to Cordwood
text: Here is a reason — a very important reason — why there needs to be a bright line separating the federal government and local police forces on immigration.

headline: A Female Gaze on Ladies Who Lust
text: Los Angeles — If you were to make a wry comedy about the plugged-in creative class, you might set it in a neighborhood like Silver Lake, the trendy, leafy enclave here, in a home like the writer-director Jill Soloway’s. Perched on a hill, it’s an airy, art-filled respite, with a color-coded library, an expansive yard decorated with bright rugs, and, in a nod to her artistic and parental temperament, a drum kit in the living room, for her husband and sons.

headline: The Audacious Pragmatist
text: SHORTLY before Ben S. Bernanke was nominated as chairman of the Federal Reserve in 2005, he paid a return visit to Stanford, where he started his academic career in 1979. In a speech, he recalled that he and his wife, Anna, had rented a house with friends because he was certain that local real estate prices would fall. Instead, prices in the Bay Area doubled, then doubled again.

headline: ‘I’ll Send You to Belize': Stars of ‘Breaking Bad’ Offered Free Vacations
text: Nothing on “Breaking Bad” is quite what it seems: a mild-mannered chemistry teacher is a powerful drug lord; a run-of-the-mill car wash is a sophisticated money-laundering operation. And a darkly comic proposal of mortal violence has led, at least, to offers of a relaxing tropical vacation for the creators and stars of this AMC drama.

headline: Cinema of Resistance
text: Select images of movies in the series at the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

headline: How Well Has The Times Advanced a Story That It Didn’t Break?
