headline: Mubarak Is Moved From Prison to House Arrest, Stoking Anger of Islamists
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s new rulers on Thursday moved former President Hosni Mubarak from a prison cell to house arrest at a military hospital, ending more than two years of incarceration but stopping short of granting him full freedom.

headline: Beethoven Comes to Kashmir
text: NEW DELHI— Zubin Mehta, the renowned Mumbai-born conductor of Western classical music, is going to perform in Srinagar, the summer capital of conflict-torn Indian-administered-Kashmir. Mr. Mehta, who has longed to perform in the Kashmir Valley, will have his wish fulfilled on September 7. Mr. Mehta and the famed Bavarian State Orchestra are scheduled to perform in Shalimar garden built by a Mughal emperor on the banks of Dal Lake in Srinagar.

headline: The Affordable Care Act and Part-Time Work
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: In Hamptons Again, Clintons Get to Work on Their Vacation
text: SAGAPONACK, N.Y. — Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton are renting a virtual Shangri-La in this lush, beachside paradise in the Hamptons. The $11 million mansion sprawls over 3.5 acres of prime real estate, with four fireplaces, six bedrooms, a heated pool and private path to the beach.

headline: Maybe the Yankees Can Have Two Parades
text: Considering the hostility between Alex Rodriguez and the Yankees’ front office, perhaps the team can arrange for there to be two victory parades if its current hot streak turns into a World Series championship in October.

headline: A Scottish Resort Has a Beef List
text: Make way, wagyu. Gleneagles resort in Scotland offers diners up to a half-dozen options of cattle breeds to choose from when selecting their steaks.

headline: For College Students, So Many Health Plans to Choose From
text: If you’re headed to college this fall, you’ve no doubt planned to pack your laptop, your bedding and your favorite music. But have you figured out your health insurance?

headline: Taking Oath, Mugabe Adds to His Rule of Zimbabwe
text: JOHANNESBURG — Robert Mugabe was sworn in as president of Zimbabwe on Thursday in a pomp-filled ceremony in the capital, Harare, that extends by five years his 33-year rule.

headline: Karl Rove Shouldn’t Pretend He Understands Health Policy
text: Austin Frakt Austin Powers Aaron Carroll points me to Karl Rove claiming that Republicans do too have health care ideas. Not surprisingly, what Rove actually does is demonstrate his party’s intellectual bankruptcy.

headline: Private Flying for (Some of) the Rest of Us
text: In less time than it takes to undergo a body scan, I breezed through the terminal and onto the tarmac.

headline: Waiting to Hear From the Doctor
text: The call came Sunday morning, just after I had returned from a bike ride on one of those rare, glorious, sunny Cleveland days.

headline: Legacy | A History of Picture-Perfect Icons at DNA
text: For the family-run DNA agency, models should be timeless icons rather than anonymous faces — and it’s been championing this idea for over half a century.

headline: Wain Kellum of Vocalocity on Winning Over Employees
text: This interview with Wain Kellum, chief executive of Vocalocity, an Internet-based business phone service, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: The Money’s Gone; the Drama Lingers
text: How to make sense of Bernard L. Madoff? After his $65 billion Ponzi scheme unraveled, cultural critics looked to literary and theatrical antecedents: the shady financier Augustus Melmotte in Anthony Trollope’s “Way We Live Now”; the corner-cutting businessman Joe Keller in Arthur Miller’s “All My Sons”; and, especially, the thieving investor in Harley Granville-Barker’s play “The Voysey Inheritance.”

headline: Image of the Day: August 22
text: A protest in New Delhi demanding pension for elderly persons from economically weaker sections of the society.

headline: Race Equality Is Still a Work in Progress, Survey Finds
text: Fewer than one in three black Americans and not even half of whites say the United States has made “a lot” of progress toward achieving racial equality in the half-century since the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. declared he had “a dream” that one day freedom, justice and brotherhood would prevail and that his children would “not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character.”

headline: The Soldier Formerly Known as Bradley Manning
text: Updated, Monday, Aug. 26 | The soldier who was sentenced as Pfc. Bradley Manning told the world Thursday that she wishes to be known from now on as Chelsea Manning.

headline: Obama’s Backup Plan on Colleges
text: White House officials are well aware that their plan to link federal financial aid to college performance faces hurdles. College presidents have generally resisted attempts to measure outcomes, and Congressional Republicans have generally resisted any domestic-policy proposal from President Obama.

headline: On a Flight Back to Cairo
text: CAIRO — The man across the aisle was reading an article headlined: “No Turning Back and No Surrender Before the Forces of Darkness.” As our plane descended over night-time Cairo, the streets were blurry in the weak city lights, and eerily empty because of a military curfew.

headline: Circumcision Rates in U.S. Drop Drastically in Western States
text: The percentage of male newborns who are circumcised in United States hospitals has dropped drastically. Over a 32-year period, the number of male newborns circumcised in the hospital decreased nationally to 58.3 percent in 2010 from 64.5 percent in 1979, according to new data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Pricing Problem Suspends Nasdaq for Three Hours
text: Updated, 9:39 p.m. | The United States stock market showed again on Thursday that it remained vulnerable to technological breakdowns even as regulators and market operators work to keep up with trading that is increasingly electronic and driven by speed.

headline: On Bus Tour, Obama Seeks to Shame Colleges Into Easing Costs
text: BUFFALO — President Obama deplored the rising costs of college on Thursday as he tried to shame universities into holding down prices. He held out the prospect of more federal student aid if they did.

headline: Obama Looks to Make College Cheaper
text: President Obama spoke at the University at Buffalo to outline his strategy for dealing with the ballooning cost of higher education.

headline: New York Film Festival Will Honor Cate Blanchett and Ralph Fiennes
text: She plays the disgraced socialite moviegoers love to hate, and he plays the noseless villain whose name you’re not supposed to say, but they’ll both be honored at the New York Film Festival. Cate Blanchett, the star of “Blue Jasmine,” and Ralph Fiennes, who portrayed Lord Voldemort in the “Harry Potter” films, will each be the subject of a gala tribute in October, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Thursday.

headline: Rockets Are Fired Toward Israel From Southern Lebanon
text: JERUSALEM — Four rockets were fired toward northern Israel from southern Lebanon on Thursday for the first time in nearly two years, according to the Israeli military. The rocket fire set off sirens in the western Galilee and raised tensions in the region against the background of the conflict in Syria.

headline: Found After Decades, a Forgotten Tape of King ‘Thinking on His Feet’
text: There are hundreds of thousands of carefully preserved manuscripts and recordings that chronicle every speech, interview and public appearance made by one of America’s greatest orators, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. At least one of his appearances, however, seems to have slipped through the cracks of time, only to be discovered nearly 50 years later in the archives of the New School.

headline: Problems With Your Gadgets? You Need a Consumer Advocate
text: I get lots and lots of e-mail. I reply to as much as I can — but certain categories, I’ll tell you right now, I can’t answer. “What should I buy?” questions, “Solve my technical problems” questions or “Endorse my book, app or product” requests. I hope it’s obvious that there’s no way I could answer all of those.

headline: The Nasdaq Is Down? It’s Time to Tweet.
text: Updated, 2:47 p.m. | When a technical problem caused the Nasdaq to halt trading in Nasdaq-listed stocks, Wall Street watchers once again turned to social media sites to share their insight.

headline: Can Cities Adjust to a Retreating Coastline?
text: Last June, in rolling out an ambitious $20-billion plan to gird New York City against the impacts of rising seas and storm surges in a warming climate, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg gave a classic “no retreat” speech, including this line:

headline: CBS Trumpets Deal With FiOS TV in Jab at Time Warner Cable
text: CBS announced Thursday morning that it had completed a new retransmission deal with Verizon’s FiOS TV service, pointedly connecting the resolution to its dispute with Time Warner Cable.

headline: A Writing Career as a Revenge Fantasy
text: Ada Calhoun, who wrote this week’s Lives essay, joins other contributors to that page in sharing the best lesson she ever received about writing.

headline: The Lawrence Massacre
text: On April 20, 1866, a letter addressed to James Knox arrived in Chesterfield, S.C. Robert E. Lee had surrendered his once-mighty Army of Northern Virginia to Ulysses S. Grant more than a year prior — but the blood of R. H. Miller, the man who had sent the letter from his home in Lawrence, Kans., was still up. Miller outlined a general list of grievances against the ex-Confederacy and then quickly turned to the real subject of his letter: the Lawrence Massacre of Aug. 21, 1863.

headline: Demographic Shifts May Help Virginia Democrats
text: WASHINGTON — For 36 years, elections for governor of Virginia have unfailingly followed this pattern: whichever political party holds the White House loses.

headline: 54 Years Of Real Interest Rates
text: Just a quick and dirty calculation: the 10-year rate minus the previous year’s core personal consumption expenditure inflation:

headline: Open’s Draw Precludes a Djokovic-Murray Final
text: The most significant news of the draw ceremony for the 2013 United States Open was made with the first chip, when the defending champion, Andy Murray, the No. 3 seed, was pulled first, putting him in the top half of the draw with top-seeded Novak Djokovic.

headline: Mubarak Leaves Prison
text: After a court ruled that he could no longer be incarcerated, Egypt’s former president, Hosni Mubarak, was moved from a Cairo prison to a military hospital.

headline: Brooklyn Bowl to Open Sister Clubs in London and Las Vegas
text: Brooklyn Bowl, one of the city’s most popular music nightspots, is expanding to two other cities, establishing clubs in London and Las Vegas, the owners said.

headline: A Few Dollars to Help a Tennis Prospect
text: After Dan Nagler graduated from St. Thomas University in 2008 with degrees in law and business, he opened a sports agency in Miami. Rather than chase the Rafael Nadals and Maria Sharapovas of the world, he wanted to seek out lesser, even struggling, professionals.

headline: Mets Add Matsuzaka and Some Intrigue for Final Weeks of the Season
text: Six years after he arrived in the United States and helped the Boston Red Sox win a World Series, pitcher Daisuke Matsuzaka became a member of the Mets.

headline: U.S. Is Suing in Texas Cases Over Voting by Minorities
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Thursday escalated its efforts to restore a stronger federal role in protecting minority voters in Texas, announcing that the Justice Department would become a plaintiff in two lawsuits against the state.

headline: Nasdaq’s Halt Briefly Pauses a Good Day for a Newly Public Company
text: Updated, 6:35 p.m. | Before the Nasdaq stock market halted trades just after noon on Thursday, Regado Biosciences had been having a pretty good day.

headline: Statement by Bo Xilai’s Son After Opening  of Trial
text: On Thursday, Li Wangzhi, the elder son of the purged Chinese official Bo Xilai, attended the opening session of Mr. Bo’s trial on charges of corruption, bribe-taking and abuse of power. It was the first time Mr. Li, a son to Mr. Bo from his first marriage, had seen his father in several years. Mr. Li released the following statement after the proceedings.

headline: F.B.I. Listed Prize-Winning Author as a Unabomber Suspect
text: William T. Vollmann probably expected to find something worth writing about in his F.B.I. file. But he did not expect to discover that he’d been listed as a suspect in the case of the Unabomber. The National Book Award winning author, known for his many works of fiction and reportage, wrote about the F.B.I.’s surveillance of him in this month’s issue of Harper’s Magazine.

headline: Sipping the Pleasures of Istria
text: On a recent afternoon, I found myself having lunch on a shaded patio about 20 feet from the banks of a placid river that empties out into the Adriatic Sea. The restaurant, Martin Pescador — named for the bird that skims the water’s surface in search of food — is in Trget, a fishing village in the region of northern Croatia known as Istria. I’d arrived there after a rough drive down a 10-mile road that hugs the Rasa River and then traverses railroad tracks and freight depots and lumberyards before dead-ending in Trget. Docked nearby were about 20 boats, the same number as residents of the village.

headline: A 3-D Scanner Reaches for the Masses
text: The 3-D printer company MakerBot on Thursday entered the new market for scanning, introducing a desktop device called the Digitizer that could help push more of the public into 3-D printing.

headline: New York Banker Arrested on Rape Charges in East Hampton
text: A Goldman Sachs banker has been charged with raping a young woman in an East Hampton rental home, the authorities announced on Thursday.

headline: Africa and Pakistan Face Polio Outbreaks, in Blow to Global Fight
text: The global effort to eradicate polio, a disease that has been on the brink of extinction for years, is facing serious setbacks on two continents. The virus is surging in Somalia and the Horn of Africa, which had been largely free of cases for several years. And a new outbreak has begun in a part of Pakistan that a warlord declared off limits to vaccinators 14 months ago.

headline: Life, Interrupted: A Test of Faith
text: With a Catholic mother and a Muslim father, I’ve always had a great interest in religion, but I’ve never practiced one myself. After I received a diagnosis of an aggressive form of leukemia at the age of 22, I put my faith in medicine.

headline: How Rare Is Crime?
text: At the end of a wrenching piece about his experience surviving a gunshot wound, Salon’s Brian Beutler describes why taking a bullet from a would-be mugger hasn’t made him any more sympathetic to profiling in its various forms, or inclined to support policies like stop-and-frisk:

headline: Likely to Succeed
text: “If you want the American dream, go to Finland.” These blunt words from a British politician, quoted by Amanda Ripley in “The Smartest Kids in the World,” may lead readers to imagine that her book belongs to a very particular and popular genre. We love to read about how other cultures do it better (stay slim, have sex, raise children). In this case, Ripley is offering to show how other nations educate students so much more effectively than we do, and her opening pages hold out a promising suggestion of masochistic satisfaction. “American educators described Finland as a silky paradise,” she writes, “a place where all the teachers were admired and all the children beloved.”

headline: Early Reader
text: Dreams, books, are each a world; and books, we know,Are a substantial world, both pure and good:Round these, with tendrils strong as flesh and blood,Our pastime and our happiness will grow. — William Wordsworth

headline: Speaking Freely
text: The freedom-of-expression guarantee of our First Amendment will soon be celebrating its 100th anniversary. This may seem surprising to those who recall that its evocative words — “Congress shall make no law . . . abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press” — were ratified 222 years ago. But for a century and a quarter those words were essentially dead letters — until 1919, when Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes resuscitated them with a shocking dissenting opinion that ultimately became the theory of our Constitution and the law of the land.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: Stick, Stone and Bone
text: Stick, Stone and Bone, which opened in 1990, is a New Age shop on Christopher Street in the West Village.

headline: Bradley Manning’s Letter to Obama
text: Pfc. Bradley Manning, who was sentenced to 35 years in prison Wednesday for giving classified documents to Wikileaks, today sent a letter to President Obama requesting a pardon. It gives voice to the disillusionment so many Americans feel with their government’s approach to national security policy and war, and conveys the injustice of his unnecessarily harsh punishment.

headline: Computer Bugs and Squirrels: A History of Nasdaq’s Woes
text: It was yet another technical difficulty for Nasdaq.

headline: Skateboards for Work and Working Out
text: AMID the thousands of New Yorkers who walk, bike and run to get around the city, skateboarders are often overlooked. But a fervent bunch use their boards as their primary mode of transportation — and as a strategy for staying fit.

headline: On Set | Rooney Mara
text: An impressionistic video portrait of the actress, shot by the photographer David Sims.

headline: Paper Gallery: Dreamscapes, Abysses and Radiation
text: Abelardo Morell and Elena Dorfman present unsettling, layered images in their photographs, while the painter Forrest Bass put his nightmares on canvas.

headline: Escaping the Heat in Art’s Fortress
text: CHANEL BALDWIN’S eyes sipped on that painting and only that painting, because it was what was available to her on this side of the money line.

headline: Ardent Victorian at the Lens
text: Julia Margaret Cameron took up the camera rather late in her life, at 48, but very early in the life of photography. And, as much as anyone of her time, this 19th-century British woman (1815-1879) helped the nascent medium grow into a viable art form.

headline: That’s Why They Call Them Gems
text: “Go ahead and put your hands in those stones,” Brogan Wikarek said, gesturing toward the bins of colorful, polished quartz. “Then ask yourself, does anything resonate?”

headline: On an Aegean Island, an Ugly Past Rolls in With the Tide
text: What’s a writer to do after his debut novel lands him in the hot seat for hewing uncomfortably close to the unsavory details of his life? Here’s one strategy: offer the world a protagonist whose personal history is just about as far from his own as is possible in the age of globalization.

headline: Take Root
text: Inside the restaurant in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, that doubles as a daytime yoga studio.

headline: Satisfying the Body and the Mind
text: It is an intimate thing to be cooked for by someone who loves to cook, and does so with skill, ardor and imagination, alone in a kitchen, knowing that at the end of the night, she will have to scrape off the dishes and scrub down the counters herself.

headline: President and Soldier: 3 Meetings, and a Lesson in Resilience
text: WASHINGTON — Three times, mainly by chance and in very different circumstances, Sgt. First Class Cory Remsburg has met President Obama.

headline: Songs and Snow
text: Photos from “Irving Berlin’s White Christmas” on Broadway.

headline: Jury Begins Work on Fort Hood Shooting
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — Choosing small details to underscore the government’s larger murder case against Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, a prosecutor on Thursday told a jury of senior Army officers that on the day the major went on a deadly rampage in 2009, he had stuffed paper towels into the cargo pants of his combat fatigues to muffle the metallic clanging of 16 magazines as he walked — a total of 420 rounds for his laser-sighted semiautomatic pistol.

headline: Can You Guess What This Is?
text: RULES1. Player has not seen the photo beforehand.

headline: Tchaikovsky’s Showpiece, Performed by a Showman
text: Familiarity, they say, breeds contempt. But that maxim, however hoary, is not unassailable. Audiences for concerts of mainstream orchestral repertory have not yet grown tired of Tchaikovsky’s showy, songful Violin Concerto in D, composed in 1878 and now almost surely played somewhere on the planet every week of the year. New evidence came on Wednesday night in the boisterous applause that followed the work’s first movement, as the violinist Joshua Bell played the concerto with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Employer Mandate, Delayed by Paperwork (and Efforts to Reduce It)
text: Over the last several weeks, we’ve taken a close look at the Affordable Care Act’s employer mandate, which requires companies with at least 50 employees to provide affordable health insurance to workers or pay a penalty. We’ve examined, among other issues, how the mandate defines affordable, how it treats workers whose hours vary — even whether it could be used as catalyst for hiring formerly undocumented immigrants.

headline: A Salad With Farm-Stand Allure
text: The calendar is leaning into Labor Day, but that does not mean summer is over. There is still much at the greenmarket to recommend for a bottle of dry German riesling. Consider leafy herbs, the whisper of sweetness in fresh corn and summer squash and a ripe tomato, all brought together with a splash of lemon.

headline: The Summer I Discovered Suburbia
text: One preteen summer, I was sent by my parents to Kent, Ohio, to spend a few days with my cousins, Jessica and Anna. They were close to my age and looked like me: Norwegian, with blond hair and blue eyes. They, and their parents, a dental hygienist and geographer, were warm and easygoing. And yet, when I arrived at their cozy two-story house, it felt like touching down on an alien planet.

headline: Seasonal Variety in a Homey Setting
text: That Trattoria 632 looks like someone’s expanded residence is not surprising. This roomy restaurant, bar and lounge was cobbled together from two adjoining homes. Although the many walls that sheltered a few generations have been removed and the space repurposed for the building’s new life, this merging wasn’t a redo, it was a make-do, on what might have been a limited budget. The resulting layout is a tad awkward, and homey touches remain, but the mismatching sets the tone for informality and adds a bit of country charm.

headline: Oh, Yes, Saturday TV Is Ladies Night
text: There were television movies before “Sharknado,” and there continue to be television movies after “Sharknado.” Witness this Saturday night, when Lifetime offers a topical drama, “Escape From Polygamy”; Hallmark Channel provides a frothy romantic mystery, “After All These Years”; and Nickelodeon kicks in “Swindle,” a children’s caper movie modeled on the “Ocean’s” films.

headline: Yahoo Surpasses Google in Web Traffic, Somehow
text: Without question, it has been a good month for Marissa Mayer, the chief executive of Yahoo. She was featured in a fancy fashion spread in Vogue magazine, Yahoo’s stock has continued to climb, and now, like a big cherry on top, the company beat Google to become the most visited Web property in America.

headline: Fools Rush In, With Camera
text: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: It’s Wagner’s Birthday, but We Get the Gifts
text: Love his music or hate his personality, the one thing you can’t do with Wagner is ignore him, especially this year, as the music world celebrates his bicentenary. However petty and malicious the man could be, his artistic achievement was huge, not only in sheer physical bulk but also in ambition, imagination and invention.

headline: When It’s All About the Timing
text: A conventional way to describe Kate and Luke’s relationship would be to say they’re just friends. But “just” hardly captures the intensity of the bond between them. Co-workers at a thriving Chicago microbrewery, Kate (Olivia Wilde) and Luke (Jake Johnson) have an effortless, comfortable intimacy. They get each other’s jokes and never tire of each other’s company. Daily lunch companions, they often extend the nightly busman’s holiday of after-work beer-drinking until closing time. They snuggle up in booths and couches, sometimes dozing off, but more like puppies in a box than lovers in bed.

headline: Council Reverses Bloomberg Veto of Policing Bills
text: The City Council voted Thursday to greatly increase oversight of the New York Police Department and of its widespread use of stop-and-frisk tactics.

headline: Triple Play: Make Your Picks for Week 22
text: The Bats blog again tests our readers’ predictive skills with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, tea leaves, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

headline: Privileged, but Wired Not to Find Comfort
text: The rich are different from you and me, as F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote, sometimes nowhere more so than in French movies. In the United States, a Viking stove in the kitchen and a BMW in the driveway may be mere background noise in a sleek thriller; in France, such emblems of class privilege can be grounds for a date with the Widow (a k a the guillotine), metaphorically speaking. In “Thérèse,” a 1920s woman is driven to commit a terrible crime, for all sorts of nominal reasons, though, in truth, her paramount motive is the accident of her birth: she’s bourgeois.

headline: Q. & A. | Edgar Wright on the Autobiographical Inspirations Behind His Boozy Film
text: Edgar Wright’s latest gleefully genre-fusing meditation on English small-town life, “The World’s End,” in theaters tomorrow, charts an epic pub crawl led by the character of Gary King (played by Wright’s co-writer Simon Pegg), a roguish, charismatic drunk. King reunites a disbanded group of friends from his teen years to finally complete “The Golden Mile,” in which a stop is made at all 12 pubs in their hometown, a task they had conspicuously failed at 20 years before. As the group makes its way toward an apocalyptic climax, old wounds are reopened, lost loves are reunited, an alien invasion is uncovered, and many, many pints are consumed. Here, the writer and director talks about real-life inspiration for the film.

headline: Last Call for Friends to Grow Up
text: On a summer evening in 1990, five British teenagers attempted a heroic pub crawl in the town of Newton Haven, a feat of herculean imbibing known as the Golden Mile. Along the way, there were vomiting, fighting and drunken sex, but amid all that fun, the group failed to make it through the requisite 12 watering holes, the last of which was called the World’s End. Their second try, more than 20 years later, is the subject of Edgar Wright’s new movie.

headline: Still Keeping Time, Staying True to the Past While Living in the Present
text: The urge toward retrospection runs strong among jazz musicians of a certain age, and to resist it requires stern commitment. But there’s also a way to be stubborn about honoring the past and its pull, making no disclaimers and leaving nothing to conjecture.

headline: Germany’s Rieslings on the Tip of the Tongue
text: The topic today is German rieslings, and since I already know the first question, let me start with the answer: No, not all German rieslings are sweet. In fact, sweet German rieslings may soon be an endangered species.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Egypt, Syria, Zimbabwe and the Philippines.

headline: Brooke Astor’s Son Is Paroled
text: New York State’s parole board ruled on Thursday that Anthony D. Marshall, the 89-year-old son of the philanthropist and socialite Brooke Astor, had grown so sick and frail that he would be granted immediate parole after serving just eight weeks of his one- to three-year prison sentence.

headline: A Return to Nature
text: There is an elusive quality to the natural light in Iceland, where long, white days of hazy luminosity don’t start and end so much as they seem to surreptitiously appear and, eventually, disappear. A similarly evanescent quality can be found in the music of Julianna Barwick, a singer and composer whose third album, “Nepenthe,” was issued by the Dead Oceans label on Tuesday. Ms. Barwick’s songs — chiefly wordless vocals, electronically looped — materialize out of ether, saturate a sonorous atmosphere, then dissolve. Environment trumps event.

headline: Egyptian Police Failed to Defend Churches, Rights Group Says
text: As my colleague Kareem Fahim reported from Nazla, Egypt, dozens of churches and other facilities connected to Egypt’s Christian minority have been attacked and burned in the last seven days by Islamists seeking revenge for the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi and a violent government crackdown that has left hundreds of his supporters dead.

headline: A Well-Traveled Table in a Majestic Setting
text: The owners of Mediterraneo, which opened in April at the new Hotel Zero Degrees in Norwalk, want diners to imagine that they have stepped into the dining salon of a large, majestic yacht. That explains the beautiful teak-and-holly floor that resembles a deck and the three enormous columns that punctuate the room.

headline: Havana Fantasies, Biology and Geography
text: A bright red sports car, a stripper and knee-length 24-karat gold chains: those accouterments define the sweet life in Miami in the feverish fantasies of Raúl (Dariel Arrechaga), a hotheaded, hormonally overcharged Havana teenager in “Una Noche.” With his best friend, Elio (Javier Núñez Florián), and Elio’s twin sister, Lila (Anailín de la Rúa de la Torre), Raúl hopes to follow countless others and navigate the straits of Florida to America on a homemade raft.

headline: The Desert Foils Friendly Scheming
text: It isn’t easy to drum up sympathy for the two 30-ish buddies of “Scenic Route,” childhood friends who reunite for a road trip to hell. Through their own shortsightedness, they find themselves stranded in Death Valley on a nearly deserted road with only jelly beans to eat, a few swigs of water and no cellphone service.

headline: Style and Kinetics Triumph in a Turbulent China
text: “The Grandmaster,” a hypnotically beautiful dream from the Hong Kong filmmaker Wong Kar-wai, opens with curls of smoke, eddies of water and men soaring and flying across the frame as effortlessly as silk ribbons. The men are warriors, street fighters with furious fists and winged feet, who have massed together on a dark, rainy night to take on Ip Man (Tony Leung), a still figure in a long coat and an elegant white hat. Even amid the violent whirlpools of rain and bodies, that hat never leaves his head. It’s as unyielding as its owner.

headline: A Surgical Center for Older Patients
text: How well will a particular patient withstand the stresses of surgery? To make that determination, surgeons typically order cardiovascular tests. Is his heart pumping efficiently? Are her lungs providing enough oxygen? But Dr. Mark Katlic never found that sufficient for older patients.

headline: One of His Biggest Fights Was Outside of the Ring
text: Muhammad Ali, born Cassius Clay, was not the only American to refuse to serve during the Vietnam War, but he was, by some measures, the most famous, the loudest and the baddest. Tracing the road to Mr. Ali’s act of defiance in 1967, Bill Siegel’s film “The Trials of Muhammad Ali” tries to recover the cultural éclat of the moment after decades of pop-history shorthand have reduced it to sound bites about the Vietcong.

headline: Clocks That Have Been Ticking Since Before the Revolution
text: TICKING SINCE BEFORE

headline: Comedy Listings for Aug. 22-29
text: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Movie Listings for Aug. 22-26
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Aug. 23-29
text: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: How BlackBerry Handled Past Wealth
text: It started in an unlikely place, far from the headquarters of more established technology companies, and grew to become a dominant player. Along the way, investors piled in, undeterred by the company’s policy of never paying a dividend.

headline: Picking Up the Scent on the Road to Bliss
text: One of my first boyfriends announced after our fourth date that he would never consider marrying or even living with a woman who smoked. I was devastated (although I didn’t smoke).

headline: What Happens When You’re Repeatedly Hit in the Head
text: “Would I allow my son to play football?” is the question that the sports journalist Sean Pamphilon positions at the center of “The United States of Football,” his documentary on the dangers of head injuries in that sport. He follows the stories of several retired N.F.L. players, living and dead, who had the degenerative brain disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy, which has been linked to repetitive blows to the head. Extreme dementia and depression set in before the disease slowly destroys the body. “What do you do with a 300-pound, 45-year-old person who’s out of control and is only going to get worse?” asks Lisa McHale, the widow of the Tampa Bay lineman Tom McHale.

headline: Jazz Listings for Aug. 23-29
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: They Probably Should Have Skipped This Dinner Party
text: Injecting the home-invasion thriller with fresh DNA, Adam Wingard’s “You’re Next” strays just enough from formula to tweak our jaded appetites. That it does so without spraying the gore to geyserlike excess says a great deal about Mr. Wingard’s sensibility. Never one to linger ghoulishly over violence — or to rely on bloodletting to plug a weak script — he prefers to strike and move on.

headline: Classical Music and Opera Listings for Aug. 23-29
text: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: The Fun Begins With the Name
text: Olive Lucy’s Kitchen Table is a pleasant place at which to pass a sultry summer evening. It has comfortable white-backed, tufted booths, pitchers of fresh fruit sangria and music that ranges from lively salsa to mellower Sinatra. Look around the room: people have fun here. A table piled with gift bags suggests a birthday or an engagement; Alan Valenti, the owner, in a phone conversation after my visits, said the restaurant, which opened last Valentine’s Day, was also a popular place for bachelorette parties.

headline: “Lightness of Being”
text: Playful sculptures abound in a group show at City Hall Park.

headline: Dance Listings for Aug. 23-29
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Caretakers Needing Some Care Themselves
text: A delicate intensity of feeling shapes “Short Term 12,” a drama about young, lost people hoping to be found. These aren’t like the strays who anxiously drift through other contemporary American movies — whose lack of purpose is reflected both in the groping camerawork and the uncertainty of a budding filmmaker behind the camera. The young director of “Short Term 12,” Destin Daniel Cretton, may have adapted some of the techniques of low-budget independent features, including a suggestion of tentativeness in the hand-held cinematography. But he’s clearly thought through his choices and found a subject that has earned its heartache.

headline: People as the Big Game in an Alaskan Hunt
text: Does that worried look on the face of Nicolas Cage in “The Frozen Ground” signal his realization that he is trapped in a police procedural that is not as good as an average episode of “Law and Order: Special Victims Unit”? Could be, although the movie, the directorial feature debut of Scott Walker, is at least watchable, unlike recent debacles starring Mr. Cage, including “Stolen,” “Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance,” “Trespass,” “Seeking Justice” and “Season of the Witch.”

headline: Pop Music Videos? I Want My YouTube!
text: A LOT has changed since 1984, when MTV first televised the Video Music Awards. Thirty years ago, record labels often spent millions of dollars on videos by top directors to promote the sale of albums. Then label executives would submit the videos to MTV and pray that the network would put them in its rotation.

headline: That Fractious Couple, Sex and Religion
text: Grotesquerie is in the eye of the beholder. That’s one lesson to be taken from the cinematic provocations of the Austrian filmmaker Ulrich Seidl, who, by presenting his characters as exotic specimens under a microscope, dares you to recoil.

headline: A Feast of the Eyes, Then a Treat for the Ears
text: Drive East, a festival focusing on South Asian music and dance, continued on Wednesday with separate presentations exploring two dance forms: first, Odissi with Sonali Mishra, and later, Kathak featuring Shambhavi Dandekar. Even though La MaMa’s first-floor theater has the look of a grim church basement, there is a bright side to seeing classical Indian dance here. Details are given jewel-box prominence: the gaze, the subtle shift of a neck, the way fingers stretch and curve are as arresting as a stomp on the floor.

headline: ‘American Modern: Hopper to O’Keeffe’
text: MoMA’s show includes paintings, drawings, prints, photographs and sculptures by more than 50 artists, bringing together some of the museum’s most celebrated masterworks.

headline: Theater Listings for Aug. 23-29
text: Theater

headline: A Medal Harvest for the Top Winery
text: Long Island producers won in nine of 32 classes of wines made from grapes in the New York Wine and Food Classic this month.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Aug. 23-29
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Market Report | Blue Gets the Black and Gray Treatment
text: Designers have embraced Yves Klein’s iconic shade of blue in standout pieces for early fall. From tops (Victoria Beckham’s prim calf-hair coat and Jil Sander’s artistic turtleneck sweater) to bottoms (Roger Vivier’s flocked leather bootie and Manolo Blahnik’s signature stiletto) and everything in between (Christopher Kane’s color-blocked velvet dress and a calf-hair bag from Michael Kors), this deep indigo hue is being paired, accented and trimmed with black and gray to prove that the similar shades can, and should, be worn together. The pièce de résistance: Dior’s ladylike watch with baguette sapphires and bright diamonds.

headline: A Plumber Lends a Sympathetic Ear
text: To describe the setup of “Sparrows Dance,” Noah Buschel’s disarmingly offbeat romance, is to risk alienating audiences fatigued by too-quirky characters and low-budget contrivance. In one corner, we have an unnamed, severely agoraphobic actress (Marin Ireland); in the other, a saxophone-playing, poetry-writing plumber (Paul Sparks). Between them lies a tiny New York City apartment and a mental-health problem as vast as a football field.

headline: An Urban Park Dotted With Gardens of Whimsy
text: A certain pants-making company promoted its denim three years ago with the imperative “Be stupid.” This was an attempt at irony. It really meant, “If you are smart, you will buy our jeans.” Variations on that tag line explained: “Stupid might fail. Smart doesn’t even try”; and “Stupid creates. Smart critiques.” In other words, to be original and creative, you might have to be willfully ignorant of what passes for conventional intelligence — or, at least, appear to be so. Think of the seemingly naïve TV detective Columbo.

headline: When Fringes Became Fashion
text: BOSTON — DOES anyone else remember that early episode of “All in the Family”? The one in which Archie Bunker, wearing a tie at his daughter’s urging, meets her boyfriend, Mike Stivic, who arrives in tie-dyed T-shirt and ripped bluejeans.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 23-29
text: “iLuminate: Artist of Light”

headline: The Pentagon as Silicon Valley’s Incubator
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In the ranks of technology incubator programs, there is AngelPad here in San Francisco and Y Combinator about 40 miles south in Mountain View. And then there is the Pentagon.

headline: Comfortable Old Friends
text: It’s sad. When the Museum of Modern Art isn’t jumping the shark with celebrity-performance art featuring the likes of Tilda Swinton, it can often be found paddling about in the lukewarm waters of the shallow end.

headline: Spare Times for Aug. 23-29
text: Battle of Brooklyn Commemoration (Sunday) It was a Revolutionary War battle that George Washington and his troops would probably have liked to forget — they lost — but the Battle of Brooklyn, on Aug. 27, 1776, was the colonists’ first major confrontation with the British after declaring independence, giving the occasion a special place in history. Its 237th anniversary will be celebrated on Sunday, from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., with events at one of the sites involved, what is now Green-Wood Cemetery, Fifth Avenue and 25th Street, Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn.

headline: Drunk, Ornery and With a Gun in His Hands
text: “Savannah,” a picturesque film based on a true story from the early-20th-century South, has a tone that leaves you expecting an outsize character to emerge and carry you to an ending that is the stuff of legends. But the man at the center of the story, Ward Allen (Jim Caviezel), turns out to be something less than that. He’s an interesting fellow but not particularly larger than life, at least as portrayed here.

headline: How the Daughter of an Ancient Race Made It Out of the Australian Outback
text: This article originally appeared in print on Aug. 29, 1971, and is excerpted, along with other tennis writing from the archives, in the Aug. 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

headline: Arthur Ashe Has to Be Aware That He Is a Pioneer in Short White Pants
text: This article originally appeared in print on Jan. 2, 1966, and is excerpted, along with other tennis writing from the archives, in the Aug. 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

headline: Apology, but No Explanation, for Massacre of Afghans
text: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash. — Staff Sgt. Robert Bales offered a tearful apology on Thursday for gunning down 16 unarmed Afghan civilians inside their homes, but said he still could not explain why he had carried out one of the worst American war crimes in years.

headline: Borg vs. Tilden
text: This article originally appeared in print on Aug. 24, 1980, and is excerpted, along with other tennis writing from the archives, in the Aug. 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

headline: Helen Wills Is Queen of Her Tennis World
text: This article originally appeared in print on Sep. 9, 1928, and is excerpted, along with other tennis writing from the archives, in the Aug. 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

headline: The Little Girl With the Big Racquet
text: This article originally appeared in print on Aug. 23, 1953, and is excerpted, along with other tennis writing from the archives, in the Aug. 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

headline: Wheelies: The Hot Wheels Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Former Windows Boss Goes to Andreessen, and Dear Miss Disruption
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Fiery Mayoral Debate Drew Few Viewers, Nielsen Says
text: The Democratic mayoral debate televised on Wednesday night was filled with fireworks. But it turns out that relatively few voters actually saw them.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Aug. 23, 2013
text: The New York Times film critics on “The World’s End,” “The Grandmaster,” and “Drinking Buddies.”

headline: Surprise! No Rent Increases!
text: A friend recently told me, breathless with excitement, that she was renewing her lease at 8 Spruce Street, the Frank Gehry-designed 76-story skyscraper, without any rent increase.

headline: Icahn Tweets Dinner Plans With Apple’s Chief, and Investors Applaud
text: Despite the hullabaloo over the Nasdaq stock market’s failure on Thursday afternoon, traders remained fixated squarely on Apple‘s then-frozen stock price.

headline: For Borrowers, Many Questions
text: In this risk-averse lending climate, mortgage lenders are unabashed in their demands for detailed documentation of a loan applicant’s financial situation.

headline: Lone Star Flavor in New York
text: Those looking for a little Lone Star soul can feel plenty at home in New York. Between the thriving scenes at Hill Country, the West 26th Street outpost dedicated to Austin-style brisket and live music, and the long-running Rodeo Bar, a Tex-Mex-flavored roadhouse pretty much directly across town, that old saw from westerns about “this town isn’t big enough for the two of us” doesn’t seem to apply here.

headline: Sturgis Biker Reunion
text: Seth Kugel's summer road trip takes him to Sturgis, S.D., during an annual gathering of thousands of motorcyclists.

headline: Motorcycles, Memorials and the Middle of Nowhere
text: It turns out I’ve been using the phrase “in the middle of nowhere” incorrectly my whole life. I used to mean it as a put-down, but I’ve discovered that it’s actually a good thing. And now that I’ve found the middle of nowhere, it turns out to be more remote than I could have imagined: on a rural mail route way outside of Philip, S.D., population 750.

headline: Walking and Talking Bed-Stuy
text: Bedford-Stuyvesant has not quite peaked on the been-there, done-that gentrification bucket list, but it already has its own Boswell recording every permutation of the landscape. His name is Morgan Munsey, or for those more familiar with his comments on the blog Brownstoner, he is Amzi Hill, a sobriquet taken from an architect who built Italianate brownstones and Neo-Grec town houses in Brooklyn from 1860 to 1892 and dabbled, as does Mr. Munsey, in real estate.

headline: The Siren Call of the Adjustable-Rate Loan
text: As if first-time home buyers were not having enough trouble getting into the market, now they have to contend with rising interest rates.

headline: Peak-Hour Pursuit
text: I am a daily commuter from suburban Connecticut to New York City. I have ridden the same train car with the same people for months (and sometimes years). I have grown enamored of a particular man I see most mornings, but I am not sure how to start a conversation with him — or whether to try. Any advice?

headline: Enter a Turkish Newcomer
text: Mavi Grill and Deli, a Turkish newcomer to Mount Sinai, is surprising, first for its location in a mostly residential area, and then for its setting, not the more typical storefront but an airy, spacious, converted house.

headline: American Tells of Odyssey as Prisoner of Syrian Rebels
text: Matthew Schrier was helpless. An American photographer held in a rebel-controlled prison in the Syrian city of Aleppo, he and a fellow prisoner had been caught trying to gouge a hole in their cell’s wooden door. The captors took his cellmate, he said, beat him, and brought him back with blood-streaked ankles and feet.

headline: Now, You Can Follow Government Intelligence Agencies Back
text: If surveillance from government intelligence agencies has you concerned, now you can at least follow them back — if only on Tumblr.

headline: Why Is Obama Caving on Tobacco?
text: LAST year I endorsed President Obama for re-election largely because of his commitment to putting science and public health before politics. But now the Obama administration appears to be on the verge of bowing to pressure from a powerful special-interest group, the tobacco industry, in a move that would be a colossal public health mistake and potentially contribute to the deaths of tens of millions of people around the world.

headline: New Claims in U.S. Case Against SAC Ex-Trader
text: Federal prosecutors filed an updated indictment in the criminal insider trading case against a former SAC Capital Advisors portfolio manager, adding a claim that he received secret information about drug trials from a second doctor.

headline: Kochs No Longer Interested in Buying Tribune Papers
text: Charles and David Koch are no longer contemplating a purchase of the Tribune Company’s chain of newspapers, a spokeswoman for the billionaire industrialists said on Thursday.

headline: A Silicon Valley for Ad Agencies, Only in the Mountains
text: AN agency holding group with ambitious growth plans is setting up shop in a growing market for agencies.

headline: Yanks Add Some Luck to Their Streak, With Two Bad Calls on One Play
text: When luck is on your side, even the most absurd calls can go your way.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Ad Revenue From Mobile for Pandora Increases
text: Pandora Media, the company behind the popular Internet radio service about to face major competition from Apple, reported on Thursday a loss of $7.8 million, or about 4 cents a share, for the second quarter but the company continues to experience rapid growth.

headline: Many Young El Pasoans Find They Can Go Home Again
text: EL PASO — In 2009, Xochitl Rodriguez, a multitalented performer from a middle-class El Paso neighborhood, was Bhutan’s first-ever invited artist in residence. After leaving South Asia, she served another residency in Kansas City.

headline: Shortage of Doctors Tough to Fix
text: Texas lawmakers invested millions of additional dollars in the 2013 legislative session to address a looming physician shortage. Voters and university regents have rubber-stamped plans to open two new medical schools, in Austin and the Rio Grande Valley. But those moves have not placated the medical community, which remains concerned that Texas has no long-term solution to produce enough physicians, particularly in primary care, to support the surging population.

headline: These Walls Speak, Recalling Victims of Violence
text: MEXICO CITY — The memorial to Mexico’s victims of violence looks like it has been dropped from the sky by an angry God. Welcoming it is not, with its rusted slabs the size of movie screens standing next to a busy intersection.

headline: Law Updated to Protect Some Who Do Roadwork
text: In 2003, Gov. Rick Perry signed the Move Over Act. It gave Texas drivers a new rule of the road when they came across a police car or other emergency vehicle parked on a shoulder with its lights flashing: slow down or move one lane over while passing.

headline: Gingrich Will Be Back in the ‘Crossfire’ on CNN
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — In defeat, the 2012 Republican presidential hopefuls have mostly faded from view, in ways that seem true to type. Mitt Romney is a contented grandfather. Rick Santorum leads a Christian movie company. Michele Bachmann is retiring from the House, although her pants-on-fire oratory is likely to find a new home.

headline: Mexican Mass Grave May Be Tied to Abductions
text: MEXICO CITY — A mass grave has been found near here, the authorities said Thursday, and they are investigating whether the victims are a group of young people kidnapped en masse from a bar in May, a crime that shocked and perplexed a capital city not accustomed to such brazen violence.

headline: Moody’s Threatens to Cut Credit Ratings of Banks
text: Believing that the government is now more likely to let large banks fail in a crisis, Moody’s Investors Service threatened on Thursday to downgrade the credit ratings of several big financial firms.

headline: A Question of How Women’s Issues Will Fare, in Washington and Overseas
text: WASHINGTON — Catherine M. Russell’s portfolio includes half the population of the planet, roughly 3.5 billion women. But working with the 70,000 employees of the State Department to make women’s issues a permanent priority, she said, may be the “harder slog” in a difficult new job.

headline: In Markets’ Tuned-Up Machinery, Stubborn Ghosts Remain
text: A generation ago, when the stock market crashed on Oct. 19, 1987, the Nasdaq stock market appeared to have done much better than the New York Stock Exchange. While the Dow Jones industrial average fell 23 percent that day, the Nasdaq composite index was off just 11 percent.

headline: German Officers’ Biases Seen as Enabling Neo-Nazis
text: BERLIN — Germany’s police and security services suffered from deeply rooted prejudices and a lack of cultural diversity, which allowed a neo-Nazi cell to carry out violent attacks against immigrants for more than a decade without being detected, according to a parliamentary committee report issued Thursday.

headline: League’s Format and Prizes Transform Street Skating
text: The first official street skateboarding contest, held in San Francisco in 1983, took place on an actual street. The course consisted of a few small wooden ramps and a parking block. Sixteen of the best street skaters alive competed for a first-place prize of $200.

headline: With Ships, Silt and a Giant Straw, a Beach in the Rockaways Is Reborn
text: It had taken every bit of nine months to pry the Beach 30th Street playground in the Rockaways from the death grip of Hurricane Sandy, but by Wednesday afternoon, it was back under the full control of the proper authorities: a mob of children, at full roar.

headline: A Limited Role for Cuomo as Obama Travels Upstate
text: BUFFALO — When President Obama arrived here on Thursday morning, emerging from Air Force One to a crowd of avid fans and a Lake Erie gale, the first person to shake his hand was Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, smiling wide. The president smiled too, hugging Mr. Cuomo before moving on to chat with the governor’s three daughters.

headline: Quarterback? Jets Have Yet to Decide
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — It is the eve of the Jets’ third preseason game, and according to the quarterbacks coach David Lee, they are not “near ready” to announce a starter. That sentence is presented without comment or judgment, merely a declaration of fact, but it is fair to consider Lee’s choice of words.

headline: Summer of the Big Dud
text: You could hope, after some of the loudest, costliest and most joyless products of the entertainment-industrial complex bombed this summer, that Hollywood would be having its Detroit gas-guzzler moment. That is, the point when a cobwebbed institution realizes that its main product is yesterday.

headline: Britain’s Brussels Syndrome
text: LONDON — The basic tenet of The Daily Mail is that Britain is not what it was (true enough, it isn’t) and that it would go a long way toward recovering its gritty greatness without wind farms, safety obsessions, green lunacy, overregulation and — above all — the European Union with its meddling bureaucrats.

headline: Young Immigrants Protest Deportations
text: Young immigrants in the country illegally have escalated their protests against deportations this week, creating awkward dilemmas for Obama administration officials who are pressing the House of Representatives to pass broad immigration legislation this fall.

headline: This Age of Bubbles
text: So, another BRIC hits the wall. Actually, I’ve never much liked the whole “BRIC” — Brazil, Russia, India, and China — concept: Russia, which is basically a petro-economy, doesn’t belong there at all, and there are large differences among the other three. Still, it’s hard to deny that India, Brazil, and a number of other countries are now experiencing similar problems. And those shared problems define the economic crisis du jour.

headline: Studio Has No Right to Bias, Court Rules
text: The New Mexico Supreme Court on Thursday affirmed a decision against a photography studio that was sued after refusing to photograph a same-sex couple’s commitment ceremony in 2006, saying the First Amendment does not permit businesses that offer services for a profit to choose whom to serve.

headline: British Player Finds a Home as Stephens’s Hitting Partner
text: Andy Fitzpatrick is not used to such plush surroundings. Fitzpatrick, a British player ranked 620th, acknowledged that he felt a little out of place in the pampered environment of a high-level WTA tournament as he assisted Sloane Stephens with her United States Open preparations at the New Haven Open this week.

headline: It’s All About Mao
text: WASHINGTON — The trial of Bo Xilai, the fallen Chinese Communist Party official and former member of the ruling Politburo, is attracting the world’s attention with its tales of corruption, sex, murder and political intrigue. But while such details are riveting, they divert attention from the real meaning of the case.

headline: Will a Boycott Help Russia’s Gays?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Golf’s Sound Check: At Tournaments, Loud Fans Are Getting Louder
text: JERSEY CITY — For 12 days, the storm had been brewing. Not the thunder and lightning and rain that suspended play for six hours Thursday at Liberty National Golf Club. No, it was the outburst by Ian Poulter on Twitter after the P.G.A. Championship that some fans had been waiting to feast on, and at about dinnertime they finally got the opportunity.

headline: Iran Said to Pave Over Site Linked to Nuclear Talks
text: Iran has paved over large swaths of a restricted military base that United Nations nuclear inspectors have sought unsuccessfully to visit for years because they suspect it was once a laboratory for testing weapons triggers, an antiproliferation monitoring group said Thursday in a study of new satellite imagery, suggesting the Iranians had tried to sanitize the site.

headline: Barclays Opens in 11-Hour Test for Woods
text: JERSEY CITY — Try telling the players with early tee times Thursday at the Barclays that the summer solstice was two months ago. For Tiger Woods, ranked No. 1, and the other golfers in the morning wave, the first round felt like the longest day of the year.

headline: A New F.B.I. Director Prepares to Take the Reins
text: WASHINGTON — James B. Comey will begin shadowing the F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, next week as he prepares to take on the job himself.

headline: Doctors Seek a Partner to Keep a Hospital Open
text: Doctors from an embattled Brooklyn hospital are making a last-minute bid to take it over with the help of a white knight, a professional management company that they say would have the expertise to turn it around.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Suing the I.R.S. Back to Basics
text: The ease with which big-money donors are able to influence the nation’s politics is nowhere better illustrated than by the charade that gives tax exemptions to obviously partisan political groups posing as “social welfare” organizations. Representative Chris Van Hollen, a Maryland Democrat, thus merits thanks for his decision to sue the Internal Revenue Service to force it to end its controversial muddying of tax law that has allowed these groups to flourish.

headline: The Corpses in Syria
text: The lifeless bodies depicted in photos and videos from Syria over the past two days suggest another chemical attack, quite possibly the deadliest single attack in more than two years of civil war. If the killings of an estimated 500 to 1,000 men, women and children outside of Damascus prove to be the work of President Bashar al-Assad’s cutthroat regime, as many suspect, the United States and other major powers will almost certainly have to respond much more aggressively than they have so far.

headline: A Federal Prod to Lower College Costs
text: President Obama has been accused of promoting small-ball ideas in his second term, but the proposal he unveiled on Thursday is a big one: using sharp federal pressure to make college more affordable, potentially opening the gates of higher education to more families scared off by rising tuitions. While there are questions to be answered about his plan, his approach — tying federal student aid to the value of individual colleges — is a bold and important way to leverage the government’s power and get Washington off the sidelines.

headline: ESPN Quits Film Project on Concussions in N.F.L.
text: ESPN on Thursday ended its official association with “Frontline,” the public television public affairs series, on a two-part documentary about concussions in the N.F.L. that is scheduled to be televised in October. After 15 months on the venture, ESPN chose to strip its name, logo and credit from the films, “League of Denial: The NFL’s Concussion Crisis.”

headline: Area 51, Where Conspiracy Theories Never Get Old
text: C.I.A. released a classified report telling what everyone already knows: There is a secret military testing base at Groom Lake called Area 51.

headline: For This Farcical Romp, Use Your Allusion
text: You’ll never again look at a sandwich cookie in quite the same way — not after you see what happens to the ones served up in the seaside cottage of rich, dotty Idris Seabright. But don’t expect me to tell you why. The funniest lines and most outrageous moments in the new play at Penguin Rep Theater, Erasmus Fenn’s “Drop Dead Perfect,” can’t be properly described in a family newspaper.

headline: C.I.A. Acknowledges Area 51 Exists, but What About Those Little Green Men?
text: RACHEL, Nev. — The Little A’Le’Inn has been an unlikely tourist destination in the Mojave Desert for nearly 25 years, selling souvenirs — from green alien coffee cups to E.T. Highway T-shirts — dedicated to the notion that we are not alone. Understandably.

headline: Can Egypt Learn From Thailand?
text: BANGKOK was rocked by anti-government demonstrations earlier this month — once a depressingly familiar sight.

headline: Clock Is Ticking for Recess, and for a Deficit Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Budget talks between the White House and Senate Republicans have gone nowhere since Congress began its summer recess, increasing chances of a fiscal stalemate that could lead to a government shutdown in October or the threat of a government default later in the fall.

headline: ‘He’? ‘She’? News Media Are Encouraged to Change
text: It was an announcement that left typically agile news presenters, reporters and editors stumbling over their words on Thursday: the lawyer for Pfc. Bradley Manning told the “Today” show that his client would like to be considered a woman and referred to as Chelsea.

text: For months now, about a dozen mayoral hopefuls have been running around New York City, popping up at candidate screenings, forums and subway stations. Recently, one candidate even passed out cookies at a senior center.

headline: Pack Your Bags

headline: Big Name Is Leaving Boies’s Firm After a Year
text: Last August, when the renowned trial lawyer David Boies announced the hiring of David M. Bernick, general counsel at the tobacco giant Philip Morris, he called the move a “huge step” for his firm, Boies Schiller & Flexner.

headline: Antidoping Agency Delays Publication of Research
text: Doping experts have long known that drug tests catch only a tiny fraction of the athletes who use banned substances because athletes are constantly finding new drugs and techniques to evade detection. So in 2011, the World Anti-Doping Agency convened a team of researchers to try to determine more accurately how many athletes use performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Guantánamo Officials Accused of Inventing ‘Fifty Shades of Grey’ Rumor
text: Updated, Friday, 10:34 a.m. | After a Congressional delegation was given a tour of the Guantánamo Bay prison recently, one member of the group recounted an anecdote he heard from officials there. “Rather than the Koran, the book that is requested most” by the detainees is “Fifty Shades of Grey,” Representative Jim Moran, Democrat of Virginia, told The Huffington Post in July.

headline: C. Gordon Fullerton, Early Space Shuttle Pilot, Dies at 76
text: Col. C. Gordon Fullerton, an astronaut who performed the first flight test of a space shuttle in 1977, then piloted two shuttle missions — including one in which an engine failed shortly after takeoff — died on Wednesday in Lancaster, Calif. He was 76.

headline: Leslie Land, a Food Writer Who Liked What Grew Nearby, Dies at 66
text: Leslie Land, a food and garden writer who published “The 3,000 Mile Garden,” a collection of her correspondence with the British horticulturalist Roger Phillips that became a series on public television, died on Aug. 10 in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. She was 66.

headline: Hynoski in Race Against Clock to Make Giants’ Opener
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — After being removed from the physically unable to perform list Thursday, Henry Hynoski has a little more than two weeks to prepare for the Giants’ season opener at Dallas on Sept. 8. Given the nature of the fullback position, he is hopeful he can be ready.

headline: A Cruel Twist and the End of Nix’s Year
text: It did not take long after the excitement of Tuesday night’s game for Jayson Nix to fall asleep. Despite his superb performance in the nightcap of a doubleheader sweep against the Toronto Blue Jays, Nix did not stay up all night celebrating. He received many congratulatory texts from friends and family members, including his brother, Laynce, who was released a week earlier by the Philadelphia Phillies.

headline: Comptroller Debate Is Nearly Friendly
text: The two Democratic candidates for New York City comptroller, who for weeks have thrown insults at each other, found something to agree on Thursday night: No, they did not want to sing on network television.

headline: Obama’s Education Plan on the Ground
text: In Buffalo, President Obama announced his new plan to decrease college costs. While some students looked on favorably, others said educational problems went far beyond the price of tuition.

headline: A First Step, Albeit an Incomplete One
text: Ryan Braun is not especially important to the baseball world anymore, except to those people who work or root for the Milwaukee Brewers. As a national figure, Braun is all but ruined. Most people will place him off in a corner of their minds — in a jail cell with giant syringes for bars, let’s say — with all the other drug cheats.

headline: More Barbs Exchanged Over H.G.H. Test Delay
text: With less than two weeks before rosters must be cut to no more than 53 players, the N.F.L. and its players union continued trading barbs Thursday about the league’s drug-testing regimen and the implementation of a preliminary test for human growth hormone.

text: The statement issued by the Brewers’ Ryan Braun on Thursday:

headline: Ron Motley, Who Tackled Big Tobacco, Dies at 68
text: Ron Motley, a trial lawyer who built a fortune out of high-risk cases against the asbestos and tobacco industries, leading the litigation team that helped bring about the largest civil settlement in American history — $246 billion — died on Thursday in Charleston, S.C. He was 68.

headline: A Fine Balance
text: The Dimore Studio designers Britt Moran and Emiliano Salci have pioneered a uniquely modern aesthetic through a subtle mixture of historical periods and a painterly palette.

headline: International Velvet
text: The rich textile has long been the calling card of the stylishly privileged. Now, it’s fashion’s turn to embrace the stuff of royals.

text: With sights, sounds, scents and a secret location, chef Paul Pairet’s immersive dining experience could be the next great leap in culinary evolution.

text: The fashion industry is broken in more ways than one: runway shows don’t match retail expectations; designers can’t keep up with demand; and customers can’t buy a coat in winter. So who’s to blame?

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 10 P.M. (Flix) WET HOT AMERICAN SUMMER (2001) On the last day of the summer in 1981, Coop (Michael Showalter), a teenage counselor at Camp Firewood, outside Waterville, Me., decides that he will finally declare his love for his lifelong crush, Katie (Marguerite Moreau). Meanwhile, the camp’s director, Beth (Janeane Garofalo), has romantic designs of her own on Associate Professor Newman (David Hyde Pierce). This comedy — directed by David Wain, written by Mr. Showalter and Mr. Wain, and with an ensemble cast including Amy Poehler, Bradley Cooper, Paul Rudd and Christopher Meloni (above, center, with Mr. Showalter, left, and A. D. Miles) — is “at its best when it jettisons parody for off-the-cuff zaniness,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. He also singled out Mr. Rudd, who “not only steals Coop’s girl, but suavely walks off with Mr. Showalter’s movie as well.”

headline: News Quiz | August 23, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Prosecutors Say Disgraced Chinese Politician Knew About Bribes
text: JINAN, China — Prosecutors in the trial of Bo Xilai, the former Communist Party star, presented testimony on Friday asserting that he knew about a villa on the French Riviera bought for his family by a tycoon and about demands for compensation from a British businessman managing the villa who was later murdered by Mr. Bo’s wife.

text: How well do you understand the use of quotation marks? Test yourself and see.

headline: Israel Claims ‘Successful Hit’ in Southern Lebanon
text: JERUSALEM — Israel responded overnight to a rocket attack on Thursday from southern Lebanon, bombing what military officials described as a “terrorist site” between Beirut and Sidon.

headline: Photojournalist Raped in Mumbai
text: MUMBAI— A female photojournalist on assignment in Mumbai was gang raped while her male colleague was tied up and beaten, the police said. Five men were being sought as suspects in the assault Thursday evening.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Obama Offers Plan to Reduce Cost of College
text: In the article “Obama Vows to Shame Colleges Into Keeping Costs Down,” Michael D. Shear and Tamar Lewin write about the president’s plan to lower the cost of higher education.

headline: North and South Korea Set Dates for Family Reunions After 3-Year Hiatus
text: SEOUL, South Korea — In a sign of improving ties, North and South Korea agreed on Friday to revive an emotionally charged humanitarian program next month that allows family members on both sides of the border to meet for the first time since the Korean War six decades ago.

headline: Jimmy Connors, Ladies’ Man
text: Technically, Jimmy Connors wasn’t the most overwhelming player. He was on the slight side; his serve was so-so, his forehand questionable. His only truly great stroke was his two-handed backhand. That he managed to win eight Grand Slam events (five U.S. Opens, two Wimbledons and one Australian Open), spend 160 consecutive weeks at No. 1 (1974-77) and rack up a record 109 career singles titles (John McEnroe and Roger Federer each have 77; Rafael Nadal has 58) is a testament, in large part, to a relentless and, at times, all-consuming will. This trait goes a long way toward explaining Connors’s most quietly astounding feat: for 16 years, he held a Top 10 ranking. In an era when tennis careers can flame out over a half-dozen seasons, Connors — who on his 39th birthday won a fourth-round U.S. Open match against the 24-year-old Aaron Krickstein in 4 hours 41 minutes — looks, in retrospect, more and more like a freak of nature or nurture or both.

headline: The Casino as Lifeline
text: For dozens of Korean and Chinese immigrants living in Flushing, Queens, riding the casino buses has become a way of life. Twice a day, they descend on unmarked bus stops off Main Street to secure a $15 seat to the Sands casino in Bethlehem, Pa. Many do not gamble. They make the trip solely for the free gambling and meal vouchers they receive when they arrive, coupons they sell on the black market. A half-day trip to the Sands can net around $40.

headline: Formal Arrest of Advocate Is Approved by China
text: HONG KONG — The authorities in Beijing have formally arrested one of China’s best-known human rights advocates on charges of disturbing public order, his lawyer and a friend said on Friday. It was the latest escalation in a case that has prompted a protest in China and criticism from the United States government.

headline: Favorite Comments in Our Tech Tools Student Challenge
text: I find that now I have most of my essential conversations digitally.

headline: New York Today: Can You Hear Me Now?
text: Soon you may long for the squeal of train against track and the squeak of underground rats.

headline: Daily Report: Pentagon Becomes Source of Support for Silicon Valley
text: In the ranks of technology incubator programs, there is AngelPad in San Francisco and Y Combinator about 40 miles south in Mountain View. And then there is the Pentagon, Somini Sengupta reports.

text: Learn more about American labor history by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Alibaba Said to Push to Allow Partners to Nominate Board Members
text: The Alibaba Group, the Chinese e-commerce giant whose anticipated initial public offering is expected to be a blockbuster, has made a proposal to the Hong Kong stock exchange that would allow the company’s partners to nominate the majority of its board members, a person with knowledge of the matter said on Friday.

headline: Mumbai Police Arrest Suspect in Gang Rape
text: A female photographer with an English language magazine was raped by five men in Mumbai Thursday evening, undercutting Mumbai’s image as the rare Indian city where women can safely move about in public spaces.

headline: Ads, Coming to a Bathroom Stall Near You
text: Last fall, Bryan Silverman called a barbecue restaurant a mile from his campus at Duke University to ask the owner whether he would be interested in saving a little money on his facilities costs. The owner, Bill Whittington, was intrigued. Mr. Silverman offered The Blue Note Grill in Durham, N.C., free toilet paper printed with a Quick Response (QR) code ad for the restaurant, as well as ads for other local businesses, in exchange for stocking the toilet paper in the Blue Note’s bathrooms.

headline: Russia Urges Syria to Cooperate in Chemical Weapons Inquiry
text: PARIS — Russia urged the government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria on Friday to allow United Nations investigators to examine evidence of a suspected chemical weapons attack this week, joining the United States in seeking a full accounting of what happened early Wednesday in the eastern suburbs of Damascus, the Syrian capital.

headline: Nasdaq’s Latest Breakdown
text: PRICING PROBLEM HALTS NASDAQ FOR THREE HOURS  |  A technological problem shut down trading on the Nasdaq market and its more than 3,000 stocks for more than three hours Thursday afternoon, Nathaniel Popper reports in DealBook. The halt was prompted by a problem with the data system that disseminates prices, Nasdaq officials said, adding that the cause had been “identified and addressed.”

headline: N.F.L. Pressure Said to Lead ESPN to Quit Film Project
text: ESPN was involved with a hard-hitting television series that delivered an unsavory depiction of professional football players. The N.F.L.’s commissioner was so perturbed that he complained to the chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, ESPN’s parent company. Not long after, ESPN stopped promoting the show, then decided to end its run after one season.

headline: Bank of America to Review Intern Working Conditions
text: LONDON – Bank of America announced on Friday that it was reviewing the working conditions of its junior employees after a 21-year-old intern died recently in London.

headline: Grace and Human Kindness in the Subway
text: Dear Diary:

headline: This Boy Band’s Already Supersized
text: The independent documentary filmmaker Morgan Spurlock made his name by making himself ill with too many Big Macs in the 2004 movie “Super Size Me,” tweaking one of the biggest American corporations. So it came as a surprise to hear that he had signed on to direct “One Direction: This Is Us,” the authorized documentary of the most popular boy band on the planet, a Pepsi-sponsored group created in the commercial petri dish of Simon Cowell’s “X Factor” talent competition show.

headline: Maybe 20 Years From Now, Tonto
text: A few weeks ago, I was invited onto morning television to discuss the fact that an unusually high number of very expensive movies had failed to make as much money from American ticket sales as their distributors had hoped. That was not exactly how the matter was framed, of course. Fast-hardening conventional wisdom has declared 2013 the year of the flop, as one box office catastrophe has followed another, and would-be juggernauts with big stars, huge budgets and endless merchandising potential have proven to be flightless turkeys.

headline: Cleaning Up After Bo Xilai
text: Bo Xilai sat on a wall, Bo Xilai had a great fall.
