text: The New York Times film critics on “The World’s End,” “The Grandmaster” and “Drinking Buddies.” All of this week’s movie reviews are available here.

headline: Algerians Look at Egypt, and Recall Their Own Nightmare
text: The similarities between Egypt’s descent into chaos and the onset of Algeria’s “Black Decade,’’ the 10-year civil war in the 1990s that killed an estimated 100,000 people, are not lost on Algerians. “Egypt is the same as it was here,’’ an Algerian acquaintance recently told me. “The exact same!”

headline: Convictions in Synagogue Bombing Plot Upheld
text: A federal appeals court in Manhattan has upheld convictions in a terrorism case that became a focal point in the debate over the government’s use of informers in undercover sting operations, though one dissenting judge concluded that the chief defendant’s conviction should be reversed because he was entrapped.

headline: Ballmer Exit Brings Microsoft a Chance for Reinvention
text: SEATTLE — Steven A. Ballmer announced on Friday that he was leaving the top job at Microsoft, paving the way for a generational change at the once-dominant technology company and giving it an opportunity to reinvent itself for a world dominated by mobile devices, social media and other technologies that have eluded its influence.

headline: In These Salads, Grains Sometimes Play a Supporting Role
text: I’m taking stock of my pantry as I do every summer, and I’ve found a number of jars, boxes and bags of grains with small amounts left in them – a half cup here, a quarter cup there, at most a cup. I put them all on my worktable last week and devised a salad for each of them. Some of the salads were more about vegetables and herbs than grains; it just depended on how much of the grain I had to work with.

headline: The Sound (of the Crying Baby) and the Fury (of the Exhausted Parent)
text: I don’t think of myself as someone who is easily angered. In my capacity as a mental health provider, I have been called every name in the book, spat at and nearly assaulted. Although these experiences are never pleasant, I can intellectualize away my feelings about patients’ hostile behavior: this is just a part of their illness. While I have certainly felt frustrated after a long night on call, I would not describe myself as feeling genuinely angry toward these patients.

headline: The Monetary Base, IS-LM, And All That (Very Nerdy)
text: Cullen Roche weighs in on my arguments about the usefulness of IS-LM — and I think we’ve reached a moment of impressive clarity. Basically, we aren’t having a real argument about the economic substance, on which we appear to agree. Instead, Roche and others are misunderstanding both what I mean by IS-LM and my reasons for invoking it in our current predicament. And much of the blame probably rests with yours truly: I probably haven’t been explicit enough about what I’m doing and why.

headline: Aug. 23: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Nasdaq Chief Defends Handling of Trading Halt
text: The chief executive of the Nasdaq stock exchange, Robert Greifeld, on Friday shot back at criticism of how his exchange handled a three-hour halt in trading on Thursday afternoon.

headline: Does ESPN’s John Clayton Have a Secret Ponytail?
text: You just covered 12 different team practices in the last 11 days. What did you dream about being when you grew up?  I wanted to cover the N.F.L. I started when I was in high school — at The St. Marys Daily Press, in 1972. I was 18 years old. I got a press pass for the Pittsburgh Steelers for the entire season. I covered the Immaculate Reception game.

headline: Bombings Strike Lebanon, as Mosques Are Targeted in Growing Violence
text: TRIPOLI, Lebanon — Car bombs exploded outside two Sunni mosques in this northern Lebanese city on Friday as many worshipers were just finishing prayers, killing dozens of people, wounding hundreds and sending new sectarian shudders through the country, already deeply unsettled by the conflict in neighboring Syria.

headline: One Man’s Trash Is Another Man’s Banned Good
text: My wife and I have a crib we used when our children were infants. It’s a high-end model in good condition, and we want to donate it to charity. But it’s a drop-side crib, which are now banned in the United States because of safety concerns. A similar rule is being considered here in Canada, and several drop-side models have been recalled — though ours is not one of them. Is it still ethical to donate the crib? Must we adhere to another nation’s regulations?  D.S., TORONTO.

text: Perry Mason vs. Katy Perry; Bronx Wentz’s old man.

text: Scenes from a Ugandan photo studio.

headline: 8.11.13 Issue
Who Made That Picnic?
text: “It’s part of our DNA,” says Walter Levy, author of “The Picnic: A History,” who points out that “picniclike” events appear in the writings of Ovid, Plutarch and Seneca. The word “picnic,” however, is of more recent vintage. An early mention can be traced to a 1649 satirical French poem, which features the Frères Pique-nicques, known for visiting friends “armed with bottles and dishes.” In 1802, the term made a hop to Britain after a group of Francophiles in London formed a Pic-Nic Society to gorge, guzzle and perform amateur theatricals. Participants drew lots to determine who would supply which dish — from calf’s-foot jelly to blancmange. “Depending on your luck,” Levy says, “you might have to bring something expensive, like pie made from truffles.”

headline: Twice Was Not a Charm for Bars Run by Stringer
text: As a young man, Scott M. Stringer tried and failed to turn a ramshackle Manhattan saloon into a thriving establishment, eventually abandoning the effort in the wake of disputed bills and a displeased landlord.

headline: Inside the List
text: COOL RUNNINGS: In “The Sports Gene,” David Epstein, a senior writer at Sports Illustrated, investigates whether there are natural-born athletes among us, just biologically built for speed and endurance. It’s a topic he’s been thinking about since he ran track in high school and college and was handily outpaced by Jamaican and Kenyan runners.

headline: Singapore Is The New Chile
text: Remember the 2005 Social Security debate? George W. Bush had just been returned to office; his campaign was focused on national security and social issues — as I like to say, he ran as America’s defender against gay married terrorists — but as soon as the returns were in, he declared that he had a mandate to … privatize Social Security.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE GOOD LORD BIRD,  by James McBride (Riverhead, $27.95.) McBride’s romp of a novel, narrated by a freed slave boy who passes as a girl, is a risky portrait of the radical abolitionist John Brown in which irreverence becomes a new form of homage.

headline: Beyond Windows XP
text: Q. I keep reading warnings about Windows XP getting retired next year with no more security updates. I don’t like the look of Windows 8, but if I upgrade to Windows 7, how long will that system be supported?

headline: Thriving on Chaos, Manziel Shocks a Traditional System
text: AS BIG-TIME COLLEGE FOOTBALL has grown into a multisponsored, million-footed behemoth, the urge to reduce each season to a few personalities has become ever more absurd, and more necessary. You have to believe there are some actual people under all those piles of money.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review:  ‘The Smartest Kids in the World’ by Amanda Ripley
text: This week, Annie Murphy Paul on “The Smartest Kids in the World” by Amanda Ripley, and Cris Beam discusses “To the End of June,” her book about America’s foster care system. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Ben Affleck to Play Batman in ‘Man of Steel’ Sequel
text: The fanboy corner of the Internet collectively fainted late Thursday when Warner Brothers put an end to wild casting rumors and said that Ben Affleck would play Batman in a “Man of Steel” sequel.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Amanda Ripley’s ‘The Smartest Kids in the World’
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Annie Murphy Paul reviews “The Smartest Kids in the World,” Amanda Ripley’s investigation into the educational experience in Finland, South Korea and Poland, and how it compares with its American counterpart. Ms. Paul writes:

headline: Cherish Is the Word
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ubiquitous Books
text: To the Editor:

headline: Trouble in Mind
text: On the morning Leonard Peacock, the high school narrator of Matthew Quick’s young adult novel, prepares a murder-suicide, he packs the Nazi pistol his grandfather brought back from the war and starts his school day with a plan. It is his 18th birthday. He is targeting his onetime best friend. Creeping through the morning with this secret knowledge, he attempts to reconcile the lives that have gone wrong around him, and to savor the freedom that comes from his imminent demise.

headline: Hidden Truths
text: When Leo Strauss died in 1973 he was virtually unknown outside the tiny academic circle that he inhabited. Forty years later his name and influence are known almost everywhere. His books and articles have been translated into nearly every European language and several Asian ones. Web sites — both pro and con — are devoted to him. International conferences debate his thought and legacy.

headline: Russia, With Love
text: When I lived in Moscow in my 20s, I’d often pass nervous young men standing in the metro station, holding flowers and waiting for their dates to show up. Meeting in the metro was a Russian tradition, and like Russia itself it seemed exotic, romantic and rife with drama. I arrived in tears to several of my own rendezvous because of confusion over the Cyrillic-only metro signs, and I missed others entirely.

headline: The Art of Fitting In
text: Like the lead characters in two new books about navigating the dynamics of high school society — Caprice Crane’s “Confessions of a Hater” and Bridie Clark’s “Snap Decision: Maybe Tonight?” — I was a bit of a fish out of water as a teenager. But there’s something about those uncomfortable years that draws me, like many adults, back to them — at least as a reader. The perspective of these novels is subtle enough to be engrossing for both teenagers and adults for whom high school’s intense friendships and antipathies still resonate. And how could they not?

headline: What the Dickens
text: To the Editor:

headline: Elusive Books
text: To the Editor:

headline: Chronicle: Memoirs by Women
text: BLUE PLATE SPECIAL  An Autobiography of My Appetites  By Kate Christensen  Doubleday, $26.95.

headline: Dreaming With Van Gogh
text: Art and art history are two subject areas in which certain electronic textbooks are not only convenient, but sometimes more effective as learning tools. Who wants merely to read about pigment-mixing without trying it, or to squint at a tiny printed reproduction of a still life by Pieter Claesz — an artist who was sharing pictures of food centuries before Instagram was invented — instead of popping open a full-screen version to better study the composition?

headline: Paperback Row
text: EVERY LOVE STORY IS A GHOST STORY: A Life of David Foster Wallace,  by D. T. Max. (Penguin, $17.) Wallace, who committed suicide in 2008 at age 46, compiled a vibrant body of work: short fiction and novels — including the magnum opus “Infinite Jest” — as well as long-form journalism about subjects ranging from tennis to politics to lobsters. Max’s biography offers a deeply sympathetic appraisal, tracing Wallace’s success as a writer and his battles against depression and addiction.

headline: Away From Home
text: Early in Cris Beam’s remarkable new book, she outlines what she calls the core questions at the heart of America’s foster care system: “Who decides the correct way to raise a child? Who makes the moves on the moral chessboard where a family’s right to privacy opposes a child’s right to protection from harm? And who should get to keep a child: the parents who nurse and tend to him, or the parents who brought him into this world?”

headline: Voice of the Voiceless
text: Autism is an endless mystery, largely unknowable by its nature, yet there are dozens of books by or about autistic people determined to explain the lives of those affected. The newest is “The Reason I Jump,” popular in Japan since it was published in 2007. The author, Naoki Higashida, was 13 years old at the time he wrote the memoir, and nonverbal. He wrote by spelling out words on a Japanese alphabet letter board.

headline: Bookshelf: Dinosaurs
text: New picture books, including David Ezra Stein’s “Dinosaur Kisses.”

headline: Poetic Virtues
text: The audience for poetry is like a vastly reduced version of the audience for college football — superstitious, gossipy and divided into factions no less fervent for having only an occasional idea of what’s going on outside their own campuses. It’s a hard crowd to write for, and the critic who sets himself up as a color commentator inevitably struggles to find a style that can please Peter without needlessly riling up Paul.

headline: Outside the Lines
text: Ask a group of kindergartners how many of them are artists and every child will enthusiastically raise a hand. Ask that same question to progressively older groups of kids and the numbers of artists will diminish with each advancing grade, until in high school only a few ink-stained hands rise from the fringes.

headline: Bookshelf: Dinosaurs
text: DINOSAUR KISSES  Written and illustrated by David Ezra Stein. 32 pp. Candlewick Press. $15.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5)

headline: Solitary Creatures
text: The first illustrations in the Canadian author Fanny Britt’s graphic novel, “Jane, the Fox and Me,” are of a school’s large campus, with buildings, stairways, paths, shadows, scattered trees, even a far-off forest and this line: “There was no possibility of hiding anywhere today.”

headline: Bookshelf: Sleep
text: “Lena’s Sleep Sheep,” by Anita Lobel, and more.

headline: Bait and Switch
text: The term “thriller” usually triggers an image of some drooling serial killer who does unspeakable things to the women he holds captive on his pig farm. Or some mad hacker who has programmed a computer virus to reroute all your e-mails to Wiki­Leaks. Less likely to come to mind is a small town where high school seniors selling booze to underage juniors constitutes a crime wave. That’s the context of Linwood Barclay’s new mystery, A TAP ON THE WINDOW (New American Library, $25.95), and, yes, it’s a killer of a thriller.

headline: Bookshelf: Sleep
text: LENA’S SLEEP SHEEP  A Going-to-Bed Book  By Anita Lobel.  24 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $11.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5)

headline: Bookshelf: Issues
text: “Noni Is Nervous,” by Heather Hartt-Sussman, and more.

headline: Bad Behavior
text: No child (except yours and mine) is nice all the time. But we don’t look the other way anymore when children are mean. Four new picture books about bullying substitute animals for children. This charming menagerie lightens things up, allows us to laugh, and sometimes sneaks in — or rams through — a valuable lesson.

headline: Alpha Dogs, Underdogs
text: The movie “Mean Girls” is nearly a decade old, but the “burn book” at the center of Tina Fey’s screenplay remains an evergreen plot device. Mostly written by the popular girls, these burn books are public logs of carefully calculated insults lobbed at social rivals and undesirables. Like everything else in the past 10 years, the burn book has moved online, and Facebook and Tumblr are littered with hateful messages written by aggressive tweens.

headline: Meryl as Mary
text: “The Testament of Mary,” Colm Toibin’s novel and play about the mother of Jesus, has been blessed in its interpreters. When Fiona Shaw played the role on Broadway, Toibin praised her “commitment to theater at its most pure and risky and dangerous.” Now Meryl Streep has narrated the audiobook, due out Sept. 10. No word yet on whether Toibin’s work will also make it to the big screen or whether Shaw and Streep will compete for the part.

headline: Gifted and Talented
text: I wanted to hate this book. After all, this was a book for children, and I don’t do children’s books. I was totally lost by Page 2 of the preface — wondering what a Zilchbot was (12 dozen of them were attacking Captain Marvelous and his friends) and why I should care about Kid Caliber or the Diamond Dame (heroes trapped in the Nulzone). As for Captain Marvelous, he seemed like a vanilla remake — a rip-off, really — of Superman, from the big red “M” on his chest to his ruby red cape and captaincy of the Legion of Justice. I am an authority on the Man of Steel, having written a full-fledged biography of him. “I know Superman, Superman is a friend of mine,” I was tempted to write to the author, John David Anderson, “and Mr. Anderson, Captain Marvelous is no Superman!”

headline: Family Stories
text: What parent wasn’t thrilled to hear about the Emory University study suggesting that children who are told stories about their families’ pasts may develop a greater ability to cope with the vicissitudes of life? But most children’s books that convey a sense of family history and tradition — “All-of-a-Kind Family,” “Little House in the Big Woods” — are written with the older child in mind. Younger children are more likely to learn the day-to-day habits of rabbits, monkeys and bears. So it’s refreshing to find three new picture books that take as their subject the stories of human families, illuminating the ways certain rituals — along with sayings, jokes, pastimes and world views — get passed down through the generations.

headline: Escaping the Past
text: Can the literary novel ever really get its arms around the problem of human evil? It keeps trying — a difficult assignment for the poor beast. In any case, an undaunted Alexander Maksik has brought his skills to this very problem. His second novel, “A Marker to Measure Drift,” recounts a season of homeless exile in the life of a 24-year-old Liberian woman fleeing an episode of gruesome violence incidental to the overthrow of the tyrant Charles Ghankay Taylor, in 2003. Maksik has produced a bold book, and an instructive one.

headline: Bookshelf: Issues
text: NONI IS NERVOUS  By Heather Hartt-Sussman.Illustrated by Geneviève Côté. 24 pp. Tundra Books. $17.95. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5)

headline: A Nose for Words
text: The day John Lennon was shot, just across the park from where I attended high school, was also the day my P.S.A.T. scores came in. The news wasn’t good. The problem was my vocabulary; I didn’t know enough words. And so, while the rest of the world was laying flowers at the Dakota, I found myself at the Stanley H. Kaplan Educational Center, where, for 10 Sundays, I was enrolled in reform school.

headline: Constant Acquisition at Microsoft, and One Deal That Didn’t Close
text: With his impending departure as Microsoft’s chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer has put an expiration date on one of the most prolific deal-making streaks in technology over the last two decades.

headline: March on Washington Original Coverage
text: Read The New York Times’s original coverage of the March on Washington and its implications in August 1963, headlined “200,000 March for Civil Rights in Orderly Washington Rally.”

headline: From the Fire Hose: Obama’s Bus Stop in Gas Country, Al Gore’s ‘Category 6,’ an Unplugging Climate Blogger
text: Updated, 12:23 p.m. | Here’s another end-of-the-week roundup of noteworthy news and analysis on issues relevant to Dot Earth grabbed from the 24/7 fire-hose flow:

headline: Study Suggests Shift in Fed Bond-Buying
text: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — A new study finds that the Federal Reserve should keep buying mortgage-backed securities even as it stops buying Treasury securities, and even as it sells off its existing holding of Treasuries and mortgage bonds.

headline: Dutch Bank ABN Amro Takes Step Toward an I.P.O.
text: LONDON – The nationalized bank ABN Amro moved a step closer to the public markets on Friday after the Dutch government said it would seek an initial public offering for the bank.

headline: Outcry Grows Against British Housing Plan
text: LONDON — Depending on where one stands in the debate on the rising cost of housing in Britain, Paul Thomas and Abigail Walker, first-time home buyers, are either part of the solution or part of the problem.

headline: Witnesses to History, 50 Years Later
text: The New York Times asked readers who attended the March on Washington to recall their experiences and reflect on the legacy of that day.

headline: A Guessing Game for Taxpayers on What They Owe
text: WHEN it comes to income taxes, my wife and I try to pay exactly what we owe. And by this I mean we try to calculate what we need to pay during the year so we do not overpay. We would rather owe a bit more in April than find out we are getting a refund.

headline: 50 Years After March, Views of Fitful Progress
text: WASHINGTON — When Daniel R. Smith was born dirt poor more than three-quarters of a century ago, there were only about 20 other blacks in his small Connecticut town. His own father had been born a slave in Virginia in 1862. Mr. Smith served as a medic in Korea in the years just after the Army had been desegregated.

headline: Second Term Playbook: Impeach
text: The G.O.P. failed to unseat President Obama in last November’s election, and “birther” fantasies of invalidating his presidency on technical grounds have gone nowhere. So the Republicans have pulled out their second-term playbook from the Clinton years, and are now gossiping about impeachment.

headline: A New Benjamin Franklin Museum
text: The new Benjamin Franklin Museum opens on Saturday in Independence National Historical Park in Philadelphia, with 21st-century hands-on exhibits and computer simulations designed to animate the character and wisdom of the 18th-century sage.

headline: 2013 U.S. Open: Players to Watch
text: Among the players to watch at this year’s United States Open are John Isner, Jelena Jankovic, Juan Martin del Potro, Dominika Cibulkova, Grigor Dimitrov and Sloane Stephens.

headline: U.S. Open Players to Watch: Not the Usual Suspects
text: Juan Martín del Potro

headline: The Impala Regains Its Swagger
text: Chevy’s latest Impala harks back to the nameplate’s ’60s heyday, when it was the quintessential big, stylish American family car.

headline: For America’s Sedan, a Great Leap Forward
text: My wife used to work as a sales representative for Johnson & Johnson. Like many sales reps, she was provided a nondescript, inexpensive company car — in her case, a Chevrolet Impala. At some point, the “a” fell off the trunk badge and we began calling it the “Impal.” The Impal’s chief virtue was its huge trunk, which could conceal many cases of sample products — typically, Tylenol PM and K-Y jelly. Say what you want about the old Impala, but it sure could haul some K-Y jelly. General Motors should have made a bigger deal of that.

headline: Review: 2014 Chevrolet Impala
text: Chevrolet aims to rid the Impala of its rental-car reputation with distinctive new styling. Tom Voelk drives the 2014 model to see if the changes to this full-size sedan are more than skin deep.

headline: For Two Female News Anchors, Morning Has Spoken
text: When you wake up at 3:30 a.m. to go to a job that starts in the predawn hours, lunch comes early. So, on a recent weekday morning at 10:45, Gayle King, one of the hosts of “CBS This Morning,” and Mika Brzezinski, the sparring partner of Joe Scarborough on “Morning Joe” on MSNBC, came together at Gotham Lounge at the Peninsula Hotel, dressed in near-matching green sheathes and very high heels, to share a midday meal (burrata and chicken Caesar salad for Ms. King; burrata and hot-and-sour soup for Ms. Brzezinski; freshly squeezed orange juice for both) and to talk about the demands of morning television, the roles of male and female anchors and not knowing who Russell Brand is.

headline: The Jazzman With a Debt to Nashville
text: SOUTH YARMOUTH, Mass. — There’s a moment in “Learning to Listen: The Jazz Journey of Gary Burton,” an autobiography due out on Sept. 3 from Berklee Press, that depicts the author’s earliest encounter with Miles Davis. It happened at a summer jazz festival in Mr. Burton’s home state, Indiana, and probably could have gone a little better.

headline: Gary Burton, Resurgent Jazz Outsider
text: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen discuss the Grammy-winning jazz vibraphonist, who has a new autobiography and a new album.

headline: Images of Bomb Blast and Aftermath in Lebanon
text: Videos from a security camera and  from witnesses in the northern city of Tripoli in Lebanon on Friday captured the moment a bomb exploded at a Sunni mosque and the aftermath of a blast at another mosque, in attacks that killed more than two dozen people and wounded hundreds.

headline: Jeep Grand Cherokees Investigated for Ceiling Fires
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether 146,000 Jeep Grand Cherokees from the 2012 model year should be recalled after reports of fires in the headliners of three vehicles, according to a report posted on the agency’s Web site.

headline: Faster Assistance for Medicare Patients
text: Just over a year ago, Medicare quality improvement organizations (Q.I.O.’s) across the country began a practice known as “immediate advocacy.”

headline: Four Frittatas and a Terrine
text: For a taste of Provence in the summer, start with eggs. That’s what Martha Rose Shulman did as she recreated some of her favorite Provençal dishes to escape the summer. She writes:

headline: Exhibition of Sicilian Antiquities Will Proceed at Cleveland Museum
text: An exhibition of ancient treasures from Sicily that had been abruptly canceled last month is back on the fall schedule of the Cleveland Museum of Art after the museum and Sicilian officials ironed out a dispute over money.

headline: Off the Charts: Emerging Markets Submerge
text: Stock markets in emerging markets have fallen sharply this year, while most developed markets are up significantly.

headline: Carmelo Anthony’s Friends and Family Celebrate His Latest Award
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Lockdown by Government Smothers Day of Planned Protest in Egypt
text: CAIRO — A tight lockdown on Cairo by Egyptian security forces on Friday all but squelched a planned day of protests by the Muslim Brotherhood and its allies, suggesting that the new military government had gained a decisive edge in its battle against supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi.

headline: Mets or Yankees?
text: The candidates in the New York mayoral race sound off on their baseball allegiances.

headline: Taking an Invention From Idea to the Store Shelf
text: EVERY once in a while, my family will toss around ideas for potential inventions. Like my son’s ultimate alarm clock, which wakes you up, tells you the weather and makes tea and toast.

headline: Whether R&B, Techno, Jazz or Metal, Don’t Pin Them Down
text: SZA

headline: '3 Things'
text: The Catsimatidis campaign has released its first attack ad against Joe Lhota.

headline: I Love You, Mom, but Hear My Record
text: It’s pretty easy to spot Ty Segall’s influences. This singer-songwriter, raised in Laguna Beach, Calif., has Neil Young’s name tattooed on his right arm and the logo from Black Sabbath’s 1972 album “Vol. 4” inked on his left. His music is likewise a recognizable combination of disparate sources, displaying a remarkable ability to synthesize different elements of pre-1980s rock — heavy ’60s garage-rock riffs, harmonies that evoke the Beatles or early Tyrannosaurus Rex, and a punk velocity — into fresh and catchy pop nuggets.

headline: 10 Weeks, 5,446 Entries: Reflections on the 2013 Summer Reading Contest
text: We knew it was shaping up to be the most successful year yet for the New York Times Summer Reading Contest, but until we closed the final post and did the math, we didn’t realize just how successful.

headline: City’s Annual Cost Per Inmate Is $168,000, Study Finds
text: New York City is an expensive place to live for just about everyone, including prisoners.

headline: Image of the Day: August 23
text: Pakistan released nearly 340 Indian fishermen from prison who had allegedly entered Pakistan’s territorial waters on different occasions.

headline: How Fights Over Fixtures Can Derail a Closing
text: Even at their smoothest, residential real estate closings are not for the faint of heart. At stake is nothing less than the roof over the buyer’s head, but the repercussions can be primal when, just before the culmination of a deal worth hundreds of thousands or, in many instances, millions of dollars, weeks of negotiations unravel when the buyer and seller suddenly squabble over who gets custody of something as inconsequential as a $150 ceiling fan.

headline: New York City’s Jail Population: Who’s There and Why?
text: The New York City Independent Budget Office released findings on the prison population.

headline: Runaways Find Homes on the Screen
text: LOS ANGELES — Early on in the new movie “Short Term 12,” teenagers living in a group home gather, as Nate, a neatly dressed young counselor with a nervous smile, introduces himself.

headline: Hey, Ludwig, There’s an App for You
text: At the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, as at many schools around the United States, students will flock to classes this fall to begin a new academic year. Though “flock” may not be the right word for Curtis, with its minuscule current student body of 171.

headline: Roger Federer Can Still Get His Game Face On
text: On the first Wednesday of Wimbledon this June, under a bright early-evening sky, Roger Federer trailed two sets to one in his second-round match against Sergiy Stakhovsky, a Ukrainian ranked 116th in the world and best known until that point for pulling out his cellphone during a match to take a photograph of a disputed ball mark. But Stakhovsky had played imposing serve-and-volley tennis, a style seldom seen nowadays, and as the fourth set unfolded on Center Court, it became clear that he was not going to succumb to nerves. Federer, 31 and seeking a record eighth Wimbledon title, would have to contrive an escape.

headline: When You Can’t Forget the Gifts You Didn’t Get
text: Lisa Kaas Boyle, an environmental lawyer in Los Angeles, knows exactly who gave her what for her February 1994 wedding. The silver serving utensils? Courtesy of Uncle Michael. The magnificent Waterford vase with the doors of Ireland etched into the crystal? That came from Jimmy Murakami, the Oscar-nominated animator.

headline: Recommended Reading
text: NYT developers share their recommendations from around the web.

headline: Not Much to Matsuzaka’s Mystery Pitch
text: We were promised gyroballs.

headline: ‘Hustlers’ Returns
text: A look back at Philip-Lorca diCorcia’s photographs of male prostitutes.

headline: Real People, Contrived Settings
text: In the early 1990s, the photographer Philip-Lorca diCorcia made five trips to Los Angeles to pick up male prostitutes in Hollywood. Cruising down a seedy stretch of Santa Monica Boulevard, where young men loitered suggestively by the curb, he would slow down in his rental car when he saw a likely prospect.

headline: Fantasy Football: Answers to Reader Questions
text: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice throughout the 2013 season. Follow them on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Nixon’s Political Wisdom, Caught on Tape
text: Our long audio nightmare is over. The final batch of Richard Nixon’s secret and self-incriminating White House tape recordings have been released. As in the 3,700 hours previously made public across the past 17 years, Nixon as president is there in all his cunning and self-pity —“Hamlet without the Prince,” in the description of Stanley Kutler, the historian who fought mightily to block Nixon and his loyalists from burying the tapes forever. They can be tedious listening, and it’s hard to judge what younger generations addicted to on-screen bursts of brevity will make of the 37th president’s schemes and maunderings amid the scandal known as Watergate. But they still offer an unparalleled voyeuristic fix, which had citizens lining up for hours to hear the initial batches played endlessly on 32 audio machines in Washington.

headline: Law School Applications Decline, Especially From Graduates of Elite Colleges
text: We’ve written before about the declining interest in law school, as evidenced by the number of people taking the Law School Admission Test and the number applying to law schools. Over at the Associate’s Mind blog, Keith Lee notes that the number of applicants is down across the board, but the drop-off is particularly sharp among people who went to elite schools for their bachelor’s degrees.

headline: Popcast: Gary Burton, Resurgent Jazz Outsider
text: If you’re only a casual listener to jazz, and not a vibraphonist, Gary Burton may not be a big name to you. But he’s probably had more to do with the development of jazz over the last 50 years than you think as a player (he developed the widely used four-mallet Burton Grip for the vibraphone); a mentor (to Pat Metheny, for starters); a conceptual inspiration (to Bill Frisell, among others, through the way he incorporated country and rock into his music during the late ’60s); and a longtime teacher and administrator at Berklee College of Music.

headline: Required U.S. Open Reading, Old and New
text: There is much to dread about late August: the heat, the humidity, those people who leave work at like 1 every Friday while you work normal hours. But there is at least one thing to look forward to: the magazine’s annual U.S. Open issue. You probably remember previous Open coverage from the magazine. There was John Jeremiah Sullivan’s article on Venus and Serena Williams, Andy Samberg’s re-enactments of iconic men’s championships and Dewey Nicks’s video gallery of women’s tennis stars. And then there’s the older stuff. Who could forget Harry Gordon on Arthur Ashe; Hal Higdon on Billie Jean King; or Allison Danzig on Helen Wills? Wait, did you forget them? Did you never know about them? Maybe that’s because those pieces, dating to 1928, do not exist on the Internet.

headline: Military Jury Convicts Army Psychiatrist on All 45 Counts in Fort Hood Rampage
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — A military jury on Friday found Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan guilty of carrying out the largest mass murder at a military installation in American history.

headline: Some Stops on the March
text: In this 50th anniversary of a pivotal summer for racial equality, the Brooklyn Academy of Music has been offering A Time for Burning: Cinema of the Civil Rights Movement, a series that wraps up with a well-known Hollywood movie and some less known historical offerings.

headline: Jacob’s Pillow, Ready for Rest
text: Dance lovers, you have one last chance, on Sunday, to catch a performance at the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., where the Martha Graham Dance Company and Kyle Abraham’s Abraham.In.Motion — both well worth a pilgrimage — close the season there.

headline: Bassoon Solos on the Water
text: The floating concert hall Bargemusic is possibly the cutest place in New York to hear music, and it is also one of the most adventurous; its Here and Now series is among the city’s most valuable homes of new and recent work. The programs are varied, the tickets reasonably priced, and the mood low key. The series gets a big showcase this week with its annual Labor Day festival, a motley assortment of sounds with an element of surprise. While a list of works has been published on the barge’s Web site, the program and performers will differ slightly for each of the four performances (Wednesday, Friday, Saturday at 8 p.m. and next Sunday at 2 p.m.).

headline: Sharp Lawyers, Willing to Cut
text: It’s called “taking silk”: the merit-based appointment of a British lawyer as Queen’s Counsel, which confers the right to wear a specially designed silk gown in court (and, for ceremonial occasions, an even bigger wig). And in “Silk,” a “Masterpiece Mystery!” series beginning Sunday night on PBS, Martha Costello, a sharp-witted defense barrister in London portrayed by a crackling Maxine Peake, wants to take silk — badly. Already stretched thin, she strategically overloads on cases that could bolster her reputation and tutors an ambitious if occasionally bumbling pupil (Tom Hughes).

headline: Living Large at Yale Gallery
text: For such a populist, accessible and at times interactive artist, Red Grooms doesn’t get much respect or exposure these days. His place in history rests mostly on his role in the invention of Happenings, less on his contribution as deviant, satirical Pop artist and latter-day American (art) Scene painter. Starting Friday, “Red Grooms: Larger Than Life” at the Yale University Art Gallery will feature Mr. Grooms’s forays into the history of modernism with a group of oversize paintings and drawings.

headline: Microcultures on the Island
text: Dance music is often depicted as some kind of monolith, and from a distance, Electric Zoo — a multistage festival held on Randalls Island every Labor Day weekend, now in its fifth year — submits to the prevailing stereotype.

headline: In a Room to Talk
text: In times of crisis, it is perhaps better to listen to walls than climb them. Lauren Yee gives new and literal life to the hoary speculation “if only these walls could talk” in “The Hatmaker’s Wife,” which begins previews on Tuesday at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater. In it, a loquacious wall speaks up to offer advice and an, uh, ear to a commitment-challenged woman named Voice.

headline: A Conservative Catholic Now Backs Same-Sex Marriage
text: HOT SPRINGS, S.D. — In the past couple of years, conservative opposition to same-sex marriage has clearly started to erode. Prominent Republicans like Senators Rob Portman and Lisa Murkowski and former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell have come out in support of gay marriage. Even David Blankenhorn, the expert witness in the Proposition 8 trial in California and a Democrat, announced that he had changed his mind.

headline: Confused by How YouTube Assigns Dates, Russians Cite False Claim on Syria Videos
text: Citing “reports circulating on the Internet,” a spokesman for Russia’s foreign ministry claimed on Friday that video posted online by opposition activists in Syria, said to show victims suffering from a chemical weapons strike outside Damascus on Wednesday, was fake.

headline: Two Market Operators, BATS and Direct Edge, Said to Be in Talks to Merge
text: BATS Global Markets and Direct Edge are in talks to merge, potentially creating one of the biggest stock market operators in the country, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Friday.

headline: Serendipity and Tradition Meet in Wallpaper Design
text: Alpha Workshops trains New Yorkers with H.I.V. for jobs in artistic fields. A new wallpaper design, called Astral, shows just how spontaneous Alpha’s students can be. Artisans at the workshop fold 15-foot-long sheets of paper, then unfold them, spread them out, and apply paint with a sponge. The paint is caught in the peaks and valleys, and no two sheets are exactly alike.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Catsimatidis Goes on the Attack
text: Thanks to his considerable fortune, John A. Catsimatidis has been a steady presence on television as he seeks the Republican nomination for mayor. His advertisements so far have touted his rags-to-riches biography and his commitment to public safety. Now, three weeks before the primary, he is going on the attack against his main Republican rival, Joseph J. Lhota. Mr. Lhota is the focus of a 30-second commercial, “3 Things,” that began airing Friday. A second new commercial, “Cares About Us,” also criticizes Mr. Lhota.

headline: Play Misty for Me
text: When designing Casamista, a portable humidifier produced by Umbra, Alan Wisniewski said he began with the idea of things that smoke: tugboat funnels, automobile tailpipes and rooftop chimneys. He settled on the last. “I thought that a traveling house with a functional chimney was a little reminder of a home away from home,” he said. The humidifier, made of molded satin-textured plastic, has a purifying filter and will fit on top of any water bottle or glass. It can also be used with water-soluble essential oils. The device comes with a USB cable and can run on AAA batteries, which are not included. Available in avocado or black for $25. Information: (800) 387-5122 or umbra.com.

headline: Museum for African Art Broadens Its Mandate
text: Soon after construction began in 2007 on the Museum for African Art’s new headquarters, engineers discovered a quicksand-like layer of sediment under the site, at Fifth Avenue and 110th Street. The structural problems were surmounted, but in other ways, the museum has had trouble finding stable ground since.

headline: Soldier Sentenced to Life Without Parole for Killing 16 Afghans
text: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash. — Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, who pleaded guilty to slaughtering 16 Afghan civilians inside their homes, will spend the rest of his life in prison, a military jury decided on Friday.

headline: Detroit Metal
text: Fordite, created through automakers’ now-defunct practice of spray painting cars by hand, has become a valuable material for some jewelers.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Next Microsoft Chief Should Pare the Menu
text: The next boss of Microsoft needs a “less is more” mindset. Chief Executive Steve Ballmer is finally on the way out. A $20 billion bump in the company’s value after the news shows just how badly investors want a new approach. The wasteful “try everything” strategy should go.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: A Writer’s Room
text: A view of Rome, a pristine computer screen, a photograph of Basquiat, an I.B.M. 196c typewriter, the ghost of another author. For these writers — each of whom releases a new book this fall — all they need to inspire is within these walls.

headline: Don’t Let The Government Get Its Hands On Obamacare!
text: Lots of people having fun with this great report from Jason Cherkis at the Kentucky State Fair:

headline: A Couple Who See Race Clearly
text: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: On Tiny Fogo Island, a Hotel Puts a Focus on Design
text: Fogo Island, a windswept fleck of land off the northeast coast of Newfoundland, has in the last several years been the site of an exciting project in economic renewal and avant-garde architecture.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 23
text: Subjects include Councilman Jumaane D. Williams; Kim Catullo, the wife of Christine C. Quinn; and Mayor Michael Bloomberg

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Obama on Equal Access to College
text: At a town hall meeting at Binghamton University, the president was asked how his plan will ensure that underrepresented groups will be able to have access to higher education.

headline: Despite ‘Enormous Strides,’ Minorities Still Face Barriers, President Says
text: SCRANTON, Pa. — President Obama declared on Friday that the United States had made “enormous strides” in race relations since the March on Washington 50 years ago, but said “institutional barriers” for African-Americans and other minorities still existed and must be overcome.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Sky Blue Looks Beyond N.W.S.L. Playoffs
text: The first season in the third attempt to establish a sustainable women’s professional soccer league in the United States is nearing a close.

headline: For Generations, a Family Vacation, Horses and All
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — The three Ogden Phippses wandered up and down the shedrow Thursday, as they do most mornings. The patriarch, Ogden Mills Phipps, 72, was steering a golf cart. His 5-year-old grandson and namesake, however, moved a whole lot quicker, allowing his grandfather to catch up only when he stopped to pet the nose of a racehorse.

headline: Screenwriter Questions Whether Tchaikovsky Was Gay, Sparking Furor in Russia
text: MOSCOW — A prominent Russian screenwriter working on a film about Tchaikovsky’s life that has just received state financing set off a firestorm this week by saying that the biopic would not focus on the composer’s sexuality because “it is far from a fact that Tchaikovsky was a homosexual.”

headline: Getting Tesla From Here to There
text: Whether Tesla Motors can meet its ambitious growth targets — not to mention support its high-flying stock price — may well depend on people like Jason Berkley.

headline: The Rise and Fall of Windows Mobile, Under Ballmer
text: Microsoft’s Windows Phone operating system is hardly as influential as its desktop counterpart. And now that Steven A. Ballmer has announced plans to retire, it is easy to point fingers at the Microsoft chief executive for the lackluster success the company has had in mobile computing.

headline: Red Wine Honey Cake
text: A different take on a Rosh Hashana favorite: Melissa Clark prepares a honey cake with olive oil, red wine and plenty of spices.

headline: A Guide for Swimmers Breaking Boundaries
text: Lynne Cox has spent more than four decades swimming past the known limits of human capacity. Driven by an explorer’s voracious desire to do what has never been done, and frankly obsessive about mental and physical preparation, she has completed scores of pioneering swims, most famously the frigid Bering Strait in just a suit, cap and goggles.

headline: A Homecoming for Honey Cakes
text: I’ve always thought that all Rosh Hashana honey cakes were born out of the same kosher recipe.

headline: The Moment | Demure With a Twist
text: There’s a twist on gender dressing taking hold of fashion, from the fullness of a skirt with brogues to a cluster of jewels on an oversize lapel.

headline: Big Ticket | $23 Million for a Floor on Park Avenue
text: A magisterial floor-through residence at 640 Park Avenue, an opulent limestone building designed by J. E. R. Carpenter as a luxury rental oasis for the millionaires of 1914, sold for $23 million and was the week’s most expensive residential transaction, according to city records. The building, at the northwest corner of Park Avenue and 66th Street, went co-op in 1946; the monthly maintenance fee for the simplex, No. 8, is $15,981.

headline: Does Media Violence Lead to the Real Thing?
text: EARLIER this summer the actor Jim Carrey, a star of the new superhero movie “Kick-Ass 2,” tweeted that he was distancing himself from the film because, in the wake of the Sandy Hook massacre, “in all good conscience I cannot support” the movie’s extensive and graphically violent scenes.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘Waiting for Waiting for Godot’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festival’s close on Aug. 25. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: War Leaves Wounds Behind the Camera, Too
text: Playwrights who know it all can often provide first-rate entertainment. But the very best plays usually come from writers who don’t necessarily have all the answers, who don’t insist on telling us what to think about the developments onstage and who don’t offer neat solutions to their characters’ problems.

headline: Movie Night, Hamptons Style
text: The Hamptons home theater is more than ready for its close-up. Twenty years ago it was a rare indulgence; these days it’s a mandatory amenity, more coveted than wine cellars and a source of exponentially greater entertainment than, say, the ubiquitous home gym or tennis court.

headline: Week in Review: S.E.C. Pushes to Fix Market Flaws
text: A barrage of bad trades from Goldman Sachs and pricing paralysis on Nasdaq is spurring regulators to push ahead on new safeguards.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘Very Bad Words’
text: The New York International Fringe Festival concludes on Aug. 25. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: We Blew the Funeral Money on an iPad, So Sing!
text: The nuns seem to be everywhere at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport. A few show up in the aisles even before the show begins, chatting up members of the audience. At intermission, nuns mill about in the lobby and the auditorium, engaging patrons in light conversation. During the musical itself — that would be “Nunsense,” which made its Off Broadway debut nearly 28 years ago — the nuns occasionally move off the stage to sing and award prizes, although thankfully not to the point of forced audience participation.

headline: Rebels Delay Peace Talks in Colombia
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Colombia’s largest rebel group said Friday that it would delay its peace talks with the Colombian government, complicating negotiations to end Latin America’s longest-running guerrilla war.

headline: Q & A
text: Demystifying Proxy Voting

headline: Carpaccio at Its Beefy Best
text: These days, on restaurant menus, you are likely to encounter carpaccio dishes made with anything but meat. There is octopus carpaccio, zucchini carpaccio or heirloom tomato carpaccio, not to mention dessert carpaccios like pineapple or mango.

headline: The Diary of Mrs. Tependris | Complicated Coats and Cabinets of Curiosities at Paris Couture, Part Two
text: The Greek-born artist Konstantin Kakanias is known for his drawings of eccentric characters, the most enduring of whom is a big-haired, beak-nosed, fashion-crazed woman-of-a-certain-age named Mrs. Tependris. This summer, at T’s invitation, Kakanias took Mrs. Tependris to the couture shows in Paris, where she was scandalized by latex-clad, masked models at Maison Martin Margiela, seated amid an audience of Qatari princesses at Armani Privé and encased in one of the artist Marina Abramovic’s space-age jumpsuits for Net-a-Porter at the Palais de Tokyo. Mrs. Tependris, who last attended the Paris shows in the mid-’90s, has kept herself busy with a different type of global affair in the intervening years. “She had to join a lot of revolutions, do a lot of political acts,” Kakanias said. “She just couldn’t do couture for a while.” Immediately following the shows last month, Kakanias shared Part One of his heroine’s adventure. Here, he fills us in on the rest of what Mrs. Tependris saw and did.

headline: Three Decades of Conversations With Fire
text: The ceramist Akira Satake is not used to playing the role of foreman, but you wouldn’t know it from the relaxed demeanor he displayed recently while leading a crew wearing protective face shields and fire-retardant gloves at Peters Valley School of Craft in Layton, in Sussex County.

headline: When Fashion Week Was Made of Simpler Cloth
text: The drumbeat for Fashion Week started a month ago in my in-box, and now it’s up to oblivion level, white noise in the black season.

headline: Not at First Sight, or Even the First Dozen
text: It was not as if they hadn’t had every chance to fall in love. For three years, Adrian Zackheim, the publisher and president of three imprints at Penguin Random House, and Elizabeth Lunney, co-founder of ABC Languages, a foreign language school, fled Manhattan for weekends to the same house owned by Nancy Winston in Westport, Conn.

headline: Head-Turners
text: Rob Sass takes a look at some trend-setting models from this year’s Monterey auctions.

headline: A Well-Traveled Concours Winner
text: PEBBLE BEACH, CALIF. — A dark green 1934 Packard 1108 Twelve Convertible Victoria with a custom body by Dietrich became the first Packard in 36 years to win the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance.

headline: Pebble Beach Gallery
text: A photographic tour of the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance, with a side trip to the cheeky Concours d’Lemons, courtesy of Jerry Garrett.

headline: Central Bank Acts to Strengthen Brazilian Real
text: Brazil’s central bank announced a $60 billion program on Thursday aimed at halting the slide of the Brazilian real, making Brazil the latest emerging economy to seek to prop up its sagging currency.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Hawaii; Kentucky; Munich
text: Aloha Festivals, Oahu, Hawaii A celebration of Hawaiian culture and history through music, dance, cuisine and art will take place at various locations on Oahu during the 2013 Aloha Festivals from Sept. 12 to 28. Highlights include an opening ceremony featuring traditional chants and hula dancing, concerts, demonstrations, activities, displays of crafts, food booths, block parties and a parade with marching bands, floats with cascades of Hawaiian flowers, and pa’u riders (women on horseback), above. Many of this year’s events pay tribute to the ocean-voyaging culture of the islands’ ancestors. All events are free and open to the public.

headline: Betony Vernon’s Guardian Angel
text: Success is, of course, a beautiful thing, a gift of affirmation from the world that comes in a neat little box. The only problem is that if you want to keep this gift, you usually have to get into the box and stay there. In other words, the good news is that you get a niche. That’s also the bad news. If you don’t fit easily in your assigned compartment, you may get uncomfortable.

headline: London Lawyers Measure Themselves for New Robes
text: Stories by lawyers about lawyers are often guilty of grandstanding for the jury (that’s us), and early in the first episode of “Silk” the barrister heroine is told, apropos of not much: “Fifteen years you’ve been doing this and you still believe, don’t you? Innocent until proven guilty.” Just in case we missed the point, it’s repeated by her a few minutes later: “Innocent until proven guilty. Four words to live by.”

headline: Go East Old Man: Off The Reservation
text: Dexter Ford is traveling from Southern California to upstate New York along mostly obscure roads, on a motorcycle that, by American standards, is quite tiny. This is the fourth of his occasional reports from the paths less traveled.

headline: Untangling a Mesh of Identities
text: It’s tough enough to be a teenager in New York City. Try this formula for confusion: “I am a Palestinian-Lebanese-American Christian woman, but I grew up as a Jew in New York City. I began my life, however, as a WASP.”

headline: Playing Spy, Sans Violence
text: “If you want to keep your hands, I want names,” an American spy growls at one point in the new video game Tom Clancy’s Splinter Cell: Blacklist. The man he is yelling at is on the ground, arms stretched, wrists trapped between the nearly closed legs of a folding chair. Our hero, the spy, whom we control in most of the game, is torturing this other man for information. He’s worried about another terrorist attack in the United States, which would be the second one in Blacklist.

headline: Car Bombs Kill Dozens in Lebanon
text: Two deadly explosions killed dozens and wounded hundreds in the largely Sunni Muslim city of Tripoli in northern Lebanon.

headline: Stopped Cold: Mercedes Sales Blocked in France
text: BERLIN — Even as showrooms in Europe prepare for the arrival of 2014 vehicles, authorities in France have sparked controversy with a drastic action: blocking the registration — effectively shutting down sales — of some popular new Mercedes-Benz cars, including the A-Class, B-Class, CLA and SL models.

headline: Your Earrings Remind Me of Grandma’s Gran Torino
text: DETROIT — With its layers of colors and psychedelic swirls, fordite resembles jasper or Mexican crazy lace. And though fordite is crafted into eye-catching jewelry, it is not a gemstone — rather, it is dried paint that built up, layer upon layer, in factories that built automobiles long ago.

headline: Wood That Proudly Wears the Marks of Previous Use
text: VENICE — “Those poles look so old,” my companion said, pointing to the striped “barber poles” lining the canals. “I wonder how long they last in that salt water?”

headline: Taking Beethoven on a Mashed-Up Quirky Adventure
text: We have come almost automatically to associate Beethoven with impressions of fist-shaking temperament and eternity-pondering quest. But during his lifetime, one popular work cast him in a different light not particularly to his liking. His Septet in E-flat (Op. 20), introduced in 1800 when he was 29, reportedly caused strangers to ask why he didn’t write more in its sunny, vivacious and genteel style.

headline: Richard Simmons, Internet Star?
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — “Richard, honey, you’ve got lipstick on your teeth.”

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Aug. 23, 2013
text: How vulnerable are financial markets to computer glitches? The Nasdaq stock exchange was paralyzed for more than three hours this week because of technical problem and Goldman Sachs reportedly lost $100 million after erroneous algorithmic trades. Joe Nocera of The New York Times and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine spoke with Heidi Moore of the Guardian on WNYC’s “Money Talking” about the real impact of software malfunctions on financial markets and what regulators can do about it.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Lebanon, Egypt, Japan and Syria.

headline: A Jazz Host Remembered as Inspiration
text: Marian McPartland, who died on Tuesday at 95, was an erudite jazz pianist whose career stretched back to the heyday of 52nd Street. But she will be best remembered for “Marian McPartland’s Piano Jazz,” the public radio show she hosted for more than 30 years, featuring duets and conversation with an array of musicians.

headline: Making the Rounds at Boxing and Brunch
text: The composer and lyricist William Finn lives on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and spends his summers at “Wasabi Gables.” That’s what he and his longtime partner, Arthur Salvadore, call their corner Victorian house in Pittsfield, Mass., for its exterior hue. Mr. Finn, 61, a two-time Tony Award winner, has been the artistic director since 2006 of the Musical Theater Lab at the Barrington Stage Company, up the block. There he was part of the team that developed and premiered “The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee” before its Off Broadway and Broadway success. After two years of revision, “Little Miss Sunshine,” by Mr. Finn and the librettist James Lapine, will open off Broadway this fall at Second Stage. On the last summer Sundays, Mr. Finn will socialize with Barrington Stage’s director, Julianne Boyd, and go to productions, when not serving as M.C. for “Mr. Finn’s Cabaret” at the theater. Rather than seeking rest, he looks for the joy in work and play.

headline: A Surprising Reversal for Emerging Stock Markets
text: FOR more than a decade, investors loved emerging markets. Now many seem to fear them.

headline: Syrian Kurds Flee to Northern Iraq
text: Authorities and aid groups in northern Iraq scramble to accommodate the thousands of Syrian Kurds seeking shelter from the conflict in Syria.

headline: Syrian Kurds Find More Than a Refuge in Northern Iraq
text: SAHELA, Iraq — Some were moved by fears that the violence in Syria would soon find them, as rumors of beheadings by Islamist militants circulated from one village to another.

headline: Local Stop: Governors Island
text: Weekend visits to Governors Island, via free ferries, have soared since it was opened to the public in 2004.

headline: Women at Google Looking Past the Glass Ceiling
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, CALIF. — When Isabelle Olsson, the lead industrial designer for Google Glass, arrived at Diane von Furstenberg’s New York studio to fit models for the new device, she wasn’t concerned about how the models would look strutting along the runway wearing tiny screens and computers on their faces.

headline: Thai Officials Play Down Effects of Oil Spill
text: KOH SAMET, Thailand — Two rescue operations were set in motion last month when a burst pipeline sent tons of crude oil gushing into the sea near this idyllic resort island. One was cleaning up the spill. The other was defending the image of Thailand’s tourism industry, crucial to the country’s increasingly fragile economy.

headline: Strolling and Playing, but No More Saluting
text: On a map, New York’s biggest summer playground looks just like an ice cream cone, shaped for the city’s enjoyment. Governors Island was an Army base until 1966, then used by the Coast Guard through the mid-1990s. It opened to the public in 2004, with guests first arriving in small numbers. But times change: on a recent weekend, 12,000 visitors took a free ferry from Brooklyn Bridge Park or the Beaux-Arts Battery Maritime Building in Lower Manhattan to enjoy the 172-acre island’s lawns, historic buildings, food carts and arts programs — all open Saturdays, Sundays and holiday Mondays through Sept. 29.

headline: The Writer’s Room
text: A view of Rome, a pristine computer screen, a photograph of Basquiat, an I.B.M. 196c typewriter, the ghost of another author. For these writers below — each of whom releases a new book this fall — all they need to inspire is within these walls.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Hell’s Kitchen condo, a Murray Hill co-op and a condo in Williamsburg.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A Connecticut colonial and a New Jersey beach house.

headline: Obama Says Law School Should Be Two, Not Three, Years
text: President Obama urged law schools on Friday to consider cutting a year of classroom instruction, wading into a hotly debated issue inside the beleaguered legal academy.

headline: Dancing Erotically, With Knives
text: HUDSON, N.Y. — The knives are always out. They hang, in a neat and gleaming row of nine, above the sink of the fashionable London home that is the setting for “Stockholm,” Bryony Lavery’s sharp and twisting liebestod of a play, which has been given a smashing American premiere at Stageworks/Hudson here.

headline: The Fine Print of Dvorak’s Contract
text: The contract that brought Antonin Dvorak to New York to lead the National Conservatory of Music of America allowed him to earn more than 25 times what he had been earning in Prague, and opened a very fruitful period of his career in which he wrote some of his best-loved works, including the “New World” Symphony and the Cello Concerto. While its details have long been known to scholars, one of the original signed contracts — discovered recently by the great-grandson of the conservatory’s founder, Jeannette Thurber, and purchased by the Dvorak American Heritage Association — will be displayed publicly for the first time on Sept. 8 at the Bohemian National Hall at 321 East 73rd Street in Manhattan.

headline: The Deal That Brought Dvorak to New York
text: It was an audacious act of Gilded Age New York. Jeannette Thurber, a wealthy patron trying to create not just a new American music school but, more broadly, a new American school of music, decided in 1891 to hire one of the greatest composers of the day: Antonin Dvorak.

headline: Transgender Woman Dies in a Possible Hate Crime
text: A transgender woman attacked last weekend in Harlem has died in a case the police said they were now investigating as a hate crime after learning that the man accused of hitting her may have used antigay epithets.

headline: Obama’s Complete Event in Binghamton
text: The president held a town hall meeting at the University of Binghamton to address a variety of issues facing higher education.

headline: Styles Reach Beyond Appearances
text: On Thursday evening at Drive East, the festival of South Asian music and dance running at La MaMa, an exuberant South Korean dancer took center stage. Jin Won, that dancer and a resident of India for 15 years, specializes in Kathak, a form of classical Indian dance. But as a skilled tabla player, she’s also as much a musician as a dancer.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Active Wear
text: With fashion pulling in so many directions in search of a definitive look for this decade, women are not forgetting the importance of pants (not leggings).

headline: A Chance at Learning
text: This year, a study administered by researchers at Harvard and Stanford drew significant attention for what it revealed about how inadequately low-income students are represented at selective colleges and universities. Only 34 percent of the highest-achieving high-school seniors whose families fell in the bottom quarter of income distribution — versus 78 percent in the top quarter — attended one of the country’s most selective colleges, based on a list of nearly 250 schools compiled by Barron’s.

headline: Moonman Brings a Red Carpet to Brooklyn
text: Brooklyn, with its reputation for nurturing rap and indie music, may not seem like the most obvious place to hold the Video Music Awards — with its emphasis on pop stars like Katy Perry and Bruno Mars.

headline: ‘On Tilt’ at the World Youth Junior Pairs in Atlanta
text: ATLANTA — At the 3rd World Youth Open Championships in Atlanta this month, Sylvia Shi and Alex Prairie, both of Baltimore, finished third in the Junior Pairs (under 26). They gained the largest plus score of the eight-day tournament.

headline: A Night Under the Urban Sky
text: Thomas Stevenson, a Brooklyn artist, organizes Bivouac New York, a rooftop camp.

headline: Movie Review: 'The World's End'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "The World's End."

headline: Afghans Share Their Views on the West’s Influence
text: The United States and its allies have worked for a decade to instill democratic and legal reforms in Afghanistan, with a particular focus on women’s rights. We asked Afghans through this Facebook note to share their views on the West’s influence in their country. We received responses via e-mail and Facebook. Here is a selection of the responses, edited and condensed.

headline: Movie Review: 'Drinking Buddies'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Drinking Buddies.”

headline: Movie Review: 'The Grandmaster'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "The Grandmaster."

headline: Sleepover in a Rooftop Camp
text: Our retreat from the grid began with a last-minute e-mail: meet on a rooftop at the edge of Williamsburg, half an hour before sunset. Bring a sleeping bag and some food to share. It was signed: Thomas, Ranger at Bivouac NY.

headline: In the Air | International Velvet
text: The rich textile has long been the calling card of the stylishly privileged. Now, it's fashion’s turn to embrace the stuff of royals.

headline: Remembering Iraq on an Indian Reservation
text: Why go back? After five years in the Army, with 27 months spent in Iraq and much of the rest in Honolulu, why would Lance Marottek, 25, return to the northeastern Montana town of Poplar, population less than 1,000? On the rough edge of the Fort Peck Indian Reservation, with a graduating high school class of just 40 students, it offers the kind of small town life many young men join the military to flee from, never to return.

headline: Friday Night Music: Lucius, Go Home
text: I first found this band on a Tiny Desk Concert, which was wonderful; but I’ve been checking in every now and then for more recent performances, and they have gotten even better — incredibly intense. Wait for the 3:10 or so mark:

headline: New This Week: ‘Driven’ Video Reviews by Tom Voelk
text: In his Behind the Wheel review in this weekend’s Automobiles section, Ezra Dyer notes that a spacious trunk has always been part of the appeal of the Chevy Impala, and cites the capacity of a previous generation of that sedan to swallow cases of Tylenol PM and K-Y jelly.

headline: Ballmer Through the Years
text: Moments of Steven A. Ballmer from conferences, commercials and interviews over the years that he was Microsoft’s chief executive.

headline: Restaurants Were His Life
text: The tales of Colin Devlin’s generosity sound like fables. Once, though he was nearly broke and working as a bartender, he pulled $1,000 out of his sock and gave it to a friend starting a restaurant.

headline: Pressure Rises on Hamas as Patrons’ Support Fades
text: GAZA CITY — The tumult roiling the Arab world had already severed the lifeline between the Palestinian militant group Hamas and two of its most important patrons, Iran and Syria.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 23
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include Councilman Jumaane D. Williams; Kim Catullo, the wife of Christine C. Quinn; and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Weekend Wheels Calendar
text: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: Jeter’s Latest Return Could Come Monday
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Derek Jeter has yet to play alongside Alex Rodriguez this season, but signs point to a Monday reunion in Toronto, barring a setback. Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said Jeter, who is recovering from a Grade 1 strain of his right calf, was scheduled to play again Friday and Saturday for Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre.

headline: Denying Accusations of Sexual Harassment, the Mayor of San Diego Resigns
text: SAN DIEGO — Mayor Bob Filner resigned on Friday under a barrage of sexual harassment complaints, offering an apology to his accusers while still denying the allegations and blaming his downfall on “a combination of awkwardness and hubris.”

headline: Microsoft With Ballmer at the Helm
text: Important milestones of Steven A. Ballmer’s tenure as Microsoft’s chief executive, tracked alongside fluctuations in the company’s stock price.

headline: Editor’s Letter
text: As this is a fashion issue, and there is plenty of alluring fashion in these pages, I thought I’d start the issue off with a short note about books. Well, about physical objects really. We photographed writers with forthcoming books — Jonathan Lethem, Edwidge Danticat, Richard Dawkins, Jhumpa Lahiri and Julian Barnes — at home in their work spaces. Quite frankly, none of the spaces look that remarkable; there are no bursts of design genius or eccentric collections. Just what one might expect: wood tables, crowded bookshelves, laptops, messy desks. But as you read each writer’s essay about their space, you understand the resonance these ordinary, simple things convey to each of them. Value is something we bestow upon objects — whether a picture tacked on the wall, a mess of papers, an old typewriter. We animate the inanimate through our memories, associations and desires.

headline: What’s Ailing the Airlines, and Us
text: To the Editor:

headline: Public Defenders Are Tightening Belts Because of Steep Federal Budget Cuts
text: WASHINGTON — Faced with steep cuts to their budgets, federal public defenders around the country have furloughed or laid off hundreds of lawyers and other staff members, spent less on expert witnesses and cut back on case-related travel.

headline: Microsoft, Then and Now
text: Microsoft’s profit is more than twice what it was in 2000, the year Steven A. Ballmer took over as C.E.O. But in that time, the company’s stock price has fallen, along with its market value.

headline: The Unending Struggle to Find Affordable Child Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: Transparency at F.E.C.
text: To the Editor:

headline: T Fall Women’s Issue
text: T’s fall Women’s Fashion issue is all about the ladies: Rooney Mara‘s visceral performances in complex films (David Amsden gets to her core), Victoria Beckham‘s injection of chic sophistication into her ready-to-wear line, and this century’s greatest botanical artist‘s stunning, otherworldly creations. Suzy Menkes investigates where the fashion industry has broken down and why it’s so impossible to get our hands on a retail coat in winter, while Howie Kahn immerses us in the sights and smells of Shanghai’s exploding culinary scene. You will also find photographs of where modern writers work and where the Milanese designers of Dimore Studio live. Plus, the photographer Glen Luchford captures the season’s bold, graphic prints amid the cacophony of New York City; Amy Schumer and Aerin Lauder test-drive a snood; the artist Ranee Palone Flynn shares the process behind shooting total strangers; and velvet returns to its place atop the high-fashion throne. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: War on Egypt’s Christians
text: To the Editor:

headline: Christie and Gay Rights
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nuclear Operator Raises Alarm on Crisis
text: TOKYO — The operator of Japan’s tsunami-hit nuclear power plant sounded the alarm on the gravity of the deepening crisis of containment at the coastal site on Friday, saying that there are more than 200,000 tons of radioactive water in makeshift tanks vulnerable to leaks, with no reliable way to check on them or anywhere to transfer the water.

headline: Biggest Sale of Year in Europe Appears to Be Near Finish
text: The Gareth Bale transfer drama appeared Friday to be reaching its merciful, and seemingly inevitable, end. Tottenham Hotspur worked to complete a deal to move Bale, its talented Welsh wing, to Real Madrid for a price that would almost certainly top the world-record fee that Madrid paid to acquire Cristiano Ronaldo in 2009.

headline: New Rules Would Cut Silica Dust Exposure
text: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration proposed long-awaited rules on Friday to limit crystalline silica, a move it said would prevent nearly 700 deaths a year by reducing exposure to these very small particles that can cause lung cancer and other diseases.

headline: The Ugly American Telegram
text: BOSTON — ON Aug. 24, 1963, the American ambassador to South Vietnam, Henry Cabot Lodge, received a top-secret message with the bureaucratically anodyne title Deptel 243. But the content of the message was anything but routine. Hastily drafted and cleared over the course of a single day, with most of official Washington on vacation, Deptel 243, also known as the Hilsman telegram, signaled a major shift in American policy. A few days later Mr. Lodge remarked, “We are launched on a course from which there is no respectable turning back.”

headline: Qualifying Chronicles: Answering Reader Questions
text: Irina Falconi, a 23-year-old American, who lost in the first round of qualifying, is writing posts for Straight Sets from the United States Open this year. You can also follow her on tumblr and Twitter.

headline: I Have a Character Issue
text: LOS ANGELES — PLAYING Skyler White on the television show “Breaking Bad” for the past five seasons has been one of the most rewarding creative journeys I’ve embarked on as an actor. But the role has also taken me on another kind of journey — one I never would have imagined.

headline: A Blunt Chief Justice Unafraid to Upset Brazil’s Status Quo
text: BRASÍLIA — Brazil’s highest court has long viewed itself as a bastion of manners and formality. Justices call one another “Your Excellency,” dress in billowing robes and wrap each utterance in grandiloquence, as if little had changed from the era when marquises and dukes held sway from their vast plantations.

headline: Settlement in Lawsuit Against Paula Deen
text: The legal battle that led to the near-instant collapse of Paula Deen’s multimillion-dollar food empire ended on Friday when the last pieces of a lawsuit, filed by a former manager at one of her restaurants, were resolved in a settlement agreement.

headline: Where Credit Is Due
text: A few months ago, a saleswoman at Macy’s tried to wheedle me into renewing my expired store credit card by offering a deep discount on the towels I was buying. So I dug it out of my wallet, where it was nestled between an expired press pass to the Texas State Capitol and an expired library card from Manchester, N.H., and happily handed it over.

headline: A Dream Examined
text: A half-century after the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, disparities in education, employment, housing and wages still exist.

headline: Apple and Microsoft, Then and Now
text: If you picked up The New York Times in December 2000, you would have seen very different headlines than exist today. Microsoft was projected to generate revenue of $6.4 billion for the last fiscal quarter of 2000, whereas Apple, the company’s almost-lifeless competitor, was clawing to reach $1 billion in revenue.

headline: At a Fed Conference, Views Differ Sharply on Stimulus’s Effect
text: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — There is still plenty of skepticism about the stimulus campaigns of the Federal Reserve and other central banks, and there is plenty of concern about the consequences. But for the first time in several years, there was also a general sense of optimism among the policy makers gathered here for an annual meeting at the foot of the Grand Tetons that things are going reasonably well.

headline: The Next Hurricane, and the Next
text: Hurricane Sandy, the monster storm that hit the Atlantic Seaboard on Oct. 29, left at least 159 dead and caused $65 billion in damages. But as a presidential task force made clear this week, Sandy cannot be considered a seasonal disaster or regional fluke but as yet another harbinger of the calamities that await in an era of climate change. With that in mind, the report says that individuals, local governments and states that expect federal help cannot simply restore what was there but must adopt new standards and harden community structures to withstand the next flood or hurricane.

headline: A Good Deal Gone Bad
text: In 2007, the president of Ecuador, Rafael Correa, offered the world a deal: find $3.6 billion and he would institute a permanent moratorium on oil drilling in the Amazon’s Yasuni National Park, one of the most biologically diverse places on the planet.

headline: Finding Lessons in Stumbles, American Aims for the Top Again
text: When the draw for the United States Open was made Thursday, Ryan Harrison’s name again appeared next to that of one of the biggest stars in the sport. This time, it was Rafael Nadal, the No. 2 seed, who comes to New York with a 10-match winning streak and a 15-0 record on hardcourts.

headline: Air War in Kosovo Seen as Precedent in Possible Response to Syria Chemical Attack
text: WASHINGTON — As President Obama weighs options for responding to a suspected chemical weapons attack in Syria, his national security aides are studying the NATO air war in Kosovo as a possible blueprint for acting without a mandate from the United Nations.

headline: Hedge Funds Win Ruling in Argentina Bond Case
