text: A dogged group of hedge funds secured a significant victory in a federal appeals court on Friday in a case that is likely to have far-reaching effects on international bond markets, parts of the banking system and the struggling nation of Argentina.

headline: Dean Meminger, Who Helped Knicks to a Title, Dies at 65
text: Dean Meminger, a speedy guard and tenacious defender who honed his basketball style in Harlem playgrounds and went on to play for the Knicks’ 1973 N.B.A. title team, was pronounced dead on Friday in a hotel room in Upper Manhattan. He was 65.

headline: In Paper War, Flood of Liens Is the Weapon
text: MINNEAPOLIS — One of the first inklings Sheriff Richard Stanek had that something was wrong came with a call from the mortgage company handling his refinancing.

headline: After Mishaps, Nasdaq Loses Standing to Rivals
text: Nasdaq was once the upstart of the financial world, set to take over the American stock market. Now, the company is looking more like a vulnerable also-ran.

headline: Questions for Microsoft as It Nears a Crossroad
text: Microsoft’s plan, announced Friday, to replace Steven A. Ballmer as its chief executive does not exactly follow — at least to people outside the company — the way they draft these things in business school.

headline: Tom Christian, Descendant of Bounty Mutineer, Dies at 77
text: Tom Christian, known as the Voice of Pitcairn for his half-century-long role in keeping his tiny South Pacific island, famed as the refuge of the Bounty mutineers, connected to the world, died at his home there on July 7. Mr. Christian, Pitcairn’s chief radio officer and a great-great-great-grandson of Fletcher Christian, the mutiny’s leader, was 77.

headline: Second Day of Barclays Is Another Marathon, This One in Fair Weather
text: JERSEY CITY — Phil Mickelson’s day began at 7:02 a.m., and when it finally ended, 31 holes later, he was on the ninth green, more than a mile away from the Liberty National Golf Course clubhouse. A white van stood ready to whisk him back, the same van that delivered him out onto the course four and a half hours earlier.

headline: N.S.A. Said to Have Paid E-Mail Providers Millions to Cover Costs From Court Ruling
text: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency apparently compensated e-mail service providers “millions of dollars” for costs they incurred in the fallout from an October 2011 court ruling that an unrelated aspect of the agency’s surveillance operations violated the Constitution, according to a newly disclosed document.

headline: A Troubled Teenager at Odds With Life in the Bronx
text: To those who did not know him, Shaaliver Douse was an example of everything that can go wrong in a young life.

headline: Syria: U.N. Notes ‘Shameful Milestone’
text: One million children are now refugees from the conflict raging in Syria, the United Nations reported Friday, calling it a “shameful milestone” in a crisis now well into its third year. Anthony Lake, executive director of the United Nations Children’s Fund, and António Guterres, the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, said in a joint statement that half of all refugees forced to flee Syria were children and that 740,000 of those children were younger than 11 years old. The statement also said that more than 7,000 children had been killed in Syria, where the total death toll in the conflict has surpassed 100,000.

headline: On Detectives’ Play List, the Ballad of the Oblivious Victim
text: A 27-year-old Brooklyn man began last Saturday healthy enough, but by midmorning had four new holes in him. This much everyone agrees on.

headline: Mexico: Bodies Linked to Abduction
text: The remains of five bodies pulled from a mass grave discovered this week in Tlalmanalco have been identified as members of a group of young people who vanished from a bar in May, the attorney general said Friday. Twelve people disappeared from the Heaven nightclub in a bustling neighborhood in Mexico City, where residents are not accustomed to the brazen acts of violence that have convulsed other regions of the country. Relatives of the victims have complained about the investigation’s slow progress. The mass grave, 30 miles east of Mexico City, contained 13 craniums, the attorney general’s office said.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 24, 2013
text: “I never intended to be a mayor who went out like this.”

headline: Man Arriving at J.F.K. Is Accused of Trying to Export Uranium to Iran
text: The request posted last year on the Web site alibaba.com was surprisingly straightforward for such a dubious proposition.

headline: A Comeback for Negro Leagues Museum
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — With an actor’s showmanship, a man wearing black glasses and a white fedora described the player behind each of the 10 bronze statues that greeted a small group of visitors inside the lobby of the Negro Leagues Baseball Museum.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Bloomberg Shares a Few Secrets of His Success: Be Early, Stay Late and Hold It In
text: He went from Eagle Scout to Wall Street titan, designed a machine that sits on bankers’ desks around the world and reshaped notions of New York City government.

headline: 50 Years Later
text: As we approach the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington, I have a gnawing in my gut, an uneasy sense of society and its racial reality.

headline: Jets Activate Holmes, Who May Make Opener
text: Santonio Holmes was removed from the physically unable to perform list and added to the active roster Friday, a sign that he could be available for the Sept. 8 season opener. If Holmes is able to return then — or soon after — he will provide a lift to an unproven receiving corps, as well as to the quarterback, whoever wins that job.

headline: Corrections: August 24, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Flip a Coin
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — The Zairian ZAIRE, a now-defunct currency that bore the portrait of Mobuto Sese Seko, was replaced in 1998 by the Congolese franc after the nation changed its name to Democratic Republic of Congo. The zaire was one of just a handful of world currencies whose name matched, or roughly matched, the name of the country that issued it. Other examples include Afghanistan’s afghani, Bolivia’s boliviano and of course the French franc. This currency club is as varied in membership as THE UN, which is itself one of several internationally oriented answers in the all-encompassing Saturday puzzle from Frederick J. Healy that manages to touch on geography in GHANA and animal species in ASIA.

headline: The New Nuclear Craze
text: There is a new discussion about nuclear energy, prompted by well-founded concerns about carbon emissions and fueled by a pro-nuclear documentary called “Pandora’s Promise.” Add a statement by James E. Hansen — who famously sounded the alarm on climate change — and, of course, industry propaganda, and presto: We Love Nukes.

headline: C Train Cafe? Transit Agency May Put Up Fight
text: New York is a huckster’s paradise, the province of the fake Rolex and the sham Prada purse, counterfeit Yankees tickets and a Times Square teeming with impostor Elmos.

headline: Tom Ewing’s Dirty War
text: Thomas Ewing Jr. was a conscientious man. Though never as flamboyant as his foster brother, William Tecumseh Sherman, Ewing was ambitious for political fame and fortune, as befitted the son of one of Ohio’s leading Whig politicians. His father had served both in the United States Senate and in the cabinets of Presidents William Henry Harrison and Zachary Taylor. Thomas Ewing Jr., or Tom, was his father’s personal secretary when the elder Ewing ran Taylor’s Department of the Interior.

headline: Staten Island Ferry Exploring Free Wi-Fi Onboard and in Terminals
text: The Staten Island Ferry, known for its free rides and inexpensive beer, may soon add another amenity: Internet access.

headline: New York City Election Choices
text: Public AdvocateThe job of public advocate is little more than a bullhorn, and sometimes not even that. The original purpose of this position was to give citizens a voice in City Hall and serve as a watchdog on the mayor and the city government. But the job’s influence has been whittled away by a succession of mayors, and its budget is a mere $2.2 million, barely enough to pay the electric bills and a few modest salaries. Its only real power comes if the mayor dies or resigns; the public advocate takes over until an election can be held in a few months.

headline: Questions About Republican’s Citizenship
text: Senator Ted Cruz faced criticism over his dual Canadian citizenship while campaigning against the Affordable Care Act in Texas. His birthplace calls into question his eligibility to run for president.

headline: Inside Job Is Considered in Armored-Car Robbery
text: The armored truck was waiting near a Pay-O-Matic check-cashing store in south Brooklyn, when the driver heard a knock on the rear door. So he unlocked it. He later told investigators that he had assumed that the vehicle’s guard had been knocking, having finished his pickup at the check-cashing store. But the man who entered the armored truck was not his partner. It was a gunman with a scarf wrapped around his head.

headline: Weighing Pain of Traffic for Preseason Games
text: Traffic is as much a part of the modern sports experience as the game itself, but not all event congestion is created equal.

headline: Yankees’ Playoff Push Takes Step Backward
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — After a week spent beating up the worst team in the American League East, the Yankees were flush with confidence and energized to find themselves back in a playoff race most people thought had passed them by. But once they flew south to face off against one of the best teams in the division, things did not go quite as smoothly.

headline: José Sarria, Gay Advocate and Performer, Dies at 90
text: José Sarria, a drag performer and gay rights advocate who many historians contend was the first openly gay person to campaign for public office in the United States when he ran for the San Francisco Board of Supervisors in 1961, died on Monday at his home in Los Ranchos de Albuquerque, N.M.  He was 90.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: Bloomberg L.P. said it would change its journalism operation, trading on the Nasdaq was halted for three hours and Home Depot reported earnings that exceeded projections.

headline: Cabrera and Tigers Rock Matsuzaka in His Mets Debut
text: The last time Terry Collins saw Daisuke Matsuzaka pitch in person — a first-round matchup of the 2009 World Baseball Classic — Collins was China’s manager and considered the Japanese ace to be one of the best pitchers in the world.

headline: Red Sox’ Ortiz Plays Down His Remarks on Incident With Rodriguez
text: LOS ANGELES — If David Ortiz was bothered that his teammate Ryan Dempster plunked Alex Rodriguez, he found a new source of exasperation as he stood at his locker Friday afternoon — that people were still asking him about it.

headline: Car Bombs Explode in Tripoli
text: The blasts killed at least 27 and wounded over 350, wreaking major destruction in the country’s second largest city

headline: Criminal Complaint Against Patrick Campbell
text: Read the full criminal complaint against Patrick Campbell, accused of trying to sell yellowcake uranium to Iran.

headline: Preserving the Game’s History
text: The Negro Leagues Baseball Museum displays players’ uniforms, signed balls and life-size sculptures of some stars.

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) LIFE OF PI (2012) Based on the novel by Yann Martel and directed by Ang Lee, this tale chronicles the life of Pi Patel (Suraj Sharma, above), the son of an Indian zoo owner who becomes stranded on a boat in the Pacific and must fight not only dehydration and starvation, but also a Bengal tiger, to survive. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that this film, which received four Oscars, including best director, best cinematography and best special effects, “unfolds in a setting that is one of the great achievements of digital cinema, and a reminder that the eclectic Mr. Lee is, among other things, an exuberant and inventive visual artist.” He added: “There are images in ‘Life of Pi’ that are so beautiful, so surprising, so right that I hesitate to describe them. Suffice it to say that the simple, elemental facts of sky, sea and animal life are captured with sweetness and sublimity.”

headline: Fallen Chinese Official, at His Trial, Faces Accuser Who Set Scandal in Motion
text: JINAN, China — In a dramatic high point of his trial, Bo Xilai, the fallen Communist Party star, faced off in court on Saturday with Wang Lijun, the former police chief whose flight to an American consulate last year set off the biggest scandal to shake the party in decades.

headline: 2 More Are Arrested in the Rape of a Photojournalist in India
text: MUMBAI — The police in Mumbai on Saturday arrested two more men accused of raping a photojournalist who was attacked while on assignment for an English-language magazine.

headline: Obama and Advisers to Discuss Syria
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is expected to meet with his national security advisers on Saturday morning to discuss reports of a chemical weapons attack by the Syrian government and how the United States might respond, a White House official said.

headline: VMware Killed the Past. Can It Claim the Future?
text: VMware is a 15-year-old tech company with a market capitalization of $36 billion. Next week, it will host 21,000 customers in San Francisco and will start to find out if that means it is young or old.

headline: How Ballmer Missed the Tidal Shifts in Tech
text: By now, you’ve probably heard: Steven A. Ballmer will soon be stepping down as chief executive of Microsoft.

headline: On The Symmetry Between Microsoft And Apple
text: I am not a tech industry maven, so I am busy coming up to speed on the implications of the Ballmer resignation. And what I’m about to say may be obvious to many. Still, I think it’s worth saying: there is, once you look past the surface, a remarkable symmetry between Microsoft’s strategy in its heyday and Apple’s strategy today.

headline: Trying to Inspire a New Generation
text: WASHINGTON — Half a century after the emotional apex of the civil rights movement, Martin Luther King Jr.'s “I Have a Dream” speech, tens of thousands of people retraced his footsteps on Saturday, and his successors in the movement spoke of the still-unmet promise of America, as he did, at the Lincoln Memorial.

headline: Maybe They’ll Never Figure It Out
text: Kathleen Geier points to some polling I’d missed: 39 percent of Americans agree that the government should stay out of Medicare, while only 46 percent disagree; the rest aren’t sure. She also points to the Suzanne Mettler work showing that many beneficiaries of Social Security and Medicare believe that they have never benefited from a government program.

headline: Scenes From the 50th Anniversary of the March on Washington
text: Last Updated | 9:24 p.m. As my colleagues reported, tens of thousands of people from across the country streamed onto the National Mall on Saturday for a daylong commemoration of the approaching 50th anniversary of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom.

headline: Growth in Tennis? Tape Measure Is Telling
text: One recent breezy evening in Montreal, Juan Martín del Potro traded powerful serves and thunderous forehands with Milos Raonic for two otherwise uninspiring sets, won by Raonic. This tale of tall tennis players highlighted what many have contended — and in some cases feared — will be the future of men’s professional tennis.

headline: In Race for N.L. M.V.P., Gomez Deserves Votes
text: For many years the basic formula for deciding who would win the Most Valuable Player award came down to the triple crown statistics — batting average, home run and runs batted in — and the record of the player’s team. There were occasional exceptions, but if a player had 140 R.B.I. for a first-place team, he had a good chance of receiving Major League Baseball’s highest single-season honor.

headline: Mandela’s Condition Remains Critical but Stable
text: JOHANNESBURG — Former President Nelson Mandela’s health remains critical but stable, the South African government said Saturday, but doctors are required to make “medical interventions” when his health becomes unstable, according to a statement released by the office of President Jacob Zuma.

headline: Linebacker Settles In, at Last, With the Jets
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Linebacker Garrett McIntyre exuded pride as he assessed a seven-year professional football career that has taken him to two countries, three leagues and six teams.

headline: Variety: Rainy Day Moods
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Today’s food for thought comes from the American writer David Mamet, who comments on the nature of man’s self-obsession and dramatization – going so far as to suggest that we all draw parallels between our internal lives and the weather. Since the “weather reflecting mood” trope is a common literary device, it’s entirely appropriate that this quote comes from a playwright.

headline: Signs of Chemical Attack Detailed by Aid Group
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — An international aid group said Saturday that medical centers it supported near the site of a suspected chemical weapons attack near Damascus received more than 3,000 patients showing symptoms consistent with exposure to toxic nerve agents on the morning of the reported attack.

headline: What Happened to the Kandy-Kolored Tangerine-Flake Streamline Baby?
text: Have you looked at the cars around you recently? I mean, really looked at them? I guess it depends on where you live, but there’s a pretty good chance that many of the vehicles you see at any given time will be silver, black, white, gray or some sort of brown or muted blue.

headline: Game in Transition, Wozniacki Remains Relaxed and Confident
text: No one can accuse Caroline Wozniacki of lacking fighting spirit, on and off the court. She has landed her fair share of lashings from the news media over the years, but she isn’t afraid of giving as good as she gets, given a chance.

headline: Golf Couple’s Vows: To Love and to Honor, and to Read Greens
text: JERSEY CITY — Patrick Reed hit balls on the driving range while listening to the indie rock band Imagine Dragons on his MP3 player, which was in the left front pocket of his golf pants. Upon completing his warm-up, he pulled his ear buds out. For the rest of an abbreviated workday Friday at Liberty National Golf Club, Reed’s wife, Justine, was in his ear.

headline: Dean Meminger: The Dream Who Was a Delight to Coach
text: What Willis Reed liked to call “Dean’s game” was remarkable not only because the Knicks handed the Celtics their first Game 7 playoff defeat on their home floor. It was also because the great Earl Monroe never got off the bench after Dean Meminger replaced him at the start of the second quarter.

headline: A New Book Offers a View of the Game That Tailgaters Rarely Encounter
text: Getting inside the body of the college football industry and examining it, organ by organ, might be compared to an exploration of the human body. The resulting emotions range wider than the country in which the sport is played — amazement and anxiety, wonderment and worry.

headline: Aug. 24: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Guru of the Long Snap
text: AUBURN, Mass. — Chris Rubio was dissecting the art of long snapping for the benefit of 23 teenagers and their parents on an unseasonably cool morning last month. He used words like “balance” and “extension” as he dabbled in the minutiae of a craft that he considers a science.

headline: Ignoring Qualms, Some Republicans Nurture Dreams of Impeaching Obama
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Kerry Bentivolio, a freshman Republican from Michigan, has a legislative dream. It is not to balance the federal budget, or find a way to help his ailing state or even take away money from the federal health care program, a goal that has so animated many other Republicans this summer.

headline: Be Yourself,  Redfin’s Glenn Kelman Says, Even if You’re a Little Goofy
text: This interview with  Glenn Kelman, chief executive of Redfin, the online real estate site, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: For Red Bulls, First Place for the Taking
text: Only three points separate the top five teams in the Eastern Conference of Major League Soccer before games Saturday and Sunday. And the Red Bulls, a club that has lost only once in its past six games, is a prime position to take sole possession of the top spot.

headline: At the Coaches Car Wash
text: Fifty top college football coaches flock to ESPN’s headquarters to discuss the season. The event, known as the Coaches Car Wash, shows how the network has become as big as the games.

headline: College Football’s Most Dominant Player? It’s ESPN
text: The nation’s annual rite of mayhem and pageantry known as the college football season begins this week, and Saturday will feature back-to-back-to-back marquee matchups.

headline: Steve Ballmer, Meet Ibn Khaldun
text: Microsoft is still a very profitable company; with some reforms, it will probably endure for a long time, sort of like the post-Diocletian Roman Empire. But you don’t need David Pogue to tell you — although it helps — that Microsoft missed the boat, big time, on major shifts in the technological landscape. And now the very network externalities that solidified its former dominance probably stand in the way of any attempt to return to past glories.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Blocking Health Reform
text: Readers discuss Republican efforts to undercut Obamacare.

headline: Coaches Talk of Injuries, Trying to Slow the Spread
text: In recent seasons, programs across the country turned toward sped-up spread offenses, often without huddles, schemes found at the intersection between football and track and field. It was the latest craze.

headline: Where Sand Is Gold, the Reserves Are Running Dry
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — With inviting beaches that run for miles along South Florida’s shores, it is easy to put sand into the same category as turbo air-conditioning and a decent mojito — something ever present and easily taken for granted.

headline: A College President, Drawn to Uncertainties
text: I GREW up literally on the wrong side of the tracks in Paoli, Pa. My father was a printer — he fed paper into big presses; my mother sold Avon products and held various secretarial jobs. Because Paoli is adjacent to the more affluent Main Line of Philadelphia, I became sensitive at an early age to class differences and racial dissonance.

headline: Amgen Said to Be Near Deal to Buy Onyx for $10.5 Billion
text: Updated, Aug. 25, 7:38 p.m. | Amgen announced on Sunday that it has agreed to buy Onyx for $125 a share.

headline: Fresh Leadership for Stale Phillies
text: Ruben Amaro Jr. has prepared for this moment since before he was born, in Philadelphia in the winter after the 1964 baseball season, when a pennant slipped away from the Phillies. His father was the shortstop.

headline: Thrill of Family Replaces Thrill of Game for Clijsters
text: Last year’s United States Open was Kim Clijsters’s swan song. A three-time Open champion, Clijsters retired for the second time. This year, she will be watching the tournament from her home in Belgium, where she is expecting her second child, a boy, with her husband, the retired basketball player Brian Lynch. She has spent the year as a fan, particularly of her friend and fellow Belgian Kirsten Flipkens, who reached the semifinals of Wimbledon. She remains involved in tennis as a WTA ambassador for USANA Health Sciences, and is renovating and developing a tennis club and academy in her hometown, Bree. This interview was edited and condensed.

headline: Addicted to Apps
text: SAN FRANCISCO — IN Silicon Valley, that fairy-tale land of robots and driverless cars, a deeply held belief motivates all: If you build it, they will come.

headline: Monopoly Goes Corporate
text: IT’S been a rough summer for Monopoly purists.

headline: Reindeer Games
text: WASHINGTON — ON the 50th anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I Have a Dream” speech, Kerry Bentivolio, a Michigan congressman, has a dream, too: to impeach the nation’s first black president.

headline: A Different Kind of Division
text: THREE months before the 1963 March on Washington, whose 50th anniversary falls this week, officials in Birmingham, Ala., opened fire hoses and loosed dogs on civil rights protesters. Two months before the march, the civil rights organizer Medgar Evers was murdered outside his home in Jackson, Miss. And a few weeks after the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I Have Dream Speech” echoed down the Washington Mall, a bomb ripped open Birmingham’s 16th Street Baptist Church, killing four little girls.

headline: The Death Memo
text: Fifty years ago this month, a young man and an older man sat down and began to plot the end of the death penalty in America.

headline: The Problem That Has Two Names
text: FIFTY years after Betty Friedan’s “Feminine Mystique” and countless principled-but-unwieldy hyphenated names later, the problem of married versus maiden names should be good and solved. But many women are still caught in an in-between purgatory: why have to choose?

headline: Florian Ortkrass
text: Florian Ortkrass is a founder and director of Random International, a group of London-based artists who combine technology and natural elements to create temporary, interactive installations, including the recent “Rain Room” at the Musuem of Modern Art. Another work, “Tower,” an appearing and disappearing water structure, opened on Friday at the Ruhrtriennale international arts festival in Germany.

headline: Foreign Policy by Whisper and Nudge
text: IF you follow the commentary on American foreign policy toward Egypt and the broader Middle East today, several themes stand out: People in the region argue: “Whatever went wrong, the United States is to blame.” Foreign policy experts argue: “Whatever President Obama did, he got it wrong.” And the American public is saying: “We’re totally fed up with that part of the world and can’t wait for the start of the N.F.L. season. How do you like those 49ers?”

headline: I’m Thinking. Please. Be Quiet.
text: SLAMMING doors, banging walls, bellowing strangers and whistling neighbors were the bane of the philosopher Arthur Schopenhauer’s existence. But it was only in later middle age, after he had moved with his beloved poodle to the commercial hub of Frankfurt, that his sense of being tortured by loud, often superfluous blasts of sound ripened into a philosophical diatribe. Then, around 1850, Schopenhauer pronounced noise to be the supreme archenemy of any serious thinker.

headline: In Syria, America Loses if Either Side Wins
text: WASHINGTON — ON Wednesday, reports surfaced of a mass chemical-weapons attack in the Damascus suburbs that human rights activists claim killed hundreds of civilians, bringing Syria’s continuing civil war back onto the White House’s foreign policy radar, even as the crisis in Egypt worsens.

headline: Working for Nothing
text: After graduating from school I despaired of finding a job and applied instead for unpaid internships, landing at The Paris Review, a literary magazine in Manhattan. I read through the slush pile, learned how to fact-check and performed light janitorial tasks, like emptying the dishwasher and taking out the trash. It was a fine four months. My parents lived in the city, so I didn’t have to pay rent; the editors were kind, smart people who seemed appropriately embarrassed by the trash situation.

headline: How Technology Wrecks the Middle Class
text: In the four years since the Great Recession officially ended, the productivity of American workers — those lucky enough to have jobs — has risen smartly. But the United States still has two million fewer jobs than before the downturn, the unemployment rate is stuck at levels not seen since the early 1990s and the proportion of adults who are working is four percentage points off its peak in 2000.

headline: Public Policies, Made to Fit People
text: I HAVE written here before about the potential gains to government from involving social and behavioral scientists in designing public policies. My enthusiasm comes in part from my experiences as an academic adviser to the Behavioral Insights Team created in Britain by Prime Minister David Cameron.

headline: Around the Nation: Players, Teams and Story Lines to Watch
text: Examining some of the to players and intriguing story lines this season.

headline: For a Chef, 41 Years in the Kitchen Takes Its Toll
text: STARTING as a dishwasher at the age of 17, the chef Mark Peel worked his way up at some of the great California restaurants: Ma Maison, Michael’s, Chez Panisse, Spago, Chinois and, finally, for more than two decades, Campanile, his own place in Los Angeles.

headline: New Jobs! If Only It Were True
text: CREATING jobs is an essential goal today, given our high unemployment rate. But when job programs rely on taxpayer backing, their success or failure should be clearly disclosed.

headline: Accounts of Syrian Prisons Describe a Volatile Mix of Chaos and Control
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Ahmed Hamadeh had spent a year in a jail in a Damascus suburb when guards chained him to fellow inmates, marched them to an outlying military checkpoint, and ordered them to dig trenches for the soldiers. He concluded that the government had “lost its mind,” he recalled later, not only because the move risked a jailbreak, but also because of the arbitrary violence that followed.

headline: Golden Rice: Lifesaver?
text: ONE bright morning this month, 400 protesters smashed down the high fences surrounding a field in the Bicol region of the Philippines and uprooted the genetically modified rice plants growing inside.

headline: Don’t Ask What I’m Writing
text: No stage of the writing process — not the editor’s first response to the manuscript, not the review gauntlet — is as fraught for writers as those first few months of uncertainty: that miserable time when we think, believe, know with absolute assurance that we’ve found the key to the novel in our heads, though maybe, probably, definitely not.

headline: What Is Economics Good For?
text: Recent debates over who is most qualified to serve as the next chairman of the Federal Reserve have focused on more than just the candidates’ theory-driven economic expertise. They have touched on matters of personality and character as well. This is as it should be. Given the nature of economies, and our ability to understand them, the task of the Fed’s next leader will be more a matter of craft and wisdom than of science.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, August 25
text: “There will be less opinion, less yelling and fewer celebrity sightings.”

headline: An Awkward Discovery at Work
text: Dear Workologist:

headline: A Right Way to Be Wrong
text: IF the Haggler had a dime for every time he’s said the real test of an organization is how it handles mistakes, the Haggler would now have four dimes. Maybe five. That may not seem like many dimes, especially now that a cup of coffee costs $2.50. But the Haggler does not enjoy repeating himself. Saying anything five times is excessive.

headline: A Proud Nation Ponders How to Halt Its Slow Decline
text: PARIS — For decades, Europeans have agonized over the power and role of Germany — the so-called German question — given its importance to European stability and prosperity.

headline: Power, Precision and Years to Grow
text: Madison Keys has begun her career with a bang, in large part because she begins points with a bang.

headline: 5 Days After Closing Border, Egypt Opens Crossing to Gaza
text: GAZA — Egypt reopened its borders with the Gaza Strip on Saturday five days after closing the crossing, which had prevented people from entering or leaving the Palestinian enclave and deepened its isolation from the rest of the world.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 25
text: As the United States observes the anniversary of the 1963 March on Washington, the Sunday shows will feature interviews with civil rights leaders and lawmakers about the state of the nation 50 years after the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I Have a Dream” speech.

headline: Venus Williams Pushes Back, Hard, at the Twilight
text: During an appearance last week on “Good Morning America” to promote the United States Open, Venus Williams was barely a minute into the interview when the host committed an unforced error.

headline: Central Bankers Say Emerging Economies Will Be Ready for Fed Exit
text: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — The stimulus campaigns of the Federal Reserve and the central banks of Europe and Japan, by depressing domestic interest rates, have helped to push trillions of dollars into developing markets in recent years.

headline: Commercial Banks As Creators of “Money”
text: Thank you, Matthew Klein! In the course of critiquing Robert Hall’s paper for Jackson Hole, he mentions and links to another half-century-old paper by James Tobin, Commercial Banks as Creators of “Money” (pdf), that I had forgotten about, and is even more precisely on point than the Tobin-Brainard piece I’ve been citing.

headline: For Tennis Players, a Tech Lover’s Paradise
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — The frontier of tennis technology is cordoned by a chain-link fence and protected from the elements by a yellowed canopy, a stretch of it torn away by one or another tropical storm. It is an open-air tinkerer’s garage, a 20-minute drive west from the beach here.

headline: The Macroeconomics of Sisyphus
text: Simon Wren-Lewis is deeply annoyed at the IMF, and understandably so. How can you publish a paper about fiscal adjustment that explicitly takes no account of monetary policy, and claim that it has any relevance to current problems?

headline: At 17, a Two-Time Grand Slam Finalist
text: With all the buzz around top players like Serena Williams and Tommy Haas playing well in their 30s, it might have been easy to overlook the teenage girl who made two Grand Slam finals this year.

headline: At 40, a Doubles Specialist Just Keeps Going
text: When you have been on the tennis tour as long as the Canadian doubles specialist Daniel Nestor, there is no shortage of amusing stories, although the dates can get cloudy.

headline: Brooklyn Boy, 3, Shot in Head, Police Say
text: A 3-year-old boy was shot in the head in his Brooklyn apartment early Saturday, the police said. A man, 22, who was in the apartment at the time was being questioned by detectives on Saturday evening, the police said.

headline: Gilbert Enjoys Playing Name Games
text: Brad Gilbert is not necessarily the Chris Berman of professional tennis. He began experimenting with nicknames on the air seven or eight years ago, but his nicknames tend to be more off the cuff, more freewheeling, than preplanned. He does not always have carte blanche in sharing them.

headline: Aug. 24: Speech by Representative Lewis
text: Representative John Lewis of Georgia addressed the crowd during the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington.

headline: Duda Is Back With the Mets
text: The Mets on Saturday recalled Lucas Duda from the minors and optioned outfielder Mike Baxter to Class AAA.

headline: The Open’s Breakthrough of 1973
text: Billie Jean King called it the year of insanity. She was talking about this year, when she has traveled around the world to promote the 40th anniversary of the Women’s Tennis Association and to publicize two documentaries about her life.

headline: Needed at Microsoft: A Catch-Up Artist
text: TWO months ago, Bill Gates met with members of the New York Times editorial board and a few editors and reporters. Public health was on his mind, and he spoke eloquently about the progress being made to combat diseases like tuberculosis and malaria, and the work of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

headline: Capital Ls
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — It was right around the time that I came across the clue for John le Carré, the British writer who was once an employee of MI6, that I began to suspect that there was more to this Sunday puzzle than meets the eye. Was the mere inclusion of the author of spygame thrillers like “Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy” making me feel more paranoid?

headline: Egypt Widens Crackdown and Meaning of ‘Islamist’
text: CAIRO — Having crushed the Muslim Brotherhood, the Egyptian authorities have begun cracking down on other dissenters, sometimes labeling even liberal activists or labor organizers as dangerous Islamists.

headline: Aug. 24: Trayvon Martin’s Mother Speaks
text: Sybrina Fulton, Trayvon Martin’s mother, spoke to the crowd during the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington.

headline: The Next Mayor, a History
text: The New York Times has made an editorial choice in every mayoral election since 1897, a few years after the five boroughs of New York voted to consolidate into one city.

headline: For New York Mayor
text: Christine Quinn, the Democratic Choice

headline: Aug. 24: Martin Luther King III Speaks
text: Martin Luther King III spoke to the crowd during the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington.

headline: Five for the Heisman
text: A look at the top contenders to win the Heisman Trophy.

headline: Fighting Education Overhaul, Thousands of Teachers Disrupt Mexico City
text: MEXICO CITY — Mexico’s highly anticipated education overhaul program — intended to weed out poorly performing teachers, establish professional hiring standards and weaken the powerful teachers’ union — is buckling under the tried-and-true tactic of huge street protests, throwing the heart of the capital into chaos.

headline: Platinum Card and Text Alert, via Pawnshop
text: Linda Ballard, 61, uses the word “love” to describe her banking relationship, lauding the ease of cashing her bimonthly paycheck, the convenience of text alerts about her balance and the features on the platinum card that she was upgraded to in July.

headline: Battling Superstition, Indian Paid With His Life
text: PUNE, India — For nearly three decades, an earnest man named Narendra Dabholkar traveled from village to village in India, waging a personal war against the spirit world.

headline: Trump University Made False Claims, Lawsuit Says
text: The New York State attorney general’s office filed a civil lawsuit on Saturday accusing Trump University, Donald J. Trump’s for-profit investment school, of engaging in illegal business practices.

headline: Father Knows Best: Romine Has Swing Coach Independent of Yankees
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Just by listening to his son’s games on the radio, Kevin Romine can tell what Yankees catcher Austin Romine might be doing wrong at the plate. Kevin Romine played seven seasons with the Boston Red Sox, from 1985 to 1991, and knows plenty about hitting, and even more about his son’s approach at the plate.

headline: Other Nations Offer a Lesson to Egypt’s Military Leaders
text: LONDON — Is the era of the military big man back? In Egypt, where Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi led a populist putsch against the elected president, prison doors are swinging.

headline: With Pressure Off, Murray Still Expects Some Nerves at U.S. Open
text: On media day at the United States Open, when many top players appeared eager to impress — or to at least manage expectations — no one looked more at ease than Andy Murray, the defending men’s champion.

headline: Harvey Isn’t on His Game; With Scherzer Pitching, Neither Are the Mets
text: The indicators were plain: sliders that spun but did not swerve, fastballs that whizzed but failed to explode, changeups that floated along capricious paths.

headline: Woodland Tied With Kuchar Atop Barclays
text: JERSEY CITY — The good news for Gary Woodland is he is tied for the lead at the Barclays with Matt Kuchar at 12-under-par 201. The better news is there is one round left to play in the first event of the FedEx Cup playoffs at Liberty National Golf Club, affording him a prime opportunity to reverse a disappointing trend.

headline: In Travers, Colt Finally Attracts Attention of People Besides His Trainer
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — No one was paying attention to D. Wayne Lukas and his colt as the spring turned to summer. If Will Take Charge had distinguished himself at all, it was for competing in all three legs of the Triple Crown. But he did not perform very well: he was beaten by a combined 45 ½ lengths in those American Classics.

headline: Cyberschools Grow, Fueling New Concerns
text: The number of full-time cyberschools serving Texas public school students will double in the coming school year despite a history of lackluster performance and a new law limiting the number of online courses that public school students are allowed to take at the state’s expense.

headline: Ted Post, Director for Film and Television, Dies at 95
text: Ted Post, a prolific director who collaborated with Clint Eastwood on two hit films, directed hundreds of episodes of television series like “Gunsmoke,” “Peyton Place” and “Rawhide,” and made a low-budget film about the Vietnam War that was widely ignored when it was released in 1978 but is now regarded by many critics as one of the best in its genre, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 95. His son, Robert, confirmed the death.

headline: Under a New Law, the Police Can Act as Gun Dealers
text: For decades, weapons confiscated by the police in Texas were supposed to be used for law enforcement purposes — or else destroyed. Starting next month, police departments across the state will be allowed to sell some of them.

headline: Charles Pollock, Designer of Popular Office Chair, Dies at 83
text: Charles Pollock, an industrial designer whose vision of “a simple line in space” led him to develop sleek, functional chairs that became a hallmark of executive suites in the latter 20th century, died on Tuesday in a fire in South Jamaica, Queens. He was 83.

headline: When Hill Country Feels Too Much Like Shreveport
text: By most standards, the new film “Ain’t Them Bodies Saints” should be a source of pride for Texas’ growing film industry. This thriller, which stars Rooney Mara, Casey Affleck and Ben Foster, is set in Central Texas; was written and directed by the Dallas-based David Lowery; and its producers include Toby Halbrooks, also of Dallas, and James M. Johnston, of Fort Worth.

headline: Hamilton Earns Pole in Belgium
text: Lewis Hamilton left it to the last second to beat Sebastian Vettel’s time and secure his fourth straight pole position of the season at the Belgian Grand Prix. In a frantic finish under heavy rain at Spa, the lead changed hands in a flurry of activity as first Nico Rosberg, Mark Webber and Vettel all beat one another’s times, only for Hamilton to go fastest for the fifth time this season.

headline: Making Some Effort, but North Texas Continues to Run the Water
text: DALLAS — On the northern edge of this city known for excessive water use, where residents have been subject to watering restrictions for more than a year, a cozy home on less than half an acre has one of the greenest lawns in town.

headline: A Divided Dream
text: Fifty years after the March on Washington, Oris Stuart returned with his son and reflected on how far the country had come, and stood still, since then.

headline: A Summer of Successes for America’s Young Stars
text: It has been a summer of triumphs for America’s best young players: three have become grandmasters, three have become international masters, and several more have earned one of the three norms — a measure of performance — needed to claim those titles.

headline: Court Is ‘One of Most Activist,’ Ginsburg Says, Vowing to Stay
text: WASHINGTON — Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, 80, vowed in an interview to stay on the Supreme Court as long as her health and intellect remained strong, saying she was fully engaged in her work as the leader of the liberal opposition on what she called “one of the most activist courts in history.”

headline: Few Answers in Game With No Real Winner
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The preseason game between the Jets and the Giants on Saturday night was meant to answer some questions for each team’s coaching staff. Most notably, could the Jets rookie Geno Smith play well enough to win the starting quarterback job over Mark Sanchez, the incumbent?

headline: Sabathia Briefly Finds Form, but Loses It (and Game)
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — For five superior innings Saturday, the world looked right again for C. C. Sabathia. He was pitching aggressively, boring in on the Tampa Bay Rays’ right-handed hitters and attacking them with his usual zest.

headline: Iowa’s G.O.P. Fears Its Role in Presidential Selection Is Diminishing
text: AMES, Iowa — On the surface, Iowa’s Republican presidential caucuses seem healthier than ever: would-be candidates are flocking here mere months after the last White House race ended, drawing sizable crowds and ample news coverage. Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and former Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania were in this central Iowa college town for a Christian conservative conference this month, and Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has come to the state twice since May.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Smith vs. Sanchez Quarterback Duel Just Got Worse
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It could have been worse for the Jets. Maybe Geno Smith could have thrown four interceptions in his first seven drives Saturday night against the Giants, instead of only three. Maybe Mark Sanchez could have shredded both knees, instead of just injuring his right shoulder, playing in the waning minutes of a meaningless game after appearing to secure the Jets’ starting quarterback position by virtue of Smith’s struggles.

headline: Julie Harris, Celebrated Actress of Range and Intensity, Dies at 87
text: Julie Harris, the unprepossessing anti-diva who, in the guises of Joan of Arc, Mary Todd Lincoln, Emily Dickinson and many other characters both fictional and real, became the most decorated performer in the history of Broadway, died on Saturday at her home in Chatham, Mass. She was 87.

headline: Risk at Coast From Fire at Yosemite
text: Gov. Jerry Brown of California declared a state of emergency for the city and county of San Francisco over the weekend, as a large wildfire near Yosemite National Park threatened water and electricity going to the area.

headline: Film on Salinger Claims More Books Are Coming
text: LOS ANGELES — J. D. Salinger may not be done publishing after all, according to claims in a new film and book set for release next week.

headline: Corrections: August 25, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 25
text: “I haven’t gone horseback riding in four years. I haven’t ruled that out entirely. But water skiing, those days are over.”

text: Jill Edith Schulster and Joseph Albert Dobias II are to be married Sunday at River Park, a restaurant in New York. Rabbi Uri Goren

Klein of New York, was married Saturday evening to John Michael Koenigsberg, a son of Jacqueline Dietz Koenigsberg and Bill A. Koenigsberg, both of New York. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

Katzman, the groom’s godmother, who incorporated Jewish and Christian traditions.

Field of Kalamazoo, Mich., was married Saturday evening to David Michael Perry, a son of Mary Nejman Perry and Dr. Henry D. Perry of Sands Point, N.Y. Michael G. Mahon, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, led a ceremony incorporating Catholic and Jewish traditions at the Yale Club of New York City.

text: Danielle Joan Manning and Matthew Samuel Ballinger were married on Saturday at the Coveleigh Club in Rye, N.Y. Raymond E. Kramer, a friend of the couple and a minister ordained by the Sanctuary of the Beloved in Conesus, N.Y., officiated.

headline: Marika Sawyer and Matthew Whitman
text: Marika Anna Sawyer and Matthew Thomas Whitman were married Saturday at the Wainwright House, an event space in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Samora Smith, an interfaith minister ordained by the New Seminary, officiated.

headline: Michelle Rose, Daniel Farmer
text: Michelle Danielle Rose and Daniel Christopher Farmer were married Saturday evening at the Whittemore House, a historic home in Washington. Ann O’Regan Keary, a judge of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia, officiated.

headline: Vows: Danielle and Matthew
text: When Danielle Manning was 14, she interviewed the boy band Dream Street and made a lasting impression on 15-year-old Matthew Ballinger, one of the band’s members. Years later, they reconnected.

headline: What’s On Today
text: 9:30 P.M. (Encore) WHEN HARRY MET SALLY... (1989) Harry (Billy Crystal) and Sally (Meg Ryan, above) first meet on a road trip from Chicago to New York, where they discuss, among other things, whether men and women are capable of having asexual friendships. When their paths cross again 10 years later, they put that theory to the test as they bond over their mutual heartbreak from previous relationships in this romantic comedy written by Nora Ephron and directed by Rob Reiner. “Mr. Crystal has the wittiest lines and snappiest delivery, but he also shows Harry to be remarkably gentle, a sensitive mensch,” Caryn James wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Grim World of Mumbai Rape Accused
text: MUMBAI – Three days have passed since a 22-year-old photojournalist said she was gang raped while on assignment in Mumbai, a city lined with luxury apartment buildings, glass office towers and marble megaliths of malls.

headline: World Expositions Can Benefit or Haunt Host Cities
text: PARIS — Few visitors to Disneyland have a world exposition on their minds as they embark on the 15-minute “It’s a Small World” boat ride. But it was for the 1964 New York World’s Fair, as the expo was known, that Walt Disney designed the ride.

headline: Political Staging in Trial of Fallen China Official
text: JINAN, China — In the weeks before Bo Xilai, the fallen Communist Party star, went on trial here on corruption-related charges, senior officials from the powerful party investigation agency told him about two officials who had been tried earlier on somewhat similar charges, Mr. Bo said in court.

headline: Two More Arrests Made in Gang Rape in India
text: MUMBAI, India — The fourth and fifth suspects in the gang rape of a 22-year-old journalist have been arrested, the police here reported Sunday, igniting new concerns about women’s safety even in a city considered among India’s most progressive.

headline: It’s Not a ‘Problem.’ It’s Called Being a Child.
text: Here’s the thing about most first graders: they are brittle, accusatory and rule-obsessed. They tense up or lay blame when something goes wrong, and they can spend an entire recess articulating regulations for games they never actually play. They are also adorable and amusing. Thank goodness, because any adult who tries to play cards with first graders soon discovers that they are incredible cheats.

headline: Unnatural Models of the Labor Market (Wonkish)
text: Bob Hall’s paper for Jackson Hole (pdf) is, characteristically for Hall, a mix of very sensible stuff and strange-looking stuff that just might involve a deep insight. (Hall used to be famous at MIT for talks along the lines of “Not many people understand this, but the IS curve actually slopes up and the LM curve slopes down” — and then, not most of the time but often enough, his apparent craziness would turn out to be a big insight that changed the way you thought about a major issue.)

headline: Confident Syria Used Chemicals, U.S. Mulls Action
text: WASHINGTON — Moving a step closer to possible American military action in Syria, a senior Obama administration official said Sunday that there was “very little doubt” that President Bashar al-Assad’s military forces had used chemical weapons against civilians last week and that a Syrian promise to allow United Nations inspectors access to the site was “too late to be credible.”

headline: Ibn Khaldun, Psychohistorian
text: I’m thinking about Ibn Khaldun this weekend, and there is, it turns out, at least one translation of Ibn Khaldun’s Muqaddimah (pdf) available online — and based on an initial skim, it truly is an awesome work, centuries ahead of its time. I was especially struck by his opening manifesto:

headline: Disruptions: A Blogger Mocks the Denizens of Silicon Valley
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Sam Biddle may have one of the easiest jobs in technology journalism. That is, easy if you have the stomach for his line of work.

headline: In Premier League, a Shuffle of Players, Then a Reshuffle
text: LONDON — Wayne Rooney, the England striker, might start for Manchester United against Chelsea on Monday night, then switch sides by the end of the week.

headline: Aug. 25: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: A Rumble in the Sky, and Grumbles Below
text: It is known as the Flushing Climb — an airplane route born 23 years ago to prevent planes taking off at La Guardia Airport from disturbing fans at Arthur Ashe Stadium during the United States Open.

headline: How to Charge $546 for Six Liters of Saltwater
text: It is one of the most common components of emergency medicine: an intravenous bag of sterile saltwater.

headline: ‘Lee Daniels’ The Butler’ Keeps Top Spot at Box Office
text: Three new movies quietly – very quietly – arrived in theaters over the weekend as the summer blockbuster season ebbed toward its end and previously released films continued to perform well.

headline: Aziz Ansari Signs to Write a Book on Modern Romance
text: Aziz Ansari, the comedian and actor who plays the crass but endearing Tom Haverford on “Parks and Recreation,” has struck a deal to write his first book, an examination of modern romance, his publisher said last week. The Penguin Press acquired the book, described as an “investigation” into what Mr. Ansari calls “an entirely new era for singles, in which the basic issues facing a single person — whom we meet, how we meet them and what happens next — have been radically altered by new technologies.”

headline: Rodriguez Out of Lineup in Final Game of Rays Series
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Alex Rodriguez was given the day off Sunday against the Tampa Bay Rays after playing three days in a row and going 1 for 11 in that span. Manager Joe Girardi said that with the Yankees playing six consecutive games on artificial turf, he wanted to give Rodriguez at least one day off, despite the fact that the infield at Tropicana Field is dirt.

headline: Well-Mannered Thai Party Throws Down Its Gloves in Government Protests
text: BANGKOK — Booming loudspeakers, crowds of cheering protesters and the riot police on alert — after a relative lull of more than two years, politics is back on the streets in Thailand.

headline: Sign-Language Interpreter Uses Newfound Fame to Advocate for the Deaf
text: For a week or so around the end of October, Lydia Callis seemed to be everywhere: On television, standing just to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s right as he, then she, urged New Yorkers to stay indoors while they waited out Hurricane Sandy. On Twitter, where admirers gushed that they could watch her “for hours.” And on “Saturday Night Live” — in caricature form, anyway — in a skit even Mr. Bloomberg could not resist mentioning.

headline: Chinese-American Commentator and Investor Is Arrested in Beijing
text: SHANGHAI — A prominent investor and online social commentator was detained Friday in Beijing on charges of soliciting prostitution just after the government stepped up a campaign aimed at cracking down on online activism.

headline: The Long Journey to Become a Tennis Ball
text: Athletes have arrived from all over the world to compete at the United States Open this week. It may be a surprise that the balls they play with typically travel far greater distances on the road to completion.

headline: A General Gets Down in the Hamptons
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — This is from the “Thought You’d Seen It All” Department.

headline: South Carolina City Takes Steps to Evict Homeless From Downtown
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — In South Carolina’s capital, officials declare that their tree-lined Main Street, clogged with shops, banks, restaurants and hotels, is evidence that a long-sought economic revival has arrived.

headline: Lundqvist Disagrees With Russian Law, but Supports Games
text: Last season, Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist was one of the first professional athletes to participate in the You Can Play campaign, promoting respect for all athletes without regard to sexual orientation. That was why some were surprised when Lundqvist, in Stockholm earlier this month to prepare for the Sochi Olympics, declined to comment on a new law in Russia that has been criticized in the West as antigay.

headline: On a Stage by Itself, Mozart’s ‘Appeal to Eternity’
text: For the closing night of the Mostly Mozart Festival, the word “mostly” could have been eliminated from the title. While Mozart has shared the stage with various composers during the lineup this month, he had the spotlight to himself for the concluding event, conducted by Louis Langrée on Friday at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Paying Tribute to a Lost Star, With Help From Handel
text: When the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment chose a program to present at this year’s Mostly Mozart festival, it settled on an all-Handel tribute to the mezzo-soprano Lorraine Hunt Lieberson, who died in 2006.

headline: What’s New at the U.S. Open?
text: Fans visiting Flushing Meadows for the United States Open over the next two weeks will notice a few changes on the grounds.

headline: Olbermann Set to Return to ESPN and Sports News
text: Sixteen years after an acrimonious parting, Keith Olbermann and ESPN are putting on happy faces for their highly anticipated reunion, the premiere on Monday of “Olbermann” on ESPN2, the spinoff channel that Mr. Olbermann helped start, falteringly, in 1993. This time, both sides say, no faltering.

headline: New Surge in Shootings by Officers
text: The episodes ran the gamut of dangerous situations faced by New York City police officers: a man stabbing his ex-girlfriend; a driver fleeing the police in a stolen car; a group of young men thought to be heading for a hidden weapon; a gunman firing at plainclothes officers on a darkened street.

headline: Mets Limp Away From Tigers With Rookie’s Homer as Biggest Highlight
text: There are fine glimpses of the future throughout the Mets’ clubhouse these days, playing roles in wins and losses, producing runs and quality starts, learning and developing.

headline: Edinburgh Strategy: Check Reviews, Take Chances, Hope for the Best
text: EDINBURGH — There are five possible endings and more than 1,500 routes to get to them in “Choose Your Own Documentary,” one of the 800-plus theater productions at the 2013 Edinburgh Festival Fringe, which concludes Monday. Inspired by the wildly successful “Choose Your Own Adventure” books, which sold hundreds of millions of copies during the 1980s and 90s, the show allows theatergoers, who are handed a remote-control voting devices on the way to their seats, directly to influence what happens at several moments in the story.

headline: Hunting Again for Salinger Within the Silences and Secrets
text: In the J. D. Salinger story “Zooey,” the title character’s mother says of him and his brother: “Neither you nor Buddy know how to talk to people you don’t like,” adding: “You can’t live in the world with such strong likes and dislikes.”

headline: A Young Jazz Singer Reminds Her Elders How It Was Done
text: Like a lunar event or a geyser, it came at the expected hour: 5:45 on a late-August Saturday afternoon at the Charlie Parker Jazz Festival in Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem. (My notes from last year mark it at 5:30.) It’s not planned, it just happens: the tempo shifts down and it becomes time for a few dozen audience members — mostly retirement age, probably sharper looking than you — to go down in front of the stage and dance together, full of grace. It’s something you ought to see.

headline: A Calculated Push Into Entertainment Lifts ‘Duck Dynasty’ Family’s Fortunes
text: Forget the ZZ Top beards and the Bayou accents, the Robertsons of West Monroe, La., are a family of traditional American entrepreneurs: ambitious, rich and spectacularly successful.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Aug. 26
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: A Small Upstart to Oversee Ad Agencies
text: A WELL-KNOWN senior Madison Avenue executive, Antony Young, is leaving the biggest agency holding group for one that, if not the smallest, is certainly the newest.

headline: A Bigger Closet for Their Art
text: LOS ANGELES — The Guess clothing headquarters downtown here — once a humble distribution center, where stonewashed jeans were shipped around the country — looks more like an art gallery these days. Paintings by luminaries like Sterling Ruby and Carroll Dunham hang beside the famously sexy Guess billboard ads. And Mr. Ruby even stopped by to install a sculpture personally.

headline: City Makes Test Scores Available on the Web
text: Beginning Monday, parents of New York City public school students will be able to see online how well, or poorly, their children performed on a new set of state reading and math exams this spring.

headline: At Louisville, Athletic Boom Is Rooted in ESPN Partnership
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — In February, the president of the University of Louisville, James R. Ramsey, traveled to Florida to meet with donors and alumni.

headline: Luminous Julie Harris, Close Up and Afar
text: As a child, long before I ever set foot in Manhattan, I entertained deep and near-religious fantasies about what Broadway theaters must be like. And at the center of those imaginings was a single figure, a woman who was said by day to be plain to the point of anonymity but who by night, once the curtain went up, became a beauty who could light up the dark.

headline: Familiarity Breeds Masochism
text: On the cover of the current US Weekly — along with One Direction; Prince William and Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge; and Gia Allemand, the “Bachelor” contestant who recently committed suicide — is a smiling young couple, Mackenzie Douthit and Josh McKee, captured on their wedding day.

headline: Yankees Find a Way to Avoid a Sweep
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — At age 37 with cranky knees, Alfonso Soriano is not nearly as swift as he once was. In an earlier life with the Yankees in his middle 20s, Soriano was able to rely on sheer speed and agility as he twice recorded seasons with 40 stolen bases.

headline: Simple Things To Pick
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Greetings, fellow BIPEDs. I hope you had a great week, and once again, many thanks to Tom Gaffney for doing a wonderful job steering the ship while I was away.

headline: A Director Peers Into His Past
text: “Strangle, strangle, strangle, strangle.” The filmmaker Brian De Palma was contentedly narrating the action of his new frenemy thriller, “Passion,” for a visitor. “The nightmare never ends,” he said as the scene concluded.

headline: ‘Reality Bites’ TV Series
text: NBC is developing a half-hour television series based on the 1994 coming-of-age film “Reality Bites,” according to Variety’s Web site. This single-camera comedy will follow the continuing romantic and professional misadventures of the movie’s heroine, Lelaina Pierce (originally played by Winona Ryder), and her group of 20-something slacker friends living in Houston during the 1990s. Helen Childress, who wrote the film’s screenplay, will also write the pilot script, and Ben Stiller, who starred in and directed the movie, will be an executive producer on the show. Casting has not been announced.

headline: Linda Ronstadt Is Ill
text: The singer Linda Ronstadt has revealed in an interview with AARP Magazine that she has Parkinson’s disease and that she is no longer able to sing as a result. Ms. Ronstadt, 67, received her official diagnosis eight months ago, although she had symptoms for the past eight years. “I couldn’t sing,” she said in the interview, “and I couldn’t figure out why. I knew it was mechanical. I knew it had to do with the muscles.” Her hands also began to shake, but she attributed that symptom to a shoulder operation. A neurologist then diagnosed Parkinson’s. “I wouldn’t have suspected that in a million, billion years,” she said. Ms. Ronstadt’s memoir, “Simple Dreams,” is to be released on Sept. 17 and chronicles her life and musical career. She has won 11 Grammy Awards and sold over 100 million records worldwide. But according to AARP’s Web site, the book does not discuss her diagnosis or the loss of her voice.

headline: A Final Book Is Planned From Elmore Leonard
text: Peter Leonard, a son of the author Elmore Leonard, who died last week at 87, hopes to complete his father’s last novel, BBC News reported. In an interview on the BBC Radio news program “Broadcasting House” on Sunday, Mr. Leonard, who is also a published author, said that the matter had “been discussed among family members and I’ve talked to Greg Sutter, Elmore’s longtime researcher.” He added that he did not know how many pages his father had already written. The book, which has the working title “Blue Dreams,” was originally conceived to feature a rogue Immigration and Customs Enforcement agent, bull riding and Mr. Leonard’s popular federal marshal character, Raylan Givens.

headline: Australia vs. Turkey at 3rd World Youth Open Championships
text: ATLANTA — After the pair events at the 3rd World Youth Open Championships came the junior (under 26) and youngsters (under 21) knockout teams. (There were too few entries for a separate women’s competition. They competed in the appropriate age brackets.)

headline: Muriel Siebert, a Determined Trailblazer for Women on Wall Street, Dies at 84
text: Muriel Siebert, who became a legend on Wall Street as the first woman to buy a seat on the New York Stock Exchange and the first woman to head one of the exchange’s member firms, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 84.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Prayer Plaza in Jerusalem for Both Sexes Ignites Uproar
text: JERUSALEM — Trying to calm months of intense wrangling over the Western Wall, Israeli officials on Sunday unveiled a new plaza where men and women can pray together. But the move was immediately denounced as discriminatory by the main group that has protested the rules at the holy site.

headline: Truman’s Finances
text: To the Editor:

headline: Spit-Take in Hollywood at Dog Treat Promotion
text: LOS ANGELES — And they say there are no animals left in Hollywood’s corporate ranks.

headline: Too Much Screen Time?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Aug. 26
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released this week include durable goods orders for July (Monday); the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller home price index for June (Tuesday); pending home sales for June, and weekly mortgage applications (Wednesday); revised second-quarter gross domestic product, and new weekly unemployment claims (Thursday); and personal income and spending for July, the Institute for Supply Management survey of Chicago purchasing managers for August, and the University of Michigan consumer confidence survey for August (Friday).

headline: The Decline of E-Empires
text: Steve Ballmer’s surprise announcement that he will be resigning as Microsoft’s C.E.O. has set off a huge flood of commentary. Being neither a tech geek nor a management guru, I can’t add much on those fronts. I do, however, think I know a bit about economics, and I also read a lot of history. So the Ballmer announcement has me thinking about network externalities and Ibn Khaldun. And thinking about these things, I’d argue, can help ensure that we draw the right lessons from this particular corporate upheaval.

headline: From Italy, a Vintage Redolent of Horrors
text: COLLOREDO DI PRATO, Italy — Vini Lunardelli is no stranger to controversy. Every year, it seems, usually during the summer, a tourist will happen upon its wines with their outrageous labels and make a fuss that is then picked up by the local — and sometimes national and international — media.

headline: Stream of Talent Continues to Flow From Cuba, With or Without Permission
text: From coast to coast this summer, the major league baseball season has had a strong Cuban influence.

headline: We’re All Still Hostages to the Big Banks
text: STANFORD, Calif. — NEARLY five years after the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers touched off a global financial crisis, we are no safer. Huge, complex and opaque banks continue to take enormous risks that endanger the economy. From Washington to Berlin, banking lobbyists have blocked essential reforms at every turn. Their efforts at obfuscation and influence-buying are no surprise. What’s shameful is how easily our leaders have caved in, and how quickly the lessons of the crisis have been forgotten.

headline: M.L.B. Media Company Buys Rights to Live Concert
text: MLB Advanced Media, the digital media company of Major League Baseball, is branching out into the licensing business by acquiring the worldwide distribution rights for a coming concert in New York City’s Central Park.

headline: Giants’ Brown, Surprise Safety of 2012, Is Lost for Season
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In 2012, safety Stevie Brown was one of the few feel-good stories in an otherwise lackluster Giants season. Let go five times by three teams, he came to the Giants last year almost as an afterthought.

headline: Challengers to South Carolina Senator Are Lining Up on the Right
text: LAKE WYLIE, S.C. — Some of the early shots in the Republican primary battle against Senator Lindsey Graham have been fired from this tiny community on the northern border of the state where the Civil War began.

headline: Surveillance Revelations Shake U.S.-German Ties
text: BERLIN — Continuing revelations, based on documents leaked by Edward J. Snowden, of sweeping American digital surveillance around the world are rattling the close ties between the United States and Germany.

headline: As Amazon Stretches, Seattle’s Downtown Is Reshaped
text: SEATTLE — Often a corporation with a grand dream to reshape a city wants tax breaks in return. Not Amazon.

headline: Adrift on the Nile
text: IN May 2011, when the promise of the Arab Spring was still fresh and exhilarating, President Obama went to the State Department to proclaim an important reorientation of American policy in the Middle East. For decades America had defined its interests in utilitarian terms: regional stability, countering terrorism and nuclear proliferation (and, in the cold war years, Soviet influence), defending Israel’s security, assuring the free flow of oil and other commerce. That often meant alliances of convenience with brutal authoritarians.

headline: Cave Collector in Minnesota Hunts for Additions to His Empire
text: RACINE, Minn. — John Ackerman has been called a tree hugger and a kook by two landowners and a devil worshiper by a local town board member. He has been accused of land snatching and gold prospecting. Others see him as an explorer and a fierce protector of an underground wilderness.

headline: Young Tech Sees Itself in Microsoft’s Ballmer
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As a young executive at Microsoft, Steven A. Ballmer helped topple older, slower-moving technology giants like the Digital Equipment Corporation, Wang and Novell.

headline: Activist Running for Mayor of Moscow Is Briefly Detained
text: MOSCOW — Aleksei A. Navalny, the Internet activist and improbable opposition candidate in Moscow’s mayoral race, was briefly detained by the police on Sunday night after holding a rally here that attracted several thousand supporters.

headline: Reading Tweets From Iran
text: Social media are an unorthodox, but useful, way to start to get a sense of Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani. In a flurry of English-language posts on Twitter since his election in June, Mr. Rouhani has given reason to hope that he is serious about resolving disputes with the United States and other major powers, most urgently about Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: War on Leaks Is Pitting Journalist vs. Journalist
text: A disgruntled loner with access to military secrets comes across documents that pull back the veil on government actions in a lost war and decides for a variety of reasons, some noble and some personal, to share them with the world.

headline: Federal Courts in Crisis
text: Observers of the federal court system cannot recall the last time such a thing has happened, if it ever has. Chief judges in 86 of the 94 Federal District Courts around the country — more than half of them Republican appointees — have now joined to sound an alarm about the grave damage to the nation’s justice system caused by years of flat financing followed by Washington’s lunatic across-the-board budget cuts known as sequestration. Their urgent plea to stop starving federal courts of adequate resources to fulfill the judiciary’s constitutional responsibilities deserves a response from Congress.

headline: Scott, Hanging Around, Outlasts a Tightly Packed Field to Win the Barclays
text: JERSEY CITY — Adam Scott was on the practice range, with his fairway wood in his hand and several balls at his feet, when he became the champion of the Barclays, the first tournament in the monthlong FedEx Cup playoffs.

headline: Mixed Signals on Employee Health Insurance
text: It is hard to know whether to rejoice or lament two striking if somewhat conflicting messages last week about the costs of employer-sponsored health insurance.

headline: Canadian Documents Suggest Shift on Pipeline
text: OTTAWA — Ever since President Obama said in June that a litmus test for the proposed Keystone XL oil pipeline from Canada was whether it would “significantly” worsen global warming, Canadian government officials have insisted it would not.

headline: Conversations With Andy Murray: The Return to New York
text: For the second straight year, Andy Murray will be talking to Straight Sets regularly throughout his run at the United States Open.

headline: As Egyptians Ignore Curfew, Talk of a U.S.-Brotherhood Conspiracy
text: CAIRO — The sounds made lately by curfew violators here are mostly not shouts or gunshots, but the clacking of dice on wooden backgammon boards, the clicking of dominoes on cafe tables crowded with hookahs and grumbling fueled by years of upheaval.

headline: A Blazing Giant Stirs California to High Alert
text: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. — A wildfire near Yosemite National Park — already one of the biggest in California’s history — continued to grow on Sunday, prompting mandatory evacuation orders for some residents and raising anxiety among officials because of the potential threat to a major source of San Francisco’s water and power supplies.

headline: What to Watch at U.S. Open on Monday
text: The 2013 U.S. Open features plenty of interesting storylines: Can Roger Federer make one more run? Is Andy Murray able to defend the title that altered his professional career? Was Serena Williams’s fourth-round dismissal at Wimbledon a fluke? Is this the year Victoria Azarenka finally wins her first United States Open title?

headline: Amgen Buys Producer of Drugs for Cancer
text: Although Amgen is the world’s biggest biotechnology company, the drug maker has been mostly absent from one of the industry’s biggest and fastest-growing markets: cancer drugs.

headline: Egypt Military Enlists Religion to Quell Ranks
text: CAIRO — The Egyptian military has enlisted Muslim scholars in a propaganda campaign to persuade soldiers and policemen that they have a religious duty to obey orders to use deadly force against supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi.

headline: An Injury Makes Clear a Shift in Power
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Rex Ryan said seven times Saturday night that it was “my decision” to play Mark Sanchez in the fourth quarter against the Giants, and maybe it really was.

headline: Shoeshines Keep Wall Street in the Black (or Maybe Brown)
text: Mauricio Dias was being courted by Wall Street.
