text: Accounts

headline: An Appreciation of Leather and Polish Shoeshines
text: My shoes, to the casual observer, look presentable. True, they’re scuffed and smudged, but that’s to be expected of a pair of black leather Bostonians exposed daily to the sidewalks of New York.

headline: Game, Set, Match...Roof?
text: Will the roof planned for Arthur Ashe stadium, which will end weather delays at the U.S. Open, sanitize the outdoor tennis tournament too much?

headline: Ashe’s Legacy on Display
text: Arthur Ashe kept everything: the receipt for his first Rolex, speeches scribbled on napkins, an autographed Time magazine with a note from Nelson Mandela on the cover. Ashe saved meticulous datebooks and his Life magazine cover story and more than 4,000 books, including several first editions, among them the first volume of poetry written by Phillis Wheatley in the 1700s.

headline: Making Choice to Halt at Door of Citizenship
text: Jonathan Wajskol, an Italian graphic designer who moved to the United States about three decades ago, has a life with the hallmarks of an immigrant success story: graduate studies at an American university; a successful international firm with partners in Milan and Beijing; and a residence in Greenwich Village that he shares with his wife and two children.

headline: Bartoli Has Many Plans. Tennis? ‘You Never Know.’
text: Marion Bartoli said she wanted to start her own fashion line, open a tennis academy in Europe and, when her body healed, once again take up classical ballet. She said she was looking forward to relaxing, and talked about marrying one day. She plans to travel, more for leisure than work. She will find new hobbies.

headline: Shock and Memories on Long Island Footbridge Where Teenager’s Body Was Found
text: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, N.Y. — Late summer at Mill River Park brings fishermen plying the pond, teenagers shooting baskets, and families tossing Frisbees across the grass.

headline: 'Wrongly Attacked'
text: Former mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani comes to the defense of Joseph J. Lhota in a response to the advertisement by John A. Catsimatidis.

headline: Louisa Jo Killen, English Folk Singer, Dies at 79
text: The English folk singer known for most of his life as Louis Killen was a bawdy, bearded pioneer of the 1950s British folk revival, a member of the Clancy Brothers and a soloist admired for giving voice to forgotten miners and sailors in traditional ballads.

headline: Riverside Interludes, Far From the Madding Crowd
text: They come strolling slowly down Grand Street, around sunset, the young couples and the people accompanied only by their worries, each claiming a boulder or a faded bench as the lights of Manhattan begin to streak the East River.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Lhota Brings In a Big Gun
text: Joseph J. Lhota jumped into the Republican race for mayor with the support of his former boss, Rudolph W. Giuliani, and now, a little more than two weeks before Primary Day, he is deploying Mr. Giuliani in a new 30-second advertisement, titled “Wrongly Attacked.” The ad is a response to a new attack ad by his major opponent in the Republican primary, the billionaire John A. Catsimatidis.

headline: 'Lived It'
text: The most recent ad from the Thompson campaign features the candidate speaking directly to the camera on stop-and-frisk.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Thompson Counterattacks
text: William C. Thompson Jr., a Democratic candidate for mayor, spent much of the previous week arguing that Bill de Blasio, one of his rivals, was stretching the truth in his latest ad, which claims that Mr. de Blasio would be “the only candidate to end a stop-and-frisk era that targets minorities.” On Sunday, Mr. Thompson intensified the debate by attacking Mr. de Blasio directly in his own 30-second television advertisement, called “Lived It.” The ad marks the first time that a Democratic candidate has gone after a rival in a television ad, and comes just over two weeks before a primary vote that appears to be a tight race among Mr. Thompson, Mr. de Blasio and Christine C. Quinn.

headline: In 2000, a War Room Didn’t Fit de Blasio’s Style
text: In the middle of the 2000 Senate race, Hillary Rodham Clinton’s advisers found themselves on a conference call about what seemed a small-bore subject: campaign signs.

headline: Bill de Blasio: ‘The Tall, White One’
text: On the mayoral election trail, New York City's public advocate, Bill de Blasio, has adopted the campaign slogan "A Tale of Two Cities" in his bid to win the Democratic nomination.

headline: Family Tradition Brings Home a Title
text: Three weeks ago, Kennan Johnson won praise at the national girls’ tennis championships in San Diego for helping feed several homeless men with leftover food from a banquet.

headline: For Voice of Straphangers, a Journey Without Stops
text: Gene Russianoff, who has spent most of his adult life reflecting upon and fretting about New York City’s subways, remembers the first time he rode a train alone. He was 4 or 5. He was running away from home.

headline: Seeking Role Unknown to Many, Public Advocate Candidates Spar in Debate
text: One candidate called it “much maligned, much misunderstood,” before conceding, “It’s not sexy and it’s not hot to talk about.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
Weiner Involved in Car Accident
text: A car carrying the mayoral candidate Anthony D. Weiner was involved in an accident on Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in Manhattan on Saturday morning, Mr. Weiner’s spokeswoman said. No one was hurt.

headline: Hantuchova Remembers Finesse in Women’s Tennis, and Misses It
text: Daniela Hantuchova has played professional tennis in three decades, from her time as a fresh-faced teenager to her years as a tour veteran, and has encountered some of the sport’s greatest champions. It might be a strange feeling to see so many former travel companions and rivals now well into their tennis dotage, their competitive spirits confined to the hit-and-giggle stuff that is the senior tour, but Hantuchova said she tried to see the funny side.

headline: Full Time, Part Time, Good Jobs, Bad
text: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: Keeping Food-Borne Illnesses at Bay
text: Each year, one in six Americans becomes sick from eating contaminated food. But while outbreaks of food-borne illness linked to processing plants or imported products capture the public’s attention and raise fears about the safety of the food supply, as many as 70 percent of food poisoning cases originate in the kitchen.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 1:42 P.M. (Comedy Central) MY COUSIN VINNY (1992) Vincent Gambini (Joe Pesci), a lawyer from Brooklyn who recently passed the bar exam on his sixth attempt, is called to a small town in Alabama to defend his cousin Bill (Ralph Macchio) in a murder trial. Marisa Tomei, above with Mr. Pesci, in an Oscar-winning performance, is Mona Lisa Vito, Vinny’s fiancée, researcher, expert witness and conscience. In The New York Times, Vincent Canby wrote that this comedy “is easily the most inventive and enjoyable American film farce in a long time, even during those extended patches when it seems to be marking time or when it continues with a running gag that can’t stay the distance.” He added that Mr. Pesci “is a puzzled delight as he attempts to gather his wits, being helped not at all by Mona Lisa’s loudly articulated common sense and her ability to read law books and retain their contents.”

headline: Celebrating Difference Between Men’s and Women’s Tennis
text: There is always noise at the United States Open comparing men and women in terms of prize money.

headline: Indian Firm to Pay $2.6 Billion to Build Its Stake in African Gas Project
text: HONG KONG – A unit of India’s state-run Oil and Natural Gas Corporation said on Monday that it would pay $2.64 billion in cash for a minority stake in a natural gas project in Mozambique, the latest example of how Asia’s biggest emerging economies are zeroing in on Mozambique’s vast offshore energy resources.

headline: Stubborn Persistence of Pop
text: We experience things via reactions now, rather than head-on. As has become the norm, the best way to engage with the 2013 MTV Video Music Awards, broadcast on MTV on Sunday night from the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, was to follow on Twitter the slanderous jokes and instantly available GIFs of memorable moments.

headline: Corrections: August 26, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: After the Wedding, the Bus
text: Dear Diary:

headline: News Quiz | August 26, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Being Adoor Gopalakrishnan
text: If Adoor Gopalakrishnan had his way, India would celebrate the centenary of Indian cinema not this year, exactly 100 years after “Raja Harishchandra,” the first feature film made in India, but in 2055. For Mr. Gopalakrishnan, 72, one of India’s finest film directors, the birth of Indian cinema began in 1955 because it was the year that Satyajit Ray made “Pather Panchali” (“Song of the Little Road”).

headline: Kerry Cites Clear Evidence of Chemical Weapon Use in Syria
text: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry said Monday that the use of chemical weapons in attacks on civilians in Syria last week was undeniable and that the Obama administration would hold the Syrian government accountable for a “moral obscenity” that has shocked the world’s conscience.

headline: U.S. Short-Seller Takes Aim at Chinese Vegetable Producer
text: Updated, 9:58 a.m. |

headline: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice
text: Note: As we explained last week, we’ll be publishing a new type of Test Yourself question, one just for English-Language Learners, each Monday morning this school year.

headline: A Show of Strength by Middle Eastern Women Photographers
text: Despite the cultural limitations many have faced, women have been at the forefront of photography in Iran and the Arab world. In societies dominated by men, female photographers are using images to raise questions and explore issues of identity. They’re telling stories — often their own.

headline: Political Staging in Trial of Fallen China Official
text: JINAN, China — In the weeks before Bo Xilai, the fallen Communist Party star, went on trial here on corruption-related charges, senior officials from the powerful party investigation agency told him about two officials who had been tried earlier on somewhat similar charges, Mr. Bo said in court.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The Prospect of More Books By a Late Literary Legend
text: In the article “Film on J. D. Salinger Claims More Books Coming,” Michael Cieply and Julie Bosman write about the claims made in a new documentary and book about the reclusive writer.

headline: ING to Sell South Korean Insurance Unit for $1.7 Billion
text: HONG KONG – The Dutch insurer ING Group said on Monday that it would sell its South Korean life insurance unit to the local private equity group MBK Partners for 1.84 trillion won ($1.65 billion).

headline: Israeli Raid in West Bank Erupts Into a Deadly Riot
text: QALANDIA, West Bank — Israeli security forces shot and killed three Palestinian men on Monday when violent clashes broke out during a raid on a refugee camp that lies between Jerusalem and the West Bank city of Ramallah, according to witnesses and the Israeli military.

headline: Daily Report: Tech Upstarts Consider Their Mortality
text: As a young executive at Microsoft, Steven A. Ballmer helped topple older, slower-moving technology giants like the Digital Equipment Corporation, Wang and Novell. These days, it’s Microsoft’s turn to fend off the upstarts as it struggles to compete in a computing world that is increasingly mobile and based in a “cloud” of Internet-connected computers to which many customers gain access at the same time. It is all part of the inevitable life cycle for technology companies, Quentin Hardy reports.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Michael Steinberger on Roger Federer as Nonreligious Experience
text: Michael Steinberger, who covered tennis for The Financial Times, wrote this week’s cover story on Roger Federer. He last wrote for the magazine on the 1977 U.S. Open.

headline: New York Today: Ballpersons
text: When the United States Open tennis tournament begins on Monday in Queens, keep an eye on those gathering the balls.

headline: Student Crossword | Insects
text: Learn more about insects by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: A Blockbuster Biotech Deal
text: Amgen, the world’s biggest biotechnology company, is gaining access to three anticancer treatments with a deal on Sunday to buy Onyx Pharmaceuticals for about $10.4 billion in cash, Andrew Pollack and Michael J. de la Merced report in DealBook. Amgen is offering $125 a share in cash through a tender offer for Onyx’s shares. The deal is expected to close at the beginning of the fourth quarter, subject to regulatory approval.

headline: Marina Abramovic Kickstarter Campaign Passes Goal
text: “The Artist Is Present” from Marina Abramovic Institute on Vimeo.

headline: Burying Tom
text: In 1989 I took early retirement from the Columbia University Libraries and moved back to rural Alabama to the house in Sawyerville, where I had spent my childhood. I would soon be joined by my partner of 22 years, Tom Miller, who had remained behind in New York to tidy up his affairs before joining me in the (very) rural South.

headline: BATS and Direct Edge to Merge, Taking On Older Rivals
text: Several weeks ago, William O’Brien, the chief executive of the trading platform Direct Edge, and several of his senior managers flew discreetly to Kansas City, Mo. Waiting for them at the Charles B. Wheeler Downtown Airport there were Joe Ratterman, head of the rival BATS Global Markets, and his team.

headline: When School Starts Tomorrow, and Your Child Is Still on a Summer Schedule
text: I know I should have, but I didn’t. How many times a day does that phrase run through a parent’s head? I know I should have cooked them a vegetable for dinner. I know I should have enforced that timeout threat. I know I should have made them change out of their PJs before camp; brush their teeth for the full two minutes; turn off the television after an hour; stop using the word “idiot” when referring to their brothers (I suspect the last two are related … thank you Snotty Boy of “Back to the Barnyard”).

headline: A Reader’s Question: How Do You Hang Up on Voice Command?

headline: The Taper Versus The Crazy
text: Joe Weisenthal is right: Wall Street is paying too much attention to the “taper”, the prospect of a slowing of Fed asset purchases, and not enough attention to the looming game of debt-ceiling chicken.

headline: Filipinos Hold Mass Protest Over Official Corruption
text: MANILA — Tens of thousands of Filipinos protested in Manila on Monday, outraged over accusations that an estimated $141 million in public money had been diverted into the coffers of politicians and their associates.

headline: The Rape Suspect Who Slept on Sidewalks
text: MUMBAI —Not far from the abandoned mill where a 22 –year-old photojournalist was raped last week in Mumbai is a street lined with ramshackle structures built with corrugated iron sheets and covered in blue tarpaulin. Before his arrest on Saturday, Vijay Jadhav, 19, one of the five suspects in the case, lived here in a slum at Jivraj Ramji Boricha Marg in the Lower Parel neighborhood, where he was frequently found sleeping on the pavement.

headline: Aug. 26: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Greece on Track for More Aid, German Official Says
text: BERLIN — With Greece’s debt crisis an issue ahead of Germany’s election next month, the highest-ranking German in the European Central Bank said on Monday that Athens could be eligible for additional aid and debt relief next year if it continued to fulfill promises for its current assistance.

headline: In Obama’s High-Level Appointments, the Scales Still Tip Toward Men
text: WASHINGTON — Behind the roiling conversation over whether President Obama might make Janet L. Yellen the first female leader of the Federal Reserve is an uncomfortable reality for the White House: the administration has named no more women to high-level executive branch posts than the Clinton administration did almost two decades ago.

headline: Outside Mumbai, Reports of Rape Buried in Pages of Newspapers
text: It was a familiar scene in the lower house of the Indian Parliament on Monday as Sushma Swaraj, the Lok Sabha leader of the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party, demanded the death penalty for the five men who allegedly gang-raped a 22-year-old photojournalist in Mumbai last week while she was on assignment for an English-language magazine.

text: Participants in Dance United, which is made up of school dropouts and petty — and not so petty — criminals who have been “sentenced to dance.” One of our runners-up this week chose this piece. Go to related article »

headline: News Flash: The CBO Isn’t Stupid
text: Brad DeLong gets very annoyed at Robert Murphy, who ridicules him for not taking into account the effect of low investment on potential output. Brad notes that Murphy apparently hasn’t done the math, which indicates that even the sustained shortfall we’ve had since 2008 (mainly in residential investment) should not have had a major effect.

headline: Rita Ora’s Rock Star After-Party Style
text: The Girl: The singer ditched her red-carpet look, complete with a mile-long feather train, in favor of a more practical, sexy sheath after the 2013 MTV Video Music Awards. Matching lips and shoes pulled it all together.

headline: Voting On Russia’s Scorched Political Earth
text: Moscow has not seen political argument this heated in years. Then again, Moscow has not seen a mayoral election in a decade. And now that the election is two weeks away, arguments about whom to vote for — or, more specifically, whether or not to vote for the opposition activist Aleksei Navalny — have reached a fever pitch.

headline: Idealized or Caricature, Architectural Renderings Are Weapons in Real Estate
text: In recent weeks, two competing illustrations have popped up in different corners of the Internet. In one of them, eight silvery towers perch at the waterfront of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, like a fleet of sailboats waiting peacefully for their captains. In the other, swollen and clearly exaggerated buildings the color of sickly flamingos loom over a diminished Manhattan skyline, threatening to swallow their neighbors in a gluttonous fit.

headline: Papers Find Mixed Impacts on Ocean Species from Rising CO2
text: Britain’s Royal Society has published a helpful new collection of papers in Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B that provide fresh insights on how the global buildup of carbon dioxide released by human activities could affect ocean ecology.

headline: Women in the Room
text: President Obama has appointed a total of 13 women to cabinet-level positions during his time in office, the same number as President Clinton during his two terms.

headline: David Maisel: Aerial Photographs
text: The Haines Gallery in San Francisco is featuring an exhibit of David Maisel’s photographs of open-pit copper mines, tailings ponds, and cyanide-leaching fields throughout the American west.

text: Can you help a nun successfully complete her pilgrimage?

headline: The Robber, the Judge, and the Case for Leniency

headline: Justice Dept. Again Signals Interest to Pursue Financial Crisis Cases
text: Patience is a virtue, and waiting for cases from the financial crisis has certainly called for such a temperament. In a recent interview, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. indicated that the wait might be over, but it is unlikely to satisfy those who have found the Justice Department’s response to be tepid at best.

headline: Image of the Day: August 26
text: The 103rd anniversary of Mother Teresa’s birth was commemorated in Kolkata, West Bengal.

text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Aug. 19.

headline: Dempsey’s Arrival Has Sounders Crowd at Fever Pitch
text: SEATTLE — The smoke began billowing innocently from hand-held devices, with colors that were a vague semblance of Sounders blue and green. By the time the thick plumes rose into the air above the several thousand marchers, it had combined into a black mixture, not unlike the byproduct of burning coal. Red flares helped little to light the way.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Victor Acosta joined the Los Angeles office of Wong, Doody, Crandall, Wiener in a new post, associate planning director. He had been a senior strategic planner at David & Goliath, Los Angeles.

text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Panel Clears Rhythmic Gymnastics Judges Suspected of Cheating
text: The governing body for rhythmic gymnastics has cleared dozens of judges who were suspected of cheating on qualifying tests last year, despite an investigation that concluded some of the test scores “could only have occurred by cheating.”

headline: An Enormous I.V. Markup, Humans as Evolutionary Force, Guerrilla Water Sampling
text: A food poisoning outbreak starts a reporter on an odyssey to find the price of saline solution; it turns out our existence may change the brains of the animals around us; a group of researchers is bringing water quality tracking to the taps we drink from.

text: Who will care for me when I’m old?

text: Concordia Cleanup Costa Concordia, the luxury cruiser that capsized off the Italian coast last year, will be salvaged next month in a maneuver that is expected to cost about $623 million. (Bloomberg, via Skift)

headline: The Long Hair a Mother Covets, and a Daughter Wants to Cut
text: My 6-year-old wants to cut her hair short. I won’t let her.

headline: A Cool Niçoise Salad for Summer’s End
text: What’s for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: Never Mind Citi Bike, Here’s Campus Bike
text: In 1892, a song celebrated “a bicycle built for two.” More than a century later, a campaign for a university is upping the ante with an offer of bicycles built for a hundred.

headline: At This Club’s Velvet Rope, the T.S.A.
text: ATLANTA — There is a new club in this city often referred to as the ATL. Somehow, despite the abundance of clubs, the name its proprietors chose was unclaimed: the Club at ATL.

headline: How Surveillance Changes Behavior: A Restaurant Workers Case Study
text: Surveillance is certainly much in the news lately. Most notably, of course, there is the continuing outcry over the National Security Agency’s call-tracking program, disclosed in the documents leaked by Edward Snowden.

headline: Vein of Iron in South Atlantic
text: Researchers have discovered a vast plume of iron and other nutrients, more than 600 miles long, in the South Atlantic Ocean. The finding challenges long-held beliefs about the sources and abundance of undersea iron.

headline: Blake Announces Retirement From Tennis
text: When word went out late Sunday evening that James Blake would be having a news conference Monday morning at the United States Open, the reason was not difficult to guess.

headline: Can’t Beat These New Clocks
text: Atomic clocks are already the most accurate timepieces in existence, typically losing or gaining a second every 100 million years or so. Now, researchers at the National Institute of Standards and Technology have built a pair of atomic clocks 10 times as precise as their predecessors.

headline: 'It's Unanimous'
text: The Quinn campaign released an ad touting three newspaper endorsements.

headline: Danny Burstein and Victoria Clark Join Broadway’s ‘Snow Geese’
text: The Broadway stalwarts Danny Burstein and Victoria Clark will join Mary-Louise Parker in the coming premiere of “The Snow Geese,” setting the stage for a theater-world trade-off that involves both a fictional couple and a real-life one.

headline: Cancer’s Ordered Disorder
text: We have no shortage of dispatches from the cancer wars, what with doctors, patients, essayists, scientists and journalists in every possible combination and permutation all checking in at length from the front.

headline: With Victory, Venus Williams Brings Old Order Back
text: For a slice of an afternoon, the world of Venus Williams looked an awful lot the way it used to: she was dominating a match at the United States Open, calmly blasting shots past a player possessing nowhere near her talent level, trotting off happily with the New York sun glancing off her pink-tinted hair and sparkling smile.

headline: MTV Awards Show Prompts Familiar Complaint
text: MTV has once again outraged an advocacy group that wants to reduce the level of adult content and profanity on television. The Parents Television Council, a nonprofit group known for criticizing shows, including “Family Guy,” for explicit content and adult jokes, took the network to task for airing condom ads and staging performances with skimpy costumes and sexually suggestive dancing during the Video Music Awards on Sunday.

headline: A Quest for Even Safer Drinking Water
text: UNIONTOWN, Pa. — On a muggy Friday afternoon in a strip mall parking lot, as thunder echoed in the Alleghenies and cottonwood seeds floated on the breeze, Lee Stanish, 32, a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Colorado Boulder, and Natalie Hull, 24, a lab manager, stepped out of a white van, its hood plastered with dead insects.

headline: Wage Stagnation and Market Outcomes
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: MTV Music Awards Red Carpet
text: At the MTV Video Music Awards in Brooklyn, guests like Taylor Swift in a plunging neckline Herve Leger dress and Miley Cyrus in a cropped Dolce & Gabbana outift, showed some skin.

headline: Food Matters | A British Outpost Opens on the Upper East Side
text: Ben Towill and Phil Winser, the duo behind Chinatown’s Fat Radish restaurant, have brought their longtime executive chef, Nick Wilber, uptown to head the kitchen at the East Pole, their new restaurant on the Upper East Side. “We weren’t looking specifically for a location up there,” explained Winser, who is responsible for the look and feel of their London-inspired industrial interiors. (Towill and Winser, both 29, have been friends since their days at Marlborough College.) “We really just stumbled on a unique property in a part of town that happens to have an open market for what we did in Chinatown.”

headline: Exploratorium Forced to Cut Back
text: When the Exploratorium in San Francisco reopened in April at a new, larger site on a waterfront pier, museum officials expected a crush of crowds — so many additional visitors that they worried the museum and its interactive exhibits would be overrun.

headline: Are There Reasons for Different Sneezing Patterns?
text: Q. When I sneeze, I do it three times; my husband sneezes once. Has anyone studied the reasons for different sneeze patterns?

headline: Ted Cruz Plays Two Truths and a Lie
text: In an interview with CNN’s Candy Crowley on Sunday, Senator Ted Cruz spoke frankly, and also not so frankly, on the movement to shut down the federal government unless healthcare reform is defunded.

headline: Scene City: Back to Manhattan After the VMAs
text: A crush of parties after MTV’s Video Music Awards.

headline: A Molten Planet and Meteorite Jewelry
text: Amid the big and alarming news — a United Nations report confirming that human-made greenhouse emissions were significantly warming the planet and leading to much higher sea levels — were some diverting discoveries. Astronomers spotted a planet that circles its star in a little more than eight hours, a well-preserved bog mummy found in Ireland is at least 4,000 years old, and marine scientists discovered a new species of clam that lives among the spines of sea urchins in the Pacific Ocean.

text: Following is a transcript of a news conference on chemical weapons in Syria by Secretary of State John Kerry on Monday in Washington, provided by Federal News Service.

text: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events that made news this week.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Dixon Penalized for Pit Crew Knock-Down
text: An incident in Sunday’s IndyCar event at Sonoma Raceway in California may have an impact on the outcome of the season championship. Will Power won the race after one of his crewmen fell down as Scott Dixon, who was leading at the time, hit him on his way out of the pits after his final stop.

headline: Crafting Couscous: No Grain, No Gain
text: When I visited a small village in northwest Morocco this summer, I was enchanted by the sight of a group of women at a food cooperative, sitting on the floor with their legs outstretched, expertly mixing water with semolina, then raking the grain with their fingers in sweeping circular motions as they prepared couscous from scratch.

headline: John Kerry's Statement on Syria
text: Secretary of State John Kerry said evidence “strongly indicates” that chemical weapons were used in Syria.

headline: U.S. Open Food Review: An Incredibly Shrinking Lunch
text: One of the joys at the United States Open every year is the food. You don’t need to eat in a fancy restaurant at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center to eat well. The food stands have the usual sporting event fare, but they also teem with quality items that go beyond hot dogs and nachos. The bad news is, you’ll pay dearly for them. The good news is, the prices do not seem to have gone up from last year.

headline: Trump Further Sullies For-Profit Schools
text: Leave it to the real estate mogul Donald Trump to give the for-profit education industry an even worse rap than it already has. Schools looking to make a buck have come under scrutiny recently for taking students’ money but providing lackluster job results. New York State’s $40 million lawsuit over Mr. Trump’s foray into the industry underscores the need for these institutions to make credentials clear.

headline: New York Film Festival to Showcase Documentaries on Science and Democracy
text: Movies  about science and democracy and a series devoted to cinematic portraiture will anchor the documentary portion of the New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Monday.

headline: New Rivals Compete for Convention Business
text: CHEKITAN DEV, a professor at Cornell who specializes in the hotel industry, drove past a Marriott Courtyard near Los Angeles the other day and was surprised by a big banner out front that invited corporate event planners to call or stop in for more information about holding meetings there — for 10 to 30 people.

headline: Long Security Lines Catch Tennis Fans by Surprise
text: As she approached the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center Monday morning, Sandra Walden of the Bronx, a longtime attendee of the United States Open, made an astute observation.

headline: Official Denies Inquiry Into Egyptian Activists
text: CAIRO — A spokesman for Egypt’s Foreign Ministry on Monday denied reports in the state news media over the weekend about an investigation into two prominent activists, Asmaa Mahfouz and Esraa Abdel Fattah, who are sometimes associated with the left-leaning April 6 group.

headline: Set Back by Recession, and Shut Out of Rebound
text: RIDGEWOOD, N.J. — In September 2012, it appeared that the world was John Fugazzie’s frozen oyster. He was in charge of dairy and frozen foods for the A.&P. supermarket chain, making $125,000 a year.

headline: Mets Disclose That Harvey Has Elbow Tear
text: More than any other player, Matt Harvey symbolized the tentative notion that the Mets might actually be nearing a renaissance. If the team rose to prominence next season, the thinking went, it would surely be following his bullish lead.

headline: After Tough Weekend, Yankees Facing Blue Jays Again
text: After a tough weekend at Tampa Bay, the Yankees are back where they want to be, playing their personal pushovers, the Toronto Blue Jays.

headline: Wildfire Near Yosemite Destroys Berkeley’s Family Campground
text: Last Updated | 10:05 a.m., Aug. 27 One of the largest wildfires in California history continued to rage near Yosemite National Park, destroying more than 160,000 acres by Tuesday, including the city of Berkeley’s popular Tuolumne Family Camp, officials said.

headline: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the West Bank, Iraq, Syria and Myanmar.

headline: Triple Play: Week 21 Results
text: It was a close call on Question 1, with just over 33 percent of you picking the Tampa Bay Rays to come out of the week leading the American League wild-card race and just under 32 percent going with the Oakland A’s. At 74-54, the Rays have a two and a half game edge over the A’s in the wild-card standings. (Tampa Bay trails Boston by a game in the A.L. East, and Oakland is second to Texas by two and a half games in the A.L. West.) Nice work, prognosticators. The Rays took two out of three games at Baltimore, then two out of three at home against the Yankees, while the A’s lost four of six over all, including two of three over the weekend at Baltimore.

headline: Feeling For | A Sake That’s Perfect for Summer Sipping
text: For the uninitiated, drinking sake probably only means throwing back porcelain thimbles of scalding liquid that turns tepid before you know it. But the traditional Japanese beverage served cold can be a pleasant answer to less-than-comfortable summer nights. A particularly delicious variety that has been popping up at many of New York’s izakayas (the Japanese equivalent to a gastropub) and sake bars recently is the Tokubetsu Junmai from the gourmet sake brewery Nanbu Bijin. Its name translates to “southern beauty,” but Nanbu Bijin is actually located in northern Japan, in a region once controlled by the Nanbu clan of samurai. This junmai — a pure, full-bodied class of premium sake — has a bright, floral bouquet, almost like a lily blossom, and starts crisp before offering a sweet finish almost like honeydew. New Yorkers can find it at Decibel, in the East Village, and Sakagura, near Grand Central Terminal.

headline: ‘Heroin Chic’ Beauty for the Office?
text: Having always had a soft spot for grunge (for nostalgia reasons, including junior high years spent in a Seattle suburb) and spinoffs thereof, like “heroin chic,” the fall runways with their disgruntled ’90s air felt as familiar as a fuzzy mohair cardigan. In beauty, lip colors were jam-black at some shows (perhaps riffing on Drew Barrymore’s plummy lips during her wild child days), while others interpreted the bare-faced era more literally (slightly greasy skin and stringy hair like Kate Moss’s in the old Calvin Klein ads). But considering that the first time around I was a jobless teenager and that a shiny complexion and unwashed hair is probably not the best combination for the office, I looked to Lloyd Simmonds, creative director of Yves Saint Laurent Makeup, for a few pointers. After all, he had to interpret the very grungy Saint Laurent clothing designed by Hedi Slimane into a viable makeup collection. Here are some snippets from our conversation.

headline: Bacteria Study Offers Clues to Typhoid Mary Mystery
text: Scientists are one step closer to explaining how Typhoid Mary could have infected dozens of New Yorkers over a 12-year career as a cook, killing at least three of them, without having ever been sick herself.

headline: Almost 5 Months Old, Bronx Native Makes Zoo Debut
text: A 17-pound snow leopard, born this spring at the Bronx Zoo, is now on display, the first son of an orphaned snow leopard from Pakistan.

headline: Remembering Muriel Siebert, an ‘Icon’ for Women
text: For a generation of women on Wall Street, Muriel F. Siebert was more than just a leader in finance; she was their point of reference.

headline: Bring Your Lunch to Work
text: There are few brown-baggers in the building where I work. This is not because the food in the neighborhood is so great (it isn’t), or because the cafeteria is Google-like (it isn’t), but because many people are either “too busy” or too embarrassed to bring their lunch. Somehow one of our oldest and sanest traditions has become a laughingstock: it’s not hip to bring lunch.

headline: Lew’s Letter to Congress About the Debt Limit
text: Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew informed House Speaker John A. Boehner that the government is likely to reach its borrowing limit in mid-October.

headline: Oppressed Becomes Oppressor
text: To his critics in the West, Robert Mugabe, president of the politically and economically troubled Zimbabwe, is a tyrant, an election rigger, a thug who uses past victimhood to justify further oppression.

headline: Weekly Ticket Sales Drop Under $1 Million for Broadway’s ‘Spider-Man’
text: For the first time since performances began in November 2010, the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” took in less than $1 million for a standard eight-performance playing week, with last week’s gross totaling $966,952. While ticket sales have been softening since last fall for the $75 million musical, the most expensive in Broadway history, a spokesman on Monday linked last week’s total to “fallout” from a well-publicized foot injury suffered by the cast member Daniel Curry during the Aug. 15 performance.

headline: His Links Severed, Ackman Sells Stake in J.C. Penney
text: Updated, Aug. 27, 6:32 a.m. | William A. Ackman sold his roughly 18 percent stake in J.C. Penney at $12.90 a share on Monday, severing all ties to the retailer two weeks after he resigned from the board. At that price, his stake was valued at $504 million, saddling him with a loss of about $473 million.

headline: A Syrah to Pair With Lamb Shanks
text: Bordeaux is the classic pairing for lamb, but that would be true of a simpler Western dish: chops or a roast, for example. This dish of meltingly tender lamb shanks with a fruity North African accompaniment requires something softer and less tannic. I would reach for a syrah from the northern Rhône Valley, like a St.-Joseph, a Crozes-Hermitage or even those rare syrah-based Côtes du Rhônes, like Éric Texier’s Brézème.

headline: James Purdy, a Fabulist Haunting the Fringes
text: When he died in 2009, at 94, James Purdy was a forgotten man. He had always been a cult writer, held in almost worshipful regard for his wildly original, sometimes shocking novels and stories that worked the margins of American society, fringe territory populated by small-town folk, failed artists and tormented gay men.

headline: Reinvigorating a Chestnut With Clarity, Not Sizzle
text: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass. — As perhaps suits a tale of the sea, Eugene O’Neill’s “Anna Christie” is encrusted with layer upon layer of barnacles. The last, daring word in modern theater and modern subject matter when it opened on Broadway in 1921, this Pulitzer Prize-winning drama of a prostitute’s redemption now seems all but buried in quaintness, myth and exotica.

headline: Obama Honors Soldier for Bravery Under Fire, and Afterward
text: For generations, soldiers have been honored at the White House for valor under fire. And no one questions the heroism of Staff Sgt. Ty Michael Carter, who raced through a hail of bullets to rescue a wounded comrade and helped keep Taliban fighters from overrunning a combat post in Afghanistan.

headline: Second Avenue, Repaved as Memory Lane
text: Until a few days ago, I had no idea who Menasha Skulnik was. Now I want Avi Hoffman to do a show about him.

headline: Dollop of Romance Is Added to Intrigue at Former Chinese Politician’s Trial
text: JINAN, China — Concluding a trial that has riveted China, Bo Xilai, the former elite Communist Party official, attacked elements of the prosecution’s case on Monday and said his former top deputy and his wife, both of whom provided evidence against him, had a passionate relationship.

headline: What Joseph Bottum Wants
text: Joseph Bottum’s essay in Commonweal making what’s advertised (and what the Times has covered) as “a conservative Catholic’s case for same-sex marriage” is so deliberately discursive — to the point of obscuring, at times, exactly what kind of argument the former First Things editor is making — that it’s hard to know exactly where a response would best begin. But I thought I would pluck out the following passage, which is an aside in the essay but a suggestive one, I think, in terms of understanding both Bottum’s personal motivations in writing this piece and some of the larger issues in play as well. He’s writing here about anti-Catholicism in American life, and he pauses to note how surprising it would be, from the vantage point of earlier eras and debates, that the church’s attitude toward homosexuality would have ended up giving fuel to an anti-Catholic fire:

headline: Video Shows U.N. Inspectors in Syria Interviewing Survivors of Suspected Chemical Attack
text: As my colleagues Michael Gordon, Alan Cowell and Rick Gladstone report, United Nations weapons inspectors visited two hospitals in the Syrian countryside outside of Damascus on Monday to interview survivors of last week’s suspected chemical weapons attack and collect patient samples, despite a volley of sniper fire that disabled the lead vehicle in their convoy.

headline: Once an Outcast, Iranian Minister Carries Hope of Easing Tensions
text: TEHRAN — Until this summer, Mohammad Javad Zarif, one of Iran’s most accomplished diplomats, was an outcast, exiled from the government by ultraconservatives for working too closely with the West. Rather than presenting the Iranian case to the world, as he had done so effectively throughout a 35-year diplomatic career, he was spending his days teaching at the Foreign Ministry’s training center on a quiet, leafy campus in North Tehran.

headline: In Performance: Sarah Lemp
text: Sarah Lemp plays Mama in “The Cheaters Club,” Derek Ahonen’s new play set at a haunted inn in Georgia. The dark comedy, being mounted by the Amoralists, is at the Abrons Arts Center.

headline: Big Sean and Albert Heath and Friends Release Albums
text: BIG SEAN

headline: Driving the 2014 Cadillac XTS Vsport
text: When I think Cadillac, my mental archive scrolls back to that crisp black and white image of Muhammad Ali, sitting next to his mother and looking over his shoulder from the driver’s seat of a new Cadillac. For many people then, the first stop upon arrival at success was probably a Cadillac dealership. Frank Sinatra had one; Elvis owned many over the years.

headline: Hunger Muggles’ Occult Dystopia
text: The book club craze may have hit its nadir. The big moment came a week ago when the NBC morning show “Today” announced that it, too, was starting a book club, presumably because so many of its competitors have them, and anointed Samantha Shannon’s novel, “The Bone Season,” its first pick. Seated in front of a backdrop on which the words “Call me Ishmael” were clearly visible, the “Today” team explained how a debut novel by a 21-year-old unknown had snagged this distinction. Not one bit of the five-minute segment concerned exactly what Ms. Shannon has written.

headline: Examined, the Virtual Life Is Worth Living
text: The habit of insisting that the virtual life is somehow not part of real life has diminished with time. Few people regard, say, online magazines as fake magazines anymore. And more than one politician has been felled by a scandal involving sex that was purely digital. So even though it wasn’t physical, it must have been real. Right?

headline: A World Traveler Is Harmless, Yet Suspect
text: I THINK I’m a friendly person, but once I get on an airplane I barely speak to anyone. I’m traveling so much, predominantly throughout the United States, Asia and Europe, that sometimes I’m not even quite sure of my itinerary.

headline: Vines and Vintner Beautify a Tuscan Hill
text: BARGINO, Italy — For all its beauty, Italy has suffered reckless development. Travel outside any big city, and you’ll come across aging sprawl: unplanned wastelands of shopping malls, factories and housing projects, many from the 1960s and ’70s. Florence, a dozen or so miles from here, is no exception. The city started devolving into a mess of shabby suburbs years ago; nearby towns like Tavarnelle and Poggibonsi added industrial parks to historic centers.

headline: Tracing the Steps That Led Up to the March on Washington
text: Outside of natural disasters, few of history’s momentous events happen spontaneously. The March on Washington may, through the haze of 50 years, have come to seem as if it were a magical bit of serendipity, but just like D-Day or the lunar landing, it required considerable planning and was the culmination of a string of events and decisions.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Google’s Schmidt Responds to Ellison, and Autocomplete’s Genesis
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Here’s what we noticed today:

headline: Growth in Global Disputes Brings Big Paychecks for Law Firms
text: Debt woes, broken contracts and soured business deals may cost global investors billions in losses and create seemingly never-ending headaches for policy makers. But there is a set of specialists profiting from such geopolitical problems: arbitration lawyers.

headline: Youth at the Head of the Classroom
text: Charter schools are developing what amounts to a youth cult in which teaching for two to five years is seen as acceptable, and even desirable.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Quinn Highlights Endorsements
text: Moving quickly to highlight newspaper editorial-page endorsements she had just collected, Christine C. Quinn, a Democratic candidate for mayor, released her third English-language television advertisement on Monday. Called “It’s Unanimous,” the ad spotlights her endorsements by The New York Times, The New York Post and The Daily News.

headline: Bethanie Mattek-Sands Makes Fashion Statements With Her Hair
text: She is known for her knee socks, war paint, tattoos and, of course, her tennis ball fringe jacket from Wimbledon 2011. But this summer, Bethanie Mattek-Sands, often called the Lady Gaga of tennis, has been making fashion statements with her hair. At Wimbledon, she wore a blue, lime green and yellow updo after a brief flirtation with a more subdued look (blond ponytail, black knee socks) at the French Open.

headline: More Painful Memories for a Slovene in New York
text: Aljaz Bedene lost in the first round of the United States Open on Monday. But at least he did not end up in the hospital.

headline: The McMansion Man
text: Joe Farrell, the largest real estate developer in the Hamptons, is changing the look of the elite beach destination.

headline: Hamptons McMansions Herald a Return of Excess
text: BRIDGEHAMPTON, N.Y. — Porsche ads clog the local radio here, houses are renting at close to the million-dollar range — for the summer — and Uber, an app that lets you order car service, reports that its new Hamptons luxury S.U.V. business is booming, $50 minimum fares and all.

headline: Officer Is Indicted on Charges of Lying About Photographer’s Arrest
text: A New York City police officer who had arrested a photographer working for The New York Times has been indicted on three felony counts and five misdemeanors accusing him of fabricating the reasons for the arrest, the Bronx district attorney announced on Monday.

headline: In Jeter’s Return, a Missed Chance for Celebration
text: TORONTO — Derek Jeter was back on the field playing alongside Alex Rodriguez in a game for the first time all season Monday, facing a Toronto Blue Jays team the Yankees had thrashed and battered in almost every previous encounter in 2013. Jeter managed to remain healthy and Rodriguez even homered in the game. What could possibly go wrong to prevent a win?

headline: Party Leader in India Becomes Ill After Speech
text: NEW DELHI — Sonia Gandhi, leader of the Indian National Congress Party, was released from a hospital in the capital early Tuesday after she became ill during a Monday parliamentary session and was briefly admitted to a cardiology unit.

headline: Pennsylvania’s Capital Files Plan for Finances With Court
text: A receiver overseeing the finances of Pennsylvania’s distressed capital, Harrisburg, filed a detailed plan on Monday showing how the city will sell or lease assets and raise new revenue as it seeks to escape from a mountain of debt and restore financial stability.

headline: Treasury Prods Lawmakers on Raising Debt Ceiling
text: WASHINGTON — Unless Congress raises the debt ceiling, the Treasury Department said on Monday that it expected to lose the ability to pay all of the government’s bills in mid-October.

headline: Third Point Hedge Fund Increases Sotheby’s Stake
text: The activist investor Daniel S. Loeb disclosed on Monday that he had acquired a large stake in the auction house Sotheby’s, sending its shares up 3 percent.

headline: Seeking Asylum in Australia, Refugees Find a Policy in Flux
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — In January, Naqsh Murtaza had had enough of war-torn Afghanistan. Mr. Naqsh, a 27-year-old Afghan, fled with his mother and two younger brothers across the border into Pakistan, the first stop on a risky journey whose ultimate destination was Australia.

headline: Zajick Pulls Out of ‘Dolores Claiborne’
text: Dolora Zajick will not be Dolores Claiborne after all.

headline: A Soft Sell for Air Fresheners, With Joan Rivers in Reality Show Spoofs
text: CAN a frank, bawdy comedian and her equally outspoken daughter find happiness selling air fresheners? And can a maker of air fresheners find happiness with such seemingly unlikely pitchwomen? When the product-peddling aspects of the advertising can be soft-pedaled — as now occurs increasingly on Madison Avenue, in a trend known as content marketing — the answer may be “yes.”

headline: For a Day at Least, British Fans Have More Than Murray to Cheer
text: In the eyes of the ever-sensationalist British news media, the opening day of the United States Open was about two players, and they were not Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal.

headline: Malicious Software Poses as Video From a Facebook Friend
text: A piece of malicious software masquerading as a Facebook video is hijacking users’ Facebook accounts and Web browsers, according to independent Italian security researchers who have been investigating the situation.

headline: Ryan Refuses to Revisit Quarterback Situation
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Jets are listing Mark Sanchez as day to day, and he believes that is a fair characterization of his health. It is better than being week to week, which would eliminate him from consideration to start the Sept. 8 season opener, but not nearly as good as not having an injured right shoulder in the first place.

headline: Pierre-Paul and Rolle Join Practice
text: A day after the Giants’ defense took a major step backward when safety Stevie Brown was placed on injured reserve, the unit took two major steps forward. Jason Pierre-Paul, a defensive end who was nearly unstoppable when he recorded 16 ½ sacks and helped the Giants win the Super Bowl two years ago, was taken off the physically unable to perform list Monday. He was joined in practice by safety Antrel Rolle, who had been sidelined since Aug. 12 with a sprained ankle.

headline: Five Years After TARP, Misgivings on Bonuses
text: “There was such a total lack of awareness from the firms that paid big bonuses during this extraordinary time.”

headline: N.S.A. Phone Data Collection Is Illegal, A.C.L.U. Says
text: WASHINGTON — In a detailed legal attack on the National Security Agency’s collection of Americans’ phone call data, the American Civil Liberties Union argued in court papers filed Monday that the sweeping data gathering violates the Constitution and should be halted.

headline: The Two Cultures of Educational Reform
text: About halfway through his magisterial study “Higher Education in America,” Derek Bok, twice president of Harvard, identifies what he calls the “two different cultures” of educational reform. The first “is an evidence-based approach to education … rooted in the belief that one can best advance teaching and learning by measuring student progress and testing experimental efforts to increase it.” The second “rests on a conviction that effective teaching is an art which one can improve over time through personal experience and intuition without any need for data-driven reforms imposed from above.”

headline: Britain’s Furor Over Fracking
text: BALCOMBE, England — The lovely green hills of the High Weald are Tory country, a corner of West Sussex full of affluent residents who commute to London and like their golf and ambles and thatched cottages. So it is a surprise, in this conservative heartland, to stumble on an encampment of hundreds of activists, foraging in the hedgerows for edible greens, sawing wood for fires, playing flutes and generally enacting a kind of mini-Woodstock.

headline: Prosecution of Ex-Marine for 2008 Iraq Shooting Sets Off Debate
text: When the gun went off inside the trailer at a Marine outpost in Iraq in 2008, the bullet pierced the left temple of a Navy hospital corpsman who was seated on his cot, rupturing his left eye and exiting though his right cheek. He survived, but was left partly blind.

headline: The Risk Pool
text: BELGRADE LAKES, Me. — THIRTY-SEVEN years ago this week my friend Pearce Bunting was at the wheel of my Volkswagen and I was in the passenger seat when he drove the car off a road in suburban Philadelphia. It bounced off a fire hydrant and then plunged into a small ravine. I remember thinking, as we flew through the air, that I was about to find out whether there was life after death. I heard the crash as if from a distant room. Then a vague blue blob spoke. “Are you all right?” it wanted to know, and then said, more reassuringly, “You’re going to be all right.”

headline: Egypt’s Journalists, Still Under Siege
text: CAIRO — I LOOKED on, astonished, as a man a few yards away told protesters that he would slaughter me.

headline: Gorky Park, Once Drab, Now Glows
text: MOSCOW — The runners and bikers arrive first, gliding along the bank of the Moscow River. Later come the legions of in-line skaters, parents pushing baby strollers, children on scooters, brides tottering on high heels.

headline: At Charter Schools, Short Careers by Choice
text: HOUSTON — Tyler Dowdy just started his third year of teaching at YES Prep West, a charter school here. He figures now is a good time to explore his next step, including applying for a supervisory position at the school.

headline: At 35, Not Quite Ready to Give Up the Dream
text: There is only so much jet lag that the human body can be expected to endure. Only so many locker rooms and hotel rooms and practice courts. We won’t even get into the emotional scars of losing week after week after week for all but the chosen few.

headline: The Ideas Behind the March
text: As we commemorate the 1963 civil rights march on Washington, it’s worth remembering how close it came to not happening at all. When A. Philip Randolph and Bayard Rustin started shopping the idea, the Urban League declined to support it, the N.A.A.C.P. refused to commit one way or another, and Martin Luther King and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference were too busy with other challenges to get engaged. President John Kennedy argued that the march would hurt the chances of passing legislation.

headline: Dangerous Ticks
text: Residents of the Northeast and the Midwest know that ticks can carry the bacteria that cause Lyme disease. What most don’t know is that the same family of black-legged ticks can also cause other diseases that are even more dangerous.

headline: Responding to Syrian Atrocities
text: There is little doubt now that President Obama is planning some kind of military response to what the administration says without equivocation was a chemical weapons attack by the Syrian government that killed hundreds of civilians. On Monday, Secretary of State John Kerry began forcefully making the case for action.

headline: Inside Donald Trump’s University
text: Apparently there is nothing Donald Trump likes better than a good shouting match, even when it involves a lawsuit accusing him of fraud.

headline: Is an Attack on Syria Justified?
text: Should the United States and its allies launch air strikes against Syria in response to the Assad regime's reported use of chemical weapons?

headline: Tobacco, Trade Agreements and Public Health
text: To the Editor:

headline: Religious Laws and Public Places
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gay Rights and the Met
text: To the Editor:

headline: Paying for College: Obama’s Proposal
text: To the Editor:

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Aug. 27, 2013
text: “The indiscriminate slaughter of civilians, the killing of women and children and innocent bystanders by chemical weapons is a moral obscenity.”

headline: Areas Affected by the Alleged Chemical Attack in Syria
text: Opposition groups said that rockets carrying chemical weapons hit the towns of Ain Tarma, Zamalka, Jobar and Muadamiya shortly after 2 a.m. Wednesday. Victims were taken to clinics in neighboring towns.

headline: Blasts in the Night, a Smell, and a Flood of Syrian Victims
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Thousands of sick and dying Syrians had flooded the hospitals in the Damascus suburbs before dawn, hours after the first rockets landed, their bodies convulsing and mouths foaming. Their vision was blurry and many could not breathe.

headline: In Chicago, Campaign to Provide Safe Passage on Way to School
text: CHICAGO — The first day of school in one neighborhood on this city’s far South Side brought a parade of security workers in neon vests, police officers on patrol, an idling city fire truck and, briefly, a police helicopter hovering above. All this to make sure that students from a shuttered elementary school could make it safely past abandoned lots, boarded-up houses and gang territory to get to their new school less than a half-mile away.

headline: A Finicky Thief of the Finest Silver Is Arrested Again
text: ATLANTA — Even before someone carefully removed a windowpane from a secluded Buckhead home here one rainy June night and slipped away with a 1734 silver mug that had belonged to George II, it was clear to detectives that a meticulous thief with a singular obsession was stealing the great silver pieces of the Old South.

headline: Over News of Clash, a Shroud of Silence in Xinjiang
text: HANERIK, China — The blood has long since been hosed away, but weeks after Chinese security forces opened fire on a crowd of Muslim protesters, killing what local residents said were scores of young men, there is a palpable fear on the streets of this dusty farming township in Xinjiang, the restive borderland region in China’s far west.

headline: Corrections: August 27, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Knuckling Down
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Before I was owned by Jade, The Extremely Spunky Border Terrier, my job was to keep a dog named Paris alive. I’d like to say that we were companions, but the vast majority of the 16 years we spent together was actually devoted to thwarting the many ways he could find each day to end his life.

headline: 2 Mayoral Rivals Step Up Fight for Black Vote
text: William C. Thompson Jr. is the sole African-American among the leading candidates for mayor of New York City, and he has long counted on the support of black voters to propel him to victory in a crowded Democratic field.

headline: Red Burns, ‘Godmother of Silicon Alley,’ Dies at 88
text: Red Burns, an educator who gained wide recognition for pushing for more creative uses of modern communications, helping to lead the movement for public access to cable television and becoming the driving force behind a celebrated New York University program to foster Internet wizards, died on Friday at her Manhattan home. She was 88.

headline: On a Large Stage, King’s Dream. On a Small One, a Nightmare.
text: PLAQUEMINE, La. — Fifty years ago this week, as thousands converged in Washington to hear the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. deliver what would become a hallowed text in American history, Ronnie Moore was sitting in a cell near here watching on a black-and-white television.

headline: San Francisco Girds for Possible Threat to Water From Wildfire
text: With an enormous wildfire in the Sierra Nevada posing a potential threat to San Francisco’s water supply, city officials were busy planning Monday how to divert water from other sources in case their main reservoir — the Hetch Hetchy, which sits 170 miles east of the city and serves about 2.6 million people — were to grow clouded with falling ash.

headline: Lone Woman in Mayoral Race Steps Up Appeal to Female Voters
text: It is not every day that a mayoral candidate is asked about her backhand.

headline: Gilbert Taylor, Celebrated Cinematographer, Dies at 99
text: Gilbert Taylor, the British cinematographer behind hit movies like “Star Wars,” “The Omen” and “Dr. Strangelove,” died on Friday at his home on the Isle of Wight. He was 99.

headline: Prosecutors Press Subpoena for Times Reporter in Leak Case
text: The Justice Department on Monday asked a full federal appeals court not to hear arguments from lawyers for a New York Times reporter, James Risen, whom prosecutors have subpoenaed to testify in a criminal leak case against a former C.I.A. officer, Jeffrey Sterling. A three-judge panel of the appeals court in Richmond, Va., ruled in July that reporters have no special privilege to avoid testifying about their sources and that Mr. Risen, who prosecutors say used Mr. Sterling as a source for a 2006 book on the C.I.A., would have to testify. Mr. Risen’s lawyers asked the full 15-judge court to reconsider the case, but the Justice Department argued in Monday’s filing that the ruling was correct and that no further hearing was justified.

headline: Peter Huttenlocher, Explorer of the Brain, Dies at 82
text: Dr. Peter Huttenlocher, a pediatric neurologist and neuroscientist whose innovative research counting billions of brain synapses — the microscopic information highways of the mind — revealed that brains develop rapidly in young children and later “prune” themselves as they mature, died on Aug. 15 in Chicago. He was 82.

headline: As Serena Williams Caps Big Day for Sisters, Her Opponent Needs a Hug
text: In her brief appearance on the center court at the United States Open on Monday, Francesca Schiavone had reached her wit’s end. Having lost her first eight games to top-seeded Serena Williams, she did what any exasperated player might do.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Gulbis, With a Favorable Draw, Cannot Capitalize
text: Ernests Gulbis was one of the more surprising upset losses on Day 1 at the United States Open, falling to 88th-ranked Andreas Haider-Maurer, 3-6, 6-3, 1-6, 7-6 (4), 6-4.

headline: A Season of Wonder, and Now a Future in Doubt
text: The great thing about being a fan is that no matter how much a team lets you down — through its own fault or bad luck — you never stop dreaming. Be skeptical, be wary, but unless you believe that someday, somehow, your team could reward you, what is the point of caring?

headline: To Protect Its Empire, ESPN Stays on Offense
text: ESPN likes to call itself the Worldwide Leader in Sports, and by most every measure it is in a league of its own.

headline: The Candidates Discuss Staten Island
text: The leading candidates for mayor of New York City weigh in on how they would help Staten Island.

headline: Festival Style: Thrift and High Fashion at Afropunk
text: Thrift-store treasures mixed with high-end designer labels dominated the style scene at the ninth annual Afropunk Fest at Commodore Barry Park in Brooklyn.

headline: Neighborhood Numbers: Tottenville
text: AREA POPULATION 23,177

headline: Undecided, and Holding Little Hope, 20 Miles From City Hall
text: Frank Jerrahian, 76, a Korean War veteran inked with half-century-old tattoos of a naked woman, Jesus Christ and a parrot, spent a recent Saturday morning as he often does: shooting the breeze at a favorite local haunt, the Page Plaza Diner, a restaurant that seems notable only for its unnotability.

headline: Billabong Writes Down Its Brand Value to Zero
text: Updated, 4:02 a.m. |

headline: The Charitable Deduction, Continued
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Word of the Day | wont
text: wont •\ˈwȯnt, ˈwont also ˈwənt, ˈwänt\• noun

headline: Tomic Advances, After Nearly Four Hours and Plenty of Momentum Swings
text: Bernard Tomic plays a cat-and-mouse style of play, toying with his opponents to the point of risking a loss.

headline: Intersection: Standing Out in Chinatown
text: Residents of Chinatown in New York City, combine elements of Chinese culture with American trends to create their own looks.

headline: U.S. Open Replay: Day 1
text: Rafael Nadal, Sloane Stephens and Venus and Serena Williams were among the big winners on opening day, which was cut short by rain.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 12:15 A.M. (HBO2) IN BRUGES (2008) Two hit men (Colin Farrell, above, and Brendan Gleeson) struggle to keep a low profile in Belgium after they are ordered to stay put by their boss (Ralph Fiennes) as punishment for a botched assignment in this dark comedy, written and directed by Martin McDonagh. “Much of the pleasure of Mr. McDonagh’s dialogue comes from intonation and repetition,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “His characters tend to repeat their own and one another’s words, a device that forces you to heed both the musicality of the language and all that lies beneath those words — the oblique hopes, the implied fears, the unarticulated relationships.” She added, “He talks a blue streak beautifully, but he has yet to find the nuance and poetry that make his red images signify with commensurate sizzle and pop.”

headline: Lower House Gives Nod to Food Security Bill
text: The landmark food security bill that guarantees a legal right to food to 70 percent of India’s 1.2 billion people was ratified by a majority vote in the lower house of the Indian Parliament, or Lok Sabha, on Monday night after a protracted debate between lawmakers.

headline: News Quiz | August 27, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Foreign Couple in China Face Charges Over Business Practices
text: HONG KONG — The police in Shanghai announced the arrest of an American woman and her British husband on charges of illegally gathering personal information as part of their work advising foreign companies on investment risks and fraud in China.

headline: They Don’t Want to Become ‘Bravehearts’
text: A 22-year-old Mumbai photojournalist has become as unfortunately iconic as the young woman known as “Nirbhaya,” the 23-year-old physiotherapist student who became the rallying call to the barricades after she was gang-raped on Dec. 16, 2012 in Delhi, while returning home on a bus. A male companion proved to be no safeguard and was also severely assaulted. She later died from her injuries.

headline: Test Yourself | History, Aug. 27, 2013
text: We’ll be featuring a history question on Test Yourself every Tuesday this school year. Some will relate current events around the world to history, while others will test students’ knowledge of important past events. Let us know what you think!

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | U.S. Accuses Syria of Using Chemical Weapons
text: In the article “Kerry Says Chemical Arms Attack in Syria Is ‘Undeniable,’” Michael R. Gordon, Alan Cowell and Rick Gladstone write about the Obama administration’s accusations against the Syrian government.

headline: Mutually Insured Destruction
text: In March 1947, a winter of heavy snowfall followed by a quick thaw and torrents of rain swelled rivers throughout England and Wales. Over the course of just 13 days, at least 27,000 homes and businesses were flooded. It was one of the worst natural disasters in British history. But thanks to climate change, which can prevent the thick snowpack from which spring floods draw their strength, that sort of flood may be less likely to happen today.

headline: A Penny Picture Photographer in the American South
text: We recommend viewing this slide show in “full-screen mode.”

headline: New York Today: Candidates Take a Swing
text: At lunchtime on Tuesday, a bunch of wealthy, successful, but ultimately indoorsy people, most likely in inappropriate footwear, will try to hit a small ball with a thin stick.

headline: What to Watch at the U.S. Open on Tuesday
text: At just 22 and seeded No. 14 at the United States Open, Jerzy Janowicz may be the most exciting — and excitable — newcomer to men’s tennis.

headline: U.N. Investigators Press North Koreans to Allow a Visit
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The first United Nations panel of experts assigned to investigate North Korean human rights abuses urged the government in Pyongyang on Tuesday to allow them to visit, even as the North called their work slanderous.

headline: Momentum Builds for Military Strike in Syria
text: LONDON — Prospects for a Western-led military strike on Syria increased on Tuesday as the American defense secretary said United States forces were ready for any contingency, the British and French leaders spoke with an aggressive new tone and the Arab League joined in accusing the Syrian government of a mass killing last week with a chemical munitions attack.

headline: Sharing the Profits Requires Some Tough Calls
text: In my search to set up a profit-sharing program, I thought carefully about ways to make the plan predictable and rational. Eventually, I arrived at the conclusion that it should be based on two metrics that we could easily track: our actual costs and our actual output, measured as the value of work that we ship in a given time period. But there were still a number of thorny issues to hammer out.

headline: Student Crossword | Geography of the Middle East
text: Learn more about the geography of the Middle East by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: A Moniker Only a Mister Could Like
text: BEIJING — “Have you noticed how woman opinion leaders are being called ‘Mr.’ on Weibo?” asked my sharp-eyed friend Mei Zhang, referring to the influential Twitter-like microblogs.

headline: Film Chronicles the Inner Workings of Berkeley
text: It has taken Frederick Wiseman 45 years to get from high school to college. The master filmmaker’s latest portrait of an institution, “At Berkeley,” centers on the University of California in Berkeley and joins an extraordinary résumé that stretches back to “High School” in 1968 and his controversial debut, “Titicut Follies,” in 1967. In between, Mr. Wiseman has established himself as one of America’s greatest chroniclers in any medium.

headline: Paulson’s Misgivings on Bailout Bonuses
text: As the five-year anniversary of the white-knuckled days of the financial crisis approaches, Henry M. Paulson Jr., formerly Treasury secretary, spoke emphatically about the outsize bank bonuses paid after the bailouts. He said the bonuses were a primary reason for the public outrage over the program he worked hard to persuade Congress to pass and the country to support.

headline: ‘Billie Jean’ Twice: Jackson’s Way and as Sultry Ballad
text: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: In Performance: Sarah Lemp of ‘The Cheaters Club’
text: “The Cheaters Club,” a new play from Derek Ahonen, is a dark comedy set at a haunted inn run by a mysterious family in Savannah, Ga. In this scene, Mama, played by Sarah Lemp, talks about the ghostly happenings in Room 305. The show, from the theater company the Amoralists, opens tonight at the Abrons Arts Center, and continues through Sept. 21.

headline: Former JPMorgan Trader Surrenders in Spain in ‘London Whale’ Case
text: Updated, 8:42 p.m. | Weeks after the United States government charged Javier Martin-Artajo, a former JPMorgan Chase employee, with hiding trading losses that ultimately reached more than $6 billion, he had his first day in court on Tuesday as he surrendered to Spanish authorities and kicked off what could be a lengthy extradition process.

headline: ‘Revenge Porn’ Could Be Criminal Offense in California
text: On a recent episode of “The Newsroom,” on HBO, the character Sloan Sabbith, a financial reporter, was mortified when an ex-boyfriend posted compromising pictures of her online, which then went viral. Her recourse – on the show at least – was to track down the offending creep and punch him.

headline: Anonymous Sources on Syrian Weapons and Mayoral Politics Bring Criticism
text: Just about everybody is in agreement about the use of anonymous sources in news stories. Readers deplore it, public editors shake a finger at it, Times editors and reporters say they try to minimize it. The Times’s “Manual of Style and Usage” calls it “a last resort,” noting that anonymous sources are to be used sparingly, only when the information cannot be provided any other way, and certainly never to smear anyone.

headline: Why Walk 30 Feet When You Can Text?
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Obama Reviews His Options on Syria
text: Who is backing who into a corner?

headline: Aug. 27: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Fertility Diary: Hope Springs Eternal
text: My new fertility clinic looks like a spa: It is white and airy, with serene Muzak playing at a tasteful volume in the background. As Solomon, my husband, and I enter, we see a table offering coffee and cake, and in the center of the gray leather couches and tan chairs, a giant, mesmerizing fish tank, as if to remind us of the cycle of life (I guess they couldn’t keep rabbits).

headline: China Expands Inquiry on Graft to Oil Industry
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese Communist Party’s drive against corruption moved into the powerful and politically delicate oil sector this week, as the authorities announced that four executives of the state-owned China National Petroleum Corporation were under investigation.

headline: From Lynas to Pollan, Agreement that Golden Rice Trials Should Proceed
text: Updated below, Aug. 28, 12:14 p.m. |Mark Lynas has done the world a service in providing on-the-ground reporting from the Philippines, digging in on some vital questions related to the destruction of field trials of non-commercial, genetically modified, vitamin-fortified Golden Rice there in early August:

headline: Make It Funky: James Brown Biopic Finds Its Leading Man
text: The producers of a planned biographical film on the Godfather of Soul,  James Brown,  are feeling good — good enough to move forward with the movie now that they have an actor to play Brown and a green light from Universal on the project. Variety reported that the as-yet untitled film will star Chadwick Boseman, who portrayed Jackie Robinson  this year in “42,” as Brown, the pioneering R&B singer who died in 2006.

headline: ‘The Great Shift': Americans Not Working
text: Looking at these two charts together is a quick way to become demoralized about the American economy:

headline: Today in Small Business: Some People Are Meant to Be Employees
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Cast of ‘Bunheads’ Offers Fans a Farewell Dance
text: Paradise was regained, albeit briefly, for fans of “Bunheads.” That much-loved ABC Family series was officially canceled last month after months in renewal limbo, but much of the cast reunited recently to perform one last dance to say farewell.

headline: Reader Idea | Using Proposed Soda Ban to Introduce Viewpoints on Progressivism
text: Learn about the Progressive Era alongside the recent proposed (and defeated) ban on large sugary drinks in New York City by reading a variety of documents on both issues.

headline: A Holiday From Taxes, and Often From the Strings Attached
text: Large multinationals based in the United States – among them General Electric, Pfizer, Apple and Citigroup – have been hoarding record amounts of cash overseas, mainly because of the 35 percent tax they would have to pay if they brought it back to the United States.

headline: Seeking Compromise in Immigration Battle
text: He opposed the Dream Act. He doesn't support the Senate's immigration bill. Many are wondering how Steve Pearce, a Republican, has succeeded in a majority Hispanic district.

headline: Border Lawmaker Woos Latinos, on His Terms
text: LAS CRUCES, N.M. — Representative Steve Pearce, a New Mexico Republican, was up early last Thursday morning, tapping along to a mariachi beat and speaking what he calls West Texas Spanish.

headline: The Real Trouble With Economics
text: I’m a bit behind the curve in commenting on the Rosenberg-Curtain piece on economics as a non-science. What do I think of their thesis?

headline: Power Out Again? No Storm, but a Cloud of Suspicion
text: Amid the devastating storms of recent years, the experience has grown familiar in some corners of Long Island — fallen wires, power poles tumbling to street level and electricity that disappeared in a flash.

headline: Vermont Yankee Plant to Close Next Year as the Nuclear Industry Retrenches
text: The Vermont Yankee nuclear reactor, one of the oldest nuclear plants in the country and the subject of heated battles over the decades, will close late next year, the company that owns it announced on Tuesday, less than two weeks after winning a protracted legal fight against the State of Vermont to keep it open.

headline: Image of the Day: August 27
text: A 200-year-old gold watch was on display in an exhibition in Kolkata, West Bengal.

headline: The Plight of the Black P.O.W.
text: Anyone who saw the film “Glory” remembers the powerful closing scene in which, after failing to take Fort Wagner, members of the all-black 54th Massachusetts Volunteer Infantry and their white officers are buried together on the South Carolina beach. While the film leaves the viewer with a powerful image of the sacrifice of African-American soldiers and their white officers, it does not address the fate of those members of the 54th Massachusetts who were captured that July day in 1863. The entrance of black troops into the Civil War following the Emancipation Proclamation placed the Confederate authorities in a difficult dilemma: what to do with African-Americans in Union blues taken prisoner on the battlefield?

headline: Ex-President of Germany, Onetime Merkel Ally, to Be Tried
