text: BERLIN — Christian Wulff, a former German president and a onetime ally of Chancellor Angela Merkel who quit over allegations of accepting favors from wealthy friends while serving as a governor, will become the first former head of state in the country’s postwar history to stand trial.

headline: A New Waldorf in Ras al-Khaimah
text: One of the seven United Arab Emirates, Ras al-Khaimah calls itself a “rising emirate.” Now it has a new luxury hotel — the Waldorf Astoria Ras al-Khaimah — to support the tourism claim.

headline: When We Were Frosh
text: Many soon-to-be college students are packing up now and in the coming weeks, getting ready to move into dorm rooms with perfect strangers. That got us thinking here about our own memories of our freshman roommates.

headline: Obama Weighs ‘Limited’ Strikes Against Syrian Forces
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is considering military action against Syria that is intended to “deter and degrade” President Bashar al-Assad’s government’s ability to launch chemical weapons, but is not aimed at ousting Mr. Assad from power or forcing him to the negotiating table, administration officials said Tuesday.

headline: Headphones Combine Good Sound and Sleek Design
text: The British audio company KEF has been making speakers and studio monitors for more than 50 years, but it only recently turned its attention to headphones.

headline: Across China, Skyscrapers Brush the Heavens
text: CHANGSHA, China — China is slowing down, but the buildings keep going up — until now.

headline: An Ambitious Construction Schedule Using Prefab Modules, With Questions
text: CHANGSHA, China — The 202-story Sky City project is not the tallest building on the drawing boards around the world. That distinction belongs to the Kingdom Tower, a project in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, that is supposed to be 532 feet taller — the first building to reach a full kilometer.

headline: Forget the Punching Bag, Try the Robots
text: Battroborgs, an electronic update of the old Rock ’Em Sock ’Em Robots toy, are a lot of fun, and hardly need the hype that the marketing team for the toy has thrown at it.

headline: Cooking With a New Computer
text: Taste Largely Decides

headline: It’s Chelsea Manning From Now On in The Times
text: The Times will begin immediately to call the former Bradley Manning by her preferred name – Chelsea Manning.

headline: Why a Conservative Christian Took a Shine to Vladimir Putin
text: It used to be that the American right was staunchly opposed to Russian Big Brother oppression. It is an article of faith among Republicans that Ronald Reagan’s implacable hostility to the Kremlin brought down the Berlin Wall in particular and Soviet Communism in general. Nor are Republicans particularly keen on President Vladimir Putin, the spiritual heir of 70 years of Soviet communism.

headline: After Ackman’s Exit, J.C. Penney Remains a Hedge Fund Play
text: William A. Ackman may have severed all ties to J.C. Penney on Monday, after selling off his 18 percent stake at an estimated $473 million loss.

headline: Wheelies: The Bye Bye Bus Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: A Record Skyscraper for China
text: Work has begun in Changsha, the capital of Hunan province in south-central China, on a skyscraper that would be the world’s tallest.

headline: The Young Developer’s Guide to Debugging JavaScript
text: We recently completed our internship program here at The Times, and it’s made me wonder what I would have liked to have known when I was a young developer. The answer: I wish I’d known more about debugging.

headline: Nudged to the Produce Aisle by a Look in the Mirror
text: EL PASO — Samuel Pulido walked into his local grocery store on a sweltering day, greeted by cool air and the fantasy-world ambience of the modern supermarket.

headline: A Chef in the Field | Sungold and Heirloom Tomatoes
text: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

headline: Ickes Returns to Democratic Committee’s Rules and Bylaws Panel
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — The Democratic National Committee’s summer meeting here late last week was starkly different from the gathering of its Republican counterparts earlier in the month. There were no surefire news-making speakers like Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey or former Speaker Newt Gingrich, nor was there consideration of any made-for-cable-news resolutions, like one that tried to bar a pair of television networks from sponsoring future presidential debates.

headline: Scenes From a Wildfire Near Yosemite
text: Firefighters continue to battle a large blaze near Yosemite National Park.

headline: Vigilantism and Its Discontents
text: MEXICO CITY — On Aug. 18, during a ceremony in the public square of Xaltianguis, a town of fewer than 10,000 near Acapulco, more than 100 women — housewives, traditional doctors, traders — were handed out rifles.

headline: 10 Questions for Jacob Lew
text: Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew has been part of Washington’s fiscal battles for three decades, since he served as an aide to then-House Speaker Thomas P. O’Neill. But soon he will be the Obama administration’s point man on an unusual convergence of fronts: extending government funding past the end of the current fiscal year on Sept. 30, dealing with the so-called budget sequester and raising the federal debt limit.

headline: In Choice of Hands, Nadal Is Not Alone
text: A European player belting tennis balls on Court 7 drew onlookers to his midday practice Sunday. Sprinting to his left, he hit a topspin forehand like he had done for as long as anyone could remember. He scampered to his right and smacked a two-handed backhand that jumped off the court. He is naturally right-handed but makes his living hitting the ball primarily with his non-dominant hand.

headline: Facebook Releases Report on Government Requests
text: Facebook on Tuesday for the first time released a report showing the number of requests about its users that it has received from government agencies around the globe.

headline: Federer and Kvitova Pass First-Round Tests, but Janowicz Does Not
text: When highly ranked players begin to struggle in early matches at the United States Open, the radar goes on alert for those vulnerable to an upset, to separate them from those with mere short-term issues: perhaps getting used to the shifting winds at the National Tennis Center, fighting off nerves, or just rebounding from a particularly hair-raising car ride from Manhattan.

headline: Mets Pitching Prospect Suspended for 50 Games
text: Chase Huchingson, a left-handed relief pitcher for the Mets’ Class AA affiliate, was suspended for 50 games after a second violation for a drug of abuse under baseball’s drug program, the league announced Monday night.

headline: Bank Executive Admits to Using Bailout Money to Buy Condo
text: In November 2008, during the depths of the financial crisis, Darryl Layne Woods, a bank executive in Missouri, applied to the United States Treasury for bailout money. His bank received $1 million.

headline: U.S. Open Food Review: Heading to the Hill
text: Because eating at the United States Open is a high-stakes game, we will feature a daily review of items available at the food courts at the National Tennis Center.

headline: Q. & A.: Cassandra Clare on ‘The Mortal Instruments’
text: “City of Bones,” the film adaptation of the first book in Cassandra Clare’s young adult fantasy series “The Mortal Instruments,” opened last week. In a recent phone interview, Ms. Clare spoke about the film, her forthcoming middle-grade series, writing with Holly Black (author of “Doll Bones” and “The Spiderwick Chronicles”) and what readers can expect from “City of Heavenly Fire,” the final novel in the “Mortal Instruments” series, due  next May. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: A Tale of Two Drag Racing Legends: ‘Snake & Mongoose’
text: HOLLYWOOD — Don Prudhomme and Tom McEwen set many records while racing on the dragstrip. They probably never contemplated walking down the red carpet.

headline: First Shots Are Fired in Britain After Debate on a Badger Cull
text: LONDON — The sharpshooters came by night, with high-powered rifles and cages. Their foes came, too, with candles and masks and bright yellow slickers.

headline: Mollie Katzen Is Still Cooking
text: Even at this point in her career, Mollie Katzen still feels the need to be clearing up Moosewood myths.

headline: Trains, Not Lines, Foil U.S. Open Fans on Day 2
text: They came by car, they came by bus, they came by plane. But the tennis fans who had it worst on Day 2 of the United States Open were those who came by train. The 7 train that connects Midtown Manhattan to the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center, to be precise.

headline: Restored Film of an Ill-Fated Mt. Everest Expedition to Show at London Festival
text: A newly restored version of a film documenting an early attempt to climb Mount Everest will be shown as part of this year’s BFI London Film Festival, the British Film Institute announced on Tuesday. “The Epic of Everest,” directed by the British explorer Capt. John Noel, followed the 1924 expedition led by George Mallory, in which both Mallory and another climber, Andrew Irvine, died.

headline: From Fashion to Crashing at County Fairs
text: New York’s fall Fashion Week starts in a few days, but you won’t find me staking out Lincoln Center to steal a glimpse of a model or designer. I’ve already had my fill of runway glamour this summer, at the Cloverbud division of the 4-H Fashion Revue at the Becker County Fair in Detroit Lakes, Minn. Better yet, I didn’t have to flash press credentials: there was no security at the red-and-white striped tent. And there were plenty of places to sit — comfy bales of hay instead of chairs crammed onto risers — and watch the kids (kindergartners through third graders) show off the ensembles they’ve put together (that is, bought at the mall).

headline: Minnesota County Fairs
text: Seth Kugel winds down his summer road trip at county fairs, where livestock competitions and pig races are just part of the action.

headline: Drinking in Istanbul and Bangkok
text: Following the publication of his book “The Accidental Connoisseur: An Irreverent Journey Through the Wine World” in 2004, the English writer Lawrence Osborne was offered what was, at first, a plum assignment: being flown around the world to write about wine and spirits.

headline: Restaurant Report: Meat Mission in London
text: Forget fish and chips: London’s current culinary infatuation is with the American hamburger, with blogs and apps serving the city’s new obsession. Until recently, the high temple of British burgermania was the dark, no-reservations Meat Liquor, near Oxford Circus. But in December, its owners, Scott Collins and Yianni Papoutsis, opened Meat Mission, in trendy Shoreditch, with such diner-friendly features as reservations and enough wattage for guests to see what they are eating.

headline: At Grand Canyon, a New Mule Trip on the East Rim Trail
text: Mules, which have been transporting Grand Canyon visitors since 1887, just got a new job. Starting this week, Grand Canyon National Park’s “long-eared taxis” will start taking riders along the south rim of the canyon for the first time.

headline: Before Byrd’s T-Shirt Night, the Mets Trade Him and Buck
text: About 500 people bought ticket packages to the Mets’ game Tuesday night that included T-shirts bearing right fielder Marlon Byrd’s name and number on the back. But as fans made their way to Citi Field, Byrd’s locker in the clubhouse was being cleared out and wiped down.

headline: Hotel Review: James Royal Palm in Miami Beach
text: Rates

headline: Red Sea and Aliens Explored, Again
text: Humans are hard-wired to want answers, explanations, solutions. We can’t just accept that Jimmy Hoffa walked into an intergalactic wormhole in the Detroit suburbs and is now living somewhere in the constellation Orion; we have to keep looking for him. We can’t just dump the contents of a jigsaw puzzle box onto a table and admire the colorful chaos; we have to waste hours assembling it.

headline: Soho Rep Announces New Season
text: Soho Rep has big ambitions for its small new season. On Tuesday the downtown theater company announced it will mount two full productions in 2013-14: the New York premiere of David Adjmi’s “Marie Antoinette,” and “An Octoroon” by Branden Jacobs-Jenkins.

headline: Sudden Burst of Residential Activity in an Overlooked Slice of TriBeCa
text: The area of lower Broadway south of Canal Street in Manhattan has long been characterized by nondescript discount stores and lunchtime counters packed with city workers. It has been mostly ignored by the wave of gentrification to the west that has flooded TriBeCa over the last decade, bringing with it baby carriages, designer boutiques and restaurants.

headline: Cocky, Aggressive and Into Gangs: Meet Tokyo’s Streetwise Toughs
text: “Tokyo Waka,” a new documentary by John Haptas and Kristine Samuelson, describes itself as a “city poem,” which is certainly accurate. The film is a short, nimble consideration of the collision between the wildness of nature and the orderly bustle of modern urban life. It is also an essay on ornithology, Japanese culture and the challenges of pest control.

headline: Retro Report: Season Two Preview
text: A preview of the documentary series Retro Report, which re-examines leading stories of decades past. New documentaries will be released every Monday this fall on The Times’s Web site.

headline: A New Vintage Online Boutique Caters to the Downtown Set
text: “We do party wear, casual Sunday statement pieces and birthday outfits,” said Hally Erickson about Total Pleasure, the online vintage boutique that she and her business partner Laura Kim started last month. (Their launch event was attended by the likes of Devonté Hynes and the ATL Twins.) She described the boutique’s selection — Velvet Baby Doll Dress, Mountain Dew Pants, Snake Skin Boy Band Jacket and other somewhat seductive and playful sundries — as being comprised of pieces that “you can relax and be casual in, but there’s still an element that makes it stand out and talks to people, without being high heels and a glittery top.”

headline: Living in Dumbo, Brooklyn
text: A creative energy lends vibrancy to a neighborhood that now has enough of its own shops and parkland to rival neighboring Brooklyn Heights.

headline: At Israeli Resort Town, Ignoring the Strife to Soak Up the Sea
text: EILAT, Israel — About 100 Israelis, mostly families with young children, piled onto a glass-bottomed boat one recent morning for a two-hour cruise around the bay of this lively Red Sea resort at the southern tip of Israel. The main attractions: the underwater coral reserve, the dolphin reef and sightseeing along the border with Egypt’s Sinai Peninsula.

headline: Some Scientists Cast Doubt on Finding of Origins of a Virus
text: Since scientists announced last week that they had tracked a dangerous new coronavirus to bats in Saudi Arabia, a debate has emerged among virologists as to whether there really is enough evidence to back up the claim.

headline: After a Brush With Death, the Terror Is Still Palpable
text: Investigation Discovery’s biggest discovery has been that there is enough real-life crime to fuel an entire cable channel. Its lineup is full of tales constructed of narration by the people involved — victims, witnesses, police officers — and rickety re-enactments.

headline: Dumbo, Brooklyn: How Noir Looks When It’s Polished
text: Neighborhood lore, at least as related by an oft-cited local history, has it that “Dumbo,” an acronym for Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass, was coined in the late 1970s by a few artists hoping that an odd name would deter development.

headline: Johannsson Is Happy He Chose U.S.
text: As the United States national team prepares to resume World Cup qualifying after a successful three games in June in which it surged into first place in its regional qualifying group and then won the Gold Cup, the team received a boost with the addition of AZ striker Aron Johannsson.

headline: Slow-Smoked Texas Barbecue at Morgans, and More Restaurant Openings
text: Headliner

headline: Chemical Attack Evidence Lasts Years, Experts Say
text: Scientists have discovered that sarin, a deadly nerve agent, can be detected long after its use on the battlefield. In one case, forensic experts went to a Kurdish village in northern Iraq four years after Iraqi warplanes had dropped clusters of bombs there. The experts found a unique chemical signature of the lethal toxin in contaminated soil from bomb craters.

headline: A TV Speaker System Heard but Not Seen
text: The Niles Cynema Soundfield in-wall sound bar may not be the ultimate in home theater surround-sound equipment, but it does one thing other sound bars do not: it fits flush to the wall, with no unsightly cabinet, and has a grille that can be painted to disappear into the décor.

headline: With Disney Infinity, a Virtual Toy Box
text: When the executives at Disney conceived of Infinity, they imagined a video game that resembled a toy box: random toys could be pulled out for any adventure.

headline: How to Legitimize Intervention in Syria
text: British Prime Minister David Cameron has summoned Parliament back from summer holiday so lawmakers can discuss — and vote on — a response to the chemical attack in Syria. American lawmakers are also on recess, until next week, but it’s doubtful that they will follow Britain’s lead in returning to Washington early to take up the question of intervention. In recent years, Congress, especially the Republican-led House of Representatives, has proven so dysfunctional and riven by partisanship that it has done little legislating on even the most important issues.

headline: French Court Lifts an Environmental Ban on Mercedes-Benz Sales
text: PARIS — Daimler, the German maker of Mercedes-Benz cars, may resume sales in France after the country’s highest administrative court temporarily lifted a ban on Tuesday.

headline: Soba Noodles at Cagen, a Honey Pot for Rosh Hashana and More
text: To Admire: At His Restaurant, He Does It Himself

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, Afghanistan, Portugal and Kenya.

headline: A Simple Solution That Made a Hard Problem More Difficult
text: Congressional leaders, in their rage against ever-rising executive compensation and income inequality, have created more murkiness.

headline: Zakopalova Stays at Zero
text: The first seed to fall on Day 2 of the United States Open was No. 31 Klara Zakopalova, but it might have been an overstatement to call her defeat an upset.

headline: To Reach Out, Befriend and Kill When Necessary: An Ever Trickier Terrain
text: The wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, among other things, were stark reminders of how little Americans know about the rest of the world. A vast majority of new recruits had never left the United States before deploying for combat, and even many field commanders were clueless about the people they were expected to live among, protect and kill.

headline: Betony
text: Inside the Midtown restaurant that bears a family resemblance to Eleven Madison Park.

headline: A Testament to Flavors Clear and Pure
text: Chances are you haven’t seen a picture of the roasted chicken at Betony. If you have, you’ve probably forgotten it, because it is just a gracefully tapering triangle of meat with golden skin. A purple-stemmed dandelion leaf lies on top of it, chanterelles and Hakurei turnips huddle at its side, a pool of jus gathers around it on a bone-white plate. In the race to become the most photographed cooked bird in the history of New York, it is no threat to the one at the NoMad.

headline: Pennsylvania Museum Selling a Hopper to Raise Endowment for Contemporary Art
text: The Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts is putting up for sale a painting by Edward Hopper from its collection to start an endowment fund to buy contemporary art. The 1934 painting, “East Wind Over Weehawken,” one of two Hopper paintings the academy’s museum holds in its collection, will be sold at auction at Christie’s in New York in December with a presale estimate of between $22 million and $28 million, the academy said.

headline: In London, the Walls Have Eyes
text: “Closed Circuit,” a slick, tasty slice of late-summer nonsense from Britain, comes soaked in gunmetal blue and paranoia. The anxiety is well founded: they’re watching us. A lot — especially through the ubiquitous closed-circuit television cameras that dot London like neighborhood constables or plague sores, depending on your view of life in the surveillance state. Millions of these cameras watch over Britain, at least half of which seem as if they’d been tapped for this movie to lord down from lampposts and buildings over the little people below, including a concerned-looking yet manly Eric Bana and an equally fretful, fetching Rebecca Hall.

headline: An Anchor Who Stars in the Highlight Reels
text: After a long, troubled odyssey around the world of cable news, Keith Olbermann returned to ESPN on Monday, promising fans he would not talk about politics anymore.

headline: An Antiwar Flame That Flickered Glows Brightly Again
text: It could be both the most eloquent and rankling protest film ever made, but it has gone unseen for so long that only cinéastes and New Wave aficionados remembered to hope for its reappearance.

headline: Times Site Is Disrupted in Attack by Hackers
text: The New York Times Web site was unavailable to readers on Tuesday afternoon after an online attack on the company’s domain name registrar. The attack also forced employees of The Times to take care in sending e-mails.

headline: Arts Group Lays Off a Publicist and Co-Founder
text: The World Music Institute has laid off its longtime publicist and co-founder, Helene Browning, because of declining donations, Karen Sander, the group’s executive director, said on Tuesday.

headline: Compensation for Your Travel Troubles
text: The day I was supposed to fly from London to Newark this spring, British Airways sent an e-mail saying the flight had been canceled. When I called to rebook, the agent offered a flight two hours earlier, which meant my boyfriend and I had to drop everything and race to Heathrow. The payoff came a month later, when the airline sent a check for $787 (300 euros each), compensation for our inconvenience.

headline: Court, Faulting Police Questioning, Overturns Gun Conviction
text: Two New York City police officers had been patrolling inside a public housing building in a drug-prone neighborhood in the Bronx when they saw a young man walking down the stairs.

headline: Bidding on the Future in Queens
Mystery of the Missing Music
text: SECAUCUS, N.J. — The quest for the lost Benjamin Britten score — an orchestration of Chopin piano music he made in 1941 for the ballet “Les Sylphides” — had moved to a warehouse here.

headline: From a Whisper to a Scream, Then Right Back Again
text: On Monday night at Glasslands Gallery in Brooklyn, the eruptions came suddenly, in places you wouldn’t have anticipated them, and reshaped the room.

headline: Boehner Sees Showdown Over Raising Debt Limit
text: Speaker John A. Boehner says he is gearing up for “a whale of a fight” with President Obama over raising the federal debt ceiling, even though Mr. Obama has repeatedly said he has no plans to negotiate with Congressional Republicans over the nation’s debt limit and wants it lifted without a political showdown.

headline: Bloomberg’s Plan for Bigger East Midtown Towers Is ‘Zoning for Dollars,’ Group Says
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to encourage construction of large new office towers around Grand Central Terminal as a way of keeping East Midtown commercially competitive amounts to an illegal game of “zoning for dollars,” the City Club of New York has asserted.

headline: Gay and Lesbian Mass Wedding Held in New Mexico
text: More than 100 people lined up outside the county clerk’s office in Albuquerque to get marriage licenses Tuesday morning, the day after a state district judge ruled that same-sex marriage was legal.

headline: The United Colors of Benetton, and the World
text: Luciano Benetton, the father of the Italian sportswear label the United Colors of Benetton, embraces and encourages a multi-culti global perspective through his company’s clothes and ad campaigns, and, now, through art. “I have always been a strong believer that people may not speak to each other because of economic or political issues, but I’m pretty sure that even those countries which aren’t speaking to each other can through art,” said Benetton, who recently curated the exhibition “Imago Mundi” (“Images of the World”) at the Querini Stampalia Foundation in Venice. The show is an extension of the Venice Biennale and includes over 1,000 works from his personal collection, by artists from Australia, India, Japan, South Korea and the United States.

headline: Keeping Costs Down
text: In Maryland, where hospital fees are regulated and some hospital systems have made a concerted effort to keep patients healthier and out of hospitals, prices have increased more slowly than in the country over all.

headline: Rodriguez Quietly Reaches a Milestone, With Another in Sight
text: TORONTO — Alex Rodriguez hit his 650th home run Monday night, leaving him within sight of a remarkable milestone. With 10 more homers he will match Willie Mays, who hit 660 home runs in his 22-year career. The home run also brought Rodriguez within reach the first of a series of five, $6 million bonuses.

headline: For Long-Shot New Jersey Senate Candidate, Passion and No Filter
text: NEWARK — To start his “Expose Cory Booker” tour, Steve Lonegan stood in front of one of this troubled city’s more rundown schools this month and attacked the mayor’s record on education.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Shopping Through Tweets and All Things D’s Options
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Jets’ Goodson Will Not Contest His Four-Game Suspension
text: Jets running back Mike Goodson said Tuesday that he would not appeal his four-game suspension by the N.F.L. for violating the league’s substance-abuse policy.

headline: Researcher Controls Another Person’s Brain Over the Internet
text: Researchers at the University of Washington have successfully connected two human brains over the Internet.

headline: Bomb Syria, Even if It Is Illegal
text: EVANSTON, Ill. — THE latest atrocities in the Syrian civil war, which has killed more than 100,000 people, demand an urgent response to deter further massacres and to punish President Bashar al-Assad. But there is widespread confusion over the legal basis for the use of force in these terrible circumstances. As a legal matter, the Syrian government’s use of chemical weapons does not automatically justify armed intervention by the United States.

headline: Cano Leaves Game After Taking a Pitch Off His Hand
text: TORONTO — Through all the Yankees injuries this year, the only good news was that Robinson Cano did not get caught in the unrelenting storm. But that may have changed Tuesday after Cano was struck on the left hand by a pitch from J. A. Happ of the Toronto Blue Jays in the first inning.

headline: To Our Readers
text: Our Web site was unavailable to some users for a time on Tuesday. The disruption was the result of an external attack on our domain name registrar, and we are at work on fully restoring service. We regret if this has caused you any inconvenience.

headline: U.S. Officials Return to Pursuit of 1985 Killer of American Agent
text: MEXICO CITY — The last time Ralph Villarruel, an American drug agent, saw the notorious drug lord, he said he watched in dismay as the suspect raised a bottle of Champagne from inside a Lear jet, as if to mock the American investigators pursuing him as the plane revved up to flee Mexico.

headline: Boo Rodriguez or Cheer Him? It’s Oh So Complicated
text: Booing Alex Rodriguez has become so reflexive that it’s easy to forget what exactly we’re booing him for. Because he cheated? He’s not alone in that, certainly not in recent Yankees history and not even among his current teammates. Because he lied about cheating? Other athletes have ferociously denied allegations, and pursued their accusers, for far longer and with far more false indignation. Because, despite receiving the baseball equivalent of a death sentence (a 211-game suspension), he simply refuses to disappear? Or because in his return to action that few wanted — not Major League Baseball, certainly, or his team’s top officials — Rodriguez is actually lifting the faltering Yankees back into playoff contention?

headline: Family Sues Miami Beach in Police Taser Death
text: MIAMI — The family of an 18-year-old street artist who died three weeks ago after being shocked with a Taser by the police filed a lawsuit on Tuesday against the City of Miami Beach and its police chief, accusing officers of “unnecessary, excessive and unconstitutional force” in their apprehension of the man, Israel Hernandez-Llach, who had been seen tagging an abandoned building with graffiti.

headline: Judge Wants Narrow Focus in Apple Price-Fixing Penalty
text: Saying she wished to “intrude as little as possible” on Apple’s business, a federal judge said on Tuesday that she wanted to narrowly focus the company’s proposed punishment for illegal price fixing of e-books.

headline: Made in Lab, Fleeting Element May Join Periodic Table
text: Scientists may be adding a new element to the periodic table, but don’t expect to see it anytime soon: created in a laboratory, it exists for less than a second.

headline: Lesley Bamberger
text: Mr. Bamberger, 48, is chief executive of the Kroonenberg Groep, a Dutch company founded in 1956 by his grandfather, Jacob Kroonenberg. It is working on its first condominium project in New York, the Huys, at 404 Park Avenue South, a conversion from an office building.

headline: Where the Mayoral Candidates Stand on Key Issues
text: An examination of some of the major issues in the 2013 New York City mayoral race.

headline: Lessons in Maryland for Costs at Hospitals
text: CUMBERLAND, Md. — This hardscrabble city at the base of the Appalachians makes for an unlikely hotbed of health care innovation.

headline: Judge Denies Defense Lawyers’ Request in Fort Hood Case
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — The Army defense lawyers who used to represent Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, the military psychiatrist found guilty last week of a shooting rampage at Fort Hood in November 2009, have asked the judge overseeing his military trial here to allow them to do what he refused to do while acting as his own lawyer — persuade a jury to spare his life.

headline: Regulators Prepare Penalties for JPMorgan
text: Two federal regulators are preparing a series of enforcement actions and fines against JPMorgan Chase stemming from its dealings with consumers during the recession, presenting the latest legal threat to the nation’s biggest bank.

headline: In Fantasy and Reality, It’s a Frenzy for Football
text: THIS time of year, Madison Avenue keeps an eye on the countdown to Christmas — 119 days until, F.Y.I. — because the fourth quarter is make-or-break for many marketers. At the same time, another countdown is being calculated just as carefully: 158 days until Super Bowl XLVIII.

headline: How Dr. King Shaped My Work in Economics
text: I had the good fortune to be in the crowd in Washington when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. gave his thrilling “I Have a Dream” speech on Aug. 28, 1963. I was 20 years old, and had just finished college. It was just a couple of weeks before I began my graduate studies in economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

headline: Puig’s Popularity Reflects Growing Hispanic Interest
text: Monica Puig, a 19-year-old from Puerto Rico, was playing her first main draw match at the United States Open.

headline: Merrill Lynch in Big Payout for Bias Case
text: Merrill Lynch, one of the biggest brokerage firms on Wall Street, has agreed to pay $160 million to settle a racial bias lawsuit that wound through the federal courts for eight years, including two appeals to the United States Supreme Court.

headline: Police Stop-and-Frisk Encounters Plunged in Second Quarter of 2013, Data Show
text: The number of police stops in New York City over recent months plummeted to levels not seen in nearly a decade, back when the Bloomberg administration was just beginning to turn to stop-and-frisk tactics, according to new data.

headline: What Happened to Jobs and Justice?
text: MADISON, Wis. — ON Aug. 28, 1963, nearly a quarter of a million people thronged the nation’s capital for the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, the largest civil rights demonstration in American history. Its impact on American politics was tremendous: in addition to building support to pass the civil rights bill that President John F. Kennedy had recently proposed, marchers succeeded in strengthening and expanding the scope of the bill far beyond what the president had envisioned.

headline: The Fight for Voting Rights, 50 Years Later
text: On the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington, the country can take pride in progress made toward the guarantee of equal rights for all. Yet it is disheartening to watch the continuing battles over the right to vote, a core goal of the civil rights movement and the foundation of any functioning democracy.

headline: Legislator Who Informed on Others Admits Lying to Authorities
text: Nelson L. Castro, the former Democratic state assemblyman from the Bronx who became a government informer and secretly recorded conversations in a corruption investigation, is in trouble because of another recording — this one quite public.

headline: The Global March on Washington
text: ATLANTA — AN important but little-known episode in the story of the March on Washington unfolded on Aug. 17, 1963, in a Paris nightclub called the Living Room.

headline: Mahalia Jackson, and King’s Improvisation
text: BAINBRIDGE ISLAND, Wash. — The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s speech at the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom in 1963 was unusual among great American speeches in that its most famous words — “I have a dream” — were improvised.

headline: Look Who’s Afraid of Democracy
text: For all of China’s vaunted influence in the world, many of its top leaders are deeply fearful of losing control of their own country. This fear is reflected in their desperation to put behind them the deeply embarrassing trial of Bo Xilai, a former high-ranking Chinese official and rising political star charged with corruption and abuse of power. The trial ended Monday. It is further reflected in a memo referred to as Document No. 9, which warns of subversive elements in Chinese society and reveals how President Xi Jinping intends to silence democracy advocates.

headline: Private Manning’s Transition
text: When Chelsea Manning, formerly known as Pfc. Bradley Manning, declared that she wanted to live as a woman, the Army’s response was callous and out of step with medical protocol, stated policies for transgender people in civilian federal prisons and existing court rulings.

headline: Less Bully, More Pulpit
text: WASHINGTON — As far as inappropriate and nasty career moves go, Miley Cyrus has Chris Christie beat.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Economics as Science
text: To the Editor:

headline: Horror in Syria: What Can Be Done?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Obama’s Trade Policy
As Game Changes, Science Can Lengthen a Pitcher’s Career
text: The image of the everlasting ace, strong and sturdy, firing fastballs and churning through innings while never giving in to pain, is the exception in baseball history. The elbow injury to the Mets’ Matt Harvey, who has a partially torn ulnar collateral ligament that may require reconstructive surgery, is really nothing new.

headline: Tunisia Broadens Crackdown on Extremists
text: TUNIS — Tunisia’s Islamist government on Tuesday declared the largest radical Islamist movement in the country a terrorist organization, broadening its crackdown on Islamist extremists and distancing itself from their violent activities.

headline: Medicaid Expansion Battle in Michigan Ends in Passage
text: CHICAGO — The fierce struggle among Republicans over whether to make Medicaid available to more low-income people played out in Michigan on Tuesday as the Republican governor, Rick Snyder, narrowly succeeded in swaying enough conservative senators in the State Legislature to accept the expansion, which was part of President Obama’s health care law.

headline: President, Not Preacher, but Speaking More on Race
text: WASHINGTON — Sitting in the Roosevelt Room with prominent African-American religious leaders, President Obama on Monday mused about how far the nation had come in the 50 years since the March on Washington led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and how far it still had to go.

headline: Homemade Couscous
text: Couscous isn’t difficult to make from scratch, says chef Ron Arazi. But the process of turning semolina into a homemade pasta connects the modern chef to an ancient Middle Eastern tradition.

headline: A Best-Ranked Player for One Country Has Decided to Represent Another
text: When Tommy Haas, a 35-year-old from Germany, was told in August that no American man was in the top 20 for the first time since the ATP rankings began 40 years ago, he begged to differ.

headline: Salvadoran Linked to Killing to Serve Time in U.S. Prison
text: MEXICO CITY — A former colonel in the Salvadoran military accused of planning the killing of six Jesuit priests during that country’s civil war has been sentenced to 21 months in a United States prison for immigration violations. The sentence, handed down in Boston on Tuesday, could set the stage for his extradition to Spain, where he would be one of the few top-ranking officers to face trial in the 1989 killings.

headline: ‘The Cheaters Club’
text: Photos from the Amoralists’ production of the new play by Derek Ahonen.

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Units of Brilliance
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s terrific midweek puzzle by Erik Agard suggests an interesting question: are the salaries we pay to athletes vastly out of proportion with the salaries we pay to people who hold other positions?

headline: Digging Up a Family Tale in Graveyards
text: I staggered forth from “The Cheaters Club,” a murky swamp of a play from the Amoralists, with a dark thought reeling through my head: that infernal “True Blood” has a lot to answer for.

headline: Candidate Ran M.T.A. (He Doesn’t Dwell on It.)
text: Not so long ago, Joseph J. Lhota would swagger through subway stations with an eye toward chipped paint and trash on the tracks — an executive surveying his stock, which was, in this case, New York City’s transit system.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate
text: Recent Sale

headline: Reports of Syria Chemical Attack Spur Question: Why?
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As President Bashar al-Assad of Syria faces the increasing likelihood of an American-led missile strike, his detractors and defenders alike are asking, Why would he launch a deadly chemical attack on a scale not yet seen in his country’s civil war — as American and allied officials assert his loyalists did last week — when he seemed to be holding his own in the stalemated conflict, and just as international weapons inspectors arrived in the country?

headline: In Advent of the Smartwatch, a Name That’s Been There Before
text: TOKYO — Clunky? Perhaps. Geeky? Absolutely. But for three decades Casio Computer’s G-Shock line of digital watches has dominated a small, yet lucrative, market.

headline: The Lasting Power of Dr. King’s Dream Speech
text: It was late in the day and hot, and after a long march and an afternoon of speeches about federal legislation, unemployment and racial and social justice, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. finally stepped to the lectern, in front of the Lincoln Memorial, to address the crowd of 250,000 gathered on the National Mall.

headline: Strike on Syria Would Cause One on Israel, Iran Declares
text: Iranian lawmakers and commanders issued stark warnings to the United States and its allies on Tuesday, saying any military strike on Syria would lead to a retaliatory attack on Israel fanned by “the flames of outrage.”

headline: New Census Numbers Show Recession’s Effect on Families
text: The portion of American households made up of married couples with children under 18 fell to 20 percent from 40 percent from 1970 to 2012, the Census Bureau said Tuesday as it detailed other fundamental changes in family life.

headline: Cano Is Hit, but Soriano and Pettitte Strike Back in Yanks’ Victory
text: TORONTO — An almost inconceivable pandemic of injuries has stalked the Yankees all season, affecting almost every one of their stars and numerous backups, all except for Robinson Cano.

headline: Salmonella in Spices Prompts Changes in Farming
text: IDUKKI, India — Spices grown in the mist-shrouded Western Ghats here have fueled wars, fortunes and even the discovery of continents, and for thousands of years farmers harvested them in the same traditional ways. Until now.

headline: For James Harris, a Dream Fulfilled
text: On a Wednesday afternoon 50 years ago, a month past his 16th birthday, James Harris sat in the living room of his family’s home in Monroe, La., staring into a black-and-white television. His parents and his older sister joined him, all of them quietly attuned to the scene on the screen — throngs of people, tiny as squares of confetti, gathered in front of the Lincoln Memorial in Washington for a civil rights rally.

headline: Canvassing Central Park and Finding New Tenants
text: At the Harlem Meer, at the north end of Central Park, John Waldman, a biology professor at Queens College, found a bullhead catfish, a newly discovered species for the lake. At Turtle Pond, in the middle of the park, Russell L. Burke, a biology professor at Hofstra University, spied scores of turtles, from red-eared sliders to snapping turtles. And in the North Woods, Glenn Phillips, executive director of New York City Audubon, counted 23 bird species in the first of five forays, among them a Wilson’s warbler and American redstarts, prized fall migrants.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Arab League Stance Muddies U.S. Case
text: CAIRO — The leaders of the Arab world on Tuesday blamed the Syrian government for a chemical weapons attack that killed hundreds of people last week, but declined to back a retaliatory military strike, leaving President Obama without the broad regional support he had for his last military intervention in the Middle East, in Libya in 2011.

headline: Unscheduled Act at de Blasio Event
text: The scene was set for a classic morning of late-season campaigning: A surging mayoral candidate (Bill de Blasio) accompanied by a once-surging presidential candidate (Howard Dean), greeting potential voters in the heart of Democratic Manhattan (the 72nd Street subway station on the Upper West Side).

headline: Underdog Charges Back to Win Match, and Fans
text: As the dusk descended, and Victoria Duval continued her comeback, the crowd at Louis Armstrong Stadium seemed to evolve along with her. She began as a relative unknown facing Samantha Stosur, the world’s 11th-ranked player and the 2011 United States Open champion. By the third set, she was “Vicky” — the United States Open’s new fresh-faced darling, a 17-year-old qualifier from Haiti with the lightning quick forehands that belied her thin, goggles-wearing appearance.

headline: Preparing Gracie Mansion for a New (Live-In?) Mayor
text: A convoy of vans and pickup trucks swarmed the house on Tuesday morning, a home-repair SWAT team armed with ladders and paint brushes, scaffolding and plywood.

headline: Key Questions on the Conflict in Syria
text: The United States will debate limited options for a military strike on Syria in response to a chemical attack on Aug. 21 that the United States government says killed more than 1,400 people, more than 400 of them children. Following is a brief Q. and A. about why the United States might be headed for a new involvement in the Middle East.

headline: Late in Game, Candidates Still Hope to Connect
text: One by one, the batters came forward, though they appeared less fit than the average Yankee or Met.

headline: Russia: Security Official Killed on Highway in Ingushetia
text: Unidentified assailants killed a prominent security official on Tuesday in the troubled North Caucasus region, which has a simmering Islamic insurgency. Akhmed Kotiyev, the head of the regional Security Council for the Ingushetia Republic, and his driver were killed by automatic fire from a passing car on a highway near Nazran, the republic’s capital, Russian state television reported. Yunus-Bek Yevkurov, the leader of Ingushetia, said that Mr. Kotiyev was known for negotiating with rebel fighters to abandon the insurgency, and that he was probably killed for that reason.

headline: France: Government Proposes Changes in Pension System
text: The government of President François Hollande announced Tuesday the broad outlines of a much anticipated pension reform bill, aimed at preserving a generous but underfunded system but which is likely to be seen by some European officials as insufficient. The bill will seek to stem a $28 billion deficit with increases in withholdings from workers and employers and, beginning in 2020, a gradual increase in the pay-in time required to receive a full pension. A reform in 2010 raised the minimum retirement age from 60 to 62 and increased the pay-in time to 41.5 years; the new bill would raise the pay-in time to 43 years by 2035. Unions and company representatives said they were disappointed.

headline: Why A.C.L. Injuries Sideline So Many Athletes
text: For athletes, few sounds are more ominous than the percussive pop that can signal a ruptured knee ligament.

headline: Las Vegas Casino Settles in Money-Laundering Inquiry
text: The Las Vegas Sands Corporation, the casino company controlled by Sheldon G. Adelson, a major Republican donor, has agreed to pay the federal government more than $47 million to resolve a money-laundering investigation that cast an unwanted glare on Mr. Adelson and his gambling empire during the presidential campaign last year.

headline: Word of the Day | ordination
text: ordination •\ˌȯr-də-ˈna-shən\• noun

headline: 10 Questions for Jacob Lew
text: Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew is interviewed by John Harwood of The Times and CNBC.

headline: At 17, Croatia’s Vekic Handles Herself Like a Seasoned Player
text: It is hard to believe that Donna Vekic is only 17. The Croatian teenager carries herself with such poise on and off the court, one would think she had been on the tour for years. She is still young enough to be competing in the United States Open girls’ event at Flushing Meadows but she has never paid much attention to the junior tour. There are far bigger prizes in her sights.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
text: 10 P.M. (Discovery, Velocity) PATRICK DEMPSEY: RACING LE MANS Like Paul Newman, Steve McQueen and James Garner before him, the actor Patrick Dempsey, above, has a thing for speed, hitting the racetrack when he’s not on the set. This four-part mini-series, filmed in June, follows Mr. Dempsey and his Porsche 911 GT3 RSR team, which he owns with the Italian soccer star Alessandro Del Piero, in the 24 Hours of Le Mans, the grueling endurance race in France. In this premiere episode, Mr. Dempsey tries to strike a balance between work and what he calls his true passion while rustling up sponsorship.

headline: U.S. Sends Envoy to North Korea to Seek American’s Release
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Washington’s special envoy on North Korean human rights issues will visit that country on Friday to try to secure the release of an American imprisoned there on charges of plotting to harm the socialist country through his Christian missionary activities, the State Department said on Tuesday.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, August 28, 2013
text: “Don’t expect anybody to thank the U.S., even if it is for humanitarian reasons.”

headline: News Quiz | August 28, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Markets Sag in Asia, Reflecting Concern About the Fed and Syria
text: HONG KONG — The turmoil in Asia’s emerging economies intensified on Wednesday as potential military action in Syria fanned market anxiety and stoked oil prices.

headline: Tragic Fable of Mumbai Mills
text: If a group of men had not assaulted a 22-year-old female photojournalist, on assignment in the derelict Shakti Mills building in the Mahalaxmi neighborhood in Mumbai on the evening of August 22, her photographs would have given us images of the city’s devastated mill district.

headline: Britain to Press U.N. to Authorize ‘Necessary Measures’ in Syria
text: LONDON — As politicians here prepared to debate a possible military intervention in Syria, Prime Minister David Cameron said Britain would propose a resolution at the United Nations on Wednesday accusing the authorities in Damascus of responsibility for a chemical weapons attack one week ago and authorizing “all necessary measures” to protect civilians.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Aug. 28, 2013
text: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Snow Leopard Cub Makes Debut at Bronx Zoo
text: In the article “Almost 5 Months Old, Bronx Native Makes Zoo Debut,’” Lisa W. Foderaro writes about a new snow leopard cub at the Bronx Zoo.

headline: Britain Orders Ryanair to Slash Stake in Aer Lingus
text: PARIS — British regulators on Wednesday ordered Ryanair to slash its 29 percent stake in Aer Lingus to 5 percent, arguing that the holding gives Ryanair too much influence over the strategy of the struggling Irish flag carrier and threatens competition on routes between Ireland and Britain.

headline: 12 Minutes of Freedom in 460 Days of Captivity
text: When I describe what happened to me on Aug. 23, 2008, I say that I was taken. On an empty stretch of road outside of Mogadishu, the capital of Somalia, out of the back seat of a four-wheel-drive Mitsubishi by a dozen or so men whose faces were swaddled in checkered scarves. Each one of them carried an AK-47.

headline: Documenting Elephants’ Compassion, and Their Slaughter
text: When Michael Nichols first photographed elephants in the lowland forests of the Central African Republic in 1991, he only caught fleeting moments of them, and at great peril. These sensitive behemoths were so afraid of ivory poachers hunting them down, they thundered off at the slightest hint of human activity.

headline: Rape Trial Casts Spotlight on Offspring of China’s Elite
text: HONG KONG — A gang-rape trial that opened in Beijing on Wednesday accompanied by a blaze of local media attention has become China’s latest legal spectacle to cast attention on the lifestyles, and alleged misdeeds, of the political elite.

headline: Strike on Syria Would Lead to Retaliation on Israel, Iran Warns
text: Iranian lawmakers and commanders issued stark warnings to the United States and its allies on Tuesday, saying any military strike on Syria would lead to a retaliatory attack on Israel fanned by “the flames of outrage.”

headline: Daily Report: Casio, King of Smartwatch Field, Braces for Invasion
text: Clunky? Perhaps. Geeky? Absolutely. But for three decades Casio Computer’s G-Shock line of digital watches has dominated a small, yet lucrative, market, Hiroko Tabuchi reports.

headline: What to Watch at the U.S. Open on Wednesday
text: It has been years since James Blake was a contender at the United States Open and the J-Block rocked Arthur Ashe Stadium. But with Blake’s retirement looming, his match against the big-serving Ivo Karlovic takes on special significance.

headline: A Renewed Push for End-of-Life Discussions
text: Give Representative Earl Blumenauer, a nine-term Democrat from Oregon, credit for two things. First, a sense of humor: He began an op-ed piece he wrote for The New York Times a few years back with, “I didn’t mean to kill Grandma.” He sometimes adopts the very phrase he got slurred with in 2010, referring to himself, ironically, as “the death-panel guy,” just as the president and his administration now embrace “Obamacare.”

headline: New York Today: Commute of the Future
text: Like walking the aisles of a hardware store, browsing for cellphone apps can be a soul-elevating experience.

headline: My Favorite Mandy Moments
text: After writing about Mandy Patinkin in this past weekend’s issue of the magazine, I got to thinking about my favorite moments from his long career, and came up with three — one from the movies, one from the stage and one from TV. You can see them below, and then have a chance to weigh in with your own favorite Mandy moments.

headline: Britain to Wait on Weapons Report Ahead of Syria Strikes
text: LONDON — The prospect of an imminent Western military strike on Syrian government targets appeared to encounter a delay on Wednesday when Britain signaled it would first await the findings of a United Nations inquiry into the suspected use of chemical weapons in an attack that killed hundreds near Damascus last week, and then hold a separate parliamentary vote, which could be days away.

headline: How Many Miles Do I Need to Murder the Head of the Airline?
text: When I was 20 and knocking around Europe, I could sleep anywhere and get up feeling great. Hostels with a one-inch-thick mattress, a beach, a railroad seat, it didn’t matter — my college roommate and I, traveling on a Eurail pass in 1968, sought out night trains because that saved us the cost of a hotel room.

headline: Murray’s Affection for the Open Goes Way Back
text: Early in his career, Andy Murray frequently named the United States Open as his favorite tournament. His choice of something other than Wimbledon seemed to have a certain pointedness. Because Murray is Scottish, it was easy to wonder if there was a nationalist edge to his choice.

headline: A Web Site Tries to Convince Mattress Shoppers to Buy Online
text: While most people might guess that mattresses would be among the hardest products to sell online, Firas Kittaneh concluded otherwise. In 2006, he closed his mall retail store because it was distracting him from selling online.

headline: Student Crossword | Classic Poems
text: Learn more about classic poems by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Private Equity Said to Be Out of Running for Hong Kong Chain
text: HONG KONG – A number of private equity groups have been knocked out of the running to acquire ParknShop, the Hong Kong supermarket chain owned by the billionaire Li Ka-shing that is considering selling itself in a deal that could command $3 billion to $4 billion, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Janet Yellen’s Wealth
text: Janet L. Yellen reported investments worth at least $4.8 million in 2012, making her one of the wealthiest members of the Federal Reserve’s board of governors, according to annual financial disclosures that the Fed released Tuesday.

headline: Leftist Leaders Accused of Trying to Overthrow South Korean Government
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Agents from South Korea’s National Intelligence Service raided the homes and offices of an opposition lawmaker and other members of a far-left opposition party on Wednesday, detaining three of them on charges of plotting to overthrow the government.

headline: Advice on Addiction in Boomers, Part 2
text: Readers have been sending questions about baby boomers and addiction to Dr. Barbara Krantz, an addiction expert at the Hanley Center, a nonprofit addiction recovery center in West Palm Beach, Fla. Part 1 of her answers is here.

headline: Advice for Middle-Age Seekers of MOOCs (or Other Courses)
text: This week’s Ask an Expert features Cathy N. Davidson, a professor of English and interdisciplinary studies at Duke University, who will answer questions about how to find and use Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) and other online continuing education tools.

headline: Ron Howard Switches Gears, Again
text: Ron Howard likes to think of himself as one of those chameleon directors, like Billy Wilder and Mike Nichols, who are known not for any one thing, but rather for doing lots of things well. He has made so many different kinds of movies that he sometimes seems to be working from a checklist: a pair of whimsical comedies (“Cocoon” and “Splash”), a fairy tale (“Willow”), a holiday film (“How the Grinch Stole Christmas”), a firefighting movie (“Backdraft”), a space epic (“Apollo 13”), a biopic (“A Beautiful Mind”), a western (“The Missing”), a boxing film (“Cinderella Man”), a buddy flick (“The Dilemma”) and two Dan Brown thrillers (“The Da Vinci Code” and “Angels & Demons”).

headline: A Record Payout in Bias Case
text: Merrill Lynch has agreed to pay $160 million to settle a racial bias lawsuit that wound through the federal courts for eight years, Patrick McGeehan reports in DealBook. The payout in the suit, which was filed on behalf of 700 black brokers who worked for Merrill, would be the largest amount ever distributed to plaintiffs in a racial discrimination suit against an American employer, Mr. McGeehan writes. Merrill, which is now owned by Bank of America, also agreed to take advice from black employees on how to improve their chances of success as brokers.

headline: A Hot Summer City
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Deadly Blasts Stoke Fears of Sectarian Strife in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — In the span of roughly an hour, as the streets were choked with morning commuters and shoppers, more than a dozen explosions struck Baghdad on Wednesday, killing at least 65 people and wounding far more, officials said. It was the latest in a series of terrorist attacks that have raised new fears that Iraq is returning to the bloody sectarian violence that nearly tore the country apart in 2006 and 2007.

headline: Oxford Dictionary Decides ‘to Twerk’
text: In the days following Miley Cyrus’s much-discussed bump-and-grind performance at Sunday’s MTV Video Music Awards, the word “twerk” — that is, to dance “in a sexually provocative manner involving thrusting hip movements and a low, squatting stance” — seems to be ubiquitous. It’s on the tip of the tongue of nearly every television host, and a search of LexisNexis archives turns up the word in more than 250 news articles in the last week alone.

headline: Aug. 28: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: The Benefits of Cash Without Conditions
text: The poor are different from you and me, as F. Scott Fitzgerald might have said. They have less money.

headline: A Wild Card Begins His Education
text: Collin Altamirano got a rough initiation into the world of pro tennis on Court 11 at the United States Open Tuesday.

headline: Fandango Acquires a Rival in Movie Tickets
text: LOS ANGELES — Fandango, the fast-growing online seller of movie tickets, has swallowed a rival company that runs Hollywood Movie Money, a popular gift-certificate system that studios use to promote DVD and Blu-ray releases.

headline: Planes, Trains and Tennis (Eventually)
text: Delays on the 7 train Tuesday morning led to scenes of sweaty fans waiting on train platforms, but may have provided some relief from the long security lines that ensnared Open-goers Monday.

headline: A Digital Back-to-School Checklist
text: The days are getting shorter. The swimsuits have been put away. The football season has begun.

headline: Slawomir Mrozek, Leading Polish Playwright, Dies at 83
text: Slawomir Mrozek, a Polish dissident playwright widely considered his country’s foremost author for the stage, died on Aug. 15 at his home in Nice, France. Mr. Mrozek, who had spent much of the last half-century in exile, was 83.

headline: Israel Takes Defensive Steps as Attack on Syria Looms
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military said on Wednesday that it was taking defensive measures to safeguard the country, preparing for the possibility that Israel becomes the target of retaliation for a Western attack on Syria, and the government authorized the calling-up of a limited number of reservists.

headline: An American Tennis Extravaganza, With Few Americans
text: Arthur Ashe Kids’ Day at the U.S. Open last Saturday, a perfect August afternoon, was also a practice day for the players in the tournament, and through no particular acumen or foresight, I lucked into the best seat in the house to view the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center’s five practice courts: the top of the grandstand overlooking Court 4. As the children’s event went on down below — something with giant tennis balls and plastic cones — I leaned on the railing and gazed in the other direction, at the astounding scene on Courts P1 through P3: Roger Federer hitting with Tommy Haas, Rafael Nadal with Feliciano Lopez, Milos Raonic with Ernests Gulbis. Off in the distance, on P4 and P5, I spotted Victoria Azarenka and Agnieszka Radwanska. After a little while Andy Murray strolled onto P1 to replace Federer. The tennis was as glorious as the weather.

headline: Guardians of King’s Dream Regroup in Washington
text: WASHINGTON — “The dream is not dead,” said Dr. Alveda King, a minister and niece of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., as she walked into the Shiloh Baptist Church here Wednesday morning. “People are proving the dream is not dead. The biggest thing is love.”

headline: Figuring Out What Time Is the Right Time to Start Hiring
text: It can be challenging for Willan Johnson to know how many people to employ at his pool-cleaning business, VivoPools, in Los Angeles, for a number of reasons.

headline: Gus, the Central Park Polar Bear, Dies at 27
text: A look back at the life of Gus, the Central Park Zoo polar bear who became a media darling after reports that he was battling depression.

headline: Searching for Smugglers: A Journey Through the Mexican Desert in an O.J.-Style Bronco
text: Traveling from Southern California to Baja, Mexico, can be tricky. It’s a numbers game, really. Several robberies and even a sexual assault have received news coverage over the last several years, and the takeaway seems to be that the best way to avoid trouble is to keep a low profile. In other words, trucking south of the border in a surfboard-laden luxury pickup probably isn’t such a great idea.

headline: Today in Small Business: #Cliffgate
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: How Do You Decide When to Add New Employees?
text: It can be challenging for Willan Johnson to know how many people to employ at his pool-cleaning business, VivoPools, in Los Angeles, for a number of reasons.

headline: Farewell to Gus, Whose Issues Made Him a Star
text: There are not a huge number of ways to become famous as a polar bear. Gus somehow managed to do it by behaving like a perfectly ordinary New Yorker: he was neurotic. He became the Neurotic Polar Bear.

headline: 90 Seconds With Pogue: Parallels Access
text: The Times’s David Pogue reviews Parallels Access, an iPad app that allows a user to remotely control a desktop or laptop computer.

headline: Nintendo Cuts a Dimension From a Device Aimed at Youths
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Nintendo’s portable video game device, the 3DS, is selling well. But a plan to court children has the Japanese company cutting prices.

headline: Lower Rail Fares in Europe
text: After the summer rush, fall travel traffic to Europe tapers off, ushering in not just less-crowded museums and beaches, but rail sales too.

headline: The Key to a Truly Great Chicken Wing
text: Americans are a wing-loving people. The Buffalo variety, by most accounts “invented” at the Anchor Bar in, yes, Buffalo, is the official food of our most sacred event of the year: the Super Bowl.

headline: Reader Idea | A Manhattan Teacher Revisits Hurricane Sandy
text: This post in our Great Ideas From Readers series comes from a fourth-grade teacher in New York City.

headline: A Better Way to Bring Your Desktop to Your iPad
text: You don’t have to be a technophile to know a few things about compatibility. VHS tapes don’t play on a laptop, iPhone apps don’t run on your microwave and a CD won’t play in a toaster.

headline: Assessing the Costs of Caring for an Aging Relative
text: Faced with the high cost of in-home care, many Americans end up providing care themselves for an aging parent or relative with a chronic condition. But by doing so, you may be putting your own finances, and even your health, at risk.

headline: Malnutrition Ravages India’s Children
text: BANDRICHIWADI, India — On the morning of July 23, Shakuntala Kirkire, a housewife in Bandrachiwadi village in the western state of Maharashtra, carried her 10-month-old daughter in her arms and walked in rain down the slope of a hill on which her village stands. Her husband, Ajay Kirkire, walked close to her, holding up an umbrella to protect their sick child as they tried to reach the government-run clinic in a neighboring village.

headline: Like a Wheel, but Turning Slower
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The first thing to know about Linda Ronstadt is that if you ring the bell at her home here, on a sedate street with views of the ocean, she’ll answer the door herself. At least she did on a recent Monday morning.

headline: Mark Leibovich Talks With the Stars From ‘House of Cards’
text: If the sordid world of Washington excites you; if Congressman Frank Underwood’s salacious maneuvering on “House of Cards” shook you up; if you enjoyed the rollicking narrative Mark Leibovich delivered in his book, “This Town: Two Parties and a Funeral — Plus, Plenty of Valet Parking! — in America’s Gilded Capital,” which was excerpted in the magazine earlier this summer; then you should watch this Times Talk. The conversation, with the “House of Cards” star and executive producer Kevin Spacey, his co-star Robin Wright, the producer-writer Beau Willimon and Mark Leibovich, chief national correspondent for the magazine, was the first Times Talk to take place not in front of a live audience, but on the set of a show. Watch below:

headline: 36 Hours in the Brandywine Valley
text: The physician and poet Oliver Wendell Holmes Sr. traveled through the gently rolling hills of the Brandywine Valley in southeastern Pennsylvania during the Civil War when he came there to search for his son, who he feared had been killed in battle. It was a grim mission — and luckily, his son survived — but the land made a strong impression. “The grazing pastures were so green ... the houses were so comfortable, the barns so ample, the fences so well kept, that I did not wonder, when I was told that this region was called the England of Pennsylvania,” Mr. Holmes wrote at the time.

headline: As the Curl Turns ...(and Turns and Turns)
text: Curly-haired women like myself often recount adolescences spent yearning for sleek, straight tresses falling down their backs. But I was a child of the ’80s, a perm-crazed time when women would stop my mother and me on the street and ask of my hair, “Is it natural?”

headline: Gun Bill in Missouri Would Test Limits in Nullifying U.S. Law
text: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. — Unless a handful of wavering Democrats change their minds, the Republican-controlled Missouri legislature is expected to enact a statute next month nullifying all federal gun laws in the state and making it a crime for federal agents to enforce them here. A Missourian arrested under federal firearm statutes would even be able to sue the arresting officer.

headline: Marriage Equality in New Mexico
text: When arguing against same-sex marriage, opponents often stress that marriage has always been defined as a union between a man and a woman.

headline: An Extra Day at Telluride, Making Time for Redford, the Coens and the Zapruder Film
text: TELLURIDE, Colo. — To celebrate its 40th anniversary, the Telluride Film Festival — which devotes each Labor Day weekend to restored classics, world cinema discoveries and possible Oscar contenders — has added an extra day of screenings. This means that the festival’s lineup, a closely guarded secret, has been announced a day earlier than usual.

headline: A Short History of the Highrise
text: A trailer of an interactive documentary by Katerina Cizek, coming on Oct. 8th.

headline: Children of Israel
text: TEL AVIV — Israel likes children and it wants more of them. It has high fertility rates — the highest, in fact, of all the states in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development: almost 3 children per household, compared with an O.E.C.D. average of just over 1.7. It invests a lot of money in making fertility clinics and treatments accessible to its citizens.

headline: Listen Up | The Garage-Rock Songstress Frankie Rose Gets in Touch With Her Inner Goth
text: “Street of Dreams”

headline: Shorter Workweek May Not Increase Well-Being
text: Think a shorter workweek will make you happier? Maybe not, a new study suggests.

headline: U.S. and Switzerland Are Close to Deal on Penalizing Banks in Tax Case
text: Updated, 7:38 p.m. |  Switzerland and the United States are close to announcing an agreement to end their long dispute over how to punish banks that helped Americans evade taxes, banking and government officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Updates on the 50th Anniversary of Martin Luther King’s ‘I Have a Dream’ Speech
text: On the 50th anniversary of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s iconic “I Have a Dream” speech, thousands of people descended on the Lincoln Memorial on Wednesday. Joined by the former presidents Bill Clinton and Jimmy Carter, President Obama paid homage to Dr. King and others involved in the civil rights era. “And because they kept marching, America changed,” the president said. “Because they marched, the civil rights law was passed. Because they marched, the voting rights law was signed.” More coverage from the day’s events.

headline: Heading Into Preseason Finale, Giants’ Offense Is a Concern
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants faced fourth-and-goal at the 2-yard line late in the opening half of Saturday night’s preseason game against the Jets when Eli Manning looked for Hakeem Nicks on a fade pattern. He later estimated that he underthrew the ball by a foot, the difference between allowing Nicks to snag it for a touchdown and having safety Dawan Landry render the pass incomplete.

headline: Voices for Equality
text: A selection of speeches since Martin Luther King Jr.’s address at the Lincoln Monument on Aug. 28, 1963, that have influenced the perceptions of race in America.

headline: Homes for $625,000
text: A colonial with a surprising interior near Minneapolis, a stucco colonial in Pennsylvania and mountain views in Arizona

headline: Holidays, High and Low
text: With the start of the school year come three Jewish holidays: Rosh Hashana, Yom Kippur and Sukkot. In “What a Way to Start a New Year!” Jacqueline Jules imagines what Rosh Hashana might be like for a young family whose new year is starting in a new house in a new town. Dina, who is about 7, finds nothing is as it should be: the friends she liked to visit for the holiday are now hours away, and her home is a mess of packing boxes. “It doesn’t feel like Rosh Hashana here,” she complains. “We don’t even have a round challah.” A series of mishaps makes the phrase “What a way to start a new year!” a common refrain in the house, until a colleague of Dina’s father suggests the family join him at the temple he attends. Though the holidays are different than Dina remembers, she learns something about making friends and embracing change. Judy Stead’s illustrations, rich with festive pinks, greens and purples, are attractive and cheerful even when her characters’ expressive faces register disappointment or impatience. “What a Way to Start a New Year!” is notable in that Jules assumes a basic understanding of the holiday; making this amusing and less obviously didactic book a pleasure to read.

headline: What You Get for ... $625,000
text: ST. LOUIS PARK, MINN.

headline: Image of the Day: August 28
text: Janmashtami, a festival marking the birth of Lord Krishna, was celebrated in Guwahati, Assam, on Wednesday.

headline: Building a Bridge From Combat to Civilian Life
text: Small things kill in combat. This truism is as old as war itself, but it proved especially correct in Iraq and Afghanistan, where a new pile of dirt or the glint off a wire in the desert sun could be the sole indication that a bomb lay beneath your feet. So at its heart, military training — from the first day of boot camp to the final predeployment war game — has always really been about paying attention to details. The military knows how to turn on hypervigilance. The question is how to turn it off.

headline: Nashville Symphony Musicians Agree to Pay Cut
text: The musicians of the Nashville Symphony — which had been riding a wave of successes before the recession and a destructive 2010 flood imperiled their financial future — ratified a new one-year contract this week that will cut their pay by 15 percent.

headline: Real Estate on Grand Cayman Island
text: The market in Grand Cayman, the largest of the three-island archipelago known as the Cayman Islands, remains “tilted much in favor of buyers.”

text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

text: Courtney Solomon, the director of the thriller "Getaway," discusses an early chase sequence from the film.

headline: China Plans Its First Unmanned Moon Landing This Year
text: HONG KONG — China plans to land an unmanned exploratory rover on the moon by the end of 2013, a step forward in the country’s efforts to master the skills of space travel, the state-run Xinhua news agency reported Wednesday.

headline: Taliban Breach an International Base, Killing at Least 7
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban breached an international military base in eastern Afghanistan on Wednesday, in a complex attack that left at least one Western soldier, four Afghan police officers, and two other Afghans dead, Western and Afghan officials said.

headline: In a Subdued Land, Passion Is a Heavy Burden
text: Plenty has been written about the essential qualities of J. M. Coetzee’s novels, their severity, restraint and erudition. Martin Amis put it most memorably, if not most accurately, when he remarked a few years ago that Mr. Coetzee’s “whole style is predicated on transmitting absolutely no pleasure.”

headline: The Asian Crisis Versus The Euro Crisis
text: So, I’m feeling young again — well, middle-aged, anyway. The rupiah is plunging again!

headline: Ackman Should Stick With Heavy Industry
text: The activist investor William A. Ackman is more persuasive as an industrialist than as a shopkeeper.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Getaway’
text: How many cameras does it take to shoot a car chase sequence? In the case of the thriller “Getaway,” many more than one would imagine. In this video, the director Courtney Solomon breaks down an intricate chase scene featuring Ethan Hawke, and shot with multiple cameras mounted both inside and outside the vehicle.

headline: Abortion Rights Arithmetic
text: In case you weren’t already alarmed by the barrage of state laws and regulations aimed at curtailing women’s constitutionally protected right to an abortion, we now have a concrete understanding of their actual impact.

headline: Murray’s Victory Is Easy, but It Doesn’t Come Quickly
text: It was 9:55 p.m. Wednesday when Andy Murray finally took his first steps toward defending his United States Open title, on a soggy court, in front of a weary crowd, at the end of a very long, very trying tournament day.

headline: Death Penalty for Rampage at Fort Hood
text: KILLEEN, Tex. — Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist who admitted to killing 13 unarmed people at Fort Hood nearly four years ago, was sentenced to death by lethal injection by a jury on Wednesday, becoming one of only a handful of men on military death row.

headline: Culprit in Syrian Chemical Attack Is Unclear, China Insists
text: BEIJING — China, clinging to a longstanding policy of noninterference, said on Wednesday that it opposed military action against Syria and insisted that the truth about the chemical weapons attack against civilians last week remained unclear.

headline: Oxford Dictionaries Online Adds ‘Selfie,’ ‘Emoji’ and Other Tech-Oriented Terms
text: Selfie, phablet, emoji. A few years ago, these words held little to no meaning for most Americans. But thanks to the onward creep of new and pervasive technologies like smartphones, Facebook and photo-sharing, and communication services like Snapchat and Instagram, they have become nearly ubiquitous.

headline: Attention Helps Cyrus and Thicke Sales
text: Miley Cyrus’s rear-shaking, tongue-wagging performance at MTV’s Video Music Awards on Sunday has been widely ridiculed by the news media. BuzzFeed has devoted at least 20 posts to it (so far); even Camille Paglia put it down.

headline: New Beauty Products that Fight Sun Damage
text: Summer days at the pool and the beach make for fond memories, but the toll that the sun, salt and chlorine take on your skin and hair is something you would probably like to forget. Not surprisingly, there are several products that claim to help with end-of-season beauty woes like brown spots and brittle hair. Herein, three new choices.

text: Foraging hits the blacktop in a new lobster-themed bicycle crawl from the White Barn Inn in Kennebunk, Me.

headline: U.S. Open Food Review: Hidden Gems
text: Because eating at the United States Open is a high-stakes game, we will feature a daily review of items available at the food courts at the National Tennis Center.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: This month, short stories and novels explore troubled lives in vastly different worlds: the heartsick staff and residents of a psychiatric clinic, soldiers returning home to dead-end jobs, tigers maimed in a magical realm, and the passionate, reckless American abolitionist John Brown.

text: Former President Jimmy Carter brings up the Voting Rights Act, gun rights and “stand your ground” during his speech on the National Mall.

text: Ever wonder what became of the owl and the pussycat from Edward Lear’s famous 1870 poem? Last seen, they “danced by the light of the moon” after having been married by a turkey.

text: Premiering October 2013, “A Short History of the Highrise” is an interactive documentary that explores the 2,500-year global history of vertical living and issues of social equality.

headline: Kudos to Economix
text: The Times economics blog is now the second-most influential in the world, according to Onalytica. As I’ve written recently, even though the economics profession is deeply troubled, this is actually a golden age for real-time economics discussion.

text: In his commemoration of the “I Have a Dream” speech, the 42nd president noted contemporary debates over gun rights and voting laws.
