Regrettably, their eyes did not wander to our table, where summery dishes were arrayed like so many luminous seashells: grilled octopus on a bed of wilted, garlic-strewn escarole; red and golden beets crowned with crescents of fresh orange; chunky red tomatoes and slips of purple onion tossed in a oregano-flecked vinaigrette; and fresh sardines cradled in endive leaves. As they turned to leave, having decided to try their luck elsewhere, my impulse was to jump up and tell them to stay.

headline: Family Problems With Delicate Solutions
text: Among the Yoruba of Africa, said Andrew Dosunmu, the Nigerian-born director and photographer, uncles are held in special regard. “If my uncle walks in here,” he said over lunch in Brooklyn, “I introduce him as my dad, because he’s responsible for me if my father’s not around. Your uncle is the same as your dad. The idea is, it’s the same blood, and there’s an obligation.”

headline: In Thailand, Rubber Price Plunge Has Political Cost
text: KHUAN NGOEN, Thailand — The rubber farmers of southern Thailand are inured to hardship, whether from the toilsome predawn harvests in mosquito-infested plantations or the vagaries of the market for their latex. But this month, they snapped.

headline: One Great Big War
text: What’s the biggest threat to world peace right now? Despite the horror, it’s not chemical weapons in Syria. It’s not even, for the moment, an Iranian nuclear weapon. Instead, it’s the possibility of a wave of sectarian strife building across the Middle East.

headline: An East End Study in True Beach Living
text: It was one of those late summer Saturdays when the air carries a slight chill and a hint of dread; the end of the season could no longer be denied.

headline: The Face Scan Arrives
text: WASHINGTON — THE future of technological surveillance is fast approaching — and we are doing far too little to prepare ourselves.

headline: Gotham’s Towering Ambitions
text: FOR much of the last century, New York City has been the financial, cultural, media, retailing and fashion capital of not just the country but the world. Yet the great Hudson River metropolis is in danger of losing that status because of a growing local attitude that favors the old over the new, stability over growth, the status quo over change and short buildings over tall ones.

headline: Facebook Post Said to Be by Assad’s Son Dares Americans to Attack
text: A Facebook post said to be written by the 11-year-old son of the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, and “liked” or commented on by several people who appear to be the children and grandchildren of other senior members of Mr. Assad’s government, may offer a glimpse into the mindset of Syria’s ruling elite as the country braces for a potential Western strike in response to a chemical weapons attack on Aug. 21.

headline: In New Wave of Walkouts, Fast-Food Strikers Gain Momentum
text: As a wave of one-day walkouts by fast-food workers gains momentum in a push for a $15 hourly wage, the movement has been notable both for the prominence of young faces and for the audacity of their demand.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Some Good News for the Yankees: Nunez’s M.R.I. Is Negative
text: The Yankees said the magnetic resonance imaging test on Eduardo Nunez’s right knee came back negative Thursday, a morsel of good news in what is turning into a frustrating season. Nunez, who twisted his knee on the turf in Toronto on Tuesday, is listed as day-to-day. He was not able to play Wednesday, nor was the regular second baseman Robinson Cano, who was hit in the left hand with a pitch Tuesday.

headline: Determined Romanian Women Finding Success
text: Simona Halep has recently been best known as the player who ended Marion Bartoli’s career, bringing the Wimbledon champion to tears after defeating her in Cincinnati.

headline: The Unsaved World
text: The rupiah is falling! Head for the hills! On second thought, keep calm and carry on.

headline: E-Cigarette Makers’ Ads Echo Tobacco’s Heyday
text: Electronic cigarettes may be a creation of the early 21st century, but critics of the devices say manufacturers are increasingly borrowing marketing tactics that are more reminiscent of the heady days of tobacco in the mid-1900s.

headline: Cracking Down on Predatory Payday Lenders
text: The predatory industry known as payday lending is finally feeling the bite of state authorities alarmed that low-income borrowers are being gouged into long-term debt running at impossible interest rates of 500 percent and more.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 30, 2013
text: “Once you realize you’re not going to die or get covered in toxic sludge, it’s pretty relaxing.”

headline: Looming Airstrikes in Syria Pose Test for Egypt’s Leaders and the Opposition
text: CAIRO — Egyptians on Thursday braced for the ninth weekend of protests against the military’s ouster of the country’s president as the looming possibility of Western airstrikes against Syria injected a new element of volatility onto the streets.

headline: Statehouse Swagger in the Gun Debate
text: As a measure of the gun culture’s dangerous sway over statehouse politicians, it is hard to top the pending proposal in Missouri that would pronounce all federal gun safety laws null and void in the state and allow the arrest of federal agents who try to enforce them.

headline: In Losses, Blake Still Controls Exit
text: Two and a half days after he had announced his career was ending, James Blake found himself saying goodbye Thursday just after midnight, giving an emotional on-court interview after his loss in a fifth-set tiebreaker in his first-round match against Ivo Karlovic.

headline: Protesters Demand Montana Judge Resign Over Rape Sentencing
text: Angry that a Montana judge sentenced a former teacher who had admitted to raping a 14-year-old student to only a month in jail, several hundred people gathered outside the Yellowstone County Courthouse in Billings on Thursday, demanding that the judge resign. The victim committed suicide three years after the rape, just before her 17th birthday.

headline: Retracing a Long and Winding Road
text: There are places Freda Kelly will remember all her life — sights she saw and experiences she gained as the secretary to the Beatles, their fan club and their manager, as well as a friend and trusted confidante of John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison and Ringo Starr for nearly the entire duration of their history-shaping rock group.

headline: Settlement Is Given a Mixed Reception
text: When news circulated Thursday that the N.F.L. had agreed to pay $765 million to settle a concussion lawsuit, it was met with mostly positive reactions from some family members of players involved in the suit.

headline: When Money Shouts
text: A tsunami of outside political money is cresting and crashing on the New York City primary election. The debris is all around: glossy leaflets, harsh TV ads, robocalls and pseudo-grass-roots events like the rally Wednesday in Greenwich Village denouncing the City Council speaker, Christine Quinn, who is running for mayor. The event was sponsored by a group called NYC Is Not for Sale, a creation of one union boss and two wealthy business executives, who have channeled their antipathy — and about $1.4 million — into an all-negative campaign for the notional candidate they call Anybody but Quinn.

headline: In Trial Account, Chinese Ex-Official Strays From Script
text: BEIJING — In secret remarks on the final session of his trial, Bo Xilai, the fallen Communist Party star, denied on Monday that he had tried to upset the party’s selection of top leaders or grab extensive new powers for himself, according to a court observer’s written record of his closing statement.

headline: Law Banning ‘Gay Cure’ Is Upheld in California
text: LOS ANGELES — A federal appeals court on Thursday upheld California’s ban on therapies that aim to change the sexual orientations of gay and lesbian minors.

headline: Modern Mouse Hole
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Here’s a Friday-level word for you: EGERIA.

headline: Corrections: August 30, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: JPMorgan Hiring Put China’s Elite on an Easy Track
text: The program was originally called “Sons and Daughters.” And although it was supposed to protect JPMorgan Chase’s business dealings in China, the program went so off track that it is now the focus of a federal bribery investigation in the United States, interviews and a confidential government document show.

headline: Should Students Live on Campus or Off?
text: Is a dormitory worth the expense? Would living elsewhere mean missing out on the "college experience"?

headline: Gus, the Captive Polar Bear
text: To the Editor:

headline: Airplane Noise in Queens
text: To the Editor:

headline: The High Turnover at Charter Schools
A Challenge to Christie
text: To the Editor:

headline: Theology and Civil Rights
text: To the Editor:

headline: Democrats See Value in Texas in Candidacy for Governor
text: FORT WORTH — Early this month, Wendy Davis, the unknown Texas state senator who rocketed to fame this summer with her 11-hour filibuster to block an anti-abortion bill, met with strategists of the Democratic Governors Association at their K Street offices in Washington. They were urging her to run for governor next year, even though Texas is not among their realistic targets for flipping a Republican-held executive mansion.

headline: California: Veterans Center Lease Ruled Illegal
text: Judge S. James Otero of Federal District Court ruled Thursday that the Department of Veterans Affairs violated federal law in leasing for commercial use parts of its campus in West Los Angeles. The ruling was in response to a class-action lawsuit on behalf of four homeless veterans, who objected to the lease when homelessness among veterans was high. Judge Otero ruled that Congress permitted such lease agreements only if the property was going to be used to provide health or other services for veterans. The campus has been leased for, among other things, a laundry for a luxury hotel.

headline: Massachusetts: Ex-Official Refunds Contributions
text: Former Lt. Gov. Timothy P. Murray on Thursday agreed to refund $50,000 and pay a $30,000 fine to settle accusations that he accepted illegal campaign contributions. Attorney General Martha Coakley said Mr. Murray received $50,000 in contributions illegally solicited by two public employees. One of them, Michael McLaughlin, an ex-housing official serving a three-year sentence for lying about his income to federal authorities, was indicted Thursday on charges of unlawfully soliciting campaign contributions from state employees.

headline: Massachusetts: Bomb Suspect’s Classmate Charged
text: A classmate of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the Boston Marathon bombing suspect, was indicted Thursday on two counts of making false statements during the investigation. The man, Robel Phillipos, 19, is accused of concealing from investigators the fact that he accompanied two of Mr. Tsarnaev’s other friends, Dias Kadyrbayev and Azamat Tazhayakov, to Mr. Tsarnaev’s dormitory at the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth days after the bombing. Investigators say that the men removed items including a laptop and a backpack, and that Mr. Kadyrbayev disposed of the backpack. Mr. Phillipos could face up to eight years in prison on each count and a $250,000 fine. Mr. Kadyrbayev and Mr. Tazhayakov have been charged with obstruction of justice.

headline: 2 Guantánamo Detainees Transferred to Algeria
text: The Pentagon announced on Thursday that it had transferred two Algerian detainees from the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to their native country. The two men, Nabil Said Hadjarab and Mutia Sadiq Ahmad Sayyab, who have spent more than a decade incarcerated without charges, were the first detainees to leave the prison since President Obama renewed his pledge to close it in May.

headline: Survivor of Back Woes Soldiers On
text: NORTON, Mass. — Tiger Woods’s back woes dominated the news on the eve of the $8 million Deutsche Bank Championship. Fifteen of the 24 questions he fielded on Thursday — and 12 of the first 14 — concerned his back, which bothered him last weekend at the Barclays in Jersey City.

headline: U.N. Leader Urges Obama to Hold Off on a Strike
text: Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general of the United Nations, cut short a European trip and rushed home on Thursday to prepare for a weekend briefing by his team of chemical weapons inspectors on the ground in Syria. He implored President Obama to refrain from a threatened military strike and to allow the procedures enshrined in the United Nations Charter to take their course.

headline: A Resident Shocks a Small Town
text: Paul Craig Cobb, 61, has been buying up property in an effort to transform Leith, N.D., into a colony for white supremacists.

headline: Frank Pulli, First Umpire to Use Replay, Dies at 78
text: Frank Pulli, who in 1999 became the first major league umpire to use instant replay to verify a call, nearly a decade before the league approved the practice, died on Wednesday at his home in Palm Harbor, Fla. He was 78.

headline: Astor’s Son Was Contrite Ahead of Release From Prison
text: After declining to speak at his trial or sentencing, Anthony D. Marshall was recently given one more chance to express remorse for stealing millions of dollars from his mother, the philanthropist and socialite Brooke Astor, in her waning years.

headline: Rival Speaks of Booker’s Sexuality, Leading to Charge of Homophobia
text: The New Jersey Senate race has lacked much in the way of drama, with Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark, a Democrat, holding a commanding lead in the polls against the Republican nominee, Steve Lonegan.

headline: Monfils Wins Crowd by Charming It, but Isner Takes the Match by Force
text: The highest-seeded American male at the United States Open, John Isner, left the court after the third set of his second-round match Thursday to resounding cheers for his opponent, Gaël Monfils.

headline: Rules Trickle Down; Money in Settlement Won’t
text: When more than 4,000 retired players agreed to accept $765 million to settle their lawsuit with the N.F.L., the league was able to cling to its most valuable claim of all — that it never ignored or obscured the risks of concussions.

headline: Sathima Bea Benjamin, Jazz Singer and Activist, Dies at 76
text: Sathima Bea Benjamin, who as an internationally recognized jazz singer became both an ambassador for her South African homeland and a beacon of principled objection to apartheid, died on Aug. 20 at her home in Cape Town. She was 76.

headline: Bruce C. Murray, Who Helped Earth Learn of Mars, Dies at 81
text: Bruce C. Murray, a planetary geologist who won his spurs interpreting findings of early missions to Mars and who led NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory through a time of flagging support for new flights in the late 1970s, died Thursday at his home in Oceanside, Calif. He was 81.

headline: History as a Guide in Syria
text: Analysts looking for historical parallels to the current situation in Syria say that past military engagements seen as successful have tended to have limited and clear objectives.

headline: Powerful Forehand Propels Sock at Open
text: Jack Sock’s forehand is best described as a windshield wiper stuck on double speed.

headline: Giant Breaks Left Leg Again
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — The sight of Andre Brown limping off the field in the first half was troubling for the Giants. The announcement in the second half that he had broken his left leg — again — was potentially devastating.

headline: The Mayoral Candidates on the Parks
text: The parks system in New York City expanded and — many would argue — flourished under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, with the creation of nearly 800 acres of new parkland, reclaimed stretches of waterfront and myriad park renovations.

headline: The Mets, Brought to You in ...
text: The Mets are headed for their fifth straight losing season, with no guarantee the streak will end in 2014. Their captain and best everyday player, David Wright, has been sidelined with a hamstring strain for nearly a month. Their best pitcher, Matt Harvey, has gone from Cy Young Award candidate to someone who may soon need Tommy John surgery. He might not pitch again for a year.

headline: Teenage Qualifier Shows Her Potential, and Age, in a Second-Round Defeat
text: They cheered and shouted her name before she took out her racket. When Victoria Duval made her appearance at the United States Open on Thursday, the fans wanted America’s newest tennis darling to continue her magic, to jump joyfully in the air as she did Tuesday and make an impressive landing in the third round.

headline: Michael Voltaggio’s Gutsy Food Adventure in Copenhagen
text: Earlier this week, the brothers Michael and Bryan Voltaggio, American chefs and former “Top Chef” contestants, traveled to Copenhagen for the third MAD Symposium, an annual food festival that brings together chefs and farmers. Curated by David Chang and his Lucky Peach team, this year’s two-day sold-out symposium was dedicated to guts — meaning both innards and courage. Chang introduced the theme literally, however, by bringing out the butcher Dario Cecchini, who proceeded to carve a pig on the stage. Between events, Michael, the chef and owner of Ink in Los Angeles, and Bryan, the executive chef of Volt restaurant in Maryland, caught up with fellow chefs and friends. Here, Michael shares his photos from the event.

headline: The Central Challenge in U.S. Health Policy
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Word of the Day | mishap
text: mishap •\ˈmis-ˌhap, mis-ˈ\• noun

headline: Jets Backups Make Final Push for Roster Spots
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It was fairly easy to identify the division on the Jets’ sideline Thursday night. The players wearing baseball caps or team-issued workout gear had secured roster spots. Those still competing for roles, or promotions on the depth chart, held their helmets or wore them.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 10 P.M. (Discovery) ALASKA STEEL MEN From repairing a hull underwater in frigid seas to sealing a cracked vessel that has struck ice, there is no nautical task that Dennis Butts; his wife, Theresa; and their crew of welders and pipe fitters at Quality Marine in Kodiak, Alaska, aren’t willing to try. “No matter how tough you are, Mother Nature is tougher,” Mr. Butts says in this new three-week series. “We’re talking boats sinking to the bottom of the ocean. You make a mistake, people die.”

headline: Walk-On Ritual
text: West Virginia’s annual tryout for football walk-ons draws roughly 80 students seeking one of about five spots. Even those chosen are unlikely to see any game action.

headline: News Quiz | August 30, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/Siena College poll of New York City consisted of telephone interviews with 1,561 adult residents throughout the city conducted Aug. 19 to Aug. 28. Of these residents, 1,162 said they were registered to vote.

headline: Stringer and Spitzer Seek Votes of Women
text: With polls showing widely different results in the race for comptroller, Scott M. Stringer and Eliot Spitzer vied for leadership on women’s rights.

headline: Democratic Voters on the Candidates
text: The New York Times and Siena College asked likely voters in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary for their opinions on the candidates for mayor and comptroller.

headline: Leading Democrats, de Blasio Has Broad Support as Primary Nears
text: Frustration with New York City’s unaffordability and its aggressive police tactics is elevating Bill de Blasio, once dismissed as a left-leaning long shot, into the lead of the Democratic mayoral primary field, according to a poll by The New York Times and Siena College.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 7 Mourners in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber pretending to be among the people receiving guests at a mourning ceremony in northern Afghanistan on Friday detonated his explosive and killed at least seven people, including the local district governor, according to the governor’s spokesman.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Aug. 30, 2013
text: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | A Tour of Graffiti Art Around New York City
text: In the article “A Feast of Urban Scrawl, Luminous and Legal,” Randy Kennedy provides a guided tour of what he considers to be the best graffiti art around New York City.

headline: The Amazon, Through an Anthropologist’s Eye
text: Nicolas Janowski lives in Buenos Aires, one of the most cosmopolitan cities in South America. But in recent years he has spent as much time as he can traveling around a region that is about as different from his home town as can be imagined — the western reaches of the Amazon, with its dizzying and imposing mix of jungle, rivers, mountains and savannah extending over Bolivia, Ecuador and Peru.

headline: America Movil Threatens to Pull Bid for Dutch Cellphone Operator
text: LONDON — The Latin American telecommunications giant América Móvil threatened on Friday to walk away from its proposed bid of 7.2 billion euros, or $9.5 billion, for the Dutch cellphone operator KPN after a local foundation moved to block the takeover.

headline: U.S. Releases Detailed Intelligence on Syrian Chemical Attack
text: PARIS — Seeking to move beyond Britain’s blindsiding rejection of military intervention in the Syrian conflict, the Obama administration received strong support from France on Friday and released a detailed intelligence summary to buttress its contention that the Syrian government used chemical munitions in an Aug. 21 attack, asserting for the first time that it had killed 1,429 people, nearly a third of them children.

headline: New York Today: Summer’s End
text: It’s the last weekday of what is, unofficially, the last week of summer.

headline: A Preview of  Retro Report’s Season Two
text: After a summer hiatus, our weekly online video feature, Retro Report, has returned with a fresh look at one of the biggest stories of the summer of 1988, the unsuccessful attempts to control wildfires that burned through Yellowstone National Park for months.

headline: Look, It’s a Trabant, It’s an El Camino. It’s the Trabantimino.
text: The town of Española, N.M., bears the nickname, “The Lowrider Capital of the World.” Each summer, the town holds the annual MainStreet ShowDown, a lowrider show sponsored by Lowrider Magazine that draws several hundred cars to compete for top honors.

headline: What to Watch at the U.S. Open on Friday
text: After spending most of her career chained to the baseline, Li Na has suddenly fallen in love with the volley.

headline: Number of Jobless People Declines Slightly in Europe
text: PARIS — While unemployment remained at record levels in percentage terms, the actual number of jobless people in the euro zone fell slightly in July, according to data published on Friday, offering fresh evidence that Europe’s struggling economy was taking tentative steps toward a recovery.

headline: A Top Banker’s Image, Clouded
text: FRANKFURT — During a long career that took him to the top of the European banking world, the Swiss executive Josef Ackermann has survived countless boardroom intrigues and even a criminal prosecution.

headline: Daily Report: Start-Ups That Could Be the Next Big Thing
text: When it comes to technology start-ups, there are a lot of paths to success, Jenna Wortham reports.

headline: China Brokerage Firm Fined $85 Million Over ‘Fat-Finger’ Trades
text: Updated, 11:51 a.m. |

headline: Seamus Heaney, Irish Poet of Soil and Strife, Dies at 74
text: Seamus Heaney, the 1995 Nobel laureate in literature, who was often called the greatest Irish poet since Yeats, died on Friday in Dublin. He was 74.

headline: India’s Lower House Passes Land Acquisition Bill
text: NEW DELHI— In the footsteps of the passage of the food security bill earlier this week, India’s lower house of Parliament, the Lok Sabha, passed the populist land acquisition bill on Thursday with an overwhelming majority.

headline: JPMorgan’s ‘Sons and Daughters’ Program
text: AT JPMORGAN, A PROGRAM TO HIRE CHINA’S ELITE  |  JPMorgan Chase started a program in 2006 called “Sons and Daughters,” as friends and family of China’s ruling elite were clamoring for jobs at the bank, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook. Although it was originally supposed to protect the bank’s business dealings in China, it went so off track that it is now the focus of a federal bribery investigation in the United States, according to interviews and a confidential government document.

headline: Why We Fight Terrorism
text: Film lovers in Pakistan have for a while been writing obituaries about Lollywood, the country’s film industry, named after the city of Lahore where it is based. At its peak in 1968, the industry released 128 films in one year; last year, only five new local films hit the cinemas.

headline: Hot Night on a Slow Bus
text: Dear Diary:

headline: God, She Said, Went ‘Gotcha,’ but Their Marriage Got Stronger
text: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Today in Small Business: Optimism!
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: The Making Of | A Restaurant in Harlem Where Everything Old Is New Again
text: We can all agree on the value of reuse, repurposing, recycling, upcycling. But too often in interior design projects, these processes are treated as ends rather than means, with results that are usually more earnest than elegant. At Vinatería, a Harlem restaurant that opened in April, almost every material has had a previous life (or lives), but that’s not what you notice about the room. Instead, you see a subtle layering of color and form and sophisticated details. Yes, the design is environmentally friendly. But above all, Vinatería is chic.

headline: The Baht and the Bubble Excuse
text: Kevin O’Rourke has been saying for a while that it’s useful to think of Ireland as “Thailand without the baht“. In this context, the history of the Asian crisis sheds some light on one of the ways defenders of European austerity policies move the goalposts: by claiming that the pre-crisis peak isn’t relevant for comparison purposes, because it was inflated by a bubble.

headline: The Advantages of Being Asaram Bapu
text: Asumal Sirumalani, a popular Indian spiritual leader who is known to his followers as Asaram Bapu, has fought a long battle against sex.

headline: The Gold Mine in the Hall
text: Now is the season for management companies to begin assembling next year’s budget for their co-op and condo clients. And guess what, folks: your maintenance is going up.

headline: It’s a Madhouse: Winner Declared in Chimpanzee Art Contest
text: How much more like humans can chimpanzees be? They share what is believed to be more than 90 percent of our DNA, they seek to express themselves creatively and when they win prestigious art contests they can’t be bothered to get on the phone to express their gratitude.

headline: The Cadillac Elmiraj Concept: A Little British, a Little French, a Lot American
text: Sometimes, getting at the essence of something involves taking a step back, approaching from a fresh angle. Perhaps that’s what happened at Cadillac when the sleek Elmiraj concept was created. Its designers are an Englishman and a Frenchman, but they seem to have been very focused on the best facets of American design.

headline: Fantasy Football: When to Take a Chance on Injury-Prone Players
text: It’s a fantasy football dilemma every season: if, and when, do I take a chance on those talented players who never seem to stay healthy? If you time these picks right, it could give you a major advantage in your league. If not, you could be in for a very long season.

headline: ‘Hurricane Marco Rubio’ – A Winning Climate Campaign?
text: Climate campaigners seem to think they have a winner with this takedown of elected officials who reject global warming science, in which fake news reports talk of the turmoil and tragedy created by Hurricane Marco Rubio, Hurricane James Inhofe, Hurricane John Boehner and more.

headline: Aug. 30: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
text: Tattoos Cause a Bridal Party Problem

headline: Pynchon’s Gravitational Pull
text: In an essay in the September issue of Harper’s, Jonathan Franzen quotes — at what he concedes is “embarrassing length” — from letters he sent to his fiancée when he was 22. “I recognize Pynchon as my major precursor,” the young, besotted Franzen wrote. “The better he is the more I want to hate him but the less I can.” In an interview with The Paris Review in 2010, Franzen described discovering “Gravity’s Rainbow”: “It was like getting the flu to read that book. It was like I was fighting off some very aggressive infection.” He wrote to his then-fiancée: “I’ll get over Pynchon somehow. Maybe through criticism, some discontinuity, some dialectic, that will enable me to forget him.” His future wife proved a stronger motivation than any dialectic. About his “Pynchonian” love letters, Franzen told The Paris Review, “I think it’s significant that she hated those letters and made her hatred of them known, and that I steered away from that voice.”

headline: Stay of Execution
text: Furman v. Georgia is among the oddest Supreme Court cases in American history. Decided in 1972, it struck down every death penalty statute in the nation as then practiced without outlawing the death penalty itself. The ruling, based on the constitutional protection against “cruel and unusual punishment,” stunned even the closest court watchers. The death penalty seemed impregnable. It was part of the bedrock of America’s legal system, steeped in the intent of the founders, the will of most state legislatures and the forceful — if occasional — rulings of the courts.

headline: Paperback Row
text: INSIDE SCIENTOLOGY: The Story of America’s Most Secretive Religion,  by Janet Reitman. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $15.95.) This is a meticulous history of the Church of Scientology, from its birth as a 1950s self-help system in the science fiction imagination of L. Ron Hubbard (1911-86) to its current status as a worldwide movement. Reitman, who spent five years piercing the walls Scientologists put up against outsiders, has rendered what our reviewer, Garry Wills, called “the most complete picture of Scientology so far.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE SMARTEST KIDS IN THE WORLD: And How They Got That Way,  by Amanda Ripley. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) A look at countries that are outeducating us (Finland, South Korea, Poland) through the eyes of American high school students abroad.

headline: Arbor Day
text: To the Editor:

headline: Southern Discomfort
text: “Tell about the South,” his Harvard classmates beseech Quentin Compson in “Absalom, Absalom!” You’ll notice he doesn’t have to be asked twice. Sensitive Southerners — and Southern writers most of all — seem to love nothing better than explaining themselves and their region to outsiders (or to themselves, if no outsider is handy). There are exceptions, though, and Wilton Barnhardt would stand at the head of any list: though born and reared in the South, he has, over the last two decades, produced three well-regarded novels that almost never stray south of the Mason-Dixon line. There ought to be a prize for such forbearance. Or maybe he was just biding time, stockpiling ammunition. Because at long last he has tackled the South head on. Lacerating but affectionate, as exuberant as it is shrewd, “Lookaway, Lookaway” is a Southern novel so sure-footed the only real question for Barnhardt is, “What took you so long?”

headline: His Favorite Wife
text: I’ve often wondered what it takes to be the wife of a captain of industry. What combination of boundless optimism and self-delusion is necessary to live with someone whose real lover is his work, who cannot turn off his competitiveness when he walks through the door, whose wealth means his opportunities and temptations with women are somewhere between “a lot” and “infinite,” and whose children and wife exist as a beautiful backdrop to what he considers his real accomplishments?

headline: Island Magic
text: At first, I resisted what appeared to be the fablelike delicacy of ­Edwidge Danticat’s new novel, “Claire of the Sea Light.” Was it going to be too precious? Would her lyricism camouflage or ennoble Haiti’s life-or-death struggles? But it quickly became apparent that her hypnotic prose was perfectly suited to its setting, the tragic and yet magical seaside town of Ville Rose.

headline: Will the Mile-High Club Shut Down?
text: The first college Meh List; Mario Batali’s Labor Day drink recipe; how Eric LeGrand stayed positive after paralysis.

headline: There Are No Sound Moral Arguments Against Performance-Enhancing Drugs
text: The argument against performance-enhancing drugs in sports is that the drugs give players an unfair advantage. But how do P.E.D.’s differ from Tommy John surgery? Or pre-emptive Tommy John surgery? What about rich kids? Is their access to superior coaching, facilities and equipment a similarly unfair advantage? In a society that embraces plastic surgery, Botox injections, Viagra and all kinds of enhancements, what moral line do P.E.D.’s cross? LYNN MOFFAT, SLEEPY HOLLOW, N.Y.

headline: Two (Sucked) Thumbs Up
text: A year ago, on the day my wife, Liz, would give birth to our first child, we sat down to watch “The Avengers.” She’d already seen it, and it wasn’t something I was particularly dying to see — superhero movies aren’t usually my thing. My cinematic taste generally tends to the somewhat obscure and the challenging — I’d much rather rewatch anything by Rainer Werner Fassbinder than sit through any of the “Fast and Furious” sequels. But Liz had started to feel the fluttering of early labor, and our birth-class instructor had advised us that this particular stage could last for several hours. The best thing to do, she said, was find a distraction: go for a walk, play cards or watch a dumb movie. As it turned out, there wasn’t going to be a need for any distractions. Within minutes, that fluttering became what Liz described, with some understatement, as cramps. What followed was such an incredibly compressed labor that there’s actually a special name for it: precipitous labor, which happens less than 3 percent of the time. Our son, Jack, was born an hour and a half later, at home, in our bed. I still haven’t seen “The Avengers.”

headline: Googling Yourself Takes on a Whole New Meaning
text: Here’s what you see if you look at my face: a skinny titanium headband stretched across my forehead. It looks like a futuristic pair of sunglasses, minus the lenses. On my right-hand side there’s a computer, a metal frame with a small, clear cube of plastic perched just over my eye. When I tilt my head upward a bit, or run my finger along the side of the frame, the cube lights up. What I see, floating six inches in front of me, is a pinkish, translucent computer screen. It gives me access to a few simple apps: Google search, text messaging, Twitter, a to-do list, some hourly news headlines from CNN (“See a Truck Go Airborne, Fly Over Median,” “Dolphin Deaths Alarm Biologists”). Beside the screen is a teensy camera built into the frame of the glasses, ready to record anything I’m looking at.

headline: Images of Jazz Greats
text: Previously unpublished pictures of Billie Holiday, Duke Ellington, Dizzy Gillespie and more.

headline: The 8.18.13 Issue
Who Made That Traffic Radar?
text: “He kept the lights off, because he didn’t want anyone to see in,” says John L. Barker of the rooms his father rented to test a radar system he was making for the U.S. military. John L. Barker Sr. — then an engineer at Automatic Signal Company — had been working on traffic lights in the 1930s, but during World War II, he dedicated himself to military research. “He pointed the machine out a window, and he tested it on cars that drove through an intersection.” Barker was about 8 years old at the time and admits that his memories are hazy. “I have no idea why I was even involved,” he says.

headline: Thomas Menino Is a Cranberry-Juice-Drinking Workhorse
text: There’s an old maxim that politicians are either show horses or workhorses. After 20 years as mayor of Boston, you’ve won a reputation as a workhorse. What do you think the show horses can learn from the workhorses?  Well, a mayor has to be a workhorse. You can’t be a show horse, because people depend on you. We see our constituents every day. You go buy a newspaper, go to a coffee shop, buy gas for our car — you see them.

headline: A Brief Vacation From Myself
text: I was looking in my closet, choosing a shirt, when I lost my mind.

headline: Alternate Realms
text: In Aimee Bender’s short stories, the value of life is measured in terms of goodness, succulence and simplicity, all qualities that can be tasted, chewed and ultimately swallowed by the mouth or the mind. In “Appleless” (one of this new book’s many parable-like fictions), the nameless narrator distrusts a girl who doesn’t appreciate the bright-hued, hand-clutched density and watery meat of apples — and the narrator goes on, with the help of others, to devour every last apple in sight. The overachieving seamstress of “Tiger Mending” isn’t satisfied with simply stitching up cut lips and handkerchiefs; she eventually takes a job in a faraway country sewing the stripes back on ruptured tigers (who apparently yawn too widely for their own good). And in one of Bender’s best stories, “The Red Ribbon,” a bored wife can’t enjoy sex with her husband unless he pays her. She likes to keep track of their accumulating ecstasies in a ledger: “ ‘I need a specific amount, each time,’ she said, ‘or,’ clearing her throat, ‘I feel I will melt into nothingness.’ ”

headline: Big Brother
text: Dennis Bock’s third novel, “Going Home Again,” begins ominously: “On the Friday evening before Kaj Adolfsson was killed, I was actually feeling pretty good about things.” But readers expecting Nordic noir will be disappointed. The murder, when we finally hear about it in the last few pages, is a minor plot point. This is not a whodunit but a story about reckoning with the past.

headline: Free Range
text: Major poets, like trick-or-treaters, tend to arrive in pairs or small groups (whether this is a matter of fate or academic convenience may be debated). And yet from roughly 1930 to 1950, British and Irish poetry seemed to fall under the sway of a single writer: W. H. Auden. Auden was hardly a solitary figure, of course — his compatriots included Louis MacNeice, Stephen Spender and Cecil Day-Lewis (father of Daniel), and the four writers were once thought to be so intimately related that the poet Roy Campbell referred to them as “MacSpaunday.” But it wasn’t a relationship of equals: the MacSpaunday poets were usually considered notable not because of how closely they resembled one another, but because of how much the other three looked like Auden.

headline: Fascist Designs
text: As capitalism transformed European economies during the second half of the 19th century, the rise of the masses revolutionized political life. Searching for identity and purpose in a confusing and changing world, many took refuge in nationalism — a continentwide phenomenon that found its most virulent expression in newly created countries like Germany and Italy, where it soon upended culture along with everything else.

headline: Land of Mystery
text: A quarter-century ago, North Korea seemed to teeter on the brink of collapse. The end of the cold war in the late 1980s and the disintegration of the Soviet Union in 1991 suggested that the era of reclusive Communist dictatorships was over. How, asked hopeful observers around the world, could Kim Il-sung’s Stalinist wasteland possibly survive under the pressure of its spectacular economic failures and the tide of democracy and capitalism rising around its borders?

headline: Winter’s Bane
text: A four-day blizzard has left the village of Three Pines looking like a toy town sheltered under a snow globe. But this secluded Canadian hamlet, tucked away in a valley deep in the mountains, contributes more than its picturesque setting to Louise Penny’s latest mystery, HOW THE LIGHT GETS IN (Minotaur, $25.99). You might even say Three Pines is the hero of the novel.

headline: Bon Courage
text: In Paris, during his sabbatical in the early 1980s, a dear friend proposed we meet not for drinks at the Café de Flore but for ice cream at Berthillon. “The doctors have forbidden me alcohol,” he said. “In France! Can you imagine?” He’d been having odd health problems, one after the other, that they couldn’t explain. Months later, he developed Pneumocystis pneumonia and got his explanation. He died soon thereafter; our naïve days were at an end.

headline: Small-Town Savant
text: Ten years ago, when Mark Haddon’s “Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time” turned up on the best-seller list and won a number of literary awards, the novel’s autistic narrator beguiled readers with his unconventional point of view. Today, even as controversy surrounds the revised classification of autism in the latest version of the American Psychiatric Association’s Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, the quirky yet remarkably perceptive points of view of autistic narrators have become increasingly familiar in every category of fiction, from young adult to science fiction to popular and literary fiction.

headline: Chronicle: Fiction in Translation
text: THROUGH THE NIGHT  By Stig Saeterbakken  Translated by Sean KinsellaDalkey Archive, paper, $15.

headline: Inside the List
text: Dark Corners: Marisha Pessl made a lot of noise with her first novel, “Special Topics in Calamity Physics” — it spent three weeks on the hardcover fiction list in 2006, and was named one of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of the year. Her follow-up, “Night Film,” hasn’t collected quite the same level of praise; in the daily New York Times, Janet Maslin cited a “haunting suspicion” that the book “was more exciting to write than to read.”

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Passion,’ ‘One Direction’ and ‘Abigail Harm’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics look at “Passion,” “One Direction: This Is Us” and “Abigail Harm.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Oral Infections Causing More Hospitalizations
text: Left untreated, a serious tooth abscess can eventually kill.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Life With J. Paul Getty
text: This week, Judith Newman discusses Teddy Getty Gaston’s memoir, “Alone Together”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Evan J. Mandery talks about “A Wild Justice,” his new book about the death penalty in the U.S.; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Fertility Treatments Produce Heirs Their Parents Never Knew
text: THE number of children conceived through in vitro fertilization has doubled over the last decade. The technology that has made these children possible has also challenged inheritance laws, especially in circumstances when a child is conceived after the death of a parent.

headline: Aging Euroskeptics
text: Prakash Loungani has an interesting (but fairly technical) presentation on one of my favorite subjects: comparing the performance of nations within the euro with performance of states within the United States. He also digs up a blast from the past: a 1992 report on a discussion at MIT about the desirability of the euro. The professors — whose names you may recognize — were all euroskeptics.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Life With J. Paul Getty
text: This week, Judith Newman talks about Teddy Gaston Getty’s new memoir and Evan J. Mandery discusses “A Wild Justice.”

headline: For Girls in India, the Pressure to Conform Comes From Family
text: I recently watched the remarkable Malala Yousafzai speak at the United Nations to commemorate a day that is named after her. The 16-year-old who was shot by the Taliban, and has since become a celebrated activist for education and women’s rights, said that Malala Day was for “every boy and every girl who have raised their voice for their rights.” She bravely reinterpreted Islam and accused the extremists of being afraid of books, pens and education. “The power of the voice of women frightens them,” she said.

headline: Call It Beyrouth: Beirut With a French Accent
text: I was finishing an aperitif on the porch at Villa Clara while other guests tossed pétanque balls in the nearby yard. The hotel’s 4-year-old namesake cozied up to her papa, showing off her latest crayon creation. “Oh, c’est magnifique,” said Olivier Gougeon, a French chef and an owner of the property with his wife, Marie-Hélène, an editor of a French-language home décor magazine.

headline: Reader Idea | Considering the Varying Viewpoints on a Pregnancy Prevention Campaign
text: This idea comes from a high school teacher in Ann Arbor, Mich.

headline: Off the Charts: Some Banks Recover, Most Don’t
text: Five years ago, the financial crisis was on the verge of getting much worse. Now, an index of bank stocks around the world has recovered most of the ground it lost. But most large banks are still down, some by significant amounts.

headline: Too Little, Gone Too Soon
text: One of the things you always heard, back when we were actually talking about stimulus rather than fighting a rearguard action against destructive austerity, was the claim that stimulus spending would inevitably end up becoming a permanent fixture of the economy. This was always said with an air of worldly wisdom — of course that’s how these things work! — even though history said very much the opposite.

headline: Verizon-Vodafone Deal Would Be a Big Payday for Deal Makers
text: Though deal makers often complain about the slow pace of business in the summer, it appears that one of the biggest takeovers in years is near.

headline: A Chicago Church Sees Justice in Land’s Bounty
text: CHICAGO — Two generations and 700 miles away from her grandparents’ farm in Mississippi, Juanita O’Neal sat in a parking lot beside the four lanes of West 95th Street here, selling peas and okra and peaches. She wore an apron embroidered with the image of a ripe tomato and the words, “Granny and Kids Garden Patch.”

headline: With Britain Haunted by Iraq, a Harsh Lesson for Cameron
text: LONDON — Humiliated by lawmakers over Syria, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain seems destined to cut a lesser figure, weakened both at home and abroad by a self-made debacle that has also highlighted his war-weary country’s reluctance to get involved with another American project in the Middle East.

headline: Seamus Heaney’s ‘Journey Into the Wideness of Language’
text: Seamus Heaney, the esteemed Irish poet who died on Friday at 74, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1995. At the time, the poet Derek Walcott, a fellow Nobel winner, called Mr. Heaney “the guardian spirit of Irish poetry.”

headline: Hynes Is Attacked by Rival on Felony Conviction Rate
text: Charles J. Hynes, who is running for a seventh term as Brooklyn district attorney, has a long record to scrutinize, and his opponent in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary, Kenneth P. Thompson, has seized on one statistic that has barely improved since Mr. Hynes took office: his felony conviction rate.

headline: Rupee Drops, and Outlook Grows Darker for India
text: MUMBAI, India — The statistical evidence is piling up that India’s economy may be in even worse shape than had been thought.

headline: The Importance of Morgan State vs. Army
text: By August 1968, the dream described so eloquently by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. five years earlier had been punctured.

headline: Republicans Brush Off the Heritage Foundation
text: It turns out that you can be too crazy even for the right-wing Republican Congressional Caucus. This week, the National Journal reported that the Republican Study Committee, a group of 172 conservative Congressmen, had banned Heritage Foundation employees from its weekly meetings.

headline: Exclusive | 104 Willow Street, Brooklyn Heights
text: A Federal-style town house dating to1826 was originally home to an importer of Merino sheep. It’s on the market for $12 million.

headline: Built When Sheep Grazed in Brooklyn Heights
text: The exquisitely renovated and inventively painted Federal-style town house at 104 Willow Street in Brooklyn Heights began its tenure in 1826 as a custom-built farmhouse with trees as its nearest neighbors.

headline: Image of the Day: Aug. 30
text: An Air India aircraft received a water salute on landing at the airport in Sydney, Australia, on its inaugural run from New Delhi to Sydney.

headline: Big Ticket | Terrace Swimming for $14.7 Million
text: A sprawling seven-bedroom, nine-and-a-half-bath duplex with a 3,800-square-foot terrace including a private outdoor swimming pool at the Aldyn, at 60 Riverside Boulevard near 63rd Street, sold for $14,711,621.25 and was the most expensive sale of the week, city records show.

headline: Five Years After Chaos, Shares of Many Big Banks Are Still Struggling
text: FINANCIAL markets were nervous five years ago, as September 2008 began, but hopeful that the world would stabilize.

headline: In Book and Magazine Profile, Views Into Djokovic’s World
text: Heading into his second-round match against Benjamin Becker on Friday afternoon, top-ranked Novak Djokovic has been on court for only 1 hour 22 minutes at the United States Open. But he has remained in the headlines this week.

headline: A Lesson for Boardroom Battles
text: Proxy access may be dead in the United States, but it lives in Israel, to the great regret of Taro Pharmaceutical Industries.

headline: Review: 2014 Kia Cadenza
text: Priced at nearly $42,000 for a fully loaded model, the 2014 Cadenza is aimed at upscale buyers, not dancing hamsters. Can the budget brand compete with the Avalon, Impala and Maxima?

headline: At 11th Hour, North Korea Cancels Visit By U.S. Envoy
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea has rescinded its invitation for a senior American diplomat to travel to Pyongyang on a mission to secure the release of an American Christian missionary imprisoned on charges of committing hostile acts against the government, the State Department said on Friday.

headline: Long Odds for Authors Newly Published
text: “The Cuckoo’s Calling” became the publishing sensation of the summer when word leaked that its first-time author, Robert Galbraith, was none other than J. K. Rowling, the mega-best-selling creator of Harry Potter.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Life With J. Paul Getty
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Judith Newman reviews “Alone Together,” the new memoir by Teddy Getty Gaston, the fifth and last wife of the billionaire J. Paul Getty. Ms. Newman writes:

headline: A Closer’s Stumbles Are Outnumbered Only by His Saves
text: Where would Jim Johnson, the Baltimore Orioles’ closer, be without Jerome Holtzman?

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Budapest; Portland, Ore.; South Dakota
text: Budapest International Wine Festival, Budapest Held in Budapest, above, at Buda Castle, this wine event, from Sept. 11 to 15 will salute female winemakers in interviews and special tastings amid the showcase of nearly 200 Hungarian wineries. Guided tastings cover pinots, rieslings and merlots along with the Tokaji wines. Musical programming highlights Hungarian jazz and folk bands. Dairies from 15 nations will participate in the festival’s inaugural European cheese contest.

headline: What I Love | Lee Child
text: Lee Child, the author of the Jack Reacher books, lives in a Manhattan apartment that’s stripped down for action.

headline: Lee Child and the Macho of Minimalism
text: To hear Lee Child tell it, the whole thing began well over half a century ago with a picture book.

headline: U.S. Assessment of Syrian Use of Chemical Weapons
text: The White House released a report contending “with high confidence” that the Syrian government used chemical weapons near Damascus.

headline: ‘A Soap Opera Bent Out of Shape’
text: Patton Oswalt moved gingerly as he eased onto a sofa on the Bushwick, Brooklyn, set of “The Heart, She Holler.” He was slowed, perhaps, by fatigue after a full morning of shooting this show, a Southern gothic horror-comedy. Or maybe it was the bloody rabbit’s foot sticking out of his chest.

headline: Empty-Handed Guests? Just Forgive or Forget
text: The Field Notes column last Sunday, “When You Can’t Forget the Gifts You Didn’t Get,” about those who cannot forgive or forget guests who failed to give a wedding gift, drew nearly 300 comments. And the overwhelming sentiment among the respondents was more generous than the empty-handed guests: they would ignore the oversight, whether it was intentional or not.

headline: Kerry Becomes Chief Advocate for U.S. Attack
text: WASHINGTON — Jabbing his finger at the lectern, his voice forceful, his words brimming with indignation, John Kerry laid out the case like the prosecutor he once was, making a closing argument to a skeptical jury.

headline: After British Vote, Unusual Isolation for U.S. on Syria
text: WASHINGTON — With a few exceptions in the past half-century, there has been a simple rule of thumb when it comes to international conflict: America does not use force without Britain at its side.

headline: New Uses for Cucumbers
text: Last spring, on a whim, I planted one cucumber plant in my small tomato garden and it grew like Jack’s beanstalk. It’s been putting out long, straight, sturdy seedless cucumbers all summer and I’ve been inspired to go beyond the Greek salads and Balkan cucumber and yogurt soups that I customarily enjoy throughout the season.

headline: Seamus Heaney Was a Funny Guy
text: Seamus Heaney, who died on Friday, was a great poet, a scholar, a translator of “Beowulf,” et cetera and so on.

headline: Miley Cyrus and the Summer of Smooth
text: Jon Carmanica and Ben Ratliff on the pop star’s controversial VMA performance and how it relates to the summer hits of 2013.

headline: Congress Points Out the Cost of War
text: President Obama may go it alone with a military strike against the Syrian regime, but for the financially struggling Defense Department there will be a price — and skeptics in Congress appear ready to play the money card.

headline: Kerry on Syria’s Use of Chemical Weapons
text: A day after the British Parliament voted against military intervention in Syria, the Secretary of State made the case for U.S. involvement.

headline: Dress Up Your Salad With Grains
text: You can turn a simple salad into a hearty, texture-rich dish just by adding a few grains, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.

headline: The Whole Fish and Nothing But
text: It was thrilling to move to the West Coast after a childhood and adolescence spent well inland, deprived of the ocean’s bounty.

headline: Mediterranean Escher: A Glimpse Inside Tel Aviv’s Central Bus Station
text: TEL AVIV – As Labor Day weekend approaches, hundreds of thousands of bus passengers, eager to savor summer’s last gasp, will pass through the Port Authority Bus Terminal. As baffling as some tourists – and even New Yorkers – find the place, imagine that sort of human traffic scurrying through a labyrinth of oddly placed stairways and market stalls. Picture that in your mind’s eye, and you’ll know what it’s like to travel by bus through Tel Aviv.

headline: Major Surge Is Unlikely for Prices of U.S. Gas
text: HOUSTON — With all the saber-rattling surrounding Syria and the spike in oil prices over the last week, gasoline prices rose by 2 cents a gallon for a second day in a row on Friday as motorists began to fill up their tanks for the Labor Day weekend.

headline: Bill Clinton to Raise Cash for Democratic Governors
text: Bill Clinton, who was the governor of Arkansas before moving to the White House, will return to his political roots — and earn a few more chits for his wife’s political future — next month by raising money for the Democratic Governors Association at a high-dollar New York City fund-raiser.

headline: With More Aggressive Game, Li Avenges Open Defeat
text: In the year since an up-and-coming youngster crushed her chance to win her favorite Grand Slam event, Li Na has accomplished something remarkable: she seems to have gotten younger.

headline: Seamus Heaney in His Own Voice
text: Seamus Heaney, the accomplished and admired Irish poet, reading from his work over the years.

headline: Tax Haven Closes for Wealthy Americans
text: LONDON — A tax deal reached between Switzerland and the United States on Thursday effectively put an end to the status of the small Alpine country as a tax haven for wealthy Americans.

headline: A Quiet Beauty Flying By
text: Each summer, a quiet migration gets under way for North American shorebirds. Measured in sheer numbers, the volume is astounding as millions of birds collect along the Atlantic coast. What is both miraculous and unnerving is that the North Atlantic Flyway guides them directly through some of the densest population centers on earth virtually unnoticed. Except for delighted bird watchers and worried managers at local airports, most New Yorkers are unaware that outside their windows, birds are coursing along an ancient migration route.

headline: Ex-Goldman Trader Fined $500,000
text: A former Goldman Sachs trader who pleaded guilty in a criminal case earlier this year to fabricating huge positions to protect his bonus agreed on Friday to pay a $500,000 fine in a related civil matter.

headline: The Audacity of the Fight for Higher Wages
text: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: In Life's Race, the Pastor Burns Rubber
text: The Rev. Scott Kraniak, chaplain at the Riverhead Raceway stock car track on Long Island, asks God to watch over drivers.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A seven-bedroom split-level ranch in Hewlett Harbor and three-bedroom town house in Tarrytown.

headline: In California, Intense Debate Over Home Care
text: An important struggle over home health care is playing out in California, the nation’s most populous state, including nearly five million residents age 65 and older.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: Two-bedroom co-ops, in Chelsea and on the Upper West Side and a town house in Bedford-Stuyvesant.

headline: Tale of the Stingray
text: The Corvette Sting Ray arrived for 1963 and was a landmark for the brand.

headline: In News Coverage and Editorials on Syria, How Much Skepticism in The Times?
text: Many Times readers are looking at recent news coverage of Syria, and editorials on the same subject, through the lens of another international conflict: the United States invasion of Iraq.

headline: Pray, Then Hit the Gas
text: Just before the cars took the track at Riverhead Raceway on a recent Saturday night, a souped-up 1965 Comet Cyclone roared out and roused the crowd by squealing and smoking its wheels and peeling out.

headline: Tennis in Harlem
text: At the U.S. Open this week and next, thousands of tennis fans have been and will be visiting Arthur Ashe Stadium at the tournament’s site in Queens. It’s not all that far from where Ashe spent some time in Harlem honing his skills with a tennis coach named Sydney Llewellyn. According to another former tennis student, Bob Davis, Llewellyn taught more African-American national champions than any other coach — among them Althea Gibson, to whom he was married for five years in the mid-’80s.

headline: A Chameleon Onstage and on TV
text: “Sesame Street” was looking for a Latino guy; “stop. reset.” was looking for an African-American guy; “The Good Wife” was looking for a white guy. They all ended up with Ismael Cruz Córdova, who was born and raised in Aguas Buenas, P.R.

headline: The ‘Black Budget,’ Revealed
text: For budget-watchers, it was a voyeuristic thrill to read through the Washington Post’s article today exposing the secret details of the intelligence community’s “black budget.” The world now knows that the C.I.A. gets the biggest chunk of intelligence spending at $14.7 billion for 2013, and that a little-known agency, the National Reconnaissance Office, gets $10.3 billion, almost as much as the National Security Agency. (The reconnaissance office builds spy satellites, which are apparently rather pricey.)

headline: John Legend, From Rugged to Clean
text: The R&B singer talks to the Styles section’s Bee Shapiro about coming from a family of tailors and how that has influenced his personal style evolution.

headline: For John Legend, No Colors Anymore, Except for Swimming
text: The Grammy-winning singer and songwriter John Legend, 34, has a new album, “Love in the Future,” scheduled for release on Tuesday. He lives with his fiancée, Christine Teigen, a model, in New York and Los Angeles.

headline: Video: With the Cadenza, Kia Moves Into a Nicer Neighborhood
text: Five years ago, the suggestion of a Kia with a retail price of nearly $42,000 would have been met with laughter and incredulous looks. But just as Toyota and Honda moved up in the 1970s and ’80s from their economy car roots, Kia has branched out with a range of new models, each generation showing more polish and sophistication than the cars that came before.

headline: At 67, Coughlin Proves a Taskmaster Can Be Tender
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When Tom Coughlin’s children were growing up, they developed a routine when it came time to ask their father for something.

headline: Wagons Ho!
text: The station wagon has been slowly fading away, but with the 2013 3 Series Sports Wagon, BMW is doing its part to keep the cars from extinction.

headline: Dave Chappelle Cuts Short a Stand-Up Show
text: A live appearance by Dave Chappelle can be an unpredictable affair, promising either brilliance or petulance, and audiences who saw him perform Thursday night in Connecticut got a little bit of both, when this onetime Comedy Central star halted his stand-up act in mid-performance and proceeded to run out the clock.

headline: Tennis in the Background
text: Tennis is a game of tradition. And for some fans, the annual visit to the United States Open in Queens is as much about soaking up the atmosphere as seeing the matches. Especially when it rains. For them, the Mojito Bar and Restaurant has provided sit-down dining and people-watching outside Arthur Ashe Stadium since 2003 (the year that Andy Roddick, now retired, won). The restaurant, which serves Latin-influenced fare, was redesigned this year to evoke South Beach. It’s Florida à la Flushing, punctuated by red and gold patio umbrellas on the terrace and artsy chandeliers inside.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 30
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a boat club on Newtown Creek, the race for mayor and a baby snow leopard at the Bronx Zoo.

headline: Yankees Stumble at the Gate
text: The Yankees are back home this weekend, with 29 games left on their schedule and at least an outside chance to end up with a playoff spot when the season comes to an end on Sept. 28. They have picked up some ground lately in their playoff quest but, interestingly enough, continue to lag when it comes to putting people in the seats.

headline: Arriving in Style Just as the Tailgate Party Winds Down
text: Considering the rarity of station wagons in America, BMW’s new tailgating 3 Series set me wondering: who exactly spends $50,000 or more on a compact wagon, instead of going the usual American route with an S.U.V. or a crossover?

headline: Lose Your Keys? Use Your Phone
text: My quest to test an app called KeyMe started with five keys.

headline: Keeping a Connection, Even on the Open Road
text: While distracted driving is a problem in any vehicle, the consequences are potentially greater on a motorcycle. So the designers of communication headsets for riders face a decision in striving to make systems safe to use.

headline: Fast-Forward Lessons in Corvette Genealogy
text: SEASIDE, CALIF. — The Chevrolet Corvette has, over its 60 years of production, reflected the changing styles and tastes of America, says Mark Reuss, president of General Motors North America.

headline: A Revered Nameplate Makes an Encore
text: The champions of the Chevrolet Corvette have included Bill Mitchell and Ed Welburn — Mr. Mitchell of the Sting Ray and Mr. Welburn of the Stingray, the difference in the rendering of the model names reflecting the different eras in which they worked.

headline: Choicest Bites of Stingray
text: Riskng bar fights at future reunions, Corvette experts offered opinions of the greatest Sting Rays and Stingrays. Price ranges from Sports Car Market magazine, reflecting varying conditions of cars at auction.

headline: From McQueen to Venus: Brave Women
text: Before getting knocked out of the U.S. Open this week, Venus Williams made quite a statement with her purple braids, piled in a knot above her visor and complimenting her printed tennis dress. You may cry fault: what about another player, Bethanie Mattek-Sands, who seems to be working on the colors of the rainbow? She’s also tattooed. People who grew up in the Evert-Connors era may gag, but exotic hair color on the courts is merely a step from the streets, and, in fact, it’s a lot more compelling.

headline: Obama Makes Remarks on Syria
text: President Obama said that he had not made a final decision about Syria, but that he was not considering any military action that would require a long-term campaign or troops on the ground.

headline: Unleashing the Potential of the Strings
text: PLAINFIELD, Mass. — On a recent sunny afternoon, Matt Haimovitz entered a carpentry workshop here that doubles as a music studio and gently pulled the door shut. The garden of the 19th-century farmhouse echoed with the shouts of children. But the newest family member was quietly leaning against the wall. It was darker than its sibling next to it and covered in pockmarks, but Mr. Haimovitz cupped his hand around its neck with loving pride: “This is my Beethoven cello.”

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Q. This year is the 150th anniversary of Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation. When was slavery abolished in New York?

headline: Twitter General Counsel Leaves as Company Prepares to Go Public
text: Alex Macgillivray, Twitter’s chief lawyer and the Internet industry’s most prominent champion of free speech rights, announced on Friday that he would step down from his post, as the company expands its global footprint and prepares for a widely anticipated public offering sometime next year.

headline: Week in Review: A $125 Billion Bet on a Multitrillion-Dollar Market
text: Verizon Communications is in talks with Vodafone to buy the British telecommunication giant’s 45% stake in Verizon Wireless. The deal, worth at least $125 billion, would be one of the biggest takeovers in history, but the burgeoning wireless industry makes the buyout attractive.

headline: Taking Their Very Sweet Time
text: Neon beer signs, sports team logos and sexy posters may be de rigueur in the dorm rooms of college males, but while at the University of Florida in Gainesville, Udonis Haslem went one better. Somehow the Gators basketball player managed to keep a pit bull hidden in his room — which at the time was more emblematic of where he’d been than of where he was going: Mr. Haslem is now a captain of the Miami Heat and has won three N.B.A. championships with the team.

headline: A Travel Book With a Global, and Personal, Touch
text: A 21-year-old artist has reinvented a cherished commodity for world travelers seeking an authentic experience in a new place: a local’s recommendation.

headline: Work, Work, Family, Work
text: Ban Ki-moon, 69, has been the secretary general of the United Nations since 2007. A South Korean, Mr. Ban spent his childhood in a war-torn country and later experienced its rebirth as an industrial power in Asia. His job never stops, so on Sundays he works, taking calls on his BlackBerry and responding to queries from his staff or heads of state. Mr. Ban lives with his wife, Yoo Soon-taek, 68, in a United Nations town house on Sutton Place, where visits from their three grown children and four grandchildren offer a break from the rigors of trying to solve the world’s problems.

headline: The Littlest Ninja Gets a Stiff Shot of Power
text: TESTED 2013 Kawasaki Ninja 300

headline: Quinn, in Times Square, Offers Plan for Veterans
text: Holding a news conference in Times Square is akin to – well, maybe not walking into the line of fire, but certainly tempting the urban gods. As a politician, you risk being photobombed by the Naked Cowboy or groped by Elmo, or simply encountering a critic who, inspired by the crowds, will deliver a monologue on your misdeeds at a volume intended to reach the back rows.

headline: Weather and Violence
text: AS temperatures rise, tempers flare. Anyone who has experienced the hostility of a swelteringly hot summer day in the city can attest to that.

headline: Smoky Eggplant Dip With Pita Chips
text: Melissa Clark makes a dip that even eggplant haters can’t resist.

headline: Ivanka Trump, Never Far From the Family Name
text: Ivanka Trump has quietly carved out a niche in the fashion industry that nobody seemed to want after we tossed out our shoulder pads: professional attire.

headline: Just One Big, Happy Family?
text: This summer, 39 members of the Peters family gathered in Smith Mountain Lake, Va., just outside Roanoke, for their 40th family reunion. What started with five nearby families in 1970 has grown to 10 families, some from as far away as Alaska and Washington State. Activities included water-skiing, a pickleball tournament and TV theme-song trivia night.

headline: U.S. Open Food Review: An Indian Oasis
text: Because eating at the United States Open is a high-stakes game, we will feature a daily review of items available at the food courts at the National Tennis Center.

headline: Getting a Doubter to Dip Into Eggplant
text: The most persuasive way to convert an eggplant hater is to fry it (the eggplant, not the hater). A less messy approach, however, is to make dip. Velvety, smoky dip with a tangy bite has seduced many an eggplant-hating guest.

headline: Apple Expands iPhone Trade-In Program to Its Stores
text: Apple is trying to give people another reason to come to its elegant retail stores: Trading in old iPhones for a store credit toward a new phone.

headline: What Makes for a Successful Family Reunion?
text: “Given the undercurrent of hostility, as well as the myriad problems that may arise — drunk uncles, political catfights, who’s gluten free and who eats only what they kill — how is a modern family to survive these squabbles?”

headline: De Blasio Sees Surge in Fund-Raising
text: It’s good to be the front-runner, at least when it comes to raising money, as Bill de Blasio is now discovering.

headline: Job Titles Retailored to Fit
text: Consider this roster of titles:

headline: A Tale’s Kafkaesque Transformation
text: LONDON — A man wakes up one morning to find himself turned into a giant insect. It’s the famous, improbable opening of Kafka’s novella “The Metamorphosis,” and it popped into the choreographer Arthur Pita’s head one day when he was thinking about working with the Royal Ballet principal dancer Edward Watson.

headline: ‘I Actually Work. I’m in the Studio 24/7. It’s Definitely a Grind.’
text: As a member of the Memphis group Three 6 Mafia, the rapper Juicy J memorably collected an Oscar in 2006, for “It’s Hard Out Here for a Pimp.” And his career has continued to follow a series of unexpected turns, from occasional actor to Twitter star (more than one million followers) to, lately, solo artist. On the heels of the platinum single “Bandz a Make Her Dance,” featuring Lil Wayne and 2 Chainz, his third solo album and major label debut, “Stay Trippy,” was released late last month on Kemosabe/Columbia Records. A few years ago, he had never performed onstage alone; now he is completing a sold-out, 40-city tour.

headline: The Few Who Elect the Mayor for All
text: As conventional wisdom has it, New Yorkers are seeking a striking change in tone in the coming mayoral election, one that makes the selection of a Democratic mayor seem almost inevitable and the party’s primary process likely to represent the conclusion of the story rather than the plot-escalating middle. As we’ve also been made to understand, a relatively small number of voters will determine the outcome of the primary race.

headline: Singles Become Doubles
text: This last July, on a searingly hot day, as the tennis player Andy Murray closed in on a historic sporting achievement — to be the first British man to win a Wimbledon singles title since Fred Perry in 1936 — the BBC cameras kept shifting their gaze from one key character to another as the match entered what would be its final game.

headline: Movie Review: 'Passion'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Passion."

headline: Movie Review: 'This Is Us"
text: The Times critic Miriam Bale reviews "One Direction: This Is Us."

headline: Movie Review: 'Abigail Harm'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Abigail Harm.”

headline: Calvin Klein’s Hamptons House Is Nearing Completion
text: For nearly half a decade, Mr. Klein, the fashion designer, has been erecting a minimalist palace the likes of which is seldom seen in an area of increasing architectural homogeneity.

headline: The House That Calvin Built
text: For just $15 a day, Suffolk County residents can drive up in an R.V. and stay at the park at the end of Meadow Lane in Southampton, N.Y., where the views of the Atlantic Ocean on one side and Shinnecock Bay on the other are considered to be among the most spectacular on the East End.

headline: New Ad Organization to Promote Cross-Cultural Marketing
text: Five big names on Madison Avenue are joining forces to start an organization devoted to promoting what is known as cross-cultural marketing: pitches directed at a general market whose demographic makeup is becoming much more diverse.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Never-Changing City
text: Echoes of the artist Reginald Marsh’s work from the 1930s are seen from Coney Island to Fifth Avenue to West Village street festivals. Marsh said he wanted to capture the “chaos of the city.”

headline: The Summer After the Storm
text: LONG BEACH, N.Y. — There was Jonathan Goldman one perfect August afternoon, happily traipsing down the Long Beach Boardwalk, dispensing wisdom to unsuspecting strollers and leaving snippets of rimshot patter floating in the salty air.

headline: Low Ratings for ‘Low Winter Sun’
text: AMC’s “Breaking Bad” has been one of the summer’s great ratings success stories, a testament to the power of binge watching and word of mouth.

headline: Malevich’s Burial Site Is Found, Underneath Housing Development
text: MOSCOW — The burial site of the Russian avant-garde artist and theorist Kazimir Malevich, in a field near Moscow, has been covered in concrete by a real estate developer to make way for luxury housing, says an enthusiast who spent years looking for the site.

headline: Changing It Up in the Bedroom
text: If you’re watching a channel called Discovery Fit & Health and someone starts talking about “the lifestyle,” you might assume the reference is to a triathlon training regimen or a vegan diet. Not on a new show the channel offers on Saturday. The lifestyle in question involves spouse swapping and other alternatives to monogamy. The show, a four-part reality series, is called “Secret Sex Lives: Swingers,” and it looks at five couples who like to mix things up occasionally in the bedroom. And they could be that ordinary-looking couple next door.

headline: Identity Puzzles From U.S. and Iran
text: More than ever, tension among forces of cosmopolitan democracy, religious traditionalism and militaristic order roil the Middle East. So Asia Society’s “Iran Modern,” an exhibition of more than 100 artworks made in Iran in the two decades before the revolution of 1979, should be something to see. Modern art was starting to thrive then, as artists explored new possibilities of identity. It opens Friday. (Through Jan. 5, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, asiasociety.org.)

headline: In Store | The Wythe Hotel’s New Concept Shop Is a Family Affair
text: To some, the Wythe Hotel in Williamsburg may represent the way Brooklyn is changing, but it’s sticking with the borough’s tradition of keeping it in the family. Opening next Tuesday is a new boutique known as the Shop, with a theme and offerings chosen by one local mastermind, which will change every four to six months. The first curator is the fashion designer Caron Callahan, whose label is based in the neighborhood. (Her husband, Sean Rembold, is the executive chef at the restaurant Marlow & Sons, owned by Andrew Tarlow, who is also the man behind the Wythe.) “They were looking for something that gave a little energy to that nook,” Callahan said. “There’s so much happening here, and the taste level is super-high.”

headline: It’s Pre-Season at Poisson Rouge
text: The fall season is looming, but plenty of ambitious artists are not content to wait for any official starter’s pistol to sound, and this week three of them come to the stylish Bleecker Street nightclub Le Poisson Rouge. Two are coming together. On Tuesday, the excellent young pianists Ran Dank and Soyeon Kate Lee present an evening of works for piano duo, including the premiere of Frederic Rzewski’s “Four Hands,” as well as Brahms’s 16 Waltzes, Op. 39 and an arrangement of Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring.”

headline: Exploring Gender and Sexuality
text: With the Supreme Court overturning the Defense of Marriage Act, and gay marriage being legalized in one state after another, the struggle for sexual equality has taken precedence over the fact of sexuality in the gay, lesbian and transgender liberation movement. But sex, in all its variety, some of it explicit, is the main subject of NewFest, the New York L.G.B.T. Festival.

headline: Putting Poetry Above Politics
text: The songwriter Mohsen Namjoo stirs things up in Iran. Mr. Namjoo, who performs Saturday at the Asia Society, plays the setar, a long-necked lute, and is steeped in Persian classical and literary traditions. But in Iran, where Western music was banned in 2005, Mr. Namjoo decided to fuse Persian music with rock and jazz and to sing — in a voice that can push from the nuances of Persian improvisation to the rougher attack of the blues — about the conditions facing his generation: unemployment, repression, violence. Though he was not allowed to perform in public or licensed to sell CDs, his music spread in private events, on the black market and via YouTube and radio.

headline: A Broader Look at the War Across Syria
