text: Uncertainty about how an outside attack could affect Syria’s civil war is one of the factors leading to disagreement among Western countries about how to respond.

headline: Road Trip to New Fringe
text: It’s a sleepy week for dance in New York; most theaters are dark, and the late-summer lull has set in. For ambitious dancegoers, a road trip might be in order, namely to Philadelphia, where the 16-day Fringe Festival gets under way on Thursday. Formerly known as the Philadelphia Live Arts Festival and Philly Fringe, a restructured entity, FringeArts, presents this year’s thoroughly interdisciplinary mix.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Skype a Decade Later and Why There Aren’t Enough Women in Tech
text: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: A Rebuilt Revis Is Looking Ahead, Not Back
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Darrelle Revis leaves his waterfront residence downtown every morning and drives to an office whose entrance is flanked by palm trees. It is always warm, always sunny, and even if it isn’t, it still seems that way to Revis. Sometimes, he said with a laugh, he has to tell himself that he is not on vacation.

headline: ‘Ona’ at Barclays Center
text: A 19-foot-high cast-bronze sculpture by the artist Ursula von Rydingsvard now stands in front of the Brooklyn arena.

headline: Tempest in the City
text: A new Public Theater production of Shakespeare’s “The Tempest” features more than 200 actors, only 6 professional.

headline: In Des Moines, a Bonanza That Not Everyone Wants
text: DES MOINES — Nearly a decade ago, Lisa Connett, newly divorced and struggling on a tight budget, decided to fight City Hall over its “franchise fee” on residents’ utility bills. Now, as a result of her class-action suit, consumers here stand to collect some $40 million in refunds on fees that courts deemed an illegal tax.

headline: Turning Chaos Into Theater, With a Cast of 200
text: Donald Gray, who will make his theatrical debut in a musical version of Shakespeare’s “Tempest” in Central Park next weekend, has taken an unconventional route to the stage. Mr. Gray, 53, was arrested for the first time at age 15, for selling drugs, and spent the next decades running the streets or in prison.

headline: All Eyes on Her
text: “She” has arrived.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Tunisia and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Tunisia, Yemen, Kashmir and the Philippines.

headline: Kerry’s Remarks on Chemical Weapons in Syria
text: Following is the text of Secretary of State John Kerry’s remarks on Friday about the use of chemical weapons in Syria, as transcribed by Federal News Service:

headline: A Parade Passing By? Not Likely
text: The historically gay Fire Island community of Cherry Grove has welcomed a parade of gay icons this summer, among them John Waters, Lynda Carter and Chita Rivera.

headline: Obama’s Remarks on Chemical Weapons in Syria
text: Following is the text of President Obama’s comments on Friday about the use of chemical weapons in Syria, as transcribed by Federal News Service:

headline: To Sleep, Perchance to Dream Another’s Reality
text: “I read in some crazy book you bought me that ‘weird’ comes from the Anglo-Saxon word for ‘wise.’ ”

headline: Another Kind of Music
text: I was in the audience at the Abbey Theater in Dublin on June 9, 1991, when Seamus Heaney read from his new book of poems, “Seeing Things.” I know the exact date because he kindly inscribed his book for me and dated it. But I wouldn’t have forgotten that night, with or without the month and year. Seamus gave a mesmerizing, witty and emotional performance, and it was a rare opportunity for me to hear the sound of his words spoken with their true accent.

headline: Microsoft Cuts Deal With Activist Shareholder to Avoid Fight
text: The saga of Steve Ballmer’s departure/retirement from Microsoft continued Friday with an agreement between Microsoft and an activist shareholder, ValueAct Capital, that averts a potentially nasty battle over the company’s lagging performance.

headline: Knockout Teams at World Youth Open
text: ATLANTA — At the 3rd World Youth Open Championships here this month, in the Youngsters (under 21) Knockout Teams, eight teams, three Chinese and five American, qualified for 32-board quarterfinals, semifinals and final.

headline: A Musical Homecoming
text: Will Sheff, front man for the rock band Okkervil River, shows reporter Larry Rohter around his small New Hampshire hometown, which inspired the band’s forthcoming album, “The Silver Gymnasium.”

headline: Capturing Rhythms of Nature in Poems
text: In his Nobel acceptance speech, Seamus Heaney said that he prized the sort of poem that provides not just “a surprising variation played upon the world,” but “a retuning of the world itself” — delivering a visceral surprise, “like the impatient thump which unexpectedly restores the picture to the television set, or the electric shock which sets the fibrillating heart back to its proper rhythm.”

headline: Lower Labor Day Gas Prices
text: Despite turmoil in the Middle East and potential Western involvement in the Syrian crisis, the price of oil has been relatively stable and the price of gas this weekend will be lower than it was in the last two years.

headline: A Treasure Map of a Childhood, Filled With Magic and Newts
text: MERIDEN, N.H. — The singer, songwriter and multi-instrumentalist Will Sheff founded the indie-rock band Okkervil River in Austin, Tex., in 1998 and now lives in Brooklyn. But memories of his years growing up in this bucolic New England hamlet in the 1980s have never been far from his mind, so when it came time to make a new CD, he decided to return home — in song and in person.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Calls in Big Gun in Dispute
text: He brokered peace in Northern Ireland and spent two frustrating years as an envoy in the Middle East. Now George J. Mitchell, the former senator from Maine, is trying to bring peace to the Midwest, as the mediator in the Minnesota Orchestra’s bitter labor dispute.

headline: Have You Met the Bergers? Of Course, You Have
text: Sometimes you walk into a thimble-size theater where the stage is just the floor, flanked by 50 or so chairs, and you think, Lord, this is going to be way too cozy.

headline: Violin and Bass Trombone Finally Meet, and It’s Love
text: The first concert of this year’s Labor Day Festival of contemporary music at Bargemusic included four world premieres. But the composer of one, David Del Tredici, insisted that his “Dynamic Duo ‘Farewell’ for Violin and Bass Trombone” was more than that: a “civilization premiere,” the first pairing — ever, anywhere — of those two instruments.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 30
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a boat club on Newtown Creek, the race for mayor and a baby snow leopard at the Bronx Zoo,

headline: Friday Night Music: Missing the Civil Wars
text: The Civil Wars have a new, and presumably final album. It’s lovely; but I haven’t been able to bring myself to post any of the official videos, because I keep thinking of what we lost when they had their falling out. What I always loved most was the magic of those live performances, and it doesn’t look as if we’ll have those ever again.

headline: Seven Days of Chic | Fashion Pills and Furry Shoes
text: 1. “Girls” GirlJemima Kirke’s druid-chic getup at the VMAs was amazing. Totem-pole-printed gauze atop a “She’s All That”-style little red dress? Sure, why not?

headline: Evangelist’s Flock Keeps the Faith After His Brush With the Law
text: TRUSSVILLE, Ala. — Inside a darkened, sweltering room here one night this week, the evangelist Matt Pitt roused a couple hundred members of his young congregation in between raucous songs and a skit about prom dates.

headline: Making the Safety Net More Visible in Philadelphia
text: PHILADELPHIA — Like many poor people in this city, Gladys James did not know she was entitled to free home help or discounted water bills. She had no idea she was eligible to re-enroll for food stamps after being cut off last year because of a misunderstanding.

headline: Judge Says Search Warrants for E-mails Must Be ‘Limited’
text: Can law enforcement obtain a search warrant to dig through a vast trove of e-mails, instant messages and chat logs because they have reasonable suspicion that the owners of those accounts robbed computer equipment from a private company?

headline: Giants Take Wait-and-See Approach After Brown’s Injury
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants have lost so many starting players during the preseason that after another key contributor went down Thursday night, it did not discernibly rattle the mood inside the team’s locker room the next day.

headline: Yankees Keep Hughes in Rotation, Just Not Against Orioles
text: The Yankees tweaked their rotation Friday so that the slumping Phil Hughes would avoid facing the Baltimore Orioles, a team the Yankees trail in the wild-card chase, in a crucial series this weekend. Originally scheduled to pitch Sunday, Hughes will switch with Andy Pettitte, who was originally set to pitch Monday against the Chicago White Sox. Pettitte will now pitch Sunday, and Hughes will pitch Monday.

headline: For News From Syrian Battleground, a Reliance on Social Media
text: When Secretary of State John Kerry delivered the United States’ report on Friday about the use of chemical weapons in Syria, he noted that “all hell broke loose in the social media” just 90 minutes after the alleged attack. As evidence of atrocities, the report cites thousands of social media updates and videos, along with reports from intelligence agencies, journalists and medical personnel.

headline: Gay and Married Couples in New Land of Taxation
text: It’s now official: same-sex married couples across the country are allowed to check one of the “married” boxes on their federal tax returns, even if their own state doesn’t recognize their union.

headline: A Colored Man’s Constitution
text: Patrolling the streets of New Orleans on the evening of Sept. 1, 1863, a police officer found a small sheaf of handwritten papers. They were hard to read, written mostly in halting, misspelled English. Glancing over a page, the policeman may have seen at first only snatches of apparently incoherent prose: “Carrige Drivers preachers of the Gospel the best Soldiers the united States Can Raise but the tel lies Sometimes and so dos all negro traders the get Drunk and lawiers and merchants.”

headline: The Luck of an Unlicensed Barber Runs Out
text: Three or four barbers were working that Thursday evening at Corner Cuts in Ridgewood, Queens, when the police walked in.

headline: L.I.R.R. Train Kills Dog in Queens, Disrupting Service for 45 Minutes
text: For the second time in two days, pets forced the suspension of service on a major transit line in New York City. On Thursday, two kittens were rescued from the tracks of a Brooklyn subway station. But on Friday, the escape of a dog from a Queens yard turned into a pet owner’s nightmare: The dog, a female pit bull, was struck and killed by a Long Island Rail Road train, and her owner was grazed trying to get her back.

headline: Fallen Official’s Defense: He Was Obeying Orders
text: BEIJING — Bo Xilai, the fallen Communist Party official, said in secret testimony during his recent trial that he was obeying orders from a powerful party agency in charge of security when he took steps to cover up the flight of his police chief to an American Consulate, according to a court observer’s written record of trial statements.

headline: Syracuse-Penn State Game Is Drawing Mostly Shrugs
text: When the first full day of the college football season kicks off Saturday afternoon, The Ainsworth bar in Manhattan’s Chelsea neighborhood will undoubtedly be ready. Reservations for more than 250 seats started being taken two weeks ago and were sold out by Thursday. Forty flat-screen televisions will be tuned to football.

headline: U.S. Moves Ahead on Plan to Sell Plum Island, Home of a Research Laboratory
text: MONTAUK, N.Y. — It has figured in conspiracy theories involving government experimentation with odd hybrid animals, à la Dr. Moreau. It was mentioned in “Silence of the Lambs” as the one place fit for the serial killer Hannibal Lecter. In real life, it was home to a high-security federal laboratory that did important research on contagious animal diseases.

headline: Vows: Adam and Kendall
text: As in their professional lives, Adam Ostrow and Kendall Aliment started their personal relationship online. After numerous tweets, Instagram photographs and G-chat sessions, they are getting married.

headline: Signs of a Shift Among Egyptian Protesters to Antigovernment, From Pro-Morsi
text: CAIRO — The continuing protests against the military takeover here showed signs on Friday of shifting into a movement against the authoritarian tactics of the new government rather than one demanding the return of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi.

headline: Gay Vows, With Ginsburg Officiating
text: WASHINGTON — Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg will preside over a same-sex wedding on Saturday in what is believed to be a first for a member of the Supreme Court.

headline: Chinese Chicken Processors Are Cleared to Ship to U.S.
text: The Department of Agriculture on Friday approved four Chinese poultry processors to begin shipping a limited amount of meat to the United States, a move that is likely to add to the debate over food imports.

headline: Relief, but Disappointment, for Plaintiffs in N.F.L. Case
text: Years ago, the symptoms started. Forrest Gregg would drag his left foot when he walked. He would thrash and kick and scream in the night, a nightmare running in his head. He would comb his hair with his right hand while his left hand trembled.

headline: A Shave in Prison Is Expected for Hasan
text: HOUSTON — Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, the military psychiatrist sentenced to death this week in the shooting rampage at Fort Hood in November 2009, will be forced to shave his beard on death row, Army officials announced on Friday.

headline: Cumulus Media Will Buy a Radio Syndicator
text: In a deal that could heighten the competition in radio against Clear Channel Communications, long the industry’s dominant player, Cumulus Media has agreed to buy Dial Global, a syndicator of sports, talk and music programming to thousands of stations, for $260 million.

headline: Puzzling Through (A Love Song)
text: In the beginning stages of writing a new batch of songs, before they are performed and recorded, my ideas are unfaithful. They can be coy or stubborn, refusing to go where I want them to — this is as it should be.

headline: With Huge War Chests, Activist Investors Tackle Big Companies
text: Microsoft executives faced an unusual challenge in April when a $12 billion hedge fund, ValueAct, announced that it had bought a nearly $2 billion stake in the company with the intention of shaking things up.

headline: Hewitt Upsets del Potro; Murray and Djokovic Rebound
text: Two former United States Open champions, both strong-willed competitors and veterans of the spotlight, carried on late into Friday night in one of the most dramatic contests of the early stages of the Open.

headline: Britain Cites Grave Risks in Leaked Data It Seized
text: LONDON — A standoff between the British government and The Guardian over national security and press freedom entered its latest round on Friday when the high court extended police powers to analyze encrypted material seized from the partner of one of the newspaper’s journalists this month.

headline: Why India’s Economy Is Stumbling
text: WASHINGTON — FOR the past three decades, the Indian economy has grown impressively, at an average annual rate of 6.4 percent. From 2002 to 2011, when the average rate was 7.7 percent, India seemed to be closing in on China — unstoppable, and engaged in a second “tryst with destiny,” to borrow Jawaharlal Nehru’s phrase. The economic potential of its vast population, expected to be the world’s largest by the middle of the next decade, appeared to be unleashed as India jettisoned the stifling central planning and economic controls bequeathed it by Mr. Nehru and the nation’s other socialist founders.

headline: Support Slipping, U.S. Defends Plan for Syria Attack
text: WASHINGTON — Facing faltering support in foreign capitals and Congress for a strike against Syria, the Obama administration on Friday made an aggressive and coordinated push to justify a military intervention on the grounds that American credibility was at stake.

headline: Jailed for Journalism
text: MONROVIA, Liberia — IT’S not uncommon in African countries like Zimbabwe and Ethiopia for newspapers to be shut, and their editors jailed. But the newspaper I edit doesn’t operate in a dictatorship. We are in Liberia, the West’s poster child for postwar democracy building. Our president, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, is a Nobel laureate who is celebrated by the likes of Bill Gates, Warren E. Buffett and Bono and has positioned herself as a champion of a free press.

headline: Politically, Our Next Big Thing
text: It is time to start thinking about running for the U.S. Senate. Allow me to explain.

headline: Stuyvesant Principal, Now Retired, Mishandled Cheating Case, Report Says
text: The principal of Stuyvesant High School, one of New York City’s top public schools, mishandled the investigation into a large cheating operation there last year from the moment he was tipped off to it until state education officials became aware of it more than a week later, a city report issued on Friday said.

headline: Lottery Numbers
For New York City Council
text: New York City’s 51-member City Council ideally gives each neighborhood a voice in the complicated politics of City Hall. Most candidates promise to get more resources for their districts, more affordable housing, schools and public amenities. And they vow to listen to citizen complaints. The differences among candidates are often a matter of temperament, experience and political skills. Here are our choices in six contested races in the Democratic primary on Sept. 10:

headline: Seamus Heaney, Poet of ‘the Silent Things’
text: Seamus Heaney was sipping bourbon during a Boston snowstorm 30 years ago, trying to explain his poetry as an escape from a terrible fear of silence that always haunted him. “What is the source of our first suffering?” he asked, quoting the French philosopher Gaston Bachelard. “It lies in the fact that we hesitated to speak.”

headline: Absent on Syria
text: UPDATE: On Saturday afternoon, President Obama said he would seek Congressional authorization before he launches a limited military strike on Syria.

headline: Shareholders, Supersized
text: The so-called activist investors flocking to Wall Street are major shareholders with hedge fund money, and they are using their clout to push around companies like Dell, Sony and Apple.

headline: A Display of Exuberance, Not Treason
text: John Isner lumbered off the practice court Friday afternoon, and as he worked his way through the usual gantlet of autograph hounds at the United States Open, many of the assembled chanted his name. It felt more patriotic than it would have a day earlier.

headline: Weekend Wheels Calendar
text: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: After Boy’s Suicide, Questions About Missed Signs
text: GREENWICH, Conn. — Boys picked on Bart Palosz almost from the moment his family moved to this affluent town seven years ago. They taunted him for his accent — he was born in Poland — pushed him into bushes or down stairs and smashed his new Droid cellphone, his sister said.

headline: Mickelson’s Hot Play Makes Him Co-Leader
text: NORTON, Mass. — It is a good thing for Adam Scott that the player of the year on the PGA Tour is not decided by an audience vote. His caddie, Steve Williams, got more shout-outs from the fans following his group Friday at the Deutsche Bank Championship. Such was Scott’s lot when he found himself in the marquee pairing with Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson, who have a firm hold on the golf viewing public, if not the award.

headline: Business Leaders’ Committee That Backed Cuomo Finishes Its Business and Shuts Down
text: The Committee to Save New York, a coalition of business leaders that spent millions of dollars supporting the agenda of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and that seemed, overnight, to become the biggest lobbying force in Albany, said on Friday that it was shutting down.

headline: G.O.P. Senators Fail to Head Off Primary Challenges by Tea Party Rivals
text: WASHINGTON — For the past two years, Republican senators facing re-election have very deliberately spent millions of dollars, hired multiple consultants and cast scores of conservative votes with one goal in mind: avoiding the embarrassing primary conflagrations that befell their party in 2010 and 2012 and cost Republicans a chance at taking back the Senate.

headline: An Attack on Syria? The Tension Rises
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Tribute to Seamus Heaney
text: To the Editor:

headline: Make Rights of Women a Top Diplomatic Priority
text: To the Editor:

headline: Navigating the Worlds of Science and Faith
War-Weariness
text: America may have lost its stomach for military intervention.

headline: In Turnaround, It’s France Backing Arms While Britain Sits on Syria Sidelines
text: LONDON — In the 2003 Iraq war, France refused to join the American-led coalition against Saddam Hussein, while Britain, as usual, fought fiercely alongside the Americans.

headline: Catch-Up Candidate, Again
text: William C. Thompson Jr., a Democratic candidate, again finds himself trailing in the polls, four years after he lost the mayoral election to Michael R. Bloomberg. His remedy: get out the vote.

headline: Staying at Michigan, With Renewed Focus
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Down State Street, at the end of campus, in the white house with the blue front door, lives perhaps the best left tackle in college football. There are stacked lawn chairs and a fire pit, remnants of a good night, in the yard. And from his front porch, Taylor Lewan can see Michigan Stadium in the distance.

headline: As Pension Chief, Thompson Gave Work to Donors
text: As a first-time candidate for New York City comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr. was feted at a downtown fund-raiser in 2001 by two luminaries of the black business world: the hip-hop mogul Russell Simmons and Mr. Simmons’s money manager, a veteran Wall Street financier who made his fortune promoting hybrid securities known as convertible bonds.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: Walkouts by fast-food workers, unemployment for baby boomers and a $160 million settlement of a racial bias lawsuit against Merrill Lynch.

headline: Trains vs. Kitties? The Candidates Answer
text: Kitten policy is rarely broached on the mayoral campaign trail.

headline: De Blasio Campaigns Less as Quinn Steps Up Her Pace
text: For most of the summer, Bill de Blasio maintained a robust public appearance schedule as he ran across New York City in an attempt to meet voters. On an average day, Mr. de Blasio could be found greeting commuters at subway stations in the morning, visiting with people at senior centers during lunch and holding news conferences later in the day to introduce initiatives or proposals he would follow as mayor.

headline: International Judge Is Removed From Case Over Apparent Bias
text: THE HAGUE — An international judge who criticized the president of the United Nations tribunal for the former Yugoslavia and the court’s recent decisions has been removed from his current case on the grounds that his remarks make him appear to be biased.

headline: Dangerous Thing To Sell
text: Administrivial Win Valuable Prizes Alert! Will Shortz’s 17th annual Westchester Crossword Puzzle Tournament will be held on Friday, September 27, 2013 at the Westchester Table Tennis Club in Pleasantville, New York, from 7:45 p.m to 9:45 p.m. This year, a special crossword solving/ping-pong biathlon component will be introduced, and in addition to the overall prizes, there will be prizes for Seniors (60 and over), Juniors (25 and under), Rookies (first-timers), Pleasantville residents, and winner of the Crossword/Ping-Pong biathlon. You can sign up here (the instructions for registering say 2012, but it should work for this year), and people are also welcome to sign up at the door. Click here for more information.

headline: Last Starter Standing, Mets’ Gee Beats the Nationals
text: WASHINGTON — To be a Mets starting pitcher this season has been to put oneself into harm’s way.

headline: Matthew Shear, Book Publisher, Dies at 57
text: Matthew Shear, the publisher of St. Martin’s Press, who helped writers like Janet Evanovich and Augusten Burroughs climb the best-seller lists, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 57.

headline: 7 Baggage Handlers at Kennedy Airport Accused of Pocketing Valuables
text: A lost pair of sunglasses might be chalked up to carelessness. A missing gold chain could have slipped off in a hotel room. Even an iPhone could have been misplaced in a rush to get through airport security. But eventually, it seemed clear that something was amiss in the baggage hold of El Al Airlines.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 31, 2013
text: “We know that after a decade of conflict, the American people are tired of war – believe me, I am too. But fatigue does not absolve us of our responsibility. Just longing for peace does not necessarily bring it about.”

headline: Labor Day
text: GOVERNMENT OFFICES  Closed.

headline: Corrections: August 31, 2013
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Showalter and Selig Said to Discuss Rodriguez
text: Baltimore Manager Buck Showalter’s comments about how the Yankees could enjoy a windfall from Alex Rodriguez’s pending suspension struck a nerve with Major League Baseball earlier this month. According to three people with knowledge of the matter, the comments resulted in a back-and-forth between M.L.B. and the Orioles, with Showalter eventually talking directly with Commissioner Bud Selig.

headline: Comparing Kerry and Obama on Syria
text: As President Obama and Secretary of State John Kerry made the case for United States military action against the Syrian government on Friday, each carried his arguments with a different tone.

headline: Experts Fear That U.S. Plan to Strike Syria Overlooks Risks
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Obama says he is seeking Congressional approval for a “limited, narrow” military strike against Syria — an aim that many Middle East experts fear overlooks the potential to worsen the violence in Syria and intensify a fight for regional influence between Iran and Saudi Arabia.

headline: Yanks Gain Ground, Even as Ace Takes Another Step Back
text: Friday’s game against the Baltimore Orioles represented the start of what is essentially the last stand for the Yankees’ playoff chances.

headline: After U.S. Exit, Afghan Army Tames a Valley
text: American soldiers who returned to the Pech Valley two years after leaving it were surprised to find the Afghan Army comfortably in control.

headline: U.S. Soldiers Find Surprise on Returning to Afghan Valley: Peace
text: NANGALAM, Afghanistan — The Americans arrived under cover of night, the static electricity from their helicopter blades casting halos of blue in the pitch black.

headline: U.S. Open Fans Affected by Coverage Blackout Have Options
text: There will be 21 hours of third- and fourth-round United States Open tennis coverage on CBS from Saturday through Monday.

headline: A Maker of Bikes Now Makes a Point of Riding Them
text: TAICHUNG, TAIWAN — THE bicycle maker Giant Manufacturing Company was established amid green rice paddies and earth-god temples, a short ride from the roar of the South China Sea. But for years its founder, King Liu, was never big on pedaling around to enjoy the scenery. The main reason he took one of his new products for a spin was to make sure everything worked.

headline: On a Mission to Make Taiwan a Cycling Capital
text: Bike sales have surged in Taiwan, bike lanes and paths have proliferated, and the island’s two biggest cities have launched bike-share programs. The trend didn’t happen by itself.

headline: Jets Trim Roster, Cutting Kicker and Veteran Tackle
text: The Jets have until Saturday at 6 p.m. to trim their roster to 53 players, but they made their first cuts on Friday. They shed kicker Dan Carpenter and the veteran tackle Antonio Garay, who confirmed his release in an e-mail. Carpenter could not supplant the incumbent Nick Folk, while the strong preseasons of Damon Harrison and Leger Douzable made Garay expendable.

headline: Back-to-Back Double Faults Spoil Hingis’s Return
text: Martina Hingis smashed nearly a dozen backhand volleys for winners, traded deft short shots and jumped high to crush overheads in her return to the United States Open on Friday. But none of that mattered in a loss with her doubles partner, Daniela Hantuchova of Slovakia, against the Open’s top-seeded doubles team, Sara Errani and Roberta Vinci of Italy.

headline: Man and Boy, 3, Shot in the Bronx
text: A man and a toddler were wounded Friday night in a shooting near Vidalia Park in the West Farms section of the Bronx, the authorities said.

headline: Ram Swats Away a Chance to Reach the Third Round
text: Rajeev Ram was two points away from his biggest Grand Slam victory, and it was time to make something happen.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (HBO) LES MISÉRABLES (2012) Hugh Jackman (above, who earned an Oscar nomination for his role in the film), Anne Hathaway (who won for best supporting actress), Russell Crowe, Amanda Seyfried and Eddie Redmayne sing their hearts out in this adaptation of the Victor Hugo novel about an inspector’s pursuit of a convict and the love between a young woman and a firebrand of the French Revolution. “The artful grunge layered onto the cast can be a distraction, as you imagine assistant dirt wranglers anxiously hovering off camera,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Ms. Hathaway, though, as Fantine, “the factory worker turned prostitute turned martyr, and singing the showstopping ‘I Dreamed a Dream,’ her gaunt face splotched red and brown,” she wrote, “holds you rapt with raw, trembling emotion.” But while the director, Tom Hooper, demonstrated in “The King’s Speech” that he can be very good with actors, his “inability to leave any lily ungilded — to direct a scene without tilting or hurtling or throwing the camera around — is bludgeoning and deadly,” she added. “By the grand finale, when tout le monde is waving the French tricolor in victory, you may instead be raising the white flag in exhausted defeat.”

headline: F.B.I. Sharpens Scrutiny of Syrians in U.S.
text: The F.B.I. has increased its surveillance of Syrians inside the United States in response to concerns that a military strike against the government of President Bashar al-Assad could lead to terrorist attacks here or against American allies and interests abroad, according to current and former senior United States officials.

headline: Obama Seeks Approval by Congress for Strike in Syria
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama abruptly changed course on Saturday and postponed a military strike against the Syrian government in retaliation for a chemical weapons attack so he could seek authorization first from a deeply skeptical Congress.

headline: What to Watch at the U.S. Open on Saturday
text: Although he has not gotten much attention from the news media — at least not outside Britain — Daniel Evans is one of the most remarkable underdog-made-good stories of the tournament so far.

headline: Drone Strike Is Said to Kill 4 Militants in Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A drone suspected of being American killed at least four militants early Saturday in an attack on a compound in the North Waziristan tribal district, near the border with Afghanistan, a Pakistani security official and local residents said.

headline: Pope Appoints Diplomat as Vatican Secretary of State
text: ROME — Pope Francis on Saturday announced the appointment of a longtime Vatican diplomat, Archbishop Pietro Parolin, as secretary of state, replacing Cardinal Tarcisio Bertone, a powerful, and divisive, figure in the Vatican hierarchy.

headline: When a Spouse Puts on Google Glass
text: Emily Nussbaum is the TV critic at The New Yorker.

headline: For That Museum-Worthy Wedding
text: Classic wedding gifts that stand the test of time.

headline: Stealth Wear, Coming to a Store Near You
text: Stealth wear, clothing and accessories created to protect their wearers from surveillance, has largely been an abstract concept. Most designs are created as prototypes, not items that can be purchased in a department or drug store.

headline: Delhi Gang Rape Accused Gets Three Years
text: NEW DELHI— A Juvenile Justice Board on Saturday convicted the youngest of the six defendants in the gang rape and murder of a 23-year-old physiotherapy student in New Delhi in December.

headline: Popcast: Miley Cyrus and the Summer of Smooth
text: This week: Jon Caramanica talks with host Ben Ratliff about Miley Cyrus’s raunch intervention on this week’s MTV Video Music Awards: the good and the bad of it, the gratuitous and the necessary, and the Tumblr-y roughening of the summer of smooth.

headline: Letters to the Editor

headline: Rare 2nd Operation Saved Yankee Pitcher’s Career
text: At the moment reliever Shawn Kelley drifted off into an anesthetic-induced slumber three years ago, he did not know what fate would befall him and his right elbow when he regained consciousness.

headline: Enjoy Labor Day!
text: We’ll be off for the national holiday on Monday — there are projects to finish and barbecues to attend — but Wheels will be back with more news and automotive culture on Tuesday. Best wishes and safe travels.

headline: Fatal Ammonia Leak Hits Shanghai
text: HONG KONG — At least 15 people were killed when ammonia leaked from a frozen storage and logistics business in Shanghai on Saturday, according to local news reports.

headline: What Happened to the Rule of Law?
text: SINCE the United Nations was created in 1945, its Charter has been more honored in the breach than the observance. So maybe it should not surprise us that President Obama seems poised to authorize American military action against Syria, in clear violation of international law.

headline: Bankers, Workers, Obama and Summers
text: Brad DeLong has an excellent piece distinguishing between two views of central banking. There’s the “banking camp,” which sees the central bank’s job as being to secure the stability of the financial system – full stop. OK, maybe also price stability. And then there’s the “macroeconomics camp,” which sees the central bank’s job as being to achieve full employment; banking stability and even price stability are basically means towards that end.

headline: Death of a Russian Orphan
text: Last October, Max Shatto was adopted from an orphanage in northwest Russia. Three months later, he was dead.

headline: World of Grief and Doubt After an Adoptee’s Death
text: GARDENDALE, Tex. — Kris loved to soar on the swings. Max liked to fly down the slide.

headline: Variety: A Heady Diagramless
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — This was a fun one. At first, I thought I had made a mistake when I started to mark the black squares, because I couldn’t believe that Joel Fagliano meant there to be so many of them.

headline: New Moon Probe Raises Questions About What to Do Next in Space
text: The last moon mission on NASA’s current schedule — a small, unmanned spacecraft that will study moon dust and the lunar atmosphere — is scheduled to launch on Friday from Wallops Island, Va., elating scientists who study the moon but highlighting political questions about what NASA should do next.

headline: If It Works, Tennis Players Stick With It, Whatever It Is
text: When Andre Agassi peered into his bag before his first match of the 1999 French Open, he was missing one crucial item: underwear. He turned down his coach Brad Gilbert’s offer to lend him a pair, then won the match.

headline: Francisco D’Souza of Cognizant, on Finding Company Heroes
text: This interview with  Francisco D’Souza, chief executive of the information technology company Cognizant, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: For Investors, No Need to Duck. Just Diversify.
text: IT’S a very risky environment for the markets right now. It’s also a very good time to be an investor.

headline: In ‘Treasury’s War,’ Missiles for a Financial Battlefield
text: THE 21st century has ushered in new kinds of warfare that don’t involve soldiers wielding weapons. One type, cyberwarfare, seems to have drawn the most commentary and analysis. A less publicized type of attack, financial warfare, is covered in “Treasury’s War,” (PublicAffairs) a useful new book by one of this strategy’s architects, Juan C. Zarate, a former assistant Treasury secretary.

headline: Trek Bicycle’s Chief, on Lessons of the Night Shift
text: WHEN I was growing up, I had a red Schwinn single-speed bike with a silver banana seat that I rode to a friend’s house and to sporting events in which I competed. At the time, Evel Knievel was popular, and I’d imitate him by placing garbage cans on their side in the driveway and jumping over them on my bike.

headline: Income Gap Grows Wider (and Faster)
text: INCOME inequality in the United States has been growing for decades, but the trend appears to have accelerated during the Obama administration. One measure of this is the relationship between median and average wages.

headline: Conquering Frustration on the Road Back to Work
text: I’VE been the director of a career counseling and consulting practice, BBCS Counseling Services, with my husband, Mitch Baskin, for 17 years. Our clients range from seasoned executives to recent college graduates. Across all age groups over the past few years, we’ve been counseling more of the long-term unemployed than ever before.

headline: Can Red Bulls Turn a Scuffle Into a Win?
text: The Red Bulls have not won a match since Aug. 3.

headline: Tripping on His Own Red Line?
text: WASHINGTON — IT started with just 20 words, intended to keep Barack Obama out of a war. The tens of thousands dying in Syria was a global tragedy, he told reporters a year ago, when the worst horrors were still months away, but as commander in chief he had to focus on American strategic interests and could not intervene in every humanitarian tragedy around the world.

headline: A Carbon Tax That America Could Live With
text: THIS summer, the Obama administration released the President’s Climate Action Plan. It is a grab bag of regulations and policy initiatives aimed at reducing the nation’s carbon emissions, which many scientists believe contribute to global warming.

headline: Rainbow Loom’s Success, From 2,000 Pounds of Rubber Bands
text: LAST weekend in Fair Harbor, N.Y., on Fire Island, a few dozen children gathered on the boardwalk for the local tradition of selling lemonade, baked goods and painted seashells to passers-by at sunset. Among the children was Julia Colen, a 12-year-old vacationer from New Jersey, who in addition to hawking cupcakes and drinks was presiding over a stand overflowing with brightly colored bracelets. Julia and a friend had made the jewelry out of tiny rubber bands, using a crafts kit called Rainbow Loom.

headline: Mary Cheney Criticizes Her Sister on Same-Sex Marriage
text: Mary Cheney, the younger sister of Liz Cheney, a Wyoming Senate candidate, sharply criticized her sister’s stance on same-sex marriage and urged her own Facebook friends to share the message.

headline: A Sidekick’s Little-Known Leading Role in Lacrosse
text: At Iroquois Lacrosse Arena in Hagersville, Ontario, the home of the Six Nations Chiefs, box lacrosse champions of eastern Canada, a photograph from 1931 hangs on the wall. Gazing ahead resolutely and gripping a lacrosse stick is a handsome dark-haired Mohawk man with a bandage over his right brow.

headline: From Example to Excess in Silicon Valley
text: I CAN remember a time when technology, and the people behind it, routinely filled me with a sense of wonderment — like the first time I logged into a chat room and, later, the first time I swiped open an iPhone.

headline: Strength of Body and Spirit Lifts Hewitt Against del Potro
text: Lleyton Hewitt battled Juan Martin del Potro under the lights on Arthur Ashe Stadium on Friday night in a match that was by turns puzzling, fascinating, maddening (for fans of both players) and ultimately inspiring. Hewitt’s resilience and love for the tough, challenging moments of a marquee match on the big stage ultimately wore down del Potro, who outplayed Hewitt for long stretches but was also prone to patches of lifeless, error-filled play.

headline: Aug. 31: Where the Candidates Are Today
text: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Ryan Tedder
text: Ryan Tedder is the frontman for the band OneRepublic and a sought-after songwriter and producer who has collaborated with pop artists including Adele, Beyoncé, One Direction, B.o.B, Maroon 5, Zedd and Kelly Clarkson.

headline: Liberal Education in Authoritarian Places
text: CLASSES are beginning at New York University’s new “portal” campus in Shanghai — the latest attempt by an American university to export its teaching and prestige abroad.

headline: A Data Broker Offers a Peek Behind the Curtain
text: IT can be disconcerting to learn what, not to mention how much, marketers know about us. Consider a consumer like Scott E. Howe.

text: Updated, 2:36 p.m. |

headline: Managing Risk on the High-Stakes Formula One Circuit
text: SPA, Belgium – The fundamentals of the epic racetrack here have not changed.

headline: Who Will Prosper in the New World
text: Self-driving vehicles threaten to send truck drivers to the unemployment office. Computer programs can now write journalistic accounts of sporting events and stock price movements. There are even computers that can grade essay exams with reasonable accuracy, which could revolutionize my own job, teaching. Increasingly, machines are providing not only the brawn but the brains, too, and that raises the question of where humans fit into this picture — who will prosper and who won’t in this new kind of machine economy?

headline: Olympic Wheel of Fortune
text: ONE of the year’s most heated competitions in all of sports will take place in a Hilton hotel conference room in Buenos Aires. But unless any of the participants get a case of the jitters, you won’t see a lot of sweat. You won’t see many athletes, either, or any courts, nets, uniforms or scoreboards.

headline: A Big Bet on an Olympic Jackpot
text: Viewed strictly from a business perspective, a spot in the Olympics is the most lucrative investment a sport can make. But the competition is stiff and usually lasts for years. And according to sports lobbying consultants, it isn’t cheap.

headline: Vive le Terroir
text: CASTELNAU DE MONTMIRAL, France — JÉRÔME GALAUP, a fourth-generation farmer here, and his wife, Nathalie, a teacher, share a dream: to combine their professions and create a teaching farm, where new generations can learn about the particularities of this hilly bit of French soil — this terroir.

headline: Explaining Twerking to Your Parents
text: Every child dreads this day: sooner or later, your parents will come to you, innocently wide-eyed, to ask you about twerking. How you handle this difficult conversation is extremely important and could have a significant impact on the way your parents think about twerking for years to come. You may prefer to put off the big “twerk talk,” but remember that it’s far better for you to be the one to explain than for them to learn on their own by searching YouTube.

headline: Political Choices
text: Leaders of the Federal Reserve and Supreme Court after World War II, and the presidents who chose them.

headline: A Year in the Life of a Watchdog
text: IT’S a Monday morning in August — last Monday, to be precise — and more than 500 e-mails have arrived in the public editor’s in-box. Some are spam. Some are requests for corrections or assignments, which can be sent to another desk. But a bunch, maybe two dozen, are legitimate topics for investigation or exposition. As my crack assistant, Meghan Gourley, does triage on the e-mail, I pick a subject for a blog post that seems timely, important and of broad interest — The Times’s use of anonymous sources, particularly on that day’s front page — and start reporting it.

headline: Silver Lining in China’s Smog as It Puts Focus on Emissions
text: HONG KONG — Jiang Kejun may be one of the few Beijing residents who see a ray of hope in the smog engulfing the city. A researcher in a state energy institute, he is an outspoken advocate of swiftly cutting China’s greenhouse gas output, and he says public anger about noxious air has jolted the government, which long dismissed pollution as the necessary price of prosperity.

headline: Catching Up With France on Day Care
text: PARIS — PRETTY much from the moment I got pregnant, neighbors and friends began urging me to apply for a spot in one of France’s state-run day care centers.

headline: For Some Afghans, Cost of Doing Business Includes U.S. Lawyers
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Dollar for dollar, Mahmood Karzai may well hold the title for getting the least value out of his pricey American lawyers. Mr. Karzai, a brother of President Hamid Karzai, paid one of them $100,000, and all he got was a single meeting and one follow up e-mail — and then the lawyer died.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Economics’ Ups and Downs
text: Readers discuss the nature of economics and science.

headline: The Chatter for September 1, 2013
text: “There’s room for improvement, and we’ve seen some missed opportunities.”

headline: Women, Bought and Sold in Nepal
text: NEPAL may be known for natural beauty and Mount Everest, but there is a dark side to this small, picturesque country. Women and girls are being bought, sold and smuggled across the Nepal-India border. Although reliable data on the scope of the issue is difficult to gather, Unicef reports that as many as 7,000 women and girls are trafficked out of Nepal to India every year, and around 200,000 are now working in Indian brothels.

headline: Women, Bought and Sold in Nepal
text: Katie Orlinsky travels to Nepal to document the growing problem of sex trafficking.

headline: Labor, Then and Now
text: On Thursday, the day after the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington, thousands of fast-food workers in 60 cities walked off their jobs, the latest in an escalating series of walkouts by low-wage workers demanding higher pay and the right to organize without retaliation.

headline: The Hazard of Free-Trade Tobacco
text: Give thanks to Malaysia for heading off, at least temporarily, an American effort to weaken the ability of countries to impose stiff rules on the sale of cigarettes and other tobacco products within their own borders. The Malaysian proposal to preserve that ability led to a stalemate at a Trans-Pacific Partnership trade meeting in Brunei last week and forced the deferral of the issue to future meetings.

headline: Doctors and Their Medicare Patients
text: Critics who want radical changes in Medicare, the public insurance program for the elderly and disabled, often allege that the program is heading for disaster because stingy payments from the government are causing a rising number of doctors to refuse to serve Medicare patients.

headline: New York’s Living Wilderness
text: For those who cherish New York State’s magnificent Adirondack Park, Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s summertime efforts to promote tourism there — like racing Mayor Michael Bloomberg in a white-water rafting competition on the Indian River — have offered diversions from local economic worries, uncertain weather and supersized mosquitoes. He has also been busy hawking the region’s wine, beer, food, hikes and kayaking.

headline: Plan B for Voting Rights
text: Voting-rights advocates generally don’t look to Justice Antonin Scalia for comfort. During oral arguments earlier this year in Shelby County v. Holder, the case in which the Supreme Court struck down a central part of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, Justice Scalia called the act a “perpetuation of racial entitlement.”

headline: A Reason to Believe in Clutch Hitting
text: PITTSBURGH — One strike from elimination in the 2011 World Series, the St. Louis Cardinals roared back and won. One strike from elimination in their division series last fall, the Cardinals did it again. So it should be no surprise that the Cardinals have been unusually clutch at the plate this season.

headline: Obama Speaks on Syria
text: President Obama spoke in the Rose Garden at the White House on Saturday, saying that he would seek Congressional approval for a strike on Syria.

text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,252 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following Americans recently:

headline: Season Record for Doubles Is Secure for Another Year
text: On July 6, in a loss to the Yankees, Manny Machado, the Baltimore Orioles’ phenom, hit a ball to left field in the third inning for his 39th double of the season. At the time, it seemed that Machado, 21, could be a serious challenger to Earl Webb, who has held the record for doubles in a season, with 67, since 1931. There was no way anyone could have known that would be the only double Machado would hit that month.

headline: Riske Upsets No. 7 Kvitova in Day’s Lone Bright Spot for U.S. Players
text: In her hotel room in Manhattan, Alison Riske has tucked away a small piece of tattered fabric, a remnant from a blanket that was given to her at the moment of her birth.

headline: My Filthy Secret
text: For years, it was my filthy secret, my private shame. I was allegedly a novelist; a crime writer, no less — a gritty, hard-boiled practitioner in the dark art of killing on the page. I was supposed to be a spinner of the tallest of tales. My books began with the disclaimer, “This is a work of fiction…”

headline: Squirrel Power!
text: SOME say the world will end in fire. Some say ice. Some say coordinated kamikaze attacks on the power grid by squirrels.

headline: President Pulls Lawmakers Into Box He Made
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s aides were stunned at what their boss had to say when he summoned them to the Oval Office on Friday at 7 p.m., on the eve of what they believed could be a weekend when American missiles streaked again across the Middle East.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 1
text: With President Obama’s announcement Saturday that he will seek Congressional approval to strike Syria, Secretary of State John Kerry will appear on the five major Sunday shows — on ABC, CBS, CNN, Fox and NBC — to talk about the administration’s approach to the crisis.

headline: Beauty and the Beasts
text: DURING an August vacation with my family, I enjoyed lodgings so spectacular that not even Bill Gates or Warren Buffett could ever buy or rent them.

headline: Lawmakers Respond on Twitter to Obama’s Statement on a Syria Vote
text: Both chambers of Congress are on recess, and many of their members are far from Washington. But the distance did not stop some of them from responding to President Obama’s statement on Saturday afternoon that he would seek Congressional authorization before launching a military strike in response to Syria’s use of chemical weapons. Many representatives and senators took to Twitter with their reactions.

headline: For the A.T.P., There Is No Tale of the Tape, and Thereby Hangs a Tale
text: It has been one of the more lucrative summers of John Isner’s career. Over the course of five tournaments in July and August, he gained 1,250 ranking points, $551,975 in prize money, and an inch.

text: Following is the text of President Obama’s address on Saturday, as provided by the White House, saying he would seek Congressional authorization for a strike on Syria:

headline: Loving Softball Is Easier Than Living It
text: ROSEMONT, Ill. — At 26, Amber Patton is in the prime of her softball career, a top player on a leading professional team that just played for its league championship. But she broke down in tears recently as she explained that she is considering walking away from the game, not because she has lost her love for it or her ability to play it at the highest level.

headline: The Jets’ Future Seems Haunted by Their Checkered Past
text: This is how the Jets wanted Geno Smith to win their quarterback competition: by shining all summer long, by dominating during the preseason, by proving beyond a reasonable doubt that he was the team’s best option for Week 1. They wanted him to earn it.

headline: The Arithmetic of Fantasy Fiscal Policy
text: Sometimes — usually, though not always, in a belligerent tone — people ask me, well, how big do you think the stimulus should have been? How much debt should we have run up? Regardless of the tone, that is actually a question worth answering. With the benefit of hindsight, we do know roughly how depressed the economy has been; we have reasonably good estimates of the effects of government spending; so we can put together an estimate of what would have happened if we had, in fact, pursued a policy of government spending sufficient to keep output at potential.

headline: Football, Australian Style, Meets Basketball
text: After four seasons as a solid contributor for North Dakota’s basketball team, Patrick Mitchell graduated last year with one professional option: a contract with a low-level club in Portugal.

headline: One Fan’s Life Lessons, From Heroes and Humans
text: The prime age for sports fanaticism is about 10. Any younger, and you don’t really know what’s going on. Any older, and you’ve discovered the opposite sex, which may reshuffle your priorities for the next several decades.

headline: How a Bookworm Broke a Hiking Record
text: Readers are welcome to comment here either on Nicholas Kristof’s column, “Beauty and The Beasts,” or on this blog post, which offers a more detailed look at Heather Anderson’s journey.

headline: Persons of Note
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — “Money doesn’t grow on trees,” my father always told me, but today it’s literally bursting out of our crossword puzzle in denominations of all kinds, if you know where to find it. You have John Farmer and Will Shortz to thank for that, and if you are doing this puzzle in the paper version of The New York Times, then my father was clearly wrong. I can’t wait to tell him.

headline: Tense Moment in the 9th, but Nova Shuts Out the Orioles
text: The ball hit by Baltimore Orioles first baseman Chris Davis in the ninth inning on Saturday against Ivan Nova went deep toward right field and hung high in the air for what might have seemed like minutes for the Yankees’ dugout. One swing with a man on base in a two-run game could quickly ruin what had been a standout performance by the Yankees’ ace of the moment.

headline: Iranian Referee Gets a Long-Awaited Call: He’s In
text: Adel Borghei spent Saturday at the United States Open, inside Louis Armstrong Stadium, clad in the navy blue uniform of a referee. He wore sunglasses and made line calls and blended into the background, even if this was far from a normal day at work.

headline: Budget Documents Detail Extent of U.S. Cyberoperations
text: WASHINGTON — Newly disclosed budget documents for America’s intelligence agencies show how aggressively the United States is now conducting offensive cyberoperations against other nations, even as the Obama administration protests attacks on American computer networks by China, Iran and Russia.

headline: Spotlight on Wendy Davis, the Democrats’ Big Hope
text: FORT WORTH — Wendy Davis burst into the national political consciousness this summer as a feminist folk hero. She was a titan in pink tennis shoes, a single mother who became a lawyer, stood up to the Republican boys’ club and, against all odds, temporarily halted enactment of a restrictive abortion bill.

headline: Conversations With Andy Murray: Dreaming Up Tennis Venues
text: Andy Murray recently toured Madison Square Garden, the site of his coming exhibition match in March against Novak Djokovic, an opponent whom he has faced in three of the last four Grand Slam finals. Although the arena is being renovated, Murray, a boxing fan, said he was excited to see how the court would be laid out, and to visit an arena that had hosted many famous boxing matches.

headline: Long at Helm, U.T. Collector Leaves Legacy With His Exit
text: In late July, the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin acquired the archives of McSweeney’s, the often cheeky journal and publisher founded in 1998 by the writer and editor Dave Eggers.

headline: Fighting Pest, Farmers Find Strange Ally: A Drought
text: Texas’ drought has left crops parched across the state, but the lack of water could have unintended benefits for South Texas farmers in one of the state’s longest-running agricultural battles.

headline: On YouTube, Comedy Troupe Tickles Brazil and Ruffles Feathers
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — As Brazil’s largest cities were being rocked by huge antigovernment protests, the president, visibly exasperated, summoned top legislators to an emergency meeting and put forward a last-gasp concession to ease the fury on the streets.

headline: Before Attempting to Top Opponents, U.S. Open Players Must Beat Traffic
text: Tim Smyczek, an American tennis player ranked 109th, boarded an official United States Open car in Midtown Manhattan around 8 a.m. on Wednesday, several hours before he was scheduled to play at the Open in Flushing Meadows, Queens.
